headline: The Goals of AARP
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Shortage of Doctors
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama’s Nuance
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hudson River Park
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mob Figure May Unearth Corruption of Lawmen
text: During the 16 years James (Whitey) Bulger spent on the lam, several of his former partners in crime testified that he had made payoffs to two dozen Boston police officers and half a dozen F.B.I. agents over his long criminal career — giving them thousands of dollars and rings, a Meerschaum pipe and Lalique glass.

headline: Coalition of Factions From the Streets Fuels a New Opposition in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — An opposition drawing its strength from Syria’s restive streets has begun to emerge as a pivotal force in the country’s once-dormant politics, organizing across disparate regions through the Internet, reaching out to fearful religious minorities and earning the respect of more recognized, but long divided dissidents.

headline: Two Rulings Find Cuts in Public Pensions Permissible
text: Judges in Colorado and Minnesota have dismissed court challenges by retired public workers whose pensions had been cut — developments that may embolden other states and cities to use pension reductions as a tool to help balance their budgets.

headline: The Impossible Public Pensions Choices
text: Last summer, I wrote about a brewing court battle in Colorado. At issue was the question of whether the state could reduce the annual cost-of-living adjustments for the pensions of state workers who were already retired.

headline: France: Moscovici Backs Hollande for Socialists
text: The Socialist legislator Pierre Moscovici, a close ally of Dominique Strauss-Kahn, said Thursday that he would support François Hollande for president. Mr. Moscovici, 53, had been hesitating about whether to support the Socialist Party leader Martine Aubry or Mr. Hollande, a former party leader, or to run himself. Mr. Hollande is the current front-runner in opinion polls for the Socialist primaries scheduled for October. Another ally of Mr. Strauss-Kahn, Jean-Christophe Cambadélis, has decided to support Ms. Aubry.

headline: Kansas Gives License to One Abortion Clinic
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Ending speculation that new regulations could make it the only state without an abortion provider, Kansas announced Thursday that it had issued a license that would allow one of three abortion clinics to continue operating.

headline: The Price of Liberty: Weeds
text: Norfolk, England

headline: Brown Graduate Does Not Give Up on His Tennis Dream
text: WIMBLEDON, England — In 2008, James Cerretani’s father, Chip, strongly suggested it was time for him to retire from tennis and put his Brown University degree to use. Three years later, Cerretani’s sister Chrissy, a former college player at Clemson, is on the verge of quitting her job in Boston to travel with him on tour, he said — and with their father’s blessing.

headline: N.F.L. Deal Is Said to Be Weeks Away as Talks Restart
text: N.F.L. owners and players continued to negotiate late Thursday evening, but progress slowed as time dwindled for striking a labor deal that would avoid the disruption of the preseason.

headline: Western Funds Are Said to Have Managed Libyan Money Poorly
text: Prominent American and European investment funds managed hundreds of millions of dollars in Qaddafi regime assets poorly, charging tens of millions of dollars in fees and producing low returns, according to a document obtained by the advocacy group Global Witness. The banks appeared to have taken advantage of a Libyan investment fund that was poorly managed and "a mess," according to a western official who spoke on condition of anonymity.

headline: China: Rules Favoring Local Companies for State Contracts Will Be Eased
text: The Ministry of Finance will repeal three rules on Friday that favor Chinese companies in competitions for government technology purchases, according to a statement posted this week on the ministry’s Web site. China has long supported a policy of “indigenous innovation,” which grants advantages to Chinese companies over foreign rivals, especially in technology industries, and tries to enforce technology transfer from foreign companies in business deals. Foreign companies and governments have complained that such rules violate free-trade agreements. In January, when President Hu Jintao of China visited the White House, Chinese officials promised to drop some of those rules.

headline: Practicing Medicine Can Be Grimm Work
text: Birmingham, Ala.

headline: Wrong Name, Wrong Date, Yet Let on a Jet
text: When the F.B.I. caught up to Olajide Oluwaseun Noibi at Los Angeles International Airport on Wednesday, he was trying to talk a Delta Air Lines agent into letting him get on a flight to Atlanta. Mr. Noibi, 24, faced some resistance because the boarding pass in his hand was issued in another person’s name and was for a flight that had departed a day earlier, according to court documents.

headline: Citing Homeless Law, Hackers Turn Sights on Orlando
text: MIAMI — The hacker group Anonymous has declared a cyberwar against the City of Orlando, disabling Web sites for the city’s leading redevelopment organization, the local Fraternal Order of Police and the mayor’s re-election campaign.

headline: For Jeter, Trenton Is the Next Stop
text: Derek Jeter, who has been on the disabled list since June 14 with a strained right calf, will probably play the first of two rehabilitation games Saturday for the Yankees’ Class AA farm team in Trenton. Manager Joe Girardi gave the news after his team’s 5-0 victory Thursday against the Milwaukee Brewers.

headline: To the Limit
text: In about a month, if nothing is done, the federal government will hit its legal debt limit. There will be dire consequences if this limit isn’t raised. At best, we’ll suffer an economic slowdown; at worst we’ll plunge back into the depths of the 2008-9 financial crisis.

headline: N.H.L. Free Agents: Where in the World Is Jaromir Jagr?
text: Confusion mounted across the N.H.L. on the eve of Friday’s free-agency frenzy. Among the complicating factors were turtles trundling across an airport runway and the legalization of gay marriage.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Prosecution Said to Be Near Collapse
text: The sexual assault case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn is on the verge of collapse as investigators have uncovered major holes in the credibility of the housekeeper who charged that he attacked her in his Manhattan hotel suite in May, according to two well-placed law enforcement officials.

headline: Cuomo Administration Closing 7 Prisons, 2 in New York City
text: The Cuomo administration, following through on one of the most contentious cutbacks included in the state budget, said Thursday that it would close seven of New York’s dozens of prisons, including a facility in the Bronx and one on Staten Island.

headline: Scott and Haas Share AT&T Lead
text: Adam Scott made a couple of long birdie putts and hit a 5-iron within 2 feet for a birdie on the 14th hole on his way to a four-under-par 66 on Thursday to share the lead with Hunter Haas in the AT&T National in Newtown Square, Pa.

headline: Smells Like School Spirit
text: Aspen, Colo.

headline: Differing Takes on Accuser’s Credibility
text: Prosecutors have strongly supported the woman who said she was attacked by Dominique Strauss-Kahn, as has a lawyer representing the woman, but his defense team has questioned her credibility since the accusations were made on May 14.

headline: For Some With Autism, Jobs to Match Their Talents
text: Steen B. Iversen tests mobile phones for the Danish telecommunications firm TDC. Before landing his job two and a half years ago, Iversen, 50, who has been diagnosed with Asperger’s Syndrome, spent more than 12 years looking for work. “It’s always been somewhat traumatizing,” he said. “I have had jobs, but I always got fired. People would laugh about me behind my back and laugh at me to my face. Those problems have more or less been a problem for me from childhood.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Local Laws Fighting Fat Under Siege
text: Several state legislatures are passing laws that prohibit municipalities and other local governments from adopting regulations aimed at curbing rising obesity and improving public health, such as requiring restaurants to provide nutritional information on menus or to eliminate trans fats from the foods they serve.

headline: Connecticut Steps Closer to Widespread Layoffs
text: HARTFORD — Connecticut legislators early Friday morning gave Gov. Dannel P. Malloy dramatically expanded authority to make radical cuts to programs and employment after state employee unions rejected a labor deal meant to balance the state’s $40.1 billion two-year budget.

headline: Two Women Struck by Car, One Fatally, in Manhattan
text: One woman was killed and another seriously injured in Manhattan on Thursday when they were struck by a car that was backing up as they were crossing the street, the police said.

headline: Boeing Labor Dispute Is Making New Factory a Political Football
text: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — Boeing’s gigantic new $750 million airplane factory here is the pride of South Carolina, the biggest single investment ever made in a state that is far more associated with old-line textile mills than state-of-the-art manufacturing. In just a few weeks, 1,000 workers will begin assembling the first of what they hope will be hundreds of 787 Dreamliners.

headline: Borders Picks Najafi Companies as Lead Bidder
text: The Borders Group said on Thursday evening that it had picked the Najafi Companies, a private equity firm that owns the Book-of-the-Month Club, as the lead bidder in a forthcoming court-supervised auction for the bankrupt bookseller.

headline: Ethics, Politics and the Law
text: The ethical judgments of the Supreme Court justices became an important issue in the just completed term. The court cannot maintain its legitimacy as guardian of the rule of law when justices behave like politicians. Yet, in several instances, justices acted in ways that weakened the court’s reputation for being independent and impartial.

headline: How the British Nearly Supported the Confederacy
text: Was it a civil war twice over? Not only did the “war between the states” divide the American people, it sundered the larger English-speaking community stretching across the Atlantic. The conflict was followed with consuming interest by the British, it affected them directly, many of them fought in it — and it split them into two camps, just as it did the Americans.

headline: Exploring Love’s True Nature
text: Did you watch “When Harry Met Sally” and wish it had dispensed with Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan? Well, of course you did. What I mean is, did you wish that the interstitial “interviews” with longtime couples could be expanded into their own feature while retaining the film’s calculated sentimentality? If so, Jill Andresevic’s “Love Etc.” is the movie you’ve been waiting for.

headline: Friday: Priest at Shiloh
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — How long, on average, does it take you to suss out that there is something fishy going on in a crossword? Let’s say we’re talking about rebuses, which is actually quite convenient because today’s grid happens to have a rebus element in it. It’s not quite like other rebuses, though, and it’s kind of clever. If you are still wondering how to enter multiple letters in a grid, please read Martin Herbach’s wonderful instructional write-up here.

headline: Hold Onto Your Morals: Life Is Tough
text: Righteousness probably doesn’t rank too high on any list of the qualities that people find seductive. Nobody tunes in to a televangelist in search of an aphrodisiac, I’d be willing to bet.

headline: The Google Inquiry Evokes Microsoft Memories
text: The ongoing antitrust investigations into Google invite comparisons to the case against Microsoft. But however easy the links are to make, many are also facile. The most significant resemblance between the two situations may be their outcomes.

headline: New Jersey Governor Vetoes Spending
text: TRENTON — Gov. Chris Christie on Thursday vetoed more than $1.3 billion in spending, much of it for schools, and struck down a sharp tax increase on high-income people in a sweeping rejection of attempts by Democrats in the Legislature to assert some control over the state budget.

headline: Thousands of Prison Terms in Crack Cases Could Be Eased
text: Thousands of prisoners convicted of crimes related to crack cocaine could get shorter sentences under a revised policy enacted Thursday by the federal agency that helps to set punishment policy.

headline: The Libya Campaign
text: Four months into the NATO air campaign, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi is still in power, protected by loyalists and mercenaries. Americans are weary of war, and patience in Europe is also wearing thin. But NATO must not give up.

headline: Beck Uses Last Show on Fox to Allude to His New Venture
text: Glenn Beck spent his final day at the Fox News Channel thanking his viewers and colleagues and promoting his new Internet channel, GBTV, to the best of his contractual ability.

headline: Indian Cinema With an Indie Sensibility
text: Starting with the pride of place given the digestive problem of the title, “Delhi Belly” thumbs its nose at propriety. Delhi belly, the traveler’s curse, afflicts a homegrown son (Kunaal Roy Kapur) in this caper comedy after he eats some particularly nasty street food. (The film lovingly shows just how unhygienic it is.) His stool sample, no less, is the trigger that sets the plot in motion, when it is accidentally switched with a similar-size package of contraband. Not what the gangster ordered ...

headline: Lies and Truth About Upper Big Branch
text: Profits trumped all, including the safety and lives of 29 miners. That is the clear conclusion of a yearlong federal investigation into the Upper Big Branch disaster. Industry must finally learn its lesson. Congress and federal regulators must ensure that it does.

headline: Another Area Girds for Revolt as Sudan Approaches a Split
text: LEWERE, Sudan — Children with shrapnel wounds lie on metal hospital cots. Thousands of others have been huddling in caves and stony riverbeds, fleeing the fighter jets and bombers prowling the skies. Villages are empty, fields unplowed. At the faintest buzz of a plane, people scatter into the bush, in a panic.

headline: Fund-Raising Begins Slowly for G.O.P. Candidates
text: Fund-raising by the Republican presidential candidates appears to be off to a slow start this year, hindered by the struggling economy, the absence of a clear and compelling front-runner, and the desire of many of the party’s biggest donors to wait and see how the race develops.

headline: Speaker Quinn on Marriage
text: Christine Quinn, the speaker of the New York City Council, is one of the state’s most powerful politicians and the nation’s most prominent openly gay officials. On Charlie Rose’s program earlier this week, she spoke of the legalization of same-sex marriage in personal terms. (Ms. Quinn plans to marry Kim Catullo in New York in 2012.)

headline: Student’s Shocking Revelation to a Professor
text: Jeffrey T. Kern had been impressed with the quiet young woman from Brooklyn, a businesslike student who always sat in the back of his class on courtroom communication at John Jay College of Criminal Justice.

headline: Lead Bidder Is Chosen for Borders
text: The Borders Group said on Thursday that it had picked the Najafi Companies, a private equity firm that owns the Book-of-the-Month Club, as the lead bidder in a forthcoming court-supervised auction for the bankrupt bookseller.

headline: Independence Day Schedules
text: NEW YORK

headline: In Fight Against Trash Station, Upper East Side Cites Injustice
text: Lorraine Johnson says she remembers the garbage trucks that lined up near her housing project on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, to unload trash at a marine sanitation station on the East River.

headline: House Panel Members Joust Over Border Gun Program
text: WASHINGTON — Republicans and Democrats on the House oversight committee this week intensified their efforts to shape the narrative surrounding Operation Fast and Furious, the border-security strategy that allowed guns to be shipped illegally into Mexico in an effort to track them to drug cartels.

headline: Some Players Waiting for Tennis Shot Clock
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Slow play — intentionally, strategically, maddeningly slow play — is not a new concern at tennis’s major events. In 1979, during a riotous match at the United States Open, Ilie Nastase protested the excessive time that the argumentative John McEnroe was taking before beginning the next point by stretching out on the baseline and pretending to fall asleep.

headline: Prosecutor Describes L.I. Video of 4 Killings
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — After all the shooting was done, and the bodies of four victims were splayed across the floor of Haven Drugs, the door to the pharmacy opened once more.

headline: Canadians Embrace Royal Couple in First Official Foreign Visit
text: OTTAWA — When the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, or William and Kate to the crowd here, arrived in Canada on Thursday for their first official foreign visit as a married couple, comparisons to Princess Diana’s inaugural visit here in 1983 were probably inevitable.

headline: San Francisco Is Awash With Mayoral Candidates
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Depending on how you slice it, there are anywhere from 9 to 37 people running to become mayor of San Francisco, including the city attorney, a state senator and a man whose legislative goals include the establishment of a new professional football team.

headline: Afghanistan: Family Killed by Roadside Bomb
text: A family of five and their driver were killed by a bomb buried in the road in the district of Marja in southern Helmand Province on Thursday, Afghan officials said. The two parents and their children, ages 3 to 6, were traveling to an engagement party in Lashkar Gah, the provincial capital, the governor’s spokesman said. Marja, a former Taliban stronghold, was subdued by the United States Marines early in 2010. Abdul Mutalib, the district governor of Marja, said a military operation was underway in the area where the bomb went off.

headline: Sleeping in a Schoolhouse, Alongside Lockers and the Gym
text: There is a silver lining in the hard reality of this Kentucky coal county’s shrinking population: Empty schoolhouses make good inns.

headline: Corrections
text: FOREIGN

headline: Romney Blasts Obama as ‘a Failure’ on the Economy
text: ALLENTOWN, Pa. — Standing before the locked gate of a steel plant that President Obama once visited while promoting his economic stimulus plan, Mitt Romney pointed to weeds and boarded-up windows and called the president’s handling of the economy a failure.

headline: Chávez Says a Cancerous Tumor Was Removed
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Hugo Chávez stunned this nation on Thursday night in an unusually concise 15-minute address on state television in which he acknowledged that he has been battling cancer. Mr. Chávez made the revelation from Cuba, where he has been in seclusion at a medical facility for the last three weeks.

headline: Head of Manhattan’s Brearley School Resigns
text: The head of the Brearley School in Manhattan, one of the nation’s most highly regarded private schools for girls, has abruptly resigned, according to letters that were sent to families and alumni from the school’s board of trustees.

headline: White House Sees Date for Budget Deal or Bust
text: WASHINGTON — The White House believes it must strike a budget deal with Congress by July 22 to avoid a risk of defaulting on the national debt, Democratic officials briefed on the negotiations said Thursday, as Senate leaders canceled a recess next week to try to break the deadlock with Republicans.

headline: Massachusetts: Dead Woman Unnoticed
text: State officials are investigating how a woman apparently died at a Fall River pool on Sunday and went unnoticed until Tuesday night. The body of Marie Joseph, 36, of Fall River, was discovered Tuesday around 10 p.m. in the Veterans Memorial Pool in Fall River. The authorities said Ms. Joseph went down a slide Sunday immediately after a 9-year-old boy and collided with him. The mayor of Fall River, William Flanagan, said city inspectors visited the pool, which was open to the public and had several lifeguards on duty, Monday and Tuesday, only to report that the water was “cloudy.” Pool staff was suspended and state officials closed 24 pools while reviewing safety procedures and training.

headline: Contador Chases a Title He Might Lose in Court
text: The Tour de France begins Saturday on France’s western coastline, and the best overall riders there will share the same goal: to win cycling’s most prestigious race and beat Alberto Contador, the Spanish rider who has dominated the event for the past two years.

headline: Omega Is Expanding Golf Profile in U.S.
text: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa. — Ever since Arnold Palmer clicked the clasp on his first Rolex wristwatch in 1967, the timepiece has been the go-to brand in well-healed golf circles. Now it faces competition from an old rival that has become the new face of one of the four major championships and the Ryder Cup matches.

headline: C.W. Whalen Jr., 90, Dies; Led Vietnam War Dissent
text: Charles W. Whalen Jr., a six-term congressman from Ohio who led Republican opposition to the Vietnam War and espoused a variety of liberal causes, died on Monday in Washington. He was 90.

headline: The Line Forms Behind Contador
text: Alberto Contador

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,633 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Late Climbs, and Late Drama
text: Stage 1

headline: Rise in High-End Sales Buoys Manhattan Housing Market
text: After a slight drop in prices at the beginning of the year, the Manhattan real estate market has stabilized in the last three months, with prices rising slightly and sales volume increasing with an expected spring surge in home buying.

headline: Word of the Day | touchstone
text: touchstone •\ˈtəch-ˌston\• noun

headline: NYT: Front Page for 07/01/2011
text: NYT: Front Page for 07/01/2011

headline: Battle For Libya | June 30, 2011
text: A family fleeing Tripoli arrived at the Libyan western mountains on Thursday and Libyans walked past destroyed buildings in Misurata.

headline: Perry and Hispanics Coexist Uneasily in Politics
text: It was an awkward moment for the swashbuckling, gun-toting governor of Texas. Fresh off the heels of several raucous welcomes before adoring groups of conservatives across the country, Gov. Rick Perry found himself staring into a crowd more intent on dessert than the speech he was delivering, and in his home state no less.

headline: As Drought Intensifies, Towns and Schools Worry About Maintaining Athletic Fields
text: LLANO — The two practice fields used by high school football teams here still look green, but perhaps not for long. This Central Texas town banned outdoor irrigation using city water last week, so workers have laid hundreds of feet of pipe from the fields to an old well. No one is sure how much water the well may hold.

headline: Assessing Senate Race, Reduced Field and All
text: Candidates are dropping out of the United States Senate race in Texas faster than teenagers drop out of Texas high schools. It’s been a month of un-declaration in the Republican race to replace Kay Bailey Hutchison.

headline: The Cubs’ Woes Increase, and Wrigleyville Feels the Pain
text: Lars Geary could have been working on his novel or at least reading one, as he manned the desk at Tickets 321.com, a one-room brokerage at 950 West Addison Street, a half-block from the Billy Williams statue that sits outside the right-field entrance to Wrigley Field.

headline: Mural Exhibit Depicts Costs to Civilians in Afghanistan
text: John Pitman Weber remembers the 1960s and ’70s in Chicago, when scores of artists would join mammoth marches protesting the Vietnam War and antiwar murals were a common sight on city streets.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Before His Fall, He Was Our ‘Breath of Fresh Air’
text: As Rod Blagojevich stands disgraced, many of us should be ashamed.

headline: Test Results Raise Questions About Extending Days
text: Mayor Rahm Emanuel and new leaders of Chicago Public Schools have been pushing for a longer school day and school year to help raise student performance. But last week’s state test results show that charter schools — which typically have more instructional time — actually have a lower percentage of students exceeding state standards.

headline: Forced Move May Mean the End of Teatro ZinZanni
text: Dancing waiters, an opera singer announcing dinner courses melodically, and Joan Baez, improbably, in blond finger waves, a beaded dress and feather headdress, speaking in British and French accents — this is all part of the circus world conjured up by Teatro ZinZanni in San Francisco, one of the Bay Area’s few dinner theaters.

headline: Seeking to Unplug the Voice of Doomsday
text: The world did not end on May 21 as Harold Camping, an Oakland evangelist, predicted. But some would still like to see Armageddon — for Mr. Camping’s radio empire.

headline: In Germany, Women’s Team Is Winning Fans
text: BERLIN — The marquee at Lido, an old movie theater turned music venue, on Thursday night read: “Germany – Nigeria.” By kickoff, the bouncers were turning people away at the door. In Germany right now, the women’s soccer players are the headliners.

headline: Online Activism Finds a Home in San Francisco
text: In late May, a Saudi blogger named Eman al-Nafjan contacted Change.org — a San Francisco group that hosts online petitions to encourage social change — seeking help for a group of Saudi women who were protesting their government’s ban on women driving.

headline: Tour Draws Immigrants to Honor Their Saint
text: Last Friday night, the faithful and the curious lined up for a special mass at St. Anthony Parish in Oakland. On a pedestal up front stood the object of their affection: a 4-foot-5 statue of a blue-eyed Mexican priest.

headline: News Quiz | July 1, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

text: 8:16 p.m. | Updated

headline: Test Yourself | History, July 1, 2011
text: Test your knowledge of history with today’s question about American history.

headline: Turmoil Over Austerity in Greece
text: WHO supported and WHO opposed new austerity legislation in Greece?

headline: News of Turnaround in Dominique Strauss-Kahn Case Stuns France
text: PARIS — The release of Dominique Strauss-Kahn on Friday from house arrest in New York represented a startling turnaround, sharpening the focus of political debate here on a central and potent issue: with the weakening of sexual assault charges against him, will he be able to resume a potentially stellar career that could lead to the presidency of his country?

headline: Apple and Microsoft Beat Google for Nortel Patents
text: 8:31 p.m. | Updated

headline: One Mouth Too Many
text: One day each month in Eastleigh, a run-down suburb of Nairobi with dirt roads and rivering sewers, a young Kenyan woman named Dorothy Gakii starts calling out numbers. “Numbaa one!” she shouts, using slow and deliberate English. “Numbaa two!” Gathered before her on long wooden benches in a church meeting hall are several dozen refugees holding scraps of paper that mark their place in line. They are waiting for food — for the sacks of dried beans and rice and maize flour piled against one wall. For the seriously malnourished, there is a nutritional porridge mix labeled, “Pure Wimbi.”

headline: What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
text: Our Summer Reading Contest begins!

headline: The Enthusiast
text: The Enthusiast: Gaby Dunn, New York-based journalist and proprietor of the Web project 100 Interviews (100interviews.com).

headline: ‘Tough, Cold, Terse, Taciturn and Prone to Not Saying Goodbye When They Hang Up the Phone’
text: Every time I hear someone use the term “strong female character,” I want to punch them. The problem is, I hit like a girl. Before I go further, here’s an anecdote that might help set the tone for what I’m about to try to say, which I worry has the potential to come across all wrong unless I manage to dispel certain widely shared assumptions without unduly setting anyone off.

headline: The Memory Problem
text: For a 102-year-old man in fine health, a missing soap dish could become an existential conundrum.

headline: Letters: The 6.19.11 Issue
text: From the E-Mail In-box of Bill Keller:

headline: New London Photo Festival Puts Focus on the Street
text: Street photography is nothing new, but it can be a particularly accessible genre. With that in mind, Brett Jefferson Stott, the founder and director of Shoot Experience, a London-based photography group, is starting up the first annual London Street Photography Festival, running today through July 31.

headline: What’s a Crisis and What Isn’t
text: Laura D’Andrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and served as chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Clinton.

headline: Top 10 Tight Ends in N.F.L.
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -– but not strictly -– by film study of all 32 teams from the 2010 season. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Criteria for top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: California’s Next Nightmare
text: People tend to underestimate the power of floods: six inches of fast-moving water can knock you down; two feet of water can float most cars away. Floods kill an average of 127 Americans a year — more than tornadoes or hurricanes — and cause more than $2 billion of property damage annually, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association.

headline: Closing the Books
text: I am the chief financial officer for a financial-services company, and I found our bookkeeper using the corporate charge card for her personal use. The misappropriation was approximately $47,000 over a six-month period. She forged a partner’s signature to acquire a card in her name. We fired her, and she paid back the funds in exchange for our not pressing charges. But I cannot get closure if she is not punished for this egregious betrayal. I recommended that we call her husband, as I think family humiliation would be punishment enough. Would this be ethical? NAME WITHHELD,NEW YORK

text: Time: 15 minutes

headline: Baked Sea Bass With Potatoes, Tomatoes and Onions
text: Time: 1 hour

text: Time: 25 to 30 minutes

headline: The Gastronomist Gets Real
text: “No, you don’t understand.” It wasn’t the first time I’d heard those words from Ferran Adrià, the chef and driving force behind El Bulli, the oft-proclaimed world’s greatest restaurant, which he recently announced is going to close in July. In my dozen or so visits with him over the last 10 years in northeastern Spain and in New York, it seemed there was always some point I was missing.

headline: The H.P. TouchPad
text: David Pogue compares the H.P. TouchPad with the iPad.

headline: Being an Ex-Governor a Double-Edged Sword for 2012
text: It’s no coincidence that most of the leading Republican candidates for president are former governors, whose executive experience is used as the primary argument for their fitness to move into the Oval Office.

headline: Djokovic Beats Tsonga to Reach Final
text: Novak Djokovic advanced to his first Wimbledon final with a hugely entertaining win over Jo Wilfried Tsonga, winning in four sets, 7-6, 6-2, 6-7, 6-3. The match featured several thrilling all-court points, with each man making acrobatic gets on passing shots. In the end, Djokovic’s solid returning and relentless ground game wore down Tsonga’s aggressive shot-making.

headline: Pronouncing the Unpronounceable
text: A few weeks back, we wrote about the myriad ways to pronounce, and mispronounce, the Van Wyck Expressway and offered to track down correct pronunciations for New York place names that reduce readers to guesswork or mumbling.

headline: A Light Lunch in Spain
text: Mark Bittman and Ferran Adria whip up a tasty dish and talk about what happens next for the famed Spanish restaurant.

headline: Tip of the Week: Saving E-Mailed Photos for Macs
text: Apple’s iPhoto program, which comes free on most new Macs, can automatically pull in pictures from a connected digital camera, but you can also easily save images attached to Mail messages too. When you open a message in the Mac OS X Mail program and see photos that you’d like to add to the iPhoto library, click and hold the cursor down on the small blue Save button in the message header. At the bottom of the drop-down menu that appears, select the “Save to iPhoto” option to save all pictures into the iPhoto program.

headline: Danish Company Blocks Sale of Drug for U.S. Executions
text: PARIS — A Danish pharmaceutical company said Friday that it would stop shipping a powerful drug to American prisons that carry out the death penalty by lethal injection because some states began using it as a substitute for another compound that was taken off the market.

headline: Who Could Replace Geithner?
For 2 Republican Leaders, a Bond, Not a Rivalry
text: WASHINGTON — When Speaker John A. Boehner was pressed on whether he shared Senator Mitch McConnell’s view on wringing savings out of Medicare in the continuing debt limit fight, he hardly waited for the questioner to finish.

headline: Providence to Buy Blackboard for $1.64 Billion
text: Providence Equity Partners agreed on Friday to buy Blackboard Inc., a maker of college coursework software, for $1.64 billion in cash, in the private equity firm’s latest foray into the education market.

headline: Friday Reading: Be Nice to Medical Receptionists
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Vain Glorious | Aesop Takes New York
text: The Australian skin care brand Aesop — Greek for “storyteller”— is a cult favorite among the type of discerning consumers who prefer their jeans dark, their espresso straight up and their bathrooms uncluttered. And like the Aesop products, the Aesop boutiques make innovative use of unusual ingredients, so there’s no sense of shopping at a chain when you pop in to pick up your Parsley Seed Anti-Oxidant Facial Serum (which, incidentally, is brilliant for maintaining a glowing complexion through the depths of sticky East Coast summers). Case in point: the first of Aesop’s four planned New York shops, which opens in the Graybar Passage in Grand Central Terminal next week, will be built primarily from recycled 19th-century newspapers. Locations on Elizabeth Street and University Place will follow by the end of the summer, and a flagship on Bleecker Street will open in December. The Moment recently caught up with the Aesop founder, Dennis Paphitis, to talk about architecture, why art inspires him and what he thinks about all-natural skin care claims.

headline: Republicans’ Downtime Throwdown
text: In politics, sometimes attacking your opponent can give them an opening to attack back. That’s what President Obama did by urging Republican lawmakers to stay in Washington until the debt debate is over.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: Nadal Tops Murray for Berth in Final
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Britain can exhale now.

headline: Keynes Film Festival
text: A guy with a beard talks about a guy with a mustache. Videos of the lecture and Q&A.

headline: Soar Losers
text: Like everyone who has argued that continuing low interest rates vindicate the Keynesian view of how macroeconomics works, I’ve faced a lot of claims that the low rates were artificial, that as soon as the Fed stopped buying bonds rates would soar. Some big-name private-sector people, notably Bill Gross, have made similar claims.

headline: The Danger in Counting on Markets to Drive a Debt-Limit Deal
text: Many astute political observers worry that an elegant resolution to the negotiations over the federal debt limit may not be in the making — and that there is a tangible possibility that the United States will default on its debts.

headline: Former Brearley Leader Returns as Interim Head
text: The Brearley School‘s trustees moved quickly on Friday to contain any damage from the abrupt resignation of its head of school, naming a former Brearley leader as interim head of school.

headline: TimesCast | Doping in Sports
text: Sports columnist Jonathan Mahler questions the cost and fairness of prosecuting two Texas sports stars.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: The Accidental Patriot
text: James de Givenchy intended to give his daughter, Stella, a 1940s candy-striped bracelet that he bought online. When the piece arrived, de Givenchy, a jeweler, was so taken with the quality of the plastic that he took it into in his workshop for further study, leaving it next to a pile of faceted lapis. The commingling was purely serendipitous. “I thought it would be so much fun,” de Givenchy said of the costume bauble-turned-fine jewelry. A very American transformation, don’t you think? $10,000. Go to taffin.com or call (212) 421-6222 for an appointment.

headline: A High-Tech Twist on a Classic Card Game
text: Remember the card game Uno? Now, Uno remembers you.

headline: LAByrinth Theater Finds a Downtown Home
text: LAByrinth Theater Company has a steady home for its newly announced 2011-12 season. The company, which has historically found space all over New York, most recently at the Public Theater, has taken up residence in the newly rechristened Bank Street Theater for the foreseeable future, a spokesman said on Thursday.

headline: Just How Many Android Tablet Apps Are There?
text: In my Times column this week, I reviewed Hewlett-Packard’s new iPad clone, the TouchPad. Since the benefit of owning a tablet is apps, I thought it would be useful to compare the number of apps available for iPad, Android tablets and the new H.P.

headline: Regulators Provide $14 Billion Bailout for Bank of Moscow
text: MOSCOW — Russian regulators said on Friday that they had averted the collapse of one of the largest Russian banks by providing a bailout package of 395 billion rubles to Bank of Moscow, suggesting the bank’s problems with bad loans were more severe than previously acknowledged.

headline: TimesCast | Strauss-Kahn Trial Derails
text: Investigators have found major holes in the credibility of the hotel housekeeper who charged that Dominique Strauss-Kahn attacked her.

headline: The Science of Song, the Song of Science
text: MANCHESTER, England — In one song that Bjork performed here on Thursday night, the bass lines were zaps of artificial lightning from a Tesla coil in a cage. In another, a sizable Victorian-looking contraption of stainless steel, the Sharpsichord — part giant music box, part harp, part gramophone — used a rotating barrel to play deep, bonging counterpoint.

headline: A Small Note on the Stimulus Debate
text: One small followup on the issue of being prematurely right about the stimulus being too small: you might think that hippies like me were basing their views on some wild and crazy, unorthodox version of economics, while the wise, judicious people who thought that $787 billion was just right were using standard analysis.

headline: A Response to Mara Hvistendahl (I)
text: The author of “Unnatural Selection” has kindly written a reply to my column on her book. Not surprisingly, she takes exception to my suggestion that sex-selective abortion poses a problem for pro-choice liberals, arguing that there’s no contradiction at all between supporting abortion rights and trying to restrict/ban abortions based on sex:

headline: No End in Sight as Minnesotans Grapple With State Shutdown
text: ST. PAUL — The state of Minnesota screeched to a stop on Friday.

headline: TimesCast | Paris Reactions
text: Parisians react to the revelations that the sexual assault case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn may be unraveling.

headline: Pistons Run a Play Out of Private Equity’s Book
text: It looks as if the Detroit Pistons will be the first professional sports team in the United States to get the private equity treatment.

headline: Finra Executives Get Big Payday
text: Wall Street’s self-policing organization is getting richer – and so are its top executives.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Is Released as Case Teeters
text: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, who is accused of sexually assaulting a hotel housekeeper, was released from house arrest on Friday as the case against him moved closer to dismissal after prosecutors told a Manhattan judge that the credibility of his accuser was in serious question.

headline: Empty Plates for Low-Income Seniors
text: There’s a long list of reasons that older people suffer malnutrition and weight loss, a geriatrician recently told a Senate subcommittee on health and aging: smell and taste diminishing with age, high rates of depression, medications that that suppress appetite or upset stomachs, disabilities that make it hard to shop and cook.

headline: Exxon Cut Financing to Climate Skeptics, Group Says
text: Greenpeace U.S.A. has issued a report saying that all of the research funding received since 2003 by Willie Soon, an astrophysicist who has been a critic of climate science, came from oil or coal interests like ExxonMobil and the Southern Company, a utility that burns coal.

headline: Last Weekend for Mini Mangoes
text: Mini mangoes from Mexico have been at produce markets in Chinatown, but this is your last chance to buy them because the season will end by this weekend. No new supplies are being shipped in.

headline: Pitmaster Robbie Richter Leaves Fatty ‘Cue
text: Robbie Richter, the pitmaster of Fatty ‘Cue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has left after a year on the job. He has not revealed his future plans.

headline: Why Clemens and Armstrong Aren’t Worth Pursuing Anymore
text: This is shaping up as a bad month for fallen Texas sports icons.

headline: Moroccans Vote for Changes the King Says Will Reduce His Power and Raise Theirs
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Moroccans voted in a landslide on Friday to approve constitutional changes proposed last month by King Mohammed VI in a bid to introduce greater political openness and ward off the unrest that has swept the Arab world.

headline: In Car Sales, Good Month for Detroit, Not Japan
text: DETROIT — Shortages of cars made by Toyota and Honda and fewer discounts over all made June the worst month so far this year for sales of new vehicles in the United States, but automakers expressed confidence that the industry would rebound later in the year.

headline: New Ways to See 3 Classic Parks
text: I LOVE the national parks. Last summer, I was lucky enough to visit three. My travels last July took me first to the Northeast, to Acadia on the coast of Maine, then later out West for a family vacation with my husband, Scott Robinson, and our younger daughter, Hannah, at Yellowstone and Grand Teton. In each, I tried to get off the beaten path.

headline: Stan Lee Starts Chinese Superhero Franchise
text: Stan Lee, the comic book creator, has announced a joint venture with a Hong Kong investment company for a new superhero franchise aimed at Chinese and foreign audiences, The Associated Press reports.

headline: How Do You Prefer Your Heart?
text: We found ourselves in a dilemma for this week’s issue: four different cover treatments and many different opinions about which one was the most aesthetically pleasing. First we did an internal poll in the art department. The rules were simple, vote on your favorite cover by putting a small wooden chip (broken coffee stirrer) into the matching cup. Only problem was, we had a tie and we needed more votes. So we opened up the judging to the entire staff and 37 staff members from every department voted.

headline: With Police Absent, Protests Surge in Syrian City
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Tens of thousands of protesters poured Friday into the streets of Hama, a Syrian city abandoned by the military and security forces, gathering in the country’s biggest demonstration in nearly four months of unrest and staking a festive claim to a region that bore the brunt of a ferocious government crackdown a generation ago.

headline: N.F.L. Deal Is Said to Be Weeks Away as Talks Restart
text: N.F.L. owners and players continued to negotiate late Thursday evening, but progress slowed as time dwindled for striking a labor deal that would avoid the disruption of the preseason.

headline: What Would Tarzan Think?
text: For those infected with jungle fever (see Prada’s chic monkey and banana frocks for spring), the good news is you can follow the trend into fall. The Marc by Marc Jacobs collection, in stores this month, features panthers and antelopes on everything from drop pants to jacquard blazers. The prints are the handiwork of Michael Roberts, who, when he’s not working for Vanity Fair as style editor at large, is illustrating childen’s pop-up books about the jungle. This clutch, for example, with its sleek appliqué ($328), is entirely fierce. Go to marcjacobs.com. For the scarf, $178, go to nordstrom.com.

headline: Tracing Unscooped Dog Waste Back to the Culprit
text: Sherlock Holmes had the case of the dog that didn’t bark, but it has taken two dozen apartment complexes and a testing company in Tennessee to bring the art of canine detection into the “CSI” age.

headline: The Ride of Frankenstein: Daring, or Just Deranged?
text: IN a world of play-it-safe auto design driven by focus groups, it’s good to see companies take some chances.

headline: Defying the Trend, a Small Town Loosens Its Belt
text: While American cities large and small are grappling with budget deficits of historic proportions — laying off teachers and police officers and closing libraries — the town of Golden Beach, Fla., is doing fine, thank you. The town, nestled along the Atlantic Ocean in Miami-Dade County, has a minuscule unemployment rate, plenty of money and little crime. Among its current or former homeowners are Ricky Martin, Bill Gates and Paul Newman. The town also has a history of exclusion — at one point in the 1980s it closed most of its roads to the outside world as part of an effort to deter crime. These days, the town has entry gates staffed by security officers. Mayor Glenn Singer, elected this year to his fourth term, discusses.

headline: Banning Babies in First Class
text: As you depart for whichever backyard, or beach, or local park, or airport marks the start of your Independence Day weekend, an update on Malaysia Airlines’ announcement that infants will not be allowed up front when the airline introduces its new Airbus A380 aircraft next year. The airline already has such a ban on its 747-400 fleet.

headline: On Strokes and (Personal) Sustainability
text: I have a long list of backlogged posts but am taking a brief break from tracking global sustainability to check my personal operating systems.* A stroke will do that to you.

headline: Weekend Fare: Fourth of July Edition
text: Free tastes of wine from Italy’s Veneto region will be served on Friday from 2 to 4 p.m. at Enoteca Di Palo, 200 Grand Street (Mott Street), in Little Italy. From 6 to 8 p.m., sparkling wines from the region will be available at I Tre Merli, 463 West Broadway (Prince Street), in SoHo.

headline: By-the-Book Celebration for China’s Communists on Party’s 90th Birthday
text: BEIJING — The party for the Party turned out to be a doctrinaire affair, as President Hu Jintao expounded Friday on the benefits of 90 years of communism with Chinese characteristics while workplaces around the country held red-song singalongs.

headline: A Collision of Creativity and Cash
text: When the Walt Disney Company bought Pixar Animation Studios for $7.4 billion in 2006, there was understandable concern that the media conglomerate that drove the famed Disney animation unit into the ground with duds like “Home on the Range” and “Chicken Little” would extinguish the creative flame that had nurtured the quirky and much-loved “Toy Story” and “Finding Nemo.”

headline: Debt Ceiling Date Does Not Budge
text: The Aug. 2 debt ceiling deadline is holding firm. The Treasury Department said Friday morning that its latest estimates still show that’s the date the government will exhaust its ability to pay all of its bills, unless Congress agrees to raise the total amount that the United States can borrow.

headline: Letter From District Attorney to Defense in Strauss-Kahn Case
text: The letter outlines interviews with the hotel housekeeper who had accused Mr. Strauss-Kahn, and raises questions about her version of events.

headline: The Man Who Keeps the Boats Afloat in Flushing Bay
text: Phil McCaughey wiped the dusty sweat off his sunburned neck and pulled a Post-It out of his pocket.

headline: Thousands in Cairo Return to Tahrir Square to Protest the Slow Pace of Change
text: CAIRO — Thousands of protesters returned to Tahrir Square here on Friday to voice frustration with what they called the slow pace of change five months after the revolution. The demonstration occurred just days after renewed clashes between protesters and the police left hundreds injured and underscored the lingering distrust between Egyptians and a police force long seen as a pillar of the former government.

headline: ‘Pirates’ Booty Approaches $1 Billion
text: Just a few months ago, the people behind “Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides” were shivering in their timbers. Would their $250 million movie win back fans, the ones who were fed up with bloated running times and bewildering plots? Or would the audience respond with a great big yo ho hum?

headline: A Lesson Not Learned
text: If you can muster some outrage, by all means go ahead and vent it on the N.B.A. Apparently learning nothing from the N.F.L.’s ongoing debacle, the N.B.A. motored full steam ahead with its lockout plans on Thursday, another league bent on image annihilation in the name of saving themselves from their own business failings.

headline: Josh Ritter’s Novel of Appalachia
text: Henry Bright is pretty much your ordinary 20th-century West Virginia farmboy, with one notable exception: when he winds up in the World War I trenches in France, he begins hearing voices.

headline: A Pacifist in the Family
text: In every presidential election from 1928 to 1948, Americans had the option of voting for Norman Thomas, the perennial Socialist Party candidate. Very few chose to do so. Thomas’s best result — 2.2 percent of the ballot nationwide — was in 1932, and he never came close to that share again. Yet when he died in 1968 at the age of 84, he was remembered as a courageous idealist who, in the words of a tribute in The New York Times, “spoke to the feelings that most Americans have about themselves.” In other words, he was an advocate for fairness, decency, justice and equality, a man to be admired though hardly one to be voted into office.

headline: The Not Quite Unhappy Marriage
text: How does one write a whole book on the boredom of marriage without becoming boring oneself? Pamela Haag’s “Marriage Confidential: The Post-Romantic Age of Workhorse Wives, Royal Children, Undersexed Spouses and Rebel Couples Who Are Rewriting the Rules” can, in spite of its exceptionally boppy subtitle, only partly answer that question.

headline: A John’s Story
text: Who has not seen the remorseful preachers, politicians, actors and other men in the news, begging forgiveness when caught with their pants down and publicly outed as “johns,” patrons of the world’s oldest profession? To be a known john is to be trailed by shame and stigma, at least in the United States and Canada. There are millions of johns, but for one to come out voluntarily — with honesty, integrity and pride — is indeed rare. In my nearly 40 years in the world of sex workers, I’ve known only one: Fred Cherry. In the 1980s in New York, Cherry sued Mayor Ed Koch for the legal right to pay for sex with prostitutes (a case Cherry ultimately lost). To ascertain if any other such brave johns had slipped my mind, I surveyed a few of my older prostitute friends. “No, just Fred Cherry,” they confirmed. (Today, I might count Charlie Sheen.) So for the Canadian comic artist Chester Brown to announce in his graphic memoir, “Paying for It,” that he is a john is truly groundbreaking.

headline: Aristotle and the Higher Good
text: Some time in the 1920s, the Conservative statesman F. E. Smith — Lord Birkenhead — gave a copy of the “Nicomachean Ethics” to his close friend Winston Churchill. He did so saying there were those who thought this was the greatest book of all time. Churchill returned it some weeks later, saying it was all very interesting, but he had already thought most of it out for himself. But it is the very genius of Aristotle — as it is of every great teacher — to make you think he is uncovering your own thought in his. In Churchill’s case, it is also probable that the classical tradition informed more of his upbringing, at home and at school, than he realized.

headline: A Parable of the New India
text: Nations are narratives. Every country is shaped by its particular set of ideas and myths. Inevitably these are simplifications, often clichés, but they hold a country together, imposing a certain coherence on diverse populations.

headline: A Novel of Race and Road Rage
text: In Tom Wolfe’s “Bonfire of the Vanities,” the mistress of a Wall Street bond salesman mows down a black youth in the South Bronx, and he encourages her to keep driving. In Will Allison’s second novel, “Long Drive Home,” another ­middle-aged money man tries to cover up his role in a racially tinged fatal accident. In Allison’s case, the beleaguered white guy is Glen Bauer, a suburban New Jersey accountant who, offended by the sight of a black teenager in a convertible barreling too fast down his sleepy residential block, swerves briefly into his path to give the kid a scare. Instead, he crashes to his death. What’s more, just as in “Bonfire,” the accident creates a downward spiral in the protagonist’s life that seems to have a momentum of its own.

headline: Taking Stock of Race in Obama’s America
text: Dramatic stories of hardship and injustice have always been at the center of the struggle for racial equality. Homer Plessy refused to ride in a segregated black train car in late-19th-­century Louisiana; the World War II veteran George Dorsey and three other African-­Americans were killed by a racist mob outside Atlanta in 1946; Emmett Till was lynched by white bigots in Mississippi in 1955; and in that same year, Rosa Parks sparked the Montgomery bus boycott when she would not surrender her seat to a white passenger. These events and many others inspired activists to press for change and convinced average Americans that change was necessary. The worst abuses of the Jim Crow era have been eliminated, but the moral outrage inspired by a personal encounter with a bigot remains the most powerful vehicle for conveying the injuries and indignities of racial inequality. Accordingly, civil rights lawyers seek out plaintiffs whose grievances reflect larger in­justices, and activists rally around people who symbolize pervasive social problems.

headline: Commanding Hitler’s Soldiers
text: In war, the finest generals may win battles, but they are ultimately condemned to defeat if their political masters are fools. One such inferior superior was Hitler, a former corporal who imposed his clumsy strategic visions on the German Army — which obeyed, willingly, to the last man’s last round.

headline: Terror of Teenage Life
text: If and when you go away to college you can become somebody else; you can kill off your old self and be reborn. So generations of young people have believed. But once they have done it — ditching provincial tastes and hometown boyfriends for a sorority, a fraternity or an undergraduate bohemia — they may trade one conformity for another; they may feel haunted by their former lives. No wonder teenage life, on and off campus, seems to fit stories of vampires, ghosts, the undead. Laura Kasischke is hardly the first to use such figures (as fans of “Buffy the Vampire Slayer” know) but with her new novel, “The Raising,” she pursues them almost perfectly. Almost a supernatural thriller, almost a campus satire and almost but not quite a coming-of-age tale, “The Raising” is also the best of Kasischke’s eight novels, the one with the broadest canvas, the most observation, its large cast arranged with a scary economy of detail.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: THE LAKE  By Banana Yoshimoto.Translated by Michael Emmerich.  Melville House, $23.95.

headline: Tennis by the Book
text: “Wow, what a tournament we witnessed this week, Johnny Mac! Before we came back on the air, we were both saying that we’ve been just flat-out blown away by the talent at this year’s Intertemporal Tennis Writers Classic. Some of the greatest writers in history came and competed and showed us what it means to write extraordinarily well about tennis. This tournament attracts the world’s sharpest minds because tennis is a global sport that’s steeped in tradition, and more, it’s a gentlemanly clash of wills where you’re out there alone, and the way you play reveals so much about who you are. Somewhere between chess and boxing lies tennis. So you have to be an elite writer to get through this tournament. That’s why no one was surprised to see Touré get knocked out in the first round. Sure, he’s done some nice stories, like his profile of Jennifer Capriati for Vogue, in which he hits with her. Do we have a clip from that? ‘The whole incident takes on the feel of intense aerobics mixed with a back-alley mugging, and you’re just deflecting and defending and, eventually, after eight or nine minutes, your arm starts to throb and your lungs start to shriek and each new shot racing at you is like a punch to the chest and you feel her inner bully.’ Touré’s a solid player, but in this tournament your forehand is your vocabulary, your backhand is your eye for detail, your ability to turn words into poetry and rhythm is your volley, your use of metaphors and symbolism is your overhead, and your deep understanding of the sport is your all-important first serve. Touré writes passionately and knows tennis, but some whispered that he might have gotten into the tournament only because of affirmative action. Maybe.

headline: Death Among Neighbors
text: Nothing brings neighbors together faster than a murder on  the block. Or so says Ruth Rendell, who subjects the residents of an  apartment house in Kenilworth (“as dreary as only a London outer suburb  can be”) to intense psychological scrutiny in her morbidly witty  suspense novel TIGERLILY’S ORCHIDS (Scribner, $26) before selecting one of them as her murder victim.

headline: Up Front: Annie Sprinkle
text: Annie Sprinkle, who in this issue reviews Chester Brown’s “Paying for It: A Comic-Strip Memoir About Being a John,” is no stranger to the documentary urge. “From the day I gave away my virginity at 17 I started documenting my sexual experiences,” Sprinkle told us via e-mail. “I still am, 40 years later.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: CHILDREN AND FIRE,  by Ursula Hegi (Scribner, $25.) In the fourth of Hegi’s novels to be set in the German village of Burgdorf, a schoolteacher heroine, seduced by Nazi propaganda, struggles to follow her moral compass.

headline: Paperback Row
text: SWEET THUNDER: The Life and Times of Sugar Ray Robinson,  by Wil Haygood (Lawrence Hill, $18.95.) This ambitious portrait places Ray Robinson as a central figure in the rise of urban African-Americans in the 20th century, tracing Robinson’s life from his birth in Detroit in 1921 as Walker Smith Jr.; to Harlem and the peak of his success as a prizefighter in the 1940s and ’50s; to his humbling final years in Los Angeles before his death in 1989.

headline: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: 7 Going on 17
text: Janet Evanovich has had seven books on the hardcover fiction lists over the past three years.

headline: Inside the List
text: JERSEY GIRL: Janet Evanovich’s “Smokin’ Seventeen” jumps past Tom Clancy’s “Against All Enemies” to give Evanovich her 12th straight No. 1 hardcover best seller in her Stephanie Plum series. Evanovich may have left her hometown, South River, N.J., for the more scenic climes of Naples, Fla., but her endearingly semi-competent bounty hunter heroine is still running around the Garden State chasing bad guys, juggling boyfriends and serving as a one-woman stimulus program for the used-car industry. Evanovich’s Web site includes a memorial page for the ill-fated vehicles that have crossed Stephanie’s path, from the Chevy Nova in “One for the Money” (“Left for dead, which is O.K. since it had already been vandalized and had no muffler, tailpipe or radio”) to the Carpet Car in “Hot Six” (“caught on fire from flaming dog poop in a bag”), the Honda CRV in “Hard Eight” (“firebombed by a rabbit”) and a maroon Econoline van from “Fearless Fourteen,” which “wasn’t really Stephanie’s, but caught her bad car juju anyway, struck by a russet potato and exploded, as predicted by Gary the Stalker.” Normally, Evanovich also holds a summerlong naming contest for next year’s book (“Holy Cannoli Seventeen,” anyone?), but she recently announced her next title early, during an interview on the “Today” show. Yup, you guessed it: “Explosive Eighteen.”

headline: NATO’s Libyan War Is ‘Like Fast Food,’ Qaddafi’s Son Says
text: In an appearance on Russia Today, an English-language satellite channel financed by the Russian government, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s son Seif al-Islam said that the international intervention in Libya was motivated purely by a desire to control Libya’s oil and gas resources.

headline: Iraq Cracks Down on Iran-Backed Shiite Militias
text: BAGHDAD — Against a backdrop of rising violence against American soldiers, Iraqi security forces have unleashed a sweeping crackdown on Iranian-backed Shiite militants responsible for most of the lethal attacks, according to American and Iraqi officials.

headline: It’s July. Do You Know Where Your Beach House Is?
text: EVEN for longtime residents, the crazy quilt of towns, hamlets and villages that stretch along the South Fork of Long Island can be a bit dizzying.

headline: Elements of an Ideal Burger
text: Cooking tips for creating the perfect burger, on everything from picking the right bun to shaping the patty to getting the perfect sear on the meat.

headline: AMC Shares Tumble on Debut
text: Shares of AMC Networks — the media company spun off from Cablevision that is home to “Mad Men” and “Breaking Bad” — fell on their full trading debut on the Nasdaq market on Friday.

headline: Vacation Rentals in Non-Hamptons Directions
text: FOR city dwellers who haven’t fallen under the spell of the Hamptons, there are plenty of other escapes, including popular beaches to the south in New Jersey and lakeside hideaways to the north in the Hudson Valley.

headline: Film Festival | Documentaries for Summer Fun
text: Our summer experiments continue! Last week: Historic Headlines. This week: A collaboration with SnagLearning to bring you “film festivals” of classroom-worthy documentaries, each day on a different theme.

headline: Making a Portfolio, and More, at Money Camp
text: WELL-MEANING parents have long sent their children to specialized camps in the hope of bringing out their inner genius — or at least keeping them busy for the summer. But recently, a camp with a different sort of specialty than the usual cheerleading and music and art camps has been popping up — one that aims to teach children money skills.

headline: Never Too Far From the Beach
text: PATSY AND CHUCK KOPPEIS have talked to more neighbors in the five months since they moved to the quirky seaside community of Bayville than in the 28 years they lived in Woodbury, 15 minutes away.

headline: Comparing Yourself to Others: It’s Not All Bad
text: “TO compare is to despair,” the saying goes, and I’ve generally found it to be true. If I try hard enough (and sometimes even if I don’t) I can usually find someone who performs better or has more. And I can feel bad about it.

headline: Watermelon and Tomato Salad
text: Mark Bittman makes a salad from the Minimalist column archives that combines sweet and savory, tender and crunchy.

headline: Election to Replace Weiner Is Set for Sept. 13
text: Fulfilling the wishes of local political leaders, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Friday that a special election to fill the seat of former Representative Anthony D. Weiner would be held on Sept. 13.

headline: The Plaza Hotel Reopens Its Tricycle Garage
text: The Plaza Hotel in New York City will revive its Tricycle Garage, which will be good news for “Eloise” fans — especially those lucky enough to stay at the renovated landmark hotel. Beginning on July 1, the Plaza will offer children’s bike rentals – including Radio Flyer tricycles, bicycles and scooters – for hotel guests and a few lucky New Yorkers.

headline: The Minimalist: Watermelon and Tomato Salad
text: I developed this recipe about five years into my stint as the Minimalist. By that point I had already exhausted (or thought I had; I was wrong) most of the obvious candidates for the column– five-ingredient pasta dishes, simple marinated meats, 10-minute green salads — and was forced to research and invent recipes that were less conventional but no more complicated. This salad is one of my favorite results of that challenge, and I still make it regularly. It turns out watermelon and tomato make spectacular plate fellows, and they’re even better with a few assertive accompaniments.

headline: Richer People Want Fewer Children
text: The economist Justin Wolfers wrote a provocative post last month arguing that children are “inferior goods.”

headline: A French Oddity Turns Heads in New York
text: Alain Daumas dreamed of driving his 1955 Citroën Traction Avant down Broadway. On a recent afternoon, his wish came true.

headline: Beijing Monastery’s Newer Neighbors
text: In a maze of alleys branching out from the 17th-century Lama, or Yonghe, Temple are new cafes and boutiques.

headline: Roller Coasters Bring a New Kind of Thrill to Vegas
text: THERE are two kinds of people who travel to Las Vegas: gamblers and roller-coaster riders.

headline: Restaurant Report: Lechonera La Ranchera in Puerto Rico
text: Pop out to Lechonera La Ranchera, about 30 minutes outside San Juan, on a Friday afternoon and you can snack on crisp pork chunks and fried plantains, enjoy the air-conditioning, then climb back in your rental car for the drive back, wondering the whole time, perhaps, why you didn’t just order takeout at the hotel.

headline: On Quebec Fur Traders’ Trail, With a Paddle
text: WE had two choices: stop and haul our canoes and gear along a four-mile trail running parallel to the river, or paddle into the canyon, with its 19 sets of rapids and near vertical walls. Either way, the decision would be final.

headline: Hotel Review: Gansevoort Park Avenue NYC
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: In Rome, Monti Is a Quiet Treasure
text: PEOPLE sometimes wander along Via Panisperna in Rome realizing they are lost, but not fretting about it. The view is divine from there, a slice of the Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore sandwiched between 19th-century apartment buildings, dilapidated palazzos, the elevated Church of San Lorenzo in Panisperna and stores like Macelleria Stecchiotti, a butcher shop selling some of the best meat in Rome. The owner, Pietro Stecchiotti, a neighborhood notable nicknamed “Pol Pot” for his occupation and ardent Communist politics, claims to have planted the vines that drape across Via Panisperna in front of his shop, framing a quintessentially Roman streetscape.

headline: In Italy, Vineyards by Vespa
text: “IS it normal for the carabinieri to be drinking at noon?” I asked, gesturing toward five members of the Italian military police swirling and sipping glasses of white wine.

headline: Chávez Can Remain Outside Venezuela for Months, Vice President Says
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Hugo Chávez, who shocked the nation by revealing that he had a cancerous tumor removed and would “continue battling,” could legally keep governing Venezuela from his seclusion in Cuba for as long as six months if necessary, his vice president said Friday.

headline: July 1, 1898 | The Battle of San Juan Hill
text: On July 1, 1898, United States forces, including Teddy Roosevelt’s Rough Riders, defeated greatly outnumbered Spanish forces at San Juan Hill and Kettle Hill near the Spanish stronghold of Santiago de Cuba. The victory allowed the United States to begin a siege of Santiago de Cuba, which led to Spanish surrender and the end of the Spanish-American War.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Lost in Space
text: “Legion Lost,” a tale of the Legion of Super-Heroes, a group of champions from 1,000 years in the future, lands at No. 2 on the hardcover list this week. The group, published by DC Comics, has had a bit of a confounding history. The Legion was created in 1958. They were time travelers from the future who had traveled to the past to meet their heroic inspiration: Superboy. Cut to 1985 when DC published Crisis on Infinite Earths, a limited series intended to streamline the decades of convoluted continuity of its heroes. It was decided that Superman never had costumed adventures as a youth, so the reason for the Legion’s founding had to be reconsidered. A lot of stories were crafted to give them a new reason for forming – until it was decided, 20 years later when DC published Infinite Crisis – that Superman did have a career as Superboy so the Legion could be inspired by him.

headline: Stuck in Dock, Flotilla Activists See the Hand of Israel
text: ATHENS — With the propeller shafts of two ships mysteriously damaged, the Greek authorities holding other vessels in port on government orders and an American boat turned back by the Greek coast guard on Friday just 20 minutes off the coast, the international flotilla to Gaza has stalled.

headline: Big Deal | Saved, Restored and Now for Sale
text: In 2007, Eric Cohler bought a house on Long Island designed by the architect Edward Durell Stone, and he had many visions for it.

headline: Weathering Wall Street's Job Cuts
text: July 1, 2011 - DealBook's Susanne Craig speaks to Reuters Breakingviews about why financial institutions are laying off staff and cutting expenses.

headline: Columbia and the Revolution
text: Columbia was America’s response to Britannia, a secular goddess who personified the national spirit.

headline: Conversion Error
text: The Murano CrossCabriolet, a convertible version of the Nissan’s small crossover, is a nightmare of design and execution.

headline: TimesCast | Strauss-Kahn Is Released
text: July 1, 2011 - In a court hearing, prosecutors acknowledged serious problems with the credibility of the hotel housekeeper who said that Dominique Strauss-Kahn attacked her.

headline: Weathering Wall Street’s Job Cuts
text: DealBook’s Susanne Craig speaks to a Reuters Breakingviews editor, Rob Cox, and a columnist, Antony Currie, about cutbacks in staff and compensation on Wall Street. How does the current round of layoffs and austerity in the financial industry compare with the “Armageddon” at the height of the financial crisis?

headline: The Week in Pictures for July 1
text: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the closing of an elementary school, the same-sex marriage law in New York and a disappearing artist at ground zero.

headline: Where Did the Fun Go?
text: A few years ago, just as the recession hit, the Chambre Syndicale, the French fashion authority, decided to separate the June men’s shows and the haute couture by a week. The two groups of shows had followed each other, as they still do in January. A week of free time in Europe is no longer regarded by publications with the joie de vivre of the past, so I usually split the time between work and pleasure. At the moment I’m in a village in Burgundy, staying at La Source des Fées, a vineyard owned by Thierry Nouvel and Philippe Greffet. The place is as lovely as it is laid back, with delicious dinners, and each night brings new guests — Dutch, Swedes, French. It’s the beginning of the European summer.

headline: Harlem Stage Announces Fall Lineup
text: Harlem Stage, the multidisciplinary performing arts center supporting artists of color that has made a huge name for itself while managing to weather the recent economic storms, announced on Friday its fall 2011 season of new dance, film, theater and music. Among the highlights are “Visible,” a new work by choreographers Nora Chipaumire and Jawole Willa Jo Zollar, which will have its world premiere Oct. 10-15 at the Harlem Stage Gatehouse. Two new editions of the WeDaPeoplesCabaret will jump-start the Uptown Nights series in September. Carl Hancock Rux is the curator on Sept. 17, with a program featuring Nona Hendryx, the political monologist Reno and the author and producer Nelson George. The Grammy-nominated trumpeter Christian Scott will offer two nights with his quintet on Oct. 28 and Oct. 29. The D.J. Rich Medina will transform the Harlem Stage Gatehouse into a space to celebrate the life of Fela Anikulapo Kuti on Nov. 19 with music, dance and conversation. On Nov. 10, as part of its Harlem Stride – Community Concert series in partnership with the Weill Music Institute of Carnegie Hall, the Grammy nominee Miguel Zenon leads his quintet in a program featuring music by great songwriters from Puerto Rico. Tickets are free. Ticket prices for most Harlem Stage performances are $20 or less; some are free and generally don’t go higher than $45.

headline: A Camp Option, but Is It Useful?
text: Wealthy families have long realized that their children need to learn about money, Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week. They will often send their children to retreats like the one run by Citi Private Bank, which focuses on investing, running businesses and giving money to charity.

headline: Hidden Entry
text: Designers have long favored sleek, flush door handles on concept cars. Now they are becoming common on production models.

headline: New Americana | Dressing for the Fourth
text: Dressing for a holiday often revolves around a slew of clichés that make us look (and feel) cheesy– orange and black, anyone? — as opposed to smartly festive. It certainly doesn’t have to. This fourth of July, opt for the unexpected in some coolly patriotic looks like Lanvin’s lamé shorts rather than classic denim, and pair them with bright, playful Superga sneakers. In the evening, go for relaxed Americana by mixing a Sonia by Sonia Rykiel T-shirt with a ladylike Donna Karan silk skirt. For a patriotic décolletage, wear this red lace bra from Deborah Marquit with a sexy sheer Equipment top. The black and white stripes (as opposed to boring blue and red) are as chic as a Mount Vernon fireworks display.

headline: What Cellphone Calls Say About Parent-Teenager Relations
text: Poor communication is a common complaint when it comes to parents and teenagers. What happens when you throw a cellphone into the mix?

headline: Whipped by Winds Over Land Parched by Drought, a New Mexico Wildfire Rages
text: LOS ALAMOS, N.M. — Driven by a relentless drought and surging summer winds, a wildfire continued to burn virtually unchecked in the Jemez Mountains near Los Alamos National Laboratory on Friday, having already scorched tens of thousands of acres in its path and leaving firefighters scrambling to keep pace.

headline: Popcast: Beyoncé Grows Up, and Half of Fiery Furnaces Gets Nostalgic
text: This week’s Popcast focuses on a pop princess who is growing up and an indie darling who is striking out on her own.

headline: Keeping Score: How Much Extra an Extra Base Really Means
text: Sean Forman is the creator of Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores in the major and minor leagues.

headline: Louisa Thomas on her book, “Conscience” and Katie Roiphe on Pamela Haag’s “Marriage Confidential”
text: This week: Louisa Thomas on her book, “Conscience,” and World War I pacifism; Katie Roiphe on Pamela Haag’s “Marriage Confidential”; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: A New Type of Student Loan, but Still a Risk
text: There are two possible reactions to the news in recent weeks that U.S. Bank and Wells Fargo are now offering fixed-rate student loans in addition to the variable rate kind that had been standard.

headline: How to Shop for a Student Loan (if You Must)
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I talk about the new fixed-rate student loans that U.S. Bank and Wells Fargo are offering.
