text: ANDREA WEBER had been thinking about leaving the Merce Cunningham Dance Company. It was 2008, she had been dancing with the troupe for four years, and her mind was slowly wrapping itself around the idea of what life after Cunningham might look like for her.

headline: Harry Potter and the Billion-Dollar Franchise
text: A look at how Harry Potter evolved from a figment of a teacher’s imagination into the foundation of an entertainment empire.

headline: Central Labor Council Elects New President
text: The New York City Central Labor Council — the umbrella organization for the city’s more than one million union members — announced on Friday that it had elected a new president who will be its first Hispanic and first full-time president.

headline: The Puzzle of Rossini’s Brief Career
text: THERE are lots of theories. Maybe Gioachino Rossini was tired. He might have been devastated by the death of his beloved mother.

headline: With Production Normalizing, Toyota and Honda Raise Incentive Spending
text: Increased incentive spending by Honda and Toyota in June suggests that the automakers are recovering production capacity.

headline: Talking (Exclamation) Points
text: IN an essay published in 1895 called “How to Tell a Story,” Mark Twain chastised writers who use “whooping exclamation-points” that reveal them laughing at their own humor, “all of which is very depressing, and makes one want to renounce joking and lead a better life.”

headline: Making a Bet on Concentrated Refills
text: From juices to shampoos to laundry detergents, many consumer products could be sold in more environmentally friendly forms than are common today in the United States.

headline: July 3 — 9
text: Dance

headline: In Colombia, a Soccer Paradox
text: POPAYÁN, Colombia—The presence of Las Cafeteras, the national team from Colombia, in its first Women’s World Cup likely will pass with little comment here. (Colombia faces the United States in a first-round Group C match in Sinsheim, Germany on Saturday.)

headline: The Fans Own the Magic
text: HARRY POTTER’S final battle with Lord Voldemort will hit movie screens on July 15, but that young wizard has already scored a decisive victory where it counts: at the box office, on best-seller lists and in the crowded arena of fantasy-driven popular culture. J. K. Rowling, a single mother when she hatched a series of magical boarding-school novels, has ascended to an Oprah-like level of wealth and influence, while Harry, with more than $6 billion in tickets sold globally, has surpassed James Bond as the top-grossing movie-franchise hero.

headline: Kate Moss Gets Married
text: Kate Moss looks pretty great in the simple but elegant beaded gown she wore Friday afternoon to wed Jamie Hince of the Kills in the Cotswolds in England. The silk dress was apparently designed by her longtime friend John Galliano. I love her young bridesmaids’ plain shifts, with their bare legs and slippers. Nothing fussy.

headline: Court Overturns Michigan Affirmative-Action Ban
text: A federal appeals court on Friday struck down Michigan’s 2006 ban on the consideration of race and gender in public-university admissions and government hiring in the latest round of the decade-long fight over the University of Michigan’s affirmative action policies.

headline: Lonely Voyage of Player, Piano and Audience
text: CRAIG TABORN was deep into a solo expedition one recent evening at the Rubin Museum of Art in Manhattan, seeming for all the world like someone cracking a secret code. Poised for action at a grand piano, he disrupted an expectant stillness with a turbulent digression. With his left hand he formed the lopsided bass-clef vamp of a piece called “Avenging Angel”; with his right he improvised complex annotations, firing them off in boldface or sleek cursive. It was taut, transfixing music, sharpened by the austerity of the setting: just Mr. Taborn at the piano, on his own.

headline: Dealbook: Zynga Files for $1 Billion I.P.O.
text: With real-world profit and an inexhaustible supply of virtual cows, Zynga is gunning for a blockbuster debut on the public markets.

headline: George Ballas, Inventor of the Weed Whacker, Dies at 85
text: George C. Ballas loved tending to his lawn with meticulous care, but the 200 or more trees crowding a two-acre expanse behind his house in Houston posed a problem: how to get around the bulging roots and manicure close enough to achieve the near perfection he desired.

headline: An Immigrant’s Welcome to New York
text: TWO smartly dressed couples, on their way into the River Cafe on the Brooklyn waterfront on a late spring Sunday, were momentarily diverted by an entirely alien sedan.

headline: Seen It Before: CBS Wins the Night With Repeats
text: For CBS, an all-repeat lineup eked out a first-place finish for the network in the ratings on Thursday as “CSI” and “The Mentalist” delivered the night’s largest audiences in prime time. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 7.8 million viewers tuned in for a rerun of “The Mentalist” at 10 p.m.. while “CSI” attracted 6.8 million at 9. “Wipeout” on ABC led the 8 p.m. hour with 6.5 million viewers, outperforming CBS’s combination of “The Big Bang Theory” (6.6 million) and “Rules of Engagement” (4.9 million). ABC earned a second-place finish, drawing 6.1 million at 9 p.m. for “Expedition Impossible” and 5.4 million at 10 for a new installment of “Rookie Blue.” Fox was third, averaging 5 million for “So You Think You Can Dance” at 8 p.m. followed by a rerun of “Glee” (2.9 million) at 9. NBC trailed in fourth with sitcom repeats and a new episode of “Love Bites” (1.8 million) at 10.

headline: Europe Gives $17 Billion to Greece to Avoid Default

headline: How Should We Cover Africa?
text: My Sunday column is a misnomer: it’s not really a column and it will appear online Friday, rather than Sunday. It’s the cover story for our new Sunday Review section, which used to be the NY Times’s Week in Review section, and it’s going up early on the Web.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, July 1
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Extra Savage
text: I discovered Dan Savage, the subject of my cover story this weekend, in 2004, when I became editor of the alternative weekly paper in New Haven. I did not know much about alt weeklies, and to get ideas I looked around for some of the best. Somebody said I had to check out The Stranger, the bigger of Seattle’s two alt weeklies. So I e-mailed the editor, who was this Dan Savage guy. I figured that couldn’t be his real name; it was probably some alt weekly stunt. But “Dan Savage” sent me a bunch of issues, and the paper was brilliant: smart, good-looking, edgy. Inside, the editor wrote a really good sex column called Savage Love, and I asked my publisher if we could drop our syndicated sex column and replace it with Savage Love. “Can’t,” he said. “Too dirty. People would object.” That was about all I knew of Dan Savage for the next couple years, although occasionally I would see links to Savage’s work on Andrew Sullivan’s blog.

headline: An Experiment That Evolved Into a Tragedy
text: TALKING animals are a dime a dozen in animated blockbusters. But what about the real thing? And what, for that matter, would it mean for an animal to talk? What indeed separates an animal from a human? These are a few of the questions raised in a new documentary about the life of a chimpanzee named Nim Chimpsky, the subject of a radical language experiment in the 1970s. “Project Nim,” which opens Friday in New York and Chicago and will be shown next year on HBO, is named after the study, which began in 1973 with an infant Nim living with an Upper West Side family and ended after much trial and tribulation in a Texas animal sanctuary, where he died in 2000.

headline: Redwood Monster Is a Co-Champ
text: In theory, the tallest people and buildings and trees stand out. Take a really, really tall tree like a giant redwood. Hard to miss, right?

headline: Another Black Eye for Cyrus Vance
text: Someday soon — today, perhaps? — an observant bookie might ask: Who faces longer election odds? Dominique Strauss-Kahn or the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr.?

headline: What’s in a Name?
text: Kay E. Holekamp, a zoologist at Michigan State University, writes from the Masai Mara National Reserve in Kenya, where she is studying the behavior of spotted hyenas.

headline: A Departure, at Long Last, From Lehman
text: Eric Salzman, a managing director and group head of Lamco, the company handling the wind-down of Lehman Brothers, seems to have finally cut his ties to the bankrupt firm. Mr. Salzman was previously a Lehman executive before the firm’s collapse in September 2008.

headline: For Home Prices, It’s Back to at Least 2004
text: IS your home worth as much as it was seven years ago? If so, you’ve done better than most Americans.

headline: An Influential Director, Two Distinct Directions
text: ROBERT ALDRICH was still in his early 30s when he made, back to back, two of the most influential films of the 1950s, “Vera Cruz” (1954) and “Kiss Me Deadly” (1955). More remarkable still is that these films had their influence on two very different groups of filmmakers, at two very different periods.

headline: Reviewer Spotlight: Annie Sprinkle on Sex, Art and Activism
text: Annie Sprinkle, who reviews Chester Brown’s “Paying for It: A Comic-Strip Memoir About Being a John” in this weekend’s Book Review, is no stranger to the documentary urge. “From the day I gave away my virginity at 17, I started documenting my sexual experiences,” Sprinkle told us recently. “I still am, 40 years later.”

headline: Reviewing the Nissan Murano CrossCabriolet
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the 2011 Nissan Murano CrossCabriolet, a two-door, all-wheel-drive convertible based on the four-door Murano crossover.

headline: We’re Holding Your Plot Device. If You Want It Back, Send Us ...
text: THE Parisian tycoon Stanislas Graff is one of France’s more loathsome lotharios. Flaunting a cocksure recklessness worthy of an International Monetary Fund director, he leads a double life as a secret womanizer who has gambled his way into debt.

headline: Wimbledon’s Finalists, in Bronze
text: WIMBLEDON, England — It’s a little-known tradition: For most of a decade, the Wimbledon men’s champions and runners-up have received large bronze sculptures created from pictures taken of them in action during their finals.

headline: Centerview Hires 2 Bankers to Start Restructuring Team
text: Centerview Partners said on Friday that it had hired two senior bankers from Miller Buckfire to start a restructuring and bankruptcy practice.

headline: Ugly, Baggy Clothes? Not for This Swan
text: IRINA DVOROVENKO, 37, has been a principal dancer with the American Ballet Theater since 2000. An award-winning alumnus of the Kiev Ballet School, she danced the lead Odette-Odile role for the opening night of the company’s “Swan Lake” on June 27, and will soon take on the role of Princess Aurora in “Sleeping Beauty.” She is married to Maxim Beloserkovsky, a fellow principal dancer, with whom she has a 6-year-old daughter.

headline: ‘Miss New India’
German Women Are Champions, but Always in Second Place
text: BERLIN — “Third place is for men,” read the advertisements for the Women’s World Cup here in Germany, billboards of large white letters painted on a green soccer field. “Boys, we will avenge you,” was the slightly more collegial version.

headline: Video Shows Large Protest in Hama, Syrian City at Heart of Previous Uprising
text: As our colleague Anthony Shadid reports, on Friday tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets of Hama, Syria’s fourth-largest city, for what activists called the largest demonstration since the Syrian uprising began.

headline: A Certain Brand of Cool
text: It was once said of Chloe Sevigny, when she was 19, after Jay McInerney wrote a profile about her in The New Yorker, that she was the coolest girl in the world.

headline: A Crowd Favorite Takes His Leave
text: The love for José Manuel Carreño poured across the Metropolitan Opera House stage in almost palpable waves as one by one, his fellow dancers, his colleagues and his daughters delivered bouquets of flowers at the end of his final New York performance on Thursday with American Ballet Theater, where he had been a principal since 1995.

headline: The ‘It’ Girl, Now a Woman
text: SHORTLY before Chloë Sevigny took off for an acting role in Europe (portraying a pre-operative, male-to-female transsexual assassin in a new mini-series called “Hit and Miss”), a job that would keep her away from her East Village apartment for several months, she visited a neighborhood holistic food store to buy birdseed for her canary. When the saleswoman asked if she was a member of the store’s frequent shopper discount program, Ms. Sevigny said yes and gave her name.

headline: June’s Political Best Sellers
text: “Demonic” by Ann Coulter debuts at No. 4. Ms. Coulter is convinced that the Democrats operate just like a mob, and a mob’s sole purpose is to stir up and agitate. Ms. Coulter defines a mob as childlike, irrational and often violent in order to promote its agenda.

headline: Free to Say, ‘I Do,’ but Where?
text: NOT too long after watching the New York State Senate pass the marriage-equality bill on television, Bill White turned to his longtime partner, Bryan Eure, and asked, “Want to have a wedding?”

headline: The Culture and Construction of Accordions
text: Castelfidardo, Italy, the home of high-end accordion makers, has shifted its focus to quality from quantity to survive.

headline: App Smart Extra: A Bedtime Story via the iPad
text: This week’s App Smart column highlights a few good book apps that might prompt your children to spend more time reading this summer.

headline: Radio Wimbledon Adapts to the Times
text: For tennis fans today, there is now the opportunity to watch the action at Wimbledon streaming live online or via multiple channels on their satellite TV or check out 3-D coverage of the final weekend of the tournament.

headline: A Reason for Cheese on Shrimp (No, Really)
text: COMBINING seafood and cheese is one of those longstanding taboos that defy explanation. Why not grate a little Parmesan on a plate of pasta with white clam sauce? Because no one in Italy does it, and that is that.

headline: Prevention: Many False Alarms in Scans That Cut Cancer Deaths
text: Federal health officials announced last fall that smokers screened for cancer by low-dose spiral CT scans were 20 percent less likely to die of lung cancer than those who had chest X-rays. But the study’s final results, published online Wednesday in The New England Journal of Medicine, also describe the downsides of screening, including a high rate of false-positive scares.

headline: Prevention: A Better Use for Cotton Swabs Than Ear Cleaning
text: Could a dry cotton puff — something as ubiquitous and low-tech as a Q-tip — protect patients from dangerous infections after surgery?

headline: Default the Final? It Happened in 1931
text: WIMBLEDON, England — What a difference 80 years makes.

headline: Contract Advice for Declarer, Courtesy of the Overcall
text: The biggest surprise at the fifth European Open Championships in Poznan, Poland, was the win by the Turkish team of Mine Babac, Lale Gumrukcuoglu, Serap Kuranoglu and Dilek Yavas in the women’s teams. They defeated Carla Arnolds, Bep Vriend, Laura Dekkers, Marion Michielsen, Jet Pasman and Anneke Simons from the Netherlands by 89 international match points to 51. The Dutch players have numerous world and European medals; I quickly lost count while trying to add them up. The best previous Turkish result had been fourth in the women’s teams for Babac and Yavas at the first World Mind Sports Games in 2008.

headline: A rebound in executive compensation; the World Bank's plan to release data; plus tech companies and urban renewal.
text: PJ Joshi on the rebound in executive compensation, Stephanie Strom on the World Bank's plan to release data, and Damon Darlin on tech companies and urban renewal. Dan Niemi is the host.

headline: In a Twist, Loggers Nurture Spotted Owls
text: As I reported in Friday’s Times, the release this week of a final recovery plan for the northern spotted owl came more than 20 years after the bird was first listed as a threatened species.

headline: Gone With a Bang, Bang, Bang
text: So far this year, the New York Police Department reports that it has confiscated more than 5,000 pounds of illegal fireworks, ranging from sparklers to professional pyrotechnics. But the scofflaws’ loss is your gain, kind of: the police released this video of the mass detonation of the entire stash, which was accomplished Friday morning at 11:05 a.m. at the firing range at Rodman’s Neck in the Bronx.

headline: She’s Plastic, Beautiful and Rules the World
text: BECKET, Mass. — “It’s Barbie’s World. We Just Play In It.”

headline: A Big Day for the Kates
text: The Duchess of Cambridge certainly knows how to get the attention of nations. And she displays a flair for the graphic touch.

headline: New York Times Co. Sells Part of Its Stake in the Boston Red Sox
text: The New York Times Company said on Friday that it had sold more than half of its minority ownership in the Boston Red Sox and several other sports properties.

headline: The Jam | Spencer Sweeney
text: The Jam is a weekly playlist curated by Sean Hanratty.

text: 8:40 p.m. | Updated

headline: Podcast: Executive Pay, the World Bank and Twitter’s New Home
text: Big paydays are back for American chief executives.

headline: Irish Flotilla Activists Show Damage to Their Boat
text: Last year, when Israel launched a deadly commando raid on a flotilla of ships challenging its naval blockade of Gaza, many outraged opponents of that action demanded to know why the Israeli Navy had not taken some sort of less confrontational action. Like, for instance, disabling the propellers of the ships.

headline: What’s Inside the Bun?
text: If there is no such thing as a healthy hot dog, how do you limit the damage at this weekend’s weenie roast?

headline: Repatriation is the Last Refuge of Scoundrels
text: OK, not quite. But the idea of granting a tax holiday for corporations that repatriate income they’ve kept overseas, and on which they have avoided taxes, is one of the worst ideas I’ve heard in a long time. (And that’s saying something in these days and times). It figures, then, that my politically clued-in friends tell me that it’s an idea gaining lots of support on the Hill, even among progressives.

headline: The Week in Pictures for July 1
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the closing of and elementary school, the same-sex marriage law in New York and a disappearing artist at ground zero.

headline: Hedge Fund Hippies
text: Noted:

headline: MoneyVille: Zynga I.P.O.’s Big Winners
text: You may never find a purple cow in real life, but Zynga’s fortunes are very real.

headline: Rule 34
text: Charlie Stross has another book coming out Tuesday; I read a draft quite a while back (connections have their privileges).

headline: This Sunday: A Referendum on Infidelity
text: Yes, we had some notion that a cover story about marital infidelity might spark conversation among our readers. As of lunchtime Friday, the number of comments had cruised past the 400 mark. But more striking than the volume of responses was their variety and complexity.

headline: Now Out of the Spotlight, Pip Isn’t Above a Cameo
text: Pip the red-tailed hawk has kept a relatively low profile since flying the nest last week — certainly when compared with being watched round the clock on the Hawk Cam.

headline: Continuing a Continuing Story by Renewing His Early New Music
text: David Borden formed his colorfully named ensemble, Mother Mallard’s Portable Masterpiece Company, in 1969, when he was experimenting with early Moog synthesizers and Minimalist compositional notions. Mr. Borden has composed prolifically for the group since then, and on Wednesday evening he brought his players to the Issue Project Room for an installment of the space’s Darmstadt Institute: Classics of the Avant-Garde series.

headline: New York Theater Brand Goes West
text: LOS ANGELES — How do you take an acclaimed theater festival in one city and turn it into a national franchise, an endeavor that could easily set off turf warfare among artists? Mark Russell thinks he has an answer.

headline: I Forgive Canada
text: Purify my mind.

headline: What’s Scrabble When You Can Play Novelist?
text: The best after-dinner games need no special equipment to play: no dice, cards, tiles or machines that bleat at wrong answers. Classics like charades and the dictionary game — sometimes called Fictionary, and tweaked for the unimaginative under the brand name Balderdash — call at most for paper and pencils. They’re D.I.Y. and lo-fi.

headline: Ever the Charmer, Brazen and Sly, but at a Faster Clip
text: NEWARK — R. Kelly isn’t a singer given to grand ideological gesture, but last year the release of his 10th album, “Love Letter,” appeared to be making a statement. For almost two decades he’s been the id of modern R&B, even as, for several years in the 2000s, he operated under the shadow of child pornography charges, of which he was acquitted in 2008.

headline: A New Shirt Closes a Gap in Modesty
text: THE first lady’s oft-bared arms aside, dress codes for women in Washington’s bread-and-butter jobs (law, Congress, lobbying) have remained steadfastly more prim than in other cities. Remember the Hillary Rodham Clinton cleavage scandal of 2007, when Mrs. Clinton, a senator at the time, was criticized for showing a flash of décolletage on the Senate floor? The offending hint of bust was barely visible; she had merely worn a blouse that dipped lower than her clavicle. It didn’t happen again.

headline: No Pause in Pursuit of Justice (and Ratings)
text: Some people will never serve on a jury. But anyone watching HLN’s coverage of the trial of Casey Anthony, the young woman charged with killing her 2-year-old daughter, Caylee, has a visceral sense of what it’s like to be on duty in that courtroom in Orlando, Fla.

headline: Canceled Recess Upends Senators’ Plans
text: Senators will return to business next week instead of going on their planned recess, because Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, said they have to. But that doesn’t mean that everyone is happy about it.

headline: Battle For Libya | July 1, 2011
text: Youth rebels patrolled the streets of Keklah, Libya, after forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi carried out an offensive on the town.

headline: Official From F.D.I.C. Picked To Lead Banking Regulator
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced Friday that he would nominate Thomas J. Curry to lead the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which oversees hundreds of national banks, including the giants Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo.

headline: Battle for Libya | July 2011
text: The latest images after Western intervention in Libya.

headline: Laura Hwang and Steve Rosenbush
text: IT was the duck rillettes that led Steve Rosenbush to Laura Hwang.

headline: The Day the Music Was Carted Away
text: A suspect has been nabbed in the case of the great Bronx Piano Kidnapping. It’s the parks department, which pleads guilty, with an explanation.

headline: A Tribute to Jeter, in Song
text: With six more hits, Derek Jeter will become the first player to reach 3,000 hits as a Yankee.Meanwhile, Fran Kowalski is hoping to get a hit soon, too. And it all has to do with Jeter. Kowalski, a singer, songwriter and producer, has released “Derek Jeter’s 3,000 Hits,” an ode to the shortstop’s career and his milestone.

headline: On the Street | The Ponies
text: The golden age of polo in the 1920s and ’30s was recalled last month on Governors Island. The 14,000 spectators carried on the tradition of dressing up.

headline: Katherine & Eric
text: In this homemade video, Katherine Macpherson and Eric Bishop discuss how they didn't let their school rivalry come between their relationship.

headline: Katherine Macpherson, Eric Bishop
text: Katherine Esther Macpherson and Eric Nathan Bishop are to be married Sunday evening by the Rev. Dr. Val Fowler at the First Presbyterian Church of Honeoye Falls in Honeoye Falls, N.Y.

headline: A Response to Mara Hvistendahl (II)
text: In her reply to my column, the author of “Unnatural Selection” also disputes my suggestion that her book’s tone of moral outrage depends on an (implicit) sympathy for aborted female fetuses as well as a concern for the societal impact of sex-selective abortion. “I make very clear in my book that the victim is women,” Hvistendahl writes — “women who in the 1960s and 1970s were used as pawns in a Western drive to reduce birth rates in Asia, women who later aborted female fetuses against the backdrop of patriarchy, and women who, now that they are scarce, find themselves at greater risk of being trafficked, kidnapped, or sold by their parents to men desperate to find wives. Sex-selective abortion is wrong because women should account for half of the human population, and in parts of the world they now account for far less. That alone justifies moral outrage.”

headline: Emily & Hui
text: In this homemade video, Emily Schlesinger and Hui Li discuss how opposites attract.

headline: Megan & Daniel
text: In this homemade video, Megan Sofen and Daniel Opel recall meeting during a summer in Wisconsin. Daniel was home from Cornell and Megan was about to embark on her freshman year at Cornell.

headline: Patricia & Sarah
text: In this homemade video, 5'9 Patricia Hewitt recalls always being tall until she met 5'10 Sarah Siegel.

headline: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
text: Strauss-Kahn dominated the Twitter feeds of New Yorkers on Friday, a day after the news broke that the rape case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn appeared to be on the brink of falling apart. Every development in the case was tweeted and retweeted — Mr. Strauss-Kahn (known as #DSK on Twitter) was in the courtroom, he had been released on his own recognizance, the district attorney was about to speak.

text: In this homemade video, Anne Zimmerman and Sean Finney recall meeting at an epiphany party and finding love when they weren't looking for it.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Madoff’s Sentence
text: To the Editor:

headline: Friday at the Women’s World Cup
text: Japan continued to impress, bringing Mexico back to earth with a 4-0 victory. Japan is through to the quarterfinals and so, almost certainly, is England, which came back to beat New Zealand, 2-1, behind a goal and an assist by Jill Scott.

headline: Ministering to Soldiers, and Facing Their Struggles
text: FORT JACKSON, S.C. — Growing up on a farm in Ohio, the son of an Army medic in World War II, David Bowlus often sneaked into the attic to try on his father’s uniform as if it were a destiny. At 16, on a family trip to West Point, he watched the cadets drill and knew what he wanted for the future.

headline: Banning Gun Imports
text: To the Editor:

headline: Court Won’t Intervene in Fate of Nuclear Dump
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court on Friday declined to step into a dispute over the Obama administration’s cancellation of a planned nuclear waste dump in the Nevada desert, saying the matter must be left for now to federal regulators.

headline: Richard H. Poff, Who Withdrew Court Bid, Dies at 87
text: Richard H. Poff, a former Republican congressman from Virginia who surprised official Washington in 1971 by withdrawing from consideration for a seat on the Supreme Court rather than submit to the harsh scrutiny he feared his anti-civil-rights voting record would arouse, died Tuesday in Tullahoma, Tenn. He was 87.

headline: Treasury’s Acting Restructuring Head Takes His Leave
text: Now that Thomas Casarella is leaving the Treasury Department as its acting restructuring chief, he intends to catch up on some light reading. Only it doesn’t involve picking up the latest James Patterson novel.

headline: U.S. Soccer Releases Open Letter to Fans
text: U.S. Soccer President Sunil Gulati released an open letter to fans on Friday, though in it he did not address the topic most of them are talking about.

headline: Giving Credit to Wal-Mart
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Last Hurrah for Sugar Snap Peas
text: Last call for sugar snap peas.

headline: Many Smartphone Customers Are Still Up for Grabs
text: About 10 years ago I met an advertising executive in New York who explained the difficulty of advertising a new brand of deodorant to consumers. “Most people never change their deodorant,” I remember him saying. “They pick one brand when they are young, and stick with it for a long, long time. If it works, why switch?”

headline: Shriver Files for Divorce From Schwarzenegger
text: LOS ANGELES — Maria Shriver has filed for divorce from former Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California, citing irreconcilable differences as she seeks to end a 25-year marriage that had long captured the public’s attention.

headline: Slavery in the Modern Age
text: Anyone who thinks slavery ended with the 13th Amendment is not paying attention. According to the latest State Department statistics, as many as 100,000 people in the United States are in bondage and perhaps 27 million people worldwide. The numbers are staggering.

headline: Google Executives Throw Themselves Into the Google+ Fray
text: It may be too soon to say whether Google+, the search company’s answer to Facebook, will avoid the same disastrous fate as some of its earlier social networking products like Buzz and Wave, but there’s no shortage of action on the site among those who have early access.

headline: Bayer Settles With Farmers Over Modified Rice Seeds
text: A Bayer AG unit will pay $750 million to settle claims with about 11,000 United States farmers who said a strain of the company’s genetically modified rice tainted crops and ruined their export value.

headline: Qaddafi Threatens Europe With Attacks
text: BIR AYAD, Libya — In a defiant speech broadcast to an unusually large gathering of his supporters on Friday, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi threatened attacks on Europe if NATO did not halt its bombing campaign, even as he also seemed to leave open a door to negotiations.

headline: Players Are Locked Out From N.B.A.’s Web Site, Too
text: When the clock struck 12:01 a.m. Friday in New York, Arn Tellem was in his backyard in Los Angeles, hosting a cookout. This is not how an N.B.A. agent typically celebrates the arrival of July.

headline: In Ohio, a New Governor Is Off to a Smooth Start
text: In Washington, Congress may still be fighting over the national budget, but in Ohio, where Republicans control the House, the Senate and the governor’s office, the budget passage has been about as smooth as a knife through butter.

headline: Accuser’s Fellow Guineans Express Bewilderment
text: Hundreds of Guinean men in bright robes and skullcaps knelt on the floor of a Bronx mosque on Friday as their imam boomed out a sermon that seemed tailored for a difficult day.

headline: His Aggressiveness Unabated, Christie Keeps His Momentum
text: Democrats said this year would be different, that they would push back harder against Gov. Chris Christie. Mr. Christie also signaled a shift, expressing a desire to be less combative.

headline: Dead in the Water?
text: Like they don’t already have enough problems.

headline: BP’s Ex-Chief and Plaintiffs’ Lawyers Spar Over Safety
text: In testimony before Congress last summer, Tony Hayward, then BP’s chief executive, asserted that his company was conducting a “full and comprehensive” investigation into the causes of the Deepwater Horizon disaster that killed 11 rig workers and spewed millions of gallons of oil into the Gulf of Mexico. He said BP had put in place a sweeping new safety system throughout the company in the wake of lapses in 2006 and 2007.

headline: Murray Lifts Game, but Not Enough
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Never mind Rafael Nadal’s sore ankle or Andy Murray’s tender hip. Everything you needed to know about the health of men’s tennis was revealed in Murray’s news conference after his 5-7, 6-2, 6-2, 6-4 semifinal loss to Nadal on Friday.

headline: Change (but Not Too Much) at the Top of the Pentagon
text: WASHINGTON — The lush Pentagon parade ground was the same, the sun-drenched view of the Potomac was the same, even the senior military assistant was the same. “Welcome aboard, sir,” Lt. Gen. John F. Kelly said in a Friday morning salute to his new boss, Leon E. Panetta, after sending off his old one, Robert M. Gates, from the same spot less than 24 hours before.

headline: As Net Stocks Sizzle, Zynga Aims High for Its I.P.O.
text: 9 p.m. | Updated

headline: An Era When the City Roared
text: “NEW YORK is now, as it has been since the 1850s, a global city, the archetype city of everyone’s future,” the novelist E. L. Doctorow wrote a decade ago. It’s arguable, though, exactly if, and when, the city also became capital of the world and whether it still is. Nonetheless, David Wallace makes a compelling and appealing case in “Capital of the World: A Portrait of New York City in the Roaring Twenties” (Lyons Press, $24.95).

headline: FIFA Addresses a Coach’s Remarks
text: Soccer’s world governing body said it had spoken with Eucharia Uche, the coach of the Nigerian women’s national team, about homophobic remarks she made to The New York Times regarding lesbian players on her team.

headline: Seven Days and 120 Miles to Go
text: Catskill, N.Y.

headline: Hemingway, Hounded by the Feds
text: EARLY one morning, 50 years ago today, while his wife, Mary, slept upstairs, Ernest Hemingway went into the vestibule of his Ketchum, Idaho, house, selected his favorite shotgun from the rack, inserted shells into its chambers and ended his life.

headline: Spurned by Lady Liberty, Macy’s Fireworks Show Stays Put
text: For this year’s Fourth of July celebration, Macy’s had hoped to turn its massive fireworks show into a birthday party for the Statue of Liberty, which was dedicated in New York harbor 125 years ago. The show’s planners wanted to surround the statue with barges loaded with shells, fire some others off from the base of the statue and even have Beyoncé perform on a stage there.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,634 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:

headline: Pay Workers Fairly and Save Money
text: DESPITE persistent unemployment and stagnant wages, few believe that our cash-strapped government is likely to simply create better-paying jobs. But there is a way for this country to get more from the millions of jobs we already finance with federal dollars, while reducing the cost of entitlement programs.

headline: What Gov. Cuomo Left Undone
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo showed that it was possible to get New York’s chronically inert Legislature to approve several of his top priorities this year. He made history, getting the new law allowing same-sex marriage passed. He started the clean-up of Albany’s tainted government with an ethics bill that requires more transparency. And he prevailed in getting a more rational tuition plan to help the state’s public universities.

headline: The Pentagon After Mr. Gates
text: Robert Gates was already a 40-year veteran of the national security establishment when President George W. Bush summoned him to assume command of a demoralized and embattled Pentagon in late 2006. He inherited incoherent spending priorities, a broken procurement process and two disastrously mismanaged wars.

headline: For Washington, a Trek to Daylight
text: WASHINGTON — Late for work, Cassandra Jackson hurried through the Washington subway the other week only to confront a broken escalator that was supposed to carry her to the street. Exactly 351 steps later she made it to the top.

headline: To Determine Queen, Power Will Be King
text: WIMBLEDON, England — In a match featuring two of the most powerful players in women’s tennis, Maria Sharapova faces Petra Kvitova in the Wimbledon singles final on Saturday. For Sharapova, the match is her first Grand Slam final since winning the Australian Open in 2008. Kvitova reached the semifinals here a year ago, and has steadily improved since, but is making her first appearance in a major final.

headline: As Nationalism Surges in Europe, Poland Begins Bloc Presidency
text: Once counted among the least enthusiastic members of the European Union, Poland took over its rotating presidency on Friday with an outspoken attack on the leaders of the bloc’s large countries for pursuing national interests instead of regional concerns.

headline: The War Comes to Galveston
text: Commander James Alden was by all accounts a resourceful and clever naval officer, talents he put to use in June 1861 as he and his ship helped establish the sprawling Union blockade against Confederate ports. Aboard his now-oddly named steamer, the South Carolina, he dropped munitions to federal troops at Fort Pickens, near Pensacola, Fla., then sailed west to join the Gulf Blockading Squadron off Louisiana. On July 2 the ship suddenly appeared off Galveston, one of the busiest ports in the South and a boom town riding a wave of cotton exports to Europe. Riding the low Gulf breakers, the South Carolina, brought to Texas President Lincoln’s Anaconda strategy: strangling the South by sea.

headline: The Voices Emerging From College Studios
text: LAST November, the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art assembled a team of 18 gallery owners, curators, collectors and artists for the purpose of making studio visits — not to already-established artists, but to art students in master of fine arts programs across the United States. The results of their travels to nearly 2,000 studios at more than 30 colleges and universities — and of a subsequent selection process that winnowed candidates they would spotlight to 12 — can be seen in “First Look III,” now on view at the museum.

headline: A Button-Down Man Sets Out, Trailed by Silliness
text: The story of a stuffy late-19th-century Englishman betting members of his equally stuffy gentleman’s club that he can circumnavigate the globe in 80 days has a certain amount of wackiness built in. Or it did, at least, by the time the Jules Verne novel that tells the tale was adapted into Mike Todd’s all-star 1956 Hollywood movie.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Bloggingheads: Will Race Save Obama?
text: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Matthew Cooper of National Journal discuss race and Obama's reelection hopes.

headline: A ‘Factory’ Worker Glances Back
text: BEING closely associated with Andy Warhol and his Factory during the 1960s has been perhaps both a blessing and a curse for Ultra Violet, the artist and writer who starred in many of his films. Without Warhol, she would quite likely be unknown today, but her history also gets in her way.

headline: How to Succeed in a Pink Power Suit
text: “Legally Blonde: The Musical,” the lightweight confection now playing at the Gateway Playhouse in Bellport, overflows with fluffiness, which is just what is called for in the book by Heather Hach and the music and lyrics by Laurence O’Keefe and Nell Benjamin.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: One Fine Day
text: Last week, there was a day I hesitate to call perfect only because I would hate it if the perfect day had already come and gone in my life. But when that perfect day comes at last it will probably resemble the one last week. The western breeze had cleaned the sun and purified the light, which fell moteless on the farm.

headline: A Drummer Goes Beyond a Legacy
text: AL FOSTER, a mild-mannered man with a perpetual smile, burst on the scene as the improbably fierce drummer with the Miles Davis band of the early 1970s. The job made his name; it even earned him a $200-a-week retainer, a benefit rare in the world of freelance musicians. But the band, heavy on rock vamps and light on harmonic progressions, was not really his style — and he let Davis know it.

headline: Mamet’s Tale of Blacks and Whites Told in Grays
text: David Mamet must be wishing he’d made the hotel chambermaid the accuser instead of just a witness in the rape case that dominates his 2009 Broadway play, “Race.” Then whatever else today’s audiences might make of it, they’d have to salute his uncanny prescience.

headline: When States Shut Down for Business
text: A look at state shutdowns over the last decade.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Performers With Talent Beyond Their Years
text: THE 29 actors in this year’s installment of the New Jersey Youth Theater’s summer musical program are “a goofy bunch,” according to Cynthia Meryl, the organization’s co-founder and artistic director. “They’re really silly,” she added. But there is a reason for that.

headline: A ‘Dream’ Perfectly Suited for the Outdoors
text: Do you recall the first Shakespeare play you ever saw? Mine was “King Lear,” which was mighty grim for a 9-year-old. I remember thinking, even as Morris Carnovsky’s Lear raged away upon the heath, “Boy, these storm scenes are awfully long.”

headline: Kansas: Judge Blocks Abortion Rules
text: A federal judge issued a preliminary injunction on Friday preventing new regulations from taking effect that would have forced the closing of two of the state’s three abortion clinics. The clinics have been unable to meet requirements of the regulations, which were issued this month and were supposed to take effect on Friday. A third clinic, operated by Planned Parenthood, was granted a license this week. In an hourlong hearing in District Court in Kansas City, lawyers for the state argued the regulations represented an appropriate way to protect the safety of patients, while lawyers for the clinics called them unnecessarily onerous. The judge, Carlos Murgia, noted that one provider had turned down two women seeking abortions because of fetal abnormalities as evidence that there would be irreparable harm if the regulations were allowed to go into effect pending the outcome of the case.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Florida: Rail Project Will Move Forward
text: Gov. Rick Scott on Friday lifted his freeze on the start of construction for a commuter rail system in central Florida. The 61-mile, $1.2 billion project has been strongly backed by the business community and Representative John L. Mica, a Republican who is chairman of the House Transportation Committee, but opposed by Tea Party activists and other critics. Mr. Scott had expressed concern because local governments would be asked to cover any revenue shortfalls after seven years of operation. But he said he felt that he had no choice but to approve the deal, as supporters had threatened to sue the state because the Legislature had authorized the spending.

headline: House Ethics Panel Confirms Two Investigations
text: The House Ethics Committee confirmed Friday that it is investigating two lawmakers, Representatives Gregory W. Meeks, Democrat of New York, and Jean Schmidt, Republican of Ohio. The committee said it needed more time for its inquiries, but said that fact does not “itself indicate that any violation has occurred.” Mr. Meeks is under investigation because of a $40,000 loan he received in 2007 and initially did not disclose from a Queens real estate broker who had been repeatedly investigated for fraud and predatory lending. Ms. Schmidt is being investigated on accusations she accepted free legal services from a Turkish-American group. Joe Jansen, an aide to Ms. Schmidt, said she intends to pay back the Turkish-American group, but has not done so at the request of the ethics investigators. The committee said it would decide how to proceed by Aug. 16.

headline: A Fight Over Keeping Boards in the Boardwalk
text: The Coney Island Boardwalk, opened in 1923, has inspired songs (The Drifters’ “Under the Boardwalk”), plays (Herb Gardner’s “The Goodbye People”) and fiction (Delmore Schwartz’s “In Dreams Begin Responsibilities”). Now, it is inspiring a question of Talmudic complexity: Can a boardwalk be called a boardwalk if it is not made of boards?

headline: Sweet, Moist and Gluten-Free
text: When she was an undergraduate, Karen Miller took a cake-decorating class with a friend. She liked it and was good at it, but there was one problem: she couldn’t eat anything she made.

headline: Prepare to Be Part of the Chef’s Family
text: AS you enter Rosa’s La Scarbitta Ristorante, a new Italian restaurant in Mamaroneck, you will see a message painted on the wall: “Come in as a stranger, leave as a member of the family.” It would be easy to dismiss it as so much marketing nonsense, but by the time you’ve met Rosa Merenda, the chef and co-owner (and you will), chatted with her husband and partner, Angelo, and eaten their food, you will indeed feel that you’ve just had a sweet familial experience.

headline: Season of the Grill, and Rosés
text: Like summer flowers, colorful dry rosés — pink, coral, salmon, near-red, almost orange — abound at East End wineries.

headline: Saturday: Don’t Believe It For a Second
text: Administrivial Notepad Alert: There will be a Notepad in tomorrow’s puzzle that says “When this puzzle is done, the circles will contain five different letters of the alphabet. Connect each set of circles containing the same letter, without crossing your line, to make a simple closed shape. The resulting five closed shapes together will form a picture of a 117-Across. The five letters can be arranged to name a good place to get a 117-Across.” DON’T PANIC. Pat Merrell provides a helpful graphic to get us through this.

headline: Hearing Set for Galea; Plea Deal Is Possible
text: A Canadian doctor indicted last year on charges he distributed performance-enhancing drugs to professional athletes in the United States is scheduled to appear in federal court in Buffalo next week for an arraignment and plea hearing, according to a court filing.

headline: Causing a Scene, and Breaking the Mold
text: A HOT new spot, the East Hampton Grill, which opened in May, is lighting up the summer on the East End. It’s a scene, but with good reason — the food is terrific.

headline: Mets’ Buchholz Is Dealing With Depression and Anxiety
text: Taylor Buchholz, the 29-year-old Mets middle reliever, has had depression and anxiety since before he was placed on the disabled list a month ago with what the team had previously described as right shoulder fatigue.

headline: Burgers, Dogs and History
text: At a different time of year, the whitewashed shack that is Harry’s Place might be mistaken for a farm stand or carnival booth. But not between St. Patrick’s Day and Halloween, when the wooden panels of its hatch windows are slung open and customers line up for the burgers and dogs that have made Harry’s a drive-in destination.

headline: Geography’s of No Matter in This Asian Bistro
text: IN a long, narrow space a few steps below street level on Greenwich Avenue — a space once occupied by the admirable but relatively short-lived Solaia — is a self-described modern Asian bistro. But that phrase barely begins to capture the amazing dishes at Kokoro, whose name means “from the heart,” said Simon Chik, a co-owner, “which is how I would describe the cooking of our chef, Anan Tiwadom.”

headline: Reads and Reactions
text: In this edition: one pundit’s serious candidate is another pundit’s long-shot flake.

headline: Billy Costello, Who Won Light Welterweight Crown, Dies at 55
text: Billy Costello, who overcame a troubled youth to become an undefeated light welterweight champion in the mid-1980s despite not putting on boxing gloves until he was 19, died Wednesday in Kingston, N.Y. He was 55.

headline: Yankees’ Robertson Making an All-Star Case
text: The way Dave Robertson remembers it, no more than 150 people lined Broad Street in Rome, Ga., the night before the 2007 South Atlantic League All-Star Game. Sitting in the back of one of the vintage convertibles that ferried athletes along the parade route, Robertson waved to his parents. Then he felt a thud. He lurched forward. His car had collided with the car in front.

headline: Ingenious Gelato
text: Tom Parisi offers 18 flavors of gelato daily at his tidy, 800-square-foot shop, Tommy 2 Scoops, in Jersey City. But he does not take credit for the ingenuity of those flavors, which include ricotta honey and parmesan olive oil and are made on the premises ($3.50 a scoop).

headline: Greek Specialties and a Beach Scene
text: TAKE a sweater and a good appetite for home-style Greek food to Niko’s Trapezi Greek Taverna; given the air-conditioning and the gargantuan portions, you will need both. This place, a narrow storefront in an L-shaped strip mall near the beach, is the work of two owners, who opened it in April 2009: Niko Katsilianos, the chef, and his brother-in-law, Jay Keating. Mr. Keating and his wife, Georgia, work the front of the house and handle the office chores and the marketing.

headline: Place Seemed Great, Till the Robbers Swarmed In
text: Two weeks later, still out thousands of dollars’ worth of musical equipment, a recording of five or six new songs, an apartment of their own and one tooth, the guys from the band called P.M.E.R. thought about whom to blame.

headline: A Welcome Mat? Not Always
text: No watercraft are likely to have more people on them this holiday weekend than the ones going to Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty, departing from Battery Park in Manhattan (crowded) and Liberty State Park in New Jersey (less crowded).

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quick Exit of Private School’s Leader Puzzles Parents
text: At the Brearley School’s graduation ceremony on June 10 — known simply as “Last Day” — Stephanie J. Hull urged the young women to take their academic achievements out into the world, in a speech that some called a highlight of her eight-year tenure as head of school.

headline: A Driving Spirit Is Conspicuous by His Absence
text: Brian Cashman has his holiday weekend all planned. While the Yankees and the Mets are playing yet another interleague series, Cashman plans to make two separate runs down to the Yankees’ Trenton farm team in central New Jersey.

headline: Something Had to Give and Mets Falter First
text: The Subway Series has gone through many permutations since its inception in 1997, with varying degrees of excitement, usually depending on whether the Mets were playing well enough to hold their own against the mighty Yankees.

headline: Alec Baldwin, the Sequel
text: It seems safe to say that few people know the following sensation: finding yourself, a few hours after the publication of your frank account of a rollicking evening with a quick-talking, sea-bass-deboning celebrity, suddenly sitting a few seats away from that very star.

headline: After Talking With Pittsburgh, Jagr Joins a Rival
text: After a baffling few days in which he was courted and then spurned by his former team, the Pittsburgh Penguins, Jaromir Jagr signed Friday with their archrival, the Philadelphia Flyers.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Accuser’s Call Alarmed Prosecutors
text: Twenty-eight hours after a housekeeper at the Sofitel New York said she was sexually assaulted by Dominique Strauss-Kahn, she spoke by phone to a boyfriend in an immigration jail in Arizona.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: July 1, 2011

headline: Basking in Russia’s Love Long After a Musical Triumph
text: MOSCOW

headline: Quiet, but Telling, Scenes in Pakistan
text: Muhammed Muheisen, 30, the chief photographer in Pakistan for The Associated Press, has been taking pictures for a decade. His work has been included in Pictures of the Day more than 80 times since the Lens blog began in 2009. But it wasn’t until last year that Mr. Muheisen felt as if he’d truly found his footing in photography, when he took to the streets in search of scenes of daily life.

headline: The Strange Poetry of Coney Island
text: For four decades, the photographer Harvey Stein has been chronicling the evolution of the seaside destination, in all its odd glory.

headline: Crime Scene in Bed-Stuy
text: Band members were attacked and robbed in their Bedford-Stuyvesant home.

headline: Conservative Cash Crop
text: The media jackals have been all over Representative Michele Bachmann for misstatements, zany ideas and alterations to history as she kicked off her presidential run in Waterloo, Iowa, home to serial killer John Wayne Gacy — not the actor John Wayne, as she said in her evocation of dreamy small-town life.

headline: Make Food Choices Simple: Cook
text: Is there enough food? How do we get it to people? What is its quality? These common questions all concern supply; people spend a lifetime addressing them, and if you closely examine any one, you’re ensnared in a complex web.

headline: U.S. Expands Its Drone War Into Somalia
text: WASHINGTON — The clandestine American military campaign to combat Al Qaeda’s franchise in Yemen is expanding to fight the Islamist militancy in Somalia, as new evidence indicates that insurgents in the two countries are forging closer ties and possibly plotting attacks against the United States, American officials say.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Tami Taylor’s Dream Job
text: We are covering the final season of “Friday Night Lights” according to the NBC schedule. We ask readers who have already seen the season on DirecTV or on DVD to please refrain from giving away future plot points in the comments section. For analysis of previous episodes, click here.

headline: Agüero’s Volley Saves Argentina in Copa América Opener
text: One gets the feeling sometimes that Argentina could start five strikers and still manage to struggle to win big games. (Tip No. 1: stop putting the ball into your own net.)

headline: Victory for Nova, but Spot Is Not Sure
text: Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said in the interview room Friday afternoon that starting pitcher Ivan Nova did not have anything to prove Friday night against the Mets. Shortly after, General Manager Brian Cashman said something similar, telling reporters that “Nova’s not pitching for anything tonight.”

headline: Love and Inheritance: A Family Feud
text: IF you could script your life, how would it play out? Make movies, win an Academy Award, own an enormous apartment on Central Park West and then, in your declining years, marry someone half your age?

headline: Obama Again Assails Tax Breaks
text: 7:32 a.m. | Updated  President Obama on Saturday repeated his challenge to Republicans to accept higher taxes on wealthy people and corporate interests, as part of a plan to reduce the budget deficit.

headline: The Weekend Word: Insurgents
text: Today’s Times

headline: Woman Stricken With E. Coli Dies in France
text: PARIS — A 78-year-old French woman died Saturday in Bordeaux from complications related to E. coli, a spokeswoman for a regional health authority said. Officials said there were no apparent links to the devastating E. coli outbreak in Germany that has killed dozens of people and sickened thousands more, despite that strain being implicated in another case in Bordeaux.

headline: Classic Ad: Pontiac Aztek
text: In this Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich welcomes the Nissan Murano CrossCabriolet into the Pantheon of Ugly Cars. Somewhere in that temple of misfits there is a Pontiac Aztek waiting to greet it.

headline: Kvitova Upsets Sharapova to Win Wimbledon Women’s Title
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The newcomer played as if she belonged, and by the time this one-sided women’s final ended, Maria Sharapova was not the only Wimbledon champion on the grass of Centre Court.

headline: A Roundup of the Week’s Racing News
text: As we prepare for Formula One’s home race next week at Silverstone — I think it can be called a “home race” because most of the teams are based in Britain — there has been a lot of news to digest. Here are some of the highlights.

headline: A Roundup of the Week’s Racing News
text: As we prepare for Formula One’s home race next week at Silverstone — I think it can be called a “home race” because most of the teams are based in Britain — there has been a lot of news to digest. Here are some of the highlights.

headline: Chasing a Name Lost to Time
text: Benjamin P. Feldman, a retired real estate investor with the time and the money to chase his enthusiasms, was rummaging through a bin at a flea market in Chelsea last winter when he came across a weathered leather change purse with words engraved in gilt: “Compliments of Sol Goldberg’s Cafe, 71 Canal Street, Tel. 2111 Orchard.”

headline: Interest Rates: A Dowist Perspective
text: One of my principles of 21st-century public discourse is that nobody ever admits that they were wrong about anything. And so it is with the totally obvious failure of the prediction that interest rates would soar once the Fed stopped adding to its bond holdings. These predictions were made by many people early this year; here’s what actually happened:

headline: Syrian President Fires Governor in Charge of a Restive City
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria fired the governor responsible for the city of Hama on Saturday, a day after tens of thousands of protesters filled its streets in the largest demonstration since the uprising began in March.

headline: Cash Is Not the Problem
text: A couple of followups to my repatriation post.

headline: The Jigsaw Puzzle of Picking All-Stars
text: Until a few years ago, the manager of the All-Star team chose all of the pitchers and reserves for his league. The responsibilities are different now, and as much as the managers might prepare, they make only 16 selections: seven by the American League manager, nine by the National League manager.

headline: Restoring Gun Rights
text: States that have passed laws to restore gun rights.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Stolen Code Is Linked to Program for Chess
text: Players who use computers to cheat are a growing concern in the chess world. Now the developer of Rybka, the winner of the last four World Computer Chess Championships, has been accused of plagiarizing code to create the program.

headline: A Lesson in Fleeting Fame From the Old Neighborhood
text: Lorenzo Charles, not to put it unkindly, was known for exactly one basketball play. With the score tied and a few seconds left in the 1983 N.C.A.A. championship game against heavily favored Houston, his North Carolina State teammate Dereck Whittenburg heaved a prayer at the rim. Charles recognized the arc of a 30-foot air ball.

headline: A Driver Who Can’t Afford Many Chances to Turn His Luck Around
text: Steve Park planned to drive in a Nascar Sprint Cup race Saturday night at Daytona International Speedway, but plans in auto racing usually call for cash, and lots of it. Park could not raise enough money, so he sat out, no matter how much he wanted to drive.

headline: 30 Seconds With Amar’e Stoudemire
text: Amar’e Stoudemire signed with the Knicks as a free agent last summer after eight seasons with the Phoenix Suns. He led the Knicks to their first winning record (42-40) in 10 years and their first playoff berth in seven. Stoudemire, 29, was limited by a pulled muscle in his back during the first-round series against Boston, and the Knicks were swept. He was in Manhattan for a promotion before the N.B.A. imposed a lockout last week.

headline: For N.B.A. Owners, 1999 Labor Deal Was Win With Regrets
text: Labor disputes in the N.B.A. have a way of producing strange and unintended consequences: $30 million contracts for backup centers, trades of retired players and David Stern’s infamous beard, to name a few.

headline: Variety: An Outdoorsy Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — I like to enjoy a good meal outdoors, and I wish my kids felt the same way. They definitely fall into the “indoors eating” category, even at restaurants with outdoor cafes.

headline: Protests Spur Shuffle of Jordan Cabinet
text: JERUSALEM — With antigovernment demonstrations growing across Jordan in recent weeks, King Abdullah II approved a cabinet shuffle on Saturday that brought in a number of new officials, notably the interior minister, but the public’s anger over accusations of corruption seemed unlikely to subside.

headline: TimesCast | French Politics
text: July 2, 2011 - In Paris, the central political issue is whether the case in New York has damaged Dominique Strauss-Kahn enough to prevent him from persuing his political career in France.

headline: For One Minor League Baseball Team, Never an Empty Seat
text: DAYTON, Ohio — The assembly line lives. Back when this region thrived on heavy industry, a Delco plant bustled on the edge of downtown. Nowadays, on the site where automobile parts once rolled off the belt, Dayton produces sold-out baseball games.

text: From today’s radio address:

headline: Russian Woman Presses Inquiry Into Son’s Death
text: MOSCOW — The mother of Sergei L. Magnitsky, whose death in state custody has become a test of Russia’s ability to investigate its own officials, is demanding access to tissue samples taken from his body so that she can send them for an independent forensic analysis.

headline: A Timely Reminder of the Mets’ Conundrum
text: Jose Reyes may be the “world’s greatest player,” as Alex Rodriguez has anointed him, but the Mets would be smart to explore practical avenues of trading him before risking losing him.

headline: John Coltrane’s House in Ruins
text: While the saxophonist’s music will live on, the house where he composed “A Love Supreme” may not.

headline: Petra Kvitova Wins Wimbledon
text: Petra Kvitova won her first Grand Slam title Saturday by beating Maria Sharapova 6-3, 6-4 in the Wimbledon final.

headline: A Departing Governor Looks Ahead to a Bigger Prize in Mexico
text: TLALNEPANTLA, Mexico — The most important candidate in Sunday’s election for governor here is the one who is not on the ballot.

headline: Crowning of Champion Is Changing of the Guard
text: WIMBLEDON, England — A statuesque blonde with sizzling ground strokes advances to her first Grand Slam final at Wimbledon and stares down a more seasoned foe known for her grit and grunts to usher in a new era in women’s tennis.

headline: Closing a State? The Rules Are Tricky
text: ST. PAUL — With no sign of a budget deal in sight, Minnesota awoke on Saturday to Day 2 of a state government shutdown, and, if anything, more confusion — not moreclarity — about how one actually carries out this sort of thing.

headline: The Swindler and the Home Loans
text: HOLDING banks accountable for all those disastrous mortgages has been remarkably difficult. But last week, a big bank agreed to pay a price: Bank of America announced that it would part with $8.5 billion to settle claims that its Countrywide Financial unit had packaged garbage loans into investments that were said to be safe.

headline: One More Mountain for Ascendant Djokovic
text: WIMBLEDON, England

text: This interview with Kathy Button Bell, vice president and chief marketing officer of Emerson, the manufacturing and technology company in St. Louis, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Tennis Pressure Strains Bond of Parent and Player
text: WIMBLEDON, England — One might reasonably suspect that the man sprinting down the deserted street in the upscale Southern California neighborhood in the dead of night was up to no good. In fact, Wayne Bryan’s only crime last week was wanting so badly for his sons to succeed that he went running because he could not sleep.

headline: Beyond the Breathalyzer: Seeking Telltale Signs of Disease
text: PEOPLE who are worried about bad breath often reach for a toothbrush, a Tic Tac or an Altoid.

headline: Have an Enjoyable Fourth
text: Wheels will be taking a short break in observance of Independence Day, but we’ll return on Tuesday with our regular coverage. Whatever mode of transport conveys you to your destination, the editors and contributors at Wheels wish you safe and happy travels this holiday weekend.

headline: Club Is Willing to Stretch Out to Get a Major
text: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa. — By being the interim host club of the AT&T National for the past two years, Aronimink Golf Club has done the golf equivalent of winning a beauty pageant — showing the judges it has just about all the necessary assets to win the prize. But, seeking a date on the major championship rotation, Aronimink’s new president, Joe Brooks, said the club might display a little something extra the judges had not yet seen.

headline: Where Big-Wave Surfing and Yachting Converge
text: NEWPORT, R.I. — The yacht designer Juan Kouyoumdjian is understandably excited about his latest creation, Mar Mostro, a 70-foot carbon fiber racing sailboat he hopes will win the Volvo Ocean Race for a third consecutive time in the fall.

headline: A Major Success Story
text: Barring a rainout, the minor league baseball team the Dayton Dragons will have its 815th consecutive sellout on Saturday, a national record.

headline: Rap Video Satirizes Syrian Crackdown
text: Updated | Wednesday | 4:39 p.m. A group called the Strong Heroes Of Moscow released a rap video last week that satirizes the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, and the arguments used to justify the crackdown on his country’s uprising. Al Jazeera has published a complete English translation of the Arabic lyrics, which say that “freedom” is a “conspiracy coming from Mars.”
