headline: The Moral Behind All the Numbers
text: AS sophisticated and mathematical as economics has become, it is ultimately a cultural phenomenon and cannot be free of ethics. So argues the Czech economist Tomas Sedlacek, who aims to humanize this most public and powerful of the social sciences.

headline: Deborah Lehman, Paul Di Capua
text: Deborah Kathryn Lehman and Dr. Paul Daniel Di Capua are to be married Sunday. Rabbi Iosef Benchimol is to officiate at the Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Robyn Goldman, Tobin Fisher
text: Robyn Sue Goldman, the daughter of Jill S. Goldman and Dr. Lee Goldman of New York, is to be married Sunday to Tobin Joseph Fisher, the son of Gerry A. Fisher and Marshall L. Fisher of Penn Valley, Pa. Jeff Goldman, a brother of the bride, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, is to officiate at Holman Ranch in Carmel Valley, Calif.

headline: Katherine Racicot, Michael Ellis
text: Dr. Katherine Helen Racicot and Michael Jay Ellis are to be married Sunday afternoon at Gilford Community Church in Gilford, N.H. The Rev. Michael C. Graham, the church’s pastor and a minister of the American Baptist Churches U.S.A., is to lead the ceremony, which is to incorporate Christian and Jewish traditions.

headline: Karla Robertson, Stewart Dorsey
text: Karla Mei Robertson, the daughter of SawTeen See and Leslie E. Robertson of New York, is to be married Sunday to Stewart Hutton Dorsey, the son of Hilary Hutton Dorsey and Steven L. Dorsey of San Marino, Calif. The Rev. Catharine Grier Carlson, a Presbyterian minister, is to officiate at the Solage Calistoga Resort in Calistoga, Calif.

headline: Emily Steinberg, Zachary Fadem
text: Dr. Emily Nurit Steinberg and Zachary Robert Fadem are to be married Sunday evening by Cantor Perry Fine at Capitale, an event space in New York.

headline: Lindsay Ross, Garrett Ricciardi
text: Lindsay Susanna Ross, a daughter of Margaret Ross and David A. Ross of Beacon, N.Y., was married Friday to Garrett Rocco Ricciardi, the son of Mary Frances Ricciardi and Rocco Ricciardi of Randolph, N.J., at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, the bureau’s floor manager, officiated.

headline: Marshall Cheek and Michael Grimstad
text: Marshall Wesley Cheek and Michael Robert Grimstad were married Thursday at Waveny Park in New Canaan, Conn. Matthew F. A. Loter, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated. On Saturday, the couple had a spiritual ceremony before friends and family led by the Rev. Dr. Sheila Gay Gross, an interfaith minister, at Ramscale Studios in New York.

headline: The Markets and Greece: Variations on a Theme
text: HOW worried are investors about Greece’s financial mess? Could it take a huge toll on Europe and upend the global recovery? A standard way to answer such questions is to turn to the financial markets, which are often thought to reflect and foreshadow the underlying health of the economy.

headline: To Foster Diversity, Paint the Big Picture
text: Q. You are a member of a minority group and want to become involved in creating a more inclusive and tolerant environment at your company. You would also like those efforts to benefit you professionally. How should you start?

headline: Minding the Mattresses
text: I  GREW up in a row house in South Philadelphia and moved to Cherry Hill, N.J., when I was 15. I played football in high school, but I got tired of getting hurt, so I joined a rock group instead. I played guitar. We appeared at high school functions and local clubs.

headline: Rebecca Krauss, Benjamin Taibleson
text: Rebecca Liane Krauss and Benjamin Philip Taibleson are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Lyle A. Fishman at Silverbrook Farm in Purcellville, Va.

headline: How Games Steer Us Through Life
text: ONE recent Saturday my family had a small emergency, one that required the hasty packing of snacks and swimsuits, many Amtrak schedules and advanced logistics concerning car seats. Through it all there was a flurry of texts on BlackBerries and iPhones. It was the kind of weekend that makes me appreciate a nice tedious Monday morning meeting.

headline: Hardcover Business Best Sellers
Paperback Business Best Sellers
This Summer, the Guilt Is Gratis
text: Do you have a minute for gay rights? How about Planned Parenthood? The A.S.P.C.A.? Greenpeace? Save the clock tower?

headline: Robert H. Widmer, Designer of Military Aircraft, Dies at 95
text: The day the legendary test pilot Chuck Yeager shattered the sound barrier in 1947, Robert H. Widmer marched into his boss’s office at the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation in Fort Worth to say he wanted to design the world’s first supersonic bomber. He was told to stick to the contracts the company was already fulfilling.

headline: Frenchwomen Weigh Impact and Fallout of Strauss-Kahn Case
text: PARIS — Anne Mansouret, the mother of a young woman who has accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn of trying to rape her in 2003, said Saturday that she was “revolted” by the gleeful reaction of many men in France to the news that the case against him in New York had been compromised by credibility questions surrounding his accuser, a hotel housekeeper.

headline: Europe Agrees to Give Billions to Greece
text: BRUSSELS — European finance ministers staved off an imminent Greek default Saturday, agreeing to release a vital installment of financial aid to Athens, while delaying a deal on a second large rescue for Greece, possibly until September.

headline: Ruling Moves Madoff Case to New Court
text: A federal judge on Friday took control of the billion-dollar lawsuit against the owners of the Mets by the trustee for Bernard L. Madoff’s victims, ruling that he must decide certain critical legal issues before the case could proceed in bankruptcy court, if it could proceed at all.

headline: In Jordan Zimmermann, Nationals See Present and Future Success
text: Last August, the highly touted Nationals prospect, Jordan Zimmermann, made his dramatic return to the major leagues a little more than a year after having Tommy John surgery. Zimmermann, a former second round pick out of Division III University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point, joined a rotation headed by Stephen Strasburg, baseball’s most electric pitching prospect.

headline: President’s Health Adds to Uncertainty in Yemen
text: SANA, Yemen — A senior Yemeni official who was briefed on the health of President Ali Abdullah Saleh said that the president’s injuries would leave him unfit to perform his duties for months, throwing a new degree of uncertainty into a political standoff that has trapped this impoverished desert nation.

headline: The Amazing Centristman
text: A superhero who fights crime with compromise.

headline: Hail, Columbia!
text: As Union soldiers went off to war, the national figure most often urging them on in political cartoons and political stump speeches wasn’t Uncle Sam, but Columbia. Forgotten today even as her name adorns universities, rivers and cities across the country, Columbia was America’s response to Britannia, a secular goddess who personified the national spirit. Both Britannia and Columbia were patterned after other goddess figures: Britannia copied Minerva’s helmet, for example, and both symbols frequently identified themselves with the Goddess of Liberty by displaying or wearing the “liberty cap.”

headline: Net Lending By Domestic Business
text: A better picture to illustrate the point that cash is not the problem: here’s net lending by domestic business:

headline: South Carolina’s Young Governor Has a High Profile and Higher Hopes
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Nikki Haley, at 39 the nation’s youngest governor, loves her iPod.

headline: And the Bride Wore Armani
text: In recap after recap of the royal wedding today in Monaco, I noticed that when the television camera was on the groom, Prince Albert II, during the vows, you could see Bernard Arnault, the chairman of LVMH, in the background.

headline: Greece Jails U.S. Captain in Gaza Flotilla
text: ATHENS — The American captain of a United States-flagged boat in the planned flotilla to Gaza was jailed Saturday, a day after trying to sail out of port, flotilla organizers said.

headline: The City in My Mind
text: OFTEN I live in one place but write about another place very much unlike it. I wrote my first novel as a student in India, and I wrote my latest while commuting among Newcastle in England, Minneapolis and Cape Town, where I reside. As befits a writer who lives more in the mind than in my physical surroundings, I base my work on memory, which I enrich with my knowledge of Somalia — where my novels are set — and supplement with my imagination.

headline: The D.A. Stole His Life, Justices Took His Money
text: Lincoln Caplan dissects a powerful dissent by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg about prosecutorial misconduct.

headline: The D.A. Stole His Life, Justices Took His Money
text: In an important prosecutorial-misconduct case this term, the Supreme Court’s conservative majority threw out a $14 million jury award for a New Orleans man who was imprisoned for 18 years, including 14 on death row, for a robbery and a murder he did not commit. One month before John Thompson’s scheduled execution, a private investigator discovered that prosecutors had hidden evidence that exonerated him.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: The Old, the Young and Medicare
text: What’s in Medicare’s future? A letter on Wednesday calling for a sharp cut in benefits and a “sober dialogue” between the generations drew more than 100 responses. This is a sampling.

headline: Surrounded by Opinion, the Times Raises Its Voices
text: YOU’RE sitting in your office at The New York Times and there’s a din outside in the street. You crack the door to listen: mass bloviating on a worldwide scale! Opinion journalism in full bellow on television, the Internet and digital ports of call of every description!

headline: Bryans Tie Record for Major Doubles Championships
text: WIMBLEDON, England — History was never the carrot Bob and Mike Bryan were chasing. They weren’t fixated on records the way the golfer Tiger Woods is on Jack Nicklaus’s record of 18 major titles.

headline: Executive Pay, Revisited: Even Higher Than It First Seemed
text: Median pay for chief executives at 200 of the nation’s largest companies rose 23 percent last year.

headline: How the Pay Figures Were Calculated
text: Sunday Business asked Equilar, the executive compensation data company, to compile and analyze pay data from corporate filings. To be included in the revised study, a company must have been incorporated in the United States and must have filed a definitive proxy statement by June 23. The 200 highest-paid C.E.O.’s at companies with revenue of $10.78 billion or more were included.

headline: We Knew They Got Raises. But This?
text: IT turns out that the good times are even better than we thought for American chief executives.

headline: There You Go! Now Drive Safe, You Hear?
text: The drive-through daiquiri stand is a Louisiana institution, a celebration of the state’s sense of duty in matters of amusement as well as its sense of amusement in matters of law.

headline: Setting Sail on Gaza’s Sea of Spin
text: JERUSALEM

headline: Unfinished Business: ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: It has been six months since Congress voted to allow military service by openly gay, lesbian and bisexual Americans, but the law banning their service is still in effect. The Pentagon has not certified that the military is ready for the change, and while that process needlessly drags on, soldiers continue to be discharged for acknowledging their sexuality. The full repeal of this discriminatory policy should be one of the highest priorities for the new defense secretary, Leon Panetta.

headline: When a Predator Collides With a Fabricator
text: SO what’s the moral of this Manhattan immorality tale?

headline: Budget Needs Let Fireworks Fly Lawfully
text: The Fourth of July promises to be more explosive than ever this year in cities and counties where fireworks had been banned for decades.

headline: New York and the Planes
text: HERE are a few lines written about New York in 1948, when the city was booming, cabs were hard to get and the best tables even harder:

headline: Unfinished Business: The Defense of Marriage Act
text: Last month, with almost no fanfare, the federal government did a very decent thing: It canceled the deportation of a Venezuelan man after he married an American man in Connecticut and claimed legal residency as a spouse. But the government did not say that it was formally recognizing their marriage, because it cannot. The Defense of Marriage Act, which ranks with the most overtly discriminatory laws in the nation’s history, remains on the books, prohibiting federal recognition of legal same-sex marriages.

headline: When Same-Sex Marriages End
text: IF you thought the fight over same-sex marriage has been tumultuous, just wait for the era of same-sex divorce. With New York State’s new law allowing same-sex marriage, not just for residents but for out-of-staters as well, a bumper crop of weddings is sure to follow — and, eventually and inevitably, a sizable number of divorces.

headline: Analysis: Tsonga Lost, on His Own Terms
text: When Jo-Wilfried Tsonga fell behind by 0-40 while serving for the first set at 5-4, I remembered a story about Pancho Gonzalez. He had such confidence in his serve that he thought the odds of coming back and holding serve were still in his favor, even if faced with three straight break points. Sure enough, Tsonga played a deft half volley to save the first break point, then uncorked two monstrous first serves to get back to deuce.

headline: Phone-Call Cartography
text: AMERICANS are more connected now than ever. Mobile phones allow people to maintain relationships with friends, family and colleagues across long distances.

headline: Games People Play
text: THE Supreme Court’s decision to strike California’s ban on selling and renting violent video games to young people raises the obvious question: what are children and teens playing on their computers and digital screens?

headline: Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!
text: NPR’s “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!” is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/programs/wait-wait-dont-tell-me/)

headline: Unsung Heroes
text: A small gesture can mean a lot. That is the simple but compelling idea animating a drive to gain official honors for the patriots, both civilian and in uniform, who stood up against the Bush administration’s immoral torture policies.

headline: A Love Still Supreme, but a House in Ruins
text: There is a ranch house out in the middle of Long Island, just south of the expressway in Dix Hills, where the saxophonist John Coltrane lived, started a family and composed “A Love Supreme” in the spare bedroom. The album is a hymn of praise and thanksgiving by a man who found peace and God after alcohol and heroin. It is the work that helped make Coltrane a jazz immortal.

headline: New York’s Approval of Same-Sex Marriage Spurs Opponents for New Fights
text: Even as gay rights groups cheered New York’s adoption of same-sex marriage last month, their opponents called the vote an isolated setback and started planning how to use the specter of New York to rally their troops and fill their coffers for the battles ahead.

headline: William and Kate, Meet L.A.
text: LONDON

headline: The Lonely Polar Bear
text: MY heart goes out to Gus, the famously neurotic polar bear in the Central Park Zoo, who used to swim endless laps around his pool. He’d dive to the bottom in a froth of bubbles, surge across and then surface like a bear obsessed. He’d backstroke to the other side, and with great paws splashing, dive down to the bottom and circle around again. Some wags called him the “bipolar bear,” but most zoo-goers sensed that he felt bored, pent-up, out of his element and depressed.

headline: A Governor’s Power to Shape the Future of a Nuclear Japan
text: SAGA, Japan — In a nation plagued by weak political leadership, it has fallen to the local governor of an obscure southern prefecture to make a crucial decision that could help determine the future of nuclear power in Japan after the Fukushima Daiichi accident.

headline: 20 Years On, It’s Déjà Vu for ‘Slacker’ and Austin
text: Christopher Kelly writes a column for the Texas Report.

headline: Teamwork and Training in Iraq
text: One of the American military legacies of the war in Iraq will be a well-trained and well-equipped Iraqi special operations force.

headline: Taking Lead, Iraqis Hope U.S. Special Operations Commandos Stay
text: BAGHDAD — In darkness and dressed in black, the American and Iraqi Special Operations commandos navigated the dense urban neighborhood here in the capital and approached a house they believed to be a hide-out for two brothers suspected of carrying out assassinations and car-bomb attacks. As the Iraqis bashed in the door, the sound of glass shattering and screams pierced the nighttime stillness.

headline: Sunday: My Treat
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Are you thirsty? I’ll bet you are. We’ve had two puzzles today, and as far as I’m concerned, that’s a full working day.

headline: Crusading From Outside to Lower College Costs
text: If there was a theme to the just-concluded 82nd legislative session it was do more with less, and Representative Daniel Branch, Republican of Dallas and chairman of the House Higher Education Committee, embraced it by attacking the cost of college from multiple angles. He pushed through legislation to try to lower what students must spend on textbooks and to mandate that undergraduate students file — and stick to — degree plans.

headline: Edith Fellows, a 1930s Child Star Trailed by Dickensian Woes, Dies at 88
text: Edith Fellows, a child star of the 1930s who was known for playing orphans and urchins but whose own life was more Dickensian than that of any character she portrayed, died on June 26 in Los Angeles. She was 88.

headline: Perry Flexed His Muscles to Influence the Session
text: Gov. Rick Perry may or may not try to become the leader of what was once called the free world. In the meantime, he has cemented his reputation as one of the most powerful governors ever to walk the corridors of the Texas Capitol.

headline: Thanks to Dewhurst, Speculation Fills the Air
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Time for Oratorical Contraception
text: ELECTIONS routinely start with candidates’ pledging more debates than they’ll ever really consent to, committing to a positivity that sours faster than unrefrigerated milk and promising to listen as much as they talk, a congenital impossibility.

headline: Complaints About Proposition 13? It Depends on Who’s Not Paying
text: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: When Myths Get Trains Running
text: San Francisco’s $1.6 billion Central Subway is finally arriving. After decades of planning, the city this week chose a construction company that will begin digging the tunnel from South of Market to Chinatown later this year. And it is all because former Mayor Willie Brown Jr., following the 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake, promised a subway to Chinatown leaders who feared that their community would suffer when the city tore down the Embarcadero Freeway.

headline: U.S. Women Advance to Quarterfinals
text: The United States defeated Colombia, 3-0, and Sweden topped North Korea, 1-0, to advance to the quarterfinals of the Women’s World Cup in Germany. Neither team has allowed a goal through two games, but plenty will be at stake when they meet Wednesday in Wolfsburg: the group winner will most likely avoid a date with Brazil in the quarterfinals. Read the article here, and come back to comment.

headline: Pedestrian Pathways
text: A clever network of pathways crisscrossing the Berkeley hills helped transform the bare brown hills into some of Berkeley’s most beautiful and romantic neighborhoods. The pathways have made life easier for hill dwellers for more than 100 years.

headline: Clinics Face Budget Reductions and a New Wave of Patients
text: On a recent Friday morning, more than a dozen patients crowded into a waiting room at CompreCare Health Center in San Jose. Many were Hispanic mothers with young children, there to see an obstetrician, pediatrician or family practitioner.

headline: Hezbollah Rejects Charges Over ’05 Killing of Hariri
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, vowed Saturday that four members of his group indicted by an international tribunal in the assassination of a former Lebanese prime minister would never be arrested. He dismissed the charges as a conspiracy to sow sectarian strife here.

headline: Page One
text: The movie, which we just saw. It’s about the Times; and Robin and I, at least, found it fascinating. David Carr (whom I’ve never met) makes the film through his sheer quirkiness, although it jumps around a lot between the big question of whether news organizations as we know them can survive and smaller stories.

headline: Mets Hold Their Breath After Reyes Grabs His Hamstring
text: For weeks now, Jose Reyes’s name has been a fixture in sentences bursting with superlatives. The best shortstop. The fastest leadoff hitter. The most exciting player in baseball. But on a muggy Saturday afternoon, a chill went through Mets fans as Reyes was linked with a familiar and discouraging concern — a hamstring injury.

headline: Expanding Hispanic Students’ Academic Horizons
text: Amalia Lopez transferred to Tamayo Elementary charter school last year from a neighborhood school, where she says no one talked to her about high school options. It was assumed, said Amalia, 14, that she would attend her neighborhood high school.

headline: Fighting the Syrian Regime From a Chicago Office
text: Yaser Tabbara may live half a world away from Syria, where he grew up. But as the uprising there continues, the Chicago lawyer has mounted a one-man legal and diplomatic assault against the Syrian regime to highlight the brutality of its response and help depose President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Tackling Pension Crisis Is a Herculean Task
text: David Greising writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Black Chicagoans Fuel Growth of South Suburbs
text: One path that so many black middle-class home buyers have followed from Chicago’s South Side in recent years ends just off Lincoln Highway, past the entrance to the Newbury Estates subdivision in Matteson.

headline: 16-Year-Old Gets Aggressive, and Wins U.S. Junior Title
text: Gregory Young is America’s newest junior champion, and an unlikely one.

headline: Saddling Up, and Hitting the Beach
text: An entrepreneur who markets luxury goods online and on paper, and himself on the cocktail party circuit, Jason Binn is the chairman and founder of Niche Media, an array of boutique magazines including Hamptons and Gotham. He is also chief adviser to Kevin Ryan, chief executive officer of the Gilt Groupe. Mr. Binn, 43, shares homes in TriBeCa; Southampton; Aspen, Colo.; and Los Angeles with his wife, Haley, 35, and their daughters, Penny, 5, and CeCe, 3. He often spends Friday and Saturday nights socializing with haute Hamptons luminaries like Christie Brinkley, but summer Sundays are for kicking back with the kids at the beach.

headline: Hotels, Horses and Handball
text: Q. An F.Y.I. item published on June 26, “The Hotel Next Door,” talked about fighting illegal short-term rentals through the city’s Buildings Department and its Web site. Can you mention any other ways to fight these violations?

headline: The Stolen Stroller: An Urban Bourgeois Problem?
text: THE call came in at 12:55 p.m.: My stroller had been stolen.

headline: Park Bowlers Roll Out the Green Carpet
text: FOR the pedicab drivers who ferry tourists around Central Park, it is a favorite sight to point out: an idyllic swath of green near the park’s West 69th Street entrance, the exclusive, enclosed preserve of the New York Lawn Bowling Club.

headline: When Waves and Sand Evoke Summertime Lust
text: IS it possible to spend a day at the beach — especially in summer — without having one’s thoughts drift, even inadvertently, toward romance? It seems unlikely with the sun, the salt air, the sand and sea, and the ample availability of unclothed skin. The following poems about the erotics of the beach were found last week in the Missed Connections section of craigslist.newyork.org. They are reprinted verbatim with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

headline: How Tim Pawlenty Is Like RC Cola
text: Regular readers of this blog will know that I’ve been of mixed minds on the electoral prospects of former Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota. I’ve gone from initial skepticism about his chances to defending him as a “top-tier” candidate while some other analysts downgraded his status.

headline: Noted Leftist Urges Chávez to Release Ailing Judge
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Even as President Hugo Chávez slowly recovers in Cuba from cancer surgery, one of his most prominent sources of intellectual inspiration, the American linguist Noam Chomsky, is asking Mr. Chávez to show compassion for another Venezuelan facing a health battle of her own.

headline: In a Journey to 3,000, a Side Trip to Trenton
text: TRENTON — The account of Derek Jeter’s pursuit of 3,000 hits would be incomplete if it did not include a footnote about Jeter’s two-night detour through this city for the most talked-about minor league rehabilitation appearance in the tristate area.

headline: A Joyful Driver ‘Much Bigger Than That Last Shot’
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — Eugene Fuller came to Wake Chapel Church on Saturday to say goodbye to a bus driver named Lorenzo Charles, the one with the quick smile who made the hard work of driving a little less of a job for those who knew him.

headline: Ruptured Pipeline Spills Oil Into Yellowstone River
text: An ExxonMobil pipeline running under the Yellowstone River in south central Montana ruptured late Friday, spilling crude oil into the river and forcing evacuations.

headline: Corrections
text: ARTS & LEISURE

headline: Court Hearings in Poordavoud and Anthony Cases
text: Court documents on efforts by Afshin Poordavoud and Ryan Anthony to regain the right to possess firearms after involuntary hospitalizations. Those rights were granted in perfunctory hearings. Later, Mr. Poordavoud returned to court on separate criminal charges after a violent episode involving a gun.

headline: Some With Histories of Mental Illness Petition to Get Their Gun Rights Back
text: PULASKI, Va. — In May 2009, Sam French hit bottom, once again. A relative found him face down in his carport “talking gibberish,” according to court records. He later told medical personnel that he had been conversing with a bear in his backyard and hearing voices. His family figured he had gone off his medication for bipolar disorder, and a judge ordered him involuntarily committed — the fourth time in five years he had been hospitalized by court order.

headline: Saturday at the Women’s World Cup
text: Sweden once again struggled to score but secured its second straight 1-0 victory on Saturday, beating North Korea in Augsburg, Germany. Midfielder Lisa Dahlkvist scored in the 64th minute. The United States followed with a 3-0 win against Colombia in Sinsheim, sending both the Americans and the Swedes to the quarterfinals. It could have been worse for the Colombians: the Americans missed at least a half-dozen other good scoring chances, and had a 27-12 advantage in shots.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 3
text: America’s debt ceiling and the failed budget talks in Congress will again dominate the Sunday talk shows this week. Guests will debate the nation’s spending issues and entitlement programs before analyzing the war in Afghanistan and the transforming effects of immigration.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: July 2, 2011

headline: Yanks Get Used to Gee and Then Get to Him
text: For the Yankees’ hitters, it seems, unfamiliarity breeds contempt, or at least confusion. Facing pitchers they have never seen before has long been a formula for frustration for the Yankees, although they recently have shown an ability to adapt more quickly.

headline: Big Banks Easing Terms on Loans Deemed as Risks
text: As millions of Americans struggle in foreclosure with little hope of relief, big banks are going to borrowers who are not even in default and cutting their debt or easing the mortgage terms, sometimes with no questions asked.

headline: Battle For Libya | July 2, 2011
text: Young Libyans posed with weapons, toy and real, in Benghazi and Tripoli.

headline: Thais Back Ousted Prime Minister’s Party in Landslide
text: BANGKOK — The party of the fugitive former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra won an overwhelming victory in a parliamentary election on Sunday that could turn Thai politics on its head and roll back the results of a coup that ousted Mr. Thaksin almost five years ago.

headline: Man Charged in Death of His Mother on Upper East Side
text: A man stabbed and killed his mother on Saturday afternoon on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, the police said.

headline: U.S. Men to Play Belgium in September
text: The United States national team will play a friendly against Belgium in Brussels on Sept. 6, a rare overseas foray for Bob Bradley’s team.

headline: Inaugural Words: 1789 to the Present
text: A look at the history of presidential inauguration addresses.

headline: Conflict in Gaza: Day 22
text: Israel bombarded dozens of Hamas targets hours before announcing a unilateral cease-fire in Gaza.

headline: A Day of War in Rafah
text: Residents of the southern Gaza town of Rafah say this war feels deadlier than previous ones.

headline: The Serie A Summer Rumor Mill
text: Like most of Europe’s biggest leagues, Italy’s Serie A is flush in the middle of its summer transfer window. This means the time is ripe for talks, negotiations and hearsay regarding the off-season’s biggest moves.

headline: Top 10 Offensive Tackles in N.F.L.
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -– but not strictly -– by film study of all 32 teams from the 2010 season. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Criteria for top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: In Istanbul, Greek History on Display
text: In a rare display of cross-cultural cooperation between countries with a history of enmity, a new exhibition in Istanbul features antiquities from Greece, including marble figurines, clay tankards, weapons, cooking utensils, jewelry and ancient idols.

headline: July 3, 1863
text: Update: now that I have a few minutes, what I get from Stephen Sears is that the portrayal in this movie is fairly accurate. The main gap seems to be the thing about the fence: apparently the double fence at the Emmitsburg Road was a big obstacle on the left wing of the attack (Trimble and Pettigrew), where in fact the attack stopped dead right there; on Pickett’s wing, the fence was much further back and wasn’t a big deal.

headline: Preserving Land for Northward Migration
text: A new report from a conservation group about the wildlands that surround Glacier National Park in Montana and Canada says that unprotected public lands within the “Crown of the Continent” ecosystem should be protected to assure that the wildest ecosystem in the country stays that way as the climate changes.

headline: Djokovic Overwhelms Nadal for Wimbledon Title
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Rafael Nadal tapped on the microphone and asked, “What happened?” He was talking about a malfunction that made his speech inaudible to the Centre Court crowd, but he might have been referring to the defeat he had just been handed.

headline: Playmaker Is the Piece Argentina Is Missing
text: LONDON — It is hard to imagine how dull soccer might be without Latin players.

headline: U.S. Airlines Challenge European Emissions Rule
text: BRUSSELS — When the European Union’s highest court hears arguments on Tuesday that Europe should not charge American airlines for their carbon emissions, it will be a showdown between environmental protection and cold cash.

headline: Six Tips for Aquatic Photos
text: In 2007 Clark Little took up photography to save money on some seashore artwork his wife wanted. That has turned into a career as an award-winning photographer who was recently honored with the Oceans Photography Award from the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History in Washington, D.C.

headline: Lawn Bowling in Central Park
text: The New York Lawn Bowling Club may look exclusive, behind the fence on their verdant green in Central Park. But they urge onlookers to try out the sport, and join.

headline: Mets Exude Caution on Reyes’s Injury
text: Mets Manager Terry Collins did not have an update on the condition of shortstop Jose Reyes on Sunday morning, but Collins made it clear that Reyes would not return until he is back to full speed, especially with the opportunity next week for him to rest over the All-Star break.

headline: Bad Tayloring
text: Noah Smith says something I’d been meaning to say about John Taylor’s recent work. Taylor actually has a pretty good point: it’s far from clear that the ARRA actually led to much of a rise in government spending, while the tax cuts that made up much of the stimulus were probably largely saved.

headline: Women, Uneasy, Still Lag as Cyclists in New York City
text: When Julie Hirschfeld opened a bicycle boutique for women, she envisioned fashion-obsessed customers with a disdain for spandex flooding in to buy bikes and accessories they would model along New York City’s paved catwalks: miles and miles of new bicycle paths. She lined her shop downtown with vintage-inspired bikes, many with Brooks saddle seats; partnered with Kate Spade to sell a $1,100 bicycle the color of freshly cut grass; and sold helmets that would pass more for fashionable hats.

headline: Nova Is Sent to Minors to Make Room for Hughes
text: With Phil Hughes set to return from a three-month stay on the disabled list, the Yankees had six pitchers vying for five rotation spots. On Sunday, they made their decision. The odd man out is Ivan Nova, who was sent to Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre in a move that paves the way for Hughes to rejoin the rotation, presumably Wednesday in Cleveland.

headline: Reader Q. and A.: Restoring Gun Rights for People With a History of Mental Illness
text: In an article in The New York Times on Sunday, Michael Luo examined how states across the country were increasingly allowing people who lost their firearm rights because of mental illness to petition to have those rights restored.

headline: To Keep Parking Lots Full, Retailers Offer Gas Deals
text: With gas prices locked at well above $3 a gallon, some retailers and manufacturers are trying to get more shoppers back on the road by picking up some costs at the pump.

headline: Djokovic Triumphs at Wimbledon
text: Novak Djokovic dethroned Rafael Nadal at Wimbledon on Sunday with a 6-4, 6-1, 1-6, 6-3 victory in the men’s final.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Lost in America'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Albert Brooks's 1985 film about dropping out and hitting the road.

headline: The Undead Are Uneasy in the Untamed West
text: Along with the usual credits for lights, sets and costumes, one job title stands out in the program for “Death Valley,” a zombie western by the AntiMatter Collective. Stephanie Cox-Williams’s work is described simply as “gore.” She does it very well.

headline: Blue Jays’ Bautista Is Top All-Star Vote Getter
text: Blue Jays outfielder Jose Bautista received the most votes in fan balloting for starting spots in the All-Star Game, which is July 12 in Phoenix. Bautista will lead an American League lineup that includes four starters from the Yankees — Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez, Robinson Cano and Curtis Granderson.

headline: Bright Uniforms and Brasses Perk Up a Stage
text: The final installment of the New York Philharmonic’s Summertime Classics series coincided with Independence Day weekend, and Bramwell Tovey, the British conductor who oversees these concerts and introduces the music with amusing commentary, was on hand to apologize (a couple of times) on behalf of his countrymen.

headline: Trapped in a Room as the World Explodes
text: Virginia Woolf published “A Room of One’s Own” in 1929. Why, all these years later, do the portrayals of women trapped in rooms decidedly not their own keep coming? Why are so many of them written by women?

headline: Palestinians Unable to Pay Full Salaries of Employees
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — The Palestinian Authority will pay its employees only half their monthly salaries in July, the prime minister told reporters here on Sunday, because of what he said was “the failure of donors, including our Arab brothers, to fulfill their pledges.”

headline: Indignation, Anger and Confusion in France Over Strauss-Kahn Case
text: Days after the revelation that the case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn was on the verge of collapse, France reacted with a mix of Gallic indignation at the American justice system, fevered speculation about his political rehabilitation and visceral anger by some  feminists that the former head of the International Monetary Fund was now being cast as a victim.

headline: Marital Bankruptcy Filed in Faraway Places
text: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — The less-than-dutiful executive wife, speaking of her upwardly bound husband, observes that “firing people has become sort of a prayer” for him. This poetic fusing of corporate cruelty and humble religious faith gives off a small taserish shock. It’s a zinger that you can imagine being wielded with bright and withering contempt by a worldly woman with a savage smile.

headline: An Alchemist Reaches Out Across Centuries
text: MANCHESTER, England — What’s a rock songwriter — Damon Albarn, of Blur and Gorillaz — doing composing an opera about an Elizabethan alchemist? The best answer might be: conjuring.

headline: Djokovic’s Dream Made Real With Wimbledon Conquest
text: WIMBLEDON, England — It was the final game of an era, and Rafael Nadal punched the strings of his racket as if it were the culprit instead of the faithful companion that had helped him win 2 Wimbledon titles and 20 straight matches here.

headline: A Big Voice Full of Blues, Bawdy and Unapologetic
text: When Miche Braden plants herself at the front of the stage, shimmies a little and sings the blues, “The Devil’s Music: The Life and Blues of Bessie Smith” finds its reason for being. As Bessie, Ms. Braden has the requisite big voice — she knows when to let it soar and when to keep it at an insinuatingly low simmer — and her committed performance gives you glimmers of what the bawdy-talking, hooch-swilling (she hates the store-bought stuff), unapologetically bisexual Bessie must have been like.

headline: From George Washington to Beatniks and Beyond
text: When I lived on West 12th Street, I bought a coffee-table book called “Greenwich Village and How It Got That Way.” It turned out to be a rich, juicy history, starring American Indians, pirates, artists, anarchists and beatniks.

headline: Speed Bumps on the Road to Virtual Cash
text: MONEY is accumulated, traded and transferred online every day, but can there be a form of currency that exists only online and yet has real-world value?

headline: Sudanese Seek Refuge From Bombings
text: As the July 9 division of Sudan nears, the government of Khartoum has been relentlessly pounding the Nuba Mountains from bombers for weeks, demanding that rebel fighters disarm.

headline: Coast to Coast to Coast to Coast
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — It’s been a long month, to say the least. Read on if you’re wondering how we traveled and passed our time during the Gold Cup.

headline: Sudanese Seek Refuge from Bombings
text: As the July 9 division of Sudan nears, the government of Khartoum has been relentlessly pounding the Nuba Mountains from bombers for weeks, demanding that rebel fighters disarm.

headline: Sunday Cat Blogging
text: Update: That’s Albert Einstein, of course. His sister Doris Lessing can be seen here.

headline: Wrong Signal Is Salvaged With Style
text: The fifth European Open Championships ended on Saturday in Poznan, Poland, with the conclusion of the main pair events.

headline: An Online Scandal Underscores Chinese Distrust of State Charities
text: BEIJING — The photographs of the alluring young woman landed like hand grenades in the world of Chinese philanthropy.

headline: With the Shuttle Program Ending, Fears of Decline at NASA
text: As NASA prepares to launch its last space shuttle — ending 30 years in which large teams of creative scientists and engineers sent winged spaceships into orbit — it is facing what may be a bigger challenge: a brain drain that threatens to undermine safety as well as the agency’s plans.

headline: Summertime Anarchy, but of the Guided Kind
text: Governors Island is positively awash in creativity, with unusual, engaging artistic notions greeting you at every turn. Sculptures by Mark di Suvero, with steel girders folded, twisted and painted bright colors, dot the landscape. “Rainforest V,” a David Tudor sound environment, chatters and hoots in a former ammo bunker. Figment, a grass-roots arts initiative, has assembled a bubbly, floppy playground and a playfully creepy miniature-golf course.

headline: Carmakers and White House Haggling Over Mileage Rules
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration and the auto industry are locked in negotiations over new vehicle mileage and emissions standards that will have a profound effect on the cars Americans drive and the health of the auto industry over the next decade and beyond.

headline: Soft-Pedal Captain America Overseas? Hollywood Says No
text: LOS ANGELES — Last week, Marvel Studios started to roll out ads for its newest movie star. He’s big and brawny! He’s star-spangled! He’s Captain America, marching into multiplexes everywhere!

headline: Revisiting the Story of a Dutiful Daughter With a Hit Song
text: For much of the 1980s and beyond “Mama, I Want to Sing” was a fixture among Harlem audiences, logging more than 2,500 performances. This mom-and-pop gospel musical also yielded a handful of sequels, hybrids and other spinoffs.

headline: 2 Republicans Open Door to Increases in Revenue
text: WASHINGTON — Two senior Republicans said Sunday that they might be open to raising new government revenue as part of a deal to resolve the dispute over the federal debt ceiling, but they warned that there was little time to enact a comprehensive deal.

headline: Two Refreshing Splashes of Summertime Homicide
text: Both Benjamin Black and Ruth Rendell have written inviting new novels filled with nicely malevolent characters. It hardly seems sporting to relegate these books to the murder-story genre just because some of those characters wind up dead of unnatural causes.

headline: Holiday Box Office Sputters Domestically but Explodes Overseas
text: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood’s Fourth of July fireworks were overseas.

headline: Extreme-Slow-Motion Portraits at Lincoln Center
text: Alan Rickman, Patti LuPone and William H. Macy tend to move pretty quickly between jobs in Hollywood and on Broadway. But the photographer and visual artist David Michalek has managed to slow them down for the next month, using extreme-slow-motion video portraiture to project their images onto the David H. Koch Theater in Lincoln Center Plaza. Beginning Tuesday Mr. Michalek will present “Portraits in Dramatic Time,” a new video installation that used ultra-high-speed, high-definition cameras to record several well-known theater and film performers in a scene. Then he slows the frames to display each emotion in larger-than-life detail as it is projected onto a screen that’s 85 feet wide and 45 feet high. Like “Slow Dancing” — his first installation of this nature, which featured dancers performing ballet, folk dance and even voguing, krumping and break-dancing in slow motion— “Portraits” represents Broadway, avant garde theater and Chinese opera, as well as several other theatrical genres, enhanced with costumes, production design, makeup and lighting. The installation will be on view at Lincoln Center through July 31.

headline: Anniversary Planned for ‘Phantom’
text: The 25th anniversary of the London premiere of “Phantom of the Opera,” the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical about a masked man who haunts a young soprano in a Paris Opera house, will be celebrated with a special production at the Royal Albert Hall in London in October, Playbill.com reported. As the Phantom and Christine, Ramin Karimloo and Sierra Boggess, above, with Mr. Lloyd Webber, left, will lead a cast of 200 people in limited performances on Oct. 1 and 2. Mr. Karimloo and Ms. Boggess, who is currently starring in the Broadway revival of Terrence McNally’s “Master Class,” originated the same roles in the “Phantom” sequel, “Love Never Dies,” in the West End of London in March 2010. The original “Phantom,” which opened there on Oct. 9, 1986, with staging by Hal Prince and Gillian Lynne, is still running. The anniversary show will be directed by Laurence Connor, who has served as associate director of the London production. Ms. Lynne will return to provide musical staging and choreography. Matt Kinley will design the set, with Maria Björnson’s original design as inspiration. “Though this special staging will naturally be drawn from the brilliant original, it will be both a spectacular and unique production,” Cameron Mackintosh, who is producing, said in a statement.

headline: Clowns and Comedy Open 59E59 Season
text: Ireland comes to Midtown Manhattan in two eccentric new shows opening 59E59 Theater’s fall season. In September Cirque de Légume, a clown duo from Dublin, will use vegetables and physical comedy to create what the company calls “pure mayhem.” The Inis Nua Theater Company of Philadelphia will mix commedia dell’arte, Japanese Kabuki theater and mime to present “Dublin by Lamplight,” a story of poetry and politics at the National Theater of Ireland in 1904. In October a large church in a small town will become the center of controversy in “The Bus” by James Lantz, followed by “Any Given Monday,” an irreverent comedy about a man trying to save his marriage through terrible means, by Bruce Graham, a former writer for the television show “Roseanne.” Last — but certainly not the least draw for 59E59 audiences — the popular “Brits Off Broadway” returns to the theater for its eighth New York program. Before the season begins, Throughline Artists, a company that promotes communication between established and emerging playwrights, presents “Summer Shorts 5.” This festival of short plays brings new works by Alexander Dinelaris (“Still Life”), Christopher Durang (“Miss Witherspoon”) and Neil LaBute (“reasons to be pretty”), among several other playwrights, beginning Aug. 4 and running through Sept. 3.

headline: Radiohead in China
text: The rock band Radiohead has made a move to join the world of social networking in China, The Associated Press reported. The group has been critical of the Chinese government’s censorship in the past, performing at Free Tibet concerts in December and urging fans through its Web site to campaign for the release of Liu Xiaobo, who won last year’s Nobel Peace Prize. But the band has started a page on the “weibo” site of Sina.com, which has been described as the Chinese equivalent of Twitter. The group may not be able to keep up its activism through the site, since Internet content is screened by the government, but so far it has posted only one comment: “testing the weibo.”

headline: Barnes Foundation Meets $200 Million Goal
text: Despite continued litigation to prevent the move of its paintings and artifacts, the Barnes Foundation said last week that it had passed its $200 million fund-raising goal to continue construction on its new home in Philadelphia, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported. Of that money $40 million has come in the form of private donations in the past year; $150 million will go toward construction of the Philadelphia building and associated costs; and $50 million will go to the foundation’s endowment. Proponents of the move have claimed that the current location in Merion, Pa., has hurt attendance and membership. The collection was formerly prohibited from being moved according to a trust indenture created by the founder, Albert C. Barnes, but the indenture was overturned in 2006 by the Montgomery County Orphans’ Court. The Merion gallery closed on Sunday. Opponents of the move have a court hearing set for Aug. 1 to prevent it.

headline: Footnotes
text: Ray Manzarek and Robby Krieger, former members of the Doors, joined numerous other mourners, above, at the grave of Jim Morrison in Paris on Sunday, The Associated Press reported. They were there to honor the 40th anniversary of the death of Morrison, the Doors’ lead singer, who died in July 1971. ... Television audiences will get a preview of Simon Cowell’s “X Factor” just before the 2011 Major League Baseball All-Star Game on July 12 on Fox, TV Guide reported. The network has not released the details of the preview.

headline: AARP Begins an Internet Radio Service, Mixing Familiar Hits With New Artists
text: With constantly changing technology, and blogs that cover the latest indie bands minute-by-minute, online music is usually considered a young person’s game. But now the AARP, one of the biggest symbols of life in the gray years, is betting that a custom digital player on its Web site will rekindle its members’ love for discovering new music.

headline: The Moral Logic of Survivor Guilt
text: If there is one thing we have learned from returning war veterans — especially those of the last decade — it’s that the emotional reality of the soldier at home is often at odds with that of the civilian public they left behind.  And while friends and families of returning service members may be experiencing gratefulness or relief this holiday, many of those they’ve welcomed home are likely struggling with other emotions.

headline: Monday: Next-to-Last Greek Letter
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — If you are a movie lover like I am, this will be a fun puzzle for you, even though it’s not the Independence Day theme you might have been expecting. It’s nothing brain-breaking either, but then again it’s Monday, and we’re just easing our way back into the groove.

headline: Nadal Finds Out Just How His Opponents Have Felt
text: WIMBLEDON, England — By the final points of his fifth Wimbledon final, Rafael Nadal had the same hollow-eyed expression he usually sees in his opponents. His last stroke Sunday, a backhand that sailed long, ended his 20-match winning streak at the All England Club and his mastery in the majors over Novak Djokovic, who cemented his No. 1 ranking with a 6-4, 6-1, 1-6, 6-3 victory.

headline: Studying How ‘Star Wars’ Mined History
text: The events in “Star Wars,” the opening credits reveal, happened “a long time ago in a galaxy far, far away.” But did similar events happen before?

headline: ESPN Reaches Deal to Carry Wimbledon
text: 9:06 p.m. | Updated Starting next year, live Wimbledon coverage will be on cable only.

headline: When All Seems Lost, Mets Rally to Win
text: A far-fetched meeting in the World Series notwithstanding, the Yankees and the Mets parted ways for the summer on Sunday. But before they did, they rewarded a vocal crowd at Citi Field with the season’s most exciting installment of their crosstown rivalry.

headline: Homework Help Site Has a Social Networking Twist
text: When Pooja Nath was an undergraduate at the Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, an elite engineering school in India, she felt isolated. She was one of the few women on campus. While her male classmates collaborated on problem sets, Ms. Nath toiled in the computer lab alone.

headline: Ruptured Montana Pipeline Was Shut Down Before
text: An Exxon Mobil pipeline that ruptured late Friday along the Yellowstone River in south-central Montana, spilling crude oil into the river and forcing evacuations, had been shut down for one day in May because of concerns over the rising waters on the Yellowstone, the company said Sunday.

headline: Prince Twins Seven-Seven, Nigerian Artist, Dies at 67
text: Prince Twins Seven-Seven, a prominent Nigerian artist and leading representative of the Oshogbo School, whose brightly colored, intricately patterned paintings evoked the world of Yoruba folklore and religion, died on June 16 in Ibadan, Nigeria. He was 67.

headline: Readers Rally Around Washington City Paper
text: When Daniel Snyder, the owner of the Washington Redskins, filed a defamation lawsuit against the Washington City Paper in February, readers rushed to show their support — and the newspaper gave them an outlet. The City Paper set up a fund for reader donations meant to offset the litigation fees, collecting 600 donations totaling $28,000 in the first three weeks.

headline: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Cast ‘Funny Girl’
text: Marilyn Michaels, a singer and comedian, wrote a Theater Talkback post last week with suggestions for the people who will be casting the demanding role of Fanny Brice in the coming revival of “Funny Girl.” Ms. Michaels, who played Fanny in the national touring production after Barbra Streisand originated the role on Broadway in 1964, wrote that the character demands not only a great voice but also a solid understanding of a certain kind of humor:

headline: Networks Want Slices of a New Pie
text: Two weeks ago, KSFX, a Fox television station in the Ozarks, told its viewers that the Fox part was going away in the fall. The station said it would still show all of its local newscasts, but the station’s fans on Facebook had other concerns. What about “American Idol”? they asked. What about “Bones”?

headline: Debt Collections Elude Uncle Sam
text: Uncle Sam could use better debt collectors. Fraudsters, polluters and other corporate and white-collar miscreants owe government agencies more than $65 billion in fines. Only pennies on the dollar are ever paid. With private companies making millions buying claims from creditors, maybe they and the feds should do business.

headline: A Failing School? Not to These Students
text: Everyone knows Jamaica High is a bad school. The past two years, it has received D’s on its report card from the city and been labeled persistently dangerous by the state.

headline: How Now-Shaky Case Against Strauss-Kahn Once Seemed So Solid
text: A hotel housekeeper whose account of being sexually attacked was so compelling that it brought tears to the eyes of seasoned investigators. Preliminary forensic and electronic evidence, as well as interviews with witnesses, that poked no immediate holes in her story. And an accused man, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, with a ticket for a flight to France, approaching boarding time at Kennedy International Airport.

headline: Tools of Entry, No Need for a Key Chain
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Front pockets and purses are slowly being emptied of one of civilization’s most basic and enduring tools: the key. It’s being swallowed by the cellphone.

headline: When Hearing Warps Reality
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Hedge Funds Seeking Gains in Greek Crisis
text: It has been a tough year for the London-based hedge fund Algebris Investments.

headline: Six Yankee All-Stars, but One Big Omission as Sabathia Is Left Out
text: The unveiling of the teams for the All-Star Game on July 12 in Phoenix stirred discussion about two of New York’s biggest stars: the Yankees’ C. C. Sabathia and the Mets’ Jose Reyes. And neither of them may end up playing.

headline: Is Ethanol a Solution, or a Problem?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: In observance of the Fourth of July holiday, stock and bond markets will be closed on Monday. The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction on Tuesday of new three- and six-month bills and an auction on Wednesday of four-week bills.

headline: Indiana’s Economy
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Brains of Killers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include factory orders for May (Tuesday); the Institute for Supply Management service index for June (Wednesday); the ADP employment report for June and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and unemployment for June and wholesale trade and consumer credit for May (Friday).

headline: Sudanese Struggle to Survive Endless Bombings Aimed to Quell Rebels
text: LEWERE, Sudan — Fatima Ramadan, mother of six, froze, her eyes shooting up to the sky.

headline: Giving Credit for Comics
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gold Mining in El Salvador
text: To the Editor:

headline: Los Angeles Bus Routes Affected by Cuts
text: The financially struggling transit authority in Los Angeles is cutting back dozens of bus lines and shortening routes to save money they say would be better spend elsewhere.

headline: In Los Angeles, Cuts Will Make Long Bus Commute Longer
text: LOS ANGELES — The women shuffle back and forth as they wait just after 7 a.m. for the orange bus crawling down the street. It will be more than an hour before they arrive at work, and soon the same journey may stretch to nearly two hours.

headline: Lincoln’s Rhetorical Fireworks
text: When the Confederacy opened fire on Fort Sumter in April 1861, Abraham Lincoln responded within hours, ordering a naval blockade of Southern ports and calling for 75,000 volunteers to “maintain the honor, the integrity, and the existence of our National Union.” But in a 19th-century precursor to President Obama’s decision to act alone against Libya, Lincoln made no effort to win immediate Congressional approval — much less appropriations to pay for his orders. The reason seemed simple enough: Congress was out of session and out of town.

headline: A Driving Range Where Playing’s the Thing
text: Have you ever stood quietly in a stall at the driving range and listened?

headline: Music in the Face of Death
text: Suzanne De Chillo wasn’t entirely enthusiastic when she set out to create a photo essay about hospice care and music therapy. In fact, she was a little scared.

headline: Stars & Stripes
text: A film by Jeff Scher celebrates the July 4th holiday.

headline: Sunday at the Women’s World Cup
text: Marta scored twice Sunday in a 3-0 win over Norway in Wolfsburg, Germany, to lead Brazil into the quarterfinals. Marta, a five-time FIFA world player of the year, sandwiched her goals around a 46th-minute strike by Rosana — scoring the opener in the 22nd and putting the game beyond doubt in the 48th. Both teams found it difficult to create chances on a surface slicked by rain.

headline: Deadly Shelling by Pakistan Into Afghanistan Is Stoking Tensions
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Rocket and artillery shells fired from Pakistan have killed 42 Afghans and wounded 48 in three provinces of eastern Afghanistan over the last five weeks, according to local Afghan security officials and tribal elders who have strongly protested the assaults over the last several days and demanded that the Afghan government protect them.

headline: ‘Stars & Stripes’
text: I’ve always liked John Philip Sousa’s “The Stars and Stripes Forever.” I first became aware of the song in Popeye cartoons from the 1930s and ’40s. It consistently accompanied his post-spinach trouncing of his rival, Bluto. The music gave Popeye strength, better posture, moral certainty and an aura of the American military’s invincibility. Battleships firing cannons even appeared in his muscles. I guess that’s what a good march does: it makes you stronger on your way to battle. This performance is excerpted from a 1906 Edison recording featuring Sousa’s band.

headline: Like It or Unfriend It
text: AMERICA and Indigenous Peoples are now friends.

headline: Analysis: How Djokovic Beat Nadal
text: How did Novak Djokovic beat Rafael Nadal? After establishing his dominance on clay, Nadal showed that he could adapt to grass. He won Wimbledon twice, in addition to reaching the finals in 2006 and 2007 — an achievement that has put him in the Greatest of All Time conversation.

headline: TV’s Supporting Role in Dodgers’ Drama
text: The fight for control of the Los Angeles Dodgers that reached United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware on Tuesday pits Frank McCourt, an owner desperate to keep his team, against Commissioner Bud Selig, who believes that McCourt has turned the iconic team into a financial wreck.

headline: French See Case Against Strauss-Kahn as American Folly
text: PARIS — The stunning reversals in the criminal case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn, a putative French presidential candidate, have reawakened a dormant anti-Americanism here, fueled by a sense that the raw, media-driven culture of the United States has undermined justice and fair play.

headline: With Each Twist in Strauss-Kahn Case, City Sees Further Reflections of Itself
text: The sexual assault case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn, with its deep undercurrents of international power, sex, race and political ambition, seemed a good Rorschach test for how New Yorkers see their city.

headline: Done With the Minors, Back to the Army for Duty in Iraq
text: CONTINGENCY OPERATING BASE ADDER, Iraq — It is a familiar outcome for the legions of young minor league players chasing their major league dreams.

headline: Corporate Cash Con
text: Watching the evolution of economic discussion in Washington over the past couple of years has been a disheartening experience. Month by month, the discourse has gotten more primitive; with stunning speed, the lessons of the 2008 financial crisis have been forgotten, and the very ideas that got us into the crisis — regulation is always bad, what’s good for the bankers is good for America, tax cuts are the universal elixir — have regained their hold.

headline: Reyes Avoids Disabled List, to Mets’ Relief, and Could Return This Week
text: Jose Reyes woke up Sunday and decided it would be a good time to try out his tight left hamstring. He bounded out of bed and walked with urgency to the bathroom, then went back to bed. It was not quite like stretching a double into a triple, but he made the round trip with no pain.

headline: In Joplin, Mo., a Declaration of Endurance
text: JOPLIN, Mo. — For the last few nights, brief shimmers of fireworks have sparkled in the dark skies over Joplin, heralding the approach of another national birthday. But the monstrous tornado that mowed through here six weeks ago forced the city to change its Fourth of July plans.

headline: Wimbledon Leaves NBC and Heads to ESPN
text: Starting next year, live Wimbledon coverage will be on cable only. NBC is out after 43 years as the tournament’s broadcast outlet, and ESPN, whose current cable deal had two years remaining, will carry everything NBC had. All matches will be carried live on ESPN, ESPN3 and the ESPN mobile app.

headline: Caucus Click: Huntsman in New Hampshire
text: Former Gov. Jon M. Huntsman Jr. of Utah sought out votes at the Manchester, N.H., home of Michelle and Paul Chretien on Sunday night. “Our goal is to win you over,” he said. “I know it’s one voter at a time, and each vote, I know it’s 11 handshakes.”

headline: More Perfect Unions
text: In 44 states, the future of gay marriage still depends on legislatures, governors and voters — and eventually, perhaps, Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy. But in New York, as in five states before it, gay marriage’s future is in the hands of gay couples themselves.

headline: Eddy Nicholson, 73, Colorful Collector, Dies
text: Eddy G. Nicholson, a businessman and leveraged-buyout pioneer who became a high-flying and colorful player in the traditionally decorous world of art and furniture collecting, died on June 16 in West Lake Village, Calif. He was 73.

headline: Pakistani Military Still Cultivates Militant Groups, a Former Fighter Says
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani military continues to nurture a broad range of militant groups as part of a three-decade strategy of using proxies against its neighbors and American forces in Afghanistan, but now some of the fighters it trained are questioning that strategy, a prominent former militant commander says.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: July 3, 2011

headline: Holiday on Monday Independence Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: Ending the Alimony Guessing Game
text: New Haven

headline: Hispanics Identifying Themselves as Indians
text: A procession of American Indians marched through Sunset Park, Brooklyn, on a weekend afternoon in early May, bouncing to a tribal beat. They dressed in a burst of colors, wore tall headdresses and danced in circles, as custom dictated, along a short stretch of the park.

headline: Relaxing, Touching the Memory, Music Helps With the Final Transition
text: Every week, three music therapists from MJHS Hospice and Palliative Care crisscross the city and suburbs to sing songs to the dying. With guitars strapped to their backs, a flute or tambourine and a songbook jammed in their backpacks, they play music for more than 100 patients, in housing projects, in nursing homes and even in a lavish waterfront home. The time for chemotherapy and radiation is over.

headline: It Gets Even Worse
text: If you thought the do-it-yourself anti-immigrant schemes couldn’t get any more repellent, you were wrong. New laws in Georgia, Alabama and South Carolina are following — and in some ways outdoing — Arizona’s attempt to engineer the mass expulsion of the undocumented, no matter the damage to the Constitution, public safety, local economies and immigrant families.

headline: The Power of a Simple Majority
text: When the New York State Senate legalized same-sex marriage with a simple majority last month, it was a reminder of how unthinkable that would have been in Washington. In the United States Senate, the most routine measures are filibustered and require 60 votes to pass.

headline: European Union to Send Food Aid to North Korea
text: BRUSSELS — Responding to the growing threat of a humanitarian crisis in North Korea, the European Union announced on Monday that it will provide about $14.5 million in emergency aid to feed more than some 650,000 North Koreans.

headline: Free Speech and the Internet
text: As the United Nations has said, access to the Internet is a human right. A report by the U.N.’s special rapporteur presented last month to the Human Rights Council in Geneva warns that this right is being threatened by governments around the world — democracies included.

headline: Jeter Ends Stint in Trenton
text: The next time Derek Jeter steps onto a baseball field, he will probably be wearing his Yankees cap, but on Sunday, he made his second, and likely final, rehabilitation appearance with Class AA Trenton.

headline: Fourth of July, High Noon of the Year
text: Here we are, high noon in the year 2011 — a little past it, actually. July 2 is the middle day of an ordinary year, but the Fourth will do. How the Fourth feels, time-wise, is a matter of temperament. Does it seem like the last outpost of the first part of the year? Or is it the border crossing into the next province of the calendar? Perhaps we can think of all those fireworks bursting overhead as a way of celebrating the new half-year.

headline: A Complicated Relationship
text: Representative Mike Thompson, long a supporter of the wine industry in his California district, is himself a vineyard owner.

headline: Relaxing, Touching the Memory, Music Helps With the Final Transition
text: Three music therapists from MJHS Hospice and Palliative Care crisscross the city and suburbs to sing songs to the dying.

headline: Congress’s Man of the Vines, Including His Own
text: NAPA, Calif. — The local wine industry’s biggest names — and boldest blends — were gathered here one afternoon in February for the annual auction that is the Napa equivalent of the Academy Awards. There, pouring wine along with well-known figures like Tim Mondavi, was another industry celebrity: Representative Mike Thompson, Democrat of California.

headline: After Backing Gay Marriage, 4 in G.O.P. Face Voters’ Verdict
text: This article is by  Danny Hakim, Thomas Kaplan and  Michael Barbaro.

headline: Four Republican “Ayes” on Same-Sex Marriage
text: A look at the four Republican New York State senators, Mark Grisanti, James Alesi, Stephen M. Saland and Roy J. McDonald, who voted to legalize same sex marriage.

headline: Cairo Vendors and Protesters Set Off Clash in Tahrir Square
text: CAIRO — Chaos erupted in Cairo’s Tahrir Square on Sunday night, as a dispute between protesters and tea vendors set off clashes among groups of young men armed with rocks, clubs and knives, and a tent city occupied by protesters was burned to the ground.

headline: Belarus Cracks Down on Clapping Protesters
text: MOSCOW — The police in Belarus used tear gas to disperse protesters on Sunday after President Aleksandr Lukashenko, presiding over a ceremony to commemorate Belarus’s Independence Day, said in a speech that shadowy forces based in “the capitals of other countries” were plotting to bring down his government.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Battle for Libya | July 3, 2011
text: The leader of Libya’s opposition movement said rebel leaders had offered Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi the option to leave power and remain in his country but had not received a response.

headline: A Rebel Offer to Qaddafi: ‘Resign’ and Remain in Libya
text: RUJBAN, Libya — The leader of Libya’s opposition movement said Sunday that rebel leaders had offered Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi the option to leave power and remain in his country, but he said that the offer, which seemed to represent a considerable softening of the rebel position, had not elicited a reply.

headline: Readers’ Street Style Photos: Lace and Fringe
text: The best of readers’ street fashion submissions for the week of June 27.

headline: On to the Super Bowl
text: The Arizona Cardinals won the N.F.C. title and will face the A.F.C. champion Pittsburgh Steelers in Super Bowl XLIII on Feb. 1 in Tampa, Fla.

headline: A Look at Sundance
text: Images from select films in the 2009 Sundance Film Festival.

headline: NYT: Front Page for 07/04/2011
text: NYT: Front Page for 07/04/2011

headline: Toddler and Manhattan Man Are Killed and 3 Are Wounded in Pennsylvania Shooting
text: A 43-year-old man and a young boy were killed in a quintuple shooting at the Pennsylvania country home of a New York City couple, the authorities said on Sunday.

headline: Hackers Claim Small Breach on Apple Site
text: A group of hackers who have attacked a number of Web sites in recent months said Sunday that they had stolen a small number of internal passwords and usernames from an Apple server.

headline: Excavation and Burial in Gaza
text: Gazans gathered to extract bodies from the rubble of their homes for burial, including the Samouni family, which lost 30 members.

headline: South Korean Soldier Kills 4 in Barracks Shooting
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean marine corporal killed four fellow marines and wounded another before detonating a grenade in what appeared to be an attempt to kill himself on Monday, leaving military officials hunting for a motive.

headline: Nestlé in Acquisition Talks With China’s Biggest Confectioner
text: SHANGHAI — Nestlé, the world’s biggest food maker, is one of several companies in talks to acquire or form a partnership with the biggest Chinese confectioner, Hsu Fu Chi International.

headline: Thai Party, Led by Thaksin’s Sister, Forms Coalition
text: BANGKOK — Thailand’s politically powerful military offered a reassurance Monday that it would not challenge the election of a party controlled by the fugitive former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra, whom it deposed in a coup five years ago.

headline: European Union to Send Food Aid to North Korea
text: BRUSSELS — Responding to the growing threat of a humanitarian crisis in North Korea, the European Union announced on Monday that it will provide about $14.5 million in emergency aid to feed more than some 650,000 North Koreans.

headline: Hague Judge Orders Mladic Removed From Courtroom
text: PARIS — The wartime Bosnian Serb commander, Ratko Mladic, put on a show of belligerence at the United Nations war crimes tribunal on Monday, shouting and laughing at the bench, even taunting his judges, but he lost the first test of wills when the presiding judge abruptly expelled him from the court.

headline: The Bicycle Dividend
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: Top 10 Centers in N.F.L.
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -– but not strictly -– by film study of all 32 teams from the 2010 season. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Criteria for top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: Complaint Box | How E-Readers Destroyed My Love Life
text: I noticed his wavy hair, his feline eyes and his lips, which moved slightly as he read. But the first thing I noticed was his book: Philip Roth’s “Portnoy’s Complaint,” one of my favorites, was cradled in his palm. Between Delancey Street and Bryant Park on the uptown F train, I fell for him hard. It wasn’t the first time I’d flirted my way into a Saturday night date with a simple phrase: “I love that book.”

headline: London Photo Display Celebrates ‘Rites of Life’
text: Fifty dramatic color photographs of ceremonies and events, ranging from birth to death, as celebrated by the world’s modern and traditional societies will grace illuminated screens at More London Riverside, a development on the south bank of the River Thames, through Sept. 6.

headline: Q&A: Fixing Flash Problems in IE9
text: Q.

headline: Microsoft to Partner With China’s Leading Search Engine
text: SHANGHAI — A year and a half after Google pulled its popular search engine out of mainland China, partly over concerns about censorship, its rival Microsoft has struck a deal with the biggest Chinese search engine, Baidu.com, to offer Web search services in English.

headline: Monday Reading: Tales of Woe Using Credit Cards Abroad
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Strauss-Kahn to Face New Sex Complaint in France
text: PARIS — Dominique Strauss-Kahn will face another complaint alleging attempted rape, this one in France, according to the lawyer for a French novelist who said in an interview published on Tuesday that she wanted “a chance to be heard” about her accusation.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Blast at Sinai Pipeline Again Halts Gas to Israel
text: CAIRO, Egypt — Unknown attackers blew up a strategic natural gas pipeline that runs through Egypt’s rugged Sinai Peninsula to Israel and Jordan on Monday, bringing the flow of gas to a halt for the third time this year.

headline: For Chávez, a Triumphant Homecoming
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — He’s back.

headline: Glimpses of Salinger Tucked Inside ‘Catcher in the Rye’
text: To the list of things that J.D. Salinger found hard to bear, we can now add these: pompous graduation ceremonies and shlepping overseas to see tulips.

headline: Williams to Drop Cosworth and Return to Renault Engine in 2012
text: Williams, the third most successful team in Formula One, has not won a world title since 1997, when it took both the constructors’ and drivers’ titles, with Jacques Villeneuve driving.

headline: Williams to Drop Cosworth and Return to Renault Engine in 2012
text: Williams, the third most successful team in Formula One, has not won a world title since 1997, when it took both the constructors’ and drivers’ titles, with Jacques Villeneuve driving.

headline: Fears Rise With Arrests in Restive Syrian City
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian security forces arrested dozens of people on Monday in a new offensive, their largest foray into a central Syrian city since withdrawing last month, prompting residents to build barricades to block a more ambitious assault, residents said.

headline: In the ‘Stroke Belt,’ Erosion of Memory Is More Likely Too
text: People in a large area of the American South have long been known to have more strokes and to be more likely to die from them than people living elsewhere in the country.

headline: Patterns: No Lasting Problems Seen for Late Talkers
text: Parents often worry when their toddlers are slow to start talking, but a long-term study has found that these children have no more emotional or behavioral problems than others by age 5 — as long as they are otherwise developing normally.

headline: Hackers Commandeer a Fox News Twitter Account
text: A series of alarming Twitter posts about President Obama appeared on Fox News’s Twitter account for political news early Monday morning, and the Web site for the cable television network said it was a victim of hacking.

headline: For Film Graduates, an Altered Job Picture
text: LOS ANGELES — One after another, touring groups of prospective students and their parents stopped late last month to pose for pictures around a bronze Douglas Fairbanks, who wields his sword in a courtyard fountain here at the University of Southern California’s School of Cinematic Arts.

headline: Study Links Smoking Drug to Cardiovascular Problems
text: Chantix, the best-selling prescription drug for smoking cessation, was linked to an increased risk of a heart attack, stroke or other serious cardiovascular event for smokers without a history of heart disease compared with smokers who did not use the drug, according to a Canadian medical journal report released on  Monday.

headline: A big dig for big fossils; reflections on the space shuttle; and the stroke belt in the south.
text: A big dig for big fossils; reflections on the space shuttle; and the stroke belt in the south.

headline: Thirst for Fairness May Have Helped Us Survive
text: Among the Ache hunter-gatherers in eastern Paraguay, healthy adults with no dependent offspring are expected to donate as much as 70 to 90 percent of the food they forage to the needier members of the group. And as those strapping suppliers themselves fall ill, give birth or grow old, they know they can count on the tribe to provide.

headline: Senegal: Canadian Company to Help Finance Zinc Supplements for Children
text: A Canadian zinc mining company and a Canadian nonprofit devoted to getting vitamins and minerals to children in poor countries recently joined forces to create a new partnership, the Zinc Alliance for Child Health.

headline: Statue of Reagan Is Unveiled in London
text: LONDON — Passers-by at the American Embassy, in the heart of London’s upscale Mayfair district, were greeted Monday morning by the disembodied voice of Ronald Reagan drifting through the air from large speakers — a prelude to the unveiling of a $1 million bronze statue of the former president here to commemorate the 100th anniversary of his birth.
