text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: What Not to Say to a Daughter-in-Law
text: Becoming a parent creates the distinct possibility of eventually becoming a parent-in-law (even more so now that all New Yorkers have the right to marry). So there is much for Motherlode readers to learn from the cautionary tale of Carolyn Bourne of Devon, England.

headline: Remembering Ray Deter of d.b.a.
text: Sad news arrived over the holiday weekend. Ray Deter, a longtime owner of d.b.a., a groundbreaking New York beer bar, died Sunday after being critically injured in a bicycle accident on June 27.

headline: Calling Foul on N.B.A.’s Claims of Financial Distress
text: At midnight on Thursday, the N.B.A. locked out its players in what could be the start of a long labor dispute. Some observers, like ESPN’s Michael Wilbon, believe the entire 2011-12 season could be threatened.

headline: Commas? Sure, Throw a Few In
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Commas? Sure, Throw a Few In
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Winning? Comedy Central Plans Roast of Charlie Sheen
text: How do you satirize a man whose life has already turned into a perpetual comedy skit? That’s for Comedy Central to figure out: on Tuesday that cable channel announced that Charlie Sheen, who has been an ex-star of “Two and a Half Men” for so long now that we can’t remember why he’s still famous, will be the subject-cum-victim of the next installment of its popular series of televised roasts. The “Comedy Central Roast of Charlie Sheen,” where celebrity guests and comedians will say to Mr. Sheen the things that they’ve already been saying behind his back and run catch phrases like “tiger blood” and “winning!” into the ground, will be filmed in Los Angeles on Sept. 10 and broadcast on Sept. 19, the channel said on Tuesday.

headline: Tweet and Shout
text: Live music is absolutely a religious experience for the fans. They are so completely awestruck by their idols. And it’s like they’re just enraptured, hypnotized, ecstatic and entranced.

headline: How We Got the Restaurant Open for July 4
text: Tokyo turnips. French radishes. The light and the land of Bridgehampton can grow anything. Lemon balm. Thai basil. When Paul Hamilton is the gardener, throw in sugar snaps and heirloom eggplants. When his makeshift staff includes four chefs with green thumbs and a closed-down kitchen, you can depend on lovely sorrel and Vietnamese coriander.

headline: 'Yelling to the Sky'
text: A scene featuring Zoe Kravitz in "Yelling to the Sky," a film by Victoria Mahoney about a troubled multicultural family.

headline: Princess Brides |  Charlene and Kate
text: Two high-profile weddings dominated the news over the weekend: Charlene Wittstock, now Princess Charlene of Monaco, whose royal festivities blended fashion and the monarchy in Monte Carlo; and Kate Moss, the reigning princess of style whose guest list read like a mashup of NME and Tatler in the Cotswalds. T wants to know whose dress you prefer – Princess Charlene’s Armani Privé duchesse silk gown or Mrs. Hince’s Galliano floor-length dress with sequins and sheer detailing. Vote for your favorite look on T’s Facebook page: www.facebook.com/tmagazine.

headline: Still Ironing Out the Gay Marital Terminology
text: Oh, brave new world of same-sex marriage bureaucracy!

headline: Blown Away
text: Competitors hurtle across an unstable surface at more than 60 m.p.h. while jockeying for position against hundreds of rivals — and without helmets, despite violent wipeouts.

headline: Motorsports: Ragan Victory at Daytona Clouds Nascar Playoff Picture
text: 2:03 p.m. | Updated Smooth racing for more than 100 of its scheduled 160 laps did not portend a smooth finish for the Coke Zero 400 at Daytona International Speedway.

headline: China Admits Extent of Spill From Oil Rig
text: BEIJING — Oil that spewed from an offshore drilling rig in northeastern China for two weeks last month has spread over 320 square miles, government officials acknowledged Tuesday, amid public uproar over why it took so long for fishermen, local residents and environmental groups to be informed of the spill.

headline: Inconceivabilities
text: Dean Baker is upset at a story that describes Argentina’s economy as “stagnant”. Actually,this sort of thing is quite common — and not just about Argentina. I’ve often found that when things happen that aren’t supposed to happen according to the prevailing economic or political orthodoxy, reporting quite often describes what “should” have happened, not what actually happened.

headline: Scorecard | Giambattista Valli Wins!
text: And Scorecard‘s back from our fashion hiatus! In Paris, Independence Day — err, we mean the first day of the couture shows — was marked by a series of new beginnings. At the storied house of Christian Dior, studio director Bill Gaytten tried his hand with an exuberant display at least in part inspired by Postwar architecture, but it’s safe to say that these prismatic creations failed to launch. Meanwhile, in the context of couture, the Chambre Syndicale’s newest guest member Giambattista Valli finally lit the critical spark.

headline: What’s In A Name? Reposted
text: I suspect that it’s a good time to repost something I wrote early into our continuing liquidity trap (the reference to awesome Fed action was about the big lending operations of 2008-2009 — QE1 — not the modest actions of 2010-2011):

headline: A Chalayan Fix
text: If you’re going to be in Paris this summer, make a point of seeing the Hussein Chalayan retrospective at Les Arts Décoratifs, which is part of the Louvre. Mr. Chalayan worked on the exhibition with curator Pamela Golbin, and it includes important pieces from Mr. Chalayan’s remarkable career, as well as films and sketches.

headline: Mr. Valli, Are You Ready for Your Close-Up?
text: Well known in Paris since his days at Ungaro, Giambattista Valli presented his first haute couture collection the other night in the tiny Galerie de la Madeleine. His atelier and showroom are just upstairs; his ready-to-wear boutique is in the passage. In a matter of a few years he has staked out this small corner of the Right Bank.

headline: Perry Breaks With a Fellow Texan: Bush
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Gov. Rick Perry, a Republican contemplating a presidential run, shares many attributes with the last man who ran for president from here, his predecessor and onetime patron, George W. Bush. He has the same straight-legged Texas swagger; the down-home, clipped speaking style; the desert-baked conservatism.

headline: A Clan and a Colorado Town, Long Thriving as One
text: STEAMBOAT SPRINGS, Colo. — Frank and Carrie Light and their eight children came here around 1900 to what was just a wide spot of a few hundred people. Then the town’s story and the family’s got intertwined. Now it is hard to tell where one begins and the other leaves off.

headline: In Shift to New Court, Risks for Madoff Trustee’s Case
text: When it comes to the Madoff bankruptcy case, the venue matters.

headline: W.T.O. Says Chinese Restrictions on Raw Materials Break Rules
text: BRUSSELS — In a dispute that highlights growing tension between China and its Western trading partners, the World Trade Organization ruled Tuesday that Beijing violated global rules by restricting exports of nine raw materials used in the manufacturing of high technology products.

headline: Portugal’s Debt Rating Cut to Junk by Moody’s
text: Moody’s Investors Service cut Portugal’s debt rating to junk status on Tuesday, ratcheting up the pressure on euro zone governments to work out a lasting solution to their financial woes.

headline: In M.L.S., When a ‘Good Result’ Is Bad
text: One of the more distressing euphemisms of soccer is “the good result,” a win, but more often a tie on the road. A point is a point, whether it be a 3-3 or 0-0 game. In Major League Soccer, where two coaches have already lost their jobs this season and making the playoffs is crucial, caution is accepted as the best strategy, especially on the road.

headline: Digital Diary: Is Google’s Hangouts Its Killer App?
text: Last night a chatroom changed my life.

headline: Case of Willie Nelson Pot Bust Isn’t Extinguished Yet
text: The seemingly routine occurrence of Willie Nelson’s being found in possession of marijuana has stoked a small conflagration in a Texas county where a judge says she will not permit what she sees as the lenient punishment of this singer by an overly deferential prosecutor.

headline: Would Top Clubs and Their Fans Support a Gay Player?
text: For a number of English Premier League clubs, this week marks the beginning of preseason training. It comes only days after the British government followed up its recently launched charter to tackle homophobia and transphobia in sports by holding a reception for the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community, hosted by Prime Minister David Cameron.

headline: A Paper Doll Is a Paper Doll Is a Paper Doll
text: Long before Ellen DeGeneres and Portia de Rossi, there was Gertrude Stein and Alice B. Toklas. The brilliantly eccentric couple made myriad contributions to the arts in the early-to-mid-20th century, notably as the hostesses of their legendary artist salons. They befriended and championed Picasso, Matisse and Hemingway and also extended their network to other modernist creatives (many of them gay).

headline: Gun Rights and Mental Illness: Answering Readers’ Questions
text: 5:52 p.m. | Updated In an article in The New York Times on Sunday, Michael Luo examined how states across the country were increasingly allowing people who lost their firearm rights because of mental illness to petition to have those rights restored.

headline: After Half a Century, a Penn Station Eagle Returns
text: Members of Albert Fritsch’s family descended on Grand Central Terminal on Friday to visit a family heirloom (and 45-pound tchotchke) that is now the three-dimensional centerpiece of the exhibition “The Once and Future Pennsylvania Station.”

headline: Rivera Sits and Panic Ensues
text: Even if you are not a Yankees fan — and thankfully not everyone gravitates to the best team money can attempt to buy. How boring would that be? — you might have to admit they do have the ability to be entertaining no matter where you fall on the love-hate scale. Because there is nothing like a little outbreak of meaningless Yankee panic in early July to make you pour yourself a glass of lemonade, sit back and enjoy. It’s kind of like fireworks, only louder.

headline: Woods to Skip British Open
text: Tiger Woods announced Tuesday on his Web site that he would not play in the British Open next week at Royal St. George’s in Sandwich, England.

headline: In Europe, a Move to Slash Phone Roaming Charges
text: For many tourists, it’s an experience they will long remember. After taking in the Eiffel Tower in Paris, the Coliseum in Rome or Buckingham Palace in London, they arrive home to something unexpected: a staggering cellphone roaming bill.

headline: Pushing Boundaries, Mixed-Race Artists Gain Notice
text: For years Heidi W. Durrow heard the refrain: editors wouldn’t publish her novel because readers couldn’t relate to a protagonist who was part black and part Danish. But when that novel, “The Girl Who Fell From the Sky,” was finally published last year (after about four dozen rejections, said Ms. Durrow, who is, of course, black and Danish), the coming-of-age story landed on best-seller lists.

headline: Illness Knocks Brian Bedford Out of ‘The Misanthrope’
text: Visitors to the Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Canada who were hoping to catch Brian Bedford playing Oronte in “The Misanthrope” this summer will be disappointed. The actor, who has performed at the festival since the mid-1970s, has dropped out because of unspecified medical reasons, according a spokeswoman for the festival.

headline: Punk Priestess Still Reigns
text: Scanning the track list at Pitchfork, in anticipation of Patti Smith’s best-of collection, “Outside Society,” I was reminded of how much I loved her National Book Award-winning memoir, “Just Kids.” It describes her early years in working-class Philadelphia, life with Robert Mapplethorpe at the Chelsea Hotel, dating Sam Shepard, Max’s Kansas City, becoming a wife and mother in Detroit. It’s not just that she’s incredibly cool, effortlessly glamorous in her own raw-edged way, but that she writes so beautifully and incredibly movingly about her love for Robert, both when it was sexual and after it had, for the most part, ceased to be:

headline: Step Into | Aloha Rag for Converse
text: The timeless Jack Purcell sneaker gets another update, this time in the hands of the über-cool retailer Aloha Rag. Launching today as part of Aloha Rag’s 20th anniversary, the Aloha Rag for Converse Jack Purcell Zip shoe remains true to Converse’s classic look but is given a bit of edginess. Featuring a calf-leather interior, embroidered skull-and-hearts logo, and zip tongue, the sneaker exudes the owner Tatsugo Yoda’s aesthetic, which combines punk style with nods to luxury. Only 150 pairs will be made available at Aloha Rag stores in New York and Honolulu and on its Web site.

headline: Best Friend and Ex-Teammate to Confront Clemens at Trial
text: One crucial notion setting Roger Clemens’s case apart from other drug scandals involving baseball stars is that his former close friend and loyal teammate Andy Pettitte, a man Clemens considered his little brother, could be the most damaging witness against him.

headline: The Charges Against Roger Clemens
text: What Roger Clemens is facing at his federal criminal trial, which begins Wednesday in Washington.

headline: Credit Cards Without Foreign Transaction Fees
text: If you’re planning a trip outside of the United States this summer, you might want to think hard about what credit card you bring along. The list of cards that have eliminated foreign transaction fees, which tack up to 3 percent onto your purchases, is growing, and using the right card can save you money on your vacation.

headline: Energy Transfer Says It Is ‘More Aggressive’ in Pursuit of Southern Union
text: For years, Energy Transfer Equity refused to issue new stock, so firmly convinced in that plan that it even walked away from potential deals in the past.

headline: Elizabeth Holtzman Thinks She’s Ideal for Weiner’s Seat
text: When it comes to New York’s suddenly vacant Ninth Congressional seat, Elizabeth Holtzman is not exactly playing it coy.

headline: French Boat Leaves Greek Waters, but Gaza May Prove Too Far
text: Defying a government order, a small French boat quietly left Greek waters early Tuesday and set course for the Gaza Strip, coordinators announced later in the day, when the craft had reached international waters. It was the first vessel to successfully depart Greek territorial waters aiming to be part of an international flotilla challenging Israel’s naval blockade.

headline: Q&A: Checking iTunes Account Purchases
text: Q.

headline: Impromptu for Piano and Taxi Horn
text: Talk about “Sounds of the City.” On Friday night I had one of those only-in-New-York experiences, a mix of musical gratification and urban racket.

headline: A Grand Rapids State of Mind
text: As a former resident of Kalamazoo, Mich., I can only say: “Doggone it, Grand Rapids. You’ve out-Midwesterned us again. How can you be so goofy and sweet at the same time?”

headline: Suzuki’s Kei Cars, Running Mild in New Jersey
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — I don’t know if it’s possible for a Honda Element to mate with a toaster, but for the sake of argument, let’s just say that it can. The resulting offspring may have been on display at the Meadowlands here over the weekend.

headline: Winning? Comedy Central Plans Roast of Charlie Sheen
text: Dave Itzkoff reports on Arts Beat that Charlie Sheen has found a way to get back onto television on Monday night – at least one Monday night.

headline: At Duane Reade’s Newest Outpost, Sushi and Hairstyling
text: Despite the beleaguered stock market, Duane Reade is turning to Wall Street to make a profit.

headline: Growing Together
text: When Frank and Carrie Light and their eight children arrived in Steamboat Springs, Colo., around 1900, it was just a wide spot of a few hundred people. Then the town’s story and the family’s became intertwined.

headline: Now Screening | Armani Couture
text: Our runway video of the haute couture collection from Giorgio Armani.

headline: Sting Cancels Concert in Kazakhstan After Crackdown on Strikers
text: Sting has thrown his support behind striking oil workers in Kazakhstan, abruptly canceling his concert that was scheduled for July 4 in the capital, Astana, after he learned of a government crackdown on the strikers.

headline: Hawk Cam | Bobby Returns, Briefly
The Onion Expands Internationally, if Canada Counts
text: Canadians hoping to get their hands on news parody will soon need to look no further than Toronto. The Toronto Star, Canada’s largest newspaper, has teamed up with the Onion to distribute the satirical publication and its sister publication, the A.V. Club, beginning in the fall. With the agreement, Toronto will become the 14th city – and the first outside the United States – where the Onion is distributed.

headline: Photo Replay: July 5
text: A view of the day in sports, in the shadows, on the soccer fields and on the roads of France.

headline: Now Screening | Armani Couture
text: Our runway video of the haute couture collection from Giorgio Armani.

headline: New Toyota Ad
text: A new Toyota ad campaign for the RAV4 sports utility vehicle is aimed at attracting the African-American consumer.

headline: Blood Relations: Mystery Writers Collaborate for Charity
text: If you ever tried round-robin story telling, in which one person begins a tale and other participants contribute to the drama, you will appreciate “No Rest for the Dead,” a new mystery written by 26 professional novelists including Alexander McCall Smith, Jeffery Deaver, Faye Kellerman, R. L. Stine, Kathy Reichs and Sandra Brown.

headline: Toyota Turns to a Bulldog to Talk Up the RAV4
text: Toyota will introduce a new ad campaign next week, promoting its RAV4 compact sport utility vehicle to the African-American market.

headline: The Mitchell Report: Name by Name
text: Players identified in Major League Baseball's report on performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Roundup: Michigan Admissions, Student Loans and Prospects for Film Graduates
text: Summer is typically a slow season on the admissions news (and news-you-can-use) front. But several articles over the holiday weekend caught our eye, and we wanted to bring them to the attention of those readers — especially future applicants and their families — who may have missed them.

headline: Bahamas Bans Shark Fishing
text: The Bahamas on Tuesday joined the growing global movement to protect sharks, betting that the endangered animals are worth more to visiting divers than they are to fishers.

headline: An Exhibition From Vatican’s Secret Archives
text: ROME — The Vatican will unveil 100 documents from its Secret Archives, including unpublished papers from the World War II era, in an exhibition in Rome next year, it announced on Tuesday. The exhibition, to be held at the Capitoline Museums from February to September, marks the first time that the papers from the Pope’s private archives have been allowed to leave the Vatican.

headline: Same-Sex Spouses in New York Will Get Health Insurance
text: Getting health insurance should become easier for gay couples who decide to marry and live in New York, which recently became the sixth state to legalize same-sex marriage.

headline: Restive City of Hama Tests Will of Syrian Government
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Fired up with zeal, activists say they have set up dozens of checkpoints in the Syrian city of Hama, alerting neighborhood groups with cries of “God is great” to the approach of feared security forces and throwing up barricades of burning tires and trash bins to block their path.

headline: Casey Anthony Not Guilty in Slaying of Daughter
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Casey Anthony, the young mother whose seeming heartlessness at the disappearance of her daughter transfixed America for three years, was found not guilty on Tuesday of killing the girl, Caylee Marie.

headline: 7 Fingers Acrobats to Return to New York
text: It’s turning out to be quite a summer for French-Canadian, hoop-diving, animal-free circus ensembles in New York City.

headline: At the Really Old Ballgame
text: Three strikes and you’re dead?

headline: Armani Privé: Foreign States
text: Giorgio Armani called his fall haute couture collection an homage to Japan. The designer who helped liberate women from boring executive wear and floppy bow ties confined his homage to traditional Japanese costumes and feminine floral patterns. There was no Goth Lolita moment or anything you might associate with Tokyo street fashion of the last 20 years. He stuck to a silhouette seemingly drawn from the kimono and obi (translated as stiff black patent leather bodices), and one or two models were slowed to a mincing gait. The prints and embroideries were lavish, but as Armani collections go, it was an island unto itself.

headline: Just One Look | Giorgio Armani
text: With kimonos and geishas for inspiration, Giorgio Armani presented a beautiful collection for Privé today, one of his finest since launching the haute couture line 6 years ago. Black velvet trouser suits lined and outlined in Japanese floral silks were a perfect mash up of his/hers and east/west, and yet linear, untricksy, and exquisite. The evening dresses were columnar, often obi’d, and with a hint of plissé or a jacquard petticoat dusting the floor. Here, a big night stunner with sequined bodice, velvet skirt (cut narrow as trousers) and hints of vivid floral silk.

headline: Huckabee’s Daughter to Join Pawlenty Campaign
text: Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the daughter and top political adviser to Mike Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas, has joined Tim Pawlenty’s presidential campaign as a senior adviser, the campaign announced Tuesday.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Accuser Files Libel Suit Against N.Y. Post
text: The hotel housekeeper in the Dominique Strauss-Kahn case filed a libel suit against The New York Post on Tuesday over a series of articles it published during the Fourth of July weekend claiming that she was a prostitute.

headline: More Law Firms Raid Competitors to Poach Rainmakers
text: The job of unwinding Bernard L. Madoff’s huge fraud and recovering money for its victims has been lucrative, reaping hundreds of millions of dollars in legal fees. Late last year, a New Jersey law firm tried to poach the legal team handling that assignment.

headline: As Budgets Are Trimmed, Time in Class Is Shortened
text: After several years of state and local budget cuts, thousands of school districts across the nation are gutting summer-school programs, cramming classes into four-day weeks or lopping days off the school year, even though virtually everyone involved in education agrees that American students need more instruction time.

headline: Cy Twombly, Idiosyncratic Painter, Dies at 83
text: Cy Twombly, whose spare childlike scribbles and poetic engagement with antiquity left him stubbornly out of step with the movements of postwar American art even as he became one of the era’s most important painters, died in Rome Tuesday. He was 83.

headline: July 5, 1975 | Arthur Ashe Becomes First Black Man to Win Wimbledon
text: On July 5, 1975, Arthur Ashe became the first black man to win Wimbledon, defeating Jimmy Connors in a shocking upset.

headline: Talking About the It Gets Better Project
text: Last fall, the advice columnist Dan Savage and his partner, Terry Miller, decided to post a video to give hope to bullied gay teenagers. Their message was that they also had been bullied as kids, but their adult lives were so much better, and included love, friendship, career achievement, marriage and parenthood.

headline: The Dutch
text: SO here is where you want to be right now, all of you who care about good food and the theater of eating it: sitting in a booth in the back of the Dutch, alternating bites of red shrimp and fried green tomatoes with hits of dry Vouvray.

headline: Reviewing the Dutch
In Silicon Valley, a Culture Clash Sullies a Romance
text: Private equity has broken venture capital’s heart, and V.C. is not taking it well.

headline: The Imprisoned Hikers’ Moms
text: This month marks two years of worry for the parents of Josh Fattal and Shane Bauer, who, along with Shane’s fiancée, Sarah Shourd, were imprisoned by the Iranian government in July 2009, accused of crossing the border illegally. Writing about them won’t end their families’ worry. But it’s all I can do to show another parent that I can’t pretend to imagine their pain. (For more on their story, read Nick Kristof’s blog posts over the years, here, and here.

headline: Mix of Old and New in Bids for 2018 Winter Games
text: The host city for the 2018 Games will be chosen Wednesday by the International Olympic Committee among candidates from South Korea, Germany and France.

headline: Celebrate Summer: Ideas for Teaching the Season
text: The Learning Network is taking it slow this month, and we hope you are too — though of course we can’t help but encourage a bit of learning as you go.

headline: Earth Angels
text: The Givenchy couture collection on Tuesday consisted of just 10 outfits, all in white or off-white, with minimal touches of gold, and each far from the everyday, as you expect of couture. The mostly long dresses or delicate tops and boleros were made in fragile tulle and lace embroidered with clusters of tiny knots, caviar beads and feathers. Some styles were bareback. Evening bags covered in superlong silk fringe and mounted on hidden stands made at least a few Americans say: “Oh, sweet. It’s Cousin Itt.”

headline: Masters’ Dream Threesome: Player, Palmer and Nicklaus
text: The Big Three will be reunited at the 2012 Masters, Augusta National Golf Club announced Tuesday. Gary Player will make his debut as an honorary starter next year at Augusta, joining Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus on the first tee to fire the opening shots in the popular Thursday ceremony that is the official opening of the tournament.

headline: Rise of World Trade Center Spurs a Retail Revival
text: As 1 World Trade Center starts to claim a place on the Lower Manhattan skyline, the area’s retail scene is beginning to revive, with landlords raising rents in anticipation of thousands of new office workers, tourists and residents, commercial real estate experts said.

headline: One Last Weiner
text: I’m as over Anthony Weiner as any of the rest of you, but as I was catching up on The Nation this weekend, I saw JoAnn Wypijewski’s byline on an article about him and felt compelled to read it. JoAnn is one of my favorite journalists. She wrote a nice story for this magazine in 2004 about the disenchantment of black voters with the Democratic Party, but the one that I am most indebted to her for is the riveting account of Nushawn Williams, a young man who infected at least 13 women with H.I.V., which she wrote for Harper’s Magazine in 1998. (Not available free online, sorry. Worth buying a subscription to the magazine, trust me.). This is one of the finest magazine stories I’ve ever read, in part because it so beautifully and sensitively evokes the desperate straits of Jamestown, N.Y., my father’s hometown. Even without that personal connection, you’ll find it a deeply satisfying reading experience.

headline: Independent Group Bolsters Romney’s Fund-Raising Totals
text: When Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, releases his campaign fund-raising filings this month, he is expected to report somewhere south of $20 million in contributions for the second quarter of the year — more than any of his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination, but somewhat less than might be expected for the candidate who has built the most robust fund-raising operation in the G.O.P. field.

headline: Looking at Ken Lay and the Lack of Financial Crisis Cases
text: Kenneth L. Lay, the former chief executive of Enron, died of a heart attack five years ago today. The stunning news came a month after a Houston jury convicted him of securities fraud and three months before his scheduled sentencing.

headline: Pitchfork Plans a Festival in Paris
text: The folks who run the Pitchfork Music Festival — the influential three-day summer showcase of indie music in Chicago — have announced plans to stage a fall festival in Paris, headlined by the folk-rock group Bon Iver. The European festival is the latest milestone in Pitchfork’s remarkable rise as a force in the world of indie rock. Not only has this summer festival, now in its sixth year, become a must-go event for people interested in indie music, but the Web site of the same name has become one of the most prominent brands in online music journalism, widely seen as having the influence to pluck bands from obscurity and jump-start their careers.

headline: New Evidence on Shaken Baby Syndrome
text: When I wrote about shaken baby syndrome last winter for the magazine, a Canadian pathologist named Evan Matshes was working on intriguing new research that hadn’t yet been published. Matshes’s paper is just out, in Academic Forensic Pathology, the journal of the National Association of Medical Examiners. It opens a new avenue of inquiry for this difficult and fraught diagnosis.

headline: Neely’s Barbecue Coming to New York
text: Pat Neely, along with his brothers, opened his first barbecue restaurant in Memphis in 1988. Their chainlet in Tennessee has expanded since then, involving Pat’s wife, Gina. The couple became Food Network stars three years ago, so now they are poised to make a grand entrance in New York.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Kenya, India, South Sudan and Afghanistan.

headline: With Help From Others, Newark Is Building for Business
text: NEWARK — Last month, a few dozen people donned hairnets and crowded around a huge oven here to sample a 25-foot matzo, which was billed as the largest ever baked. The event celebrated the completion of the new headquarters of the kosher food giant Manischewitz in this city’s industrial East Ward.

headline: Pettitte Affidavits
text: Sworn affidavits by the former pitcher Andy Pettitte and his wife, Laura, regarding conversations between Andy Pettitte and Roger Clemens about Clemens’s alleged use of Human Growth Hormone.

headline: As It Campaigns to Build in the City, Wal-Mart Donates $4 Million
text: He called Wal-Mart “one of the great corporate citizens in this country.” He praised its efforts to conduct background checks before selling guns. He flatly rebuffed suggestions that the company was killing jobs.

headline: Fennel Marmalade
text: I can’t think of a better accompaniment for this Provençal-inspired condiment than a piece of grilled fish. For a simpler meal, try this marmalade atop a bowl of brown rice or a bruschetta.

headline: End-of-Life Care: A Portrait
text: Coming soon to a public television station near you: “Consider the Conversation: A Documentary on a Taboo Subject.”

headline: Reid Shifts Senate Attention From Libya to Debt Limit
text: With Republicans protesting that the Senate should be concentrating on the debt limit standoff this week, Senator Harry Reid, the Nevada Democrat and majority leader, on Tuesday conceded the point and abruptly called off a planned debate on Libya.

headline: When a Smartphone Is Too Much for Travel
text: With the rise of the iPhone and the Blackberry, it’s hard to imagine hitting the road without a phone that can’t download music, serve up maps or send and receive e-mail. But sometimes a body just needs to make a few calls from the road. Sometimes a body needs a featureless phone.

headline: Where Opera Is Stretched Yet Unbroken
text: LONDON — “In my life, why do I give valuable time to people who don’t care if I live or die?” That’s the refrain of “Heaven Knows I’m Miserable Now,” the 1984 Smiths song.

headline: For French Tourists, Strauss-Kahn Town House Is Must-See
text: Louis Lelias, 30, skipped up to the door of 153 Franklin Street on Monday afternoon. He smiled broadly and stuck out his fist, extending his pinky and thumb to make a jovial “hang loose” hand gesture, as his wife snapped a picture.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Kenya, India, South Sudan and Afghanistan.

headline: Cold Boiled Chicken à la Chinois
text: Time: 1 hour 20 minutes, plus several hours’ refrigeration

headline: Chicken, Simmered and Chilled
text: TRUE confession: I love cold chicken. Cold roast chicken, cold fried chicken, a meaty cold chicken carcass for finger-licking nibbling. And during the long days of summer, I crave cold boiled chicken, brightened with hot pepper, sesame oil and scallions.

headline: Chicken for Summer: Cool, Easy and Exciting
text: If the dog days have got you down, cold chicken might be the answer. This Chinese-inspired dish is served straight from the fridge, and only minimal cooking is required. Simmered gently with ginger and star anise, showered with scallions, hot pepper, and sesame — what’s not to like? What are some of your recipes for cold meals in hot weather?

headline: A Fourth, for Many Fourths to Come
text: The subjects on Monday were timeless. There was a backyard barbecue, the National Mall, a neighborhood parade, the Liberty Bell, a swimming pool. And fireworks, of course.

headline: Energy Transfer Raises Southern Union Bid to $5.1 Billion
text: 5:23 p.m. | Updated

headline: That Perfect Florida Tomato, Cultivated for Bland Uniformity
text: Jonathan Lethem has seen the future of agribusiness, and that future is strange. In his novel “Girl in Landscape” (1998), he imagined humans inhabiting a new planet where meals grow inside “potatoes” that can be planted and harvested. Among the flavors: meat, cake and tea. “Fish,” one character announces, as if he were Ferran Adrià, “is the weirdest one.”

headline: Zynga Stands Out Among Tech I.P.O.’s
text: Technology firms have gone to market this year by the bushel with little earnings in tow. Zynga arrives with income aplenty from online games like FarmVille. And Zynga’s profitability is even more bountiful than it first appears.

headline: A Rural Homecoming Stirs Trouble
text: “Make sure you don’t set anyone’s loins on fire,” a Tennessee plumber (Mark Darby Robinson) instructs his significantly younger and poutier female companion (Rachel Korine) midway through “Septien.” Given the film’s preponderance of flabby men in saggy underwear — not to mention alarming sexual imagery — viewers with weak stomachs can only hope she complies.

headline: In Cuba, the Voice of a Blog Generation
text: Like any other first-time author, Yoani Sánchez was looking forward to receiving copies of her book, “Cuba Libre,” after it was published last year. But when the package sent from Buenos Aires by her publisher arrived in Havana, the Cuban customs service impounded the parcel and, after she complained, sent her a notice explaining its action.

headline: Our Opening in Arles
text: As members of the photography world make their annual pilgrimage to Les Recontres d’Arles in France this week, we are proud to say that The New York Times Magazine Photographs exhibition is one of the year’s big draws. Our photo director, Kathy Ryan, co-curated the show with Lesley A. Martin, the publisher of Aperture Books.

headline: Obama Seeks to Reopen Budget Talks
text: President Obama on Tuesday invited Democratic and Republican Congressional leaders to meet with him in the White House on Thursday, saying that “greater progress is in sight” on a deal to raise the nation’s debt limit and reduce the deficit.

headline: For Jaguar Drivers, a Letter Brings Its Privileges
text: When I think back to driving school, I cannot stave off the memory of fighting sleep at a cramped desk while being lectured about illegal U-turns and the perils of driving at speed. But at the Jaguar R Performance Academy, which I attended late last month at Monticello Motor Club northwest of New York City, I was wide awake to the instructors’ message about respecting speed as well as, more thrillingly, how to handle it.

headline: The Humbling of a Powerful Frenchman
text: Worlds collide in “Rapt,” a solid yet fleet French thriller about a society kidnapping and its shockwaves. You see one world in the gangbuster opening that, with a racing camera, follows a sleek, unidentified man as he hurtles through a day in a matter of moments, rushing out of his home, whooshing into an office, bolting from a meeting and all but flinging himself into the arms of one woman before embracing another. This frenetic activity soon jolts to a halt, though, when his chauffeured car is jacked and he’s snatched by armed kidnappers who turn him into a victim even as the outside world transforms him into the accused.

headline: Chinese Gem That Elevates Its Setting
text: GUANGZHOU, China — It says something about the state of architecture today that the most alluring opera house built anywhere in the world in decades is in a generic new business district at the outer edge of this city, has no resident company and a second-rate program.

headline: Drink Up | New Cocktails in N’awlins
text: “I came here with AmeriCorps after the storm and never really left.” That’s the story of T. Cole Newton, a post-Katrina New Orleans transplant and the owner of 12 Mile Limit, a new bar in the Mid-City neighborhood that doubles as Newton’s own private cocktail laboratory. “This place has been a bar for 90 years,” he says, “and after the storm it was under two feet of water.” The people who used to own the place, he added, “threw a lot of wild parties here.” Cocktails are the specialty now, immensely creative drinks that celebrate the bartending history of New Orleans while embracing a new influx of ideas and characters. “Everyone becomes a New Orleanian, if you give them long enough,” Newton says. “Miss your flight, you’ll be here five years”.

headline: A Building’s Fluid Forms
text: A look at the Guangzhou Opera House, designed by Zaha Hadid.

headline: TimesCast | July 5, 2011
text: American intelligence reports say Pakistan’s spy agency ordered a journalist's death; Casey Anthony’s trial was to Twitter as O.J. Simpson’s was to cable news; and a British tabloid’s phone hacking.

headline: Fireworks Lift NBC
text: NBC topped the ratings on Monday, a night of mostly repeats and holiday programming, as the annual “Macy’s Fourth of July Fireworks Spectacular” attracted its most viewers in 11 years. According to Nielsen’s estimates 8.6 million people tuned in to the NBC broadcast at 9 p.m., more than for any other program on the night and up from 6.9 million viewers a year ago. CBS ranked second for the night, leading the 10 p.m. hour with its own Fourth of July special, “Boston Pops Fireworks Spectacular,” which drew 6.6 million viewers, outperforming a repeat of NBC’s special in the hour (5.3 million) and a repeat of ABC’s “Extreme Makeover: Weight Loss Edition” (3 million). ABC, in third place, averaged 3.1 million viewers from 8 to 10 for a rerun of “The Bachelorette” while Fox was fourth with repeats of “MasterChef” (2.3 million) and “House” (1.5 million).

headline: Verizon to Drop Its Unlimited Mobile-Data Plan
text: On July 7, Verizon will become the third major mobile phone carrier to ditch its unlimited-data plan and go to tiered pricing, following AT&T and T-Mobile.

headline: Time Out to Enjoy All Things Phish
text: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y. — When your friend volunteers to work at a music festival in exchange for a ticket and ends up with the title of “Good Vibe Regulator” at a custom-built all-night disco bar modeled after a giant pinball machine, you know you’ve ended up someplace pretty cool. Last weekend that meant Super Ball IX, the ninth festival by Phish, the eclectically funky rock quartet.

headline: Team Players | Bergdorf Goodman and Pomellato
text: These days, high-low collaborations are almost second nature: Versace for H & M, Missoni for Target, Karl Lagerfeld for Macy’s. (Who doesn’t love the chance to purchase some Karl for a fraction of the price?) But two posh partners can produce a pretty sensational must-have, too: See Pomellato’s 12-piece exclusive collection for Bergdorf Goodman.

headline: Bike-Friendly? Check the City’s Mass Transit System
text: Two things about my colleague Christine Haughney’s article on the reluctance of New York-area women to become bicycle commuters were striking. One was the main reason cited: fear. (Excessive sweating followed.) The second was an accompanying  graphic with data from the Census Bureau’s American Community Survey indicating which cities have the most bike commuters and from an Australian study looking at gender differences in bike commuting.

headline: Smorgasburg
text: A new open-air food court and weekly market, Smorgasburg is a brand extension of the Brooklyn Flea, at East River Waterfront in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Q&A: Making the Most of an Evening in Milan
text: A friend and I will be spending a week in Venice in November. We will be flying home to New York City from Milan, and will have just one afternoon and evening there. Do you have any recommendations as to how to spend that short amount of time in Milan? What not to miss and where to have dinner?

headline: Brooklyn Market: Woodstock of Eating
text: SMORGASBURG, the open-air market held every Saturday in an empty lot on the Williamsburg waterfront, is like a summer rock festival for food: exciting, overwhelming, sweaty, hot. You’ll hit your limit, and then you’ll want more.

headline: Executive Pleads Guilty to Leaking Apple Secrets
text: A technology executive charged with leaking sensitive information about Apple products to hedge fund traders pleaded guilty on Tuesday in Manhattan, the latest guilty plea in the government’s crackdown on insider trading facilitated by so-called expert networks.

headline: Smorgasburg, How to Eat Through Saturday
text: Every Saturday, an empty lot on Williamsburg’s East River waterfront is transformed into Smorgasburg (a mash-up of smorgasbord and Williamsburg), an open-air food festival with more than 90 stands, over 50 of which sell stuff that’s ready to eat: chilled soups, grilled meats, Vietnamese salads, fresh juices, cold-brew coffee, ice cream in clever flavors, sesame noodles with a pedigree. In this week’s $25 and Under column, I call Smorgasburg “a fitting playground for a food-crazy generation that photographs what it eats.”

headline: Phish Fest at Watkins Glen
text: The eclectic funk rock quartet performed their ninth festival last week, called Super Ball IX.

headline: How to Be a Jerk
text: The owners of the Brooklyn Farmacy soda fountain in Cobble Hill demonstrate how to make a classic egg cream.

headline: A Star Sits, but a Nation Moves On
text: POTSDAM, Germany — The raging debate here over the star forward Birgit Prinz appeared all but settled Tuesday night.

headline: Just One Look | Chanel
text: Superbly romantic and resolutely urban, Karl Lagerfeld’s collection for Chanel haute couture was a celebration of nightfall and all its aesthetic offshoots: the shimmer of streetlights on cobblestones; the deep blues and purples that bow to black; the silent army of shadows. To make this clear he built a neon-lit model of the Place Vendome in the Grand Palais with Coco herself atop the obelisk. The clothes were sensational and womanly: jutting peplums, ankle grazing dresses and coats, gloves and boots to elongate every silhouette. Here, on Stella Tennant, a draped and tucked dress in black silk taffeta with a spine of crystal buttons.

headline: New York City Schools Allocation Memo
text: The memo details a new policy that will tie a school’s performance to the school’s ability to roll over money from one year to the next.

headline: For Soda, the Genie Is Out of the Bottle
text: WHO killed the soda fountain?

headline: Video Game Industry Continues Major Growth, Gartner Says
text: The video game industry is expected to continue growing at a  rapid pace for several years to come, with game-related spending reaching $112 billion by 2015, according to a report issued Tuesday by Gartner, the technology research company.

headline: Dodgers Are Pressing M.L.B. for Files in Bankruptcy Court
text: The Los Angeles Dodgers demanded on Tuesday that Major League Baseball turn over documents the team believes will show that baseball’s “abusive” treatment of the team led to its filing for bankruptcy.

headline: Tuesday at the Women’s World Cup
text: With the quarterfinalists in Groups A and B all but mathematically settled, Tuesday’s games were about pride and playoff seeding.

headline: Breast-Feeding in Niger
text: To the Editor:

headline: Politicians’ Children
text: To the Editor:

headline: Top Ten Fantasy Wide Receivers
text: Roddy White tops our list of fantasy football receivers for the 2011 season.

headline: Enough With the Delays: Why Wimbledon Switched to ESPN
text: ESPN’s new 12-year, nearly $500 million deal to carry Wimbledon was driven by the All England Club’s desire to have a single media entity carry the entire tournament and to show every match live — ending NBC’s past practice of tape delays.

headline: ‘Don’t Ask’ Policy Lingers
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Twists in the Strauss-Kahn Case
text: To the Editor:

headline: Just One Look | Givenchy
text: For Givenchy haute couture, Riccardo Tisci presented ten stunning floor-length dresses of intricately seamed sheer tulle decorated with lace, pailettes, beads or fringe. The inspirations for the collection were clouds, angels and birds of paradise, the latter reduced to a splattering of pearls on white tulle. Making all this fragile romance signature Tisci were the industrial sporty zippers connecting sleeves to bodices and snaking boldly up backs. Here, a nude dress encrusted exclusively with hand-cut nude tulle pailettes.

headline: Urban Fisherman
text: Ben Sargent is the star of a new Cooking Channel series that shows him fishing for and cooking his catch.

headline: In Hawking Seafood, He Reeled In a Show
text: THE morning began with a promising sign.

headline: U.S. to Prosecute a Somali Suspect in Civilian Court
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration announced Tuesday that it would prosecute in civilian court a Somali accused of ties to two Islamist militant groups. The decision to fly the man to New York for trial, after interrogating him for months aboard a United States naval vessel, is likely to reignite debate about the detention and prosecution of terrorism suspects.

headline: How 10,000 People Keep a Secret
text: THERE are picnics, and then there are picnics.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Fixing the Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: Dining Calendar
text: In Bucks County

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Pairings: Rosados and Duck
text: Can a rosé be macho? Appropriate for the guy mopping the ribs with sauce as they sizzle? Listen up before you grab that beer.

headline: Rosés of a Different Color
text: THE weather is hot, and, yes indeed, the wine is pink. If you have even the slightest doubt, let me assure you: rosé madness continues.

headline: A Soft Spot for Goat-Milk Ice Cream
text: The very notion of goat-milk ice cream is uncommon enough. But Sophia Brittan, below, churns into even more exotic territory with her Turkish-style goat-milk ice cream at Victory Garden, in Greenwich Village.

headline: Dressing Up Meat in Summer Coats
text: Spice rubs from Tom Douglas, a marquee chef in Seattle, have a deep complexity, thanks to some unusual ingredients like piri-piri, dried seaweed flakes, ground ancho chiles, sumac and dried citrus peels, which the average home cook might not be able to grab from the spice rack.

headline: A Skillet Is a Basket Is a Grill
text: Williams-Sonoma’s new perforated stainless-steel skillet, which resembles a wire basket, is not just another unnecessary grilling gimmick. You can use it to cook morsels of poultry, seafood, meat and vegetables like a stir-fry, or toss ingredients into it for ratatouille. Its smooth surface releases cooked foods, and it cleans more easily than mesh. A little oil, and you’ll get a bit of flame-up that enhances the pieces of food as they cook. The handle is removable so you can cover the grill while the food cooks or smokes. Other styles include a bigger chef’s pan and a roaster, but the skillet, or fry pan, as it is called, is the most practical.

headline: Yankees Say All Is Well as Rivera Sits
text: CLEVELAND — Mariano Rivera completed his normal throwing regimen Tuesday afternoon, but continued soreness in his right triceps sidelined him for a second consecutive game against the Indians. He said that the discomfort, just above his elbow, had subsided since Sunday, but that the head trainer, Gene Monahan, recommended he rest for at least another day.

headline: A Search Is Under Way for Tainted Sprout Seeds
text: Authorities are frantically trying to trace all of the tainted fenugreek seeds from a large shipment linked to a deadly E. coli outbreak in Europe, saying the product was distributed more widely than previously thought.

headline: Montana: Assessing Damage From Spill
text: Almost four days after an Exxon Mobil pipeline broke and spilled some 42,000 gallons of crude oil into the Yellowstone River, government officials and wildlife advocates struggled Tuesday to evaluate what the impact to water, birds and fish would be. Some 350 emergency personnel are working to ease the effects of the spill — absorbing pooled oil and conducting aerial flights to spot oiled birds and other damage. Alan Jeffers, an Exxon spokesman, said that so far, none of the towns that take drinking water from the river have stopped doing so. Amy Cilimburg, an organizer with the conservation group Montana Audubon, confirmed that few oiled birds had been spotted and said that the group was concerned about contaminants’ entering the food chain in the long term. The river rose above flood stage on Tuesday, arousing fears that the oil would be pushed into undamaged areas.

headline: Bloggingheads: A Moral Budget
text: Jim Wallis, left, of Sojourners and Richard Land of the Southern Baptist Convention debate the causes of the budget deficit.

headline: Some Pet Owners Judge Jeter Name Best in Show
text: In his 17 seasons in the Bronx, Derek Jeter cemented his legacy as one of the great Yankees. He is the team’s captain. He has five World Series rings. He entered Tuesday’s game six hits from becoming the first Yankee to join baseball’s 3,000-hit club.

headline: As a Deadline Approaches, N.F.L. Meetings Resume
text: Meetings between lawyers and staff for the N.F.L. and its players resumed Tuesday, with lawyers drafting language for a potential deal on certain issues. Among those present were people who are concerned with drug testing and how free agency would work.

headline: TimesCast | Online Reaction to Trial
text: Casey Anthony's trial has been to Twitter as O.J. Simpson's trial was to cable news.

headline: Acquittals of Ex-Officials Feed Anger Across Egypt
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian criminal court on Tuesday acquitted three former government ministers of corruption while convicting a fourth in absentia, verdicts most likely to further inflame public anger over the pace of efforts to hold former officials accountable for killing more than 800 people during the country’s 18-day revolution.

headline: Apologize? To Him? Unrepentant After Some Salty Words for Christie
text: Gov. Chris Christie’s office scolded the State Senate president on Tuesday for calling the governor names and saying he wanted to punch him. But the Senate leader, refusing to apologize, said Mr. Christie was in no position to complain about harsh language.

headline: Safeguarding Spent Nuclear Fuel
text: The Times's Matthew L. Wald looks at options for safely storing spent nuclear fuel as the American nuclear industry faces new scrutiny following the nuclear incident in Japan.

headline: A Safer Nuclear Crypt
text: MARSEILLES, Ill. — Watching intently as a huge white steel container surfaced from a 42-foot-deep canal, workers set upon it with long-handled tools, like sailors wrestling a flailing whale to the deck of a ship.

headline: Systematic Cheating Is Found in Atlanta’s School System
text: ATLANTA — A state investigation released Tuesday showed rampant, systematic cheating on test scores in this city’s long-troubled public schools, ending two years of increasing skepticism over remarkable improvements touted by school leaders.

headline: O’Reilly ‘Let It Fly’ on Her Spectacular World Cup Goal
text: Five players — none of them forwards — have scored goals for the United States national team through two games at the Women’s World Cup in Germany. None were as spectacular as the 25-yard frozen rope that exploded off Heather O’Reilly’s right foot in a 3-0 win against Colombia on Saturday.

headline: Iced Coffee Gets Its Day in the Sun
text: IN 2010, Americans ordered 500 million iced coffee drinks in restaurants and cafes, up from 400 million in 2006, according to data from the market research firm NPD Group.

headline: Opportunities at Home Reduce Illegal Immigration From Mexico
text: Economic, demographic and social changes in Mexico are suppressing illegal immigration as much as the poor economy or legal crackdowns in the United States.

headline: Antitax Extremism in Minnesota
text: How far will Republican lawmakers go to protect millionaires? Those who think a default on the federal government’s credit seems implausible should take a sobering look at the “closed” signs dotting Minnesota. The Republican Party there readily shut down the state’s government on Friday by refusing to raise taxes on the 7,700 Minnesotans who make more than $1 million a year.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Lawyers and Prosecution Meet to Discuss Dismissal or Plea Deal
text: Lawyers for Dominique Strauss-Kahn emerged from a meeting on Wednesday with Manhattan prosecutors, characterizing the session as “constructive.”

headline: Another Blow to Farmworkers
text: In California, once a national model of farmworker organizing and progressive labor laws, things have fallen far since the heyday of Cesar Chavez and the United Farm Workers. Of the more than 400,000 workers on 40,000 California farms, the union represents only a tiny share. It listed just 5,219 members in a report to the federal Department of Labor last year. Conditions in the fields and camps are as bad as ever, but the union is adrift and torn by a squalid battle over the movement’s future.

headline: The Greater Evil
text: Outrage is a word badly weakened by overuse. This is unfortunate because it would be good to have now, at full strength, for the despicable things the British tabloid News of the World is accused of doing to a murdered 13-year-old girl, Milly Dowler, and to her family and friends.

headline: In Making a Big Leap, Many Helping Hands
text: ATLANTA — When Ralph Boston rehearsed the long jump form that would win him three Olympic medals in the 1960s, he needed only some flat terrain and a soft place to land.

headline: Opportunities at Home Reduce Illegal Immigration From Mexico
text: Thanks in part to new economic and educational opportunities in Mexico, the extraordinary flow of migrants that delivered millions of illegal immigrants to the United States over the past 30 years has sputtered to a halt.

headline: For Mexicans Looking North, a New Calculus Favors Home
text: Economic, demographic and social changes in Mexico are suppressing illegal immigration as much as the poor economy or legal crackdowns in the United States.

headline: American Artist Who Scribbled a Unique Path
text: Cy Twombly, whose spare, childlike scribbles and poetic engagement with antiquity left him stubbornly out of step with the movements of postwar American art even as he became one of the era’s most important painters, died on Tuesday in Rome. He was 83.

headline: Preserving Health Coverage for the Poor
text: The poor and disabled people who rely on Medicaid to pay their medical bills could be in grave jeopardy in this sour I’ve-got-mine political climate.

headline: Building a More Inclusive Work Force
text: In recent years, there has been a dramatic rise in the diagnosis of autism spectrum disorders (A.S.D.). The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that 730,000 people in the U.S. under age 21 have an A.S.D. It’s much harder to estimate the number of adults on the autism spectrum because only in recent decades has the condition been regularly diagnosed.

headline: Still a Case for Trying Strauss-Kahn
text: What is so wrong with the original plan to hold a trial for Dominique Strauss-Kahn to decide if he committed an act of sexual violence against a hotel housekeeper?

headline: Greek Finance Minister Moves From Crisis to Crisis
text: ATHENS — As he approached the end of another 16-hour workday, Evangelos Venizelos had one question on his mind: Will Europe come up with the money that Greece so desperately needs? As the new Greek finance minister, Mr. Venizelos is the man in charge of steering a nearly bankrupt economy back on track — and, perhaps, preventing another global financial crisis.

headline: Mika Myllyla, Olympic Skier in Doping Scandal, Dies at 41
text: Mika Myllyla, a Finnish Olympic gold medalist and winner of three world championships in cross-country skiing whose career crashed after he was caught up in a doping scandal in 2001, was found dead on Tuesday in his apartment in Kokkola, Finland. He was 41.

headline: America’s Birthday Under Fire
text: July 4, 1861 dawned on a divided America, and the holiday itself became a battleground. Across the country, businesses closed, salutes were fired, and people picnicked, but in the South celebrations were unusually restrained. “The Fourth of July passed very quietly here,” reported Sarah Lois Wadley, a Louisiana teenager, “my mind was so much occupied by other things that I had almost forgotten the day.” Wadley approved: “I think that the day should have been observed with unusual strictness, but it is but natural and right that the feeling should have been more of sober thankfulness and religious prayer than of noisy joy.”

headline: For Mets, a Tough Task Awaits
text: LOS ANGELES —  Terry Collins was looking through a collection of statistical analyses on Tuesday, checking over certain matchups that his team would be facing over the next several games, when it hit him.

headline: Obama Summons G.O.P. and Democratic Leaders for Deficit Reduction Talks
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama stepped up pressure on Congressional Republicans on Tuesday to agree to a broad deficit-cutting deal, pledging to put popular entitlement programs like Medicare on the table in return for Republican acquiescence to some higher taxes.

headline: N.B.A. Disputes Forbes Analysis Suggesting League is Profitable
text: In a statement e-mailed to The Times, Tim Frank, a spokesman for the National Basketball Association, has disputed an analysis by Forbes Magazine suggesting that the N.B.A. turned a $183 million operating profit in its 2009-10 season. Instead, according to Mr. Frank, the league lost $340 million that year and has lost money every year during the current collective bargaining agreement.

headline: 4 Rangers Headed for Arbitration
text: Four Rangers restricted free agents elected to go to salary arbitration Tuesday after failing to reach agreement with the club by the 5 p.m. deadline.

headline: Immigration Upended | Staying Home
text: According to academic research, the likelihood of Mexicans coming to the United States has fallen to a historic low. Members of the Orozco family talk about their decisions to make the journey or not.

headline: Migrant Voices | Antonio
text: Antonio Orozco recounts crossing the U.S.-Mexico border in his youth, and explains how the experience differs for his sons today.

headline: Migrant Voices | Angel
text: Angel Orozco describes his life as a student in Arandas, Mexico, and explains why he sees no need to attempt the dangerous trek across the U.S.-Mexico border.

headline: Migrant Voices | Andrés
text: Andrés Orozco compares job prospects in the United States with those of his native Arandas, Mexico.

headline: Zuckerberg Finds Fans on Google+
text: Any guesses as to who is the most popular person on Google+, the company’s new social networking service? Ashton Kutcher, perhaps? Or Lady Gaga?

headline: Gaza: Israeli Missile Strike Kills Two
text: An Israeli missile strike killed two Palestinians and wounded a third in central Gaza on Tuesday, according to a medical spokesman for the Hamas-led government there. The Israeli military said the victims had been preparing to fire a rocket at Israel and were believed to be members of an Islamic extremist group. Hamas and Israel have largely adhered to an unofficial cease-fire since the spring, but the Israeli military said three rockets had been fired from Gaza into Israeli territory this week.

headline: Brawl Erupts During Impeachment Talks in Afghan Parliament
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Members of the Afghan Parliament came to blows Tuesday as a majority for the first time began to discuss impeaching President Hamid Karzai, signaling the near-total breakdown of relations between the Parliament and the president as the country teeters on the brink of a constitutional crisis.

headline: Italy: Austerity Measure Withdrawn
text: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on Tuesday withdrew a disputed clause of the country’s austerity bill that would have allowed one of his family’s companies to temporarily avoid a heavy fine in a legal dispute. Under the measure, part of the $68 billion bill, companies could ask that especially high fines be suspended as long as appeals were pending. Fininvest, the Berlusconis’ holding company for family assets, was fined $1.09 billion in 2009 for bribery, and a decision by a Milan appeals court is expected this week. Mr. Berlusconi said the measure was “necessary” to protect “companies and citizens.”

headline: The Art of Cy Twombly
text: Cy Twombly’s career slyly subverted Abstract Expressionism, toyed briefly with Minimalism, seemed barely to acknowledge Pop art and anticipated some of the concerns of Conceptualism.

headline: Big Business Leaves Deficit to Politicians
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Watching a Trial on TV, Discussing It on Twitter
text: As the lawyers for Casey Anthony gathered at a restaurant in Orlando, Fla., on Tuesday afternoon, two hours after a jury found their client not guilty of killing her daughter, Caylee, the television host Nancy Grace was sequestered in a studio one block away, delivering her own verdict of sorts.

headline: Before You Judge, Stand in Her Shoes
text: New Haven

headline: Wednesday: Like Much Social Interaction Nowadays
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — This was not an easy puzzle to construct, I’m telling you that right now.

headline: France: Strauss-Kahn Formally Accused
text: A lawyer said Tuesday that he had mailed a criminal complaint to the Paris prosecutor’s office accusing Dominique Strauss-Kahn of attempting to rape the novelist Tristane Banon in 2003. After Mr. Strauss-Kahn, the former chief of the International Monetary Fund, was arrested in New York in May on a similar charge, Ms. Banon hired the lawyer, David Koubbi. When prosecutors receive the complaint, an investigative judge would be appointed to look into the allegations. Mr. Strauss-Kahn’s lawyers have said that Ms. Banon’s accusations are “imaginary.”

headline: In Reversal, Schools Doing Well Can Keep Unspent Funds
text: Tying student achievement and school financing in a new way, the city’s schools chancellor has reversed an unpopular move by his predecessor, allowing individual principals to roll over all the money they save from one year to the next — but only if their schools perform well on the city’s controversial progress reports.

headline: ‘You’re Making Me the Bride?’ a Hiccup for Gay Unions
text: As he got ready for work on Tuesday, Fredy H. Kaplan, a 5-foot-9, 160-pound gay rights activist from the East Village, turned to his 6-foot-1, 250-pound fiancé and made it official. “You’re going to be the bride,” he said.

headline: City Workers’ Bias Suits Rise, Despite Softer Bloomberg Tone
text: The number of discrimination cases filed by city employees in New York has risen even as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has adopted a far less adversarial tone than his predecessor did in dealing with the city’s vast work force.

headline: Reader Q. and A.: Upending Immigration in Mexico
text: Updated Damien Cave’s answers to readers’ Questions can be found here.

headline: M.T.A. Crew in a Cavern Has an Eye on Sept. 11
text: Any observer walking around ground zero is surrounded by signs of progress: 1 World Trade Center has slowly but surely reached the 70th floor, its frame partly wrapped in glass; 4 World Trade Center stretches about 30 stories above its base; and the World Trade Center memorial looks ready to meet its Sept. 11 opening deadline.

headline: The Twitter Zone
text: WASHINGTON

headline: The Art of Cy Twombly
text: Cy Twombly’s career slyly subverted Abstract Expressionism, toyed briefly with Minimalism, seemed barely to acknowledge Pop art and anticipated some of the concerns of Conceptualism.

headline: Struggling for Power in Afghanistan
text: THE Western campaign for hearts and minds in Afghanistan is based heavily on providing roads, dams, buildings and, especially, electricity. The United States Agency for International Development, or U.S.A.I.D., expects to spend $2.1 billion this year in Afghanistan. It has been working there for half a century, since the Soviets and Americans were competing to be the country’s development partners.

headline: Why Exercise Makes Us Feel Good
text: Why does exercise make us happy and calm? Almost everyone agrees that it generally does, a conclusion supported by research. A survey by Norwegian researchers published this month, for instance, found that those who engaged in any exercise, even a small amount, reported improved mental health compared with Norwegians who, despite the tempting nearness of mountains and fjords, never got out and exercised. A separate study, presented last month at the annual meeting of the American College of Sports Medicine, showed that six weeks of bicycle riding or weight training eased symptoms in women who’d received a diagnosis of anxiety disorder. The weight training was especially effective at reducing feelings of irritability, perhaps (and this is my own interpretation) because the women felt capable now of pounding whomever or whatever was irritating them.

headline: Angel Investors Learning to Assess Business Plans
text: In April, I wrote about the Pipeline Fund Fellowship, which is training its inaugural group of 10 female fellows to become angel investors. Since then, the fellows have moved several steps closer to choosing the business that will receive their pooled resources of $50,000. During a daylong event held last month at Eileen Fisher headquarters in Irvington, N.Y., they heard pitches from 10 start-ups seeking financing and narrowed the field to three. Of those, one will be chosen to receive the $50,000.

The move raised fears that Spain and Italy might soon find themselves in the line of fire, too.

Pat Burrell, the San Francisco Giants’ left fielder, and Javier Lopez, a relief pitcher, play cards at a prime spot in the center of the room, exercising their veterans’ prerogative. A few younger teammates idly watch the television on the wall.

headline: Would You Like Some Dog Food With Your Diapers?

headline: Rhino Poaching Threatens Conservation Gains
text: Twenty years of careful conservation efforts have nurtured rhinoceros populations in Africa back to relative health, after they were close to extinction in the early 1990s. Now those efforts risk being undone because of a sharp increase in poaching.

headline: The Dark Art of ‘Breaking Bad’
text: In the first three seasons of the AMC series “Breaking Bad,” Aaron Paul — or rather, his meth-dealing character, Jesse Pinkman — has been slapped, mauled and beaten purple by, respectively, a hit man, a sociopath and a federal drug-enforcement agent. If he were a piñata, the candy would have poured out of this guy long ago. And apparently there is little mercy for Paul in the new season on the way. For there Paul was, one day in late May, standing on Tijeras Avenue in downtown Albuquerque, being tasered by a brawny man in sunglasses.

headline: Why Caylee’s Death Is Personal
text: I was in a doctor’s examination room yesterday, waiting for a specialist I had never met. She swept in at 2:30 and didn’t say hello, or ask me what I was there for. Instead she blurted, “Did you hear the verdict?” and we discussed the case for 10 minutes.

headline: A Fount of Soda Knowledge
text: When I was researching the history of the American soda fountain for my story this week, all roads led to Gregory Cohen, probably the country’s leading expert on the institution. Mr. Cohen, 43, grew up in Midwood in Brooklyn, frequenting Chodosh’s corner store and soda fountain (long closed, it was a fount of egg creams and memories that now has its own Facebook page. If you grew up drinking ginger yips, he knows that you are probably from Georgia, and on top of that he will mix you one at his soda fountain, Lofty Pursuits, in Tallahassee, Fla. (It’s a combination of ginger syrup, soda water, and vanilla ice cream.) His masterwork is a complete taxonomy of soda fountain drinks, compiled from a lifetime of interviews and research in antique manuals like “Ice Cream at the Soda Fountain,” a two-volume set published by the United States Department of Commerce soon after Prohibition went into effect. To learn the precise difference between a milkshake and a malted, an ice cream soda and a French soda, an ade and a fizz, follow the “flow chart.”

headline: Picasso Work Is Stolen From San Francisco Gallery
text: No bigger than a standard sheet of paper, Picasso’s “Tête de Femme (Head of a Woman)” is hardly one of his largest works, but that apparently made it all the easier for a thief to steal it from a gallery in San Francisco on Tuesday. The San Francisco Chronicle reported that the work, a 1965 pencil drawing measuring 10 5/8 inches by 8 1/4 inches, was taken from the Weinstein Gallery in the city’s Union Square neighborhood; the robbery was reported to the police at 11:41 a.m. and the work was being offered by the gallery for more than $200,000.

headline: World, Not Ended
text: QE2 — “quantitative easing 2″, the Fed’s program of buying long-term bonds — ended last week. For a program that arguably did very little, QE2 attracted an amazing amount of vitriol. On one side, it was accused of fomenting “currency wars”, driving up inflation and/or exchange rates in developing countries. On the other, it was claimed that the program was masking the true effects of the US budget deficit, and that interest rates would soar after it ended.

headline: When Grown-Ups Went to See Films About Grown-Ups
text: Of the many notable things about “Kramer vs. Kramer” — nine Oscar nominations, five wins — perhaps the most surprising is this: It was the highest-grossing film of 1979. To repeat: “Kramer vs. Kramer,” a film about a divorce, was the highest-grossing film released that year. (To be fair, the fifth-highest-grossing film released that year was about a man going insane in Vietnam.) To further illustrate how tastes in blockbusters have, er, evolved, here are the five top-grossing films of 1979 and the five top-grossing films of 2010.

headline: The Divorce Delusion
text: In the summer of 1979, six months before the Oscar-winning divorce drama “Kramer vs. Kramer” hit the theaters, my mother foreshadowed Joanna Kramer’s abrupt departure by moving out of our house. She’d been told by a priest that this was the best strategy for saving her marriage, so she left not so much to find herself (like Meryl Streep’s character) as to find a job, something my father (like Dustin Hoffman’s Ted Kramer) had strictly forbidden her to do.

And while all the world’s a stage, the stage will not serve as a butcher’s block when the play is presented in New York: the Royal Shakespeare Company says it has excised the rabbit-skinning scene for its Lincoln Center Festival residency.

headline: Just One Look | Valentino
text: Talk about transparency: the Valentino haute couture collection was not only primarily based on tulle and lace, but Maria Grazia Chiuri and Pierpaolo Piccioli, the designers at the helm of the house, also informed the audience of the number of hours it took the atelier to render their light as air creations. Those precious embroideries and appliques take hundreds of hours of handwork. The results? My god. As exquisite a set of dresses as a princess could wish for, especially a youngish princess with a hankering for 30s/70s long lengths, raised waists, and all grown-up grooviness. Here, a dress of gold lace inset into tulle with a dusting of hand painted feathers in violet, rose and amber (to paint the feathers? 215 hours).

headline: Only 4 Fliers for Last Shuttle Launch
