text: A view of the day in sports, with joy in South Korea and crashes in France.

headline: On Day of Crashes, British Rider Overtakes a Pack at the Finish
text: After a carnage-filled afternoon along the craggy coast of Brittany, Mark Cavendish, a Briton racing for the HTC-Highroad team, reclaimed his status as one of the fastest men on two wheels after a frustrating start to the 2011 Tour de France.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Spain and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Spain, Greece and Nepal.

headline: Creamer Set to Defend Her Open Title
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — Paula Creamer grew nostalgic as she packed the trunk locker. It was a time for reflection, to revel in what she had achieved but also to close the lid on the past and move on.

headline: Now Screening | Gaultier Couture
text: Our runway video of the haute couture collection from Gaultier.

headline: The Caucus Click: Surf’s Up in Iowa for Pawlenty
text: Tim Pawlenty brought his campaign to the Surf Ballroom, site of Buddy Holly’s last concert, in Clear Lake, Iowa.

headline: Obama Takes Questions From His Tweeps
text: President Obama has begun taking questions from his Tweeps.

headline: An Artist of Selective Abandon
text: With the death on Tuesday in Rome of Cy Twombly at the age of 83, postwar American painting has lost a towering and inspirational talent. Although he tended to be overshadowed by two of his closest colleagues — Robert Rauschenberg and Jasper Johns — Mr. Twombly played an equally significant role in opening pathways beyond the high-minded purity and frequent machismo of Abstract Expressionism, the dominant painting style in the late 1940s and ‘50s, when the three men entered the New York art world.

headline: The Caucus | Debt Ceiling Deadline Nears
text: As debt negotiations enter what could be the final stretch, John Harwood and Michael D. Shear discuss the political landscape, and Op-Ed columnist Ross Douthat discusses Republicans' strategy.

headline: Walcott Limits Money Schools Can Roll Over
text: Math conundrum: When is 70 percent more than 100 percent?

headline: Facebook Offers Video Chat in Arrangement With Skype
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Hoping to give its users a more intimate way to stay in touch, Facebook on Wednesday introduced video chatting inside its online social network through a deal with Skype, the Internet calling service.

headline: Simpler Fish Held On Long Past Jaws’ Arrival
text: It was not until the Devonian period, about 420 million years ago, that fish evolved jaws; before that, fish had to suck in their prey with their mouths.

headline: Jeter Will Play, Chase More Hits Against Indians
text: CLEVELAND -– Derek Jeter’s pursuit of 3,000 hits will continue uninterrupted. He will start at shortstop and hit leadoff Wednesday night against the Indians, despite strong hints from Manager Joe Girardi that he would receive the day off. Jeter said after Tuesday’s game, when he went 2 for 6 to draw within four hits of the milestone, that he very much wanted to play Wednesday.

headline: Claire Cain Miller on Google's social network; cybersecurity awareness; news.
text: Battle of the giants? Google is launching a new social network that aims to be different from Facebook's. Bettina Edelstein speaks with Times technology reporter Claire Cain Miller about what's in store and what's at stake. Security experts recently met at the White House about an ongoing cybersecurity campaign. J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Trend Micro's David Perry about what's happening on that front. The news roundup includes hacks on an Apple server and the FoxNews Twitter feed; the Qosimo 3D laptop from Toshiba; the disappearance of Google's Realtime Search; and crowd sourcing to manage traffic when a 10-mile stretch of highway shuts down for 53 hours in Los Angeles. J.D.'s tip of the week: how to print your address book.

headline: George Lang, Mastermind Behind Café des Artistes, Dies at 86
text: George Lang, a restaurateur and cookbook writer who in the 1970s transformed Café des Artistes into one of New York’s most romantic, beloved dining spots and in the 1990s helped restore the historic Budapest restaurant Gundel to its former glory, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Stressed and Depressed, Koreans Avoid Therapy
text: SEOUL — It can sometimes feel as if South Korea, overworked, overstressed and ever anxious, is on the verge of a national nervous breakdown, with a rising divorce rate, students who feel suffocated by academic pressures, a suicide rate among the highest in the world and a macho corporate culture that still encourages blackout drinking sessions after work.

headline: Video: The Debt Ceiling Deadline Nears
text: As debt negotiations enter what could be the final stretch, John Harwood and Michael D. Shear discuss the political landscape, and Ross Douthat, a Times op-ed columnist, looks at the Republicans’ strategy.

headline: In Michigan, a Venerable Lincoln Dealer Puts a Lock on the Door
text: Metropolitan Lincoln, a dealership in Garden City, Mich., is closing after more than 50 years of business. Located less than 10 miles from Ford Motor Company headquarters in Dearborn, Mich., the dealership historically has been among the sales leaders for Ford’s Lincoln brand and the discontinued Mercury brand.

headline: To Lake Tseny by Oxcart
text: John S. Sparks, curator of ichthyology at the American Museum of Natural History, writes from Madagascar, where he is studying native freshwater fish.

headline: Spritzenhaus
text: WHAT distinguishes Spritzenhaus in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, from the dozens of other beer gardens in the city? For starters, the owners call it a beer hall. Instead of an outdoor garden with some foliage poking through, you get a giant indoor shell with industrial metal stools, exposed brick and subway tiles. Furthermore, the chef, Rolf Weithofer, formerly of Prime Meats, serves semiformal fare like cider-glazed pork bellies and salads sourced from the nearby Eagle Street Rooftop Farm.

headline: Immigration Upended: Damien Cave Answers Readers’ Questions
text: 2:20 p.m. | Updated  Leer el artículo en español aquí: http://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/07/world/americas/immigration-en-espanol.html.

headline: Shades of John Lennon, or a Professor
text: STILL defiantly hanging on to those aviator sunglasses? Well, you’re now on notice. This summer, the shape of shades has come full circle. Round sunglasses, by now a two-year-old trend for women, have finally been embraced by men.

headline: U.S. Adds Body Bombs to Concerns on Air Travel
text: WASHINGTON — Air security is expected to tighten, particularly for international flights into the United States, in light of recent intelligence that terrorists might be considering boarding flights with surgically implanted explosive devices, an American security official said Wednesday.

headline: In Provence, an 18th-century Farmhouse With a Pool
text: A four-bedroom restored farmhouse in Provence is on the market for $2.67 million.

headline: Now Screening | Gaultier Couture
text: Our runway video of the haute couture collection from Gaultier.

headline: July 6, 1957 | Althea Gibson Becomes First Black Player to Win Wimbledon
text: On July 6, 1957, Althea Gibson became the first black tennis player to win Wimbledon. Gibson also won the women’s doubles championship later in the day.

headline: Living Together Pays Off More for the College-Educated
text: Living together outside of marriage can carry economic benefits. But the payoff seems to be much higher for those with college degrees than those without, says a new study from the Pew Research Center.

headline: House Hunting in ... Provence
text: A FOUR-BEDROOM RESTORED FARMHOUSE WITH A SWIMMING POOL IN PROVENCE

headline: Inside Track | Rafael Medina’s Madrid
text: Rafael Medina, 20th Duke of Feria and Marquis of Villalba, is no stranger to titles. He has been called Spain’s Best Dressed Man and Europe’s Most Eligible Bachelor (though he dropped that last title in October when he married Laura Vecino in a ceremony spread across more than 90 pages of Hola!). His latest distinction is that of fashion arbiter: Scalpers, his line of bespoke suits and shirts and Euro preppy accessories, has blossomed into a mini-empire of 12 stores and kicked off a craze in Spain for embroidered opera slippers and bright handkerchiefs. ‘‘I think everybody should feel comfortable wearing a bold pocket square,’’ says the democratizing duke, who was raised in Seville but now lives in Madrid. Here are a few of his standby spots in the capital.

headline: Scene City: Shark Attack Sounds
text: Has Montauk lost its cool or is it more fun? That question hung in the salty air on July 2 at the annual Shark Attack Sounds party.

headline: China’s Bizarre Food ‘Safety’ Scene, and Our Own
text: Almost all of the attention we’ve paid to food safety in recent weeks has been fixed on the deadly E. coli outbreak in Germany. And justifiably so. But if you happen to have taken a peek at China in the last few months you would have seen an eye-popping string of food safety oddities culminating in the state-sponsored suppression of journalists.

headline: Paramount Creates Big-Screen Cartoon Unit
text: Paramount Pictures took a big step toward the big-screen cartoon business on Wednesday — ratcheting up a rivalry with one of its business partners, DreamWorks Animation, in the process — by establishing an in-house unit devoted to the genre.

headline: Nothing Scary About These Sharks
text: HAS Montauk lost its cool or is it more fun?

headline: A Dance, and More, to Romare Bearden
text: Romare Bearden, born 100 years ago this Sept. 2, inspired artists in many disciplines, including dance. On Thursday an excerpt from “On the Block,” a ballet based on the stories evoked in Bearden’s six-panel collage, “The Block,” will be performed by dancers from the Nanette Bearden Contemporary Dance Theater at the Oberia D. Dempsey Multi-Service Center in Harlem.

headline: Homes for $529,000
text: A house in Nevada City, Calif., and condos in Denver and Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Cravath to Hire Antitrust Chief
text: Christine A. Varney, the government’s top antitrust lawyer, is leaving the Justice Department to join Cravath, Swaine & Moore as a partner, representatives of the law firm confirmed on Wednesday.

headline: What You Get for ... $529,000
text: CAMBRIDGE, MASS.

headline: The Modern Apothecaries
text: THESE days, even mainstream beauty creams sometimes make such improbable claims that they might as well be swarthy Lotharios (think Nivea’s My Silhouette!, whose maker was fined $900,000 last week by the Federal Trade Commission for suggesting that consumers could slim down just by applying it).

headline: TimesCast | July 6, 2011
text: Britain's phone-hacking scandal; Dominique Strauss-Kahn's lawyers meet with prosecutors; and the Roger Clemens trial begins.

headline: U.S. and Mexico Sign Trucking Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Mexican truckers will be able to carry goods deep into the United States, and vice versa, under a deal signed Wednesday in Mexico City to keep a 17-year-old promise.

headline: George Lang, Creator of Romance Who Lived Through a Nightmare
text: William Grimes recalls the life of George Lang, owner for a quarter century of the former Café des Artistes. Mr. Lang died on Tuesday at the age of 86. He escaped the horrors of his native Hungary in World War II, after losing his parents in Auschwitz. In 1975, he took over the Upper West Side restaurant mainly known for its Howard Chandler Christy murals of naked nymphs. As Mr. Grimes noted in a 2003 review, the restaurant had its ups and downs, but at its best, it could be one of the city’s best-loved and most romantic restaurants.

headline: Wireless, Not Wimpy, Speakers
text: Modern technology is great and all, but it’s still studded with pain points. Just ask anyone who’s ever tried to set up a home network, to send a video by e-mail or to maintain a phone call driving down I-95.

headline: Watches Are Rediscovered by the Cellphone Generation
text: MICHAEL WILLIAMS, who runs A Continuous Lean, a men’s style blog, ditched his Timex when he got his first cellphone in 2001.

headline: Congressman Supports Melting-Pot Museum
text: Representative James P. Moran, a Virginia Democrat who is concerned about the propagation of ethnic museums on the National Mall in Washington, sees a possible antidote: a National Museum of the American People, dedicated, in the words of a resolution Mr. Moran plans to introduce in the House, to celebrating all immigrants, “from the very first to the most recent.”

headline: For Obama, Brevity Is Not the Soul of Twitter
text: The one thing that President Obama’s Twitter town hall was not? A test of his ability to answer in 140 characters.

headline: U.N. Women’s Agency Publishes Sobering Report on Lack of Gender Equality
text: PARIS — Most countries still do not explicitly criminalize rape within marriage, according to a sweeping United Nations report of global women’s rights published Wednesday.

headline: Spain Confronts Decades of Pain Over Lost Babies
text: SEVILLE, Spain — Prodded by grieving parents, Spanish judges are investigating hundreds of charges that infants were abducted and sold for adoption over a 40-year period. What may have begun as political retaliation for leftist families during the dictatorship of Gen. Francisco Franco appears to have mutated into a trafficking business in which doctors, nurses and even nuns colluded with criminal networks.

headline: Scorecard | Givenchy Wins!
text: It appears to Scorecard that a guy named Gil isn’t the only homme nostalgic for 1920s Paris this summer. At midnight — OK, 10 P.M. — Tuesday, Kaiser Karl dazzled at Chanel with a bouclé memory trip down the Rue Cambon. Yet when it comes to reaching new celestial heights, ever-rising star Riccardo Tisci and his petits mains at the Givenchy atelier had the most intricate crystals and dégradé pearls stitched down.

headline: Taliban Fighters Attack Afghan Police Posts
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban fighters attacked and overran several Afghan border police posts on Wednesday, killing nearly two dozen police officers in a remote area of northeastern Afghanistan, according to the provincial governor.

headline: Increase in Measles Cases
text: An increase in the number of measles outbreaks in Europe, Asia and Africa in recent months is cause for concern at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in the United States. Candice Burns Hoffmann, a press officer for the center, said in a release that the United States was experiencing “the highest number of measles cases since 1996,” in large part because of unvaccinated travelers recently returned from overseas.

headline: Video of British Debate on Hacking Scandal
text: As my colleagues Sarah Lyall and Alan Cowell report, during a debate in the House of Commons on Wednesday, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain agreed that there should be a public inquiry into the workings of the British newspapers following reports that journalists for The News of the World hacked into the voice mailboxes of murder and terrorism victims.

headline: Casey Anthony Verdict Brings HLN Record Ratings
text: The conclusion of the Casey Anthony trial in Florida prompted spikes in television viewership on Tuesday, especially for the cable news channel HLN, which drew its biggest total audience in its 29-year-old history.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Spain and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Spain, Greece and Nepal.

headline: On Location | Paris
text: A young couple on a tight budget renovate a two-bedroom apartment with a gallery-like aesthetic.

headline: Please, Go to Sleep
text: Bedtime gives us some of our best parenting memories, and some of our worst. There are nights when “The Children’s Hour,” as Longfellow dubbed it, is the sweet, warm essence of all the reasons you had children, but also nights, as Adam Mansbach’s satirical best seller has captured, when you would give anything for them to “Go the ____ to Sleep.”

headline: ‘America’s Got Talent’ Gets Plenty of Viewers
text: “America’s Got Talent” attracted its third-largest audience ever on Tuesday as the latest two-hour installment of the NBC reality competition drew 15.5 million viewers and dominated the night’s ratings, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Only the show’s two previous season finales, in 2010 and 2009, garnered more viewers.

headline: Options Abound to Protect the iPad
text: It dawned on me three months after buying an iPad 2 that keeping the tablet encased in its original clear packing sleeve was a bit like having my living room furniture covered in plastic: practical, yet tacky.

headline: Literature Can Turn Most Lethal
text: The setting: a college classroom in Vermont. The year: 1994. The topic: Unraveling a Literary Mystery. The professor: the most brilliant man in captivity, and he actually is in captivity, confined to prison for the 1982 murders of two female students. If Dr. Richard Aldiss reminds you of Dr. Hannibal Lecter, you are as smart as the nine super-special students in this class.

headline: Boating Apps Help Sailors Get There and Back Again
text: Compact GPS devices have transformed boating, helping sailors and fishing enthusiasts find their way to port.

headline: Citroëns to Rally Through New York for Bastille Day Celebration
text: For this last Sunday’s Auto Ego in the Automobiles section, I accompanied Alain Daumas and his family as he steered their 1955 Citroën Traction Avant through Times Square, fulfilling a longtime dream of his, where the car attracted as many gape-mouthed stares and clicking cameras as the surrounding towers and billboards.

headline: ‘Senator Pothole’ Encounters One
text: Senator Pothole came thisclose to being done in by a real one on Tuesday — a tire-destroying, rim-ruining pothole along the Brooklyn-Queens border that he said was “the size of Battery Park.”

headline: In Paris, a Home Far From the Tourist Center
text: PARIS — When Tom Budding and his girlfriend, Julia Jeuvell, decided to move to Paris from London in 2008, they were faced with two options: either live in a cramped apartment in the heart of Paris, or explore the dodgier neighborhoods in the city’s hinterlands for more space and value.

headline: A Hilltop Cottage in Nova Scotia
text: Eliot and Alexandra Angle in their summer home in Chimney Corner, Cape Breton, Nova Scotia.

headline: Obama Averaged 2,099 Characters in His Twitter Answers
text: It took President Obama 3,111 characters to answer the question put to him by House Speaker John A. Boehner in just 19: “Where are the jobs?”

headline: All Greek To Him
text: I’ve been complaining for a while about the Hellenization of economic discourse — the way everyone is being treated as being just like Greece, when in fact Greece — with a long history of fiscal irresponsibility, very high public debt, and a country without a currency — doesn’t bear much resemblance even to the other peripheral Europeans, let alone the United States.

headline: Canadian Doctor Tied to Professional Athletes Guilty of Drug Charge
text: BUFFALO — A Canadian doctor pleaded guilty Wednesday to a felony charge of bringing misbranded and unapproved drugs into the United States to treat high-profile athletes recovering from injuries, sometimes with substances banned by their sport and seen as potentially performance enhancing.

headline: Digital Music Leads Boost in Record Sales
text: What’s the biggest surprise in the music industry this year? Music sales are actually up for the first time since 2004.

headline: Just One Look | Gaultier
text: O.K., it’s actually two looks this time.

headline: Romney Holds London Fund-Raiser
text: LONDON — Mitt Romney told reporters outside a lavish town house in the heart of the upscale Mayfair neighborhood on Wednesday evening that he was “meeting a few friends” while in London. The invitation from his campaign to attend an evening reception, on a street where a house was listed recently for $26 million, was more candid: “Suggested contribution to Romney for President: $2,500 per person.”

headline: Sirens, Trucks’ Gears and Piano Melodies in the Great Outdoors
text: Talk about “sounds of the city.” On Friday night I had one of those only-in-New-York experiences, a mix of musical gratification and urban racket.

headline: Sentence of the Month Bonanza Throwdown Showdown
text: Once again, it’s time for our monthly clash of the titans, a battle of semantic juggernauts — a sweat-drenched, take-no-prisoners, blood-guzzling thumb-wrestling match between the best of all the immortal clauses I happened to read and tweet in June. It’s the historic fourth edition of Shamblanderson’s Sentence of the Month Bonanza Throwdown Showdown. The stakes, as always, are suffocatingly high. This month’s winner will face off at the end of the year with Joe DiMaggio, David Foster Wallace, Bill McKibben and others in Shamblanderson’s Too-Big-To-Even-Be-Believed Best Sentence of the Year Bare-Knuckle Apocalyptic Imbroglio Faceoff. (I’m looking into making this a live event at Yankee Stadium or Madison Square Garden. I’ll pass on details as soon as I have them.)

headline: Becoming One of the ‘Relevant’
text: ON a recent Friday night, Bebe Zeva, a teenage fashion blogger, journalist and model based in Las Vegas, was dining at the restaurant Lodge in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, with a group of 20-something contributors to the online magazine Thought Catalog.

headline: There’s a Busy New Bank Robber, the Police Suspect
text: Some three months after the authorities captured the so-called Holiday Bandit and charged him with robbing nine banks, the police said another prolific bank robber was on the loose in the city.

headline: Libyan Rebels Gain Inches Toward Link to Tripoli
text: QAWALISH, Libya — Rebels opposed to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi seized control of this village in the mountains on Wednesday, extending their hold in western Libya and inching toward a supply route to the capital that they hope to sever.

headline: Long Wait for Premiere of Long Play by Ibsen
text: LONDON — Of the roughly two dozen major plays by Henrik Ibsen, it was not masterpieces like “Hedda Gabler” and “A Doll’s House” that he described as his most important work. Rather it was the little-known “Emperor and Galilean” of 1873, a deeply personal reckoning with powerlessness that foreshadowed his famous domestic plays, but whose daunting structure — nine hours long, dozens of characters — led Ibsen to classify it as closet drama, meant to be read in private.

headline: Feiffer’s Dancer Returns to Leap Ever So Seriously
text: The ebullient, emotional dancer first came to the public’s attention in 1957. Year after year she was moved to express herself: trenchant political criticism, urban anxiety, seasonal highs and lows. You name it, she danced it. Accompanied by sparse words, her lithe, flexible body sprang and collapsed in modern dance poses, creating a choreographed phrase across the newspaper page. And then in 2000, still looking trim in her unitard, she retired.

headline: UBS Hires Defense Banker
text: UBS said on Wednesday that it had hired Michael Ruppert, a defense industry banker. Mr. Ruppert, who had worked at Lockheed Martin and Lehman Brothers, joins UBS from Lazard, where he worked in its Washington office. He will be based in New York and report to Karl Knapp.

headline: Arguing From the Facts
text: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

headline: Summer Style | Buttoned Down
text: With Paris in the throes of couture, fashion fanatics expect extravagance on and off the runways. And while designers are delivering an abundance of glamour, the front-row look couldn’t be simpler- without a trace of the Balenciaga, Chanel and Celine ensembles we’ve come to expect from the fashion flock. Instead, we’re seeing a lot of slouchy Oxford shirts and plain, tailored trousers. Does this trio of taste makers — French Vogue’s editor in chief, Emmanuelle Alt, the model Caroline De Maigret and the heiress Bianca Brandolini d’Adda — portend a new austerity? And will it linger into fall? Or is it just simply too hot to dress up?

headline: James McAvoy: First Class
text: Scottish actor James McAvoy discusses his career and upcoming role in “X-Men: First Class” with Times reporter Dave Itzkoff.

headline: Companions in Battle: Animals of the Civil War
text: As Union and Confederate soldiers left the comforts of home for the grim realities of war, many brought along family pets or adopted wild animals. Not only did these animals provide entertainment to lonely soldiers, they often became companions in battle, suffering alongside their regiments.

headline: The Warm Weather Brings a T-Shirt Shortage of Sorts
text: THERE is one thing that Britney Spears, circa-1980s Madonna, Gwen Stefani, “I Dream of Jeannie,” the Spice Girls, “Clueless” and Matt Dillon in “Over the Edge” have in common: a devotion to the crop top.

headline: City to Open Sunday, 7/24, So Gay Couples Can Say I Do
text: New York City, whose elected officials strongly supported the legalization of same-sex marriage, is planning to take the unusual step of opening city offices on a Sunday so that gay couples can wed as soon as the law takes effect.

headline: Scouting Report
text: ARRIVALS

headline: Shopping Snapshots for July 7
text: The leather T-shirt looks to be big this fall and ThreeASFOUR has a new line of fitness wear.

headline: Just One Look | Elie Saab
text: Elie Saab’s haute couture is essentially a red carpet preview — that is, for anyone who doesn’t live in a world where private clients attend balls in fully beaded gowns. There is no day here: Elie does evening and consistently beautifully. His best looks this season were more covered up than usual — less cleavage and gams, more sleeves and skirt–and featured some of the other trends of this couture season: pearl embroideries, 30’s silhouettes, and a cool palette of ivories, skin tones and dark inky blues and teals. Here, a lace stunner that shows a lot without exposing anything.

headline: How High Can You Bounce?
text: RUBBER crept up on us this summer. Neon-bright rubber accessories, as delectable as ice pops on a steamy day, turned up in fashion collections high and low, and without any of the drippy mess.

headline: An App to Make Your Words Musical
text: The Gregory Brothers have become YouTube sensations by taking spoken rants and using auto tune to turn them into songs, such as Charlie Sheen’s “Winning!” and Christine O’Donnell’s “I Am Not a Witch.”

headline: TimeCast | Dismissal or Plea?
text: July 6, 2011 - Attorneys for Dominique Strauss-Kahn met with prosecutors Wednesday to discuss the future of the case.

headline: L.A. Prepares for Worst and Hopes for Best in Freeway Shutdown
text: LOS ANGELES — You would think that Los Angeles, of all places, would know how to handle a catastrophe.

headline: Assange Claims Credit for Egypt’s Revolution
text: Updated | Thursday | 9:04 a.m. As Dan Murphy reports on The Christian Science Monitor’s Backchannels blog, a new online ad for WikiLeaks seems to imply that the work of its founder, Julian Assange, helped spark the Egyptian revolution in January.

headline: As Many Guitarists Meet, Much Strumming Ensues
text: The world of the classical guitar has become appealingly chaotic over the last few decades, in much the same way the new-music world has: players with traditional tastes and interpretive instincts work alongside guitarists steeped in pop and folk sensibilities, with avant-gardists and world-music devotees contributing new textures and languages to the mainstream.

headline: Wooing Voters (or Not) With a Climate Pitch
text: Sometimes it’s just not prudent to bring up certain subjects in certain company.

headline: Under an Enchantment and Catching Z’s for a Century, but With Both Eyes Open
text: Light but large, marvelously limpid, the style of classical ballet that American Ballet Theater as a company now possesses is often on the verge of greatness. And of its various full-length vehicles none currently shows the troupe so well as Kevin McKenzie’s production of “The Sleeping Beauty,” which has returned to repertory for this final week of the troupe’s annual eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House. True, the production, new in 2007, has always been seriously flawed; in a ballet that should evoke a peak of civilization, most of Tony Walton’s sets and a few of Willa Kim’s costume designs are all too Disney. The staging’s merits, however, have now come into their own.

headline: TimeCast | First Day of Clemens Trial
text: July 6, 2011 - The Roger Clemens trial begins and a key witness for the prosecution is his former friend and teammate Andy Pettitte.

headline: What’s Missing From the Women’s Game? Cynicism
text: Sweden and the United States just reminded me why women’s soccer stands by itself as a special sport. The women never stop playing. Never mind technique or tactics, I am talking here about heart.

headline: Want a Best-Defense Award? Find Your Way to the Zone
text: When tennis players are seeing the ball larger than life, they say that they are in the zone. There are times when bridge players have a similar experience. Elke Weber from Germany (East) was in the zone in the diagramed deal from the Mixed Teams at the fifth European Open Championships in Poznan, Poland, two weeks ago.

headline: TimesCast | British Phone Hacking
text: Prime Minister David Cameron is under pressure to call for an immediate inquiry into the British tabloid phone-hacking scandal.

headline: In With the New
text: Karl Lagerfeld, the veteran, presented moody blues, and young talent emerged during the haute couture shows in Paris.

headline: Charles Isherwood on Shakespeare in the Park
text: Charles Isherwood on Shakespeare in the Park

headline: A Vision in Melancholy
text: PARIS — Karl Lagerfeld always maintained that his childhood was different from other little boys’. He read “Buddenbrooks,” all 243,000 words of it, when he was 8 and told his mother he should have a valet. She told little Karl he talked too much.

headline: Fewer Americans File for Bankruptcy
text: After steadily climbing for several years, the number of Americans filing for bankruptcy is on the decline, though that is not necessarily an indicator of an improving economy.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Google’s Social Network
text: Battle of the giants? Google is introducing a new social network that aims to be different from Facebook‘s. On this week’s Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein talks to Times technology reporter Claire Cain Miller about Google+, the search engine’s new social network. It’s the fourth go-around for Google in social media, and Ms. Miller describes what’s at stake.

headline: Teen Art Gallery
text: A high school student uses social media to put together a show of promising young artists.

headline: An Exhibition Whose Curator Is 17
text: YOUTH, it turns out, is not always wasted on the young. Through Aug. 4 the New York Open Center in Manhattan is hosting the inaugural exhibition of the Teen Art Gallery, with paintings, collages, sculptures and photographs by 38 artists. The oldest artist in the show just turned 20, the youngest is 15; they all live in the New York region.

headline: At Top of Delaware Chancery Court, Adherence to Tradition
text: WILMINGTON, Del. — The Court of Chancery in Delaware has been the battleground of some of the biggest legal fights in corporate America.

headline: Amid War, Fierce Adversaries of the Creepy-Crawly Variety
text: Perhaps it’s mean-spirited to say that a movie based on the director’s personal experience of a brutal 26-year civil war is unpleasant. But that’s the word that comes to mind after watching the Sri Lankan filmmaker Sanjeewa Pushpakumara’s debut feature, “Flying Fish.” One of the film’s recurring motifs is insects — crawling on people’s legs, clustering on their food — and after a while it starts to feel as if the characters in Mr. Pushpakumara’s slow-moving, three-stranded story are being treated in much the same way as those anonymous bugs.

headline: After Hacking Revelations, a Boycott Spreads Online
text: 11:58 a.m. | Updated As new allegations about voice-mail hacking by The News of the World rippled through newspapers and the British Parliament, a campaign to pressure companies to withhold their ad dollars spread through social media.

headline: Robert Sklar, Film Scholar, Is Dead at 74

headline: Noise-Canceling Devices for a Good Night’s Sleep
text: BEFORE my son was born last fall, I’d always been puzzled by the idea of “white noise.” Have you seen those CDs and expensive alarm clocks (usually sold in airline catalogs) that offer the sounds of nature: waves crashing, rain drizzling, and so on? The products claim that a flat, featureless, continuous sound somehow encourages slumber. The idea seemed bizarre to me: When I sleep, I want quiet, not noise — not even the pitter-patter of angels dancing in the clouds.

headline: Belarus: First, Claps; Then, Arrests
text: In the latest crackdown on a form of protest that has been gathering strength in Belarus, the police arrested scores of people who were standing on sidewalks and clapping Wednesday, human rights groups said. The applauding protests began because authorities in President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko’s government take more severe actions against traditional public political expression, like unfurling banners. The clapping protests are organized anonymously on social networking sites for Wednesday evenings and began last month. Some participants stand silently while others clap. Plainclothes police officers typically swoop in and grab those who applaud, sometimes roughing them up. Vesna, a Belarussian rights group, said the police detained about 150 clappers on Wednesday. After past protests, judges have sentenced clappers to 15 days in jail or a fine.

headline: WikiLeaks Memoir ‘Postponed’
text: A book deal that Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, signed only six months ago has fallen through, according to a report in The Guardian on Wednesday, but Canongate, his publisher in Britain, said it was still expecting to publish the book. Canongate did not provide a date for its release, however. According to The Guardian report, Mr. Assange, left, had expressed concern that the memoir could be used against him by prosecutors in the United States. American officials have been weighing whether to try to charge Mr. Assange since WikiLeaks released a trove of State Department cables, but it is unclear where that effort stands. The book deal was announced in December; Mr. Assange said he expected to earn $1.7 million for the memoir, which was being ghostwritten by Andrew O’Hagan, a novelist. The memoir was originally scheduled for publication in April 2011 in Britain, although Mr. Assange’s American publisher, Knopf, did not release a publication date. “With projects like these, you never know about delivery, and you never know about timetables,” said Paul Bogaards, a spokesman for Knopf, part of Random House. “My understanding is that the book has been postponed.”

headline: Somalia: About-Face on Aid
text: The Shabab, the Islamist rebel group fighting the government of Somalia, announced that it would again allow aid organizations to operate in the areas the group controls. A rebel spokesman, Mohamoud Raghe, said in a news conference in Mogadishu that the aid groups were going to be allowed to work in order to help bring relief to areas hard-hit by a severe drought. The Shabab said its drought committee would work with the organizations. The rebels in the past accused many aid groups of acting as spies and of being anti-Muslim. Some analysts said the Shabab decided to allow the aid groups to work again because it wanted to stop the flow of hundreds of people to government-controlled areas in search of food.

headline: Settlement Is Reached in Suit Over Katrina Grants

headline: Her Own Boss, on the Streets She Loves

The justices should grant the stay to allow Congress to pass the law. It would ensure that states are in compliance with the treaty, which requires that foreign nationals be told of their right to have their embassy notified of their arrest.

headline: For One Night, Artie Lange Returns to Radio

On a Fox Sports Radio program hosted by his friend and fellow comedian Nick DiPaolo (who in turn was filling in for Tony Bruno), Mr. Lange joined the show to take questions from listeners and riff on current events. According to a live blog of the program posted by Punchline magazine, discussion of the sad circumstances that kept Mr. Lange off the airwaves was not abundant, though Mr. Lange said he’s been getting sober at a rehabilitation facility in West Palm Beach, Fla., and Mr. DiPaolo introduced him to the show by joking, “You might have seen him on ‘Intervention.'”

headline: No, Seriously: No Excuses
text: In the early days of the education-reform movement, a decade or so ago, you’d often hear from reformers a powerful rallying cry: “No excuses.” For too long, they said, poverty had been used as an excuse by complacent educators and bureaucrats who refused to believe that poor students could achieve at high levels. Reform-minded school leaders took the opposite approach, insisting that students in the South Bronx should be held to the same standards as kids in Scarsdale. Amazingly enough, those high expectations often paid off, producing test results at some low-income urban schools that would impress parents in any affluent suburb.

headline: Rhode Island Rejects Tax Change Said to Favor Small Business
text: Are national corporations using state laws to shave millions of dollars off their tax bills — and gain an advantage over smaller rivals? That’s the claim some lawmakers and activists are making in statehouses around the country, and as states grapple with deep cuts in spending and seek new sources of revenue, it is putting big business on the defensive. This year, the fight moved to Rhode Island.

headline: European Central Bank Raises Rates as Expected
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank maintained a pose of studied aloofness Thursday toward the Greek debt crisis, pushing its benchmark interest rate nearer to precrisis levels and laying the onus on government leaders to cope with rising tensions that threaten the integrity of the euro zone.

headline: Country Boy for the Whole Country
text: BLAKE SHELTON has been getting choked up a lot lately. First came his May wedding to fellow country star Miranda Lambert, his girlfriend of several years. And then came the subsequent weeks when he barely got to see her at all.

headline: Do Microbes Help Hyenas Communicate?
text: Kay E. Holekamp, a zoologist at Michigan State University, writes from the Masai Mara National Reserve in Kenya, where she is studying the behavior of spotted hyenas.

headline: Man Charged in Germany in Killing of U.S. Airmen
text: FRANKFURT — A 21-year-old man who opened fire on a busload of United States airmen at the Frankfurt Airport in March, killing two, acted after viewing a jihadist propaganda video but was apparently not part of a terrorist organization, German prosecutors said Thursday.

headline: White House Paints Doomsday Default Scenario
text: As the high-wire negotiations with the Congressional leadership resume Thursday over raising the nation’s debt ceiling, one message from President Obama and his top aides has remained consistent: The consequences of default would be very, very scary.

headline: The New Start-Ups at Sun Valley
After Charges of Discrimination, a Canceled Opera Is Reinstated
text: A British opera company said on Thursday that it would present a new opera by the “Billy Elliot” writer Lee Hall, following a dispute in which Mr. Hall said homophobia had led to the opera’s cancellation.

headline: Yes, Coins Too
text: Several readers have asked a good question about my article in today’s newspaper, which reports that the government is printing less paper currency: What about coins?

headline: Bubble? What Bubble?
text: Marc Andreessen, one of Silicon Valley’s biggest venture capitalists, has no fear.

headline: Venerating Sacred Relics of Shakespeare
text: WASHINGTON — Underground, not far from the handsome Great Hall at the Folger Shakespeare Library where a fascinating exhibition is on display, just beyond the institution’s reading rooms, down its back stairs and through a vault door that seems far more imposing than the “rocks impregnable” Shakespeare invoked in a sonnet, there is a wall on which more than 70 volumes lie flat on mounted shelves.

headline: Thursday Reading: Measles Cases Spike as Unvaccinated Travelers Return Home
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: For Jeter and Clemens, It’s a Game of Trajectories
text: The world of sports has long provided metaphors for life, and for many Americans — certainly this American — no sport is riper for epistemological picking than baseball.

headline: One Vote Down, One to Go for N.Y.S.E. and Deutsche Borse Merger
text: 8:48 a.m. | Updated

headline: A Walk in the Woods With Mark Zuckerberg
text: You might think a long quiet walk through the woods with Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, is a treat only his closest friends and dearest family get to enjoy. Yet a chummy stroll with one of the richest men in the world is actually reserved for a few select potential Facebook employees.

headline: Vain Glorious | Bugs Be Gone
text: After a particularly humid (and therefore buggy) fourth of July weekend, inquiring T staffers wanted to know: is there spray, balm, milk or mist that actually works? Luckily, Andreas Kokkino, one of T’s fashion editors, knew the answer. While in Stockholm, styling for an upcoming feature, he unearthed one of Scandinavia’s best-kept secrets: highly effective insect repellents. Who knew? At the top of his list is the DEET-free, all-natural MaxMedica MyggA Roll On (around $13, go to familjeapoteket.se). If you prefer a spray, forget the OFF! and opt for MaxMedica MyggA Spray. Another good one: NoSkito Mygglotion, (around $15). It’s easy to slather on and soothes skin with aloe vera.

headline: Still ‘Far Apart’ on Debt, 2 Sides Will Seek Broader Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, convening budget talks at the White House on Thursday, said Republicans and Democrats were still “far apart” but expressed confidence they could agree on an ambitious deal to prevent the government from defaulting on its debt.

headline: Saraghina’s Co-Owner Leaves to Focus on New Restaurant
text: Massimiliano Nanni says he’s left Saraghina, the easygoing Italian restaurant he co-owned in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, to focus on the Mediterranean bistro, Celestino, that he expects to open down the street later this summer.

headline: Malone Explains Bet on Barnes & Noble
text: SUN VALLEY, Idaho — John C. Malone, the billionaire deal maker, said on Thursday that a deal for Barnes & Noble “would be a bit of a flier for us.”

headline: A Royal Whirlwind in California
text: LOS ANGELES — There will be stops in Beverly Hills and Skid Row, along with a charity polo match in Santa Barbara. But there will be no time for Disneyland or the La Brea Tar Pits.

headline: Twice-Rejected S. Korean Town Lands 2018 Winter Games
text: SEOUL, South Korea — When the town of Pyeongchang first pitched its Olympic dream 12 years ago, some International Olympic Committee members confused it with Pyongyang, the North Korean capital. Even within South Korea it was known until recently mainly for having bid unsuccessfully for the 2010 and 2014 Winter Games.

headline: Anthony Is Sentenced to 4-Year Term for Lying
text: Casey Anthony was sentenced on Thursday to a four-year jail term, the maximum possible, for lying to the police, but will be freed this month because she has spent nearly three years behind bars in Orlando, Fla., awaiting trial.

headline: June Sales Reports Show Shoppers Opened Wallets
text: June retail sales blew by analyst expectations and suggested that consumers, at least when they were shopping, were feeling good.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: One Down, One to Go for NYSE-Deutsche Merger | Now that NYSE Euronext shareholders have approved a deal with Deutsche Börse, the fate of the exchange merger lies across the Atlantic.

headline: Pfizer Puts Nutrition and Animal Health Units on the Block
text: Pfizer is stepping up a streamlining effort to focus on drugs.

headline: F Is for Americans Getting Fatter
text: A new report issued on Thursday says Americans have become increasingly obese over the last 20 years. The report, by Trust for America’s Health, a nonpartisan advocacy group, and the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, tracks the level of obesity in the 50 states since 1990.

headline: The Elusive Rupert Murdoch
Poetry Pairing | July 7, 2011
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: Why the Republicans Resist Compromise
text: The chart that I’m going to show you is one of the more important ones that we’ve presented at FiveThirtyEight in some time. It helps explain a lot of what’s going on in American politics today, from the negotiations over the federal debt ceiling to the Republican presidential primaries. And it’s pretty simple, really, although it took me some time to track down the data.

headline: News Corp. Scandal Could Hurt BSkyB Deal
text: Amid the widening phone-hacking scandal, the News Corporation may find its deal-making ambitions diminished.

headline: Haste vs. Procrastination on Nuclear Waste
text: As I noted in Wednesday’s paper, companies that operate nuclear reactors are increasingly turning to dry casks to store nuclear waste as their pools of spent fuel fill up. Some experts suggest that such casks should be used more widely to reduce the amount of fuel in the pools as a safety measure.

headline: A Tenacious Rise to the Top in the Brutal Men’s World of Tabloids
text: LONDON — It was March 2003, and Rebekah Wade, then the editor of The Sun newspaper, was being interrogated by the House of Commons select committee on culture and the media. The topic: dubious tabloid practices.

headline: Asked & Answered | Andrew Richardson
text: The stylist Andrew Richardson is a prime example of what the British really mean when they use the word “smart” — having that rare ability to weather the most indecent (or mundane) of circumstances with a show of dignity and class. As the editor in chief of Richardson magazine, a slow labor counting only five issues in 15 years, Richardson has parlayed his interests in post-punk glamour, Helmut Newton’s heroic erotica and transgressive comic books like Frigidaire into a range of professional experience, including a role in Madonna’s 1992 elegy to moral hang-ups, the “Sex” book, to become an agent provocateur of the most polished kind.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Rock Star’s Lawsuit Against Tony Awards Is Moved to New York
text: Bret Michaels will probably have a return engagement with the Tony Awards in New York – not to perform or present any trophies, but to pursue a lawsuit against the organizers of that show and CBS, which broadcast the program and the accident in which, Mr. Michaels said, he was nearly killed.

headline: A Problem in Following Doctor’s Orders
text: Mr. M was a typical new patient: 74, with diabetes, hypertension and elevated cholesterol. He had some prostate enlargement and back pain. His bag of pill bottles was depressingly bulky. I spilled the bottles out at our first visit, sorting them by disease.

headline: What If We Just Tell Everyone to Send us Their Waste?
text: I started TerraCycle almost a decade ago with a goal of making a profit by eliminating waste, and today our company offers free collection programs for more than 45 waste streams in the United States, along with similar programs in 15 other countries. The premise is simple: sign up on our Web site, fill a box with a specific type of waste, send it TerraCycle and we’ll donate 2 cents (or the foreign equivalent) for every unit of waste to the charity or school of your choice.

headline: Contraction, Still Contractionary
text: A new paper from the IMF (pdf) puts another nail in the coffin of the doctrine of expansionary austerity. It basically shows that results purporting to show economic expansion following spending cuts and/or tax increases were based on a statistical illusion: an expanding economy can often lead to rising revenue and/or falling spending (e.g. because safety-net spending falls or because the government cuts back in an attempt to cool off inflationary pressures). And as a result, what the Alesina-Ardagna results capture is muddle by reverse causation.

headline: U.N. Report Criticizes Israel for Actions at Border
text: JERUSALEM — A new United Nations report that has been distributed to members of the Security Council strongly criticizes Israel for using live fire against unarmed demonstrators who tried in May to breach its border fence from Lebanon. Israel is planning to respond in detail shortly in a letter to Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, officials here said Thursday.

headline: Internet Providers to Help Thwart Online Piracy
text: In a deal with the major entertainment media companies that has been years in the making, the leading Internet service providers have agreed to a uniform procedure for notifying customers about repeated instances of digital copyright infringement.

headline: Two Jobs Reports Point To a Higher Gain in June
text: New claims for unemployment benefits in the United States declined last week to the lowest level in nearly two months, according to a government survey on Thursday, while a separate report on jobs from the payroll processing company ADP was better than economists had forecast.

headline: Democrats Pick David Weprin, an Assemblyman, to Run for Weiner’s Seat
text: For decades, David I. Weprin has played the role of good Democratic soldier, the scion of a vaunted Queens political family who repeatedly won elections as a city councilman and currently as a state assemblyman.

headline: Opening Doors at West Point
text: Brenda S. Fulton graduated in the West Point class of 1980, the first to include women. In a few weeks she will return to the military academy in another historic role: as the first openly gay or lesbian member of its Board of Visitors, which advises the president on all things West Point.

headline: The Mother of the Noisy Child Responds
text: It has always been the goal to create a “small world” feel here on Motherlode. I hadn’t realized how small it had become until one reader recognized herself in another reader’s comments last week. She would like to explain. And ask your advice about her trip home:

headline: British Tabloid to Close After More Serious Allegations
text: Last Updated | 3:26 p.m. Following more serious allegations about misconduct at The News of the World, a British tabloid owned by a division of Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, the newspaper will be closed down after publishing one final edition this Sunday.

headline: Theater Talkback: A Method to Their Madness
text: “Madness in great ones must not unwatch’d go.” That well-turned observation was originally made about one Prince Hamlet, and doubtless it’s useful advice regarding future heads of state. But the dictum applies equally to those who tread the stage. Few things test the mettle of an actor – or separate the artists from the hacks – like the simulation of a whopping case of mental illness.

headline: Meet the Future Officers, 1,635 Strong
text: Of the candidates in the New York Police Department’s newest class of recruits, 493 have earned a baccalaureate degree. Twenty more have earned a master’s degree, and two others have earned doctorate degrees.

headline: Statement on the Closing of the News of the World
text: News International today announces that this Sunday, 10 July 2011, will be the last issue of the News of the World.

headline: Mouret Named Creative Director of Robert Clergerie
text: A little hot news out of Paris now that the couture has wrapped up: Roland Mouret, the designer known for slim-fitting cocktail attire, has just been named creative director of the footwear and accessories company Robert Clergerie.

headline: Ailing Taylor Swift Cancels Shows
text: For the first time in her dizzying rise in country-pop, Taylor Swift has been sidelined by sickness, announcing that she had to cancel four concerts on her current tour because of bronchitis. It was the first time Ms. Swift, who at 21 has become one of the best-selling singer-songwriters in the United States, had postponed or canceled a show because of illness, her spokeswoman, Paula Erickson, said.

headline: A Treatise on Issues of the Workplace. Not.
text: It requires no great critical insight to figure out what’s wrong with “Horrible Bosses,” a foul-mouthed new comedy of male resentment directed by Seth Gordon. The problems can be enumerated with a prim scowl and a wagging finger. The movie, in addition to being expectedly vulgar, is noisy and preposterous, and its humor flirts with racism, goes steady with misogyny and pretty much marries homophobia. There are guns, drugs, several references to sex acts involving urine, and gross insults — unless they are extravagant compliments; I’ll get back to you — to the respected profession of dentistry.

headline: Guess Where This Is
text: It’s time again for our weekly contest: guess the location of the photograph above.

headline: New World Cup Order
text: The undoing came on an innocent enough play, a free kick by Sweden that caromed off a startled American defender. But when that carom sent the ball careening straight into the corner of the net, it was the clearest sign yet that the world order of women’s soccer had been reset.

headline: Hoping Moves Pay Off After Free-Agent Frenzy
text: It might have been a relatively weak class of free agents, but the spending frenzy that broke out across the N.H.L. last weekend said a lot about the financial and competitive state of the league. From noon Friday to 5 p.m. Eastern on Tuesday, about 100 free agents signed contracts with new N.H.L. clubs or headed to Europe.

headline: Regulators Finalize New Derivatives Rules
text: Federal regulators on Thursday adopted the first in a series of new rules for the derivatives market, giving the government broad new authority over the $600 trillion industry that played a central role in the financial crisis.

headline: A Numbers Game
text: In this morning’s paper, there was just another reason why it’s tough not to like hockey players. And it isn’t just their ability to skate backward while giving another player “the business” or even growing excellent-but-irritating beards during the playoffs as show of solidarity. It’s a code of selflessness and a collective disdain of the me-first culture that pervades locker rooms on every level of most organized sport.

headline: Investigating the Dreaded ‘Check Engine’ Alert
text: Few automobile problems are more vexing than the “check engine” light. When the light comes on, it may mean you simply didn’t tighten your gas cap enough after filling up — or it could mean there’s major trouble brewing in your catalytic converter.

headline: A Green Network for New Yorkers
text: New Yorkers, never shy about speaking their mind, have a new outlet: a Web site that promises to directly connect residents and city government with the aim of putting words into action.

headline: ArtsBeat - July 7, 2011
text: The Streb Extreme Action Company performs on a rotating ladder near the site of the Whitney's new space in Manhattan, and a 17-year-old curator launches an exhibition of work by young artists.

headline: Locks of Love Lost
text: On the prowl recently for an Art Deco ring, I found myself at Erie Basin, a shop in Red Hook, Brooklyn, that sells surprisingly affordable antique jewelry. Their Deco diamonds were nice — they looked like they were mined from the top of the Chrysler Building — but what really grabbed me was a very old, and very peculiar, signet ring in rose gold. Its band was filled with hundreds of braided threads the color of raw umber. “Silk?” I hazarded. “Actually,” explained Russell Whitmore, the shop’s owner, “that’s hair.”

headline: City Web Site Seeks to Link Up Ideas From the Public
text: More green space. Cleaner subway stations. Wider bike lanes. New Yorkers have plenty of ideas on how to make the city better, and now the mayor’s office is introducing a Web site that aims to connect citizens with the city’s government to share those ideas.

headline: Winter in July
text: The invitation for the White Fairy Tale ball called for white and silver, and most guests on Wednesday at the Château de Wideville near Paris obliged.

headline: Nets Star Has Deal to Play in Turkey
text: Deron Williams is set to become the biggest N.B.A. star to play in Europe — a development that is bursting with intrigue, risks and caveats.

headline: NYSE Euronext Shareholders Approve Deal With Deutsche Börse
text: NYSE Euronext handily won shareholder support on Thursday for its proposed merger with Deutsche Börse. But executives at the American exchange operator conceded that they have more work to do to complete the merger.

headline: Excerpt: 'As You Like It'
text: A scene from the Royal Shakespeare Company's production of Shakespeare's play. (Video courtesy of the Lincoln Center Festival.)

headline: A Big Winner, but How?
text: Although he plays in the same league as the Phillies aces Roy Halladay, Cole Hamels and Cliff Lee, a good case can be made that Atlanta’s Jair Jurrjens — with his 12-3 record and 1.87 earned run average — should be the National League’s starting pitcher in the All-Star Game next Tuesday. He leads N.L. pitchers in wins and E.R.A. this season, and his 4.2 Wins Above Replacement have been perhaps the biggest factor keeping the Braves in the wild card lead.

headline: The Frendzy, a Renault for Workaholics
text: For those who struggle to maintain a firewall between their professional and personal lives, a concept car from Renault suggests that your resistance is admirable, but futile.

headline: Felton Has Bright Trail Blazers Future, Eventually
text: While the lockout has squelched player movement in the N.B.A. — except when they are leaving for Turkey like Deron Williams — it’s worth a look back at one of the moves made before business went dark: Portland’s trade for former Knicks guard Raymond Felton.

headline: Twitter Co-Founder Joins Venture Capital Firm
text: Biz Stone is keeping busy in his new life after Twitter.

headline: E.P.A. Issues Tougher Rules for Power Plants
text: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday issued new standards for power plants in 27 states that would sharply cut emissions of chemicals that have polluted forests, farms, lakes and streams across the Eastern United States for decades.

headline: Cambios en México Reducen Inmigración Ilegal a Estados Unidos
text: AGUA NEGRA, México — La extraordinaria migración mexicana que llevó a millones de inmigrantes ilegales a Estados Unidos en los últimos 30 años se ha reducido a un mínimo, y una investigación señala a una causa sorprendente: varios cambios en México no publicitados que han hecho que quedarse en el País sea más atractivo.

headline: Brian Eno and Rick Holland, Bjork and CD reviews
text: Ben Sisario on "Drums Between the Bells" by Brian Eno and Rick Holland, Jon Pareles on Bjork's new album, "Biophilia," and CD reviews

headline: Should Hospitals Be Run by Doctors?
text: Are the best hospitals run by medical doctors or business managers?

headline: Morgenthau Comes to Vance’s Defense
text: Robert M. Morgenthau, the former Manhattan district attorney, released a statement on Thursday defending how his successor, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., and his office had handled the case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn.

headline: Tech-Wary Buffett Shies Away From Facebook
How to Design a Hot Product
text: When Cisco killed the beloved Flip camcorder a few months ago, a lot of people were shocked and upset—including me. It just seemed like such a ham-handed, thoughtless way to terminate an iconic, very popular gadget.

headline: The Semi-Inevitability of Mitt Romney
text: Yesterday’s big news in Republican presidential politics was a poll showing Michele Bachmann within single digits of Mitt Romney … in New Hampshire. Jon Chait, who’s been beating the “Bachmann can win” drum for months now, naturally claims vindication. I’m going to stick with my boring “Bachmann can’t win, and her rise is good news for Romney” conventional wisdom, buttressing this CW with a great passage from a Will Wilkinson dispatch from Bachmann’s Iowa kick-off:

headline: New Housing Program Is Aimed at the Unemployed
text: Help is on the way from the federal government for some homeowners struggling to make their mortgage payments because of prolonged joblessness.

headline: Popcast: Deciphering New Projects by Bjork and Brian Eno
text: This week’s very special conceptual episode of Popcast takes a look at heady new projects from two of pop music’s quirkier auteurs.

headline: Why Didn’t They Include a Movie Magazine?
text: A devoted film fan who is also a media reporter got a surprise while watching a movie on the Turner Classic Movies cable channel on Wednesday night.

headline: July 7, 1981 | Reagan Nominates O’Connor, First Woman, for Supreme Court
text: On July 7, 1981, President Ronald Reagan appointed an Arizona judge, Sandra Day O’Connor, to the Supreme Court. She was confirmed two months later, becoming the first woman to serve on the nation’s highest court.

headline: Basking in the Presence of an Ever-Changing God
text: Hindu sculptures are no ordinary things. They’re cosmic implosions, concentrations of spiritual energy so dense as to turn physics inside out. They funnel light from other universes into our mundane world. And they do so consciously, with intent.

headline: Photo Replay: July 7
text: A view of the day in sports, with races in mud, on streets and past a monastery.

headline: In First Ad, Bachmann Says ‘No’ to Debt Limit Increase
text: Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota on Thursday released her first presidential television ad in Iowa, declaring that she will not vote to raise the nation’s debt ceiling.

headline: The News of the World Closes
text: July 7, 2011 -- Ravi Somaiya reports from The News of the World headquarters in London.

headline: Elizabeth Smart Hired as ABC News Contributor
text: Elizabeth Smart, who was kidnapped at age 14 and was held by a Salt Lake City street preacher for nine months in 2002 and 2003, has joined ABC News as a paid contributor.

headline: Seeing Things | Hammer Time
text: Take three recent U.C.L.A. architecture school graduates with beards, brains and a hefty dose of design savvy and put them together with lumber, tools and a great space in L.A.’s Highland Park neighborhood and you get Knowhow Shop. The cooperative shop — think Pop’s wood shop rather than pop-up shop — has only been open since January and business is booming. After working with several local architecture firms, Joshua Howell, Justin Rice and Kagan Taylor decided to strike out on their own.

headline: Buffett Hearts Blankfein
New Maps on Subway Platforms Seek Clarity
text: For years, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has been pushing the subway system into the digital age, with electronic signs in trains telling you what stop is next, and signs on platforms saying how long you have to wait until the next train comes.

headline: Apple Customers Have Downloaded 15 Billion Apps
text: Apple said Thursday that customers had downloaded more than 15 billion mobile applications from the iTunes App Store. This is a jump from January last year, when Apple said it had passed the 3 billion mark for the number of apps downloaded.

headline: Georgia, Looking for Spies, Arrests Photographers
text: TBILISI, Georgia — Police officers working on a counterespionage campaign arrested a group of photographers on Thursday that included the president’s personal photographer and two working for Western news services, The Associated Press and the European Pressphoto Agency.

headline: TimesCast | July 7, 2011
text: Graham Bowley on Rebekah Brooks, chief executive of News International; and Brian Stelter and Jeremy W. Peters on why News Corporation closed The News of the World.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Sudan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Sudan, Spain and Myanmar.

headline: At the Paper, Shock, Anger and a Retreat to a Pub (Free Beer)
text: LONDON — When the chief executive of News International, Rebekah Brooks, walked onto the floor of the News of the World newsroom on Thursday afternoon and began speaking, many of the paper’s 200 or so employees thought she would be announcing her resignation after scrutiny of her role in the phone-hacking scandal that has rocked Britain this week.

headline: Albert Trummer Refuses Plea Deal in Bartop Pyrotechnics
text: Albert Trummer, who was arrested twice last year after setting alcohol aflame on the bartop of his haute cocktail haunt Apothéke in Chinatown, rejected a plea deal from prosecutors on Thursday that would have let him plead guilty to disorderly conduct and avoid jail time.

headline: The Caucus Click: Congress in the Cabinet Room
text: President Obama invited leaders from the House and Senate to the White House to discuss a budget deal.

headline: ‘America’s Got Talent’ Keeps Viewers Transfixed
text: “America’s Got Talent” had another night on top of the ratings as 12.5 million viewers tuned in to NBC’s reality competition on Wednesday, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The hourlong episode at 9 p.m. far exceeded the ratings for any other program on the night, lifting NBC to No. 1 in prime time, even as the rest of the network’s programs lagged behind in their respective time slots.

headline: Yemen President Speaks on TV for First Time Since Injury
text: SANA, Yemen — President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen appeared on television Thursday for the first time since he was injured in a bombing of his presidential compound’s mosque a month ago. The prerecorded broadcast from Saudi Arabia, where he has been recuperating since the attack, showed him speaking with difficulty, with a red Saudi headdress and a darkened face from the severe burns he suffered.

headline: 36 Hours in Honolulu
text: The city brims with summer’s delights, with colorful produce in the market stands and Hawaiian music spilling onto beaches.

headline: 36 Hours in Honolulu
text: HONOLULU has never been hotter, and not just because it’s July. The city’s "it" factor has been on the rise since President Obama announced, two years ago in Singapore, that his self-described “home state of Hawaii” would host the 2011 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. This November, the 21-nation Pacific Rim summit may bring as many as 10,000 people to Waikiki, the renowned Honolulu destination on Oahu’s south shore. While the city primps for the media glare, it also brims with summer’s delights. Mangoes and sweet summer fruit add splashy colors to the market stands. Pikake, puakenikeni, gardenia and tuberose grace Chinatown lei stands, and Hawaiian music spills onto beaches from sunset-drenched oceanfront lounges.

headline: Letter to A.Q. Khan
text: A letter apparently written to Abdul Qadeer Khan by a senior North Korean official 13 years ago has become the strongest evidence yet suggesting that Pakistan’s top military officials were involved in the secret sale of equipment to the North.

headline: Shift in Treasuries System Vexes Older Investors
text: Pauline Gordon wants to know where her savings are.

headline: MasterCard Brings ‘Priceless’ to a Pricey Place
text: MasterCard Worldwide is expanding its efforts to bring its long-running “Priceless” advertising campaign to life.

headline: Hot and Bothered
text: I work with a dozen others in a city office building. One colleague says that she has an autoimmune disease. She says that we must keep the windows in our small office closed at all times; if we open them, she becomes ill. With no ventilation, the temperature reaches the high 70s. Our boss has offered her a separate room, but she refuses to move from our shared space. What is the right thing to do? We are all miserable, and productivity is at an all-time low. B.S., NEW YORK

headline: For Michigan’s Karting Kushners, Track Time Is Family Time
text: BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich. — To those who think the words “family” and “motorsports” belong only in a discussion of racetrack infields and R.V.’s, a Michigan family of five offers a high-revving rebuke.

headline: Offended by an Office Breast Pump
text: It has been nearly a year since a reader, T., wrote asking for advice on becoming a family of four. Her son arrived in November, and, in spite of T.’s fears (and, perhaps, because of your wise advice) the transition of her daughter has been relatively smooth.

headline: Canceled ABC Soaps Find New Home Online
text: Three months after ABC canceled the soap operas “All My Children” and “One Life to Live,” the network said Thursday that the shows would be given a second life online by Prospect Park, a two-year-old media and production company.

headline: Staten Island’s Imperiled Boy Scout Haven Is Saved
text: Pouch Camp, the wooded Boy Scout camp on Staten Island that for 60 years has provided the pleasures of overnight camping and summer day camp for thousands of boys and girls, will be saved under an agreement announced this week.

headline: Removal of Priest’s Cases Exposes Deep Holes in Immigration Courts
text: For more than three decades, Robert Vitaglione never turned down a client, representing thousands of immigrants in New York’s overburdened federal immigration courts. But he is not a lawyer. He is a Roman Catholic priest without formal legal training or supervision — and it showed.

headline: Pattern Boldness | Marimekko
text: Bold stripes and prints may be all the rage right now (think Marni, Jil Sander, Prada), but Marimekko has been doing them for years — 60 to be exact, when the designer Armi Ratia and her husband, Viljo, took over a small Finnish textile company, Printex, and reinvented it with a graphic sensibility and an optimistic, almost utopian, outlook, not just as a global lifestyle brand but as a way of life. Jackie Kennedy wore a red Marimekko dress on the cover of Sports Illustrated in 1960; the Marimekko unisex Even Stripe T-shirt was a fixture on the rock and jazz festival circuit in the ’70s. Today, there is no shortage of new Marimekko material around thanks to collaborations with the likes of Crate and Barrel and Converse; and a free-standing Marimekko shop is scheduled to open in the Flatiron district in the fall. But true believers should get their clicker fingers in shape for July 13, when a trove of vintage Marimekko goes on sale on 1stdibs in conjunction with Katy Kane Vintage and Couture Clothing. The perfect, plain shirtdresses, matching jacket and shorts ensembles in unfussy floral prints and breezy striped shifts all came from a single owner, a Westchester-area homemaker, with very progressive taste. When she found a style she liked, she bought it in multiples. That orange and blue awning stripe shirt a little too bold for your taste? It’s also available in ivory and blue. What is more, many of the pieces were never worn and are still wrapped in tissue paper — and are as fresh and new as the day they were designed.

headline: Hunger Strike by Inmates Is Latest Challenge to California’s Prison System
text: LOS ANGELES — Thousands of inmates at prisons throughout California have been refusing state-issued food in a mass hunger strike to protest conditions at the state’s highest-security prisons, where some inmates are kept in prolonged isolation.

headline: Opera? Musical? Please Respect the Difference
text: MORE than ever, composers are busily breaking down walls between stylistic categories. Opera in particular has been a poacher’s paradise. We have had folk opera, jazz opera and rock opera. Bono, who collaborated with the Edge on the music and lyrics of “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” called the show “Pop-Art opera.” Whatever that means. But of all such efforts, mixing opera with the Broadway musical might seem by far the most natural combination.

headline: More Anti-Austerianism
text: Via Philip Lane, a paper from the BIS (pdf) analyzing in detail four famous alleged cases of expansionary austerity. The bottom line: none of them show what they were supposed to show. Instead, all they show is that if you have austerity policies at the same time that other big expansionary things are happening, the economy may actually expand.

headline: Hunting for Windows in a House by Frank Lloyd Wright
text: Darwin D. Martin, a soap-factory executive in Buffalo, was a serial client of Frank Lloyd Wright. Between 1903 and 1928, the charismatic architect designed a half-dozen buildings for Martin’s family, including a carriage house and a mausoleum. Wright referred to his shy, bookish patron as “my best friend,” borrowed $70,000 from him over the years and never repaid the loans.

headline: 2 Continents, 1 Work and 31 Hand Positions
text: Competition to acquire “For Beginners (all the combinations of the thumb and fingers),” Bruce Nauman’s latest video and sound work, was fierce from the moment it went on view at the Sperone Westwater Gallery on the Bowery last fall. Michael Govan, director of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, wanted the work because he said it “sums up the history of art.” Only trouble: François Pinault, a big collector of Mr. Nauman’s work, wanted it too. Mr. Pinault, the luxury-goods magnate and owner of Christie’s, is constantly on the prowl for great new art to put in his two spaces in Venice, the Punta della Dogana and the Palazzo Grassi.

headline: Puppy Purchasing When Drunk, a Common City Scourge

headline: Chilly Scenes (and Sounds) of Scandinavia
text: Scandinavian people are cool like Bergman; southern Europeans are hot like Fellini. This sounds like a stereotype, but you will find little to disconfirm the first part, at least, in “North by New York: New Nordic Art” at Scandinavia House, the American-Scandinavian Foundation’s cultural center. Here, with some mild exceptions, emotional (and imaginative) restraint is the rule. This mixed bag of 15 contemporary artists is not a big enough sample to allow scientific conclusions, though all the Nordic nations are represented: Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Iceland and Finland. Who knows what else the guest curators, Robert Storr and Francesca Pietropaolo, might have picked that might have altered the general mood of guarded sobriety?

headline: A Life-Affirming Female Force, Ready to Rumble
text: What would Western civilization have been like had it worshiped not a single, remote, male god, but two or more vividly present divine beings of both genders? Would we now have a kinder, gentler and more balanced society? Maybe not, but if the visual culture of India is any indicator, our art of the past thousand years might have been sexier.

headline: A Streamlined ‘Magic Flute,’ Reimagined by Peter Brook
text: “A Magic Flute,” not “The Magic Flute,” is the title the director Peter Brook gives to his enchanting adaptation of Mozart’s beloved opera, which opened at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater of John Jay College on Wednesday night. Mr. Brook uses this slight alteration of the original German title to make clear that his pared-down, 100-minute, touchingly intimate version of the opera — performed by just seven appealing singers, two arresting actors and the elegant onstage pianist Franck Krawczyk — is just a take on the original, an exploration.

headline: Dick Williams, Hall of Fame Manager, Dies at 82
text: Dick Williams, the hard-nosed Hall of Fame manager who achieved the rare feat of taking three different teams to the World Series, died on Thursday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 82.

headline: Collaborations Bring Cascades of Motion and Emotion
text: LONDON — The ballerina Sylvie Guillem, whose three-choreographer evening, “6000 Miles Away,” is being performed at Sadler’s Wells this week, has carved out a path for herself unlike almost any other in the dance world. At 23 she left the Paris Opera Ballet, despite being its biggest star. Even then she knew her own mind and her need for freedom, a desire that has been the hallmark of a career that has encompassed a 17-year stint as “principal guest artist” at the Royal Ballet in Britain and collaborations with artists of all kinds.

headline: West 49th Street, 4:07 P.M.
text: Mallory Maskornick was greeted by a summer storm as she emerged from an audition for “Godspell” at St. Malachy’s church.

headline: His Workout Partner? The City
text: THE EAST RIVER PARK in Lower Manhattan was animated on a recent morning: against a backdrop of the city skyline and the boat-dotted water, groups of children played on lush lawns, sunbathers basked in the sun’s glow and joggers ran by on the paved path. And at the playground, Charlie Gasparino was in the middle of a grueling workout. Using the monkey bars, he did more than a dozen sets of pull-ups — some including as many as 30 — and alternated them with fast-paced push-ups. He was soaked in sweat in just 15 minutes and still had another hour to go.

headline: Forms of a God

headline: Weekend Miser
text: Do you remember how to kick it with A Tribe Called Quest? The legendary Tribe took a different approach to hip-hop in the early 1990s, blending Afro-centric rhymes with jazz and promoting social change through its music. This year’s Brooklyn Hip-Hop Festival, which begins on Monday, seeks to do the same with the help of a Tribe member, Q-Tip, who is the headliner at the festival.

text: Classical

headline: In Too Deep
text: It’s impossible to look cool when you’re part of a tour group. Instead of bravely exploring on your own, you’ve chosen to be led around like a frightened kindergartner. My wife and I were on a tour bus while in Hawaii recently, and our guide made me feel even more uncool because he was very rugged and handsome. After a couple of hours, he announced we were stopping for what he called “snack break,” as if we actually were kindergartners. He then mentioned that down a nearby path there was a cave we could check out. Not being a terrorist mastermind, I’ve never had a huge desire to hang out in a cave. But the opinion of absolute strangers means a lot to me, and I was desperate to differentiate myself from the other travelers in this cool, rugged guide’s eyes.
