headline: Now Showing | Haunted Houses
text: If your own cramped, un-air-conditioned apartment isn’t stifling enough for you right about now, pay a visit to “The House Without the Door,” a new group show at David Zwirner Gallery in Chelsea. Some of the homes represented, like Philip-Lorca diCorcia’s charred suburban pile, might very well be broken beyond repair. Gregor Schneider’s “Dead House,” on the other hand, has been so compulsively overconstructed, there is no apparent way out or in. Mona Hatoum’s “Home” is literally a charged place, where ordinary household objects carry the threat of electric shock. And the apartment of Thomas Ruff’s “Interieur 9B,” shown above, looks like its tenant might have been vacated feet first. All of the artists are somehow navigating that fraught psychological turf between house and home, according to Zwirner’s Kristine Bell, who put together the show and who shares her own “inescapable container” with two boys under the age of 6.

headline: The Value of Cooking
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cairene Bloggers Document New Protest
text: As our colleague Liam Stack reports, more than two dozen officials and allies of former President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt were charged with murder, attempted murder and terrorism on Thursday, in what many observers described as an attempt to neutralize the large demonstration planned for Friday.

headline: Age Is Just a Number — Right Now, 2,998 for One Person in Particular
text: After four games with the Yankees since coming back from the disabled list, Derek Jeter is 4-for-18. So those four hits mean he just needs another three to get to . . . the number of hits Eduardo Nunez had in his last two games filling in for Jeter.

headline: An Epidemic of Heater Failures
text: AUDIS with underperforming heaters and Ford pickups with clunking driveshafts are among the mechanical ailments covered in recent technical service bulletins.

headline: Going For Baroque
text: OK, after a terrible week on the economic policy front, I think we all need some music therapy:

headline: Pictures of the Day: Florida and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Florida, Afghanistan, Haiti and Sudan.

headline: Consulting Group Says E.V.’s Are Not Needed to Curb Greenhouse Emissions
text: In a report sure to rankle proponents and producers of electric vehicles, the Boston Consulting Group concluded that automakers could meet increasingly stringent federal greenhouse emissions requirements for 2020 mainly by making cost-effective improvements to existing internal combustion vehicles.

headline: When Time Comes, Giants Will Hold Camp at Home
text: The Giants announced Friday that they would hold training camp at their facility in East Rutherford, N.J., not their longtime summer base in Albany, because of “logistical and timing restrictions” resulting from the N.F.L. lockout.

headline: DealBook: Google’s Deal-Making Math
text: In a wide-ranging discussion at the Allen & Company conference here with Evelyn M. Rusli, Google’s chairman, Eric E. Schmidt talked to reporters about his company’s takeover ambitions and the threat of regulatory challenges. While increased antitrust scrutiny is a “concern,” Mr. Schmidt, the former chief executive of Google, said it should not significantly impact the company’s purchasing power, since the company is largely focused on bite-size acquisitions that are too small to land on regulators’ radar screens.

headline: Drilling Into New York’s Fracking Report
text: The New York Department of Environmental Conservation has posted the voluminous draft document laying out how the state plans to regulate the controversial gas drilling method known as fracking.

headline: Tweeting an Anniversary and 5 Million Slurpees
text: Each year, the 7-Eleven chain of convenience stores invites its customers to join in celebrating 7-Eleven Day, which is the anniversary of its founding on July 11, 1927.

headline: The First Lady of the N.B.A.
text: AS she was finishing lunch at the R Lounge overlooking Times Square recently, La La Anthony craned her neck and motioned toward the back of the room, over the head of her lunch guest, projectile whispering, “Just give me one second, O.K.!”

headline: Playing a Jukebox Full of Show Tunes
text: Sincere ambition — a combination of gee-whiz naïveté and drive — might describe the affable stage personality of Neil Berg, a composer, pianist, producer and outspoken baseball enthusiast whose theatrical sampler, “Broadway Showstoppers and the Songs of Neil Berg,” opened a two-week engagement at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency this week.

headline: Obscure Works With Famous Allusions
text: The most striking thing about the guitar recital Martha Masters presented on Thursday evening was not her playing — though that was satisfyingly fluid — so much as her approach to programming. The concert, part of the New York Guitar Seminar at Mannes College the New School for Music, was devoted largely to pieces that are not heard often, though in some cases lesser-known composers filled their works with allusions to more famous colleagues.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Florida and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Florida, Afghanistan, Haiti and Sudan.

headline: A $22 Billion Question for India: What to Do With a Treasure?
text: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM, India — What should India, rising but still plagued by poverty, do with a newly discovered treasure of gold coins, statues and jewels in the vault of a Hindu temple, valued at some $22 billion?

headline: Chasing Down Sea Lilies
text: Rich Mooi, curator of invertebrate zoology and geology at the California Academy of Sciences, writes about his expedition to the Philippines, where he surveyed echinoderms off the coast of Luzon Island.

headline: Bringing Up Baby Artichoke
text: IN Italy, artichokes are almost as common as onions, so normal and necessary are they considered. Every little vegetable shop has a crate of artichokes sitting casually by the front door, and entire stalls are devoted to them at the market. A pile of violet-tinged freshly picked beauties with their silvery leaves is quite an enticing sight. And the stalls come complete with little old ladies who will trim and prepare them for you if you want to pay a little extra.

headline: What Would ‘The Good Wife’ Do?
text: Two years ago, “The Good Wife,” a CBS drama, opened with a familiar tableau: a politician apologizing for sexual peccadilloes. By his side, also caught in the glare of cameras, was his pale, stone-faced wife. What was going through her mind? Since then,  politicians continue to face the cameras asking forgiveness. But wives have become conspicuous by their absence; the public no longer expects them to stand by their philanderers. What are these wives thinking? The show’s creators, Robert and Michelle King, who write together and have been married since 1987, speculate about the pressures  peculiar to the wives of errant politicians as they weigh whether to forgive their husbands.

headline: Artifacts of a Simpler, and Cheaper, Time
text: Tom Jolly, our former sports editor, is the Associate Managing Editor of The New York Times

headline: Artichokes, Sweet Young Things
text: Baby artichokes from foggy California are delicious and no trouble to prepare. Just peel a few outer petals to reveal the tender heart. To offset their natural sweetness, take a tip from Italy and pan-fry them for a tasty snack with drinks, an antipasto or light lunch, or an excellent accompaniment to simple grilled fish.

headline: TimesCast | Job Growth Falters
text: The Times's economics columnist David Leonhardt questions if President Obama is to blame for the slow job growth.

headline: The Jam | Dean Bein
text: Dean Bein, the founder of True Panther Sounds (home to indie artists like Girls, Delorean, Glasser and the king of Sierra Leone’s bubu music, Janka Nabay), offers the second installment of Sean Hanratty’s summer playlist. “I chose Dean for his earnest passion for music,” says Hanratty of the 28-year-old label head who attends roughly 300 shows each year. “His taste in music is pretty impeccable.” If you like what you hear, check out the second year of MoMA PS1 Warm Up 2011, which runs every Saturday through Sept. 3. Bein, along with many other record heads, is one of its curators.

headline: Crème Fraîche Cheesecake With Sour Cherries
text: Time: 11/2 hours, plus cooling

headline: Meeting in the Middle for a Velvety Cheesecake
text: AMONG cheesecake lovers, there’s a sharp divide. Some like their cheesecake New York deli style: rich cream-cheese-filled wedges, the best of which have not been shellacked with neon red bits that may or may not be berries.

headline: What You See Is What You Get
text: IN “The Invisible Gorilla,” a book about what we see and what we think we see (it came out in paperback in June), two cognitive psychologists, Christopher Chabris and Daniel Simons, describe an experiment they performed with a chess grandmaster named Patrick Wolff. They briefly showed him a diagram of a chess position from an “obscure master game,” gave him a set of pieces and asked him to re-create the position on an empty board from memory. He did so almost perfectly and then repeated his performance.

headline: 3, 2, 1, and the Last Shuttle Leaves an Era Behind
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — There was a time, some of us remember, when a countdown at Canaveral stopped the world in its tracks. On television or at the launching, every breath was held at liftoff and every eye followed the fiery plume of ascent, up and away. Godspeed, said someone who was everyone.

headline: Cheater’s Sour Cherry Cheesecake Crostini
text: If you crave the creamy richness of this sour cherry cheesecake but don’t feel like baking, here is a shortcut recipe. It’s less sweet than cheesecake but still dessert-worthy. Or serve it as a cheese course paired with a glass of sweet wine.

headline: Frolicking in Berlin and Outer Space
text: People on Sunday

headline: Rock Stars of Books: Musicians’ Big Sales
text: When Sammy Hagar appeared at Left Bank Books in St. Louis in March to autograph copies of his memoir, it was not a typical book signing.

headline: For Korda, There Is No End to the Burden of Fatherhood
text: COLORADO SPRINGS – After winning the 1998 Australian Open, the tennis player Petr Korda carried his daughter Jessica in his arms. Eleven years later, he was carrying Jessica’s bag as she began play in her fourth major, all United States Women’s Opens.

headline: From Solos to Duets
text: STANDING side by side one evening this spring at Smoke, the Upper West Side jazz haunt, Carolyn Leonhart and Wayne Escoffery seemed very much like a working team.

headline: Love’s Hard, Comic Work, on a Stage Most Worldly
text: The winter’s wind seems particularly biting in the forest of Arden that has sprung up in the Park Avenue Armory, just as the summer’s heat has begun to reach a peak. If you’re looking for an escape from swampy weather, the Royal Shakespeare Company’s production of “As You Like It” might prove just the ticket. Michael Boyd’s staging of one of Shakespeare’s most joyous comedies seems determined to remind us of the high cost of love’s pleasures, to the point that you begin to wonder if the prize could ever be worth the perils endured. The production emanates a distinct, unsettling chill, at least until the courtiers and rustics seeking love and sustenance in the woods begin to see a few green leaves sprouting from the trees, along with all that poetry.

headline: Wedding Etiquette
text: Saying Thank You In the 21st Century

headline: Scorecard | Azzedine Alaïa Wins!
text: The rest of the couture shows may have wrapped Wednesday, but Scorecard knows that if the ekphrastic praise for a women’s-wear master forever beloved by one French Culture Minister and one Cher Horowitz showing on schedule (sort-of) for the first time in 8 years is any proof, M. Alaïa wouldn’t have it any other way.

headline: She Wanted a TV Show, but the Stage Will Do, Too
text: Near the end of her infectiously nostalgic memoir with music, “The Judy Show: My Life as a Sitcom,” the writer and stand-up comic Judy Gold gives a shout-out to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo for championing the legislation that allows her to marry her therapist girlfriend in New York State. But the lack of acceptance in Burbank, Calif., still bothers her.

headline: The Week in Pictures for July 8
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a swim down the Hudson River, renovation of the Cortlandt Street subway station and a tour of shadows in Coney Island.

headline: Sudan Movement’s Mission Is Secured: Statehood
text: JUBA, Sudan — On the desk in his office in Juba, the capital of what will soon be the world’s newest country, R. Barrie Walkley, the American consul general, has a telling picture. It is of him and George Clooney shaking hands in a crowd during the independence referendum here in southern Sudan in January.

headline: Still Searching For Bruckner’s True Intentions
text: POSTERITY has not always treated Anton Bruckner kindly. The popular image of this composer as an unwitting visionary — “half genius, half klutz,” as the conductor Hans von Bülow once said — developed early on. During Bruckner’s lifetime conservative critics recoiled from his music. Eduard Hanslick called him the “gentlest and most peaceable of men who becomes an anarchist during the act of composition.”

headline: It’s Hard Out Here for a Reality-Show Celebrity
text: As goes the economy, so goes the reality-television gravy train. Once it was possible to swan from one show to the next, start a rumble or two, collect a check, then repeat. Shows that collect second-generation D-listers — like “Famous Food,” which begins Sunday on VH1 — serve as after-care facilities for reality veterans, made on the principle that no reality star, once filmed, should go unfilmed.

headline: Reviewing the Hyundai Elantra
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the 2012 Hyundai Elantra. The sedan wears the brand’s so-called fluidic sculpture design theme well, he writes, but a body crease here or a teardrop motif there might represent a touch too much for some shoppers:

headline: Between the North and South Poles, a Layover in New York
text: Few New Yorkers seemed to appreciate this week’s blazing sunshine like Johan Ernst Nilson. A sunburned Swedish explorer, on break from his journey from the North to the South Pole, Mr. Nilson leaned back in his chair in the entrance of the Standard Hotel on Tuesday morning, sipped a soda and relished the warmth. It’s not just been a long winter: it’s been a journey filled with chases by bears and death-defying dips in icy Arctic waters.

headline: Tech Companies: Undervalued or Not?
text: Marc Andreessen, one of Silicon Valley’s biggest venture capitalists, and Warren E. Buffett, of Berkshire Hathaway, have two things in common: They are both worth huge amounts of money, with billions of dollars at their investing disposal, and they both try to invest in companies that are undervalued.

headline: Musical Ambition, Defying All Barriers
text: Like a lot of the performers at this year’s Latin Alternative Music Conference, Henry D’Arthenay, the guitarist and singer of the Venezuelan band La Vida Bohème, pondered onstage whether to speak to the audience in Spanish or English. On Wednesday night at the Mercury Lounge, he made a quick decision: “Let’s communicate through music,” he said, in both languages.

headline: On the Street | Lining Up
text: Graphic stripes are the stars of summer fashion.

headline: Musical Americana Afloat at Bargemusic
text: The pianist Olga Vinokur has become a mainstay at Bargemusic, usually as a chamber player and sometimes as a soloist. She had the stage to herself on Wednesday evening, and she used the opportunity to present a program of American music, mostly by living composers and mostly in a tonal, approachable style.

headline: Unemployment; the Greek crisis; Japan’s prospects; the economics of summer camp; and brilliant investors in Congress.
text: Unemployment; the Greek crisis; Japan’s prospects; the economics of summer camp; and brilliant investors in Congress.

headline: Metropolitan Preview: Private School Enrollment and Tuition Rising
text: In this Sunday’s Metropolitan cover story, I chronicle the effort by the educational entrepreneur Chris Whittle to create Avenues, a new for-profit private school in Manhattan’s Chelsea neighborhood. An internationally focused school with a bilingual bent, it eventually plans to enroll about 1600 students in nursery through 12th grades.

headline: AntiSec Hackers Hit F.B.I. Contractor
text: Hackers who have claimed responsibility for a spate of recent break-ins said on Friday that they had infiltrated the networkof IRC Federal, an engineering contractor that works for federal agencies including the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and stole internal documents from its database and e-mail system.

headline: Chic in Review | Justin Who?
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.BalenciagaNew fall 2011 ad campaign will make its debut next week on a brand-new Web site.

headline: Lazard’s Golub, a Vice Chairman, Retires
text: Steven J. Golub, a longtime veteran of Lazard who briefly served as interim chief executive of the investment bank, has retired, a spokeswoman confirmed on Friday.

headline: Costas and Michaels Team Up to Call Mets-Giants
text: On Friday at 10 p.m. Eastern, Bob Costas and Al Michaels will call the Mets-San Francisco Giants game on the MLB Network. They will announce the first three and the eighth and ninth innings on the network. To accommodate fans in the New York and San Francisco markets, where the MLB broadcast will be blacked out, Costas and Michaels will head to the Mets’ SNY booth for the fourth and fifth innings and SNY’s Gary Cohen and Ron Darling will shift to the MLB booth. When Costas and Michaels work in the Giants’ CSN Bay Area booth for the sixth and seventh innings, the Giants announcers Mike Krukow and Duane Kuiper will replace them on MLB. Although this is billed as the first game Costas and Michaels have called together, they were boothmates in the movie “BASEketball,” a 1998 comedy. It will, indeed, be the first baseball game for Michaels since 1995, when he was at ABC Sports.

headline: Optimism Encounters Frustration
text: “Are any of you guys 14 or 15?” Rachel Taylor asked from the stage at the Studio at Webster Hall on Wednesday night. “Or are we finally playing to a crowd of people out of middle school?”

headline: The Best School $75 Million Can Buy
text: How do you sell a school that doesn’t exist?

headline: Dawn & Jibril
text: Dawn Zimniak and Jibril Jackson recount how love at first sight turned into long-lasting chemistry, two dogs, and a wedding proposal.

headline: Marriage With Challenges
text: As we have all been made aware again, recent events have caused newsmagazines, opinion leaders and millions of females in the United States and France to wonder: What in creation is up with men? Why all the sexual entitlement, puerile text messaging and secret paternities? Moreover, given what we’ve seen of male instinct, is any man ever really knowable?

headline: The Danger of a Little Learning

headline: Up Next for U.S.: Rematch With Mexico
text: The United States national team’s first game since the Gold Cup will be a doozy: a rematch of the Gold Cup final with Mexico on Aug. 10 at Lincoln Financial Field in Philadelphia.

headline: Allegations Link U.S. Companies to Brazilian Sex Tourism
text: The Justice Department has been conducting a criminal investigation of sports fishing expeditions in the Amazon that may have been used as covers for Americans to have sex with underage girls, according to newly filed court papers.

headline: Just Sign Here
text: Say what you will about Michele Bachmann, she’s not media-shy. Nor is she particularly hesitant about stating her beliefs. And judging from the level of coverage she has received since announcing her candidacy for president on the Republican ticket, the media is quite interested in her every public move.

headline: A Demonstration of Science Seemingly Made for TV
text: So many of the stories that temporarily unite the United States are tragic, even cataclysmic. Shooting sprees. Trial verdicts. Bombings. Acts of God.

text: After months of bleak unemployment reports, bad news isn’t very surprising. But this bad?

headline: Some 3,000-Hit Quirks
text: As much as Derek Jeter’s pursuit of 3,000 hits has been chronicled around the clock, the moment he finally does reach the milestone — in the age of high definition and smartphones — will be even more inescapable.

headline: Shutdown in Minnesota Ripples Out to Day Care
text: LEXINGTON, Minn. — Among the thousands of people struggling with the state government shutdown here, 14-year-old Skye might be among the most unlikely.

headline: As Same-Sex Marriage Becomes Legal, Some Choices May Be Lost
text: Now that same-sex marriage has been legalized in New York, at least a few large companies are requiring their employees to tie the knot if they want their partners to qualify for health insurance.

headline: Companies That Make Gay Couples Marry to Get Benefits
text: At least a few big companies in New York — Corning, I.B.M. and Raytheon — are now requiring their gay employees to marry if they want health coverage for their same-sex partners.

headline: Brunch, Biking and a Fancy Cocktail
text: Six days a week, Sheila Lewandowski, 46, and Brian Rogers, 38, run an adventurous performance space in Long Island City, Queens, called the Chocolate Factory theater. On Sundays they forage for cholesterol and watch “Battlestar Galactica” on Netflix. The couple, who are married, live next door to the theater with their dog, J. R., a pit bull terrier and Labrador retriever mix that they found on the Jackie Robinson Parkway.

headline: Pakistan Condemns Mullen’s Statement on Journalist’s Killing
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani government issued an angry denunciation on Friday of the statement by the Obama administration’s top military official that the killing of a Pakistani journalist was sanctioned by the nation’s authorities.

text: The best of readers’ street fashion submissions for the week of July 4.

text: PHILADELPHIA — Who owns 10 exceedingly rare American gold coins from 1933?

headline: Memory AWOL, Robbery Suspect Still Figures He Didn’t Do It
text: Every now and then on a given afternoon, when the Q100 bus pulls to a stop on 21st Street in Queens, somebody actually gets off. But mostly, people just keep getting on, and on, and on, cramming themselves in the center aisle, all bound for the final destination.

headline: Runner-Up to Weiner in 2010 Is G.O.P. Choice to Run for Seat
text: Republican Party leaders in Queens and Brooklyn on Friday chose Bob Turner, a retired cable television executive, as their nominee in a Sept. 13 special election to fill the seat of former Representative Anthony D. Weiner.

headline: Amylin to Resubmit Diabetes Treatment to F.D.A.
text: Amylin Pharmaceuticals, a biopharmaceutical company, said its experimental diabetes treatment Bydureon will be resubmitted for regulatory approval in the United States this quarter. The company, based in San Diego, and its partners, Eli Lilly & Company of Indianapolis and Alkermes of Waltham, Mass., announced late Thursday that a study requested by the Food and Drug Administration did not tie Bydureon to dangerous changes to heart rhythm. The data were released in summary form on June 24. The F.D.A. rejected Bydureon, a longer-acting form of the companies’ Byetta medicine, in October over concerns that high doses might cause heart risks. The companies said Thursday that they planned to refile their application with the new data on heart rhythm in the third quarter, sooner than expected.

headline: Google’s Chairman to Testify Before a Senate Panel
text: Eric E. Schmidt, the executive chairman of Google, has agreed to testify at a Senate subcommittee hearing on the company’s dominance of the Internet search industry, yielding to the panel’s demands. Mr. Schmidt will testify in September, the company said Friday. “We’re happy to accommodate” the subcommittee, said Mistique Cano, a spokeswoman for the company. The move resolves a standoff between the company and the Senate Judiciary antitrust subcommittee, which had threatened to subpoena Mr. Schmidt or Google’s chief executive, Larry Page. The subcommittee plans to examine whether Google is using its position as owner of the world’s most popular search engine to hurt competition in the Internet industry. The Federal Trade Commission, the European Union and the State of Texas are looking into accusations by Internet companies that Google favored its own services in search results and increased ad rates on its rivals.

headline: Deutsche Bank Said to Be Ready to Select New Leader
text: LONDON — The question of who will become chief executive of Deutsche Bank is likely to be resolved this weekend when members of the bank’s board are set to meet and propose a successor to the current chief, Josef Ackermann, according to two people with direct knowledge of the situation.

headline: An Evolving View of Natural Family Planning
text: In August 1999, Bethany Patchin, an 18-year-old college sophomore from Wisconsin, wrote in an article for Boundless, an evangelical Web magazine, that Christians should not kiss before marriage. Sam Torode, a 23-year-old Chicagoan, replied in a letter to the editor that Ms. Patchin’s piece could not help but “drive young Christian men mad with desire.”

headline: The Upper East Side vs. the Waste Transfer Station
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Tactic in Fight Against Doping: No Syringes Allowed
text: Biathletes and cross-country skiers have been caught with blood-doping paraphernalia at the Olympics. Major League Baseball players have claimed they have received injections — not of steroids, but of vitamins and painkillers. Cycling teams have left behind trash cans littered with syringes.

headline: Women on Bikes in the City
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bikers’ Dream: A Bronx Velodrome
text: DWARFED by the soaring expanse of the long-vacant Kingsbridge Armory, a small group of bike advocates and Bronx residents strolled through the main hall recently and imagined a mecca of bicycling.

headline: For an Endless Summer, With Beach Food
text: Giving new meaning to the notion of an underground surf scene, Thomas Wilson, a former owner of Mas, and Gene Ashe, a former general manager at 5 Ninth, have brought the feeling of endless summer to the basement of the Film Center Building on 44th Street just east of Ninth Avenue. Open since last summer, Réunion Surf Bar, named for a French-owned island off the coast of Madagascar and decorated with boards Mr. Wilson frequently pulls down to ride out in East Hampton, has become a hub for Broadway actors, employees of Billabong and Quiksilver, creative-industry workers from the area and surfers looking for quirky takes on beach food and tropical cocktails. Last year, Laird Hamilton paid a visit with Julian Schnabel, but on Wednesday the happy hour crowd included two friends from college sharing their impressions of first moving to New York. DIANE CARDWELL

headline: Training School Principals
text: To the Editor:

text: APP WhatWasThere

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Q. There is a plaque at 82 Jane Street in the Village stating that Alexander Hamilton died there in 1804 after his duel with Aaron Burr in New Jersey. To me the building does not look as old as 1804. Please advise if the plaque is correct, or should it read “On this site”?

headline: The New State of South Sudan
text: On Saturday, South Sudan becomes a free and independent country. It is a well-deserved victory for its people. Under a 2005 American-backed political accord that ended two decades of civil war, the people of the mainly Christian territory voted overwhelmingly in January to secede from the Arab Muslim north.

headline: I Owe William Jennings Bryan an Apology
Pakistani Troops Ordered to Use Bullets to Quell Karachi Turmoil
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — The federal government gave paramilitary and other security forces shoot-on-sight orders against gunmen who have plunged this sprawling southern port city into four days of ethnic and political violence that has left more than 70 dead, including 18 people on Friday.

headline: For Hire: A Visitor to the Grave of Your Dearly Departed
text: Hawthorne, N.Y.

headline: Central Park Cyclists Get Wish to Share Shortcut. But Slowly.
text: Bicyclists trying to get legally from one side of Central Park to the other have long faced a challenge: because the park’s pedestrian paths are closed to cyclists, they have to either ride the looping vehicular drive south to 60th Street and then head north again, potentially going miles out of their way, or brave the narrow, crowded transverse roads.

headline: Governor Says Montana Was Misled on Oil Spill
text: HELENA, Mont. — Gov. Brian Schweitzer criticized Exxon Mobil on Friday for its handling of the Yellowstone River oil spill, saying that the company had withheld documents and misled state officials and local residents about the pipeline rupture.

headline: How to Promote a Merger
text: It seems surprising that organizations dedicated to advocating for gays and lesbians, African-Americans or teachers could take such a burning interest in telecoms that they would endorse AT&T’s $39 billion plan to buy T-Mobile, which is under review by the Federal Communications Commission and the Justice Department.

headline: A Bridge Too Low and a Lesson for Visionaries
text: I’m concerned that the Second Avenue subway project makes no allowance for personal teleportation modules. I’m worried that the new wing of the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, does not account for the possibility that films might someday be projected directly onto the backsides of our eyelids.

headline: Grief and Questions After Death at Ballpark
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Josh Hamilton doesn’t make a habit of tossing baseballs to fans in the stands, so when he fielded a foul ball early in Thursday night’s game against the Oakland Athletics, he did what he usually does — he turned it over to the ball girl along the left-field line at Rangers Ballpark.

headline: California Cuts Weigh Heavily on Its Colleges
text: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — The doors to the state’s newest medical school are already open, technically. A gleaming building with new labs is ready to house researchers and students. But when the state budget was approved last week, the plans to open the medical school at the University of California’s campus here were shelved for at least another year.

headline: Safe, Not Sorry, on Drilling
text: The Cuomo administration seems prepared to strike the right balance between environmental protection and economic development as it writes the rules that will govern hydraulic fracturing, a controversial technique used to extract natural gas from shale formations.

headline: Phone Scandal Poses Defining Test for a Murdoch Son
text: On Thursday afternoon, James Murdoch assembled senior executives in the top-floor boardroom in the News Corporation’s London headquarters and told them of a momentous decision: to shutter the 168-year-old tabloid at the center of a deepening phone-hacking scandal and the original heart of the Murdoch media empire in Britain.

headline: Perils of Smoking, on Graphic Display
text: The World Health Organization issued a report on Thursday noting that large pictorial warnings on cigarette packages are effective in deterring smoking. The report, which addresses the global smoking epidemic, validates the recent decision by the United States Food and Drug Administration to require that big, stark images be placed on cigarette packages and advertisements to show that smoking causes death and severe illness.

headline: Pentagon Shift Ends Ousters Under ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon instructed the military on Friday to stop removing personnel who are gay from service and to begin accepting applications from homosexual recruits who are otherwise qualified to serve.

headline: Celebrating a Connection to Three Collectors
text: Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

headline: TimesCast | U.K. Tabloid Scandal
text: July 8, 2011 - Arrests deepen the crisis swirling around Rupert Murdoch's media empire in Britain.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Betty Ford, Former First Lady, Dies at 93
text: Betty Ford, the outspoken and much-admired wife of President Gerald R. Ford who overcame alcoholism and an addiction to pills and helped found one of the best-known rehabilitation centers in the nation, died Friday in Rancho Mirage, Calif. She was 93.

headline: From the Gutter, Into the Sewer
text: London

headline: An Advocate for Hunters Discusses Wolves’ Return
text: This spring, Congress passed legislation that removed wolves from the endangered species list in Montana and Idaho. This delisting represents a success, of sorts, for the controversial federal program that reintroduced wolves to the northern Rockies in the 1990s.

headline: HBO Comedy Will Find Discomfort in Baseball
text: Larry David was fretting about Derek Jeter. “What do you think?” he asked as he arrived at breakfast in Manhattan on Thursday, when Jeter’s career hit total was 2,997. “Do you think he can do it?”

headline: New Art Fair to Mix Charity and Contemporary Works
text: THE smell of oil paint in the Bridgehampton air will barely have dissipated from one art fair before another begins this week. The inaugural artMRKT Hamptons, to be held from Thursday to July 17 on the grounds of the Bridgehampton Historical Society, comes hard on the heels of ArtHamptons, less than a mile away at Sayre Park, which closes Sunday.

headline: WNPR Host Brings Her Mike to East End
text: Sagaponack, N.Y.

headline: Murdoch’s Fatal Flaw
text: It’s often been noted — especially of late — that Rupert Murdoch’s entree into British newspapering took place in 1969, when, as a brash young Australian publisher, he bought The News of the World, a spicy Sunday paper that he turned into an even spicier tabloid, a cross between The New York Post and The National Enquirer.

headline: Rangers Re-Sign Michael Sauer and Artem Anisimov
text: The Rangers announced Friday that they re-signed defenseman Michael Sauer and center Artem Anisimov, but three other restricted free agents remain unsigned and face salary arbitration hearings in Toronto later this month.

headline: Egypt’s Tahrir Square Again Echoes With Cries for Justice
text: CAIRO — One woman called for a new revolution. A man called for former President Hosni Mubarak to be executed. An angry crowd in an auditorium here on Thursday night listened to stories of protesters injured or killed during Egypt’s revolution and in demonstrations since, and stood and applauded when a mother spoke of loss.

headline: Anthony Verdict Sets Off Spate of New Legislation
text: The jury has spoken, the public has seethed and now it is time for politicians to offer their opinions on the verdict that dominated the news.

headline: Saturday: Titanic-Taloned Terrorizers
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — We first met Caleb Madison in the spring of 2008, when at the age of 15 years and 3 months, he became the youngest constructor published during Will Shortz’s tenure at the time (Across Lite, Solution). Time marches on however, and while that torch has been passed to other youngsters, Mr. Madison has now graduated from high school and is on his way to an Ivy League university in the fall. Let’s all take a moment to pat ourselves on the backs and delude ourselves into thinking that doing his puzzles motivated him to become the fine, young, upstanding, educated gentleman he is today. We might as well take at least partial credit for it.

headline: A Gloomy Report on Jobs
text: In June, the economy added only 18,000 jobs.

headline: Nat King Cole, Beyond the Music
text: MANY of us remember Nat King Cole’s gentle, mellifluous voice singing hits like “The Christmas Song,” “Too Young,” “When I Fall in Love” and “It’s All in the Game.” And of course “Unforgettable,” which his daughter Natalie Cole turned into a poignant two-generation duet.

headline: Ritual Power, Gathered at the Bruce
text: Judging from the comments in the visitors’ book at the Bruce Museum, “Power Incarnate: Allan Stone’s Collection of Sculpture from the Congo” is a very popular show.

headline: The D.S.K. Endgame
text: For almost two months now, the chattering classes in London, Paris, New York and the Hamptons have struggled to talk about anything but D.S.K. The old animalistic elements have exerted their magnetism: power, sex, violence and race.

headline: Cuomo Appoints Top Aide of Paterson’s as His Own
text: Lawrence S. Schwartz, a longtime adviser to Democratic politicians who once helped run a campaign for former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, was appointed on Friday to be the top aide to Mario’s son, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: At Princeton, a Grueling Summer Program to Perfect Pliés
text: PRINCETON, N.J.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around New Jersey. Items may be submitted by mail to the New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Death Penalty, Still Racist and Arbitrary
text: Houston

headline: Corrections: July 9
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Every Ware Imaginable
text: A good pan is hard to find. But not if you make your way to Harris Restaurant Supply in Port Chester. Although the place has been in business for more than 40 years, the front door is as discreet as a speakeasy’s — even the G.P.S. can’t quite locate it (hint: Harris is just south of Mill Street). Yet inside lies a Disney World of wares for kitchen and table, indoors and out — 8,000 square feet of them.

headline: Tastes Imported From Southern Italy
text: THE roomy patio of Le Fontane in Katonah is especially appealing on a hot summer’s day, or night. Greenery surrounds the secluded sheltered area, and a few fans keep the air moving. Although this carefully created restaurant with a kitchen inspired by southern Italy is closer to Route 100 than to the Appian Way, the winsome service and warm, garden-sweet air on the patio lend the feel of there, rather than here. Not least, the food can be quite good and the prices reasonable.

headline: The Family of Israel Switt vs. The U.S. Department of Treasury
text: Court documents related to the civil case brought by Israel Switt’s heirs. The family wants to retrieve rare coins that the federal government says were stolen.

headline: U.S. to Face Mexico Again
text: The United States national team’s first game since the Gold Cup will be a rematch of the final with Mexico on Aug. 10 in Philadelphia. It will be their first meeting in a friendly since 2008.

headline: Yeast Is in the Air? Then Bake!
text: When Keith Kouris, 54, opened the Blue Duck Bakery Café in Southampton with his wife, Nancy, in 1999, all the breads were made in the little kitchen in back. As the business grew — Blue Duck breads are now in markets and restaurants from Montauk to Manhattan — Mr. Kouris moved his bread-baking operation in 2008 to Southold.

headline: For a New Bistro, Big Shoes to Fill
text: WHEN Bistro M closed in April, foodies across Long Island were unhappy. The tiny restaurant, nestled beside the railroad tracks in Glen Head, was one of the best around. But their dismay was short-lived, because in May, Mitchell SuDock, an owner and the executive chef of Bistro M, and Toni Contino, the dining room manager there, opened Mitch and Toni’s American Bistro.

headline: Lost Day for Jeter and Missed Opportunity for Fans
text: Derek Jeter grabbed a pen from his locker Friday afternoon and drew an imaginary circle around the weather map on his computer screen. The New York area was covered in yellow, orange and green. “That’s not good,” Jeter said.

headline: Caramel Caribou, in a Cone
text: Salem Valley Farms Ice Cream Company is housed in a red, barnlike building that sits amid a patch of grass to the southwest of downtown Salem. It is less than 10 miles from Devil’s Hopyard State Park and Gillette Castle, and on the warmer days of summer every bit as popular a tourist attraction.

headline: Brasserie Cuisine True to Its French Roots
text: IN the shade of a chestnut tree outside Le Laurentis Brasserie in Lakeville, two men wearing aprons over their jeans were playing what I mistakenly referred to as boccie. “It’s pétanque,” one of them said — setting the scene for the solidly Gallic experience to come.

headline: Chris Cahill, 54, of Skateboarding’s Z-Boys, Dies
text: Chris Cahill, an original member of the Zephyr team or Z-Boys, a skateboarding phenomenon that transformed the sport with punk belligerence and a fluid surfing style born in a rundown Southern California neighborhood, was found dead on June 24 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 54.

headline: Burgers, With Pucks on the Side
text: The owners of Uber Burger, a 100-seat, fast-casual restaurant that opened at the Prudential Center complex in December, seem to have a good handle on what people attending an event in the arena might want. One of the seven partners is Mark Gheduzzi, senior vice president for facilities with the New Jersey Devils, and another is Gordon Lavalette, the team’s executive vice president for finance and administration.

headline: For No-Frills Barbecue, a Trip to the Strip Mall
text: IT has been years since I savored barbecued pork the way it is served in South Carolina, and even longer since I had a plate of it Memphis-style, but a sign for barbecue still catches my eye. When it is paired with the word greens, evoking dark, silky collards or turnip greens or mustard greens that have been cooked on the back of the stove all day, it’s enough to make me turn the car around.

headline: Rangers Re-Sign Sauer and Anisimov
text: The Rangers announced that they had re-signed defenseman Michael Sauer and center Artem Anisimov, but three other restricted free agents remain unsigned and face salary arbitration hearings in Toronto later this month.

headline: Night Raids Curbing Taliban, but Afghans Cite Civilian Toll
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — United States Special Operations forces have carried out an extraordinary number of night raids over the past year, turning them into one of their most effective tools against the insurgents even as they stir accusations of abuse, resentment among Afghans and divisions with the government.

headline: Bloggingheads: Tweeter in Chief
text: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Matt Lewis of The Daily Caller debate Obama's use of social media.

headline: A Natural Talent Who Reaches Unnatural Speeds
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Upon first glance, there is little that stands out about Bobby Parnell. At 6 feet 4 inches and 200 pounds, he is relatively tall, but by no means does he possess the presence of the imposing Randy Johnson.

headline: A Rainy Day for the Yankees
text: The weather kept the Yankees off the field and fans outside the stadium gates.

headline: A Bed and a Key at 81 Bowery
text: Annie Ling spent a year photographing the Chinese immigrants living in cramped quarters in a tenement on the Bowery.

headline: A Murdoch Loyalist Hangs On, Raising Questions About a Corporate Strategy
text: LEICESTER, England — Despite the scandal burning around News International, its top executive, Rebekah Brooks, rebuffed numerous calls for her to resign on Friday, raising questions about the strategy of its parent company, the News Corporation, in defending itself against a barrage of police inquiries and lawsuits stemming from phone hacking at one of its British tabloid newspapers.

headline: Manuel Galbán, Guitarist With Cuban Bands, Dies at 80
text: Manuel Galbán, a Cuban guitarist best known for his work with the all-star ensemble Buena Vista Social Club and its various offshoots, died on Thursday in Havana. He was 80.

headline: Officer in Critical Condition After Punch in Bronx Street Encounter
text: As temperatures hovered in the 80s on Wednesday, a group of children frolicked in the spray of an open fire hydrant in the Bronx. Then someone among them hurled a cup of water or a water-filled balloon at a passing car, the authorities said, setting off a chain of events that left a New York City police officer in critical condition two days later.

headline: 9/11 Memorial Reservations to Be Offered on Web Site
text: With two months to go before its scheduled opening, the 9/11 Memorial in Lower Manhattan will start taking reservations online on Monday morning.

headline: Betty Ford Dies
text: Betty Ford, the outspoken and much-admired wife of President Gerald R. Ford, has died at 93.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: July 8, 2011

headline: A New Breed of Campaign Tracker
text: Michael D. Shear reports from New Hampshire on Aaron Fielding, whose full time job is is to get close to Republicans with his video camera.

headline: Trailing G.O.P. With Cameras, Seeking Gaffes
text: AMHERST, N.H. — Aaron Fielding quietly stalks his prey — Republicans — with his video camera, patiently waiting for a political moment worthy of YouTube.

headline: Alabama: Suit Fights Immigration Law
text: Civil rights groups filed a class-action lawsuit on Friday against a new state law that cracks down on illegal immigration, saying it would violate the constitutional rights of United States citizens. The law, which supporters described as the toughest of its kind in the nation, requires public schools to report students’ immigration status, makes it a crime to give a ride to an illegal immigrant and bars all contracts with those immigrants. “This law revisits the state’s painful racial past,” said Mary Bauer, legal director of the Southern Poverty Law Center, one of the groups bringing the suit.

headline: Massachusetts: Mob Boss’s Girlfriend Will Ask for Release From Jail
text: Catherine Greig, the longtime girlfriend of James (Whitey) Bulger, will ask to be released into home confinement at a federal court hearing on Monday, according to papers filed by her lawyer. Ms. Greig, 60, went on the run with Mr. Bulger in 1995 and was captured with him in California last month. She is charged with harboring a fugitive, a crime that carries a maximum sentence of five years. Her lawyer, Kevin Reddington, wrote in a court filing on Thursday that Ms. Greig was not a criminal but a “traveling companion” to Mr. Bulger, 81, a former Boston crime boss charged in 19 murders. Ms. Greig, he wrote, is “a kind, gentle person with a loving personality.” Ms. Greig and her twin sister would put up their homes as collateral, according to the filing.

headline: Sheila Bair’s Bank Shot
text: ‘They should have let Bear Stearns fail,” Sheila Bair said.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Alaska, Seriously?
text: With only one episode of “Friday Night Lights” left, sadly, we are being prepped for departure and readied for leaving Texas.

headline: 2nd Brazilian Official Quits in Graft Case, Giving New Leader a Chance to Clean House
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The resignation this week of yet another minister in the government of Dilma Rousseff, the president of Brazil, may have added to the tumult of her nascent presidency, but it is also showing that her managerial push for efficiency could make it tougher for corruption to persist in her administration, analysts said.

headline: A Women’s Soccer Wellspring for 40 Years
text: In the German city of Potsdam, a soccer team and academy has helped shaped the women’s game in Germany since the nation was divided.

headline: On Eve of Moscow Gala, Questions Swirl About a Charity and Its Stars
text: MOSCOW — For a month, this city has been preparing for the most spectacular, glittering charity concert in recent history.

headline: Georgia: Photographers Still Jailed
text: Responding to concerns raised by local rights groups and photojournalists, President Mikheil Saakashvili’s administration denied Friday that the arrest this week of a group of photographers on suspicions of spying was made in retaliation for their journalistic work. Manana Manjgaladze, Mr. Saakashvili’s spokeswoman, said the case “is about a serious leakage of information from our institutions, not about journalism or media activities.” A civil rights group, the Georgian Young Lawyers’ Association, asked the Interior Ministry to publicly justify the secrecy concerning the case. One of the four remaining detainees, Giorgi Abdaladze, a freelancer, has announced a hunger strike, according to his lawyer. The police released a fifth, a photographer for The Associated Press, early Thursday.

headline: Battle for Libya | July 8, 2011
text: Libyans gathered for Friday prayers in Zintan and Benghazi.

headline: Rwanda: Sentencing in Genocide
text: A Dutch court of appeal has sentenced a Rwandan refugee to life in prison for his role during Rwanda’s 1994 genocide. The refugee, Joseph Mpambara, 43, an ethnic Hutu businessman, led an attack on an Adventist compound in Muganero where Tutsi families had sought shelter, and hundreds were killed during the resulting bloodbath, the court said. He also was involved in holding up an ambulance that was carrying two Tutsi women and their children who were hacked to death with machetes, the three judges found.

headline: France: Inquiry of Official Delayed
text: A French court on Friday postponed for the second time a decision about investigating claims that Christine Lagarde, the new chief of the International Monetary Fund, abused her power as the French finance minister in 2008. A decision is now expected on Aug. 4. At issue is her intervention in a legal battle between the businessman Bernard Tapie and the Crédit Lyonnais bank. As finance minister, Ms. Lagarde cut short legal proceedings and chose independent arbitration instead. Mr. Tapie was awarded about 400 million euros.

headline: Germany: Vote on Saudi Tank Deal
text: German opposition parties were unable to muster a majority to oppose the reported multibillion-dollar deal to sell 200 German-made tanks to Saudi Arabia. The news that Chancellor Angela Merkel and Germany’s security council had signed off on the shipment of state-of-the-art tanks to the Middle East after the Saudis helped suppress the uprising in Bahrain led to an uproar this week and to the failed attempt by left-wing parties to scuttle arms shipments through legislation in the Bundestag. Mrs. Merkel, who also leads the security council, has refused to confirm or deny that a deal is in place, citing legal requirements to keep all the council’s decisions secret.

headline: Uploaded Upheaval: Famous Tracker Videos
text: In recent years, fallout from footage by operatives with video cameras has changed the course of elections.

headline: A Pioneering Gay Bar in Atlantic City
text: Prohibition, a gay bar and nightclub at Resorts Casino Hotel, is trying to tap a ripe market.

headline: The World This Week
text: A look back at the case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn and protests in Syria.

headline: Mets Beat Giants with Three Runs in Ninth
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A year ago, the Mets arrived at AT&T Park eight games over .500 and with Carlos Beltran set to make his season debut after off-season knee surgery. It was supposed to be the beginning of a push toward an unexpected playoff run in the second half of the season, but it turned out to be the beginning of a cascade into oblivion.

headline: Thousands of Malaysians Rally for Changes to Elections
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Police officers arrested almost 1,700 people and fired tear gas at protesters here in Malaysia’s capital on Saturday in an attempt to prevent an afternoon rally by advocates of an overhaul of elections.

headline: The Weekend Word: Stumbling
text: Today’s Times

headline: Kerry Collins, Unappreciated Quarterback
text: Because Kerry Collins had an uneven and at times tumultuous career, his retirement announcement on Thursday did not receive much fanfare. (A lockout doesn’t help matters.)

headline: What if the Debt Ceiling Isn’t Raised?
text: There are few signs of progress in the meetings between President Obama and Republican Congressional leaders about the need to raise the federal debt limit.

headline: Urban Forager | It’s Prime Time for Black Raspberries
text: Sweet, tart and thimble-shaped, black raspberries resemble the red supermarket variety, only they are smaller and give a greater punch to the palate. This time of year, black raspberries are ripe and abundant throughout the city and the metropolitan area, growing wild along the side of the road, on parkland and in neighbors’ backyards.

headline: Panetta Says Defeat of Al Qaeda Is ‘Within Reach’
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta, who arrived in Kabul on Saturday, said the United States was “within reach of strategically defeating Al Qaeda” and that the American focus had narrowed to capturing or killing 10 to 20 crucial leaders of the terrorist group in Pakistan, Somalia and Yemen.

headline: This Sunday: Nocera Shoots, Scores
text: If Joe Nocera had his way — and he usually does — it wouldn’t be me writing this note, it would be him. Last fall, he was a top candidate for the job as editor of this magazine, and miraculously, I ended up with it instead. I didn’t know him well at the time. In fact, the only real conversation I’d had with him before then was when I tried to lure him to come work with me at Bloomberg Businessweek. I liked him instantly, though, and before I even moved in to my new office here, we had lunch, and I asked him to be my part-time consigliere, while he kept writing his Saturday column for the business page.

headline: Endless Summer
text: Mickey Black, the third-generation owner of Pine Forest Camp in northeastern Pennsylvania, is facing increasingly demanding expectations from his clients for the summer camp experience.

headline: Making Summer Camp Worth It
text: The business of summer camp has grown tougher because of the economy, but parents also expect more.

headline: When S’Mores Aren’t Enough: The New Economics of Summer Camp
text: Greeley, Pa.

headline: Live From Estadio Mario Alberto Kempes … It’s Mario Alberto Kempes
text: For millions of Argentines, his name ranks high along with anyone named Perón, or Maradona.

headline: The Fatalist Temptation
text: I’m seeing more and more pieces like this one, in which pundits look at stubbornly high unemployment and declare that it must be structural — something we just have to live with, or at least something that will take long-term policies (translation — someone else’s problem) rather than mere stimulus, to correct.

headline: Anti-stimulus
text: Here’s the CBO estimate of the effect of the Recovery Act on the deficit — not identical to its likely effect on the economy, but a rough guide — in billions of dollars, by fiscal year (fiscal years start in October of the previous calendar year):

headline: A-Rod Facing Knee Surgery
text: We interrupt the Derek Jeter 3,000 watch for some news with potentially much more importance for the 2011 Yankees: Alex Rodriguez has a meniscus tear in his right knee.

headline: Italy Premier Loses Appeal on a Fine
text: ROME — A Milan appeals court on Saturday ordered one of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s family holding companies to pay $798 million to a rival group as compensation for its corrupt activities in a takeover battle, further weakening the prime minister.

headline: After Years of Struggle, South Sudan Becomes a New Nation
text: JUBA, South Sudan — The celebrations erupted at midnight. Thousands of revelers poured into Juba’s steamy streets in the predawn hours on Saturday, hoisting enormous flags, singing, dancing and leaping on the back of cars.

headline: With Suzuki, There’s Less Than Meets the Eye
text: It was April 2001, and I had gone to Oakland Coliseum to see what the big deal was with the new Seattle Mariners outfielder Ichiro Suzuki.

headline: Rodriguez Must Decide: Surgery Now or Later
text: Even as a diminished version of himself for the last few weeks, Alex Rodriguez has still gotten hits, reached base and played strong defense at third base. But Rodriguez is paid for his all-around game, including speed and prodigious power. Without those, he is not the same.

headline: A Severe Case of Portfolio Whiplash
text: MARKETS continued to zigzag in the second quarter as investors sought risk, then shunned it, then sought it again — depending on whether they were unnerved by economic and political developments or hopeful for benign resolutions to them. Ultimately, not much was resolved, but there may have been more sleep lost than money, as stocks were little changed and bonds recorded modest gains.

headline: This Time, Japan’s Gloom Runs Deeper
text: TOKYO

headline: Not-So-Representative Investors
text: SHOW me a new study about water on the moon, or why pregnant women don’t tip over, and I’m happy as a pig in whatever it is that pigs like. I’m just a big fan of science.

headline: A Snatched Cat, and Then a Snatched Flier About a Snatched Cat
text: Melvin Bukiet walked out of his five-story town house on West 108th Street on Tuesday and went the half-block to Broadway to drop a letter in the mailbox.

headline: Variety: A Tougher-Than-Usual Cryptic
text: Administrivial Chance-To-Win-Valuable-Prizes Update: If you are planning to be in the New York City area on or about the date of August 6 between the hours of 11AM and 5 PM, sign yourself up for Lollapuzzoola 4, the crossword tournament that is just about the most fun you can have with a sharp #2 pencil. Your hosts, Brian Cimmet and Patrick Blindauer, tell me that the constructors of the puzzles you will be wrestling to the ground are Mike Nothnagel, Elizabeth C. Gorski, Andrea Carla Michaels, Tony Orbach, Doug Peterson, and Byron Walden. There will also be non-tournament games by Neville Fogarty, Allison Cimmet and Todd McClary. Click here to sign yourself up for an amazingly fun day!

headline: China’s Rapid Growth Doesn’t Ensure Stock Gains
text: ECONOMIC superlatives abound about China. It’s the world’s biggest auto market. It’s the largest producer of steel and, of course, the largest exporter. Yet there has been nothing extraordinary lately about the performance of China-focused mutual funds.

headline: An Inflation Hedge Carries Its Own Risks
text: INVESTORS who placed bets on mutual funds specializing in inflation-protected Treasury securities were among the bond market’s biggest winners over the last two years, even as other Treasury funds struggled.

headline: Behind the Rush Into Exchange-Traded Funds
text: EXCHANGE-TRADED funds have clearly come of age.

headline: Investment Tips for the Accident-Prone
text: IT’S one of the oldest jokes on Wall Street:

headline: Best Seat in House? It’s in the House
text: After a few brief flirtations during the week, I was finally ready for my annual affair with France, with cycling. By 8 a.m. on Saturday, I put myself in front of the television to catch the entire eighth stage of the  Tour de France — the cities and villages, the mountains and seacoasts, and, oh, yes, the riders.

headline: Welcome to South Sudan!
text: A warm welcome to the world’s newest country, South Sudan, after a tumultuous independence struggle of more than 50 years that cost more than 3 million lives. South Sudanese deserve the celebration they’re enjoying in Juba and around the country.

headline: Stepping (Carefully) Into Junk Bonds
text: AFTER posting impressive double-digit returns for the last two years, high-yield bonds rose at a much slower pace in the first five months of this year and stumbled in June, ending the second quarter with a gain of only 0.65 percent. .

headline: Mets’ Tejada, Ex-Neighbor of a Stadium, Now Works in a Big One
text: SAN FRANCISCO — On any particularly windy day in Santiago de Veraguas, Panama, a right-handed hitter with prodigious power could hook a foul ball down the left-field line at Estadio Omar Torrijos Herrera and, with the proper roll, almost reach the back of Ruben Tejada’s childhood home. Almost.

headline: Shreds of Moon History on the Block
text: It was two weeks before the liftoff of the Apollo 11 mission when Thomas Moser’s boss walked into his office at NASA and announced, “We’re putting a flag on the moon.”

headline: At a Paper Set to Close, Defiance and Foreboding
text: LONDON — With the tremors of The News of the World scandal still spreading across the landscape of British life, the newspaper’s staff assembled on Saturday for the paper’s last working shift before it is shut down by the Murdoch empire as part of its strategy for limiting the damage to its worldwide brand.

headline: For Years, the Tabloids’ Sting Kept British Politicians in Line
text: LONDON — In 2004, Clare Short, a Labour member of Parliament, learned what could happen to British politicians who criticized the country’s unforgiving tabloids. At a lunch in Westminster, Ms. Short mentioned in passing that she did not care for the photographs of saucy, topless women that appear every day on Page 3 of the populist tabloid The Sun, owned by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation. “I’d like to take the pornography out of our press,” she said.

headline: Two Lockouts, Each With a Different Playbook
text: The N.F.L.’s labor dispute commenced in March with all of the subtlety of an eight-man blitz. Within hours, the players had dissolved their union and sued the league, and the owners had imposed a lockout.

headline: Ways to Shine in a Challenging Market
text: FRETFULNESS overtook optimism among stock investors in the second quarter. Many markets started the year strongly. Then, as spring turned to summer, recession worries rumbled back in the United States, debt continued to dog Europe, and inflation fears re-emerged in some emerging economies. The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index lost 0.4 percent for the quarter, and several key international markets, including China and India, also chalked up losses.

headline: Investment Income? Use Your Imagination
text: THE Federal Reserve says it’s winding down its quantitative easing program, but it makes no such claims for the regular kind of monetary easing, keeping short-term interest rates near zero.

headline: Somehow, the Unemployed Became Invisible
text: GRIM number of the week: 14,087,000.

headline: Cultivating His Plants, and His Company
text: This interview with  Jack Dangermond, founder and president of Esri, which offers geographic information systems, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: McIlroy’s Bandwagon Needs to Slow Down
text: The next day, Rory McIlroy had to play the final round of the 111th United States Open, but with an eight-stroke lead at 14 under par, he was already being rushed to canonization by some golf people. Padraig Harrington even proclaimed that McIlroy, the boyish-faced Northern Irishman, would someday surpass Jack Nicklaus’s record of 18 major victories. And when McIlroy was told about Harrington’s prediction during his postround interview at Congressional that Saturday evening, he half-smiled in embarrassment.

headline: Science to Art, and Vice Versa
text: NATHALIE MIEBACH uses science to make art. A sculptor who lives in Brookline, Mass., she translates weather data and other scientific measurements into three-dimensional objects that accurately display temperature variations, barometric pressure and moon phases, among other things.

headline: The Therapist Will See You Now, via the Web
text: SEE a therapist without leaving your home?

headline: Choices for Greece, All of Them Daunting
text: WITHOUT outside help, Greece is probably insolvent right now. In evaluating the country’s prospects, it’s worth asking what it would take for Greece to pay all of its bills and what kind of damage we might expect along the way.

headline: Picking the Lock of Google’s Search
text: BOB STROM is the owner of Ballard Lock & Key, which provides locksmith services in Seattle. If you live in the area and find yourself locked out of your car or home, here is an essential piece of information about Mr. Strom’s company: it really exists.

headline: Virtual Bridge Allows Strangers in Mideast to Seem Less Strange
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Moad Arqoub, a Palestinian graduate student, was bouncing around the Internet the other day and came across a site that surprised and attracted him. It was a Facebook page where Israelis and Palestinians and other Arabs were talking about everything at once: the prospects of peace, of course, but also soccer, photography and music.

headline: Don’t Fret. Just Ask for What You Need.
text: “YOU can’t be afraid to ask,” my Uncle Art used to say when recounting tales of his successful 40-odd-year career selling mattresses up and down the Eastern Seaboard.

headline: Energy at an Early Age
text: I  GREW up in Manchester, England, an industrial city. My father, a carpenter, had an accident at work, severing the top of two fingers. With the settlement he received, he bought a grocery store that sold beer and wine, and when I was 10, I helped in the shop after school. Before that I delivered newspapers. I always had money as a kid, but never enough time to spend it.

headline: Healing Power of a Game
text: Japanese high school teams use baseball to try to forget their disaster for at least a little while.

headline: In Japan, High Schoolers Use Baseball to Help Forget
text: OFUNATO, Japan — Entering this port city by car these days means confronting nature’s fury and its fickleness all at once. The tsunami that hit Japan’s northeastern coast four months ago tore through the modest downtown, gutting buildings, crushing cars like beer cans and sweeping shops out to sea.

headline: Executive Pay, Revisited
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jeter Reaches 3,000 Hits With Home Run
text: Derek Jeter became the 28th player in baseball history to reach 3,000 hits on Saturday, with a home run in the third inning at Yankee Stadium off the Tampa Bay Rays’ David Price. In doing so, Jeter became the first player in the Yankees’ storied history to reach the hallowed number.

headline: Alabama, 1963: The Heart of Civil Rights in America
text: A look at the civil rights struggle in Birmingham, Ala., in 1963.

headline: China’s Struggle With Inflation Continues as Price Index Rises
text: SHANGHAI — In the latest sign that China is still struggling to tame inflation, the government said Saturday that the consumer price index rose by 6.4 percent in June, the highest rate in three years.

headline: Long-Hitting Tseng Cultivates Following on the Course and on the Leader Board
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — The best player in women’s golf is winning majors at a pace that puts her ahead of Tiger Woods. At 22, Yani Tseng is 3-up on her contemporary Rory McIlroy in major victories, with four to his one.

headline: Solutions for Saving the Space Program
text: How to keep NASA in business.

headline: Teenager Cements His Status as the Best in the Netherlands
text: If there was any doubt about Anish Giri’s status as the Netherlands’ biggest chess star, it was put to bed by his showing in the Dutch national championship. He finished two points ahead of his nearest competitor, Ivan Sokolov, in the 10-player field.

headline: Before Bruce, Clemons Was a Big Man on Campus
text: As the hard-charging, flashily dressed tenor saxophonist in Bruce Springsteen’s E Street Band, Clarence Clemons achieved legendary status as a master musician and performer.

headline: Derek Jeter Joins an Exclusive Club
text: Derek Jeter became the 28th major league player, and the first as a Yankee, to record 3,000 hits. He hit a home run off David Price in the third inning.

headline: The Republic of South Sudan
text: After more than five decades of guerrilla struggle and two million lives lost, the Republic of South Sudan, Africa's 54th state, declared its independence.

headline: The Boss on Stage, but ‘Saddie’ Out in Right
text: One summer night in 1973, two friends who had not met since high school bumped into each other outside a bar on the Jersey Shore: Bruce Springsteen was walking in, his old baseball teammate was walking out. They went back inside, had a few drinks and reminisced.

headline: Videos of Celebration in South Sudan
text: As my colleague Jeffrey Gettleman reports, the Republic of South Sudan declared its independence from its neighbor to the north on Saturday. The move was greeted with a flood of celebration in its streets and rounds of congratulations from leaders across the globe. News organizations descended on Juba, the country’s capital city, to chronicle the birth of the world’s newest nation.

headline: A Yankees Legend From the Beginning
text: The Times’s Tyler Kepner takes a look at what many Yankee fans call “The Jeter Era.”

headline: Webber on Pole and Paddock Notes at Silverstone
text: SILVERSTONE, England – There seems to still be a little bit of a hangover from the Canadian Grand Prix, which was one of the wildest – and the longest – races in Formula One history. First we had the uneventful European Grand Prix in Valencia two weeks ago, and now we have had two days of action at Silverstone with no surprises.

headline: Webber on Pole and Paddock Notes at Silverstone
text: SILVERSTONE, England – There seems to still be a little bit of a hangover from the Canadian Grand Prix, which was one of the wildest – and the longest – races in Formula One history. First we had the uneventful European Grand Prix in Valencia two weeks ago, and now we have had two days of action at Silverstone with no surprises.

headline: Searching for Perspective Amid All the Labels
text: Re “Surrounded by Opinion, The Times Raises Its Voices” (July 3):

headline: 30 Seconds With Ron Artest
text: Did you hear the one about the basketball player who wanted to try stand-up comedy? It’s not a joke, at least not to the Lakers’ Ron Artest, who will deal with another kind of rim shot when he hosts a comedy show called “Ron Artest: The Ultimate Comedy Tour” at Carolines on Broadway in New York on Friday.

headline: Scandals Redefine Rules for the Press in Europe
text: PARIS — A widening phone-hacking scandal is prompting a broad reassessment of the balance between press freedom and privacy in Britain, even as France grapples with the consequences of its tradition of protecting the powerful.

headline: Jeter Reaches Fabled 3,000, and It’s a Blast
text: The pursuit of a sports milestone can seem like a march to the inevitable. Fans have known for years that barring a catastrophic injury, Derek Jeter would reach 3,000 career hits. The only question was how.

headline: Presidential Candidates Warn About Debt Deal
text: DES MOINES — The decision by House Speaker John A. Boehner to scale back budget talks with President Obama unfolded as Republican presidential candidates were campaigning against any outcome that smacks of compromise, underscoring divisions in the party over whether to raise the federal debt limit.

headline: Why Are Wages Still Rising? (Wonkish)
text: One reason comparisons between current events and the 1970s are so wrong — and fears that stagflation is just around the corner are so wrong (and have been wrong for three years running) — is the absence of any surge in wages:

headline: Aide to Leader of Georgia Tied to Spying
text: MOSCOW — The personal photographer of President Mikheil Saakashvili of Georgia was shown Saturday on Georgian television confessing to selling information to a man he suspected of being an agent for Russia.

headline: Legal Tactic Raises Issues for Juveniles
text: In April 2010, three boys, ages 12, 12 and 13, were accused of raping a 12-year-old female classmate in the gymnasium of their San Francisco middle school. Last month, the allegations against two of the boys were found to be true by a juvenile court judge, and they now await sentencing. The third boy is free and could have had his case dismissed — despite a detailed confession to the police — because a psychologist chosen by his lawyer said he was not competent to face a judge.

headline: After Making History, Jeter Makes the Yankees Winners
text: With one out in the third inning Saturday, space was at a premium on the rail of the Yankees’ dugout. Players and staff members crowded shoulder to shoulder, jostling for what they hoped would be the best view of history. Manager Joe Girardi was at one end, arms draped over the railing in his familiar pose; second baseman Robinson Cano was at the other end, a towel across his shoulder and one leg raised on the steps.

headline: The Library Is Closed, but You Can Still Get Books
text: At San Jose’s Seven Trees Library, books are coming and going, even though the building is closed.

headline: South Korean Wins Her Fifth World Title
text: Kim Ju-hee of South Korea defeated Fahpratan Looksaikongdin of Thailand by unanimous decision on Wando Island, South Korea, to become the Women’s International Boxing Council light flyweight champion, making her the holder of five world titles.

headline: Let Be: An Answer to Hamlet’s Question
text: We could imagine a five-minute version of “Hamlet.”

headline: Flamboyant Financier Refocuses After Fall
text: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Major Health Problems Linked to Poverty
text: PHARR — Laura knows what comfort feels like: Before leaving Reynosa, Mexico, for Texas a few years ago, she lived with her in-laws in a house with bedrooms and flushing toilets, with electricity and a leak-free roof.

headline: The Plunge
text: A point of pride in Point Richmond, the Plunge’s big indoor pool has brought joy to residents for three-quarters of a century. After being closed for nine years, it reopened as a state-of-the-art facility in August 2010. EVAN WAGSTAFF

headline: School Counselors Fear They Will Bear Burden of Budget Cuts and New Exams
text: In the fall, the anticipated consequences of a $4 billion reduction in state financing to school districts will begin to become apparent to Texas students and their parents: fewer teachers, bigger classes and sparse extracurricular programs.

headline: Commentary: Jeter’s Pursuit of 3,000
text: Mike Tanier provided live commentary of today’s Yankees-Rays game. Derek Jeter had five hits, eclipsing the 3,000 career hit milestone.

headline: In Tsunami-Torn City, Seaside Playgrounds Become Debris Dumps
text: SENDAI, Japan — There is still a traffic jam these days along Hama Kaido, the two-lane road that parallels this city’s former coastal playground for miles. But the minivans and sedans that once roamed in search of picnic grounds, golf courses and horse stables have been replaced by thousands of dump trucks.

headline: Erotic Vagrancy, Anyone?
text: WASHINGTON

headline: For Fans of Robert Ellis, Vivid Contrasts in a Stylish CD
text: Robert Ellis is running his thumbs over the case of his new CD, “Photographs.” Ornately framed vintage pictures of his parents adorn the cover, and the 22-year-old from Houston is trying to demonstrate that each frame is finely embossed.

headline: More Than 20 Shot Dead in Monterrey, Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — At least 20 people were killed — even the hot dog vendor outside — when armed men sprayed gunfire on a bar in Monterrey, Mexico, late Friday, the latest sign of the business hub’s slide into violence in the past year and one of three slaughters over the weekend.

headline: A Sordid Cast Around Casey Anthony
text: AS a reflection of the criminal justice system, the not guilty verdict for Casey Anthony — who in all likelihood bore responsibility for her 2-year-old daughter’s death, but will never pay for that particular crime — was reassuring. Juries are supposed to presume the innocence of even the vilest defendants. Evidence must outweigh emotion. And in the end there simply wasn’t enough lucid, specific proof that Anthony had murdered her little girl.

headline: 3,000 and Counting
text: Derek Jeter collected his 3,000th career hit in the third inning of Saturday’s game, becoming the first player to record the milestone as a Yankee.

headline: Action! Romance! Social Justice!
text: SUMMER reading often consists of mindless page-turners, equally riveting and vacuous. So as a public service I’m delighted to offer a list of mindful page-turners — so full of chase scenes, romance and cliffhangers that you don’t mind the redeeming social value.

headline: Instant Music Gratification
text: I saw Gil Scott-Heron perform, for the first time, in the fall of 1994. Like any scion of radical parentage, I was well acquainted with Heron’s sprawling catalogue. Still, even for me, a young man who reveled in the track listings of limited releases, the rangy Heron had packed a few surprises. In the midst of old favorites, he uncorked a haunting and somber ode to the civil rights activist Fannie Lou Hamer. If he gave the title I missed it, which is possible given that I was mesmerized by the song’s elegiac simplicity. I tried to commit every note to memory, but ultimately, I was left with shards of lyrics, pieces of melody and a deep intense longing for a song I couldn’t name.

headline: The Worst Time to Slow the Economy
text: It was not surprising to hear the Republican presidential candidates repeat their tiresome claim that excessive government spending and borrowing were behind Friday’s terrible unemployment report. It was depressing to hear President Obama sound as if he agreed with them.

headline: Redistricting Squeezes G.O.P. Class of 2010
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Way Above the Shuttle Flight
text: As the space shuttle carries out its final mission to the space station orbiting 220 miles above the globe, NASA’s plan to conduct far more important research from a telescope that would be perched almost a million miles from Earth is in trouble.

headline: Laid-Off Art Teachers Turn to Their Craft to Express Themselves
text: Katrina Barge, an artist who was among the 1,000 public schoolteachers laid off last summer, sat up a bit straighter as she described a recent painting. “It’s called ‘Though I’m Broken and Bruised, There’s Hope in This Pain,’ ” she said.

headline: Etgar Keret
text: What’s interesting? The Sunday Review asked Etgar Keret, an Israeli short story writer and filmmaker who lectures at Ben-Gurion University of the Negev in Beersheba and at Tel Aviv University. Last year he received the Chevalier Medallion of France’s Ordre des Arts et des Lettres.

headline: Texas’s Progress on Juvenile Justice
text: Just four years ago, the Texas juvenile justice system was awash in allegations of brutality, neglect and sexual abuse by staff members. Thanks to leadership by Gov. Rick Perry and thoughtful, decisive action by the Legislature, a state juvenile justice system that was in chaos a few years ago is making impressive strides.

headline: Even Better Beach Reading!
