text: My Sunday column offers my own list of the Best Beach Reading Ever — essentially a list of my favorite works of fiction, in the sense of great page-turners that also brim with literary value or illuminate social justice themes. I listed my top 10, and I invite you to tell me where I erred — and which of your favorites I left off. This is your chance to recommend to other readers what novel to take on a summer vacation. Go for it.

headline: Wait Wait . . . Don’t Tell Me!
text: NPR’s “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!” is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/programs/wait-wait-dont-tell-me/)

headline: Dim and Dimmer
text: The House is scheduled to vote this week on a daft and destructive measure that — in the name of individual freedom — would repeal national energy efficiency standards for light bulbs enacted by Congress in 2007. Though utterly without merit, the bill stands a fighting chance in a legislative body where ideology now routinely trumps common sense.

headline: Mideast Countdown
text: It pays to be skeptical when it comes to Israeli-Palestinian peace efforts. We’re not getting our hopes up when the United States meets on Monday with the United Nations, the European Union and Russia on this quixotic quest. The State Department said the group will “take stock of where we are” — which is not exactly encouraging. Negotiations have been stalled since last fall.

headline: Long Live Harry Potter
text: “All was well.” Those are the final words in the last of the Harry Potter books. Since 2007 — when the seventh and final volume was published — we’ve known how the series ends. This Friday, legions of Harry Potter fans will witness his struggle to make all well again when “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2” opens across the universe.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: What to Do to Make Our Schools Better
text: A lively debate about charter schools, high-stakes testing and impoverished students arose as David Brooks criticized Diane Ravitch, she answered back and readers joined the fray.

headline: American Adventurism
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sail On, Sailor
text: In winter, they are missing. But as spring gives way to summer, the sailboats return, one by one, taking up their moorings in the Hudson River, anchored against the tide. Traffic on the West Side Highway hurtles past them, tugs and barges make way midstream, their wakes lapping against these hulls at rest. Some days, the sailboats look near enough to be some quiet enclave of the West 80s. But no matter how close they seem, there is always a faraway-ness to them.

headline: Afghan Bodyguard Kills Two From NATO Coalition
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A bodyguard for Afghanistan’s intelligence service killed two members of the NATO-led coalition on Saturday morning when he opened fire on a convoy heading out to train police officers, Afghan officials said.

headline: In Defense of Antidepressants
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

headline: Anne LaBastille, Advocate, Author and ‘Woodswoman’ of Adirondacks, Dies at 75
text: The gratifying struggle for Anne LaBastille was how to balance her yearning for the serenity of solitude in the wilderness with her mission to let the world know, as best she could, that it must preserve wilderness.

headline: Rahm Emanuel and Unions Square Off Over Work Rules
text: Over the past five years, the office of City Hall’s inspector general fielded about 200 complaints alleging that city truck drivers were loafing or sleeping at job sites. But the drivers were most likely not shirking any duties, said Inspector General Joseph Ferguson. And that, he said, is the real problem.

headline: Shocker! Tabs Won’t Change!
text: AS anyone in Congress or corporate America can attest, nothing spurs reform like a good old-fashioned crisis. But will the upheaval in Britain over illegal hacking of voice mail by The News of the World lead to any buttoning up in the Dumpster-diving, cash-for-trash world of tabloid media?

headline: Gen. Tso’s Default Chicken
text: WASHINGTON

headline: A Mandate? Not Really
text: YOU may remember a brief time in 2009 when Washington seemed once again to be the most consequential city in the political world — a place where leaders might finally “set aside childish things,” as the young president urged, and set about dragging government into the future.

headline: The Art of the Interview
text: THERE’S a startling moment in Janet Malcolm’s new book, “Iphigenia in Forest Hills,” her account of the trial of a Russian-speaking émigré accused of murdering her husband. Having endured the paranoid harangue of a “law guardian” whom she suspects of being partial to the prosecution, Ms. Malcolm picks up the phone and calls the defense attorney: “Then I did something I have never done before as a journalist. I meddled with the story I was reporting. I entered it as a character who could affect its plot.”

headline: Redemption in Birmingham
text: CHRIS McNAIR, symbol of the civil rights struggle in Birmingham, Ala., reported to federal prison last month, bereft of the media respect that has been his companion for most of his 85 years. In 1963, Mr. McNair’s 11-year-old daughter, Denise, died along with three other black Sunday school girls in the Ku Klux Klan bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church. Mr. McNair, then a school-teacher turned photographer, transcended his anguish to become an agent of community healing, a popular politician whom white people appreciated for his policy of not bringing up his child’s martyrdom.

headline: Is Sex Passé?
text: WHAT could be more eternal than sexuality? The fog of longing, the obsession with the loved one’s voice, smell, touch. Sex is discombobulating and distracting, it makes you immune to money, politics and family. And sometimes I think the younger generation wants to give it up.

headline: Fred Newman, Writer and Political Figure, Dies at 76
text: Fred Newman’s influential role in New York life and politics defied easy description.

headline: A Taste Test for Hunger
text: CONSIDER this paradox: according to conventional wisdom, hunger is supposed to decline as a country’s wealth increases. Yet in China and India, hunger appears to be growing even as incomes increase at phenomenal rates.

headline: The Good Short Life
text: BALTIMORE

headline: The View From the Broadcasters’ Booth
text: As the 2011 Cubs sink into oblivion, followers of the team can console themselves with one thought: at least Ron Santo was spared.

headline: Sunday: Body Enhancement
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — My first reaction to the theme of this puzzle when I first understood what was going on was “ruh roh.” I had gotten the circled letters I, M, and P at that point, figured out where Ben Pall and David Kahn were probably going with it, and thought, “Well, it was nice knowing them.”

headline: Tough Calculus as Technical Schools Face Deep Cuts
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Despite a competitive economy in which success increasingly depends on obtaining a college degree, one in four students in this country does not even finish high school in the usual four years.

headline: Hands-On Learning
text: Matthew Kelly, 19, is bright but struggles in traditional high school. Vocational courses have awakened a passion for machining and made math more relevant for him. Produced by Purple States.

headline: In Vizquel’s Mold, but All His Own
text: CLEVELAND — The shortstop for the Cleveland Indians is a dazzling defensive player from Venezuela who switch-hits, wears No. 13 and first belonged to the Seattle Mariners. This was true in the 1990s, when Omar Vizquel helped the Indians to two American League pennants. It is true again today, with Asdrubal Cabrera.

headline: Queens Grocery Worker Slain in Robbery
text: It was around closing time when a masked man with a gun walked into a Queens grocery on Friday night and, as a robbery attempt failed, fatally shot a 65-year-old clerk as he ran for the front door, the authorities said.

headline: U.S. Is Deferring Millions in Pakistani Military Aid
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is suspending and, in some cases, canceling hundreds of millions of dollars of aid to the Pakistani military, in a move to chasten Pakistan for expelling American military trainers and to press its army to fight militants more effectively.

headline: Award Watch
text: With the season more than halfway finished, let’s take a look at the leaders for the major awards. Check back at the end of September to see if these choices hold up.

headline: Porous and Violent, Afghan-Tajik Border Is a Worry for the U.S.
text: HAMADONI DISTRICT, Tajikistan — Using a raft made of scrap wood and the inner tube of a truck tire, four armed men recently crossed the river from Afghanistan to a tiny, nameless border settlement here and kidnapped the two adolescent sons of a local army recruiter.

headline: Answer for Invasive Species: Put It on a Plate and Eat It
text: With its dark red and black stripes, spotted fins and long venomous black spikes, the lionfish seems better suited for horror films than consumption. But lionfish fritters and filets may be on American tables soon.

headline: Worshiping at the International House of Prayer
text: The International House of Prayer, a Christian ministry founded by Mike Bickle, has rapidly blossomed into a movement.

headline: Where Worship Never Pauses
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The worship music, throbbing soft-rock appeals performed by live bands, has continued here without pause, day and night, since May 1999. Voices calling to Jesus or pleading with God to help tornado victims or make Congress ban abortion resound in an auditorium that is the physical and spiritual heart of the International House of Prayer, a Christian ministry rapidly blossoming into a movement.

headline: 15 Strikes, 1 Inning
text: On June 24 against Colorado, A. J. Burnett became the first Yankee to record four strikeouts in an inning. A week later, a Yankees prospect outdid him.

headline: For Price and Jeter, Not Their First Historic Meeting
text: As of Saturday, the first and last home runs that the Tampa Bay Rays’ David Price has allowed in the majors have come off the bat of Derek Jeter. Price, of course, will give up more, but he has forever linked his name to Jeter’s as the pitcher who gave up the Yankee captain’s 3,000th career hit.

headline: With Final Putt, Wie Makes the Cut
text: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. — After she punctuated her second round with a 35-foot putt, Michelle Wie pumped her right arm as if she was hand-cranking ice cream. Wie stood over the putt on the final green knowing she had to drain it to have any chance of making the 36-hole cut at the United States Women’s Open.

headline: All-Stars Galore
text: One number to remember this All-Star week: 82. That was the record number of players recognized as All-Stars in Anaheim last summer. If many more players follow the lead of the Yankees’ Mariano Rivera, Derek Jeter and Alex Rodriguez, who all dropped out of Tuesday’s game because of nagging injuries, there could be a new mark.

headline: Back to Nature, After a Detour Into the Unnatural
text: The little girls giggled at the fashion show bounty. “Imagine yourself as a homesteader,” said the sign above their heads at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal National Wildlife Refuge visitor center here. They obliged, holding floral calico dresses against their chests, gauging fit.

headline: Wichita Doctor Takes Up Fight for Abortions
text: WICHITA, Kan. — Not long ago, Dr. Mila Means, the physician trying to open an abortion clinic in this city, received a letter advising her to check under her car each morning — “because maybe today is the day someone places an explosive under it,” the note said.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,641 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Suffering From Dementia
text: In March of 2007, Alan Schwarz visited with Sylvia and her husband John Mackey, who was suffering from dementia at the time. The Hall of Fame tight end died this past week.

headline: A Player Defined by Greatness and Illness
text: As John Mackey described the biggest game he won, he merely demonstrated all he had lost.

headline: The Dawning of Africa’s 54th State
text: Many of those who turned out to celebrate the independence of South Sudan, overcome with emotion, spoke of their fathers, mothers, sons and daughters killed in the long struggle to break free from the Arab-dominated north.

headline: O’Toole Prepared for Reality of L.P.G.A. Tour on a TV Show
text: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. — The first two rounds of the 66th United States Women’s Open featured intermittent play sandwiched between weather delays totaling more than eight hours. Many of the golfers found it hard to summon their best performances at the Broadmoor’s East Course after sitting around for hours — or in some cases, a full day — between shots.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Olmsted’s Southern Landscapes
text: Frederick Law Olmsted is rightly remembered as an eminent landscape architect, but in 1861 it was his work as a journalist and an administrator that brought him acclaim.

headline: Ronaldinho Soldiers On
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — In January, Ronaldo de Assis Moreira, the buck-toothed soccer virtuoso and bon-vivant who was the world’s best soccer player five years ago, signed to play for Brazil’s most popular soccer team, Flamengo. In March, Ronaldinho Gaúcho wanted to indulge in the Rio’s famous Carnival and organized his own street bloco (crew), called Samba, amor e paixão (samba, love and passion) and in short order produced an offshoot party with his followers.

headline: Japan’s Late Goal Shocks Germany
text: Japan scored one of the biggest upsets in the history of women’s soccer Saturday, defeating the two-time defending champion Germany, 1-0, in overtime of the World Cup quarterfinals and thwarting German expectations of winning a third title on home soil.

headline: Police Officers Held in Killing of Egyptian
text: As part of a sequence of actions intended to appease protesters, Prime Minister Essam Sharaf of Egypt said Satruday that he has ordered the suspension of all police officers accused of killing demonstrators during the protests that led to President Hosni Mubarak’s ouster.

headline: Boehner Scales Back Deficit Talks, Citing Tax Increases
text: WASHINGTON — Citing differences over tax revenues, House Speaker John A. Boehner said on Saturday night that he would pull back from joint efforts with President Obama to reach a sweeping $4 trillion deficit-reduction plan tied to a proposal to increase the federal debt limit.

headline: Corrections: July 10
text: NATIONAL

headline: Battle For Libya | July 9, 2011
text: Sights from rebel-held territory, as life goes on amid war.

headline: A Fan Holds History in His Hands, Briefly
text: Christian Lopez and his girlfriend, Tara Johnson, were shopping at a Petco on Friday when they noticed the torrential rain pouring outside. Since Johnson had bought tickets to the Yankees game on Saturday as a birthday present for Lopez, the couple immediately began thinking that a Friday rainout might increase the chances they would get to witness Derek Jeter’s 3,000th career hit.

headline: Rain Suspends Play at United States Women’s Open
text: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. — This is fast becoming the United States Woe-man’s Open as the golfers grudgingly let Mother Nature play through.

headline: Documents: Scouting Reports on Jeter
text: Few things are ever certainties in the M.L.B. draft, but Derek Jeter was about as close as it came.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: July 9, 2011

headline: Terry Collins Lauds Jeter
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Terry Collins, who has managed many games against Derek Jeter, both with the Anaheim Angels from 1997 to 1999, and with the Mets this year, did not seem overly surprised by the way Jeter reached 3,000 hits Saturday.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 10
text: As President Obama convenes another round of debt ceiling negotiations with Congressional leaders on Sunday, lawmakers and administration officials will talk about what’s at stake on the Sunday shows.

headline: Japan Joins France in Women’s World Cup Semifinals
text: Karina Maruyama scored from a tight angle in the 108th minute as Japan stunned host Germany, 1-0, in the quarterfinals of the Women’s World Cup, posting one of the biggest upsets in the history of women’s soccer. Japan will be joined in the semifinals by France, which eliminated England on penalty kicks are the teams played to a 1-1 tie. Read the article, and come back to comment.

headline: Video: Suffering From Dementia
text: In March 2007, Alan Schwarz visited with Sylvia and her husband, John Mackey, who had dementia. The Hall of Fame tight end died this past week.

headline: Spectacular or Ordinary: Rethinking Ichiro
text: Ichiro Suzuki has been a widely celebrated player since he broke into the majors in 2001, immediately winning both the Most Valuable Player and Rookie of the Year awards.

headline: No Replay for Hairston as the Mets Fall to the Giants
text: SAN FRANCISCO — About an hour after he had hit a pinch-hit home run against Giants closer Brian Wilson on Friday night, Scott Hairston, his wife and some friends sat at a local restaurant to celebrate. He was not recognized by the other patrons, even after he had crushed the spirits of many of them.

headline: Is It Panic Time for the Copa América Favorites?
text: The 12 teams in the Copa América have all played two of their three first-round games. Costa Rica, Venezuela and Peru all have wins under their belts. Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay do not.

headline: Joint Chiefs Chairman Meets With Chinese Counterpart
text: BEIJING — The United States’ top military officer met with Chinese officials in Beijing on Sunday, in the first such trip in more than four years and a sign of revival in what has for years been a stagnant military relationship between the two powers.

headline: Dual Berlin Shows Highlight the Photographer Brassaï
text: In Berlin, the National Gallery has dedicated a double exhibition to Brassaï, the famed Hungarian artist born Gyula Halasz. One show focuses on street pieces by the artist, shown without context, the other on his relationships with his contemporaries. The shows, jointly titled “In the Studio and On the Street,” run through Aug. 28.

headline: Retracing a Ride to a Fatal Duel on July 11, 1804
text: The question was, have you ever taken a murderer across the Hudson?

headline: Feel The Pressure
text: Regular readers of this blog know that I make a big deal of the failure of interest rates to rise despite massive government borrowing. There’s a reason for that: what happens to interest rates is a key indicator of which economic model, and hence which economic policies, are right.

headline: Emphatic Farewell for British Paper Caught Up in Hacking Scandal
text: LONDON — Reporters leaving the newsroom of The News of the World for the final time on Saturday night were told by the police to leave their desks, including their notebooks, untouched. They were allowed to keep only their cellphones.

headline: Alonso Grabs Victory from Vettel on Ferrari Anniversary at Silverstone
text: SILVERSTONE, England – Sebastian Vettel’s domination took a little dip on Sunday at the British Grand Prix, but this time it had nothing to do with a weakness of the driver or the car.

headline: Alonso Grabs Victory from Vettel on Ferrari Anniversary at Silverstone
text: SILVERSTONE, England – Sebastian Vettel’s domination took a little dip on Sunday at the British Grand Prix, but this time it had nothing to do with a weakness of the driver or the car.

headline: For Deutsche Bank, Talk of a Shared Chief Position
text: FRANKFURT — Deutsche Bank’s next move on who will succeed Josef Ackermann as chief executive after he retires remains far from resolved.

headline: Obama Leans on G.O.P. for a Deal on Debt Ceiling
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama tried on Sunday to revive the chances for a sweeping budget agreement to reduce the nation’s deficit and repair its perilous finances, but Congressional Republicans continued to balk, insisting on a more modest deal to avert a default on the national debt.

headline: Panetta Says Iranian Arms in Iraq Are a ‘Concern’
text: BAGHDAD — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said Sunday that weapons supplied by Iran had become a “tremendous concern” for the United States in recent weeks in Iraq, where more American troops died in June in combat-related episodes than in any month since June 2008.

headline: Scores Are Killed as Train in India Derails
text: NEW DELHI — Dozens of people were killed and more than 100 were injured when a train headed for the capital here derailed in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh on Sunday.

headline: At the Ed Sullivan Theater, a Stupid Human Trick
text: Updated 3:11 p.m. | Most visitors to the Ed Sullivan Theater enter by way of a ticket to David Letterman’s “Late Show.”

headline: Envoy Meets With Leader of Yemen on Accord
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama sent his counterterrorism chief to Saudi Arabia over the weekend to meet with Yemen’s badly injured president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, with the envoy telling him that the only way to get American aid flowing again was to sign an accord that would effectively remove Mr. Saleh from power.

headline: ‘Horrible Bosses’ Is Another Naughty Hollywood Hit
text: Another weekend, another splash in the cinematic sewer. Paramount’s “Transformers: Dark of the Moon” remained a huge No. 1 at North American theaters with $47 million in ticket sales ($261 million to date). But it was the unexpectedly strong performance of “Horrible Bosses” — noted by critics for its homophobia and misogyny — that caught Hollywood’s attention.

headline: Italian Debt Adds to Fears in Euro Zone
text: LONDON — Top European officials planned to meet on Monday to wrestle with threats to the currency union as fears mounted that Italy could become a victim of the debt crisis even as discussions stalled over a second bailout for Greece.

headline: The Grand Illusion
text: So, no Grand Bargain. Jonathan Cohn has it right:

headline: Bears With a Treehouse and Tidy Tales for Children
text: Bear Country, which Stan and Jan Berenstain created for their popular Berenstain Bears children’s book series, resembles human sitcom land a few decades ago. Each story about the Bears — Mama, Papa and their cubs, generically named Brother and Sister — features a nagging problem that homespun wisdom neatly and sweetly solves. With titles like “The Berenstain Bears and the Messy Room” and “The Berenstain Bears and Too Much TV,” the books promise gentle laughs, lessons and escapades, but nothing too naughty — the Cosbys with fur.

headline: Where The Money Went
text: Somehow I missed the BEA’s very useful page tracking the Recovery Act and how it is translated into taxes and spending. (Thanks to the commenter who mentioned it). It’s especially useful for thinking about what the Obama stimulus really involved — and what it didn’t.

headline: With Grit and 10 Players, U.S. Women Oust Brazil
text: It has become a defining characteristic of American soccer, the certitude that even when skill and tactics are insufficient, and referees’ decisions are contrary and damaging, somehow resolve can prevail.

headline: A Compass for Conservative Politics
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — Without the soupy South Florida humidity and the fastidiously clipped lawn, the Newsmax headquarters here would be a lot like one of those diners in New Hampshire and Iowa where autographed pictures of politicians cover the walls.

headline: Women’s World Cup: U.S. Wins in a Shootout
text: Down to perhaps its last gasp, the United States women’s national team got the tying goal from Abby Wambach on a late header to force a penalty-kick shootout Sunday and the Americans incongruously and incredibly eliminated Brazil in the quarterfinals of the Women’s World Cup in Dresden, Germany. “These girls just bring out the best in each other,” United States Coach Pia Sundhage told ESPN after the match.

headline: Sons of Rosemary’s Baby: Birth of the New Horror
text: As a cultural commodity that got any respect, the horror movie was dead by the early 1970s. The collapse of the studio system, the aging of its stars, the decline of Grade-A monster movies like 1931’s “Frankenstein” into rubber-suit rip-offs aimed at the teenage trade — all were stakes driven into a once vibrant genre. By 1975 a scary movie was called by any other name. Time magazine’s cover story on “Jaws” ran 3,300 words, and not one of them was “horror.”

headline: A Job Change for Boston Curator
text: George T. M. Shackelford, chairman of art of Europe and curator of modern art at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, is moving to Texas to become senior deputy director of the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth. A leading scholar of late 19th- and early 20th-century French art, Mr. Shackelford is co-organizing “Degas and the Nude,” with Xavier Rey, curator of paintings at the Musée d’Orsay in Paris. The show is scheduled to open on Oct. 9 in Boston before going to Paris.

headline: After Another Yankees Victory, News of a Big Loss
text: It had been a gorgeous weekend for the Yankees, with Friday night’s dreary rainout quickly brightened by the euphoria of Saturday’s Derek Jeter extravaganza.

headline: Jimmy Roselli, Italian-American Singer, Dies at 85
text: He was a skinny Italian-American kid from Hoboken, N.J., who could croon like an angel. Before long, his singing made women swoon and grown men cry. For decades, he sang standards to adoring crowds worldwide, including, notably, “My Way.”

headline: Rethinking Addiction’s Roots, and Its Treatment
text: There is an age-old debate over alcoholism: is the problem in the sufferer’s head — something that can be overcome through willpower, spirituality or talk therapy, perhaps — or is it a physical disease, one that needs continuing medical treatment in much the same way as, say, diabetes or epilepsy?

headline: Rodriguez to Have Surgery, Will Miss Four to Six Weeks
text: Shortly after the Yankees beat the Rays, 1-0, Sunday, the team announced that the All-Star third baseman Alex Rodriguez will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his right knee Monday at the University of Miami Hospital in Florida. Expected recovery time is four to six weeks, the Yankees said.

headline: 100 Missing After Riverboat Full of Russian Families Sinks
text: MOSCOW — A riverboat filled with families cruising on the Volga River sank on Sunday, and about 100 people were missing hours later, feeding fears that the episode could be the country’s worst such accident in recent history.

headline: Landing an Overtrick via Some Dental Work
text: Pair events are in some ways artificial because overtricks can count for so much. Chicago or teams, where making or breaking the contract is paramount, is a purer form of the game. Occasionally, though, that quest for the overtrick produces some good technical play, as in the diagramed deal from a 12-board fast pairs on Bridge Base Online (bridgebase.com) on June 30.

headline: Answering Questions on Baseball’s Role in Japan’s Recovery
text: Ken Belson is writing a three-part series on high school baseball in Japan and the steadying influence it has had for some in the wake of the tsunami and earthquake that hit the country in March and the nuclear crisis that has followed. The first article in the series appeared in Sunday’s Times. Ken will answer reader questions this week about the series and his reporting in Japan.

headline: The Long and the Short of It
text: A number of people have been telling me about David Brooks and Ruth Marcus agreeing that there’s not much government can do about short-run economic performance, that we need to focus on long-run solutions. It’s a common sentiment inside the Beltway.

headline: Fans Pick M.L.S. All-Star First XI
text: A poll of M.L.S. fans, at least the ones who voted online, via text message and on Twitter, named the league’s First XI for the All-Star Game, on Sunday. The Galaxy put four players on the list, the Red Bulls three.

headline: The Old Internet Neighborhoods
text: It took my husband and me eight months to conceive our first child. Much of that time was passed in bored agitation, like a long wait at a Verizon Wireless store. To pass the time, swap information, and quiet my mind, I turned to an online message board for women who are Trying to Conceive — TTC, one of the first message-board acronyms I learned. Then, rapidly, I learned the rest of the lingo known to the voluble and surprisingly large community of women who turn to the Internet to ask intensely personal questions: TWW (two-week wait), BFN (“big fat negative”) and OPK (ovulator prediction kit).

headline: Delivering Squalls of Grunge Anew
text: First came the drone: a buzzing swarm of electric guitar tones. A clear, arching guitar line rose out of it. Then bass and drums clobbered their way in with a riff, and Chris Cornell lofted his voice into the moaning, chantlike melody of “Searching With My Good Eye Closed,” intoning, “I’m on my way/Lookin’ for the paradigm.” After 14 years between tours, Soundgarden was back in full force, its paradigm intact, when it performed on Friday night at the Prudential Center in Newark. “Sorry for the long wait,” Mr. Cornell told the crowd.

headline: Tanglewood’s Season Opens With Good Friends Like Verdi and Bellini
text: LENOX, Mass. — James Levine has long been a mainstay of Tanglewood, though he will not appear at the Boston Symphony Orchestra’s summer home this season; shortly after resigning as the ensemble’s music director in March Mr. Levine cancelled all engagements here. But the show went on with aplomb at Tanglewood’s rainy opening night on Friday, with Charles Dutoit celebrating the 30th anniversary of his debut with the orchestra and conducting an all-Italian program of operatic and symphonic works.

headline: A Return to Rossini’s Days of Yesteryear
text: KATONAH, N.Y. — Great minds have long grappled with one of opera’s enduring mysteries: Why did the composer Gioachino Rossini, at the height of his fame and his creative powers in 1829, stop composing operas and effectively retire after the premiere of “Guillaume Tell” at the Paris Opera that year?

headline: Syncopated Tap Rhythms Tattooed Onto the Floor
text: Historical film footage of tap-dancers is often less than ideal: the images grainy or full of wavy lines, the sound muddy or distorted, the camera sliding all over the place. And still it’s usually enchanting. Even on recordings and whether doing the simplest steps or telling the silliest jokes, the older generations of hoofers have an undeniable presence and artistry. You can’t stop watching.

headline: Injuries and Triumphs Color a Ballet Season
text: History often happens during American Ballet Theater’s eight-week spring season, principally because of its stars. This season, which ended Saturday, was distinguished by three guest artists in particular: Alina Cojocaru (from the Royal Ballet of London) in three roles, with her enchanting radiance and heart-catching fragility, and Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev (the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow), each in two, with their ardent vitality and astounding elevation.

headline: Wall St. Banks Expected to Post Weak 2nd-Quarter Results
text: Only a few short months ago, JPMorgan Chase traders were on such a roll that they did not have a single losing day in the first quarter.

headline: Behind the Mask, Giving Hints of How It’s Done
text: On Thursday night Sbtrkt was at Camp Bisco, the annual festival — organized by the Disco Biscuits and held in upstate New York — that rounds up the progressive end of the jam band and improvisational electronic music spectrum. On Friday night he was at Wrongbar, a sleek spot in Toronto, where the hip-hop superstar Drake stopped in for a quick collaborative performance.

headline: Monday: Response to a Bad Pun
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Welcome to the Department of Redundancy Department, where we try to describe things adjectively in a way that means the same thing as the noun we’re describing. Synonomously speaking, of course.

headline: Check In, Swim Out: A Floating Hotel as Art
text: As boat christenings go, this one was rollicking. In lieu of a Champagne bottle smashed against a hull, there was late-night bourbon and diving off the roof of the Queen Zenobia into dark waters lighted with natural phosphorescence. Nine strangers in bathing suits floated on an overwhelmed inflatable raft; a couple held hands on a pair of deck chairs; a moose head in a houseboat was decorated with a headlamp and a bra. Though the official ceremony would come later, on Friday night the Boggsville Boatel and Boat-In Theater, New York City’s newest and perhaps loopiest tourist outpost, was open for business.

headline: Mind Over Crime for a Superpowered Team
text: “Alphas,” a series beginning Monday night on Syfy, is an uneasy hybrid: a science-fiction action series that also wants to be a heart-tugging law-and-order procedural, the type where the crime-fighting team represents a bickering but affectionate family.

headline: Despite Violence, U.S. Firms Expand in Mexico
text: MATAMOROS, Mexico — When the latest bloody headlines from the drug war in Mexico reach headquarters in New York, Ken Chandler, the manager of an American electronics manufacturing plant here, jumps on the phone.

headline: Carmakers’ Goals Stretch Credulity
text: The world’s carmakers are indulging in pipe dreams again. Carlos Ghosn, Nissan’s chief executive, predicted in June that the company would sell 82 percent more vehicles globally in 2016 than last year. Alan R. Mulally, the chief at Ford Motor, earlier projected a 50 percent bump, while Ferdinand Piëch, chairman of Volkswagen, is shooting for just a tad less growth than that. If the rest of the industry is as optimistic, in about five years manufacturers will be producing almost 20 million more cars than market forecasters expect will be sold.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include trade deficit for May (Tuesday); import prices for June (Wednesday); retail sales for June, the Producer Price Index for June and business inventories for May (Thursday); Consumer Price Index for June, industrial production and capacity utilization for June, and Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for July (Friday).

headline: If You Build It
text: As part of an art installation, adventurous guests can now spend the night in their very own boat and sleep under the stars in Far Rockaway.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: In Harlem, a Rally to an Accuser’s Defense
text: As the sexual assault case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn teetered on the brink of collapse, several supporters of his accuser gathered in Harlem on Sunday to urge the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., to pursue the case “vigorously.”

headline: ABC Sends Greetings to Hallmark Movies
text: The Hallmark Hall of Fame movie franchise has a new home on network television: ABC. A multiyear agreement, announced last week by Hallmark, came two months after CBS decided not to renew its deal to show the feel-good movies at greeting-card-buying times of the year. In a twist the Hallmark Channel will show the movies a week after they have their premieres on ABC. “Our agreement to follow ABC premieres with encores on Hallmark Channel is an exciting, unprecedented use of broadcast and cable,” Brad Moore, the president of the Hallmark Hall of Fame, said in a statement. The first movie on ABC, “Mitch Albom’s Have a Little Faith,” will be shown in December.

headline: Stars Announced for Next Bond Film
text: After being held back for years by financial troubles at MGM Studios, the 23rd James Bond film has begun casting in earnest, with Javier Bardem and Ralph Fiennes, both confirmed to appear, according to The Daily Mail. Mr. Bardem, who won an Academy Award in 2008 for his villainous turn in “No Country for Old Men,” has been previously quoted by The Los Angeles Times as saying that he was in talks to play the nemesis of Daniel Craig’s 007. Mr. Fiennes’s role was not specified. Directed by Sam Mendes and partly financed by Sony, the film is slated for release on Nov. 9, 2012, and is to begin shooting this year.

headline: Fire Stops Rihanna
text: A concert performance in Dallas by the singer Rihanna ended abruptly on Friday night after a small fire broke out above the stage. The fire occurred during the hit song “California King Bed,” forcing concertgoers to evacuate the American Airlines Center as sparks rained down on the stage from the rafters, according to the Web site Celebuzz! Although no official makeup date has been announced, Rihanna expressed her frustration on her Twitter account with a promise that she would return. No injuries were reported.

headline: Barry Bremen, Professional Impostor, Dies at 64
text: Barry Bremen, a novelty-goods salesman who achieved a kind of flash celebrity in the 1980s as a ubiquitous impostor who slipped past security to shag fly balls in the major leagues, shoot baskets in the N.B.A. and accept somebody else’s Emmy Award on national television, died on June 30 in Phoenix. He was 64.

headline: A New WNET Site Goes Live
text: A few weeks behind schedule, WNET’s MetroFocus Web site is set to make its official debut Monday, joining the ranks of Gothamist, DNAinfo, NearSay and numerous others in keeping tabs on local news, culture and urban life in New York City.

headline: Water Suites
text: The Boggsville Boatel is a floating hotel-movie theater-art installation in Queens.

headline: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Review ‘Master Class’
text: Terrence McNally’s 1995 play “Master Class” imagines what happens when the opera diva Maria Callas leads an emotional master class for several students at the Juilliard School in the early 1970s. The new Broadway revival, which opened on Thursday, stars Tyne Daly as Callas (Zoe Caldwell, who played the role in the original production, won a Tony Award).

headline: Yankees’ Robertson Added to All-Star Team
text: By Sunday morning, Yankees reliever Dave Robertson had basically given up on making his first All-Star team. He had made plans to spend the All-Star break in Connecticut with his wife, Erin, and was looking forward to maybe doing some fishing during his three days off.

headline: Courtesy Lessons, and Other N.Y.C. Tales
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: N.F.L. Labor Talks Bog Down Over Rookie Wage Scale
text: With time nearly expired to salvage a full N.F.L. preseason, negotiators for the league and its players will resume talks Monday to end the four-month-long lockout.

headline: Filly’s Unbeaten Streak Reaches 19 Races
text: Harness Racing’s biggest star, See You at Peelers, ran her unbeaten streak to 19 races on Saturday, winning a division of the $145,208 New York Sires Stakes and setting a new track record at Vernon Downs for 3-year-old fillies.

headline: On the Road to Better Gas Mileage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Petraeus Confident as He Leaves Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Just days away from the end of his tour as the supreme military commander in Afghanistan, and the end of a 37-year military career, Gen. David H. Petraeus said he was leaving in the belief that his plan to turn around the war and hand over security to the Afghans could be achieved.

headline: From Zappos, an Unadorned Approach
text: IF sex sells, then nudity cannot be far behind. At least that is what Zappos, the online retailer, hopes with its new advertising campaign featuring naked models doing everyday things like jogging, hailing a cab and playing Frisbee in public.

headline: An iPad App for Cosmo Guys
text: Cosmopolitan offers the answers to a lot of crucial questions. Should you get back with your ex? How do you make your pony tail sexy? Are those the right sunglasses for summer?

headline: Prescription Drugs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Underpaid Judges?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Complex Family Trees
text: To the Editor:

headline: At All-Star Game, Politics and Passion Are Also in Play
text: Demonstrators plan to pass out white ribbons; Phoenix plans to pass out chains.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Guns and Mental Illness
text: To the Editor:

headline: The U.S. Capitol at War
text: When Thomas U. Walter returned to Washington at the beginning of July 1861, he found an appalling mess. For 10 years he had served as the architect in charge of building the new Senate and House wings of the United States Capitol and the cast iron dome that would crown the rotunda. When war broke out, Congress was not in session and the building was empty. The Union Army took it over.

headline: Message From a Charter School: Thrive or Transfer
text: In 2008, when Katherine Sprowal’s son, Matthew, was selected in a lottery to attend the Harlem Success Academy 3 charter school, she was thrilled. “I felt like we were getting the best private school, and we didn’t have to pay for it,” she recalled.

headline: Cautionary Lessons From State’s Shutdown
text: ST. PAUL — The shutdown of the State of Minnesota has forced the opening of a new hearing room here, where pleas have flowed forth, one after the next, for a week.

headline: Injuries in Descent Force More Cyclists From Race as Safety Becomes Goal
text: ST.-FLOUR, France — The first week of the Tour de France was filled with harrowing scenes of twig-thin riders splayed out on the pavement, bleeding from the head or clutching broken limbs.

headline: Music Site Lets Users Play D.J. to Virtual, and Discerning, Crowds
text: The hottest new club isn’t in Los Angeles or New York. It’s on a Web site called Turntable.fm, where big-headed cartoon characters populate the D.J. booth.

headline: Accusations of Abuse by Priest Dating to Early 1940s
text: WINSLOW, Ariz. — Alfred Moya was stopping at a restaurant in rural Gallup, N.M., on his way home to Phoenix in the summer of 2007 when he happened to glance at a newspaper article about children who had been sexually abused by a priest.

headline: Jobs for Welfare Recipients: New York’s Approach
text: To the Editor:

headline: Roland Petit, Choreographer, Dies at 87; Conquered Ballet Taboos and Hollywood
text: Roland Petit, France’s leading choreographer after World War II, who swept away time-honored ballet taboos and whose mix of entertainment and art also made his work popular in Hollywood, died Sunday in Geneva. He was 87 and had lived in Switzerland for more than a decade.

headline: Cozy Ties Mark Newspaper’s Dealings With Scotland Yard
text: LONDON — On Jan. 9, 2003, Rebekah Wade, until recently the editor of The News of the World, was summoned to an unusual meeting at Scotland Yard, the headquarters of the Metropolitan Police Service here. Detective Superintendent David Cook, the lead investigator in a gruesome cold-case killing of a man found with an ax in his head, confronted Ms. Wade with a worrying accusation: He and his family were being followed and photographed, he said, by people hired by her newspaper.

headline: Black News in New Focus
text: NBC News and Interactive One, a network of Web sites aimed at African-Americans, plan to announce a partnership on Monday that will combine the editorial and sales resources of both properties. The partnership will focus on aligning NBC’s African-American news site, TheGrio.com, and Interactive One’s news Web site, NewsOne.com.

headline: Syrian Opposition Leaders Boycott a Government Dialogue Opening
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian officials on Sunday formally opened what they described as a national dialogue aimed at a transition to multiparty democracy, but the country’s opposition leaders boycotted the event, calling it a sham to mask the government’s brutal crackdown on the pro-democracy protests that have shaken Syria’s ruling Assad family.

headline: A Yankees Team That Is Powerful, Yet Vulnerable
text: Perhaps nothing symbolizes the Yankees’ successful first half better than a quip made by their general manager, Brian Cashman, on the morning of June 16: “They got Cliff Lee, we got Brian Gordon.”

headline: How Seawater Can Power the World
text: Princeton, N.J.

headline: Despite Criticism by an Owner, Positive Feelings
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In the wake of public criticisms from Fred Wilpon, the Mets’ principal owner, in a May edition of The New Yorker, the team held a meeting in the cramped visitors’ clubhouse at Wrigley Field. Carlos Beltran, one of the players singled out by Wilpon, spoke to his teammates and the coaching staff.

headline: A Tabloid Shame, Exposed by Earnest Rivals
text: The phone-hacking scandal that is mushrooming in Britain, with arrests, skullduggery and influence peddling, would be a delicious story for The News of the World if it were not about the newspaper itself. Instead, the hunter became the hunted, and last Thursday Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation summarily slid the 168-year-old News of the World under a double-decker bus. Its final issue was Sunday.

headline: For Boehner, Lofty Budget Goals Checked by Reality
text: WASHINGTON — At a private meeting about deficit reduction at the White House last week, Speaker John A. Boehner told his fellow Congressional leaders and President Obama that he did not spend 20 years working his way up to the top job on Capitol Hill just for the cachet of the title — he wanted to accomplish something big.

headline: Not a Typical Pizza Place Anymore
text: MAPLEWOOD, N.J. — Four years ago, Arturo’s, a corner pizzeria here, resembled countless others that sold slices and takeout pies to customers who were not asking who grew those tomatoes, where, or how.

headline: No, We Can’t? Or Won’t?
text: If you were shocked by Friday’s job report, if you thought we were doing well and were taken aback by the bad news, you haven’t been paying attention. The fact is, the United States economy has been stuck in a rut for a year and a half.

headline: Open Course Softens Since the Last Visit, but It Can Still Bite
text: SANDWICH, England — Even with the Dungeness nuclear power plants towering over the horizon to the northwest, walking back in time on the Sunday before the British Open at Royal St. George’s is as easy as a stroll through the town where the sandwich was invented.

headline: Labour Party Vows to Fight Murdoch’s Bid to Take Over Satellite Company
text: LONDON — The $12 billion bid by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation to take over Britain’s most lucrative satellite broadcast company, British Sky Broadcasting, ran into fresh trouble on Sunday when the opposition Labour Party promised to take the battle against the takeover to a vote in the House of Commons — a step that, if successful, could deal a fatal blow to the bid.

headline: Quick Action Helps Google Win Friends in Japan
text: KESENNUMA, Japan — An oddly equipped car made its way last week through the rubble in this tsunami-stricken port city. On the roof: an assembly of nine cameras creating 360-degree panoramic digital images of the disaster zone to archive damage.

headline: New for Aspiring Doctors, the People Skills Test
text: ROANOKE, Va. — Doctors save lives, but they can sometimes be insufferable know-it-alls who bully nurses and do not listen to patients. Medical schools have traditionally done little to screen out such flawed applicants or to train them to behave better, but that is changing.

headline: The Method to Their Madness
text: The Republican Party’s strategy in the debt-ceiling negotiations has baffled centrists and vindicated liberals. For months, the party’s leaders have repeatedly turned down deals that would cut spending significantly because their members won’t compromise on taxes. To moderates, this intransigence is inexplicable: Are they crazy? To the left, it’s all-too-predictable: See, we told you they were crazy!

headline: Reaction to the U.S. Win Over Brazil
text: Selected reactions of the players and coaches who took part in the United States’ thrilling penalty-kick victory over Brazil on Sunday, via ussoccer.com and other sources:

headline: Tailoring the Tees to the Players to Bring the Fun Back to Golf
text: Long odds have never seemed to bother Barney Adams, the amiable inventor, club maker and founder of Adams Golf, a company that defied experts to become one of the top sellers of hybrids and fairway woods. Evidently, they still don’t, because he recently came out of retirement at 72 to take on what may be his biggest challenge yet.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Royal Couple Are Adored From a Distance on Brief Visit to California
text: LOS ANGELES — The royal couple were certainly seen on their first visit here, the pictures of their outfits incessantly analyzed as their images played on a constant loop on television. Prince William was occasionally even heard.

headline: Economy Faces a Jolt as Benefit Checks Run Out
text: An extraordinary amount of personal income is coming directly from the government.

headline: Judge Rules Ex-Firefighter Cannot Sue Over Mosque
text: A Manhattan judge has dismissed a lawsuit by a former New York City firefighter who is trying to stop the construction of an Islamic community center in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Subway Crush No Longer Gets Weekends Off
text: New York City slows down on the weekends, and its subway is no exception: long waits, jumbled routes, trains that skip stops and sometimes never appear.

headline: Remembrances of Empty Subways of Weekends Past
text: Ah, weekends on the New York City subway — that bucolic, tranquil period when the commuting masses empty out of the metropolis and blissfully human-free subway cars yield a comfortable seat to even the most jaded straphangers.

headline: Bad Borders, Good Neighbors
text: Herzliya, Israel

headline: Facundo Cabral, Singer of Conscience, Dies at 74
text: Facundo Cabral, an Argentine singer-songwriter who was one of the most eloquent voices of protest against military dictatorships in Latin America from the 1970s onward, died on Saturday, shot to death while on tour in Guatemala. He was 74 and lived in Buenos Aires.

headline: An Aggressive Ruling on Clean Air
text: The Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday issued a welcome and overdue rule compelling power plants in 27 states and the District of Columbia to reduce smokestack emissions that pollute the air and poison forests, lakes and streams across the eastern United States. The regulation reflects the E.P.A.’s determination to carry out its mandates under the Clean Air Act despite fierce Congressional opposition, and bodes well for progress on a host of other regulatory challenges the agency faces.

headline: Patrolling Coney Island’s Piers, but No Longer the 2-Ply
text: Coney Island, like many parts of New York, is just too big to get all abuzz when a civic crisis befalls one sector of the citizenry.

headline: Offering Slow, Small Changes, Morocco’s King Stays in Power
text: RABAT, Morocco — With the pace of democratic change stalled or staggering under violent crackdowns in the Middle East and North Africa, Morocco’s recent decision to alter its Constitution provides what some see as an alternative to the bloody confrontations that have marked the Arab Spring.

headline: Rival Claims to Sea Territory Made by Israel and Lebanon
text: JERUSALEM — Israel is to submit a claim to the United Nations in the next few days demarcating its maritime boundary with Lebanon, officials here said Sunday, amid a dispute between the countries over an area of the Mediterranean Sea that is potentially rich with energy resources.

headline: 4 Die and 2 Are Injured as Motor Boat Crashes in Hudson Upstate
text: Four people were killed and two others seriously injured early Sunday when a motor boat crashed and sank in the Hudson River near the town of Red Hook, N.Y., the Dutchess County sheriff’s office said.

headline: Screening for a Better Medical Student
text: Medical schools for years have accepted students with high academic skills. Now some schools are trying to find a way to screen students for better social skills.

headline: Dangerous Omissions
text: The gunman in the Virginia Tech massacre, Seung-Hui Cho, should never have been allowed to buy the weapons he used in the 2007 rampage. He had been found mentally ill and ordered into treatment by a court, yet that record never made it into the database of the National Instant Criminal Background Check System used for screening prospective gun purchasers.

headline: Dropping the Ball on Health Exchanges
text: In the frenzied final days of New York’s legislative session, an important health care measure fell by the wayside. The Republican-led State Senate failed to pass a bill to establish a health insurance exchange where individuals and small businesses would be able to buy coverage starting in 2014. An identical bill had already passed the Democratic-led Assembly.

headline: Jeter’s Moment
text: Here’s the thing about Derek Jeter: He’s great and we love him, with an admiration that has little to do with statistical milestones and big round numbers. He got his 3,000th hit on Saturday, as a million flashbulbs popped and documentary cameras rolled and cheers and emotion washed over Yankee Stadium. It was an extraordinary moment, mixed with relief. His chase for an abstraction was finally over, and he could go back to the day-in, day-out job of being Derek Jeter, Yankee shortstop. That’s the great long trip he’s still on, and we’re just glad to be along, never mind what the hit odometer says.

text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: In a Rush to Finish the U.S. Women’s Open, and Poised to Win
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — In her native South Korea, Hee Kyung Seo is known as the Supermodel of the Fairways. Her golf over four taxing days at the Broadmoor’s East Course was so fetching, Seo might be known by nightfall Monday as the 66th United States Women’s Open champion.

headline: A Vigorous Prosecution of Strauss-Kahn Is Urged
text: As the sexual assault case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn teetered on the brink of collapse, several supporters of his accuser gathered in Harlem on Sunday to urge the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., to pursue the case “vigorously.”

headline: Battle for LIbya | July 10, 2011
text: Demonstrators took to the streets in Zintan and rebel fighters patrolled on the outskirts of Qawalish.

headline: Solid First Half Ends on Sour Note for the Mets
text: SAN FRANCISCO — After Sunday night’s game, the modest Mets All-Star contingent of Carlos Beltran, the injured Jose Reyes and Jay Horwitz, the team’s vice president for media relations, were planning to fly to Phoenix on a charter plane with the more expansive Giants contingent of five players, Manager Bruce Bochy and several coaches.

headline: Precision Castparts to Buy Primus International for $900 Million
text: Precision Castparts said on Sunday that it had agreed to buy Primus International, a maker of airplane parts, for $900 million in cash.

headline: Rory McIlroy’s Changing Homeland
text: The golfer’s religion holds less importance in Northern Ireland than it did for his predecessors.

headline: Northern Ireland’s McIlroy Transcends Boundaries
text: Rory McIlroy’s religion was, until a few days ago, a mystery to Barry McGuigan.

headline: Collector as Artist: The Barnes Foundation
text: Take an interactive tour with Randy Kennedy through the Barnes Foundation, one of America’s strangest art museums since the day its doors opened in 1925.

headline: More Words to Come About Casey Anthony
text: The Casey Anthony book blitz has begun. St. Martin’s Press said it had acquired a book about Ms. Anthony, the Florida mother who was found not guilty last week of killing her 2-year-old daughter, Caylee. “Inside the Mind of Casey Anthony,” by the forensic psychiatrist and television pundit Keith Ablow, will be released this year. “Dr. Ablow delivers a cogent, comprehensible way of understanding exactly how Casey Anthony’s psyche may have developed and how her psychological development and the dynamics within her family ended the life of Caylee Anthony,” a spokesman for St. Martin’s, part of Macmillan, said in a statement. “Whether readers liked or hated the jury’s verdict, Dr. Ablow will answer the question, ‘Why is Caylee Anthony dead?’ ” Dr. Ablow has been discussing the case on Fox News for three years. He was the co-author, with Glenn Beck, of “The 7,” which was released in January by Threshold Editions, part of Simon & Schuster.

headline: Word of the Day | centrifuge
text: centrifuge •\ˈsen-trə-ˌfyüj\• noun

text: The day in sports, from the Women’s World Cup in Germany to track and field in England to the Tour de France.
