headline: News Quiz | July 11, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Mexico Wins Under-17 World Cup
text: Mexico won the FIFA Under-17 World Cup for the second time on Sunday, continuing its recent run of success at the junior level with a 2-0 victory over Uruguay at the Azteca Stadium in Mexico City.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 6 in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least six people were killed on Monday when a suicide bomber detonated explosives in northern Pakistan, according to reports in local news media. At least 15 people were reported to have been wounded.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, July 11, 2011
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “After Home Schooling, Pomp and Traditional Circumstances.”

headline: Li Ka-shing Group Offers $3.8 Billion for British Utility
text: Northumbrian Water, a British utility, said on Monday that it had received a takeover proposal worth $3.8 billion from a company controlled by Li Ka-shing, Hong Kong’s richest man.

headline: Murdoch Tabloids’ Targets Included Downing Street and the Crown
text: LONDON — The scandal that has enveloped Rupert Murdoch’s media empire in Britain widened substantially on Monday with reports that two of his newspapers may have bribed police officers or used other potentially illegal methods to obtain information about Queen Elizabeth II and former Prime Minister Gordon Brown.

headline: Inside Tito’s Nuclear Bunker
text: During the convulsions that upended Yugoslavia in the 1990s, a secret came to light near the Bosnian town of Konjic. There — it turned out — the dictator Josip Broz Tito had constructed a labyrinthine bunker complex 900 feet below ground to protect him and his inner circle in the event of a nuclear attack. Today, it seems as remote as Yugoslavia itself.

headline: Plaques in Prague Commemorate Holocaust Victims
text: The small bronze cobblestones can be easy to miss, but they are scattered, in plain sight, all over the streets of Prague and numerous other cities across Europe. Collectively these simple, handmade stone plaques, called Stolpersteine (“stumbling blocks”), conceived and designed by the German artist Gunter Demnig, comprise one of the largest Holocaust memorials in the world. They serve as poignant public markers, announcing to passersby that the buildings the stones are set in front of  were once the homes of men, women and children who were carted away and murdered by the Nazi regime during World War II.

headline: The Early Word: Abandoned
text: Today’s Times

headline: Q&A: Moving Old Palm Contacts
text: Q.

headline: Aretha vs. the Monkees
text: Something about the middle of May makes Aretha Franklin call me. For details on the most recent occurrence, see my profile of her in this weekend’s magazine. The first time, though, was more than 43 years ago, on May 18, 1968, a rainy day on Long Island and the day I received my First Communion. There was actually a trinity of holy events: the ceremony itself, with long lines of boys in navy blue suits and girls in white veils; then the family pancake breakfast at Howard Johnson’s; and finally, a trip to the local record store, where to mark the special occasion I was being allowed to pick out an entire album instead of my usual single.

headline: Congressional Week Ahead: More Budget Maneuvering
text: After a weekend surprise in the negotiations over the debt limit, the House and Senate return Monday to join the budget fray and take up assorted other business that includes a House vote on the repeal of light bulb efficiency standards.

headline: In Europe, an Outline of Options
text: BRUSSELS — European finance ministers promised on Monday to lighten lending terms for struggling countries like Greece and suggested that the existing bailout fund be expanded and allowed to pay for the purchase of sovereign bonds.

headline: The World’s Newest Nation
text: WHERE is the new nation of South Sudan?

headline: An Interactive Tour Through the Barnes Foundation
text: Take an interactive tour with Randy Kennedy through the Barnes Foundation, one of America’s strangest art museums since the day its doors opened in 1925.

headline: Unemployment? Who Cares?
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: Complaint Box | Charity for Sale
text: The other day, as I was laying down the usual $20 at my local drugstore, the clerk asked me if I’d care to donate a dollar to help fight feline leukemia. Now, generally speaking, I’m anti-feline leukemia, but there is a remarkable tone deafness when it comes to cash-register exchanges. Really, I only wanted some gum, not a test of my capacity for sympathy as a human being.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Fat, Flat and Falling
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Best Political Quotes of the Weekend
text: Miss out on the political back-and-forth over the weekend? Fear not. The Caucus has gathered up the best quotes from politicians.

headline: Hertz Extends Offer for Dollar Thrifty
text: Hertz Global Holdings, seeking to gain the support of Dollar Thrifty shareholders for its takeover bid of more than $2 billion, announced on Monday that it would extend the offer to Aug. 5.

headline: Why Do Hyenas Laugh?
text: Kay E. Holekamp, a zoologist at Michigan State University, writes from the Masai Mara National Reserve in Kenya, where she is studying the behavior of spotted hyenas.

headline: Fall of Rome?
text: I’ve been relatively sanguine about Italy, in a depressed sort of way: the debt level is high, but the deficits have been fairly modest, so I thought the Italians could limp along for a long time.

headline: Bumps Remain as Military Leaders of U.S. and China Meet
text: BEIJING — The leaders of the Chinese and American militaries sought on Monday to cast aside decades of hostility between the two countries’ armed services, pledging at a joint news conference here to pursue a “great opportunity” to create a shared vision of cooperation.

headline: Panetta Presses Iraq for Decision on Troops
text: BAGHDAD — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said here on Monday that the United States military would have an “enduring presence” for many years in the Middle East. He pushed Prime Minister Nuri Kamal-al Maliki to name a defense minister and to let the United States know whether he wanted some American troops to remain in Iraq beyond the end of this year or not.

headline: Monday Reading: New Ways to Visit Cuba, Legally
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Dunkin’ Brands Looks to Raise as Much as $460 Million
text: The owner of Dunkin’ Donuts is looking to raise as much as $460.6 million in a stock offering, the latest privately held company looking to go public.

headline: Scores of Children Among 128 Dead in Russian Sinking
text: KAZAN, Russia — The rain was not relenting on Sunday afternoon as the Bulgaria left the riverbanks for the open expanse of the reservoir. So the baby sitters gathered the children together and led them to the activity room to play.

headline: Monetary Rage
text: We had dinner last night with Margaret Ray and Dave Anderson, the authors of the AP adaptation of our textbook (which is terrific, by the way). Over our $350 $22 bottle of wine, we talked about various issues involved in trying to explain economics — and everyone agreed that monetary economics is where people are most likely to get not only confused, but furious.

headline: Global Markets Tumble on Continued Worries Over Europe’s Debt Crisis
text: Financial and energy companies took a beating on Wall Street on Monday as stocks in the United States followed global markets lower on concerns about the euro zone debt crisis.

headline: Peabody and Arcelor Seek Control of Macarthur Coal
Why Italy? Why Not America?
text: A good question from some commenters. But it’s a question I’ve written about before:

headline: Bass Player for Coheed and Cambria Charged With Robbing Pharmacy
text: Just hours before his band was to open for Soundgarden on Sunday, the bass player for Coheed and Cambria, the alternative rock band from Nyack, N.Y., was arrested on charges of robbing a pharmacy in Massachusetts to get prescription painkillers, the Associated Press reported.

headline: Sole Mates | Shoe Saving Tips From the Pros
text: During summer months, the feet are most on display. And while many of us go out of our way to pamper our toes with pedicures, our shoes can take the real beating. Just because you aren’t tromping through snow and slush doesn’t mean your footwear doesn’t need T.L.C. Just ask David Mesquita. Along with his father, Carlos, David owns Leather Spa, New York’s go-to shoe repair. “Pre-treating shoes is actually a bigger part of our business than repairing destroyed ones,” says David, who sees some 500 pairs a day. Here, the Mesquita men share their tricks and tips for taking care of all types of footwear before the damage is done.

headline: Historic Headlines Will Be Back Aug. 8
text: Thank you to those of you who wrote in, enthusiastically, to tell us you like our new offering, Historic Headlines. Summer is when we experiment on the blog, and hearing from you helps us decide what to keep, and how to refine it, for the school year.

headline: Ah, How the French Celebrate
text: As best as one could tell, the most famous Frenchman in New York — you may also safely call him the most notorious — was not to be found at Bastille Day celebrations held on Sunday along East 60th Street. We didn’t make it to a similar event held on Smith Street in Brooklyn, where the French population is said to be growing. But we assume he wasn’t there, either.

headline: The Concentrated Pain of Job Loss
text: I wanted to add one other explanation — to those Catherine Rampell cited, in her much-discussed Sunday article — for why unemployment has not become a larger political issue. Given how high unemployment is, there are surprisingly few people who have experienced unemployment in the last couple of years. This is the flip side of the historically high average length of the unemployment: joblessness is concentrated among a subset of the population, rather than affecting a larger group of people for shorter periods of time.

headline: Church of England Seeks Accountability From News Corp. in Hacking Scandal
text: The Church of England has entered the debate about the phone-hacking scandal at The News of the World — as an investor.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Orient Express
text: Travel to several Middle Eastern countries may be discouraged, but for three weeks in July, Shubbak, the first festival of contemporary Arabic art in London, offers near-full immersion in the region’s art scene, with some 70 exhibitions, plays, readings, film screenings and dance performances across the city. “The daily news reports of political and social developments in the region have understandably influenced how people think about Arab countries,” explains London’s mayor, Boris Johnson, who is sponsoring the festival. “Shubbak offers something new, showing that the quality of contemporary art coming out of the region is brilliant and challenging.”

headline: One Play Erases Doubts About a Coach
text: Sometimes coaches know stuff. Sometimes they get it wrong.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Nestle to Buy Control of China’s Biggest Confectioner | Nestlé said on Monday that it had agreed to pay $1.7 billion for a 60 percent stake in a big Chinese confectioner, its second significant foray into the rapidly growing Chinese market in less than three months.

headline: The Myth of the Allergy-Free Dog
text: Dog lovers with a pet allergy have a big problem when it comes to having a dog in the home. But the usual solution — getting a breed known to be hypoallergenic — may not be a safe bet. In fact, there may be no such thing as a low-allergy or allergy-free dog, according to a new report. The study found that the quantities of dog allergens in homes with supposedly hypoallergenic breeds are no different from those in homes with dogs widely considered non-hypoallergenic.

headline: Changing Tone, Obama Pressures Both Parties on Budget Deal
text: 12:57 p.m. | Updated  President Obama challenged Republicans on Monday to live up to their demands to cut the nation’s deficit and address its long-term debt by enacting spending cuts, revenue increases and changes to entitlement programs.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Alonso Win Caps Milestone Week for Ferrari
text: Heritage had its day at the Silverstone Circuit in Northhamptonshire, England, as Ferrari, the oldest team in Formula One, commemorated the 60th anniversary of its first grand prix victory with, fittingly, a victory.

headline: Celebrity Targets of Tabloid Cheer Its Demise
text: As my colleagues John F. Burns and Alan Cowell report, there was widespread revulsion in Britain last week when it was revealed that journalists at The News of the World, a British tabloid newspaper, had hacked into the voice mail of a 13-year-old girl following her abduction in 2002.

headline: Old Stories, Spun Anew
text: LONDON — If a cloud of sawdust seems to hang over the Old Vic Theater these days, that’s because Kevin Spacey is chewing his way through the scenery there like an atomic termite. In a ripping old-fashioned star turn as Shakespeare’s Richard III, Mr. Spacey gives fierce and flashy physical life to every twist of a power-mad man’s corkscrew mind. Richard may be slowed down by a hunched back and hobbled gait, but this performance spins a classic, much-interpreted character until we’re all dizzy.

headline: Writer Remains Literary Voice of Knockemstiff
text: KNOCKEMSTIFF, Ohio — There used to be a road sign, pocked with bullet holes, marking the beginning of this little village in southern Ohio, but someone stole it a few years ago, and there hasn’t been much urgency about putting up another. The residents already know where they are, and not many strangers pass through. One of the two main roads in town, Shady Glen, eventually runs out of pavement and turns to dirt.

headline: Numberplay: The Master Theorem
text: This week we gain access to the Master Theorem — an online collection of beautiful original puzzles including an ancient crossword, an adventure at the Crayola naming lab, and a pigpen cipher.

headline: Crowds in Syria Attack U.S. and French Embassies
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Pro-government demonstrators attacked the American and French embassy compounds in Damascus, Syria, on Monday, angered over visits by the ambassadors to a central Syrian city that has emerged as a flashpoint of the popular uprising against the government.

headline: At Least 6 Dead in Russian Plane Crash
text: MOSCOW — A Russian passenger plane caught fire and crash landed in a Siberian river on Monday, killing at least six people and prompting fresh concerns about the safety of Russia’s aging Soviet-era aircraft.

headline: Ozawa and Dench Among Winners of Rich Prizes From Japan Art Association
text: The conductor Seiji Ozawa, the actress Judi Dench and the painter Bill Viola have been named 2011 Praemium Imperiale laureates, an honor that comes with a 15 million yen prize (nearly $186,000 at the current exchange rate) given by the Japan Art Association, which made the announcement on Monday. The association describes the award as recognition of “lifetime achievement in the arts in categories not covered by the Nobel Prizes.”

headline: Amazing Robot Arms
text: Four examples of robots performing specific tasks that a human might complete more efficiently.

headline: Why Most Investors Don’t Measure Returns Correctly
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: In Search of a Robot More Like Us
text: MENLO PARK, Calif. — The robotics pioneer Rodney Brooks often begins speeches by reaching into his pocket, fiddling with some loose change, finding a quarter, pulling it out and twirling it in his fingers.

headline: What Makes Teeth Chatter
text: Q. What might cause teeth to chatter other than the cold?

headline: A Winning New York-Balanced Meal
text: When the United States Department of Agriculture pushed aside the traditional food pyramid in favor of a simplified “Food Plate,” City Room took note. It didn’t quite look like the way our city eats. We published our own version, and asked readers to offer their suggestions.

headline: Lonza to Buy Arch Chemicals for $1.2 Billion
text: The Lonza Group, a Swiss supplier of pharmaceutical ingredients seeking to diversify its product lineup, said on Monday that it had agreed to buy Arch Chemicals for $1.2 billion in cash.

headline: Drive to Stem Shingles Meets Few Expectations
text: Five years have passed since the Food and Drug Administration approved a vaccine against shingles. By now, experts had expected a substantial proportion of people older than 60, the most vulnerable population, to be protected from outbreaks of this nasty viral disease and the persistent, debilitating pain it can leave behind.

headline: Star Is Now an ‘Officier’ in the Legion of Honor
text: PARIS – Liza Minnelli has three Tonys, two Golden Globes, an Oscar, an Emmy and a Grammy legend award. Now the 65-year-old singer and actress also has the rank of “officier” in the Legion of Honor, the award for service to the French state created by Napoleon in 1802. In the grand salon of his ministry on Monday, Culture Minister Frédéric Mitterrand pinned an enameled vermeil medal affixed to a red grosgrain ribbon onto Ms. Minnelli’s black silk brocade jacket.

headline: Turning (Fresh) Water Into (Very Expensive) Wine
text: Paul Ryan’s drinking companions identified. A bit about one of the two amigos in my Keynes lecture.

headline: Cyprus Navy Chief Dies in Blast at Arms Depot
text: ATHENS — The leader of the Cyprus Navy died in a large blast that leveled a munitions storage facility and prompted two of the country’s highest military leaders to resign from their posts, the defense ministry said. At least 11 others — including the commander of the naval base — also died, and dozens more were wounded.

headline: Now Grilling | Juicy Summer Chicken
text: I suspect I’m not the only griller around whose friends are grateful he studied Sam Sifton’s walk-through for Texas-style beef ribs, but on the days when I didn’t have 8 hours to slow cook 12 pounds of meat, I would default to German hamburgers and Italian sausages. This opened the floodgates. Without my noticing, I went from cooking barbecue bimonthly (that’s every other month) to semimonthly (almost every other week).

headline: British Official Refers BSkyB Deal to Another Regulator
text: As a phone-hacking scandal threatens to derail News Corporation’s bid to buy BSkyB, a British official has referred the merger to the Competition Commission for approval, which could delay approval for months.

headline: Rethinking a Gift to Jeter
text: It was gracious, magnanimous, a class act.

headline: Women’s World Cup: A Great Cultural Display of Fútbol
text: This past weekend, I witnessed the beautiful game in its truest form.

headline: Are Jobless Benefits Keeping the Unemployed Complacent (and Invisible)?
text: In an article on Sunday, I wrote about why our unemployment crisis has been largely ignored by Washington. Among the major factors I cited were that unemployed workers are less likely to vote than their employed counterparts. Additionally, the jobless are not as politically organized as they once were because they are more geographically dispersed and because the institutions that organized them have become weaker.

headline: Free Tickets for Virgin Mobile Music Festival
text: TV on the Radio, The Black Keys and Cee Lo Green will be among the bands appearing at this year’s Virgin Mobile Freefest, a free music festival to be held on Sept. 10 in Columbia, Md., the festival’s organizers announced on Monday. This is the third year that this mobile telephone company started by Richard Branson, along with Kyocera Wireless, has footed the bill for the festival, which is expected to draw about 40,000 people. The tickets are to be given away through Virgin Mobile Live’s Facebook page starting at 10 a.m. Friday. For the past annual festivals, the tickets disappeared in a matter of minutes.

headline: Sheila Bair to Write Book on Financial Crisis
text: Sheila C. Bair has landed a book deal to give her inside account of the financial crisis, just as her tumultuous five-year term as chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has ended.

headline: Repeal Vote Set on Light Bulb Standards
text: The House is expected to vote as early as Monday night on a measure to repeal efficiency standards for light bulbs that are scheduled to take effect at the beginning of next year.

headline: Overriding the Jury in Capital Cases
text: WASHINGTON — Alabama allows judges to reject sentencing decisions from capital juries, which sounds like a sensible idea. You might want a mature and dispassionate jurist standing between a wounded community’s impulse toward vengeance and a defendant at risk of execution.

headline: Student Reading Contest Winner | On Dominique Strauss-Kahn
text: We promise we didn’t plant, pay for or otherwise cajole BrandonK-BSGE2016 to post the comment above to the first week of our summer reading contest. If we had written our fantasy response, however, I’m not sure we could have done better.

headline: Sentence of the Week, Telegram Edition
text: Here are this week’s candidates:

headline: To Survive Ice Ages, Gray Whales Adapted
text: Like those of its cousins the humpback and the blue, the population of the California gray whale was severely depleted by the whaling industry. But researchers are reporting that until humans came along, the California gray was remarkably resilient.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Jason Bender joined Empower MediaMarketing, Cincinnati, in a new post, vice president for creative. He had been executive creative director at Possible Worldwide, part of WPP.

headline: Campaign Says: ‘Got PMS? Get Milk’
text: Madison Avenue has always had a difficult time talking about what takes place within a woman’s body, as evidenced by decades of euphemistically evasive advertising for menstrual products.

headline: A Fashion Taste of the 18th Century
text: A new exhibit in the Grand Trianon at Versailles gives a fashion face off between modern and 18th century style

headline: Look, Perceive, Fold
text: A robot was programmed to recognize and fold towels.

headline: Really? The Claim: A Tennis Ball on the Back of Pajamas Can Cut Snoring
text: THE FACTS

headline: Jonathan Groff and Rutina Wesley Named to Cast of ‘The Submission’
text: The actors Jonathan Groff and Rutina Wesley have played characters in emotionally charged tight spots before, he in Broadway’s “Spring Awakening” (and in diva showdowns on Fox’s “Glee”) and she on HBO’s “True Blood” as Sookie’s troubled friend Tara. This fall the two will find themselves together in a pickle of their own making in the new Off Broadway play “The Submission,” which MCC Theater is producing at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

headline: Small Businesses That Understand Social Media
text: A few weeks ago, I wrote a post questioning whether all small businesses should invest time and money in social media. The post was a reminder that business owners need to consider the costs and potential returns of social media before taking the leap.

headline: Vain Glorious | Blue Crush
text: Yves Klein. Stéphane Mallarmé. Joni Mitchell. The color blue has served as inspiration for artists, poets and musicians, so why not Giorgio Armani? The designer showed an entirely blue collection this past spring, and this week he takes it to the perfume counter with the release of La Femme Bleue. “I wanted to create a fragrance that absolutely evoked the idea of the color blue,” Armani said. “I was inspired by my collection, which was itself inspired by the desert of the Tuareg nomads. I wished to create a rare and unique perfume that would stimulate certain olfactory senses and refer back to my fashion collection.” If notes like black iris and dark chocolate don’t say “rare and unique,” the fact that only 1,000 numbered bottles of La Femme Bleue were produced should do the trick. Not to mention the $600 price tag. At Giorgio Armani boutiques and Bergdorf Goodman.

headline: Scientists Turn to Crowds on the Web to Finance Their Projects
text: In January, a time when many scientists concentrate on grant proposals, Jennifer D. Calkins and Jennifer M. Gee, both biologists, were busy designing quail T-shirts and trading cards. The T-shirts went for $12 each and the trading cards for $15 in a fund-raising effort resembling an online bake sale.

headline: The Caucus | Grand Debt Bargain in Doubt
text: July 11, 2011 - Jeff Zeleny on the latest from the stalled debt negotiations and Monica Davey on the government shutdown in Minnesota, which provides a cautionary tale for Washington.

headline: Dangerously Dry
text: Chart and map showing extreme drought conditions in the United States.

headline: Suspect in Mutilation of an Afghan Woman Is Freed
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The only suspect arrested in the case of a woman mutilated for leaving her husband has been released, local Afghan officials and the woman’s father said Monday, in a move that has angered human rights advocates and the woman’s family.

headline: A Lifetime of Speed, Preserved in Salt
text: The Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah were popularized by a dedicated, if lunatic, fringe of motoring culture, who saw in the uninterrupted expanse of white an ideal surface for testing the limits of automotive technology. A new documentary positions one man at the middle of the movement.

headline: Caucus Video: Debt Negotiations Stalled; A Cautionary Tale From Minnesota
text: Jeff Zeleny on the latest from the stalled debt negotiations, and Monica Davey reports on the government shutdown in Minnesota, which provides a cautionary tale for Washington.

headline: Simple Ways to Prevent Injuries and Drownings
text: Even more common than illness as an aftermath of swimming are injuries and drowning. Yet swimmers and their guardians can easily prevent an overwhelming majority of these accidents and tragedies.

headline: Water Holds Pleasures, and Menaces That Lurk
text: I learned to swim at age 3 at Brighton Beach, where each morning, June to October, my father swam freestyle back and forth between the rock jetties. Summering near water was a family essential as I was growing up, a pleasure I carried into adulthood. For more than 30 summers, I swam daily from Minnesota to Wisconsin and back against the current of the scenic St. Croix River. In my 40s, I joined the local YMCA so I could swim year-round.

headline: Drought Spreads Pain From Florida to Arizona
text: COLQUITT, Ga. — The heat and the drought are so bad in this southwest corner of Georgia that hogs can barely eat. Corn, a lucrative crop with a notorious thirst, is burning up in fields. Cotton plants are too weak to punch through soil so dry it might as well be pavement.

headline: The Case For Going Big
text: My column today has a generally sympathetic take on the G.O.P.’s brinksmanship in the ongoing debt ceiling negotiations, but it ends with a big caveat: Some of the same factors that make this a good time for Republicans to take the hardest possible line (a Democratic president who wants a conservative-seeming deficit package, the likelihood that future tax increases are in the offing with or without Republican concessions this time around, etc.) also make it a good moment for Republicans to go for a big deal rather than a small deal, even if the big deal is somewhat less than ideological pure. For an example of what I mean, consider this line from James Pethokoukis, hailing John Boehner for pulling a Reagan at Reykjavik and walking away from the lure of a big deficit deal:

headline: Sawyer’s Jaycee Dugard Interview Boosts ABC
text: ABC’s special edition of “Primetime” on Sunday featuring Diane Sawyer’s interview with kidnapping victim Jaycee Dugard delivered the highest ratings on the night by a wide margin and, excluding sports broadcasts, that network’s largest audience of the summer. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 14.8 million viewers tuned in to the two-hour broadcast from 9 to 11 p.m., easily outperforming the second most watched program, “60 Minutes” on CBS at 7 p.m. (8.1 million).

headline: Glove Department | Superhero Style
text: In the old days, superhero tie-ins were simple affairs — a sticker at the end of a loaf of Wonder Bread, say, or a toy in a Happy Meal. These days, as superheroes have become huge box-office draws, the tie-ins are more high-end. Take, for example, the Richard Chai x Acura glove. It was inspired by “Thor,” the film about Marvel’s Norse hero, and S.H.I.E.L.D., the intelligence and security organization that has been lurking around Marvel’s other superhero films and whose agents drive Acuras. Ah, corporate synergy.

headline: 7 Steps in Appealing a Health Insurance Denial

headline: Demand Strong to Visit 9/11 Memorial
text: Despite a technical hiccup that temporarily prevented some people from reserving tickets to the 9/11 Memorial when it opens to the public, 5,000 passes were distributed within the first hour after the ticket system opened at 9 this morning. headline: Drawing Dance: A Visit to Purchase College
text: The Brooklyn-based artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the fourth in a series of graphite drawings he plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from Purchase College.

headline: Solar Panels Still Rare, Despite Glow of $7 Power Bills
text: When Ed and Paula Antonio moved from a small home in Marine Park, Brooklyn, to a roughly 3,000-square-foot house in Belle Harbor, Queens, they realized that with all that space and a central air-conditioning system, their electricity costs would run much higher. So after intensive research and analysis and the bids of five contractors, they paid $72,000 to install 42 solar panels on their new roof.

headline: Using Clawbacks to Punish Bank Executives
text: A common complaint has been the absence of prosecution of financial executives for their role in the economic crisis in 2008, but what is equally striking is the large compensation those executives received while their companies pursued increasingly risky policies that led to the crisis.

headline: Media Culpa? Coverage of Jobs vs. Deficit

Major news organizations have devoted much more air time, ink and pixels to America’s debt concerns than to the 14-million-person army of jobless workers, they argued.

headline: Childbirth: Wait to Restart the Pill, C.D.C. Says
text: Women who have just given birth should wait at least three weeks before they start using birth control pills because of the risk of serious, potentially fatal blood clots, public health officials announced last week. Women who deliver by Caesarean section or have other risk factors for blood clots — like obesity or a history of previous blood clots — should wait at least six weeks before using these medications, they said.

headline: ‘Stone Arabia’
text: She always said it started, or became apparent to her, when their father brought him a guitar for his tenth birthday. At least that was the family legend, repeated and burnished into a shared over-memory. But she did really think it was true: he changed in one identifiable moment. Up until that point, Nik’s main occupations had been reading Mad magazine and making elaborate ink drawings of dogs and cats behaving like far-out hipsters. He had characters — Mickey the shaggy mutt who smoked weed and rode motorcycles; Linda the sluttish afghan who wore her hair hanging over one eye; and Nik Kat, his little alter ego, a cool cat who played pranks and escaped many close calls. Nik Kat addressed the reader directly and gave little winky comments about not wanting you to turn the page. Denise appeared as Little Kit Kat, the wonder tot. She had a cape and followed all the orders Nik Kat gave her. Nik made a full book out of each episode. He would make three or four copies with carbon paper and then later make more at some expense at the print shop, but each of the covers was created by hand and unique: he drew the images in Magic Marker and then collaged in pieces of colored paper cut from magazines. Denise still had Nik’s zines in a box somewhere. He gave one copy to her and Mom (they had to share), one to his girlfriend of the moment (Nik always had a girlfriend), one was put in a plastic sleeve and filed in his fledgling archives, and one went to their father, who lived in San Francisco.

headline: A Rock-Star Life Imagined, but Never Actually Achieved

headline: Risks: Perhaps July’s Reputation Is Justified

Joel Sachs and the superb young musicians of the New Juilliard Ensemble were on the stage, fresh new works were on the music stands, the birds were making a ruckus in the sculpture garden’s trees (at least during the first half) and the garden was packed with listeners sipping drinks and taking in the performance.

headline: Jungle Gymnasts on a Farewell Tour
text: HANOVER, N.H. — The border between wildness and civilization, anarchy and order, was something that perpetually intrigued the choreographer Merce Cunningham. When the curtain rises on his 1968 “RainForest,” we’re at once in a singularly Cunningham vision of feral behavior. Though the piece is famous for its décor of helium-filled silver pillows by Andy Warhol — six of which hang like a forest’s foliage while the rest are loosely scattered around the stage like undergrowth — they wouldn’t seem the least bit wild were it not for the behavior of the dancers.

headline: Echoing the Tones of Francis Bacon
text: PARIS — The stakes are high for Wayne McGregor in his new “Anatomie de la Sensation,” at the Paris Opera Ballet. It is this British choreographer’s first full-length work for a ballet company; the music is by Mark-Anthony Turnage of recent  “Anna Nicole” fame; the sets by John Pawson, an architect well known for his minimalist rigor. Most pertinently, there is a discernible subject: the piece is subtitled “Pour Francis Bacon” and has more than a suggestion of narrative content from a choreographer best known for intellectually complex, sensually abstract dances.

headline: Two Cities Find an Effective Way to Combat Distracted Driving

headline: Improvisation in Harlem, Corner of Hip-Hop and Jazz
text: One of the magnetic forces holding together a lot of New York’s better jazz musicians right now is the hip-hop composer and producer J Dilla, who died in 2006. It has to do with the fascinatingly human lurch and pop of his sampled rhythm tracks, but something bigger, too: the improvisational curiosity he had about rhythm and sound. He’s at the heart of the contention that hip-hop and jazz have internal points of contact, not just philosophical ones.

headline: A Songwriter’s Legacy: Baseball Ditties, From Mickey to the Mets
text: Ruth Roberts’s songs were recorded by Arthur Godfrey, Dean Martin, Patti Page, Debbie Reynolds, Jimmy Dean and the Beatles. But even if Mets fans do not remember her as they do Marv Throneberry, they know the song she wrote (with Bill Katz): “Meet the Mets,” the team’s bouncy theme ditty since 1963.

headline: Derek Jeter, the Natural
text: To the Editor:

headline: It’s a Season of Recalls for Voters in Wisconsin
text: Summer in Wisconsin once meant a quieter state capital, the State Fair and a run of Brewers baseball games. But in a year of political strife in the state, this is the summer of elections.

headline: In Brad Richards, Rangers Have a Dedicated Leader
text: Brad Richards, the Rangers’ new $60 million center, doesn’t want to be called a savior, although he did say last week that if the Rangers win their first Stanley Cup since 1994, “you can call me whatever you want.”

headline: TimesCast | The Cost of a Catch
text: July 11, 2011 - The fan who caught Derek Jeter's 3,000th hit ball and gave it up now faces a five-digit tax bill.

headline: Returning Jeter’s Big Hit: No Good Deed Goes Untaxed (Perhaps)
text: Here is the fan’s fantasy: You go to the ballpark and under a picture-perfect sky not only do the Yankees win, but in recognition of your exemplary behavior, the team also showers you with free season tickets, signed merchandise and a personal audience with the Yankee-est of Yankees, Derek Jeter. The team president hands you his card, with his e-mail address.

headline: An Addition to the List of Tax Loopholes
text: As the White House and Congress wrangle over raising the debt ceiling and reducing the federal deficit, tax loopholes would seem to be an easy target for compromise.

headline: Hamilton Again Faces Life’s Harsh Realities
text: PHOENIX

headline: City Hall Resists a Proposal to Ban Cars on Some Roads in Central Park
text: It is a plan that seems tailor-made for the environmentally minded Bloomberg administration: Banish cars from the verdant, vertical roadways that slice top to bottom through Central Park.

headline: Betty Ford, Pioneer
text: Chicago

headline: Venture With K.K.R. Makes Education Deal
text: Jonathan N. Grayer, the former chief executive of the education company Kaplan Inc., formed an investment partnership with the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company in early 2010. Now, after looking at 350 companies over the last year and a half, they have done their first deal.

headline: At the British Open, Everyone’s a Favorite
text: SANDWICH, England — Steve Stricker, fresh off the charter plane after winning his third straight John Deere Classic in the United States, was squinting in the English sunshine outside the clubhouse at Royal St. George’s and considering who might win this year’s British Open.

headline: Polygamist, Under Scrutiny in Utah, Plans Suit to Challenge Law
text: Kody Brown is a proud polygamist, and a relatively famous one. Now Mr. Brown, his four wives and 16 children and stepchildren are going to court to keep from being punished for it.

headline: A Small City’s Depleted Pension Fund Rattles Rhode Island
text: The small city of Central Falls, R.I., appears to be headed for a rare municipal bankruptcy filing, and state officials are rushing to keep its woes from overwhelming the struggling state.

headline: Ideology Trumps Economics
text: There is a huge gap in logic at the heart of the Republican intransigence on a debt-ceiling deal, and President Obama helped to illuminate it on Monday.

headline: For Heath Bell, Where to Next?
text: PHOENIX — Heath Bell, a three-time All-Star closer for San Diego, says he expects to be traded before the July 31 nonwaiver trading deadline. Bell can be a free agent after the season, and the Padres are in last place.

headline: News Corporation Moves to Delay BSkyB Deal to Avoid Its Collapse
text: LONDON — Battered by allegations of phone hacking by the now-shuttered News of the World, Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation on Monday effectively delayed government action on its proposed takeover of the satellite broadcast giant British Sky Broadcasting as the company scrambled to save the $12 billion deal from collapse.

headline: Off to Phoenix, at Any Cost
text: PHOENIX — American League Manager Ron Washington said he added the Yankees’ Dave Robertson because of Robertson’s effectiveness against left- and right-handed hitters. Robertson said he was thrilled to make the trip, although it meant a 3:40 a.m. wakeup call on Monday and a commercial flight through Chicago.

headline: All Hail the (Democratic) King
text: Rabat, Morocco

headline: Long List of All-Stars, but Still a Few Names That Are Missing
text: PHOENIX — Jose Reyes took batting practice when the All-Stars worked out on Monday, even though he is on the disabled list. So did Ryan Braun of the Milwaukee Brewers. Both players were elected to start but unable to play because of injury.

headline: Amazon Backs End to Online Sales Tax in California
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon said Monday that it would back a California ballot initiative that would roll back a new state law that forces more online retailers to collect sales tax.

headline: A Tourism Office Falls Victim to Hard Times
text: SEATTLE — An alluring billboard beckoned to motorists on a busy industrial corridor here this spring. It displayed just one image, a panoramic view of a valley and mountains and sunshine, and one word, “Montana.”

headline: The Ball at Their Feet, Their Fate in Their Hands
text: There was a double déjà vu on Sunday as, once again, desperate American athletes made one last sortie down the field.

headline: At Co-op Melding Old and New Manhattan, Protests on a Vote
text: It started with a faulty voting machine. Followed by the early announcement of results that turned out to be wrong. Which led to demands for a new vote, snowballing anger, mounting divisiveness, whispers of treachery, a heated protest, mutiny and talk of a lawsuit.

headline: Vaccination Ruse Used in Pursuit of Bin Laden
text: WASHINGTON — In the months before Osama bin Laden was killed, the Central Intelligence Agency ran a phony vaccination program in Abbottabad, Pakistan, as a ruse to obtain DNA evidence from members of Bin Laden’s family thought to be holed up in an expansive compound there, according to an American official.

headline: Union Chief Faults School Reform From ‘On High’
text: WASHINGTON — Amid one of the most contentious periods in recent memory for teachers’ unions, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, Randi Weingarten, on Monday called for education reform that emanates from teachers and their communities, rather than from “those who blame teachers for everything.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Routine Ruse in Men’s Soccer Tumbles Into Women’s World Cup
text: COLOGNE, Germany — There often seems to be more diving in soccer than in the Summer Olympics. Phantom contact, or the slightest collision, can lead to theatrical belly flops and exaggerated somersaults by players deceptively trying to draw fouls on their opponents, kill time or catch a breather when tired. A player writhes on the ground, seemingly unable to continue, and is whisked away on a stretcher, only to return moments later, miraculously healed.

headline: Family of Robert F. Kennedy Rethinks His Place at Library
text: WASHINGTON — As archivists prepare to make public 63 boxes of Robert F. Kennedy’s papers at the John F. Kennedy Library in Boston, his family members are having second thoughts about where they should be housed and are considering moving them elsewhere because they believe that the presidential library has not done enough to honor the younger brother’s legacy.

headline: The Long Pursuit of Justice in Lebanon
text: An international tribunal has called on Lebanon’s government to arrest four suspects indicted in the 2005 car-bomb killing of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri and 21 others. All four of the accused are members of Hezbollah, the militant Shiite movement whose cynical mix of politics and armed intimidation helped bring Prime Minister Najib Mikati to power.

headline: Immigrants May Be Fed False Stories to Bolster Asylum Pleas
text: The man caught on the wiretap urged his immigrant client to fabricate a tragic past if he wanted asylum in the United States. To say that he was a victim of political repression in Albania. Or police brutality. Or even a blood feud.

headline: New York’s Lagging Judicial Pay
text: Across the country, judicial salaries are falling woefully behind what is needed to sustain a high-quality justice system. The problem is acute in New York State, where judges have gone without a raise for a dozen years.

headline: Sam Denoff, TV Writer, Is Dead at 83
text: Sam Denoff, an Emmy-winning writer for “The Dick Van Dyke Show” who helped bring to the screen some of its most memorable episodes, including “That’s My Boy???,” “Bupkis” and “Coast-to-Coast Big Mouth,” died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 83.

headline: Tuesday: Nut With a Cupule
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — The last time we saw Bill Thompson, he wowed us with a debut pangrammatic puzzle (Across Lite, Solution, blog) and he’s back today with a missing word theme that you might guess before you get to the payoff at 68 Across, but if you don’t, worry not. All will become clearer in the light of DAY.

headline: The Knives, and Forks, Are Out
text: The prospect of being serenaded by Hannibal Lecter is certainly more appealing than sitting down to dinner with him, at least to the noncannibals among us. Now, thanks to the composer-lyricists Jon and Al Kaplan, we can bask in the song stylings of one of the movies’ most famous mass murderers, in “Silence! The Musical,” an exuberantly gross spoof at Theater 80 in the East Village.

headline: The Magic Lever
text: The world economy is a complex, unknowable organism. Most of us try to diversify our investments and balance risk and security to protect against the unexpected.

headline: Obama Grasping Centrist Banner in Debt Impasse
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama made no apparent headway on Monday in his attempt to forge a crisis-averting budget deal, but he put on full display his effort to position himself as a pragmatic centrist willing to confront both parties and address intractable problems.

headline: Los Angeles Democrats Pressed to Retain Seat
text: LOS ANGELES — California’s 36th Congressional District has been in Democratic hands for more than a decade. It was never a district Democrats thought they might have to worry about after its longtime representative, Jane Harman, stepped down in February.

headline: In New Jersey, Ally One Day, ‘Punk’ the Next
text: TRENTON — Stephen M. Sweeney, the State Senate president, is a brawny man with a pug’s face, and a natty pink tie-and-suspender combo. He leans back in his leather chair as he considers my question:

headline: Budget Talks Beginning to Take On a Testy Air
text: WASHINGTON — Even before they gathered around a long table in the Cabinet Room for another round of budget negotiations on Monday, President Obama and Republican leaders began taking shots at one another.

headline: Chernobyl’s Lingering Scars
text: Oddly enough, the 25th anniversary of the worst nuclear accident in history has been marked by journalism about animals. Two magazines, Wired and Harper’s, have published lengthy articles about the rebirth of animal life in the so-called exclusion zone around the Chernobyl nuclear plant in Ukraine.

headline: Egypt: Cabinet Reshuffle Promised
text: The prime minister, Essam Sharaf, said Monday that he would reshuffle the cabinet within a week and would try to hold public trials of former government officials and police officers accused of killing protesters during the revolution. The announcement, broadcast on state television, was a bid to appease thousands of people who have taken to the streets recently protesting what they say is the slow pace of reform by Egypt’s ruling military council. Also on Monday, military officials said that four American citizens were detained in Suez by local citizens and handed over to the military authorities.

headline: Fairer Treatment for Katrina’s Victims
text: The federal Department of Housing and Urban Development announced last week that it had reached a legal settlement in a civil rights lawsuit over Louisiana’s Road Home program, which distributed aid to those trying to rebuild homes destroyed by Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Waiting for Rain
text: A corner of southwest Georgia is scorched by heat and drought.

headline: Turkey: Deal Breaks Deadlock
text: Turkey’s main opposition party ended a two-week parliamentary deadlock on Monday, when the deputies agreed to be sworn in after reaching a deal with the ruling party to show common effort in bringing imprisoned politicians who had been elected back to Parliament. The 134 delegates from the Republican People’s Party, or CHP, were joined by 36 pro-Kurdish politicians in boycotting the parliamentary opening on June 28, in protest of local court rulings that barred nine elected candidates, currently in jail on terrorism-related charges, from joining the assembly. The Parliament still convened but establishment of legal commissions for executive activities was delayed in absence of opposition deputies, who lacked parliamentary approval without the oath.

headline: Obama Administration Rolls Out Standards for Health Insurance Marketplaces
text: WASHINGTON — In a big step to carry out the new health care law, the Obama administration unveiled standards on Monday for insurance marketplaces that will allow individuals, families and small businesses in every state to shop for insurance, compare prices and benefits and buy coverage.

headline: Seeking Your Favorite U.S. Soccer Moment
text: George Vecsey writes for Tuesday’s Times that, for him, Abby Wambach’s injury-time goal against Brazil on Sunday immediately brought to mind Landon Donovan’s injury-time winner against Algeria at last summer’s World Cup. Maybe it did the same for you.

headline: Montana: Tests Indicate Water Is Safe After Oil Spill
text: Air and drinking water along the Yellowstone River in Montana have so far met safety standards in government tests after an oil spill, the Environmental Protection Agency said Monday. The agency said that while floodwaters had prevented tests since the rupture of an Exxon Mobil pipeline on July 1, the waters had receded and the E.P.A. was able to begin testing and cleanup. Findings so far have shown that the water is safe to drink, the agency said.

headline: Two Officers Beat Heckler After Arrest, Police Say
text: Two police officers in the Bronx were arrested Monday on charges that they assaulted a man who had heckled them for arresting him, officials said.

headline: California: Intent Sought on ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: A federal appeals court in California ordered the Obama administration to say whether it intends to continue to enforce the law that prohibits openly gay men, lesbians and bisexuals from serving in the military. The “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy is in the process of being repealed, but the lawsuit challenging it is still in the courts. The administration has argued that the existing law be maintained until it can be ended in an orderly way. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled Wednesday that the policy had to end, and on Monday gave parties in the suit 10 days to explain “why this case should not be dismissed as moot.”

headline: Corrections: July 12
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Fire Devastates Synagogue Under Repair in Manhattan
text: A four-alarm fire broke out Monday night at an Upper East Side synagogue that was being renovated, spitting flames through stained-glass windows, destroying the roof and heavily damaging the upper floors, the Fire Department said.

headline: With Pitches From His Father, Cano Is Last Hitter Standing
text: PHOENIX — Jose Cano pitched six games for the Houston Astros at the end of the 1989 season. Chances are, though, that his most gratifying pitches in a major league park came Monday night in the Home Run Derby at Chase Field.

headline: Battle For Libya | July 11, 2011
text: A day in the life of rebel forces in Zintan, Libya.

headline: An App for Organizing Facebook Friends
text: Sharing on Facebook can get complicated if you only want to do so with college friends, colleagues or golf buddies. You have to manually sort potentially hundreds of people into separate groups.

headline: Word of the Day | venal
text: venal •\ˈve-nəl\• adjective

headline: NYT: Front Page for 07/12/2011
text: NYT: Front Page for 07/12/2011

headline: Freshmen Republicans Push House Toward Right
text: Nobody would dispute that the 240 Republicans who serve in the House of Representatives are a conservative bunch. A big part of the story are the 85 Republicans — roughly one-third of the caucus — who are serving in Congress for the first time, or who are doing so after having lost or retired from their seats previously. Because of them, the Republican caucus has continued to drift toward the right despite now occupying most of the swing districts in the country, which are normally fertile ground for moderates.

headline: New York Man Pleads Guilty to Wire Fraud in Art Swindle
text: A New York City man pleaded guilty on Monday to one count of wire fraud in a case in which the authorities said he persuaded an investor to buy a painting by the 19th-century French artist Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot, inflated the price and then pocketed some of the money.

headline: News Quiz | July 12, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Summer Exhibitions Bringing World’s Best to U.S.
text: A proliferation of exhibition games coming to the United States this summer as part of the World Football Challenge promises to make a busy soccer summer even busier. Major League Soccer’s commissioner says the league’s growing credibility is part of the draw, but a lot of money, and marketing opportunities, are also at work. Read Jack Bell’s article here, and come back to comment.

headline: Copa América: Argentina Advances Behind Messi
text: Maybe Lionel Messi wasn’t the problem after all.

headline: Assassination in Afghanistan Creates a Void
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Ahmed Wali Karzai, the powerful half brother of Afghanistan’s president, was assassinated Tuesday, removing from the political scene a divisive power broker who was accused of corruption and alienated the American military, but whose connections and ruthlessness made him a critical force in volatile southern Afghanistan.

headline: Test Yourself | English, July 12, 2011
text: Test your editing skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues, from the “Software as Self-Expression” portion of the Room for Debate discussion “Computer Science’s ‘Sputnik Moment’?”

headline: Betty Ford: Gilded Cage, Meet Free Spirit
text: I’ve taken millions of photos during my career, but a hands-down favorite is a shot I took of Betty Ford during her last full day as first lady, on Jan. 19, 1977. Like Mrs. Ford herself, the picture is unique. It goes straight to the heart of who and how she was.

headline: Company Agrees to Share AIDS and Hepatitis Drugs With Patent Pool
text: In the first agreement between a pharmaceutical company and the new international Medicines Patent Pool, Gilead Sciences announced Tuesday that it would license four of its AIDS and hepatitis B drugs to the pool.

headline: Lawmakers to Call Murdoch to Testify in Hacking Case
text: This article was reported by  John F. Burns,  Don Van Natta Jr. and  Alan Cowell, and written by Mr. Burns.

headline: The Early Word: Pressure
text: Today’s Times

headline: Are We About to Repeat the Mistakes of 1937?
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul.

headline: At Prado in Madrid, Rome’s Artistic Influence
text: Western landscape painting only began to flourish in the 16th century, as artists from all over Europe made their way to Rome; the city became a sort of research laboratory for the exchange of ideas between artists of different nationalities. Foreign painters encountered works by Caravaggio and Raphael, themselves inspired by archaeological sites and the naturalistic and poetic paintings of Giorgione and Titian.

headline: Packed in a Box, Another Transportation Idea for Cities
text: LONDON — As car-sharing services continue to evolve, so should the vehicles used in those programs, say James Brooks and Richard Bone, recent graduates of the Vehicle Design program at the Royal College of Art. The former classmates recently opened their own firm, Brooks & Bone, and designed a vehicle specifically for urban car-sharing services that resembles the prototypical box on wheels. And that, precisely, is the point.

headline: Fantasy Focus: First-Half All-Stars
text: Here are the players at each position who have earned the most profit relative to their draft-day costs. All average draft position (ADP) data, courtesy of MockDraftCentral.com and based on standard 12-team mixed leagues. A player not taken in the top 188 picks is considered undrafted for purposes of this exercise.

headline: Q&A: Sharing That GarageBand Opus
text: Q.

headline: An Eye for Young Talent
text: HOW old are the artists whose work is featured in the current exhibition at the New York Open Center?HOW, according to this video, did the exhibition come about?HOW were the artists found?

headline: Whom Are You Calling Partner?
text: That person strap-hanging next to you and snorting with laughter may well be me. Embarrassed by my habit of laughing out loud on the subway, I should have known better than to read David Sedaris’s latest essay on the way to work. Sedaris writes in The New Yorker about learning German, a variously painful and hilarious experience that I, too, have undergone. Of his travels across Germany, he recalls:

headline: A Safer Way to Start a Business
text: Most new entrepreneurs don’t have much spare time. But beginning next fall, those with a couple of hours to kill can immerse themselves in Startup Fever, a board game that challenges players to start and build rival companies.

headline: A Powerful Photo Editor for the iPad
text: The iPad may have a so-so camera, but it has some first class photo-editing software.

headline: A Plague of Danglers
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: A Plague of Danglers
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Koch Theater ‘Vacancy’ Sign Beckons Top Dance Troupes
text: Wanted: One intrepid cultural organization to share the cost of operating a Lincoln Center theater that recently lost one of its tenants to financial difficulties. Must be able to balance a budget and attract large audiences with programming dynamic enough to fill 2,600 seats.

headline: Dissident Chinese Writer Flees to Germany
text: BEIJING — After being denied an exit visa 17 times, yanked off planes and trains by the police and threatened with yet more prison time, one of China’s most persecuted writers, Liao Yiwu, slipped across the border into Vietnam last week and then made his way, via Poland, to Germany, where he promptly declared himself an exile.

headline: Updates on British Phone-Hacking Scandal
text: On Tuesday, The Lede is following developments in the phone-hacking scandal in Britain, as fresh revelations of misconduct by journalists continue to come to light.

headline: Fracking Water Killed Trees, Study Finds
text: A study that argues for more research into the safe disposal of chemical-laced wastewater resulting from natural gas drilling found that a patch of national forest in West Virginia suffered quick and serious loss of vegetation after it was sprayed with hydraulic fracturing fluids.

headline: In Debt Ceiling Fight, Obama Has the Edge
text: Last year, President Obama and House Republicans managed to reach a last-minute accord on preserving the Bush tax cuts, and then in April they just barely averted a government shutdown. But now, in this debate over the debt ceiling, each side seems ready to make a stand at last and find out whom the voters really trust when it comes to righting the nation’s finances.

headline: Do You Believe in Magic?
text: OK, David Brooks has what amounts to a reply. I don’t want to get into a tit for tat. But I do want to take on the claim that believing that simple actions can bring big improvements in the economy amounts to belief in magic.

headline: Kenzo Picks New York Retailers to Lead
text: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton announced Tuesday that Humberto Leon and Carol Lim, founders of Opening Ceremony, will be creative directors of Kenzo. Their first collection for the Paris-based brand will be shown this fall.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Rules Set for New Health Insurance Exchanges
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Out and About | Provincetown on Parade
text: Summer sojourners to Provincetown, Mass., typically have an object in sight: a breezy beach, a lobster roll, a parade of thousands. The tiny, affluent sandbar on the northern tip of Cape Cod remains a low-key, largely gay resort town for the summer — except during theme weeks, when the population swells to more than 100,000, many of them bopping to a heavy disco beat. Every tribe has its week in P-town: there’s Bear Week (happening now), Family Pride Week (July 30-Aug. 6) and by late August it’s time for Carnival (Aug. 14-19). That means rollicking street parties, colorful floats and an infinite supply of garish costumes.

headline: Insincerely Yours
text: Jonathan Chait is puzzled by the behavior of the anti-deficit lobby, which persists in blaming Democrats for the failure of Republicans to act responsibly:

headline: U.S. Trade Deficit Jumped in May
text: A rise in imports of petroleum products helped widen the United States trade deficit in May to more than $50 billion, marking its largest gap since late 2008, according to government statistics released on Tuesday.

headline: Thugs of the World
text: I obviously never had a very good opinion of Rupert Murdoch’s role in US and UK affairs. But I never expected to see the kinds of things now coming to light as the phone-hacking scandal metastasizes — hacking Gordon Brown and the Queen, bribing the police, hiring investigators to dig up dirt on the people investigating the hacking, and on and on.

headline: With Sonic, G.M. Stands Automaking on Its Head
text: ORION TOWNSHIP, Mich. — The only subcompact car being built on American soil will soon roll out of an assembly plant here in suburban Detroit that is as unusual as the car itself.

headline: Small Car, Big Changes
text: General Motors is using a variety of techniques to make the Chevrolet Sonic profitable.

headline: Worries About a Gonorrhea ‘Superbug’
text: Government heath officials are warning that gonorrhea, one of the most common sexually transmitted diseases, is becoming increasingly resistant to the last type of antibiotics left to treat it.

headline: New Yorkers Speaking Softly
text: Theodore Roosevelt — he’s the one who doesn’t have a highway in Manhattan named after him — seems to be enjoying a resurgent popularity among the city’s political and chattering classes.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Forecast App Tells Friends Where You’re Going
text: Check-in applications like Foursquare tell your friends where you are at any given moment. Forecast, a new mobile application, tells you where your friends are going to be.

headline: Lowering Economic Expectations
text: As my colleague David Leonhardt has written, government officials (both in the White House and at the Federal Reserve) have been overly optimistic in their economic forecasts. In particular, conservatives like to make fun of the administration’s rosy projections from 2009 for how the economy would behave under the Recovery Act; the administration’s economic advisers predicted unemployment today would be below 7 percent, rather than the 9.2 percent we’re actually stuck with. Buzzwords like “shovel-ready” and “Recovery Summer” have also become major mockery talking points.

headline: Longer Wars, Fewer Medals of Honor
text: Today, President Obama will award the Medal of Honor, the United States’ highest military decoration, to Sgt. First Class Leroy A. Petry, who lost his right hand in 2008 while tossing away an insurgent grenade that could have killed two of his fellow Army Rangers in Afghanistan. It will be only the second time that the medal has been given to a living soldier in the nearly 10 years since the Sept. 11 attacks, and only the ninth time the medal has been awarded to an Iraq or Afghanistan veteran.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: An Addition to the List of Tax Loopholes | President Obama has talked about eliminating tax breaks for partners at hedge funds and private equity firms — along with those of corporate jet owners, oil companies and others taking advantage of quirks in the tax code.

headline: Gaz Metro Bests Fortis to Buy Vermont Utility
text: Gaz Métro of Canada, the owner of the Green Mountain Power Corporation, said on Tuesday it would buy the Central Vermont Public Service Corporation for $472 million in a deal that would join the two largest electric utilities in Vermont.

headline: Tucker Blair for Opening Ceremony
text: On Tuesday, Opening Ceremony’s Humberto Leon and Carol Lim were named creative directors of Kenzo, the vibrant, print-happy French house founded by the Japanese designer Kenzo Takada and owned by LVMH. And still, the two are showing no signs of slowing their constant flow of designer collaborations. Aiming to have you in stitches this summer, Opening Ceremony releases its first collection of needlepoint belts with Tucker Blair, the Washington-based purveyor of the classic preppy pant cinchers. Out with the lobsters, anchors and other yacht club clichés and in with leopard spots, hopping bunnies and fluorescents. A belt of international flags winks at the hip store’s Olympics-emulating moniker and its yearly “host” country shopping experience, celebrating the styles of different nations. Available exclusively at Opening Ceremony stores and online starting Friday, these embroidered beauties make for perfect waist watching.

headline: In Effort to Cut U.S. Deficit, New York Teaching Hospitals May Lose Aid
text: New York State’s prestigious teaching hospitals could lose more than $1 billion a year as part of plans under negotiation in Washington to reduce the federal deficit that the hospitals say will lead to drastic service reductions.

headline: Senate Bill Seeks to Raise Revenue by Closing Tax Havens
text: With officials in Washington struggling over a deal to cut the nation’s deficit, two senior Senate Democrats on Tuesday urged the federal government to focus on the billions of dollars in revenue lost to offshore tax havens.

headline: It’s Hot Around the U.S. Again
text: Hot summer weather across the country will continue on Tuesday with temperatures expected to top 95 degrees in cities from St. Louis and Atlanta to Baltimore and Montgomery, Ala.

headline: Bowery Presents Expands to Philadelphia
text: The Bowery Presents empire of rock clubs and theaters has already expanded from the Lower East Side to New Jersey, Massachusetts and Maine, and now it is spreading to Pennsylvania.

headline: Patient Voices: Macular Degeneration
text: Six men and women speak about their lives with progressive vision loss.

headline: Doctoroff Named Chief Executive of Bloomberg L.P.
text: Daniel L. Doctoroff, a former deputy to MayorMichael Bloomberg of New York who became president of Bloomberg L.P. three and a half years ago, was promoted on Tuesday to be the company’s chief executive.

headline: Amid the Cleanup in Japan, Four-Wheel Fragments of Daily Life
text: SENDAI, Japan — It took minutes for the tsunami that hit the coast of Japan in March to destroy entire cities. It will take years to clean up the mess that was left behind.

headline: Man Accused of Stealing Picasso Drawing to Plead Not Guilty
text: The attorney for the New Jersey man charged with stealing a small Picasso drawing from an art gallery in San Francisco on July 5 said the man plans to plead not guilty, according to The Associated Press. Mark Lugo, of Hoboken, was arrested last week in a hotel in Napa, Calif., about 50 miles north of San Francisco, and the police recovered the drawing stolen from the Weinstein Gallery in San Francisco.

headline: Parenthood vs. Passion
text: In the Sunday Review this past weekend, the writer Erica Jong took on her daughter’s generation for the second time in less than a year. Last fall she wrote in The Wall Street Journal about how today’s mothers invest too much of themselves in their children, and are “imprisoned by motherhood.” This latest, titled “Is Sex Passé?” suggests that women are giving up sex for motherhood, too.

headline: Playing the Odds to Land a Job
text: At the Resorts World Casino New York City, which is set to open in late summer, what are the odds of getting hired for a permanent position?

headline: News Corporation Looks to Bolster Stock With Buyback Plan
text: The News Corporation on Tuesday moved to stanch the accelerating drop in its stock price, announcing a program to repurchase $5 billion in shares.

headline: Thinking Cap: The Weight Panic

headline: Notes From the Underground | Phoebe Jean & the Air Force
text: Phoebe Jean & the Air Force performed at Cakeshop recently, opening a lineup of queer-centric acts, including Follower and the Chilean electro dance smash MKRNI. Looking like a mischievous, overgrown elf in a floppy hat and XXXL T-shirt that cloaked her like a dress, Phoebe performed her signature mix of classic club breaks, funk and electronic, while her drummer, dressed in skintight animal-print pants, maniacally contorted his face. Collectively, the group brought the low-ceilinged room to a sweat.

headline: Who’s the Real Leader in Debt Talks?
text: With the clock ticking toward the Aug. 2 deadline to increase the nation’s debt limit, President Obama and his Republican adversaries are arguing over big, complicated questions about spending cuts, tax increases and revamping the nation’s entitlement programs.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Finds New Life on ESPN Classic
text: On the same week that the acclaimed drama “Friday Night Lights” is ending on NBC it is starting on the ESPN family of sports networks.

headline: All-Stars and No-Shows
text: In a stroke of good fortune, the All-Star Game on Tuesday night comes fully stocked with a complete complement of conversation topics, issues to argue about, players to wag a finger at or sit back and appreciate. This is a particularly good thing because, with two of the four major American professional sports not operating at the moment, we need all the diversion we can get.

headline: AARP’s New Social Security Calculator
text: With all the chatter about making potential changes to Social Security, many people are probably thinking that they should start collecting benefits as soon as they can.

headline: The Voices of Macular Degeneration
text: Age-related macular degeneration is a common eye disease that gradually destroys central vision. An estimated 1.8 million Americans age 40 and older have advanced disease, and 7.3 million people have intermediate disease, putting them at risk for vision loss.

headline: Parliament to Oppose News Corp.’s BSkyB Deal
text: The British government plans to back a Labour Party motion in Parliament to block the News Corporation‘s $12 billion bid for British Sky Broadcasting, British news outlets reported on Tuesday.

headline: Wisconsin’s Summer of Recall Elections Begins
text: Voters in Wisconsin on Tuesday began going to the polls — an odd time for an election, but only the beginning of what is to be a summer of elections for a state in the throes of political discord.

text: BAGHDAD — Terrorism fears in the United States are all but halting visas for Iraqis, even those who risked their lives aiding the American war effort, making them especially vulnerable ahead of the planned American military withdrawal.

headline: Berlusconi Pledges to Push Through Austerity Bill
text: ROME — Acknowledging publicly that Italy was in danger of being pulled into Europe’s sovereign debt crisis, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on Tuesday insisted that his government would push through a contentious austerity bill.

text: If a rat skipped across the subway tracks, caked in soot, eyes burning red, splashing in the sewage, certain thoughts would most likely come to mind.

headline: Planning for Retirement While Helping Out the Children
text: No wonder retirement planning is getting more complex. Many older Americans’ sense of financial security remains rattled by the recession, and now many of them expect to have to help other family members financially, including adult children, after they retire.

headline: At Jury Selection, Hardin Hits Spots and Changes Speeds
text: WASHINGTON — In questioning the potential jurors in Roger Clemens’s perjury trial, Rusty Hardin, Clemens’s lawyer, has been smooth and charming, going out of his way to make connections with the people who might decide his client’s fate. While his questions to the jury are supposed to be specifically related to the case, Hardin has gotten away with asking some off-beat ones.

headline: Eying 2013 Mayoral Race, Stringer Raises $655,000
text: Demonstrating continued fund-raising strength as he eyes a likely bid for mayor in 2013, the Manhattan borough president, Scott M. Stringer, is expected to report this week that he raised $655,000 in the first six months of this year.

There’s an interactive map that includes box offices, restrooms, parking, on-campus restaurants and subways.

headline: Paul Taylor Archives Go Online
text: For more than half a century the choreographer Paul Taylor has inspired, enchanted and puzzled audiences with his dances onstage. Now fans can get a peek behind the curtain as his archives are opened to the public.

headline: Exclusive Clip: ‘The Car Show’
text: “The Car Show,” starring the comedian and podcast fixture Adam Carolla, the Pulitzer Prize-winning automotive journalist Dan Neil, the former N.B.A. player John Salley and the erstwhile Garage 419 host Matt Farah will have its premiere on Speed Wednesday at 10 p.m.

headline: Young Executives to Meet With Capital’s Old Guard
text: The White House and the U.S. Chamber of Commerce have been at war for much of the last two-and-a-half years. One thing they can agree on, however, is the need to attract successful young people, especially at the start of an election season when campaign cash will be at a premium.

headline: Reviewing Brushstroke
Brushstroke
text: THE ingenious gentleman David Bouley has been marching the streets of TriBeCa for more than 25 years. He first tasted fame in 1985 as the chef at Montrachet on West Broadway, then mainlined it two years later with the eponymous Bouley.

headline: Airport Body Scanners and Health
text: Do airport body scanners cause cancer? Some Transportation Security Administration employees believe so, according to documents released in late June by the Electronic Privacy Information Center, a privacy-rights advocacy group in Washington.

headline: Not Satisfied, Protesters Return to Tahrir Square
text: CAIRO — Past a battered Fiat displaying T-shirts on its hood with the words “I am free,” and a little way from a vendor hawking roasted sweet potatoes wrapped in membership applications for the former ruling party, a sign hangs from a tent in Tahrir Square that says something about the pride, regret and hope of Egypt’s revolution.

headline: River as Teacher
text: If my “mild” stroke (is there such a thing?) had not intervened, I would have been heading tonight to the banks of the Hudson River, on the campus of Marist College, to talk about energy technology and policy with participants in River Summer. This annual project aims to foster a multi-disciplinary approach to watershed issues at faculties at universities and colleges up and down the Hudson.

headline: France Reauthorizes Libya Bombing Campaign While Hinting at Negotiations
text: PARIS — Lawmakers here on Tuesday reauthorized France’s participation in the NATO-led bombing campaign in Libya against the forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, while French officials said they were increasingly optimistic about the possibility of a negotiated end to the conflict.

headline: Russian ‘Tubs’ Sail Waters Despite History of Failure
text: KAZAN, Russia — Prosecutors in Russia opened a broad investigation into the river transport industry Tuesday after a tour boat sank and as many as 128 people drowned, including dozens of children trapped in a playroom.

headline: London Theater Journal: Finding Truth in Phoniness
text: LONDON — As a general rule, when actors come across on stage as actors, that means they’re “acting” – instead of, you know, being – which is considered a crime against art. But since I arrived here a few days ago, I’ve had occasion to witness two fine actors giving highly theatrical performances – the kind in which you’re conscious of their working the stops and pedals of the instruments that are their bodies. And I was reminded that for certain roles, a touch of the phony is just what’s needed to create an illusion of authenticity.

headline: Click if You See a Female Cyclist in Manhattan
text: It is a commonly used figure in the world of New York City cycling: Male cyclists outnumber female cyclists three to one. But that number has transit experts in a lather as they argue that this ratio, arrived at through census data, misses out on most of the cycling world.

headline: Lumiere | The Curious Case of Pierre Loti

headline: Zereoue Happily Trades Football for Fútbol
text: Even at 34, Amos Zereoue looks like your prototypical N.F.L. running back. His body and legs still look like they could power over linebackers. He stands 5-8 with shoulders broad enough to make one doubt whether they would fit through a doorway. But Zereoue has been retired from the N.F.L. since 2005 after seven seasons for the Steelers, Raiders and Patriots.

headline: Fed Officials Divided on Need for More Monetary Stimulus
text: Federal Reserve policy makers disagreed on whether additional monetary stimulus would be needed even if the outlook for economic growth remained weak, minutes of their meeting last month showed.
