headline: Sherwood Schwartz, Creator of Gilligan and the Bradys, Dies at 94
text: Sherwood Schwartz, who created “Gilligan’s Island” and “The Brady Bunch,” two of the most affectionately ridiculed and enduring television sitcoms of the 1960s and ’70s, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 94.

headline: The Factory Age Isn’t Over
text: The number of factories in the United States employing more than 1,000 workers fell by one-third from 1997 to 2007, leaving 1,014 such factories. This probably will not surprise you. The shattered windows of empty factories have become a familiar sight.

headline: E.U. Vows to Back Banks That Fail Stress Tests
text: BRUSSELS — European officials vowed on Tuesday to support banks that fail stress tests but left unresolved deep disputes that have held up a second rescue package for Greece.

Narea’s “The Fund” and Norb Vonnegut’s “The Gods of Greenwich.” All three books are worth a read, but the discerning Wall Street reader may find some more realistic than others. headline: Ron Paul Will Not Seek Re-Election
text: Representative Ron Paul, the long-serving Texas Republican, will not seek re-election next year so he can focus on his bid for his party’s presidential nomination instead, according to his campaign.

headline: For ‘Smash’ Writers, ‘On a Clear Day’ Workshop Is Homework
text: Through an unusual alignment of stars, the playwrights Theresa Rebeck, David Marshall Grant, Jacquelyn Reingold, and others working on the upcoming NBC series “Smash” — about the making of a Broadway musical — will do research next week at a developmental workshop for an actual musical opening on Broadway in December, a revival of “On a Clear Day You Can See Forever.”

headline: With Blunt, Salty Talk, Panetta Era Begins

headline: U.S. Goalkeeper Made Quite a Comeback of Her Own
text: MÖNCHENGLADBACH, Germany — They would joke about it later, but the moment grew too chaotic for Hope Solo. She had to get away. This time, she left on her own, not at the insistence of others.

text: Steve Klinsky is founder and chief executive of New Mountain Capital and chairman of the Growth Capital Committee within his industry’s Private Equity Growth Capital Council.

headline: A Half-Century Later, Student Artwork Sprouts Where ‘Sociopaths’ Roamed
text: Fifty years ago, 84th Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, beat out some pretty stiff competition to be designated the “worst block” in New York City — a “ghetto of sociopaths,” in the words of the rector of a nearby Episcopal church who despaired that city officials would ever do anything to clean up the mess.

headline: Fiscal Puzzle: Trying to Balance a City Budget

headline: On Experts and Global Warming
text: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.Experts have always posed a problem for democracies.  Plato scorned democracy, rating it the worst form of government short of tyranny, largely because it gave power to the ignorant many rather than to knowledgeable experts (philosophers, as he saw it).  But, if, as we insist, the people must ultimately decide, the question remains: How can we, nonexperts, take account of expert opinion when it is relevant to decisions about public policy?

headline: Two Islands Are a Stage, and All Are Actors
text: There are actors around spitting out Shakespeare, but the real star of the boisterous “Henry V” being staged outdoors by New York Classical Theater as part of the River to River Festival might be whatever’s on the feet of the audience members. A good pair of walking shoes is essential for this rollicking exercise in participatory theater, because the spectators turn into Henry’s army as he invades France, charging up hillsides and bellowing battle cries. Oh, and there’s a boat ride.

headline: Nearly 5 Workers for Every Available Job
text: More bad news on the job market front: the number of jobless workers per job opening stayed flat at 4.7 in May, according to a new report from the Labor Department. That is more than twice the average ratio seen during the boom years that preceded the Great Recession.

headline: A Married, Reimagined Jesus
text: The creators of “The Magdalene,” a musical based on an alternate telling of the story of Mary Magdalene, have achieved the seemingly impossible: they have managed to take stunningly incendiary material and douse it with blandness and bathos.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Russia, West Bank, Kenya and Afghanistan.

headline: Over the Years, Close Finishes but No Title
text: SANDWICH, England — Three decades ago, when Bernhard Langer showed up at Royal St. George’s for the British Open, he was a skinny 23-year-old with a pile of thick, curly hair, a thin mustache and two obscure victories on the European Tour.

headline: The Trees and Fields Are Laced With Arias
text: It has been four years since the Metropolitan Opera decided to stop presenting full operas in its summertime concerts in New York City’s parks, a decision that was difficult to understand, given the popularity of these free performances, and the likelihood that they were winning the company new listeners. Now, presumably, the Met’s high-definition opera screenings are expected to be its audience builders: It is presenting free screenings of 10 of them in its Met Summer HD Festival, at Lincoln Center from Aug. 27 to Sept. 5.

headline: Show Is Stopped but Then Goes On After Injury to Royal Shakespeare Company’s Romeo
text: Sam Troughton, the star of the Royal Shakespeare Company’s production of “Romeo and Juliet” at the Park Avenue Armory, injured his knee during a matinee performance on Tuesday, halting the performance, said Nada Zakula, a spokeswoman for the company.

headline: McConnell Proposal Gives Obama Power to Increase Debt Limit
text: The Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, said Tuesday that a bipartisan budget deal with President Obama was probably out of reach, and he proposed a plan under which the president could increase the federal debt limit without Congressional approval for offsetting spending cuts.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Russia, West Bank, Kenya and Afghanistan.

headline: New York’s First Private Food Truck Court Comes to Queens
text: The city’s moveable food-truck feast is about to become more stationary, with the establishment in Long Island City, Queens, of what may be its first food truck court on private land. It’s expected to open in two weeks at 43-29 Crescent Street, not far from Jackson Avenue.Rockrose Development Corporation, the lot’s owner, has come to an agreement with the New York City Food Truck Association, which has recruited a group of trucks interested in participating, said David Weber, president of the trade group.

headline: U.S. Women Working on Legacy Apart From 1999 Team
text: MÖNCHENGLADBACH, Germany — Sunday’s wild victory over Brazil allowed the United States to begin coming out of the considerable shadow of the 1999 team that won the Women’s World Cup with pioneering players like Mia Hamm, Brandi Chastain, Julie Foudy, Kristine Lilly and Briana Scurry.

headline: ‘Rebecca’ to Sing, Manderley to Burn on Broadway
text: A $16 million musical production of “Rebecca,” based on the classic 1938 novel by Daphne du Maurier, has been scaled down to a budget of about $12 million — largely thanks to the loss of a collapsing staircase special effect — and is now on track for Broadway, the producers announced on Tuesday. Preview performances at a Shubert theater still to be named are scheduled to begin March 27, 2012, with an opening night set for April 22.

headline: With Tiny Cans, a New Trash Equation
text: Reaching for a petite dessert dish instead of the mixing bowl may help you curb your ice cream consumption. Grabbing a basket rather than a shopping cart helps control how many “necessities” you pick up at the store.

headline: Fatty  ‘Cue Is Coming to the Village
text: To replace their former restaurant Cabrito, Zakary Pelaccio and Rick Camac plan a Manhattan version of Fatty ‘Cue, their Asian-style barbecue place in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. They don’t have the details yet, but they say it will have a somewhat different menu and design and no smokehouse, which the one in Brooklyn has. They hope to open around Labor Day. Follow @ZakaryPelaccio on Twitter for updates.

headline: Baking Bread (and More) in Brooklyn
text: Zachary Golper, who baked bread and pastries for Le Bec-Fin in Philadelphia, and Kate Wheatcroft, his wife, have had New York in their sights for some time. The result is the bakery Bien Cuit, in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn.

headline: Get Your Bling and Adidas Tracksuit, Wayne, a British Class War Is Raging
text: Owen Jones’s first book, “Chavs: The Demonization of the Working Class,” begins more like a Noël Coward play or a late-model Ian McEwan novel than like a rumbling social polemic. That is, it opens with a misfired witticism uttered at an elite East London dinner party.

headline: Bloomberg on the Debt Ceiling
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg addresses the negotiations Washington over the nation's budget.

headline: U.S. and Chinese Officials Named to I.M.F. Posts
text: WASHINGTON — Christine Lagarde, the new head of the International Monetary Fund, named an American official as her chief deputy Tuesday and, in a move that reflects China’s rising influence, added a Chinese official to the ranks of her senior advisers.

headline: Tumbles and Twitches in an Alien World Undersea or in Outer Space
text: A woman transformed into a half-human and half-dog creature, multiple bodies joined to form knotty masses, human towers that teeter high in the air: an evening with  Pilobolus Dance Theater  should be filled with wonder.

headline: Organizing My Online Friends
text: I don’t consider my neighbor my “friend.” My boss isn’t necessarily my “friend” either (although I do like my boss!). I also wouldn’t categorize a person I met 20 years ago in high school as my “friend.” Yet on social Web sites like Facebook these people are all lumped into one giant social bucket called “friends.”

headline: Picnics, Deemed Perfect and for Sale
text: Takeout shops and restaurants around the city will gladly pack a lunch or supper to enjoy in the park. Perfect Picnic, a new store on the Lower East Side, is dedicated to assembling food for an outdoor feast.

headline: City Food Trucks Work Together to Solve Parking Problem
text: WHEN beset by predators, there is always a comforting resort: the safety of the herd.

headline: Kip Tiernan, Founder of First Shelter for Homeless Women, Dies at 85
text: Kip Tiernan was dumbfounded when she saw women disguising themselves as men to get a meal at a men-only homeless shelter in Boston nearly 40 years ago — so much so that she went ahead and founded the nation’s first homeless shelter for women.

headline: TimesCast | July 12, 2011
text: Hamid Karzai's half brother is killed; calls grow for News Corporation to drop the BSkyB bid; and the phone-hacking scandal puts David Cameron in an awkward position.

headline: In Mogadishu: A Lifeline For Somali Rape Victims
text: “Why did you come here when no one else does?” The African Union communications director asked us over dinner at its compound in Mogadishu. Good question. We were warned against it, especially by war-zone regulars. It’s been called the most dangerous city—or place—on earth. In fact, we had to delay our trip for two weeks due to multiple suicide bombings and riots inside the area controlled by Mogadishu’s transitional government (TFG). So, why go? I gave the short answer, “We’re supporting a local social entrepreneur in launching a sexual violence hotline.”

headline: Austin’s Very Own Martini
text: AUSTIN, Tex.

headline: Additional Letters: Searching for Perspective
text: Following up on the reader letters that appeared in my print column for this week, here are some additional letters via e-mail to my last three columns, Surrounded by Opinion, the Times Raises Its Voices, On NYTimes.com, Now You See It, Now You Don’t and Where Words Can Never Do Justice.Thank you, stateless soul, for your informative discussion of feedback on the new Sunday Review in the Times July 3. I cannot convey how much I dislike the new format. I, like the feedback you mentioned, sorely miss the political cartoons and the late-night television gag lines. The weekly news is dire enough without taking away our opportunity to laugh while we are informed. The political cartoons were always the first thing I turned to on a Sunday morning. Wouldn’t Art Buchwald turn over in his grave to see you eliminate his life’s work?

headline: Love’s Flames Amid a City in Flames
text: Fire breathes from just about every scene in Rupert Goold’s hot-tempered, hard-charging staging of “Romeo and Juliet,” the second production in the Royal Shakespeare Company’s repertory season at the Park Avenue Armory. The warring Capulets and Montagues show occasional signs of pathological pyromania, and the buildings of Verona appear to be wallpapered in mesmerizing images of flames.

headline: New York Live Arts Announces Fall Season
text: New York Live Arts, the new artistic initiative created this year by the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company and Dance Theater Workshop, is offering something new for artists and audiences this fall. For theatergoers, the group plans to present works from more than 40 artists, including a Replay Series that looks back at artists’ most significant and popular works. The performers include Big Dance Theater, John Jasperse, John Kelly, Yvonne Meier, Richard Move and Reggie Wilson. For artists, New York Live Arts has begun a two-year residency that offers a rarity in the art world: salary, health benefits and a commission for a work. The first artist to benefit is Yasuko Yokoshi, a Hiroshima-born choreographer who came to the United States in 1981.

headline: Everyone Else’s Problem
text: “Half of U.S. social program recipients believe they ‘have not used a government social program,’ ” according to a paper by Suzanne Mettler, a professor at Cornell, posted on Boing Boing. And, yes, that includes everyone who has ever taken a mortgage deduction, taken out a student loan or collected Social Security upon retirement. If you’re wondering why it’s so difficult to come to an agreement on the debt ceiling and taxes, it may be because, as Cory Doctorow writes, we live in “a society of people who subsist on mutual aid and redistributive policies who’ve been conned (and conned themselves) into thinking that they are rugged individualists and that everyone else is a parasite.”

headline: Still Fighting Fire With Fire to Honor the Fallen of 9/11
text: The 10th anniversary of 9/11 is near, summoning not only horrible memories of that cataclysm but also the anxiety of measuring up. Ten years on, there still aren’t enough words, gestures, ceremonies or moments of silence to match the wound. Not paying attention is unthinkable, but it’s even harder to think of an adequate tribute.

headline: British Distiller Diageo Shifts Its Focus in Acquisitions to Fast-Growing Markets
text: LONDON — Baijiu, a popular Chinese spirit known for its harsh and fiery kick, might not be everyone’s preferred drink, but the management at Diageo liked it so much that it pursued a takeover of a baijiu maker in China for two years.

headline: Illicit Love and All Its Consequences
text: As bad ballets go, Alexei Ratmansky’s two-act “Anna Karenina” is one of the best. It tells its potted version of Tolstoy’s novel with a fair bit of narrative clarity; it manages many complex changes of scene deftly; its décor and costumes (by Mikael Melbye) are generally elegant; its extensive use of video projections (by Wendall Harrington) is unusual and effective; and most of its leading characters are immediately identifiable and distinct. But these virtues don’t suffice. The ballet is a complete waste of everybody’s time.

headline: With Dugard, ABC News Notches a Rare Win
text: ABC News got one more boost from its exclusive interview with the kidnapping victim Jaycee Lee Dugard: it beat NBC in the evening news competition last Thursday.

headline: Wall Street Warns Lawmakers on Debt
text: The White House and Congress received dual warnings from Wall Street on Tuesday about the consequences of failing to raise the federal debt ceiling in a timely manner.

headline: VMware Shows Its Cloud Strategy
text: VMware made a handful of product announcements on Tuesday that add up to the company’s bid to become the Microsoft of cloud computing.

headline: Bloomberg Urges Washington to Raise Debt Limit
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, warning of potentially “catastrophic” effects to the financial system, urged Republicans and Democrats on Tuesday to stop bickering over taxes and spending cuts and move swiftly toward an agreement to raise the country’s debt limit.

headline: Roberts Blossom, Quirky Character Actor, Dies at 87
text: Roberts Blossom, a durable character actor who was known for playing cantankerous old coots, both comic and sinister, but who may be best remembered as the kindly next-door neighbor in the comedy “Home Alone,” died on Friday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 87.

headline: City Opera Director Defends New Season
text: On Tuesday it was George Steel’s turn.

headline: Mayor Bloomberg Adds 70 Hybrids and E.V.’s to City Fleet
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg turned Tuesday into something of a plug-in car day in New York City, announcing the addition of 70 new plug-in hybrid and purely electric vehicles for government fleets, as well as the start of Drive Electric NYC, a Web site aimed at helping city residents learn about E.V.’s. The city also is hosting, with Nissan, a free screening of the documentary “Revenge of the Electric Car” in Central Park Tuesday evening.

headline: War May Be Hell, but a Competition Show Awaits
text: The best propaganda doesn’t tip its hand. Want to make a show that engenders respect and sympathy for the armed forces without complications? Take it out of the theater of war. Afghanistan is no closed set.

headline: Rare White House Ceremony for Medal of Honor

headline: In the Wake of Disaster, Baseball Endures
text: In the aftermath of the earthquake and tsunami that struck Japan, three high schools from affected areas came together to create a baseball team.

headline: In Fukushima, Japan, a Baseball Story of Coming Together and Carrying On
text: ONO MACHI, Japan — When the earthquake and tsunami hit northeastern Japan in March, high school baseball teams up and down the coast were suddenly without fields to play on, including those closest to crippled nuclear power plants in Fukushima. Radiation levels were so dangerous that schools there were abandoned and players were evacuated to towns and cities across the country.

headline: Friends in Revolution
text: On Friday, I wrote about Friendfactor, an organizing tool used in the successful battle for gay marriage in New York State.  Friendfactor combines social media and real-world friendship to motivate people to get active.  Instead of getting an e-mail from a group asking you to support a political goal, you get one from a close friend or family member asking you to “help me get my full rights.”    Friendfactor is particularly interesting because it seems to offer a solution to one of the biggest obstacles in using social media for political change:  people need close personal connections in order to get them to take action — especially if that action is risky and difficult.

headline: Schools Chiefs See a Path to Proposing Their Own Accountability Systems
text: Some state education chiefs say that if Congress does not overhaul No Child Left Behind, the main federal law governing public education, by the fall, they may be allowed to propose their own accountability systems as an alternative.

headline: Family Differences, Global Issues
text: ATHENS — In a sun-drenched room at the foundation here that is named for his father, Nick Papandreou pondered the task confronting his older brother, George: dismantling the Greek welfare state largely erected by their father, Andreas Papandreou.

headline: North Dakota and N.C.A.A. Are at Odds Again Over University’s Sioux Mascot
text: Officials at the University of North Dakota thought the long battle over the college’s Fighting Sioux nickname was finally over when they reached an agreement last year to retire the mascot. Then, the North Dakota legislature passed a law this year forcing the university to keep the name.

headline: Florida: Naval Reservist Enters Diversion Program
text: A Navy reservist agreed Tuesday in Federal District Court in Miami to enter a pretrial diversion program to avoid conviction on a passport violation that could have prevented him from becoming the American citizen he says he believed he already was. Petty Officer Elisha L. Dawkins would not reveal the terms of the agreement, saying only that, going forward, he wants to continue his military service and finish his nursing degree. Petty Officer Dawkins, who was born in the Bahamas and raised in Miami, was indicted in March, while he was serving at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. Before serving in the Navy, he was in the Army, and both branches believed he was a citizen when he enlisted, as did the State Department when it issued him a passport, in spite of a deportation order dating to 1992.

headline: TimesCast | Karzai's Half Brother Killed
text: July 12, 2011 - President Karzai's half brother, the linchpin of the security and power structure in southern Afghanistan, was shot and killed Tuesday.

headline: French Coach Relies on Poetry
text: MÖNCHENGLADBACH, Germany — Bruno Bini, the coach of the French women’s soccer team, was not feeling well early Tuesday afternoon. Something he ate did not agree with him. But by evening, he hoped to recover a more celebrative mood.

headline: In PopCap Deal, Electronic Arts Has Its Eyes on Zynga
text: For many, Electronic Arts has long been synonymous with video games: many (including this reporter) have whiled away a few hours away with the Madden franchise, the Need for Speed series and the Sims lineup over the years. (Maybe more than a few.)

headline: In Fiscal Fight, G.O.P. Distrust of Obama Runs Deep
text: WASHINGTON — If President Obama thought he could rattle House Republicans with his warning on Tuesday that Social Security checks might get held up in the event the debt limit was not raised soon, he was mistaken.

headline: An Alabamian as Polarizing as the Issues
text: GARDENDALE, Ala. — Newspaper editorials have called him treasonous. The N.A.A.C.P. has called for his resignation. Chamber of commerce groups and civil libertarians have found common cause in disgruntlement, and a Republican sheriff more or less accused him of being an accessory to any deaths that take place in his county.

headline: Efforts to Rein In Executive Pay Meet With Little Success
text: Executive pay continues to skyrocket despite years of criticism by corporate governance gurus, fierce efforts by unions to temper compensation and calls by politicians to regulate pay.

headline: A Pathway Out of the Debt Crisis
text: Political gain, not economic sense or sound policy, has always been at the core of Republican strategy on the debt-ceiling talks — a cynical ploy to appear serious about cutting spending while actually holding hostage the nation’s strong credit rating. Now that the real risks to their strategy are becoming apparent, including the possibility of cutting off Social Security checks, the more experienced members of the party are beginning to rethink their plans.

headline: Libyan Rebels Accused of Pillage and Beatings
text: ZINTAN, Libya — Rebels in the mountains in Libya’s west have looted and damaged four towns seized since last month from the forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, part of a series of abuses and apparent reprisals against suspected loyalists that have chased residents of these towns away, Human Rights Watch said Tuesday.

headline: McIlroy Defends His Decision to Rest Before British
text: SANDWICH, England — Rory McIlroy, who has been overwhelmed by the outpouring of worldwide support that followed his United States Open victory, is coming into the British Open without a competitive round in the one month since he took apart the field and the Congressional Country Club course.

headline: Netflix Raises Price of DVD and Online Movies Package by 60%
text: DVDs are not dead yet, but they are going to cost more — at least for customers of Netflix, the popular entertainment service, which said on Tuesday that it was sharply increasing the price of its Internet-plus-DVDs-in-the-mail plan.

text: Players who enjoy links golf will be the ones to beat in this year’s British Open at Royal St. George’s.

headline: Revolution Dims Star Power of Egypt’s Antiquities Chief
text: Until recently Zahi Hawass, Egypt’s antiquities minister, was a global symbol of Egyptian national pride. A famous archaeologist in an Indiana Jones hat, he was virtually unassailable in the old Egypt, protected by his success in boosting tourism, his efforts to reclaim lost artifacts and his closeness to the country’s first lady, Suzanne Mubarak.

headline: California Counties Talk of Cutting Ties to State
text: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — Natives here have long called this area the Inland Empire, a grand title for a stretch of cities about 50 miles east of Los Angeles. Now, a few political leaders are hoping this empire will lead a movement to break off from the State of California.

headline: Pride, and Sadness, as a Nation Is Born
text: It was a day long awaited, but Jane Kani Edward could not bring herself to fully embrace the moment.

headline: With New Fire Department Technology, a ‘Mayday’ Could Bring Faster Help
text: For a New York City firefighter in trouble, issuing a “mayday” has always set off a frenzy. It prompts chiefs to shout to try to keep people off the air. As radio silence takes hold, firefighters count heads and try to determine from whom and where the call came.

headline: Considering Interleague Play All Season Long
text: PHOENIX

headline: To Rebound, RIM Courts the Carriers
text: OTTAWA — Even though Research in Motion, the maker of BlackBerry devices, has been undermined by Apple’s iPhone and phones using Google’s Android software, the exceptional success of its competitors could provide the foundation of its recovery.

headline: Blaze Shatters a Heart of New York Jewish Life
text: The fire that severely damaged Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun on Monday night sent ripples of distress across the Modern Orthodox community of Manhattan’s East Side and among Jews around New York familiar with Ramaz, its affiliated school.

headline: Debt Talk Mired, Leader for G.O.P. Proposes Option
text: WASHINGTON — From the White House and Congress to financial centers, pessimism spread on Tuesday about the prospects of a debt-limit deal between President Obama and Republicans, prompting the Senate Republican leader to propose a “last-choice option” that piqued the administration’s interest but angered conservatives in his own party.

headline: Britain’s Press Scandal
text: The phone hacking scandal in Britain that has already brought down The News of the World and now hangs over at least two other newspapers has exposed a culture of illegal intrusions, systematic bribes to corrupt police officials and thuggish threats of damaging publicity to silence criminal investigators. It is not over yet.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Strange Waters
text: The Civil War famously pitted brother against brother, but it also pitted comrade against comrade: especially in the opposing officer corps, the Union and Confederate armies were staffed with men who had earlier served on the same side, and in many cases were even at West Point together, both as students and instructors. One of the themes of Michael Shaara’s classic novel “The Killer Angels” is the close relationship between Lewis Armistead, who attended West Point but did not graduate, and Winfield Scott Hancock (class of 1844), who opposed each other at Gettysburg. No fewer than 20 members of the class of 1846 became Civil War general officers: 10 of them Union, 10 Confederate.

headline: Suffering in the Parched South
text: Right now, the official drought map of the United States looks as if it has been set on fire and scorched at the bottom edge. Scorched is how much of the Southeast and Southwest feel, in the midst of a drought that is the most extreme since the 1950s and possibly since the Dust Bowl of the 1930s. The government has classified much of this drought as D4, which means exceptional. The outlook through late September shows possible improvement in some places, but in most of Texas, Oklahoma, southern Arkansas, and northern Louisiana and Mississippi the drought is expected to worsen.

headline: Some Advice for a Murdoch
text: James Murdoch should stage his own tactical retreat and resign from the News Corporation. The heir apparent to his father’s media empire has lost authority.

headline: News Corp. Announces Stock Buyback as Shares Slip Again
text: The News Corporation moved on Tuesday to reverse the accelerating drop in its stock price, announcing a program to repurchase $5 billion in shares.

headline: G.O.P. Bid to Void Light Bulb Law Fails
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans on Tuesday failed to advance a measure that would repeal regulations that increase efficiency standards for light bulbs, rules that they have assailed as an example of government overreach.

headline: A San Diego Barrio’s $58 Million Moment Arrives
text: SAN DIEGO — A 20-year effort by city officials to bring a supermarket and other essential services to Barrio Logan, a working-class neighborhood south of downtown, has entered its final phase with the construction of a $58 million retail and housing development aimed at Hispanic shoppers.

headline: Art Groups Preserve Chelsea by Buying, Not Renting
text: It is an all-too-familiar pattern in many communities: artists discover an inexpensive, underdeveloped neighborhood and move in, only to be ousted from the area by soaring retail rents once it catches on in popularity.

headline: The Start-Up of You
text: The rise in the unemployment rate last month to 9.2 percent has Democrats and Republicans reliably falling back on their respective cure-alls. It is evidence for liberals that we need more stimulus and for conservatives that we need more tax cuts to increase demand. I am sure there is truth in both, but I do not believe they are the whole story. I think something else, something new — something that will require our kids not so much to find their next job as to invent their next job — is also influencing today’s job market more than people realize.

headline: A Time Clock Is Expensive, Not Exclusive
text: Ernst & Young’s Entrepreneur of the Year prize is the world’s most prestigious business award for entrepreneurs, and if you don’t believe that, just ask Ernst & Young. It operates along the lines of a beauty contest or spelling bee, with regional winners advancing to the grand finals, hosted last year by Jay Leno in Palm Springs, Calif.

headline: Banking on the Future
text: FOR decades, we have neglected the foundation of our economy while other countries have invested in state-of-the-art water, energy and transportation infrastructure. Our manufacturing base has migrated abroad; our innovation edge may soon follow. If we don’t find a way to build a sound foundation for growth, the American dream will survive only in our heads and history books.

headline: As Rebels Capture Towns, Destruction Follows
text: A human rights organization reports that a series of abuses are occurring, as rebels capture towns across Libya once under control by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Wednesday: Patron Saint of Sailors
text: Administrivial Mac OS X Lion Update Alert: Some of you have already heard that when the new Mac operating system Lion is released this Thursday (or thereabouts), those who update to it will be unable to use Across Lite to open and solve your crossword puzzles. LitSoft, the company that makes Across Lite, has released Across Lite v2.1 specifically for Mac users who run SnowLeopard (OS X 10.6) or the new Lion (OS X 10.7). On Thursday, July 14, you will be able to download the update here, and there will be a permanent link to this page in the right-hand column under “Solving Software and Apps”, as well as a link on the Premium Puzzle page in the near future.

headline: Rush to Defend Tax Rule on Inventory and Profits
text: WASHINGTON — One of the biggest revenue-raisers proposed by President Obama in negotiations with Congress is what he describes as an arcane change in the tax treatment of business inventories — things like steel, groceries and oil.

text: WASHINGTON — The Fukushima Daiichi meltdowns show that it is time for “redefining the level of protection that is regarded as adequate” at American nuclear plants, a special task force of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has concluded.

headline: Agreement on Debt Talks: Health Groups Dislike Proposals
text: WASHINGTON — Budget negotiators have not found a way to avert a government default on federal debt obligations, but with their ideas to cut Medicare and Medicaid they have managed to provoke opposition from almost every major group that represents beneficiaries and health care providers.

headline: Jaroslav Jirik, 71, Dies; 1st Eastern-Bloc Player in N.H.L.
text: Jaroslav Jirik, a Czech hockey star who played a role in his national team’s emotional victory over the Soviets in 1969 after the Soviet invasion of his homeland and who later became the first Eastern-bloc player to appear in the National Hockey League, died Monday when the small plane he was piloting crashed in the Czech Republic near Brno. He was 71.

headline: Connections to Murdoch Start to Chafe British Leader
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron is usually the nimblest of politicians, radiating self-assurance and blessed with an almost Reaganesque ability to deflect criticism. But as the phone hacking scandal spreads, Mr. Cameron has been placed in the unaccustomed position of appearing vulnerable and behind the curve.

headline: Not Ready to Change Baseball History?
text: “The Curious Case of Curt Flood,” a new HBO Sports documentary (Wednesday, 9 p.m.), raises a tantalizing question: what if Flood’s legal challenge to baseball’s reserve clause had had a better advocate before the United States Supreme Court than Arthur J. Goldberg, a former associate justice?

headline: Plenty of Action Before the Game, but No Immigration Law Protests
text: PHOENIX — The All-Star Game parade was snaking along Jefferson Street on Tuesday afternoon when a rancorous voice rang out from the crowd.

headline: Presidential Historian and Colleague Arrested in Theft of Documents in Maryland
text: WASHINGTON — A presidential historian and author, Barry H. Landau, was arrested with a colleague on Saturday in Baltimore on charges of stealing historical documents from the Maryland Historical Society, including ones signed by Abraham Lincoln.

headline: The Forgetful Mr. Smith
text: President Obama’s top immigration enforcer, John Morton, recently instructed his officials to take mitigating factors into account, like an immigrant’s family ties in the United States and education status, when deciding which deportation cases to pursue. It was not a major breakthrough, but it was sensible and humane, which is why it drew the ire of Representative Lamar Smith, who thinks Mr. Obama is too soft on illegal immigrants.

headline: Theodore Roszak, ’60s Expert, Dies at 77
text: Theodore Roszak, who three weeks after the Woodstock Festival in 1969 not only published a pivotal book about a young generation’s drug-fueled revolt against authority but also gave it a name — “counterculture” — died on July 5 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 77.

headline: Ted Danson to Star in ‘C.S.I.’
text: CBS has landed a very familiar name, Ted Danson, to lead its most familiar drama, as the network tries to keep alive the one-time top show in television, “C.S.I.”

headline: Rob Grill, Lead Singer of the Grass Roots, Dies at 67
text: Rob Grill, the longtime lead singer and a very nearly original member of the Grass Roots, the immensely popular rock group of the 1960s and afterward, died on Monday in Tavares, Fla. He was 67.

headline: Unrelenting Heat Alters Routines Across the U.S.
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — When the temperature rises to three sweltering digits, it is a sure sign of a stolen summer day: Children find little joy in the outdoors, adults recoil at the work of their sweat glands and whole communities slog forward in the hope of a cooler tomorrow.

headline: White House, in Shift, Turns Against Syria Leader
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, after weeks of urging Syria to carry out democratic reforms and end a brutal crackdown, has now turned decisively against President Bashar al-Assad, saying that he has lost legitimacy and that it has no interest in Mr. Assad keeping his grip on power.

headline: China’s Economy Slowed a Bit in the 2nd Quarter
text: The Chinese economy expanded at an annual rate of 9.5 percent during the second quarter, the National Bureau of Statistics reported on Wednesday, a figure that, for all its strength, represented a slowdown from the sizzling pace of previous quarters, and underlined the challenges now facing policy makers in Beijing.

headline: Fielder’s Blast Leads Way for N.L.
text: PHOENIX —In the second inning of the All-Star Game on Tuesday night, Jose Bautista charged into the corner down the right-field line at Chase Field. Bautista, the slugger for the Toronto Blue Jays, has probably been the best player in baseball this season, and he slid for a catch in foul territory.

headline: Witnesses Give Details of Ahmed Wali Karzai’s Last Minutes and His Killer
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Ahmed Wali Karzai was conducting business in his normal fashion on Tuesday morning, holding court as 60 to 70 people filled the rooms of his large residence that also served as his office in central Kandahar, when one of his most faithful commanders asked to speak to him alone and then shot him at point-blank range.

headline: Can Shoes Really Tone the Body?
text: New scientific experiments can be inspired by a simple question, and in the case of John Mercer, that question was, “So, John, do toning shoes work?”

headline: Britain: Assange Extradition Fight
text: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, returned to a British court on Tuesday in his fight against extradition to Sweden, where he has been accused of sexual abuse. Mr. Assange, left, nodded as his lawyers tried to persuade judges at the Royal Courts of Justice to overturn a previous decision that he return to Sweden to face the accusations, made by two women in Stockholm last year. Ben Emmerson, one of Mr. Assange’s lawyers, said that his client’s behavior in Sweden might have been “disreputable, discourteous, disturbing,” but that it did not constitute a crime under British law, rendering any Swedish arrest warrant invalid. The hearing will continue Wednesday.

headline: Savings in Mind, Mets Deal Rodriguez to Brewers
text: From the day he was hired last October until his most recent meeting with reporters on Sunday, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson was asked what he would do about Francisco Rodriguez and his prohibitive vesting option for 2012.

headline: Friends and Family Remember Sanderson
text: Donald Sanderson’s death in an amateur hockey game has revived a debate over what role fighting should play in hockey.

headline: News Quiz | July 13, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Japan: Jump in Heatstroke Deaths
text: Heatstroke deaths quadrupled this spring and summer as many Japanese switched off their air-conditioners in response to government appeals to curb electricity use. Twenty-six peopled died of heatstroke from June 1 to July 10, the government said, and almost 13,000 were taken to hospitals for treatment. Japan has shut down 35 of its 54 nuclear reactors since the March earthquake and tsunami, reducing national power capacity by 11 percent.

headline: Japan’s Women Have Come Farther Than Most
text: Nadeshiko Japan! A word unknown to the soccer world outside of Japan, Nadeshiko is the name used for the Japanese women’s national team. It means beautiful flower.

text: NATIONAL

headline: Test Yourself | Math, July 13, 2011
