headline: Janice Hahn Keeps California House Seat for Democrats
text: LOS ANGELES — Janice Hahn survived a costly battle to hold onto a congressional seat for Democrats here, defeating a Republican businessman, Craig Huey.

headline: China’s Economy Slowed a Bit in the 2nd Quarter
text: HONG KONG -- The Chinese economy expanded at an unexpectedly robust pace during the second quarter of this year, data released Wednesday showed, but a slowdown from the sizzling pace of previous quarters also underlined the challenges that now face policy makers in Beijing.

headline: Photographing the Mystery of Healing
text: When Vance Gellert studied pharmacology in the early ’70s, he found that a scientific method of systematic observation, precise measurement and disciplined testing could explain the efficacy of most treatments. For that matter, it was a satisfying way of explaining much of the world around him.

headline: How Kevin McCarthy Wrangles the Tea Party in Washington
text: Most mornings when he is in Washington, the House majority whip, Kevin McCarthy, wakes up at 6 a.m. on his office sofa — which is a slight improvement over the air mattress he once slept on, and probably better than the houseboat that a fellow Republican congressman, Lynn Westmoreland, has half-jokingly tried to convince him to share. McCarthy pulls on some ratty gym clothes, descends three flights of stairs and exits the building, where, when the weather is agreeable, he meets up with about a half-dozen other G.O.P. members on their mountain bikes. Together they cruise along the Mall, past the Lincoln Memorial, across a bridge and along the Potomac River. An hour later, McCarthy will shower in the House gym, head off to breakfast with some other gaggle of Republicans, attend the morning management meeting with Speaker John Boehner and Eric Cantor, the majority leader, huddle throughout the day with his whip staff and committee chairmen and conservative advocacy groups and random needy or disgruntled members until it’s finally evening and time to round up a bunch of other Republican colleagues for a dinner that can go on for several hours because McCarthy takes it upon himself to draw the others out from their professional shells with questions like, “What’s the most embarrassing thing that happened to you at college?” or “What was the first concert you went to?” By 11 at night, he is back on his office couch with his BlackBerry and the next day’s briefings, some 2,300 miles from his wife and son and daughter in Bakersfield, Calif. — and then asleep, in a federal building, by 1 a.m.

headline: Hope Solo’s Big Save
text: Hope Solo was at the center of the United States comeback in the team’s win over Brazil in the quarterfinals, but that was nothing compared with her own personal and professional turnaround in the past four years. Solo was the Americans’ goalkeeper at the start of the last World Cup, too, but was benched by her coach and then banished by her teammates for what was seen as the unforgivable sin of criticizing the player who replaced her for the semifinal match. Now, it seems, all is right in her world again. Read Jeré Longman’s article here, and come back to comment.

headline: In Paris, Classical Music at a Holy Site
text: From March through December, the beautiful and intimate Ste. Chapelle plays host to a series of concerts. Hidden behind the walls of the Palace of Justice, in the Ile de la Cité, the historical heart of Paris, the spot (8, Boulevard du Palais, 33-104-407-1238) makes a magical site for glorious music.

headline: Where a Minimum-Wage Increase Would Bite
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Greg Cosell, Unheralded Maestro of N.F.L. ‘Matchup’
text: It’s a February afternoon in Indianapolis. The former Auburn quarterback and Heisman winner Cam Newton is under his first N.F.L. microscope. On live national television, in front of some 200 reporters at Podium C in the N.F.L. scouting combine media center, Newton is fielding (fending off) rapid-fire questions about expectations for the N.F.L., his character, his level of “football focus,” his baggage.

headline: Europe Tries to Curb U.S. Role in Tracking Terrorists’ Funds
text: BRUSSELS — The European Commission on Wednesday presented proposals for tracking the finances of terrorists in Europe that are aimed at ending the primary role of the United States in those efforts.

headline: A Mormon Spectacle, Way Off Broadway
text: MANCHESTER, N.Y. — With its cast of 700, 1,300 costumes, 10-level stage and thrill-a-minute special effects of earthquakes, floods, fireballs, airborne deities and burnings at the stake, the annual Hill Cumorah Pageant, one could argue, has more in common with the spectacle of “Spider-Man” than with the merry snark of “The Book of Mormon.”

headline: Obama Campaign Reports Big Fund-Raising Quarter
text: President Obama raised more than $86 million for his re-election campaign and the Democratic National Committee in the last three months, besting  previous campaign fund-raising records for the quarter and far outpacing the Republicans who are hoping to replace him in the White House.

headline: The Early Word: Pessimism
text: Today’s Times

headline: A Bit of Scotland by the Sea in England
text: SANDWICH, ENGLAND — The first challenge is to procure the keys. The next is to fit through a doorway designed for the shorter men of the 12th century. All that remains is to climb a tight, winding stone staircase and then a wooden ladder that leads to a final door and, at last, like Dr. William Laidlaw Purves more than a century ago, you are atop the Norman bell tower at St. Clement’s Church, squinting in the direction of the beach in search of prime golfing land.

headline: Updates on British Phone-Hacking Scandal
text: On Wednesday, The Lede is following developments in the phone-hacking scandal in Britain.

headline: Doing the Math on Employer Health Insurance
text: Our post last month on the McKinsey & Company study that suggested — but absolutely did not predict — that up to 30 percent of employers would shed the health insurance plans they now provide workers in 2014, when the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act largely takes effect, drew some readers into an interesting discussion. After one reader wondered what prevents those companies from dropping health insurance now, another, adam of Washington, wrote a thoughtful response that is worth reprinting at length. The premium calculator he describes was developed by the Kaiser Family Foundation and allows users to enter demographic data and generate an estimate for how much insurance will cost when purchased on the exchanges created by the health care overhaul. Here’s what adam wrote:

headline: Al Gore’s Reality Show
text: Al Gore, the former vice president, Nobel Prize winner and climate campaigner-in-chief, is opening a new global climate change activism program called the Climate Reality Project.

headline: Apax Leads $6.3 Billion Buyout of Kinetic Concepts
text: 8:28 p.m. | Updated

headline: City Opera’s Troubled Vision Quest
text: At this point the troubles of the New York City Opera are more and more confounding. During the news conference on Tuesday at the Guggenheim Museum, George Steel, the company’s embattled general manager and artistic director, tried to exude a positive vibe about City Opera’s intention to leave Lincoln Center and take productions to various locales around the city, from Brooklyn to East Harlem to Central Park. The company’s stage will be New York City itself, he said, a “theater with eight million seats.”

headline: Victim’s Family Appears Amid Rage at Tabloids
text: LONDON — On the day when Rupert Murdoch retreated from the biggest media takeover bid in Britain’s history, the wider significance that many here see for the way that power in the country is wielded found its most poignant expression in the sight of an ordinary family standing silently, subdued but assuaged at last, at the door of 10 Downing Street.

headline: Parties Can’t Agree on the Consequences of Default
text: The fact that politicians in Washington can’t agree on how to raise the debt ceiling is hardly surprising. The fact that they can’t agree on what happens if they don’t may be more significant.

headline: Big in Berlin
text: It’s not as though anyone in Berlin really needed proof, last week, that the city’s once-hip central Mitte neighborhood had officially jumped the shark — two years’ worth of boutique hotel and Mavi-store openings, plus skyrocketing rents and a mass exodus of the gallery scene, had all been fairly obvious clues. But as the local fashion crowd milled around on Wednesday night outside the opening of Andreas Murkudis’s sprawling concept shop, newly and thrillingly relocated to a remote stretch of Potsdamer Strasse once ruled by drug dealers and prostitutes, there seemed to be only one sentiment on everybody’s lips: Goodbye, and good riddance. Murkudis may have helped pioneer the Mitte retail scene when he began selling Margiela and Yohji from three minimalist storefronts inside a courtyard off Münzstrasse in the early 2000s, but with a few notable exceptions — the recently opened Gestalten bookshop, the Kunstwerke contemporary art museum — it’s no longer the place that in-the-know young people go to hang out and discover things. It’s the place they go when they need something from American Apparel.

headline: In South Korean Sports, a Culture of Corruption
text: SEOUL — On the day South Koreans rejoiced over the selection of Pyeongchang as the host city of the 2018 Winter Olympics, prosecutors continued to peel back layers of a long-hushed dirty secret of the nation’s sports landscape.

headline: Japan Premier Wants Shift Away From Nuclear Power
text: TOKYO — Prime Minister Naoto Kan said Wednesday that Japan should reduce and eventually eliminate its dependence on nuclear energy in what would be a radical shift in the country’s energy policy, saying that the Fukushima accident had demonstrated the dangers of the technology.

headline: The Few, The Proud, The Non-Hysteric
text: Martin Wolf:

headline: Live Blog: Lobbyists Meeting on Financial Overhaul
text: The Dodd-Frank financial regulatory overhaul will turn a year old next week. In honor of its birthday, bankers, regulators and journalists are gathering in New York on Wednesday to discuss some of the law’s thorniest provisions — derivatives, the new consumer protection agency and, of course, its efforts to end “too big to fail.”

headline: This Morning In Peevishness
text: William Galston writes, “What if the Right and the Left Are Both Wrong About Why the Economic Recovery Is So Slow? A New Theory.” And the new theory is that it’s all about household balance sheets.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Tiny Trash Cans Can Boost Recycling
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Syria Calls Pipeline Explosion an Accident
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian officials blamed a technical problem for an explosion that damaged a natural gas pipeline near Deir al-Zour, a restive region in eastern Syria near the Iraqi border.

headline: Missing Boy’s Dismembered Body Found; Suspect Says He Panicked
text: Updated, 12:35 p.m. | The search for a missing 8-year-old Brooklyn boy ended early on Wednesday when investigators discovered what they believed to be his dismembered remains in an attic refrigerator of a Brooklyn man and in a trash bin on a street, the police said. The man, who made incriminating statements, was being questioned and was expected to be charged, the police said.

headline: Let’s Ban Books, Or at Least Stop Writing Them
text: There was exciting news last month among the Twitterati. Brian Stelter, The New York Times prodigy and master of social media, announced to his 64,373 followers that he is going to write a book. The obvious question: What’s up with that?

headline: Face Time | Maureen Kelly, Tarte Cosmetics
text: Tina Turnbow is a professional makeup artist, who is known for lending her celebrity clients editorial polish.

headline: Not Always a ‘Bridesmaid,’ Kristen Wiig Plans a Follow-Up Film
text: When your screenwriting debut is viewed as a a bellwether for the viability of female-oriented comedies and becomes one of the biggest successes of the season, it’s safe to say the film industry won’t let you stay idle for very long. So it goes for Kristen Wiig, the star and co-writer of “Bridesmaids,” the $150 million hit, who could be spending her summer unwinding to the music of Wilson Phillips and chowing down on cheap Brazilian food but is instead moving on to her next project.

headline: Just a Quick Bite With Leonardo
text: MILAN — The setting can seem a lot like quarantine. The entrance, through several holding pens and sets of automatic doors, leads to an enormous, vaulted, semiprivate room, the patient stretched out to the right. A bedside crowd coos appropriately.

headline: Times Company to Repay Carlos Slim Early
text: 9:54 a.m. | Updated The New York Times Company said Wednesday that it would pay back the $250 million loan from Carlos Slim Helú, a Mexican telecommunications billionaire, on Aug. 15, freeing itself from one of its larger financial obligations.

headline: In California, a Not-So-Special Performance for Democrats
text: The Democratic candidate, Janice Hahn, won last night’s special election in California’s 36th Congressional District, an ethnically diverse but generally well-off district in along the Santa Monica Bay in Los Angeles. She will succeed a Democrat, Jane Harman, who retired in February to become head of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars.

headline: News Corp. Drops Bid for BSkyB
text: The News Corporation has withdrawn its $12 billion bid for the majority of British Sky Broadcasting, the satellite broadcaster, as the firestorm continued in Britain over a phone-hacking scandal.

headline: ‘I Am Not a Statistic': The Invisibility of the Unemployed
text: I’ve received a lot of interesting e-mail in response to my article over the weekend about how the unemployed became invisible. But one from an unemployed woman named Tina Friedman was particularly striking. She talked about how, paradoxically, hearing about the huge numbers of unemployed workers may desensitize people to the jobs crisis.

headline: Texting With a Deadly Object
text: Overshadowed by the agonized debate over same-sex marriage was a bill passed by the State Legislature late last month to get tougher with drivers who use electronic devices while they’re at the wheel. These are the geniuses who think that they can take their eyes off the road for a few seconds to thumb-type on a small keyboard while doing 65, and not become a threat to themselves and everyone in their path.

headline: 3 Bombs Hit Crowded Sites in Mumbai
text: MUMBAI, India — Three explosions ripped through Mumbai at the height of the evening rush on Wednesday, killing at least 17 people in what Indian officials called a coordinated terrorist attack on the country’s economic capital.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Bernanke Says Fed Would Consider New Stimulus
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, gave a subdued account of the economy’s health Wednesday and said that the Fed was prepared to expand its economic aid campaign once again, if necessary, though such a step was not imminent.

headline: Game of Fathers and Sons Is Complicated for Fielder
text: PHOENIX — Prince Fielder walked into the interview room at Chase Field late Tuesday night behind his two young sons, Jadyn and Haven. They had watched their father hit a three-run homer to power the National League to a 5-1 victory over the American League in the 82nd All-Star Game and now they were going to sit beside him at the news conference as he discussed being named the game’s most valuable player.

headline: Excerpt: 'Rescue Me'
text: Denis Leary's firefighter drama returns for its final season.

headline: Budget Excursions for Volunteers
text: A DELUXE room at the luxurious Snake River Lodge & Spa in Jackson, Wyo., typically goes for $385 a night, but it can be reserved for as low as $192 this fall. The catch: In order to qualify for the discount, travelers must agree to spend a portion of their vacation taking down barbed wire fences so local wildlife can roam more freely.

headline: Deutsche Börse Gaining as Deal Deadline Nears
text: 7:32 p.m. | Updated

headline: Ben Sisario on a new piracy crackdown; the state of hacking; news.
text: Bettina Edelstein speaks to Times culture reporter Ben Sisario about why the music and movie industries are joining forces with big Internet service providers to crack down on copyright infringement. And Trend Micro's David Perry is back to chat with J.D. Biersdorfer, this time about the state of hacking and the shadowy groups involved in recent exploits. The news roundup includes a Google-iRiver e-book reader; an HTC smartphone with a direct line to Facebook; imported tech components preloaded with malware; another big hack from Anonymous; the Windows XP 1,000-day countdown; and a study on Americans and their smartphones. J.D.'s tip of the week: using the backup program in your operating system.

headline: World Cup Semifinals: United States 3, France 1
text: Live coverage and analysis of the United States’ semifinal game against France in the Women’s World Cup in Mönchengladbach, Germany. The Americans are coming off one of the most dramatic victories in U.S. Soccer history, their penalty-kick win over Brazil in the quarterfinals. The French also advanced on penalty kicks, beating England. Check back frequently for updates.

headline: Oprah to Take Top Post at Her Network
text: Oprah Winfrey stood before cable company executives at an industry conference last month and admitted that the beginning of OWN, her cable channel, was not going well, in part because she had been too focused on the end of her daytime talk show.

headline: Rocking With Wizards
text: A look inside the wizard rock circuit; a group of rock bands inspired by Harry Potter.

headline: Danielle Chiesi Settles S.E.C. Action
text: Danielle Chiesi, the hedge fund trader who pleaded guilty this year to charges of insider trading, agreed to pay $540,535 to settle a related civil action brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Her payment includes $500,000 of improper gains and $40,535 of interest. Ms. Chiesi, a central figure in the prosecution of Raj Rajaratnam, is scheduled to be sentenced in Federal District Court in Manhattan on July 20. Read more »

headline: Reaction to the Leiby Kletzky Killing
text: Interviews with neighbors of the Kletzky family after the discovery of what is believed to be the body of their missing son.

headline: Carrefour’s Brazilian Deal Founders
text: The deal that was set to shake up the French and Brazilian supermarket sectors has effectively collapsed.

headline: Damaged Synagogue Is an Architectural Milestone Too
text: The fire that roared through Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun on Monday night not only upended an important religious body but also badly damaged a milestone in the development of synagogue architecture. The restrained neo-Classical design speaks of a turning point in the early 1900s when Jews no longer felt bound to incorporate Moorish elements in their places of worship as a way of distinguishing them from Christian churches.

headline: Whither the Government Sedan?
text: With about 600,000 federal cars and trucks under his watch, President Obama wants the government fleet to “lead by example” by adopting hybrid, electric or other advanced powertrain technologies in coming years. On Tuesday, Mayor Bloomberg unveiled an N.Y.P.D. cruiser based on the Chevrolet Volt, part of a 70-unit order of plug-in hybrids and electric vehicles for New York.

headline: The Tiger Mom’s Other Child
text: There are the cartoonish headline tales of Tiger Moms and their obedient, violin-playing daughters and dutiful, Intel STS-prize-winning sons. And then there are the often more complicated lives of real Asian-American sons and daughters, recently explored by Wesley Yang in his much commented-on article “Paper Tigers” in New York magazine.

headline: Harry Potter Sang Bass, Hermione Sang Tenor
text: The world of Harry Potter stretches far beyond the lines of admirers waiting for hours outside bookstores for the latest entry in theJ. K. Rowling series or to see the most recent installment in the multibillion-dollar movie franchise, the final chapter of which opens Friday.

headline: Freed Chinese Artist Accepts Job in Berlin
text: BEIJING — Ai Weiwei, the Chinese artist and recently imprisoned dissident, said Wednesday that he had agreed to become a visiting lecturer at the Berlin University of the Arts in 2012, but that he did not know whether China’s government would allow him to leave the country to work there.

headline: Jeter’s Milestone Hit Is Producing a Run on Merchandise
text: Since Saturday, $2.5 million to $3 million of products related to Derek Jeter’s 3,000th hit have been sold by Steiner Sports, which has partnerships with Jeter and the Yankees.

headline: All Milwaukee
text: The All-Star Game happened a long way from Wisconsin, but for a game held in Phoenix, Milwaukee had a pretty good night. Prince Fielder put on a show, turned fans who spent most of the festivities booing him into his personal fan club, and then everyone found out that the Brewers had traded for Mets closer Francisco Rodriguez.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 5 French Soldiers in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber killed five French soldiers guarding a meeting between NATO officers and Afghan tribal elders on Wednesday morning northeast of the capital, one of the bloodiest days for French troops in Afghanistan.

headline: Two Words to Live By
text: Not long ago I suggested that frail, elderly patients write “Do Less” across their foreheads with a Sharpie, but I’m rethinking that. Two other words might serve better: “comfort” and “function.”

headline: Death Becomes a Soaring Tenor
text: “I WAS looking for Cary Grant with high notes,” the director Doug Hughes said, describing the job requirements for the role of the not-so-Grim Reaper in his Roundabout Theater Company production of “Death Takes a Holiday.” “A gift for light comedy, a gift for sincerity — gifts that don’t often coexist — and a great singer. It’s a combination of elements you might have in a studio star of the ’30s, ’40s or ’50s.”

headline: Beyoncé Holds On to No. 1 With ‘4’
text: Beyoncé holds the top spot on the Billboard album chart this week, with her “4” (Columbia) selling 115,000 copies in its second week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan. That is a 63 percent drop from last week, but still a healthy lead over Adele’s “21” (XL/Columbia), which remains at No. 2 with 79,000 sales.

headline: Look of the Moment | Hilary Rhoda
text: The Look: Tightly edited — a cropped pantsuit paired with minimally embellished sandals is a crisp take on summer casual.

headline: London Theater Journal: Surprised by ‘Betrayal’
text: LONDON — This woman doesn’t know what to do with her face. That’s the impression given by Kristin Scott Thomas in the first scene of Ian Rickson’s terrific new production of Harold Pinter’s “Betrayal,” which I saw Tuesday night at the Comedy Theater. Ms. Scott Thomas’s impeccably chiseled features — a glamorous alabaster mask in films like “The English Patient” — appear almost to be melting here, involuntarily rearranging themselves as she tries to settle on a single, composed expression.

headline: Nearly 250,000 Ram Pickups Recalled for Steering Flaw
text: Chrysler is recalling almost 243,000 of its Ram pickup trucks because there could be a “loss of directional stability,” the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: After BSkyB Deal’s Collapse, What’s Next for News Corp.?
text: The News Corporation‘s investors appear to be breathing a sigh of relief now that the media conglomerate has withdrawn its troubled $12 billion bid for British Sky Broadcasting. Shares in the company were up more than 6 percent as of early Wednesday afternoon, to $16.31.

headline: Irish Report Finds Abuse Persisting in Catholic Church
text: DUBLIN — The Roman Catholic Church in Ireland was covering up the sexual abuse of children by priests as recently as 2009, long after it issued guidelines meant to protect children, and the Vatican tacitly encouraged the cover-up by ignoring the guidelines, according to a scathing report issued Wednesday by the Irish government.

headline: Clip: 'Sarah's Key'
text: A scene from "Sarah's Key," starring Kristin Scott Thomas as a writer investigating a dark moment in French history.

headline: Losing Three Children, Starting Again
text: Nearly two years ago, Diane Schuler drove the wrong way on the Taconic Parkway in New York and crashed her minivan into an oncoming S.U.V. Eight people were killed, including Ms. Schuler, her 2-year-old daughter, Erin, and her three nieces, Emma, 8; Alyson, 7; and Katie, 5.

headline: The Obama Doctrine Revisited, Again!
text: The Obama-doctrine debate is back! Daniel Drezner — foreignpolicy.com blogger, Tufts professor and author of “Theories of International Politics and Zombies” — brought it back from the dead last week in Foreign Affairs. Fareed Zakaria, in his regular column, tried to put a stake in its heart. But these doctrinal debates are hard to kill.

headline: TimesCast | July 13, 2011
text: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain details a wide-reaching public inquiry into the phone-hacking scandal, and News Corporation drops its bid for BSkyB.

headline: Champagnes With a Sense of Where They Are
text: If you ask most people where their last bottle of Champagne came from, they would most likely look puzzled. “The store?’’ they might say falteringly, or “France?”

headline: The Latest in Credit Card Scams
text: Updated to add comment from a lawyer for BBG Communications./4.05 p.m

headline: Evernote Raises $50 Million for Acquisitions
text: Evernote, the note-taking service that gives users an auxiliary brain, announced Wednesday that it had raised $50 million in financing. The company said in a news release that it planned to use the funds to aggressively expand its operations and to acquire other companies that will help the service grow even more quickly.

headline: TimesCast | Phone Hacking Inquiry Opens
text: July 13, 2011 - Speaking in Parliament amid growing criticism over his ties to News Corp., Britain's Prime Minister, David Cameron, detailed a wide-reaching public inquiry into the hacking scandal.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: Live From Manchester
text: Back in 2009, Hans-Ulrich Obrist, the co-director of London’s Serpentine Gallery, described the burgeoning Manchester International Festival (MIF) as a tribute to the British architect Cedric Price, who, in the 1960s had an idea to build a flexible, interdisciplinary arts space in East London. Price’s “Fun Palace,” as he called it, was never realized, but its spirit thrives in this biannual 18-day festival, now in its third incarnation. This year, Alex Poots, the festival’s director, has come up with another stellar lineup of music, theater and visual arts events to match the city’s reputation as both a creative incubator and provocateur.

headline: Red Bulls Sign Rost, Veteran German Goalkeeper
text: Going against the conventional wisdom in Major League Soccer that asserts paying big money for a goalkeeper rarely makes sense, the Red Bulls on Wednesday used their third slot for a designated player to sign Frank Rost, 38, whose contract with Hamburg of the German Bundesliga had expired.

headline: Unearthing Exotic Provisions Buried in Dodd-Frank
text: At a meeting in February to discuss the recent overhaul of financial regulations, lobbyists and policy makers never once mentioned Wall Street. They did not talk about derivatives, mortgage-backed securities or any of the exotic products at the center of the crisis.

headline: Wait ‘Til 2013
text: Rich Lowry on the debt ceiling negotiations and the next election:

headline: Advice for Jeter From One Who’s Been There
text: History sublimely addressed, a threshold spectacularly crossed, Derek Jeter now resumes the indeterminate life of an aging shortstop. Yes, 3,000 hits are indelibly carved as a franchise first, but the resulting glow is bound to fade like perspiration stains on his pinstriped jersey.

headline: Pothole That Nearly Claimed Al D’Amato Has Been Filled
text: Senator Pothole’s pothole has been fixed.

headline: Can Mets Fans Handle a Fire Sale?
text: The Mets’ trade of closer Francisco Rodriguez took people by surprise only because Sandy Alderson’s announcement came just after midnight Tuesday.

headline: Youth-Culture Photographer Ryan McGinley Sued for Copyright Violation
text: The 33-year-old photographer Ryan McGinley has forged a substantial reputation over the last several years with work that presents a lush vision of youth culture, though one he choreographs and largely creates himself — lithe, naked bodies cavorting in the woods or on sandhills or deep inside caves.

headline: On Location | An Icelandic Home Near the Arctic Circle
text: A three-bedroom modern house set on nearly 1,000 acres between snow-capped peaks and the misty waters of a nearby fjord.

headline: In Iceland, a Home that Pays Homage to the Motherland
text: HOFSOS, Iceland — Even in Reykjavik, the cosmopolitan capital of Iceland, there’s no escape from the elements. Beyond sleek towers overlooking the harbor is the hint of mountains, their outlines hazy in the glow of the midnight sun. On the clearest July day, glaciers float on the horizon.

headline: Frenchman Still in Yellow, at Least for Bastille Day
text: LAVAUR, France — Thomas Voeckler, a French rider in the Tour de France, does not wear the yellow jersey often. But when he does, he knows how to please the home fans.

headline: Democrats Criticize Republicans on Crisis Commission
text: Washington was all prepared for a hearing on Wednesday on “What Went Wrong” with the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, which was set up in 2009 to look into the causes of the meltdown.

headline: ‘America’s Got Talent’ Bests America’s Pastime
text: Broadcast at the same time as Major League Baseball’s All-Star Game on Fox, “America’s Got Talent” still managed to deliver Tuesday night’s most viewers, as 13.8 million tuned in to the show’s latest two-hour installment, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Karzai Buries a Brother, and Quickly Appoints Another as Successor
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai wept as he buried his half brother in the family graveyard just south of the city of Kandahar on Wednesday morning, but he moved swiftly to nominate another brother in his place within an hour to reinforce family and political pre-eminence in Kandahar, his ancestral home.

headline: Murdoch's Political Triage
text: Dealbook's Andrew Ross Sorkin and media editor Bruce Headlam discuss News Corporation's announcement it is withdrawing a $12 billion bid for Britain's main satellite television broadcaster.

headline: The Caucus | Third Debt Option Emerges
text: July 13, 2011 - Michael Shear on public and private pronouncements on debt negotiations; Nicholas Confessore on President Obama's fund-raising haul.

headline: Murdoch’s Political Triage
text: By dropping efforts to acquire outstanding shares of the British Sky Broadcasting Group, Rupert Murdoch is trying to quell the political uproar that threatens his empire. DealBook’s Andrew Ross Sorkin and The New York Times’s media editor, Bruce Headlam, discuss News Corporation’s announcement that it is withdrawing its $12 billion bid for Britain’s main satellite television broadcaster.

headline: European Union Proposes Overhaul of Fisheries Policy
text: PARIS — The European Union on Wednesday proposed a major overhaul of its fisheries policy, including the creation of a market in fishing rights.

headline: Photo Replay: July 13
text: The day in sports, with the Women’s World Cup in Germany and the start of Kobe Bryant’s five-city summer tour in the Philippines.

headline: Congressmen Call for U.S. Investigation of News Corporation
text: Two members of Congress are calling for government inquiries in the United States into the conduct of Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, which is enmeshed in a deepening hacking scandal in Britain.

headline: Video: Latest on the Debt Negotiations; The President’s Campaign Cash
text: Michael D. Shear on public and private pronouncements as debt negotiations continue. Also, Nicholas Confessore reports on President Obama’s fund-raising haul: $86 million.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from India, Afghanistan and Spain.

headline: George Harrison Documentary, Directed By Martin Scorsese, to Make Its Debut on HBO
text: Though he was known as the quiet Beatle, George Harrison had enough to say – and his friends and family had enough to say about his life and music – to fill a two-part documentary directed by Martin Scorsese that will make its debut on HBO in the fall.

headline: A Parent’s Waking Nightmare
text: I should write something about poor Leiby Kletzky, the 8-year-old boy whose dismembered body was found in a Brooklyn freezer this morning. He had disappeared on Monday after apparently getting lost the very first time his parents let him walk home alone from school.

headline: Extra Boost Lifts the U.S.
text: MÖNCHENGLADBACH, Germany — She had been a starter on the left wing until the Women’s World Cup opened. And then Megan Rapinoe was sent to the bench. No one could be happy with such a demotion.

headline: What Obama’s Numbers Don’t Tell Us
text: There are two things we know for sure about the $47 million President Obama raised in the last three months for his re-election campaign: It’s a lot of money, and it’s far more than any of his potential Republican opponents have raised.

headline: In Berlin, Rocking the Fashion Trade Fair
text: BERLIN

headline: Northern Ireland Courses Still a Long Shot for British Open
text: SANDWICH, England — No matter how bright Rory McIlroy’s present and future might be, the British Open will not be heading to Northern Ireland anytime soon.

headline: Tensions Escalate as Stakes Grow in Fiscal Clash
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, warned on Wednesday of a “huge financial calamity” if President Obama and the Republicans cannot agree on a budget deal that allows the federal debt ceiling to be increased. Moody’s, the ratings agency, threatened a credit downgrade, citing a “rising possibility” that no deal would be reached before the government’s borrowing authority hits its limit on Aug. 2.

headline: Rag & Bone’s Urban Art Project
text: If you’ve been in Soho this past week, you may have noticed the monster-size rooster applied to the side of Rag & Bone’s Houston Street store (73 East Houston Street). Curious? So were we. Turns out the designers Marcus Wainwright and David Neville have invited visiting artists to tag their building’s wall as part of a continuing project. (Brooklyn’s ballpoint-pen extraordinaire Nicholas Forker started the series in May with an installation called “Action Man.”) What’s up now is a piece by the graffiti street artist Gaia. Here, a video of the three-day installation reveals him applying a wheat-paste backdrop of Peter Bruegel’s “The Triumph of Death,” then painting the rooster on top. As in many of Gaia’s neighborhood paintings, in which animals recur as protectors of the streets, this rooster is just looking out. Not that anyone is calling New Yorkers chicken.

headline: Egypt Purges Mubarak-Era Police Officers
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s transitional military government announced the early retirement of more than 600 senior police officers on Wednesday. It was an effort to mollify thousands of protesters at a six-day-old protest in Cairo’s Tahrir Square who have been demanding swifter justice for those complicit in wrongdoing under President Hosni Mubarak, who was ousted in February.

headline: As Immigration Audits Increase, Some Employers Pay a High Price
text: David Cox was at his desk in September 2009, when his receptionist announced an unexpected visitor, a special agent from Immigration and Customs Enforcement, also known as ICE. Mr. Cox is chief executive of L. E. Cooke Company, a fourth-generation, family-owned nursery in Visalia, Calif., that grows deciduous trees and shrubs. The agent handed Mr. Cox a letter and informed him he had three days to produce I-9 employment-eligibility forms for all current employees. Mr. Cox said the agent was “pleasant and nonthreatening,” but he noticed she carried a gun.

headline: Car2go, Daimler-Backed Sharing Program, to Go Electric in San Diego
text: San Diego will soon be home to an all-electric, one-way car sharing service from Car2go, the Daimler subsidiary. The first of its kind in the United States, the program would allow members to rent the Smart Fortwo Electric Drive by the minute in a city that is becoming a focal point for E.V. launches.

headline: What If You Suspect an Employee is Undocumented?
text: We’ve just published an article by Adriana Gardella that describes the impact of stepped-up enforcement by Immigration and Customs Enforcement, also known as ICE, on American small businesses. It cites the example of David Cox, who runs a family-owned nursery in Visalia, Calif., that was one of 1,444 businesses audited by ICE in 2009. Last year, 2,196 businesses were audited.

headline: Turkish Police Say 15 Suspects Plotted Attacks
text: ISTANBUL, Turkey — The police have detained 15 suspected Al Qaeda militants on evidence that they had plotted to attack foreign diplomatic targets including the United States Embassy in Ankara, Turkey, the Anatolian News Agency reported on Wednesday.

headline: Will Anything Be Done About Falling Fans?
text: Following the death of the Texas firefighter Shannon Stone at a Rangers game last week and the potentially tragic near spill of another fan at the Home Run Derby at Phoenix’s Chase Field, there is no indication that Major League Baseball will order up a full-scale review of ballpark safety.

headline: An Appraisal:  Sherwood Schwartz’s Modern Families
text: Sherwood Schwartz passed away Tuesday at the ripe old age of 94. Sherwood Schwartz might be one of those names that you recognize, but you can’t remember from where. He created two of the most beloved sitcoms of the 1960s and 70s – “Gilligan’s Island” and “The Brady Bunch.” You may write these off as shlock, just like the critics did, but I’m sure you can recite the theme songs – both written by Schwartz, himself. He always said, “Tell them everything they need to know in the theme song.”

headline: The Fictions of Asylum Seekers — in Fiction
text: The case of Dominique Strauss-Kahn and the hotel housekeeper has thrown a spotlight on the fictions of asylum seekers, with the revelation that the West African woman who accused Strauss-Kahn of sexual assault fabricated details of her asylum application to the United States.

headline: Patient Plan Behind Tender Offer for Temple-Inland
text: International Paper’s $3.3 billion offer for Temple-Inland should be termed a “patient hostile.” The company has officially begun a tender offer for Temple-Inland’s outstanding shares. But this is a mere placeholder, and International Paper is settling in for what could be a long fight.

headline: Anxiety Hovers Over Iraqi Commandos
text: BAGHDAD — A photographer and I recently embedded with an Army Special Forces unit that operates from a corner of Camp Victory, the United States military’s vast complex near the airport. Such embeds are extremely rare and this one took many months to secure — while the regular Army welcomes reporters with nearly unimpeded access, the Special Forces are leery of journalists. This was underscored by the long list of ground rules they require reporters to adhere to in order to protect operational secrecy.

headline: Mercedes Hopes a Good Walk Brings Spoils
text: FRANKFURT

headline: A Mountainside Homestead
text: A three-bedroom Cape Dutch style homestead near Cape Town is on the market for $1.4 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Cape Town
text: A CAPE DUTCH STYLE HOMESTEAD NEAR CAPE TOWN, SOUTH AFRICA

headline: Viewers Choose ‘Talent’ Over Big League Bats
text: 4:34 p.m. | Updated Americans, it seems, like talented people who can jump over beds of nails and ride motorcycles in cages more than they like the best sluggers and pitchers in baseball.

headline: When It’s O.K. to Skip a Loan Payment
text: It’s generally a bad idea to skip mortgage and other loan payments. Late payments damage your credit score and add late fees to your monthly total.

headline: When a Sex Offender Isn’t
text: Boy meets girl. Boy and girl fall in love. After dating for a year, they have sex, and the girl’s mother thinks they are moving too quickly. The girl’s mother calls the police, hoping they will scare boy and girl a little. Instead, he is arrested and put on the Texas sex-offender list, since he is 19 and she is 16, which is a year shy of the state’s age of consent. Boy avoids jail, is put on probation, and is forced to move out of his home because the law says he can’t live in the same house as his 12-year-old sister. Eventually, boy and girl marry, have four daughters and, 15 years later, he is still a registered sex offender who is not allowed to coach his children’s soccer teams, get a job at a major corporation or leave the state without registering with law enforcement.

headline: Scouting Report
text: LIMITED EDITIONS

headline: Shopping Snapshots for July 14
text: Marchesa’s jewelry collection channels the look of Miriam Haskell, the Olsen twins create a chic minimalist line of handbags and more.

headline: People-Powered
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#320", 592, 420, true, chameleonData);

headline: Assemblyman Hikind on Kletzky Killing
text: Assemblyman Dov Hikind speaks about the death of Leiby Kletzky and the fact that the suspect is from the Jewish community.

headline: European Leaders Delay Summit Meeting Over Greece
text: BRUSSELS — European leaders on Wednesday delayed a proposed summit meeting in an effort to bridge crucial differences over the role of private investors in a second Greek bailout.

headline: On Electric Cars, City Hopes to Lead by Examples
text: It may have been the only auto showroom in city history to feature shirtless roller skaters, tip-seeking jugglers and an on-site churro vendor.

headline: Counting Down to the Primetime Emmy Nominations
text: You’ve watched the shows, admired the actors, writers and producers, posted your reactions on Twitter and Facebook, read the recaps and commented on the criticism. But none of it matters until the television industry decides the best work of the 2010-2011 season, the only way it knows how: by handing out awards.

headline: Despite Benefit Disparities, Middle Class Supports Mortgage Deduction
text: A couple of weeks ago, David Streitfeld and Megan Thee-Brenan of The New York Times reported on the results of a Times/CBS News poll on homeownership in the United States. The poll found continued support for government subsidies for homeownership, including the mortgage interest deduction. Noting broad, bipartisan support for the deduction, Mr. Streitfeld and Ms. Thee-Brenan acknowledged that “… almost no one favors discontinuing the mortgage tax deduction, a prized middle-class benefit that has been featured on some budget-cutting proposals.”

headline: Two Studies Show Pills Can Prevent H.I.V. Infection
text: Two new studies released on Wednesday add to the growing body of evidence that taking a daily pill containing one or two AIDS drugs can keep an uninfected person from catching the fatal human immunodeficiency virus.

headline: Amid Minnesota Crisis, Pawlenty Faces Scrutiny
text: On the presidential campaign trail, Tim Pawlenty, who in January completed two terms as governor of Minnesota, runs largely as an implacable foe of government spending, saying he drew “a line in the sand” in his home state and stood tough against Democrats during a government shutdown in 2005.

headline: Model and Front-Runner
text: THE first thing that registers in a glance at the new advertising campaign for Thierry Mugler A*Men fragrance is that the model, shown running across the page, appears to have neon laser beams shooting out of his rump.

headline: Small Health Woes Increase Dementia Risk
text: A runny nose, fallen arches and dentures aren’t risk factors typically associated with brain health. But new research suggests that small health problems can add up, and the combined effect can increase a person’s risk for dementia.

headline: The Downtown Crowd Finds an Uptown Perch
text: IT’S the dining version of the scene where the Gale house judders down in Oz. Monochrome up until that point, the world is suddenly, gorgeously Technicolor once Dorothy opens the door.

headline: Google+ Improves on Facebook
text: Google, the most popular Web site on earth, is worried about the second-most popular site. That, of course, would be Facebook.

headline: Nothing Sells Like a Duchess
text: RELATING to the period of June 30 to July 10 — known in these quarters as The Great North American Fashion Tour of Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, and Her Many, Many Designer Dresses (Including Some Previously Worn) — this reporter received no fewer than two dozen e-mails from publicists seeking to give credit to the designers who made the clothes she was wearing.

headline: The Caucus | The President's Fundraising
text: July 13, 2011 - Nicholas Confessore reports on President Obama's large fundraising haul: $86 million.

headline: Asked & Answered | Errol Morris
text: In his latest film, “Tabloid,” Errol Morris, the celebrated documentarian behind “The Fog of War,” the Oscar-winning portrait of Robert McNamara, and “The Thin Blue Line,” which helped get a man off death row, turns his famous Interrotron on a former Miss Wyoming whose stranger-than-fiction escapades twice invited the scrutiny of tabloid newspapers. In the late 1970s, a beauty queen named Joyce McKinney followed the object of her affections, a plump Mormon missionary named Kirk Anderson, to England, where she may or may not have abducted him at gunpoint. Through the Daily Express, McKinney claimed that Anderson consented to a three-day tryst at a cottage in Devon and was later brainwashed by the Mormon Church. With headlines like “Manacled Mormon,” the Daily Mirror told a different story, one that painted McKinney as an S&M-practicing predator who chained Anderson to a bed and forced him to have sex with her with the hope of getting pregnant. McKinney fled the country in an outlandish disguise and, three decades later, made the news again, this time for persuading a South Korean doctor to clone her beloved pit bull, Booger. The Moment sat down with Morris in SoHo to discuss his mad meditation on obsession, hysteria and the tabloid rag.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from India, Afghanistan and Spain.

headline: Colorized
text: Stealing a page from the sneaker playbook: dress shoes with color.

headline: Elvis Would Be Proud
text: SNEAKERHEADS, rejoice.

headline: Town & Country Man Eases Into His New Home
text: JAY FIELDEN cut a lean figure as he paced his glass-walled office on the 33rd floor of the Hearst Building. Occupying that space, the top editor’s perch at Town & Country, is a bit, he said, “like being a gerbil in a cage.”

headline: Gone With the Wind
text: “This matter is best disposed of from a great height, over water.” I hear that line from “North by Northwest” when I see George Steinmetz’s images from this year’s Défi Wind competition off the coast of Gruissan, France. When one of them ran in last weekend’s magazine, Steinmetz became the first photographer to make a repeat appearance in “Look.” Back in early March, Steinmetz’s picture taken from high over frozen water — the setting for a pond hockey tournament in Wisconsin — marked the debut of “Look” as a regular feature. Here, above and below, are some additional photos from his windsurfing shoot.

headline: ‘Sex on the Moon’
text: Prologue

headline: Supposition as Research: A Sort-of-True Story About NASA and a Thief
text: Here is the no-frills version of the Thad Roberts story: Mr. Roberts aspired to a career with NASA and became an intern at the Johnson Space Center. In 2002 he stole a 661-pound safe that contained priceless Moon rock samples. He was caught by an F.B.I. sting as he tried to sell this loot to mineral collectors. He was sentenced to eight years and four months in prison.

headline: Homes for $800,000
text: An 18th-century house in eastern Maryland; a contemporary house in central Vermont; and a 1911 house in St. Louis.

headline: What You Get for ... $800,000
text: CHESTERTOWN, MD.

headline: Creem Set to Return to the Newstand
text: It has been more than two decades since rock fans could pick up a copy of Creem magazine at a newsstand and submerse themselves in the fabled publication where critics like Lester Bangs and Dave Marsh helped define a generation of popular musicians. But there are plans afoot to resurrect the printed magazine this fall, The Associated Press reported this week.

headline: France Loses to the U.S., With Typical Elegance
text: The proper thing to do — even before praising American resilience and Pia Sundhage’s coaching — is to respect France.

headline: A Fantasy Book Revives Store Sales
text: Amid the growth of the e-book business and online retailers like Amazon, sales of print books in brick-and-mortar stores have been suffering all year.

headline: Summer Office Hours on The Choice
text: Like many readers of The Choice, your blogger has been taking — and will continue to take — some time away from the keyboard this summer to recharge, and plan for the school year ahead.

headline: Returning Upriver With Very Few Fish
text: John S. Sparks, curator of ichthyology at the American Museum of Natural History, writes about his expedition to Madagascar, where he studied native freshwater fish.

headline: Kickoff
text: The opening-night party for the Bread & Butter urban and street fashion trade fair looked like something out of Burning Man.

headline: A Flying Giselle, Coming Right at You
text: Films of the two-act Romantic ballet “Giselle” go back almost 80 years. The clips of black-and-white silent film of Olga Spessivtseva (1932) and Margot Fonteyn (1937) used to be rare as gold dust; now you can see them on YouTube. The ancient film technology, however, makes anyone watching today frustrated by its obvious inadequacies. So it’s dismaying that the new “Giselle in 3D,” featuring one of the finest casts achievable today, makes even more basic cinematic errors. The performance, recorded at the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, features Natalia Osipova, from the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow, as Giselle amid an otherwise all-Mariinsky cast. The filming is by the British company Can Communicate, a title that turns out to be somewhat optimistic.

headline: Pawlenty’s Playbook for Skipping Marriage Pledge
text: Here’s a political puzzle: How do you decline to sign a pledge defending marriage if you are a Republican presidential candidate? Now, consider you need to win Iowa, where conservative voters have proven their affinity for candidates who are demonstrative about their faith. And those voters already have made it know that they feel that the candidates are focusing almost exclusively on the economy at the expense of social issues.

headline: Summer Styles | Sirens
text: The hazy and humid days of summer are upon us, and it seems many are coming down with a case of scarlet fever. Rather than run around in barely there ensembles, women are wearing clothes that get attention for their vivid color. The English television presenter Fearne Cotton keeps things casual in cheery off-shades, while the actress Charlotte Poutrel goes glamorous and the model Karolina Kurkova dazzles in floor-length silk. The heat is on.

headline: The Truths That Only Repetition Reveals
text: There was Mike Scheidt, the guitarist and singer from the doom-metal trio Yob, at Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday night. He was playing a pattern, long-form and superficially simple. Doom tends to stay slow and precise; he cycled a few chords, or sometimes only one, over and over.

headline: Dump Your Printer to Escape the Madness
text: First, we kill all the printers.

headline: ‘Arias With a Twist’ to Return to New York
text: “Arias With a Twist,” a night of song, dance and leggy life-sized puppets created by the performer Joey Arias in collaboration with the puppeteer Basil Twist, will return to New York for a four-week run at the Abrons Arts Center beginning Sept. 14.

headline: NBC Names Jennifer Salke Its Entertainment President
text: NBC filled a long dormant top spot in its entertainment division Wednesday when it announced that Jennifer Salke would join the network as president of entertainment.

headline: Readers’ Favorite Local Drinks
text: The Times asked readers on Facebook to share their favorite local drinks, like the Mexican Martini of Austin, Tex. Beers, cocktails and spirits are all eligible. Below are a few highlights; add yours to the mix in the comments section below.

headline: Do You Use a Big Green Egg?
text: When I lived in Atlanta in the late 1980s, I learned to cook Thanksgiving turkeys, Fourth of July pork shoulders, and Sunday night burgers on the Big Green Egg. When I moved to Oxford, Miss. in 1995, I had to leave my Egg behind. It wouldn’t fit in the moving truck.When my mother in law, Marley Hobbs, age 88, moved two doors down a couple years ago, she saved enough room in her moving truck for her Egg. Of late, I’ve been borrowing hers more frequently, while pondering the purchase of a Primo, one of those glossy black oblong models. Sure, they’re expensive. But, after reporting my story on them, I want one more than ever.

headline: Pact on Adoptions Ends a U.S.-Russian Dispute
text: MOSCOW — More than a year after an adopted-child abandonment scandal led Russian officials to threaten a ban on adoptions of Russian children by Americans, the United States and Russia have reached an agreement that will allow such adoptions to proceed under heightened scrutiny.

headline: Daytime Show About Women Isn’t Soap Opera
text: There is sweet surrender in watching the American soccer team at the Women’s World Cup. It’s a daytime television event that forces viewers to set aside routine tasks — and attitudes built up over a lifetime.

headline: The Cloyne Report
text: Report by Commission of Investigation into the handling by Church and State authorities of allegations and suspicions of child sexual abuse against clerics of the Catholic Diocese of Cloyne.

headline: Sniffing Out a Diamond Ruse, Then Finding a Steppingstone
text: Bridge Base Online broadcasts the best bridge from around the planet. But the toughest job is arranging commentators, experts who type about the bidding and play as it occurs.

headline: Foursome’s Boundless Musical Map
text: Brooklyn Rider has found a handful of fascinating ways to keep its repertory both fresh and broad. Its involvement with Yo-Yo Ma’s Silk Road Project has helped this quirky string quartet understand musical styles beyond the Western mainstream and has put it in contact with potential collaborators who play non-Western instruments. Because a couple of the quartet’s members compose and arrange, they can supplement commissions from other composers with works of their own. And every now and then the group fills out its playlist the old-fashioned way: by looking back at the conventional repertory and spending some quality time with, say, a Mozart quartet.

headline: New Service Offers Music in Quantity, Not by Song
text: Daniel Ek, the 28-year-old co-founder and public face of Spotify, the European digital music service, paced around the company’s loftlike Manhattan office on Tuesday afternoon, clutching two mobile phones that buzzed constantly.

headline: Keys to Easier iPad Typing
text: While the iPad is great for reading, it’s not quite as good for writing, unless you are exceptionally skilled with the virtual keyboard. The obvious answer is to add a real keyboard, which a number of companies are happy to provide.

headline: Judge Halts Landmark’s Alterations
text: A state Supreme Court judge has ordered renovations halted at a landmark office building at Fifth Avenue and 43rd Street that preservationists call a model of modernism. A former bank that was originally part of the Manufacturers Trust Company, it was designed by Gordon Bunshaft of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill in the era of the gray flannel suit.

headline: Union Leaders Give Players Support to Play Overseas
text: If the locked-out N.B.A. players choose to take their talents overseas, they will do so with the spirited support of their union’s leadership.

headline: Q&A: Sending Certain File Types (or Not) By Gmail
text: Q.

headline: Horseplay for the Staid Mariinsky
text: The Mariinsky Ballet, which many of us remember as the Kirov, is generally known as the elevated, refined, instructive, grand, and most serious of ballet companies. It has often danced its 19th-century ballet repertory with a peculiar mixture of mannered authority and unspontaneous condescension. Yet in Alexei Ratmansky’s 2009 version of “The Little Humpbacked Horse,” it’s positively frolicsome, fresh as a daisy, endearingly friendly, cute as can be, bubbling over with high spirits and even giggly.

headline: As Clemens’s Trial Begins, Government Details Its Evidence
text: WASHINGTON — Opening statements in the perjury trial of Roger Clemens, one of baseball’s greatest pitchers, began on Wednesday in federal court, with the government insisting it had overwhelming proof that Clemens lied when he told Congress that he never used performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Track Your Stolen Hardware With These Apps
text: In light of the recent arrest of a TSA agent at the Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International airport who is said to have stuffed a passenger’s iPad down his pants, now might be a good time start thinking about tracking your hardware on the road.

headline: G.O.P.’s No-Tax Stance Is Outside Political Mainstream
text: The back-and-forth of the debt limit negotiations can be perplexing. But the facts driving the debate are quite straightforward. Any deal, or any workaround to a deal, will need to be approved by a majority of the House of Representatives. The Republicans in the House of Representatives are extremely conservative on fiscal matters and are significantly out of step with the public as a whole. Given that Democrats continue to control the Senate and the White House, and that their votes may be necessary in the House as well, this makes compromise nearly impossible.

headline: On Debt, Death, Taxes and Temperatures
text: A few days ago, I had a short e-mail exchange with Vaclav Smil, a master analyst of risks and resources, on strokes and aging, climate policy, the global debt crisis and a few other light subjects. I’ve excerpted our chat below in the form of a dialogue.

headline: Galleon Case Figure Settles With S.E.C.
text: Danielle Chiesi, convicted of insider trading as part of the case against the Galleon Group hedge fund, agreed to pay $540,000 to settle related allegations by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: The Voice of a GPS Device on Your Phone, at a Price
text: App shopping is a fairly painless diversion, thanks to all the $1 programs on the market. But in one important category, voice-guided navigation for drivers, the stakes are higher. You can spend $70 on one, or you can take your chances with something cheap or free.

headline: Shooting Twice, at Once
text: When shooting stills and video simultaneously, Doug Mills, a staff photographer in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, has tried a creative trick or two. He once strapped the video camera around his neck, using his stomach to hold it in place. The results, he said, were “freewheeling and dangling and very difficult to work with.”

headline: Calls for Congress to Investigate the Conduct of the News Corporation
text: Public criticism of the News Corporation’s conduct in the British hacking scandal has crossed the ocean to the United States — and crossed the floor to the Republican side — as half a dozen members of Congress urged the government to investigate possible misconduct, including violations of a law that guards against foreign corruption.

headline: Import Prices Fall for First Time in a Year
text: Prices of goods imported to the United States fell in June for the first time in a year as oil and food expenses retreated, the Labor Department said Wednesday.

headline: Secrets of a Garlic Grower
