headline: Shopping for Bottle Openers With Iacoli & McAllister
text: The partners behind the Seattle product design firm set out to find appealing tools for uncapping bottles.

headline: Bottle Openers
text: ON hot, sticky days, there’s something reassuring about having a bottle opener close at hand: you will not be locked out of liquid refreshment. But a distinctive opener goes beyond the mechanics of removing bottle caps, adding something extra to summer festivities.

headline: An Antiques Store Docks at Sag Harbor
text: La Maisonette, a new antiques store in Sag Harbor, offers an industrial setting — polished concrete floors and walls painted sea blue and misty gray — for French and Belgian antiques.

headline: The How-Tos of House Painting
text: EVERY summer, thousands of homeowners entrust their homes to college-age painters, possibly on the theory that if you’re smart enough to matriculate, you can smear paint on a flat surface. Seriously, how could you mess it up?

headline: Sales on Gus* Modern, Steuben and More
text: Steuben is discounting some pieces up to 30 percent, through Friday (the Bamboo bud vase, originally $750, will be $525; the Petal Cut ice bucket, regularly $600, will be $420); 667 Madison Avenue (61st Street), (800) 783-8236 or steuben.com.

headline: For a Famed Los Angeles Architect, a Day of His Own
text: John Lautner settled in Los Angeles in the late 1930s, spending much of his career there and designing some of the city’s most celebrated examples of modern architecture. Now the city is recognizing the life and influence of the architect, who died in 1994, on what would have been his 100th birthday, by declaring July 16 John Lautner Day.

headline: Tyler Florence on His Kitchen of the Year
text: Tyler Florence is used to wearing many different hats: he’s not just a chef, he’s a Food Network TV personality, a columnist for House Beautiful magazine, a restaurateur, a cookbook author and the owner of his own chain of kitchen stores in Northern California. And next week, Mr. Florence will be in New York showing off his skills in another food-related discipline: kitchen design.

headline: A Table of Patchwork Walnut
text: Jason Roskey, a furniture designer who runs the Brooklyn company Fern with his wife, Maggie Goudsmit, started out as a visual artist making mixed-media pieces and collages. And the Orchard low table, his latest creation, seems to reflect that: the tabletop has what he calls a “patchwork construction” of salvaged claro walnut from orchards in Northern California.

headline: Houses Made of Sticks and Stones
text: Meticulously and gorgeously wrought, Clark Sanders’s stone house and straw-bale structures in the Catskills are his calling cards.

headline: A History of Design Gets an Update
text: The second edition of “A History of Design from the Victorian Era to the Present” (W. W. Norton; $50) is being published this week, more than four decades after the first edition. The new book, by Ann Ferebee and Jeff Byles, is “a capsule history of design in a nutshell, with all the major players and the major pieces,” said Nancy Green, the editor of both editions (the first was published by Van Nostrand Reinhold, in 1970).

headline: In the Catskills, Building Stone by Stone, Bale by Bale
text: EAST MEREDITH, N.Y.

headline: Jawbone Will Sell a Health-Tracking Bracelet
text: Jawbone, a company best known for its line of sleek, futuristic-looking Bluetooth headsets and music accessories, is taking a big leap away from the audio industry.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Piracy and Hacking
text: Internet service providers and the music and movie industries are joining forces to fight copyright infringement. On this week’s Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein talks to Ben Sisario, a Times media reporter, about a new joint effort to crack down on downloads of pirated content with repeated warnings for offenders and eventually, tougher measures, like slowed-down connections and blocked browsing.

headline: Girl Power Wins at Google’s First Science Fair
text: If Google‘s first science fair is any indication, the top scientists of the future will be women. Google has announced the fair’s winners, and they are all young women.

headline: With Boy’s Killing, Parents Confront Worst Fears
text: They are the road rules of parenting, the self-defense tips of childhood, the maxims passed down for generations: Don’t talk to strangers. Don’t sit in the last car of the subway train. If you are lost, look for someone in a uniform. If something bad happens, scream!

headline: Baseball Gets Records on Pitcher’s Procedure
text: Major League Baseball officials said Wednesday that they had finally received copies of medical records for a novel stem cell procedure that Yankees pitcher Bartolo Colon underwent in the Dominican Republic last year to help his ailing shoulder and elbow.

headline: Issues Holding Up Debt Ceiling Agreement
text: Issues holding up debt ceiling agreement.

headline: Tablets Continue to Dent PC Sales
text: Modest growth returned to the computer industry in the second quarter following a dip earlier this year, although consumer appetite for tablets continued to dampen demand for desktop and laptop PCs.

headline: Phantoms of the East River
text: “Fast, sleek, elegant … can anyone tell me what that is?” our guide calls out, pointing at the sky. We have just pulled out of New York Harbor, wind lifting the flaps of our purses and murses, the financial district glittering at our backs.

headline: TimesCast | Three Bomb Attacks on Mumbai
text: Three bomb blasts shook the city of Mumbai at the height of the evening rush hour, killing at least 20 people.

headline: The Republican Case for Compromise
text: North Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: New Thai Government Is Delayed by Legal Challenges
text: BANGKOK — Efforts to form a new government in Thailand are being snarled by a docket of legal challenges and what critics say are the slow workings of the country’s Election Commission.

headline: Clouds Around Karzai Darken the Road Ahead
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — At midday, the glare and dust obscures Afghanistan’s horizon in what seems a metaphor for the position of the Afghan president as political and economic crises mount on every front: it is increasingly hard to see how he will find his way.

headline: A Murdoch Discount in News Corp. Stock
text: Rupert Murdoch’s political influence may be surpassed by his impact on the value of the News Corporation. The stock routinely trades more cheaply than media rivals’, largely because the company, which is listed in the United States, is run at Mr. Murdoch’s whim. As a result of the British phone-hacking scandal, the Murdoch discount has widened to 30 percent.

headline: President Hints at Fresh Start for Sudan, but Many Are Skeptical
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — It is a grand title, carrying the suggestion of a new era, a new dawn. Now that the southern part of Sudan has split off and formed its own nation, many politicians here in the north, including President Omar Hassan al-Bashir, have a new way of referring to what remains of their country. They call it the “second republic.”

headline: N.C.A.A. Inquiry of Auburn Isn’t Over, Exchange Reveals
text: NORTH AUGUSTA, S.C. — Last month, when athletic officials from the Southeastern Conference met in Destin, Fla., the annual gathering had an eye-popping moment.

headline: Private Equity Princes Reach Deal for 76ers
text: A group led by Joshua Harris, a co-founder of the private equity firm Apollo Global Management, announced late on Wednesday that it had reached an agreement to buy the Philadelphia 76ers basketball team from the sports company Comcast-Spectacor.

headline: Battle For Libya | July 13, 2011
text: Hospital staff dealt with rebel casualties in Zintan, Libya, while schoolchildren learned the Tamazight language in Yafran.

headline: Some Rural Lawmakers Defy Power Erosion
text: RITZVILLE, Wash. — State Senator Mark Schoesler might seem a marginalized man at first glance. In this ever bluer state, he is deep red Republican. In his dusty hometown here in rural eastern Washington, the population is in perpetual decline and Main Street resists revival. Although it has been nearly 20 years since Mr. Schoesler became a state lawmaker, fewer and fewer of his colleagues in Olympia, the capital, have a clue about what he does for a living.

headline: A Loss That Hurts, but Not Too Much
text: The Yankees were able to win 14 of 18 games with Derek Jeter on the disabled list because Nick Swisher thrived and Robinson Cano flourished and Eduardo Nunez emerged and Mark Teixeira slugged. And yet none of their regular players hit better during that three-week stretch than Alex Rodriguez, who batted .356.

headline: Amazon Takes On California
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon, the world’s largest online merchant, has an ambitious and far-reaching new agenda: it wants to rewrite tax policy for the Internet era.

headline: Austria: Anthem to Undergo a Wording Change
text: The main political parties in Parliament agreed to change the lyrics of the national anthem within several months to include a reference to women. After decades of debate, one passage of the text is expected to be altered from the current “Home you are to great sons” to “Home of great daughters, sons.” The move must be formalized by a parliamentary vote in the fall.

headline: Judge Delays Decision on Bulger’s Girlfriend
text: BOSTON — Prosecutors insisted that Catherine Greig actively helped James (Whitey) Bulger evade capture for 16 years, despite knowing his criminal past. The defense countered that Ms. Greig was a kind and simple woman who had been tightly controlled by Mr. Bulger and deserved to be released on bail.

headline: Rebels Briefly Lose Control of Western Libyan Town
text: QAWALISH, Libya — Military forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi counterattacked and briefly recaptured this front-line town from opposition forces on Wednesday, but they were beaten back by a large rebel force late in the day.

headline: Yankees Fan’s Generosity Is Returned, With $50,000 to Ease His Debt
text: A week ago, Christian Lopez was living an unremarkable life. He had a job, a girlfriend, a significant student loan debt. Then fate (he retrieved Derek Jeter’s 3,000th hit) and choice (he simply returned the ball to the Yankees shortstop) changed all that.

headline: All-Star Game Viewership Hits Low Point
text: The National League’s 5-1 victory over the American League in Tuesday’s Major League Baseball All-Star Game on Fox was seen by an average of 10.9 million viewers — the fewest ever recorded by Nielsen and 9 percent below the audience for last year’s broadcast.

headline: Knicks Let Go of Two Scouts, Including One Who Earned Fine
text: Two Knicks scouts, including one who was disciplined for illegal workouts, are being dismissed this month after their contracts expire.

headline: T. Lux Feininger, Photographer and Painter, Dies at 101
text: T. Lux Feininger, a painter and photographer who, as a young student at the Bauhaus, used his camera to compile an invaluable and visually distinctive record of the artistic avant-garde in Germany between the wars, died last Thursday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 101.

headline: Armor Settles Claims Over Bribery
text: Armor Holdings, the maker of military trucks, agreed to pay $16 million to resolve American claims that it bribed a United Nations official to win contracts connected to peacekeeping missions.

headline: George M. Ross, Who Helped Establish Major Jewish Museum, Dies at 77
text: George M. Ross, a Goldman Sachs executive and a philanthropist who successfully resisted the gravitational pull of the nation’s usual cultural capitals to help establish a major museum of Jewish history in Philadelphia, raising $154 million for the project, died on Friday at his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 77.

headline: Judge Blocks City’s Crisis Pregnancy Center Law
text: Scolding city officials for supporting a law he called “offensive to free speech principles,” a federal judge on Wednesday temporarily barred New York City from enforcing a new law that would require crisis pregnancy centers to disclose more information about their services.

headline: Marketa Kimbrell, Who Brought Theater to the Forgotten, Is Dead at 82
text: Marketa Kimbrell, an actress and co-founder of a theater company that brought stage productions to audiences for whom they were rarely available, among them prison inmates, died on July 6 in Sykesville, Md. She was 82.

headline: Class Dismissed
text: Childhood ends, this time forever, with tears and howls, swirls of smoke, the shock of mortality and bittersweet smiles in “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2,” the grave, deeply satisfying final movie in the series. A pop cultural happening extraordinaire, the Potter movies took uncertain flight in 2001 with Harry, then an orphan of 11, home alone with his grotesquely unloving relatives. Times were grim, at least off screen — the first opened in November of that year — but Chris Columbus’s directorial touch was insistently light as Harry was initiated into a world alive with odd doings, strange creatures and the evil that would almost consume it.

headline: 7 Blocks to Walk, Brooklyn Boy Never Got Home
text: It was only seven blocks. The boy had begged and his parents had said yes, he could walk part of the way home from day camp by himself. Together they had memorized the route. They had practiced a dry run together.

headline: Open-Winning Caddie Is Back, but Not With His Champion
text: SANDWICH, England — When Ben Curtis, the last man to win a British Open Championship at the Royal St. George’s Golf Club, steps up on the windswept first tee Thursday, Andy Sutton will be there.

headline: A Rose by Any Other Brand
text: Fragrance vendors make much of the essential masculinity and femininity of their products. But when the labels are removed, it's not so easy to guess which scents belong to which gender.

headline: How Police Traced a Boy and a Suspect
text: Map showing locations in the murder of a Brooklyn boy.

headline: Pumpkin Pie: Provocative or Just Tasty?
text: IS it the olfactory equivalent of a little red dress?

headline: Mets Will Evaluate Parnell’s Ability to Close
text: When Francisco Rodriguez was lost for the season last August with a thumb injury, the Mets had a chance to see if Bobby Parnell, their hard-throwing young relief pitcher, could assume the role as closer of the future.

headline: Some Want the Open to Return to Portrush
text: SANDWICH, England — No matter how bright Rory McIlroy’s present and future might be, the British Open will not be heading to Northern Ireland anytime soon.

headline: News Corp. Newspapers May Face U.S. Inquiry
text: Public criticism of the News Corporation’s conduct in the British hacking scandal has crossed the ocean as half a dozen members of Congress this week urged the United States government to investigate possible misconduct, including violations of a law that guards against foreign corruption.

headline: A Clash Over Gas Drilling in New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Supreme Court Scorecard
text: The recently concluded Supreme Court term is not lacking for sober analysis, so I’ll indulge my freedom to take a different approach. This is an annotated scorecard, a personal take on the term based on what jumps out at me as I look back over the past year.

headline: The Last Shuttle: A Paean to Spaceflight
text: To the Editor:

headline: One Man Drowns and Another Is Critically Injured at a Public Pool on Staten Island
text: A 21-year-old man who was participating in a lap swim program at a public pool on Staten Island drowned Wednesday morning, and a second man in the same pool, an off-duty city lifeguard in his early 20s, was in critical condition after nearly drowning, officials said.

headline: ‘Backdoor Amnesty’: A Republican Chides Obama
text: To the Editor:

headline: Little Headway in Latest N.F.L. Labor Talks
text: Little progress was made Wednesday as negotiators for N.F.L. owners and players continued talks in hopes of striking a deal to end the four-month-long lockout.

headline: Father and Son Split on Tactics in Murdoch Family Drama
text: Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation announced Wednesday that it was withdrawing its $12 billion bid to buy complete control of the satellite giant British Sky Broadcasting, a move intended to calm the torrent of derision directed at the company since journalists at its British newspapers were implicated in a widespread phone-hacking scheme.

headline: How U.S. Companies Can Help Solve the Debt Crisis
text: To the Editor:

headline: If Indian Point Closes, Plenty of Challenges
text: Peculiarities of the electricity system in New York State, including its unusual independent status, would make it difficult and expensive to replace electricity from the Indian Point nuclear power plant if Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo succeeds in shutting it down, experts on the grid warn.

headline: A Trade About Money, Not Manpower
text: Francisco Rodriguez’s recent change of agents helped hasten his trade to the Milwaukee Brewers, a critical deal that at least marginally enhances the Mets’ ability to re-sign Jose Reyes.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Housing Boom, if You’re a Bird
text: SUKADANA, Indonesia — Along the spine-jarring road that runs through this city on the South China Sea, in between the sparse, waterlogged shacks of corrugated aluminum and wood, colorful buildings have begun to sprout.

headline: Bloggingheads: Libya and Impeachment
text: Glenn Greenwald, left, of Salon.com and Ilya Somin of George Mason University School of Law debate Congressional options on Libya.

headline: The Courts Step In
text: In three new rulings, federal judges in different states have acted to block immediate enforcement of measures that restrict abortion rights and women’s access to affordable contraception, lifesaving cancer screenings and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases. These rulings are important victories for women’s health and reproductive rights.

headline: Shooting for 5 Stars in Hotel Market
text: After rotating through various hotel jobs as an intern, Emily Ditman, 23, wound up an account executive at Hospitality eBusiness Strategies. An Internet marketing company, it elevates the Web presence of, and directs potential clients to, hotels and hotel-based restaurants. Ms. Ditman received a B.S. in hospitality and tourism management in May 2010 from the Tisch Center for Hospitality, Tourism and Sports Management at New York University. She lives in Hell’s Kitchen with her sister, Stephanie, a Jujamcyn Theaters intern.

headline: Ruling Ends Theater’s Bid for Brooklyn Waterfront
text: In a blow to St. Ann’s Warehouse, a widely admired theater in Brooklyn, a judge has issued a ruling that essentially nullifies a set of decisions by the federal, state and city governments over the last several years that led to approval of a new home for the theater.

headline: Thursday: Where To Find a Date
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle is the first collaboration between the constructors Brendan Emmet Quigley and Ian Livengood, and if this is any indication, I truly hope we see a lot more from them. I think this grid is a thing of beauty.

headline: Utility Shelves Ambitious Plan to Limit Carbon
text: WASHINGTON — A major American utility is shelving the nation’s most prominent effort to capture carbon dioxide from an existing coal-burning power plant, dealing a severe blow to efforts to rein in emissions responsible for global warming.

headline: Back When Even War Seemed a Bit Less Scary
text: The kind of social networking taking place between actors and audience at the St. James Theater, where the recent Broadway revival of “Hair” has splashed down for a welcome return visit this summer, doesn’t require any fancy digital gadgets.

headline: Vive la Similarité
text: West Tisbury, Mass.

headline: To Track Militants, U.S. Has System That Never Forgets a Face
text: WASHINGTON — When the Taliban dug an elaborate tunnel system beneath the largest prison in southern Afghanistan this spring, they set off a scramble to catch the 475 inmates who escaped.

headline: After Coming Together for a Frantic Search, a Community Is Left Reeling
text: When day broke on Wednesday in Borough Park, Brooklyn, the swarms of volunteers went home defeated, and the detritus of a frantic 36-hour search for a missing boy lay strewn by the curb.

headline: Harry, I Hardly Knew Ye
text: For a while I half wondered if some swine flu had wrought epidermal havoc in barnyards near and far. Why all the chatter about Hogwarts?

headline: Cuomo Says Curbing Public Pension Benefits Will Be His Top Goal in ’12
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, basking in the afterglow of a legislative session that he described as “unusually successful,” said Wednesday that his top priority next year would be limiting retirement benefits for new state and city workers.

headline: Drawdown in Iraq
text: President Obama is fulfilling his promise to wind down the Iraq war. When he took office, there were about 142,000 American troops on the ground; now there are 46,000. All are supposed to be gone by Dec. 31 under a 2008 agreement between Washington and Baghdad.

headline: The F.E.C. Awakes
text: It is heartening that the usually dysfunctional Federal Election Commission has now ruled that candidates cannot solicit large-scale donations for the new “Super PACs” intent on raising hundreds of millions for the 2012 elections. For too long the F.E.C. has spent much of its time creating loopholes for party machines and declining to punish even egregious violators.

headline: A Living Message From the Past
text: Several outposts of Morse code blazed to life again, if only for a night, with the help of a group of enthusiasts bent on preserving what they call “the music of Morse,” one key-tap at a time.

headline: Gun Mayhem Along the Border
text: It is an open and deadly scandal that at least 70 percent of the weapons recovered in Mexico’s bloody drug war originate in the United States, where shady gun buyers operate freely thanks to loopholes in American law. To its credit, the Obama administration has ordered the more than 8,000 dealers along the border to begin reporting multiple sales of AK-47s and other semiautomatic battlefield weapons to the federal firearms bureau.

headline: Thousands Mourn Boy Killed in Brooklyn
text: With shock and grief clutching Borough Park in Brooklyn, thousands of mourners and residents poured into a neighborhood courtyard Wednesday evening for the funeral of an 8-year-old Brooklyn boy who was abducted and killed this week as he walked home from camp.

headline: The Opposing Party
text: Senator Mitch McConnell has a clever plan to resolve the federal debt impasse. Congressional Republicans would invite President Obama to raise the debt ceiling on his own, and then they would excoriate him for doing so.

headline: Borders Faces Liquidation After Takeover Bid’s Rejection
text: The Borders Group may be near liquidation after a committee of its unsecured creditors on Wednesday rejected a proposed takeover by the Najafi Companies, a private equity firm.

headline: E-Mail From Billy Hunter to N.B.A. Players
text: Read the original email Billy Hunter, the executive director of the National Basketball Players Association, sent to 450 N.B.A. players this week.

headline: For a Night Each Year, the Airwaves Buzz With Morse Code
text: POINT REYES NATIONAL SEASHORE, Calif. — It has been a little more than a decade since the last of the nation’s commercial Morse code radio stations officially went off the air, as new technology sank a system that had been a lingua franca of maritime communication since before the Titanic.

headline: California: Democrat Wins House Race
text: A Los Angeles city councilwoman, Janice Hahn, survived a costly battle to hold onto a Congressional seat for Democrats in Los Angeles on Tuesday, defeating a Republican businessman, Craig Huey, in a special election. Ms. Hahn collected 55 percent of the vote to Mr. Huey’s 45 percent, according to a semiofficial tally. She is expected to be sworn in next week to succeed the 36th Congressional District’s longtime congresswoman, Jane Harman, who retired in February. The 36th District has long been a Democratic stronghold. Turnout was low, with only 22 percent of registered voters casting ballots. Mr. Huey was able to keep the race competitive in part because he spent nearly $900,000 of his own money on the campaign. But he could not overcome Ms. Hahn’s Democratic advantage.

headline: Obama Speaks About His Mother
text: Barack Obama has often told the story of his mother's deathbed dispute with her insurance company and left the clear impression that the fight was over health benefits for medical expenses.

headline: Book Challenges Obama on Mother’s Deathbed Fight
text: The White House on Wednesday declined to challenge an account in a new book that suggests that President Obama, in his campaign to overhaul American health care, mischaracterized a central anecdote about his mother’s deathbed dispute with her insurance company.

headline: Brazil Wins and Advances
text: Alexandre Pato and Neymar scored two goals each as defending champion Brazil defeated Ecuador 4-2 to reach the Copa América quarterfinals in Cordoba, Argentina. Brazil finished first in Group B and will play Paraguay in the next round, while Ecuador was eliminated.

headline: Corrections: July 14
text: NATIONAL

headline: Donovan
text: A series of original artworks, exclusively online.

headline: Fruity, Savory, Creamy, Boozy
text: The summertime appeal of ice pops (as they’re properly called — “Popsicle” is a trademarked word that’s become a default name) is easy to understand. They’re sweet, colorful, lickable and a manageably small snack in an age of gargantuan portions. They recall a simpler time, before the era of artisanal-gelato shops.

headline: Nuance Releases an App for Speech-Based Search
text: Nuance’s voice-recognition technology is used for things like translating speech to text and delivering turn-by-turn directions for drivers. Now the company wants to help people search on their mobile phones.

headline: Word of the Day | buccaneer
text: buccaneer •\ˌbə-kə-ˈnir\• noun/verb

headline: NYT: Front Page for 07/14/2011
text: NYT: Front Page for 07/14/2011

headline: Obama Camp Says It Raised $47 Million for His Run
text: President Obama raised $47 million for his re-election campaign in the three-month period that ended June 30, his aides said on Wednesday, far outpacing the Republican candidates who hope to replace him.

headline: For Judges, a Sunday Unlike Any Other
text: On a summer Sunday, Justice Thomas D. Raffaele of State Supreme Court in Queens would usually be in a bathing suit at the Jersey Shore. Instead, on July 24, the Sunday that New York’s same-sex marriage law goes into effect, he plans to be in his judicial robes at the city clerk’s office on Queens Boulevard, ready to marry people, possibly in large numbers.

headline: News Quiz | July 14, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Rupert Murdoch’s Empire
text: Chart of News Corporation’s 2010 revenues, by sector.

headline: Test Yourself | English, July 14, 2011
text: Today’s question was written by Susan Behrens, who is a professor at Marymount Manhattan College and the author of “Grammar: A Pocket Guide.”

headline: News of the World Makes Headlines of Its Own
text: WHAT scandal brought about the end of British newspaper News of the World?WHAT are the accusations against the some of paper’s journalists?WHAT are the journalists’ tactics that have come to be known as “the dark arts”?WHAT other newspapers and media outlets are owned by the News Corporation?

headline: Officials Say Bombers in Attack on Mumbai Had Some Training
text: NEW DELHI — Indian officials said Thursday that the bombers who had traumatized Mumbai during the evening rush a day earlier appeared to be trained in handling explosives and had possibly used timers to synchronize the deadly triple blast. But they also said that investigators had not identified any suspects and that they had been hampered by a soaking rainstorm that impeded evidence-gathering.

headline: Are Bank Examiners to Blame for Slow Job Growth?
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Turban-Hidden Bomb Is Detonated at Service for Karzai’s Brother
text: This article is by  Taimoor Sha h, Alissa J. Rubin and  Jack Healy.

headline: London Park Hosts Summer Festival Lineup
text: Victoria Park, in the East End, is one of of London’s oldest, largest and most loved green spaces. It’s also a stone’s throw from the creative hub of the city — the once slummy, now hip Shoreditch. Put these two things together and it should come as no surprise that the park will host a series of high-decibel events through the summer, keeping residents and visitors creatively entertained.

headline: The Early Word: Tension
text: Today’s Times

headline: At Reagan Library, the Gipper as Gearhead
text: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — Ronald Reagan, a president who never passed on an opportunity to be photographed astride a horse, also loved auto racing. His affinity for motorsports is explored in an exhibition at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation and Library.

headline: In Shadow of Death, Iraq and U.S. Tiptoe Around a Deadline
text: BAGHDAD — The government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki is privately telling American officials that it wants their Army to stay here after this year.

headline: Q&A: Getting Twitter and Facebook to Communicate Again
text: Q.

headline: China Urges U.S. to Protect Creditors by Raising Debt
text: HONG KONG — China, one of the United States’s biggest creditors, urged American policy makers on Thursday to act to protect investors’ interests, highlighting rising concerns around the globe about the protracted budget talks taking place in Washington.

headline: Murdochs Now Say They Will Appear Before Parliament
text: LONDON — Facing the unpleasant prospect of being represented by a pair of empty chairs and a period of silence at a parliamentary committee hearing on phone hacking next week, Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation, and his son James reversed themselves on Thursday and said that yes, they would testify at the hearing after all.

headline: A New Horror Recalls Another
text: A horrified city can only imagine the darkness that must now envelop the family of Leiby Kletzky, the 8-year-old boy from Borough Park, Brooklyn, whose dismembered remains were found on Wednesday, two days after he had disappeared.

headline: A Tool to Help Business Owners Struggling With Social Media
text: Carolyn Betts is more knowledgeable about social networking than the average small-business owner. Back in 2004, when she had just started working for an executive recruiting firm, she saw how her sister in college was spending a lot of time on this student-focused site called Facebook and immediately started using it to reach out to sharp graduates to fill junior-level positions. She soon became a relatively early user of LinkedIn and Twitter, using them to expand her online presence. So when Ms. Betts started her own recruiting company in San Francisco in 2009 to find sales executives for start-ups, no one had to tell her to make social networks part of her operation.

text: 9:25 p.m. | Updated

headline: Eric Cantor Is the Democrats’ New Bogeyman
text: Just about everything having to do with the debt ceiling debate in Washington remains up in the air as negotiators continue in vain to seek some agreement — with the deadline fast approaching.

headline: Moelis Hires Former JPMorgan Banker
text: Moelis & Company, the boutique merger advisory firm, continued its hiring spree on Thursday when it announced that a former JPMorgan Chase banker, Yorick Van Slingelandt, would join the operation in Dubai.

headline: ConocoPhillips to Split Into Two Businesses

headline: NBERing
text: I should have given notice that yesterday was NBER day; Gauti Eggertsson and I presented our debt-deleveraging paper to the NBER Summer Institute. Really good discussion. Also, “to haircut” is now a verb, as in, “The ECB shouldn’t cut anyone off, it should just haircut the riskier debt.”

headline: Obama, Moderate Republican
text: OK, not exactly. But Nate Silver’s analysis of the budget proposals is a must-read. Nate looks at polling, and extracts the following implied preferences for the mix between tax increases and spending cuts in a debt deal:

headline: Photofly Brings 3-D Models to the Masses
text: Since Photofly, a service that turns uploaded photos into three-dimensional models, was introduced in May, it has received an average of 80 uploads an hour, for a total of 70,000 images, according to Autodesk, the service’s creator.

headline: Claudia Schiffer | Sweater Girl
text: “I wanted to make easy pieces that are practical yet chic,” says the model Claudia Schiffer, as she showed off examples from an eponymous new cashmere line in her airy, art-filled Notting Hill, London living room. “You know simple but well-cut dresses and tops that you can throw on with leggings and boots for the school run, and pair with a great pair of earrings or a cool cuff for dinner.’’ Comprised of chunky-knit jackets, dresses and buttery boyfriend sweaters, the collection (created in collaboration with the German knitwear label Iris von Arnim) ranges from about $400 to $1,600, and debuts later this month at net-a-porter.com.

headline: Behind the Scenes with Miranda July
text: Behind-the-scenes from Miranda July's cover shoot with Sam Taylor-Wood. Video courtesy of Jennifer Johnson.

headline: China Presses Its Tax Case in Dispute With Artist
text: BEIJING — The Chinese authorities have accused the design company that handles the work of the artist and dissident Ai Weiwei of failing to pay corporate taxes since 2000, according to his wife, Lu Qing, who attended a hearing with tax officials on Thursday.

headline: Miranda July Is Totally Not Kidding
text: Miranda July stood in her living room in the Silver Lake neighborhood of Los Angeles, apologizing for the sunflowers. It really was a copious amount of sunflowers.

headline: Fannie Freddie Phooey
text: Over at The Big Picture, David Min has a terrific takedown of the claim that Fannie and Freddie caused the housing bubble. Every time you hear or read someone claiming that Fannie and Freddie were responsible for large amounts of subprime/risky lending, you should remember that this is based on essentially phony numbers: people at AEI invented their own definition of subprime, which isn’t the standard definition, and, more important, doesn’t work: the supposedly high-risk loans that F&F were making or buying were, demonstrably, not actually high-risk:

headline: Off Wall St., a New ‘Hang Out’ Area by the River
text: Marlene Olivieri settled contentedly on a hardwood chaise lounge to spend a few minutes with “Hour of the Rose.” Richard Salvadeo and Stephen Pierce tucked into their lunches from bar stools offering an unobstructed panorama of the East River and the Brooklyn skyline. Jackie, meanwhile, could scarcely be dragged out of the water fountain in which she’d happily immersed herself.

headline: ‘Green’ Economy Is Real but Needs a Push, Study Suggests
text: Like so many buzz phrases, “green economy” is an expression that is generously tossed around with little regard for its meaning.

headline: Thursday Reading: Pills Can Prevent H.I.V. Infection
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Nominations Released for Prime-Time Emmys
text: Two sweeping new HBO dramas, “Boardwalk Empire” and “Game of Thrones,” will challenge AMC’s three-time winner “Mad Men” for the title of best drama in the 63rd annual Primetime Emmy Awards this year.

headline: A Hotel Minibar
text: It’s no secret that minibars have been evolving of late. Once receptacles of mass-market mixers and anemic airplane bottles of spirits, the in-room refrigerators at many hotels now offer an altogether more thoughtful selection, often with idiosyncratic touches like guitar strings and artisanal chocolates. But rare is the minibar that takes the “bar” part seriously. Enter Zetter Townhouse, in London’s Clerkenwell District.

headline: Williams Raises Its Bid for Southern Union to $5.5 Billion
text: The Williams Companies on Thursday raised its offer for the Southern Union Company to $5.5 billion, extending a bidding war for the pipeline operator by topping a revised $5.1 billion bid from Energy Transfer Equity.

headline: English Amateur Secures Share of Lead With a 65
text: SANDWICH, England — The arc of European Tour dominance in major championship golf, which began at the 2010 United States Open with the surprise victory by Northern Ireland’s Graeme McDowell, did not merely continue Thursday in the first round of the British Open at Royal St. George’s. It also got younger.

headline: As Italy Moves to Calm Investors, Europe Delays Meeting on Greece
text: Italy managed to sell five-year bonds in an auction on Thursday, but yields were at their highest level in three years, a sign that some investors remained nervous about the risk of the sovereign debt crisis spreading from Europe’s vulnerable periphery to its core economies.

headline: Emmy Nominators Do Right by ‘Friday Night Lights’
text: You win a few, you lose a few. At the top of the list, in the best drama category, the Emmy nominators righted their most egregious wrong of the last four years and gave a nod to “Friday Night Lights,” which in its fifth and final season was one of the handful of best shows on television — as it has been every season. I won’t hold my breath for an Emmy, but a little recognition was still nice.

headline: JPMorgan Names Co-Head of North America Investment Banking
text: JPMorgan Chase on Thursday named Larry Slaughter, a senior European banker, as a new co-head of investment banking for North America, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

headline: Arena Opera, Mortier Style
text: MADRID

headline: 2011 Emmy Award Winners
text: A list of nominees and winners of 2011 prime time Emmy Awards, held on Sunday night at the Nokia Theatre in Los Angeles. Winners are denoted in bold.

headline: As Costs Fall for Energy, Prices Drop for Producers
text: Producer prices declined in the United States in June, dragged down by a fall in energy prices like those for gasoline and electrical power, according to government statistics released Thursday.

headline: Emmy Voters Don’t Stint on Baffling Choices
text: In comedy, I find it hilarious that Louis C.K. was nominated for best actor while his show, “Louie,” was aced out. He is the show, the show is he. I suppose that by doing it this way, the nominators can indicate that they recognize his talent without endorsing his dark, boundary-pushing humor.

headline: Natural Splendor
text: Known for transforming ordinary tabletops into shinier talking points with his bas-relief-esque goblets, pitchers and trays, Michael Galmer of Galmer Silversmiths in Long Island City, Queens, has always believed that silver can be as polished a metal as any. “It’s very dynamic,” says Galmer, who has three decades of experience and a number of special projects for Tiffany & Company under his belt. “I was always in love with it.”

headline: A History of College Grade Inflation
text: We’ve written before about some of the work of Stuart Rojstaczer and Christopher Healy, grade inflation chroniclers extraordinaire. They have put together a new, comprehensive study of college grading over the decades, and let me tell you, it is a doozy.

headline: New Faces, New Maps, New Battles
text: LAS VEGAS — The population of Latinos has exploded here, and they want their voices heard not just in the halls of schools like Clark High or on the growing number of Spanish-language radio stations, but also in Congress.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: The Gardener’s Illness Solved
text: On Wednesday I challenged readers to figure out the case of a middle-aged gardener with a fading rash, numbness and tingling and intermittent muscle contractions.

headline: Poetry Pairing | July 14, 2011
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: ‘Boardwalk Empire’ and the Aversion to the Quick Fix
text: When your period crime drama comes to HBO with some of the biggest budgets the network has ever approved – and possibly the biggest expectations since “The Sopranos” – maybe you expect that your show will be an Emmy darling in its very first season. In that respect, “Boardwalk Empire,” HBO’s sprawling series about organized crime in Prohibition-era Atlantic City, did not disappoint, coming away with 18 nominations on Thursday morning including outstanding drama.

headline: Odds Catch Up With a Team in Japan
text: TOKYO — It was a long shot, but it was a chance worth taking. That was the mood on the Soso Rengo team, a combination of players from three high schools just miles from the crippled nuclear reactors in Fukushima.

headline: Widened Access to Health Care Saves Lives
text: Sierra Leone is at the vanguard of a revolution that appears to be substantially lessening health dangers in what has been one of the world’s riskiest countries to be a pregnant woman or a small child.

headline: Politics Gives Some U.S. Subsidy Programs Staying Power

headline: Confusion Over Parliament’s Power to Compel Murdochs to Testify

The decision came after the two men initially refused an invitation to attend an oversight committee hearing, and Parliament then took the extraordinary step of issuing a summons to order them to appear.

headline: Psychodrama in the Comedy Category

I don’t begrudge Mr. LeBlanc — “Episodes” wasn’t nearly as funny or interesting as it should have been, but he was the best thing about it, and he showed some real wit in his approach to playing himself, or someone sort of like him.

After all, eight years should be long enough for the pain to subside from the not-so-funny episode that happened at royal St. George’s in 2003.

But it feels like there’s a lot of momentum behind Steve Buscemi, who worked very hard to give some life to the lead character among the cardboard cast of “Boardwalk Empire.”

headline: In One Place: Store, Cafe and Hangout
text: ON summer evenings, a tree-lined strip of Dyckman Street — a main thoroughfare in Inwood, near Manhattan’s northern prow — becomes a giant block party. Crowds from several splashy bars spill out onto the sidewalk, clutching beers and cigarettes as they chatter loudly and peck away on their smartphones.

headline: Life Is a Wheel: The Story of the Bike
text: A bicyclist not in possession of his bicycle is at sixes and sevens. Mine, after only about 65 miles of test driving here in New York City, is now winging its way, via FedEx, to Portland, Ore., where I’ll pick it up on Monday for the trip home. (Cost of shipping: $180.) In the meantime, like any bereft parent missing a child, I can tell you about it. (You can read about my previous cross-country bike ride, and why I am going to cycle across the country again, in my recent story in the Travel section.)

headline: Clemens Judge Declares Mistrial
text: WASHINGTON — The federal judge presiding over Roger Clemens’s perjury case declared a mistrial Thursday, saying the government made a fatal misstep even a “first-year law student” would have avoided when it presented inadmissible testimony that prejudiced the jury against Clemens.

headline: Dining With the Karzais
text: Growing up, I rarely ate at restaurants. If my parents took the family out for pizza or Chinese food, it was usually a special occasion of some kind. On a few really special occasions, we ventured out to Helmand, an Afghan restaurant in East Cambridge. To a teenager’s eyes, the restaurant was romantic, not to say exotic: flatbread fresh from the oven! Pumpkin appearing in dishes other than pumpkin pie!

headline: When Hospital Overcrowding Becomes Personal

Yet for one local commuter, who also is a musician, the impending traffic jams represent a green light to practice his craft.

headline: A Burger and a Happy Homecoming
text: I am a quarter of the way through my first, yearlong tour in Afghanistan. I recently left my base in eastern Afghanistan and made the three-day journey home to Michigan via Qatar, Kuwait, Ireland and Atlanta. During my layover in Atlanta waiting for my final flight, I did what any American would do after a long hiatus in a foreign land: I ate fast food. That’s how I found myself sitting at the Wendy’s in Concourse C of Atlanta’s Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport reflecting on my return to America.

headline: A Contentious ‘Killing’ Gets Some Emmy Love
text: When Mireille Enos learned Thursday morning that she’d been nominated for her portrayal of Detective Sarah Linden on the AMC drama “The Killing,” she was far from that murder mystery’s gloomy setting of Seattle, at least geographically. She was in London, filming the zombie horror film “World War Z,” when her manager and her publicist interrupted the undead apocalypse to advise her of the Emmy honor.

headline: Vitamins to Prevent Vision Loss

text: Trust your gut. Do your research. You can make yourself crazy. You can’t be too careful.

headline: Jane Austen Manuscript Sold for $1.6 Million
text: A heavily corrected unfinished draft of an early Jane Austen manuscript sold at auction at Sotheby’s in London on Thursday for almost 1 million pounds ($1.6 million), three times the estimated presale price, The Associated Press reported. The draft of “The Watsons” went to an unidentified buyer; Sotheby’s said it is the only major manuscript by Austen still in private hands.

headline: In a Fantasyland of Liars, Trust No One, and Keep Your Dragon Close
text: With the arrival of “A Dance With Dragons,” Book 5 in George R. R. Martin’s rousing “Song of Ice and Fire” cycle, it’s high time we drove a stake through the heart of J. R. R. Tolkien and “The Lord of the Rings.” Like its predecessors “Dance” has its share of flagons ’n’ dragons, and swords ’n’ sorcerers, but that doesn’t make Mr. Martin the American Tolkien, as some would have it. He’s much better than that.

headline: Debate Over the Egg Industry Agreement
text: Last week, the Humane Society of the United States and the United Egg Producers issued a joint press release announcing their intent to urge Congress to pass an (evidently) already-agreed-upon series of improvements for the nation’s 280 million egg-laying hens. This sent most animal rights activists, much of the food policy press and many concerned, aware consumers into a frenzied victory dance. At least it appeared that way on my Twitter feed.

headline: For Carl Andre, Less Is Still Less
text: THE work of Carl Andre, one of the only Minimalists to accept the term, is often as barely there as sculpture can get. In the first book to survey his ascetic half-century career, a maximalist doorstop published this month by Phaidon, the art historian Alistair Rider relates the story of a German artist who enthusiastically sought out Mr. Andre’s work at a gallery in 1967, only to become confused when he couldn’t find it. This was because the work, 100 square plates of hot-rolled steel arranged in a rectangle almost completely covering the gallery entryway, was directly beneath his feet. He had mistaken it for the flooring, a mistake that comes with the territory in Andre country, where art — as Mr. Andre has said — gets perilously “close to zero,” meant to be experienced as much with the body as with the eyes and mind.

headline: Bank Earnings Season Starts on a High Note
text: Bank earnings season has begun, a quarterly ritual in which the nation’s biggest banks emphasize their gains and explain away their losses on early-morning conference calls with analysts and investors. The stock market then gives its verdict.

headline: Matthew Weiner Explains Why ‘Mad Men’ Will (Hopefully) End Like ‘Abbey Road’

So here are all the details we could squeeze from him on Thursday afternoon in a 10-minute conversation about the show’s latest Emmy bounty and his coalescing plans to end the series.

headline: The Buzz Around Jim Brown

Rhoden got him to sit in the barber’s chair as part of a continuing series of interviews. Brown discusses his support of Muhammad Ali during the Vietnam War, the current N.F.L. labor situation, his concerns regarding the rule changes that reduce the physical nature of pro football, and why he left the game (Raquel Welch?) at age 29.

headline: Genetic Code of E. Coli Is Hijacked by Biologists
text: Synthetic biology, the quest to hijack living systems and convert them to human-directed goals, is on the march. Last year biologists synthesized the entire genome of a small bacterium and showed how it could successfully infect a second bacterium. Now, in what may be a more significant advance, biologists have shown they can radically change a genome, not just copy it.

She was chosen by Photo District News as one 30 new and emerging photographers to watch in 2011. Her conversation with Kerri MacDonald for the Turning Point series has been edited and condensed.

headline: Transportation Department to Test Collision Warning Systems
text: On Wednesday, the Transportation Department announced that it would begin tests of electronic crash-avoidance warning systems in August. The Connected Vehicle Safety Pilot Program is designed to determine how test participants, all ordinary drivers, respond to hazard alerts, how accepting they are of the technology and how effective the systems are in different driving environments.

headline: London Theater Journal: A ‘Much Ado’ With Dr. Who
text: My mind wasn’t up to lofty things Wednesday night. Jet lag, which had been crouching in corners since I arrived last weekend, finally decided to leap out and smack me around. And that double martini at lunch probably hadn’t been a good idea. By 7:30 all I really wanted was to stay at home, horizontal, and watch something silly, trashy, a tad shameful – maybe a vintage 1980s Britcom on one of those recycling channels where they advertise miracle diet pills.

headline: Holbein Sells for More Than $70 Million, Says Dealer
text: A German billionaire has paid more than 50 million euros ($70 million) to buy an oil painting of the Madonna by Hans Holbein the Younger, Bloomberg News reported. Reinhold Wuerth, a manufacturer of screws and other industrial hardware, bought the painting from the heirs of the princes and landgraves of the state of Hesse, according to an e-mailed statement sent Thursday by Britta Fischer Public Relations on behalf of the Wuerth Collection, Bloomberg reported. The Staedel Museum, where the painting has been displayed since 2003 on long-term loan, said in a statement that it had tried to buy the work itself, but that its offer of 40 million euros ($57 million) was rejected. Christoph Graf Douglas, the art dealer who handled the sale, would not give the final purchase price but said it was more than 50 million euros. The painting, “The Madonna With the Family of Mayor Meyer,” from 1525-28, depicts the mayor of Basel’s family–to whom it belonged for nearly 100 years–at the feet of the Madonna.

headline: The Musicals of Andrew Lloyd Webber
text: Photos of “Cats,” “The Phantom of the Opera” and other shows.

headline: Contador Fades at End of Grueling Stage and Loses Time to Top Rivals
text: LUZ-ARDIDEN, France — Alberto Contador, the defending champion of the Tour de France, lost precious time to his main rivals Thursday in a grueling stage in which he had been expected to begin a long-awaited push.

headline: Lloyd Webber’s Latest Creation: Breathing Space
text: LONDON -- Andrew Lloyd Webber has earned seven Tony Awards, a knighthood and hundreds of millions of dollars for writing some of the most popular musicals of all time, from his 1968 breakthrough, “Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat,” to “The Phantom of the Opera,” the longest-running show ever on Broadway. Nearly as legendary is his ego, a self-confidence worthy of an impresario whose success has long emboldened him to think on grand scales.

headline: Louis C. K. Learns to Appreciate an Emmy Nomination
text: We anticipated that Louis C. K. might react to the news that he’d been nominated for an Emmy (as lead actor in his FX comedy series, “Louie”) the same way that a timid audience member might react to his so-honest-till-you-can’t-take-it-anymore standup performances: by covering his eyes and hanging his head in shame.

headline: Italy to Adopt Austerity Plan to Fend Off a Debt Crisis

headline: 36 Hours in Bar Harbor, Me.
text: THERE are summer resorts that get busier and more chic over the years. And then there are the ones, like Bar Harbor, Me., that feel deliciously frozen in time. Don’t look for Starbucks, McDonald’s or Ralph Lauren here. Fashion shoppers stop at places with names like Cool as a Moose. Carmen Verandah and the Thirsty Whale are among the evening hot spots. Bar Harbor is the largest town on Mount Desert Island, and nearby Acadia National Park encompasses some 50 square miles. The rest of Mount Desert belongs to residents and a tony array of summer tenants: Brooke Astor summered here, as did myriad Rockefellers and, once upon a time, the town of Northeast Harbor had so many Philadelphia families that it was dubbed “Philadelphia on the rocks.” They all came lured by the striking setting of mountains, woodlands, lakes and ocean waves crashing against granite cliffs. Then and now, Mount Desert has served as a glorious nature camp for biking, hiking and boating. At day’s end, a visitor can cozy up with a blueberry beer and lobster. Evening strollers can watch sailboats drop anchor and the mist slip down over the hundreds of islands that dot the water.

headline: 36 Hours in Bar Harbor, Me.
text: This summer resort feels frozen in time.

headline: Searching for the Wives of Wall Street

text: Trailer for "The Future" starring Miranda July.

headline: A Pile-Up of Public Service Messages in the Subway
text: It wasn’t my imagination after all. Train announcements at 59th Street-Columbus Circle were so plentiful, audible and detailed — be careful what you wish for, as we are ever reminded —that it seemed at times as if they never ended. No more rumble of a subway train; a trip underground had become a nonstop serenade by the voice of Carolyn Hopkins: “Ladies and gentlemen, the next Brooklyn-bound local train is now arriving. Please stand away from the platform edge, especially when trains are entering and leaving the station.”

headline: City Hall Accused of Steamrolling Opposition to Bronx Shelter

headline: Photo Finish for NBC and CBS
text: A game show, a talent show and a dating show lifted NBC into a virtual tie for first place with CBS in the ratings on Wednesday night as NBC drew about as many viewers on average as CBS’s lineup of “Big Brother” and crime show reruns. According to Nielsen’s estimates, NBC’s reality competition “America’s Got Talent” earned the night’s largest audience with 11 million viewers at 9 p.m., but the network lagged behind CBS the rest of the night as “Minute to Win It” garnered just 4.8 million at 8 and “Love in the Wild” drew 5.1 million at 10.

headline: Scattered Attempts at Carbon Capture
text: As my colleague John Broder and I reported in Thursday’s paper, American Electric Power is dropping its plan to build a commercial-scale version of a carbon dioxide scrubber at Mountaineer, its coal-fired power plant in New Haven, W.Va. The company decided that since public service commissions in West Virginia and Virginia had refused to give it full reimbursement for a pilot version that it ran for two years, it could not expect to recover its investment for the full-scale version — even if the Energy Department was going to pony up $334 million, or half the cost.

headline: Aftershocks Pose Major Obstacles to Rebuilding New Zealand City
text: CHRISTCHURCH, NEW ZEALAND — The once bustling central business district resembles a wasteland. Office furniture can be seen sitting inside partially collapsed buildings. Piles of bricks and steel lie along the closed, empty streets.

headline: The 405 Closing: a Myriad of Options to Keep Angelenos Moving

The planned work threatens to clog surface streets near the Interstate, leading many Angelenos to call the impending amalgam of bottlenecks, honked horns and frayed nerves Carmageddon.

headline: A Book Critic at the Ballet
text: A few years ago, The Guardian had the witty idea to ask its sports writers and cultural critics to swap jobs for a day. The results were delightful. An observation from the newspaper’s rugby columnist, Thomas Castalgnede, sent to review a production of “Tosca” at the Royal Opera House, has stuck with me. “What I saw in ‘Tosca’ was exactly what drew me to sport,” he wrote. “I just love to watch people give it everything — in any walk of life.”

text: The only limerick I have ever really appreciated was written in Bob Marshall’s 1981 book, “Diary of a Yankee-Hater.” It was about Billy Martin, the former Yankees manager who in a drunken rage attacked an honest-to-goodness marshmallow salesman. headline: Ready to Take a Faithful Leap

Finding his story charming and amusing, I laughed.

headline: Romance With No Recipe
text: The season’s weather has had no effect on the efforts of the people who deliver the mail to Mr. Critic’s garret on West 41st Street. There were questions this week from people celebrating marriages and those who might be doing so soon, as well as from visitors from afar. You may as ever send your inquiries about where to eat in New York City to me at dinejournal@nytimes.com. I will do my best to answer. Please be as specific in your needs as possible. As in therapy, so too in restaurant advice: you must start at the beginning, and tell me what you feel.
