headline: Ron Paul’s First Ad Attacks Debt Limit Talks
text: Representative Ron Paul’s campaign is investing six figures in its first television ad buy. The 65-second spot promoting his candidacy for president will start running Friday in Iowa and New Hampshire, according to the campaign’s chairman, Jesse Benton.

headline: An Emmy Shake-Up in Late Night
text: “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” may have received its first-ever Emmy nomination on Thursday, but that doesn’t mean its host, Jimmy Fallon, is full of unadulterated joy.

headline: Theater Listings: July 15 — 21
text: Theater

headline: New Herbicide Suspected in Tree Deaths
text: A recently approved herbicide called Imprelis, widely used by landscapers because it was thought to be environmentally friendly, has emerged as the leading suspect in the deaths of thousands of Norway spruces, eastern white pines and other trees on lawns and golf courses across the country.

headline: 7 Estonian Hostages Set Free in Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Seven Estonians who were kidnapped nearly four months ago while cycling in Lebanon’s eastern Bekaa Valley were released Thursday, Lebanese officials said.

headline: Paul Taylor Leaps Over to the Koch
text: THE corpse is still warm, and already they are dancing past it.

headline: Sudan Strikes Could Be War Crimes, Report Says
text: UNITED NATIONS — An unpublished report from the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Sudan gives details of violence that has erupted in an important border state, including widespread aerial bombardments that kill civilians, executions, possible mass graves and attacks on churches.

headline: Ralcorp to Spin Off Post Foods to Shareholders
text: 7:22 p.m. | Updated

headline: In Vermont, a Beloved Car Collector’s Barn Awaits a New Herd
text: In North Bennington, Vt., some know it simply as “Terry’s Barn.” The unfinished four-story combination home and multicar garage, now for sale, was owned by Terry Ehrich, the longtime editor and publisher of Hemmings Motor News.

headline: Dr. Dolittle’s Kind of Co-op
text: OVER on Lenox Hill, one block south of Hunter College, are two back-to-back apartment houses covered with storks, monkeys, pelicans, owls, hounds and a particularly uncuddly set of rabbits.

headline: O’Neal Joining ‘Inside the NBA’
text: If a delicate balance exists in the chemistry that makes TNT’s “Inside the NBA” a successful and amusing studio program, will a huge new ingredient named Shaquille O’Neal alter it? The camaraderie that binds Charles Barkley, Kenny Smith and Ernie Johnson as a team is difficult to imitate — as ESPN has shown — so why try to change the chemical balance? The answer: because Shaq exists.

headline: The Latest on Debt Ceiling Negotiations; Fundraising Numbers for the Presidential Candidates
text: The latest on the negotiations to raise the U.S. debt ceiling and a look at the fundraising numbers for the current candidates for president. National political correspondent Jeff Zeleny and Washington correspondent Mark Landler join Michael Shear, chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com.

headline: In One Place: Store, Cafe and Hangout
text: On summer evenings, a tree-lined strip of Dyckman Street — a main thoroughfare in Inwood, near Manhattan’s northern prow — becomes a giant block party. Crowds from several splashy bars spill onto the sidewalk, clutching beers and cigarettes as they chatter loudly and peck away on their smartphones.

headline: 4 Out of 5 in Community College Want to Transfer, Report Says
text: As many as four out of five community college students in the United States want to transfer to a four-year institution so they can obtain a bachelor’s degree, according to a report released Thursday by the College Board.

headline: Condos Steal a Page (or 20) From Co-ops
text: AT first glance, 255 Hudson Street looks like a typical SoHo condominium, with a soaring glass facade, million-dollar listings and a chic designer lobby. But despite having housed entertainment figures like Bethenny Frankel and Kirsten Dunst, this building has more in common with a conservative Park Avenue co-op than a celebrity-friendly downtown high rise.

headline: At the Table, Like Father, Like Son?
text: My boyfriend of five years, with whom I try not to nitpick, has terrible table manners. He eats standing up, with his fingers, and picks food off my plate without permission. When I raise the subject, it results in hurt feelings and no improvement. Then I spent time with his family: His dad eats the same way. Since my boyfriend finds his father’s table manners gross, would it be helpful to point out their similarity?

headline: After Rent Rise, Time to Pull Up Stakes
text: NOT all that long ago, rental prices were low enough for Jeni Aron to afford an alcove studio in a luxury doorman building, Hudson Crossing, on Ninth Avenue and 37th Street. She enjoyed a nicely furnished lobby, a landscaped patio, a storage room for her bicycle and a 24-hour gym that she used early in the morning.

headline: Republican Attacks Persist for Consumer Bureau
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans threatened Thursday to roll back the scope and authority of the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau even before it officially opens for business next week.

headline: Was It Love? The ‘Manacled Mormon’ and His Kinky Weekend
text: By virtue of its title alone, “Tabloid,” Errol Morris’s astonishing new documentary, achieves a degree of serendipitous timeliness. Mr. Morris, as usual unseen, though occasionally heard shouting questions from off screen, trains his prying, voracious eyes on England in the 1970s. It was a time ripe with newspaper sleaze that offered premonitions of the present day, even as the prevailing vices, carnal and journalistic, may seem quaint by current standards.

headline: The Guilty Pleasure of a Drive Through Central Park
text: “Go through the park,” Dudley Moore slurs to his chauffeur in the 1981 film “Arthur,” his character giddy and drunk and in need of simple and profound pleasure. “You know how I love the park.”

headline: In Sunny Rome, Solving a Murder Involves Sharp Suits and Sexy Talk
text: Michael Dibdin, the British crime novelist and professional Italophile, died four years ago, having left behind 11 novels centered on Aurelio Zen, the stylish Venetian detective whom he dispatched throughout Italy to solve murders typically executed against the backdrop of political corruption, Mafia wrongdoing and aristocratic entitlement.

headline: The Appeal of Adjustable Rates
text: THE 30-year fixed-rate loan has earned its reputation as the sensible, conservative move in the aftermath of the financial crisis, especially with near-low interest rates. But despite risks, some borrowers still are getting or keeping adjustable-rate loans, which have even lower rates.

headline: Rupert Murdoch Defends His Company and His Son
text: In an interview with The Wall Street Journal, a newspaper he owns, Rupert Murdoch defended the way his son James has handled the phone-hacking scandal and said that News Corporation had responded to the misconduct by its tabloid journalists “extremely well.”

headline: Burdened in a Ravaged South Africa
text: “Life, Above All,” a grave and quietly moving story about a South African girl of extraordinary character, does something that few painful dramas accomplish: It tells a tale of resilience without platitudes about the triumph of the human spirit or without false promises about an unclouded future. The battle fought by its 12-year-old heroine, who struggles to save her family and best friend from prejudiced neighbors who often look like a mob, may be over when the movie comes to its stirring close, but there’s no end to the fight.

headline: Nathan Lane to Star in ‘The Iceman Cometh’ in Chicago
text: Nathan Lane will play one of the stage’s great dramatic characters — the doomed salesman Theodore (Hickey) Hickman — in the Goodman Theater’s revival of Eugene O’Neill’s “Iceman Cometh” in spring 2012, the Chicago-based theater announced on Thursday.

headline: Signs of Improvement in Age-Restricted Market
text: STARTING in 2009, the bottom fell out of the age-restricted housing market in New Jersey, as people 55 and older made the decision to “age in place” rather than try to sell their longtime homes in an uncertain real estate environment.

headline: More Wall Street Banks Grab Groupon I.P.O.
text: Wall Street is lining up for a piece of Groupon’s initial public offering.

headline: Porches Reclaim Their Place
text: UNTIL recently, Lynn Hock, a designer with an architectural degree, was a midcentury modernist — “definitely not an old house person,” she said. But that changed this spring when, after years of looking for a home in the Hudson River village of Hastings-on-Hudson, she and her husband, Jonathan Hock, a documentary filmmaker, walked up the steps of an 1851 Gothic Victorian with a broad, welcoming porch laced with gingerbread trim — and fell in love.

headline: Condemning Slavery With a Paintbrush
text: Misinformation has spread widely about Robert S. Duncanson, an African-American painter. Before and during the Civil War he specialized in portraits of abolitionists and landscapes as exotic as Roman ruins and Kashmir glades. Art historians rediscovered him in the 1920s, but soon muddied his biography with legends and typos.

headline: Illustrating Damsels in Distress and Emissaries From Our Deep, Dark Ids
text: Mayor La Guardia was appalled. Out for a walk one day in Manhattan in 1942, he happened upon a store displaying a copy of a periodical called Spicy Mystery. In lurid hues and slashing graphic style, its cover pictured a curvaceous, terrified young woman in a partly shredded dress hanging by bound hands from a hook alongside slabs of meat. She was menaced by a demented, knife-wielding brute of a man who looked back over his shoulder at whoever was holding the gun that cast its shadow on him. Shocked and dismayed, the mayor vowed to ban all such scurrilous literature from his fair city.

headline: Building New, Looking Older
text: OYSTER BAY

headline: Earle S. Altman
text: Mr. Altman, 79, is the chairman and a founder of ABS Partners Real Estate, a brokerage, management and consulting firm that also invests in commercial property.

headline: Q & A
text: Personal Liability of Board Members

headline: Harmonies From Outer Space
text: There was a time when a cappella was one of music’s best-kept secrets. Relatively few people were aware of just how sophisticated the genre had become or how many sounds the best a cappella singers could draw on: not just standard notes, but vocal percussion, orchestral imitation and more.

headline: Keeping Score: Sizing Up Trade Needs in the A.L. East
text: For the last three seasons, the Red Sox, the Yankees and the Rays have jockeyed among themselves for the American League East title and the A.L.’s wild-card berth, with each team missing the playoffs once. In 2011, these three teams are again atop the East, with the Red Sox leading at the All-Star Game break and the Rays having the most ground to make up.

headline: Always Moving, Always Frozen
text: In those rare lulls when there’s no live dance to see in New York — summer brings a few — there’s still dance in its galleries. At the Metropolitan Museum, I start on the ground floor with the Hellenistic bronze of a veiled and masked dancer, less than nine inches tall. A masterpiece of implication, it firmly shows, by means of surface alone, the lines and twists of the dancing figure beneath layers of fabric. At the Museum of Modern Art, in Matisse’s painting “La Danse,” five nude women create an image of primeval dance as they circle before an empty blue sky and a green grass sward.

headline: Opera Star Tries Doin’ What Comes Natur’lly
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.

headline: Taking a Look at the Governor, Back When He Was a Democrat
text: Gov. Rick Perry, a no-apologies conservative known for slashing government spending and opposing all tax increases, is about as Republican as you can get.

headline: News Corp. Hires Top Criminal Defense Lawyer
‘Prime Suspect’: Returning to the Source
text: The pursuit of happiness is relentless on American television. Even the most willful, irascible loners find true love in the end. Brenda, the bossy and single-minded homicide detective played by Kyra Sedgwick on “The Closer,” got married. Mary, the misanthropic United States Marshal played by Mary McCormack on “In Plain Sight,” is expecting a baby.

headline: Intense Drama, Via the Catwalk
text: Although summer is considered the off season for New York theater, there’s always plenty to see from Memorial Day to Labor Day. “Hair” is back, swinging its free-loving tresses on Broadway, where Maria Callas is also giving life lessons courtesy of Terrence McNally and Tyne Daly in “Master Class.” Visiting Britons from the Royal Shakespeare Company are mounting five full-scale productions at the Park Avenue Armory.

headline: A Festival With a Lot of Wiggle Room
text: I try never to let a summer go by without spending some quality time at Tanglewood. But as much as I enjoy the atmosphere (and most times, the performances) at the Boston Symphony’s weekend concerts at the Koussevitzky Music Shed, for me the most stimulating programming is the annual Festival of Contemporary Music, now held at Seiji Ozawa Hall.

headline: Nobody Wins the Debt Default Blame Game
text: The chances of a default on the United States debt are still fairly small. The prices for credit default swaps, financial instruments that pay investors in the event that a default happens, imply just a 0.05 percent chance, or 1-in-2,000, of a default occurring within the next year, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Riding in Cars With Music
text: Get me to my car, stat. Windows down. Sun roof back. Radio blaring, damaging the already tender speakers. It’s where music sounds best, where a new song jumping out of the radio can be enough to put nearby drivers at risk. Two a.m., F.D.R. Drive, “Make It Rain” bouncing off the car frame — that’s when things make sense.

headline: N.B.A. Lays Off 11 Percent of Workers
text: More than 100 N.B.A. employees were laid off this week, heightening the sense of economic distress as the league’s owners and players haggle over a new labor agreement.

headline: A Few Hours for the Best of Youth
text: One of the perks of my job is that I get a lot of free DVDs in the mail, and one of the frustrations is that there is never enough time to watch them. This summer, though, I am determined to find a few hours for “Zazie Dans le Métro.” This 1960 Louis Malle film, released by the Criterion Collection in June, is one of the movies that made me who I am today.

headline: A Great Guide (Apologies to Its Author)
text: Pauline Kael died 10 years ago this summer, only a few days before 9/11; most remembrances of her were lost in the haze and fury. I’ve been thinking about Kael a lot recently, missing her bawdy and crackling voice, wondering what she’d say if she were alive to weigh in on, say, “Black Swan” or “The Social Network.” (I suspect she’d have smacked both around, while finding things to enjoy about David Fincher and Aaron Sorkin’s work in the Facebook movie.)

headline: The All-American
text: John Kerry surprised a lot of people when he endorsed Barack Obama for president in early 2008. Kerry was a longtime friend of Obama’s chief rival, Hillary Clinton. He had served in the Senate for a quarter-century and had built a reputation as a cautious, incremental figure — like Clinton herself. But for Kerry the time had come for a decisive break with the past. “I felt very strongly we needed a new narrative for the country,” he told me during a long conversation last fall.

headline: An Artist Shows His Train of Thought
text: It has become something of an annual tradition at the Matthew Marks Gallery to invite one of its artists to organize a summer exhibition, and this year it is Thomas Demand. He has taken over the gallery’s West 22nd Street space in Chelsea, reconfiguring it with an installation of labyrinthine walls based on a drawing by the artist Martin Boyce and presenting a show opening Tuesday called “La Carte d’Après Nature.”

headline: A House Tour for Cinephiles
text: When he arrived in Los Angeles, the architect John Lautner said that he was so shocked that he was physically ill for a year. “It was so ugly,” he said of the city where, for the next 50 years or so, he nonetheless built some of the most celebrated buildings of the 20th century.

headline: 4 Charged in Smuggling Egyptian Antiquities
text: Federal authorities announced on Wednesday that they had broken up an international ring that had been smuggling Egyptian antiquities into the United States. The Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s Homeland Security Investigations department said it was the first time that a cultural property smuggling network had been dismantled in the United States.

headline: Taxi Fare for the Uncommon Man
text: Having seen Simon Russell Beale memorably embody the most noble of princes (in the title role of “Hamlet”), the baddest of all lieutenants (as Iago in “Othello”) and the most fatuous of fops (in Dion Boucicault’s “London Assurance”), I am looking forward to his portrayal of someone to whom superlatives do not apply. That’s Jimmy MacNeill, the willfully anonymous London taxi driver of “Bluebird,” a 1998 play by Simon Stephens receiving its American premiere this August in an Atlantic Theater Company production.

headline: $4 Million Welcome for Lynch at Bank of America
text: Gary Lynch, the former chief legal officer at Morgan Stanley who decamped to Bank of America this year, received a stock award worth approximately $4 million from his new employer, a regulatory filing showed.

headline: BIRGIR ANDRESSON AND POUL GERNES: ‘Bolt Out of the Blue’
text: Sean Kelly Gallery

headline: Walkout Sours Global Whaling Conference
text: A meeting of the International Whaling Commission ended in disarray on Thursday when Japan and its allies used the most basic of procedural maneuvers to kill a proposal to protect whales in the southern Atlantic: they walked out.

headline: ‘LEIDY CELESTE NICOLE’
text: Museum 52

headline: House Tour: Greenport, N.Y.
text: A city couple used their instincts, travels and professional background to salvage a rundown North Fork property.

headline: ‘KATHERINE BERNHARDT, ALFRED JENSEN, CHRIS JOHANSON, CHRIS MARTIN, ANDREW MASULLO ANDJUDITH SCOTT’
text: Mitchell-Innes & Nash

headline: House Tour: Greenport, N.Y.
text: WHAT Three-bedroom house on a tiny waterfront lot.

headline: HAAS & HAHN: ‘Painting Urbanism:Learning From Rio’
text: Storefront for Art and Architecture

headline: Why Is Contemporary Art Addicted to Violence?
text: Well-meaning laments about violence in the media usually leave me wanting to bash someone upside the head with a tire iron. To begin with, the reformist spirit is invariably aimed down the rungs of cultural idioms, at cartoons, slasher films, pornography, rap music and video games, while the carnage and bloodletting in Shakespeare, Goya and the Bible get a pass. Low-culture violence is literal, while high-culture violence is symbolic or allegorical and subject to critical interpretation. Low-culture violence coarsens us, high-culture violence edifies us. And the lower the cultural form, or the ticket price, or — let’s just say it — the presumed education level of the typical viewer, the more depictions of violence are suspected of inducing mindless emulation in their audiences, who will soon re-enact the mayhem like morally challenged monkeys, unlike the viewers of, say, “Titus Andronicus,” about whose moral intelligence society is confident.

headline: For 9/11, a Flag and a Day of Service
text: Members of Congress on Thursday made stitches in part of the National 9/11 Flag, a torn and discolored American flag that hung at the World Trade Center site in the weeks after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: ‘EVERYTHING MUST GO’
text: Casey Kaplan

headline: For ‘Justified,’ No Best Drama Nod but No Complaints
text: “Justified,” the Kentucky crime drama on FX, is appearing on various Emmy snub lists, but don’t expect to hear any complaining from Walton Goggins, the excitable actor who plays a cagey ex-con on the series.

headline: ‘CATCH THE MOON IN THE WATER’: Emerging Chinese Artists
text: James Cohan Gallery

headline: Biggest Coal Company and Coal Country Collaborate on Mega Mine
text: A newly announced partnership between the world’s biggest private coal mining company and coal-burning country cuts against recent efforts to paint China green because of its push on manufacturing wind turbines and solar panels. All of its efforts on renewable energy come atop ongoing expansion of its use of coal.

headline: McCartney at the Plate
text: When the Beatles played at Shea Stadium on Aug. 15, 1965 (and again on Aug. 23, 1966), I was a little puzzled, maybe even a little miffed, at their choice of location. As an 11-year-old I had what I figured was a clear idea of what was right and proper, and to me the spanking new Shea Stadium was the home of the Mets, an upstart team that seemed destined forever to inhabit the basement in the National League standings, and not, therefore, the kind of place that deserved the Beatles’ magic. As I saw it, the Beatles were to music as the Yankees were to baseball, and if they were going to play at a baseball stadium, Yankee Stadium was the place for them.

headline: A Brazilian Master of Genre Mixes
text: The Brazilian songwriter Tom Zé doesn’t make a habit of performing in New York or in the United States. The last time he toured was in 1999, backed by the Chicago instrumental band Tortoise. And there’s no one like him in Brazilian music or, for that matter, anywhere. So it’s a coup that the Lincoln Center Festival has booked him for a concert at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday.

headline: Authority, From God to Dad
text: The first and only time I saw “The Tree of Life,” Terrence Malick’s solemn contemplation of God, family and creation, the mostly older audience at the Lincoln Plaza Cinemas remained as silent and motionless as a church congregation rapt in prayer. I quickly adjusted to the reverential mood of a film whose monumental images of erupting volcanoes and churning seas, as many have observed, recall Stanley Kubrick’s “2001: A Space Odyssey.”

headline: The Conductor Will Also Direct
text: The main reason I am looking forward to the Mostly Mozart Festival’s production of “Don Giovanni” is that the Hungarian conductor Ivan Fischer and the Budapest Festival Orchestra are top-notch Mozart performers. The orchestra was formed in 1983 by Mr. Fischer and the brilliant pianist Zoltan Kocsis, who recruited talented, eager and adventurous young Hungarian musicians.

headline: Visiting the Original Birdland
text: It has not escaped my attention that birds are some of the greatest musicians in the world. One afternoon last year in Washington Heights, I stopped for a while to listen to a little songbird up on a street lamp, throwing down a long and miraculous series of patterns in what sounded like changing keys: olé, you poet, you beast. Best thing I had heard all week.

headline: For Dark Skies, a Dark Show
text: One of the most pleasurable summer vacations I ever had was spent in an early-19th-century farmhouse in Westport, Mass., one week in August some years ago, when the rain was so blessedly relentless that I had no choice but to watch the first three seasons of “The Wire,” virtually without interruption. I’d come with a file full of recipes and big shellfish ambitions, but once I was introduced to the Barksdales, McNulty, Omar, Bunk, the Baltimore waterfront and Hamsterdam, cooking seemed like a dismal waste of time.

headline: A ‘Who Is It?’ More Than a Whodunit
text: “The Chameleon” fictionalizes an especially colorful chapter in the believe-it-or-not true story of Frédéric Bourdin, a French-born serial impostor and master of disguise who assumed scores of identities, especially those of missing teenagers. The movie focuses on one of his alter egos, Nicholas Barclay, a 13-year-old Texan from a working-class background who vanished without a trace in 1994 and “reappeared” three years later.

headline: A Prescient Novel Retains Its Power
text: A decade after 9/11, it’s worth rereading Don DeLillo’s 1997 masterpiece, “Underworld,” to appreciate how uncannily the author not only captured the surreal weirdness of life in the second half of the 20th century but also anticipated America’s lurch into the terror and exigencies of the new millennium.

headline: The Me My Child Mustn’t Know
text: On a recent weekend morning, I set out with my son to do errands. As we drove from the post office to the health food store, he began fiddling around with the radio, looking for NPR. I reached over and turned it off. He turned it back on. I turned it off again. He shot me a look, puzzled. After all, he knew I enjoyed the fact that, at age 12, he was a fan of public radio.

headline: Saluting a Radio Man Who’s One of a Kind
text: “He put us all on the map. Without his support, you’d be looking at an empty stage.”

headline: At the Met, a Canvas Ahead of Its Time
text: The one thing I want to do this summer is swing by the 20th-century galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and spend some time with “Strasse auf Helgoland II,” a nearly abstract street scene painted in 1924 by the Romanian artist Arthur Segal (1875-1944), who was affiliated with everything from Post Impressionism to Cubo-Futurism, with German Expressionism and Dada in between. Glowing, dramatically shaded geometric planes in tones of brown, blue and green extend outward to cover a wide and ersatz wood frame in this astute and irreverent synthesis of modernist tendencies and tics. It never fails to jolt my eye or remind me that art history is essentially nonlinear and full of overlooked treasures awaiting rediscovery.

headline: His Horizontal Life
text: Randy Kennedy narrates a look at three ground-hugging works by the Minimalist sculptor Carl Andre.

headline: Past Meets Present in Walk After Dark
text: Middle of the night is my time, always has been, especially in New York in the summer. The city looks better, sounds better, feels softer, or at least a little less specific. I think and remember better late, or imagine I do.

headline: Fed Chief Hedges Remarks on Possible New Stimulus
text: A day after he helped lift markets with his testimony, Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, tempered his words. And in reaction, the markets, too, pulled back.

headline: Materials and Their Space
text: A look at the work of the Minimalist artist Carl Andre.

headline: Up Front: Laura Kipnis
text: In books like “Against Love: A Polemic” and “How to Become a Scandal,” Laura Kipnis has combined sharp analysis with blistering wit to challenge prevailing notions about love and sex, power and desire, hubris and retribution in American life. On our cover this week, she reviews “The Art of Cruelty,” by Maggie Nelson, a wide-ranging inquiry into the aesthetic and ethical questions raised by images of brutality in our culture.

headline: An Unlikely Pair, Making Musical Sense
text: Anton Bruckner had a steadfast circle of supporters, including some significant conductors and composers. But, as his obituaries in 1896 made clear, he was more widely seen as a strangely solitary Austrian church musician with oversized ambitions whose sprawling symphonies were earnest yet awkward and self-indulgent works. Bruckner faced setbacks and adversity, and feared that his music would never be appreciated.

headline: An Evangelist, an Atheist and an Act That Tests Faith
text: The American culture war, that combustible, stupefying cocktail of religion, sex, politics and everything else that gets people hot and bothered, represents a rich vein of satiric and dramatic potential. George Ratliff’s “Salvation Boulevard,” adapted from a novel by Larry Beinhart (“Wag the Dog”), suggests that it may sometimes be too rich. The movie, set in and around a Sun Belt megachurch with a charismatic pastor, is a console full of jammed and disconnected hot buttons.

headline: BHP Billiton to Buy Petrohawk for $12.1 Billion
text: 9:16 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Hot List: A Single Pleasure Ere Summer Fades
text: Just one thing, you tell yourself, as the summer slips by like so many summers before it. If you manage to do nothing else for your own pleasure in this season of unclaimed hours, you will read that book, see that movie, watch that show, gaze at that painting, listen to that guitarist. Even people who do these things for a living – the New York Times arts critics – can’t always organize their cultural calendars to include what they most want to do. We asked them to share the single item in, or closely related to, their critical discipline at the very top of their summer bucket list. Here are their selections.

headline: A Desolate Croon That Seethes and Hints at a Band’s Next Phase
text: Maynard James Keenan works in mysterious ways. He juggles three bands: Tool, Puscifer and A Perfect Circle, the one he brought to Hammerstein Ballroom on Wednesday night. He’s a frontman who stays out of the spotlight: on a platform separate from the rest of the band, set back on the stage, lighted so that he is just a silhouette. And he tours at whim. A Perfect Circle’s most recent album, “eMOTIVe” (Virgin), was released in 2004.

headline: A Tree That Shelters Animal Life and Maybe Even a Dead Parent
text: Sadness and longing haunt the films of the French director Julie Bertuccelli, whose gorgeous second feature, “The Tree,” is set in Queensland, Australia, on the outskirts of Brisbane. Here, on the edge of the outback, the environment is so luminous that every outdoor shot has an aura of magical realism.

text: For Children

headline: Interest Rate Stories
text: Something I’ve been meaning to write: there are two different stories about why deficits might drive up interest rates. They’re not at all the same — although members of the pain caucus have deliberately blurred the distinction. And for policy purposes it’s quite crucial to understand what we’re talking about.

headline: Internet Use Affects Memory, Study Finds
text: The widespread use of search engines and online databases has affected the way people remember information, researchers are reporting.

headline: Hundred Acre Gang Is Back in Town
text: It may be easiest to describe “Winnie the Pooh,” an ever so slight, entirely charming new Disney animated feature, by saying what it is not. It is not “Cars 2.”

headline: Ties That Bind: Life-Sustaining Friendships Transcending Life’s Brutalities
text: For those who may have wondered if foot binding, wife beating and a crooning Hugh Jackman could fit into one movie, here’s the short answer: no. At once preposterously genteel and sadistic, “Snow Flower and the Secret Fan,” adapted from the Lisa See novel, turns on two sets of female friends, the first in early-19th-century China, the second in modern Shanghai. What joins all four women, beyond filmmaking folly, is love, feet and the sort of extravagant misery that routinely turned movie theaters into rain forests, drenched with the tears of audiences and characters who were cinema’s ladies of perpetual suffering.

headline: Making Rating Shops Look Good
text: Mortgage securities destroyed the reputations of credit rating agencies. Could sovereign debt restore them?

headline: A Kidnap Thriller Cuts It Close
text: A troubled marriage swerves toward catastrophe in “Daylight,” an unusually delicate psychological thriller that favors suggestion over exposition.

headline: Seeking Your Harry Potter Photos
text: Can you show us your best Hermione? Your finest Dumbledore? Your slickest Snape? The final film in the Harry Potter series opens at midnight tonight and for fans, plenty of magic is likely to happen both onscreen and off. Are you planning to see the film and will you be dressing up? We’re taking photo submissions of all the wizardly costumes you come across. Submit them to http://submit.nytimes.com/harry-potter.

headline: Pakistan: Bail for Terror Suspect
text: A Pakistani court granted bail on Thursday to the person suspected of being the mastermind of a deadly 2009 attack on the Sri Lankan cricket team. The suspect, Malik Ishaq, left, had been kept in jail since 1997 on a series of terrorism charges, and he was showered with rose petals by hundreds of waiting supporters as he left prison. “We will peacefully continue our mission,” Mr. Ishaq told reporters, saying his hard-line Sunni group, Lashkar-e-Jhangvi, would continue to pursue its anti-Shiite struggle through legislative means. The group is suspected to have been a central player in several terror attacks in the Punjab Province of Pakistan, and had been linked to the March 2009 attack, which killed six police guards and two bystanders in the eastern city of Lahore and halted international cricket competitions in Pakistan. The date for the trial has not been set.

headline: A Kindhearted Man in a Small Town
text: Justin Lerner’s debut feature, “Girlfriend,” is set and shot in his Massachusetts hometown, and the story is built around a man in his 20s named Evan, a character inspired by, and played by, a local actor with Down syndrome, Evan Sneider. As you might expect, the film is eminently respectful in its handling of this kindhearted, sexually curious protagonist, at times irritatingly so, as when the camera goes coy and turns away to focus on autumn leaves during one particularly physical encounter.

headline: The Cult of Running
text: Maybe you’ve been corralled by someone who wants to bend your ear for 90 minutes about his fantasy baseball team or his Hummel figurine collection, though you’re not a fantasy baseball player or figurine collector. Such people seem not to grasp the cutoff point between “I’m willing to hear a little bit about your obsession” and “You’ve gone on too long and entered a zone that’s of interest only to other people like you.”

headline: With Deal on Rookie Wages, N.F.L. Lockout Nears the End
text: An agreement in principle that would end the four-month-long N.F.L. lockout is within reach for the first time after negotiators for players and owners finally settled on a rookie wage system, clearing one of the last major hurdles that had separated the sides, a person briefed on negotiations said Thursday.

headline: A Soldier and a Fractured Fairy Tale
text: Shot on 16-millimeter film out in the forest on what must have been a tiny budget, Alex Ross Perry’s “Impolex” deploys the open-ended, low-affect style favored by many young do-it-yourself filmmakers to a grab bag of genres. Taking place just after World War II, it follows the wandering of a handsome, sulky young soldier named Tyrone (Riley O’Bryan) who has found a German V-2 rocket. The movie’s title is an acronym for the explosive-monitoring program in which he is participating, and its plot follows a thread laid down in Thomas Pynchon’s novel “Gravity’s Rainbow.”

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,647 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Thursday:

headline: Sluggish Market Stalls Funds That Thrive on Direction
text: Managed futures funds, which bet on the ups and downs of stocks, bonds, commodities and currencies, have been crowing for years about their performance during the financial crisis.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Anarchists and Tasseled Loafers
text: Amid shattered glass and the black smoke of urban pyres, I found myself in a riot some years ago — the anarchists-led assault on the World Trade Organization meetings of 1999. At the height of what became known as The Battle of Seattle, I bumped into an otherwise mild-mannered, libertarian-leaning friend on the streets, gasping at the bitter taste of tear gas. He was ecstatic.

headline: Just About Anything for Love
text: The unlikely convergence of an opportunistic blonde, a nerdy lottery winner and a clutch of missing persons forms the spine of “Lucky,” an off-kilter romantic comedy suggesting that women — like Meat Loaf — will do just about anything for love.

headline: Tom Vander Ark’s New York-Area Charter Schools Falter
text: After years spent directing the distribution of more than $1 billion from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation into hundreds of schools across the nation, Tom Vander Ark set his sights on the New York area, with a plan to create a network of charter schools of his own.

text: John Kerry has carved out an important role in President Obama's foreign policy. James Traub profiles him in this week's Magazine and reflects on traveling overseas with the Senator.

headline: Japanese Team Comes of Age, and Lifts a Country
text: FRANKFURT, Germany — Shortly before Japan faced the two-time defending champion Germany in the quarterfinals of the Women’s World Cup, Coach Norio Sasaki gave his players solemn, even grim inspiration.

headline: California to Require Gay History in Schools
text: LOS ANGELES — California will become the first state to require public schools to teach gay and lesbian history.

headline: Ireland Confronts the Vatican
text: Throughout the long scandal of sexual abuse by rogue priests, the Vatican has blatantly resisted the idea that civil law must trump church rules in confronting criminal acts. This was evident again in the revelation that the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland continued to cover up abuse cases long after it had issued rules to protect children in 1996.

headline: A Service Station With Actual Service (Forget About Coffee)
text: As you approach this well-heeled town in a county that bills itself the Hamptons of the Chesapeake, don’t be scared off by the seasonal, spray-painted sign at the Citgo that offers a place to butcher your deer carcass.

headline: Another Dirty Water Act
text: Republicans in the House of Representatives — with the support of some key Democrats — seem determined to destroy the intricate and essential web of laws and regulations protecting the country’s environment. Their latest target is the hugely successful 1972 Clean Water Act.

headline: Births Are Outpacing Immigration for Mexican-Americans, Report Says
text: The fast-growing population in the United States of people of Mexican origin increased far more in the last decade from births here than from immigration from Mexico, according to a report on Thursday by the Pew Hispanic Center.

headline: Killing Rattles a Jewish Community’s Long-Held Trust of Its Own
text: Yocheved Schachter, a 47-year-old nurse who lives in Borough Park, Brooklyn, acknowledges that she has a double standard of sorts: one for people who share her background, and one for people who do not.

headline: The Real Winnie the Pooh Returns to the Hundred Acre Wood
text: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood’s formula for freshening up old cartoon characters like Alvin and the Chipmunks and the Smurfs goes something like this: Reformulate them in 3-D, give them a skateboard and sunglasses, add some dance moves and inundate children and their nostalgic parents with advertising.

headline: Drug Ban Pledged by Breeders’ Cup
text: The Breeders’ Cup pledged on Thursday that its annual two-day event would be free of race-day medication by 2013, bringing its drug rules more into line with those in the rest of the world.

headline: More Horrors in Mumbai
text: India’s government showed extraordinary restraint after Pakistani terrorists killed more than 160 people in Mumbai in 2008. The fear ever since then has been that another attack could spark a war between India and Pakistan, rivals with nuclear weapons.

headline: Congestion in Calendar for Fans in Los Angeles
text: CARSON, Calif. — Soccer fans in the Los Angeles area face a potentially frustrating decision Saturday night.

headline: Police Sort Through Suspect’s Account as He Pleads Not Guilty in Killing
text: For a couple of hours on Monday night, Leiby Kletzky, 8, sat in a car outside a catering hall in Rockland County, N.Y.; the windows were rolled down, if the man suspected in his killing is to be believed.

headline: In Petrohawk’s Sale to BHP, a Quest for Capital
text: BHP Billiton‘s $12.1 billion purchase of Petrohawk Energy places a hefty premium on the independent energy company. But in the deal, BHP believes it is getting a bargain.

headline: Soso Rengo Eliminated
text: The Soso Rengo team, a combination of players from three high schools just miles from the crippled nuclear reactors in Fukushima, lost, 8-1, in the opening round of a regional knock-out contest in Fukushima. The team of players sent into exile by the tsunami and nuclear crisis that started in March had hoped to qualify for a trip to the national summer championship tournament in August.

headline: A World Sheltered From TV, if Not Violence
text: Down the block from the home of Levi Aron, the hardware-store clerk accused this week of slaughtering a child in Brooklyn, a neighbor, Miriam Levy, spoke about peculiar qualities that she had discovered only after Mr. Aron’s arrest.

headline: U.S. and China Try to Agree on Military Strategy
text: BEIJING — During three days in China this week, the top American military officer, Adm. Mike Mullen, exchanged warm pledges with his Chinese counterpart to improve the reliably fractious relationship between the two forces. He watched Chinese Su-27 fighters barrel roll over an air base, saw a Chinese counterterrorism exercise in a stifling bunker beneath an army post and squeezed into a Chinese submarine at a naval base.

headline: The Debt Alarm Is Heard
text: As negotiators in the debt-ceiling talks sputtered and raged, the chill reality of an imminent government default crept up Wednesday and made a mockery of their gamesmanship. Two major rating agencies warned that a once-unthinkable downgrade of the nation’s credit rating would be at hand if this crisis was not immediately defused.

headline: TimesCast | Better Being a Beta
text: July 14, 2011 - A new study shows that although alpha males may get all the attention, it could be better being a beta. At least if you're a baboon.

headline: Out of Poverty, Family-Style
text: Shortly after Candace Keshwar immigrated from Trinidad to Boston in 2002, her life took a difficult turn. Her dream had been to go to college and have a career where she could help others. But her first daughter was born with cerebral palsy and Keshwar spent the next seven years caring for her at home. She grew isolated. Her husband worked in construction, but jobs were sporadic, and the family relied on government assistance. “It was a real dark space for me,” Keshwar said. “I kept thinking, ‘This cannot be my life. I know I have the potential to do so much more.’”

headline: Outlaws Make Better Lunches
text: THE past few years have been a golden age for street food in New York City. You could get just about anything from a food truck in Midtown Manhattan — from waffles and schnitzel to halal chicken and lamb over rice — despite the fact that street vending is for all intents and purposes illegal there.

text: GA’A, Libya — Five months after the armed uprising erupted in Libya, a new round of portable antiaircraft missiles — weapons that governments fear could be obtained by terrorists and then fired at civilian jetliners — have been slipping from storage bunkers captured by rebels.

text: WASHINGTON — The endgame in the fight to increase the nation’s debt limit has only begun, but intense exchanges this week between the two parties have made it clear that this is not so much a negotiation over dollars and cents as a broader clash between the two parties over the size and role of government.

headline: Friday: Dark Time For Bards
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s finally Friday, and I’m pleased to say that today we have a grid that is the result of playing well with others. Maybe it really is true that everything we ever needed to know we learned in kindergarten.

headline: O.K., Keep Looking Down: Sidewalks Will Stay Ad-Free
text: In a city in which every possible surface — above-ground and below, mobile and stationary — seems fated to become a vehicle for advertising, sidewalks remain that rare commercial-free zone: a blank canvas on which the harried pedestrian can move through crowds, head down, lost in thought.

headline: Jeter on His Decision: Team Before All-Stars
text: TORONTO — Responding to criticism from some of his peers and the voting public, Derek Jeter defended his decision to not attend Tuesday’s All-Star Game in Arizona in order to rest his right calf. Jeter said Thursday that he felt obligated to make sure his leg was healthy heading into the second half, adding that he was “surprised” that his absence caused such a stir.

headline: Murdoch’s Woes Could Include Bancrofts
text: Add to Rupert Murdoch’s list of potential headaches a blast from the past: the Bancroft family. The media mogul’s British newspaper scandal has upset some members of the family who gave in to News Corporation’s $5 billion offer to buy Dow Jones in 2007.

headline: Kurdish Rebels Kill 13 Turkish Soldiers
text: ISTANBUL — Kurdish rebels fighting for autonomy in southeastern Turkey ambushed a group of soldiers near Diyarbakir on Thursday, killing 13 and wounding 7, the Turkish military said on its Web site.

text: Rules proposed recently by New York State for regulating a controversial form of natural gas drilling are drawing expressions of guarded optimism from the natural gas industry but objections from some environmentalists, who say they do not go far enough in protecting water supplies.

headline: Borg and McEnroe, in Rivalry and Friendship

headline: Colon Is Tentative About His Injury, Raising Yankees’ Concerns
text: TORONTO — Bartolo Colon handed the ball to Joe Girardi without saying a word and began walking toward the Yankees’ dugout. His pace was slow, deliberate, the gait of a man bothered by more than just the shortest — and worst — start of his career. The same left hamstring injury that sidelined him for three weeks once again troubled Colon, who winced while covering first base before leaving.

headline: Death and Budgets

Clendinen is dying of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or A.L.S. If he uses all the available medical technology, it will leave him, in a few years’ time, “a conscious but motionless, mute, withered, incontinent mummy of my former self.”

Seeger, a reclusive, idiosyncratic art collector who disposed of Picassos, Beckmanns and Bacons nearly as fast as he bought them, and who for several years in the 1980s owned Sutton Place, one of Britain’s grandest Tudor estates, died in Whitby, North Yorkshire, on June 24. He was 81.

headline: Henry Carlisle, a Supporter of Oppressed Writers, Dies at 84
text: Henry Carlisle, whose broad literary career included supporting oppressed writers, editing Camus, helping translate and publish Solzhenitsyn, and writing a novel that mused about cannibalism, died on Monday in San Francisco. He was 84.

headline: Rory McIlroy Hangs In During Tough Round
text: SANDWICH, England — The knock on Rory McIlroy, back when there were any knocks on him, was that he did not deal well with adversity, that he would sometimes quit on a bad round or would try so hard to bring it around that it was almost as bad.

headline: A Moral Victory for Jerry Kelly
text: SANDWICH, England — When Jerry Kelly learned that he would be hitting the opening tee shot in the British Open on Thursday at 6:30 a.m. local time, he was amused. After all, eight years should be long enough for the pain to subside from the not-so-funny episode that happened here in 2003.

headline: A Follow-Up on Miero
text: On my win-a-trip journey through Niger last month, I wrote about encountering a starving woman, Miero Finiba, who was also pregnant and had a badly infected leg wound. It looked as if she might lose her leg, lose her baby, and lose her life, from some combination of the infection and hunger (she hadn’t eaten for 24 hours). The win-a-trip student winner, Saumya Dave, a medical student, quite properly became distraught and asked: Is there anything we can do?

headline: In Paris, a Tribute to Davis Featuring Three Famed Alumni
text: The French famously take jazz very seriously, and have for decades warmly welcomed American musicians to their country. So it comes as no surprise that a tribute to one of the greatest of them all, Miles Davis, will take place at the Olympia Theater (28, boulevard des Capucines; 33-892-683-368) on Monday, July 18. Three of his band’s most famous alumni, the pianist and composer Herbie Hancock, the bassist Marcus Miller and the saxophonist Wayne Shorter will be on hand to celebrate him.

headline: The Insider | Paul Kominek
text: The Travel Almanac, the newest of a growing crop of compact niche magazines (see: Apartamento, Boat and Afterzine), looks at the art of travel through the perspectives of artists, musicians, writers and filmmakers who are well, well-traveled. The journal was founded two years ago by Paul Kominek, a musician and sometime D.J. from Germany, with the help of his friend John Roberts, an American musician who, like Kominek, lives in Berlin. “By using the topic of traveling as an overarching theme, it gave us an amazing excuse to ask high-profile artists or cultural icons questions that avoid the obligatory ‘What do you do?’ and ‘How did you get started?’ and instead ask about different aspects of their lives that we personally find more interesting,” says Kominek. The first volume, on Japan, debuted this spring. The cover is printed on textured German cardstock, the interior pages on creamy Swedish drawing paper. It features tips from the likes of David Lynch, James Murphy and Javier Peres, as well as some handsome photographs of traditional Japanese inns, called “ryokans.” T turned the tables on Kominek and asked for his own travel preferences, and his Berlin mainstays.

headline: Weather Clears, but Field Bunches Together
text: SANDWICH, England — The only thing that can be said with any certitude at the halfway mark of the 140th British Open is that neither the No. 1-ranked golfer in the world, Luke Donald, nor the No. 2-ranked golfer in the world, Lee Westwood, will be factors this weekend at Royal St. George’s. The two, each from England, were done in by a seaside links course that will only get tougher.

headline: BP to Tighten Deep-Sea Drilling Practices as It Tries to Rebound
text: LONDON — BP said on Friday that it was changing its deepwater drilling standards in the Gulf of Mexico as it seeks to repair its reputation and resume offshore operations after the disastrous oil spill last year.
