text: Atrios likes to say that the eternal question, as you look at absurd policy debates, is whether these people are evil or stupid.

headline: No Vacancies, but Some Reservations
text: GULF SHORES, Ala. — It seems like old times here on the Gulf Coast. The Flora-Bama Lounge is hopping, there’s a two-hour wait for a table at the Original Oyster House, and the first complaints you hear among the charter boat operators are about the latest fishing limits — not oil slicks.

headline: Security Forces Open Fire on Syrian Protesters
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Even as the now-familiar ritual of Friday protests raged across Syria, activists, diplomats and some government officials suggest that a staggering economy, a better-organized though still divided opposition, and a fumbling government response are recasting Syria, even if President Bashar al-Assad manages to survive in office.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: Dr. Paul Ekman, a psychologist and specialist in the study of emotions and deceit, sits with the artist David Michalek to talk about Mr. Michalek’s new video installation, “Portraits in Dramatic Time,” on view at Lincoln Center. Mr. Michalek’s “Portraits” are short films of actors and artists performing scenes. But the film is wound down to what its creator calls “hyperslow motion,” showing the nuance of each gesture and facial expression, frame by frame, on an 85-by-45-foot screen on the wall of the David H. Koch Theater in the plaza.

headline: Regulators Are Said to Weigh Softer Derivatives Rules
text: Federal regulators are considering backing off a plan to curb Wall Street’s control over the derivatives market, another potential win for the big banks.

headline: Night Owls | Alexis Bittar for Jason Wu
text: All too often, the jewelry that we see at fashion shows makes it only to the end of the runway and back. Thankfully, the owl pin designed by Alexis Bittar for Jason Wu — the one that adorned Wu’s fall peacoats and blazers — is very much real and ours for the buying, arriving in stores on Friday. Fans will recognize the owl, a k a Miss Wu, the designer’s muse and logo (“perhaps because of too many late nights sketching,” Wu says), and also appreciate Bittar’s gutsy take on it. Inspired by the photographer Robert Polidori’s book on the restoration of Versailles, “Parcours Museologique Reviste” (Steidl), the two fell hard for the contrast between grand décor and raw metals. “I love the juxtaposition,” says Wu, who calls his fall collection Baroque Sportswear. “The piece combines opulence with early ’90s grunge,” Bittar says. “And a sense of raw romanticism,” Wu adds. “A perfect complement to the clothes.”

headline: Obama Reiterates Desire for Comprehensive Budget Package
text: President Obama on Friday reiterated his desire to reach a grand bargain that would deal with the nation’s long-term debt problems even as leaders in Washington take action to avoid a financial default by the government.

headline: Libya Rebels Get Formal Backing, and $30 Billion
text: ISTANBUL — The United States formally recognized the rebel leadership in Libya as the country’s legitimate government on Friday, allowing the rebel government access to $30 billion in Libyan assets held in the United States. It is not yet clear how and when the money would be released.

headline: Inflation Day
text: OK, so the new report is out. Headline prices actually down, as predicted, but core inflation running above the Fed target on a monthly basis.

headline: Please Don’t Swat the Bug Tattoo
text: Naked-flesh season is in full swing in New York, with people letting theirs hang out of skimpy bathing suits, half-buttoned shirts and distressed shorts. But a lot of that flesh isn’t as naked as it used to be. These days, it has tattoos on it.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: BP to Adopt Voluntary Safety Standards in the Gulf of Mexico
text: Seeking to assure federal regulators that it has learned the lessons of the Deepwater Horizon blowout and spill last year, BP said on Friday that it would adopt strict new voluntary standards for any future drilling projects in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: ‘Stay Cool and Seldom Speak’
text: A few weeks ago my father recommended that I download “All Eternals Deck,” a new album by the Mountain Goats. Maybe because of his enthusiasm, it took me a while to get into it. At first listen I was put off by the country-tinged voice of the singer and lyricist, John Darnielle. (Despite the plural in its name, the band used to be just Darnielle. Now a drummer and bassist have joined him.)

headline: Saudi Investor Suggested Brooks Had to Go
text: As my colleagues Sarah Lyall and Alan Cowell report, Rebekah Brooks, the embattled chief executive of Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper operations, announced her resignation on Friday, after weeks of pressure.

headline: Bits Pics: Showing the Location of Tweets and Flickr Photos
text: Have you ever wondered where people are located when they post on Twitter or take a digital photo? Eric Fischer, a programmer and designer, recently answered this question by creating a series of maps showing people’s location when they send a Twitter message or upload a photo to Flickr, the photo-sharing Web site.

headline: BMW Fund Takes Stake in Britain-Based Parking Service
text: LONDON — BMW i Ventures, a fund started by BMW in February that invests in urban mobility projects, announced Thursday that it would take a minority stake in ParkatmyHouse, a Web service that pairs motorists with available parking spaces offered by homeowners or businesses in Britain.

headline: Jordanian Police Break Up a Peaceful March With Beatings
text: AMMAN, Jordan — Riot police officers wielding wooden clubs broke up a peaceful demonstration near a square in this city’s downtown on Friday afternoon, beating protesters and journalists. The episode was a sign of rising tension over the slow pace of political reform in the kingdom.

headline: A Word With: Kent Tritle
text: St. Ignatius Loyola, the Roman Catholic church, rests nobly at Park Avenue and 84th Street amid the wealth and power of the Upper East Side. Its music program is equally imposing, an important part of the city’s concert scene. Kent Tritle, the organist and choral conductor, has overseen the church’s lyrical side for 22 years. It’s an established, comfortable perch.

headline: In Fiji, Hands That ‘See’
text: Blind masseurs, known throughout Asia to be excellent therapists because of their heightened sense of touch, are becoming a trend for spa and wellness retreats worldwide.

headline: Santorum Fund-Raising Numbers Near Bottom of G.O.P. Field
text: Rick Santorum, a former Pennsylvania senator, was among the first Republican presidential candidates to file a fund-raising report on Friday with the Federal Election Commission. He raised $582,000 during the last three months, according to his report, and has $229,000 in the bank.

headline: The Royal Shakespeare Company at the Park Avenue Armory
text: The Royal Shakespeare Company at the Park Avenue Armory

headline: The Cubicle Is a Canvas at a Midtown Art Show
text: David Muenzer, a receptionist at the law firm Latham & Watkins, was feeling bored and curious one day in February. He decided to explore the firm’s storage space.

headline: Northwest Rivals Barely Separable on and Off the Field
text: There hasn’t been much between Portland Timbers and Seattle Sounders in their two Major League Soccer clashes this season.

headline: You Say You’re a Dream Renter? Prove It.
text: LANDLORDS in New York City can afford to be picky. With a vacancy rate in Manhattan of under 1 percent, apartments sometimes rent in hours, not days or weeks. Good tenants are not that hard to find. On top of that, evicting problem tenants can be expensive and time consuming.

headline: House Republicans Plan Vote on Deficit
text: With budget negotiations with the White House stalled, Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio said Friday that the House would vote next week on a three-part plan to cut the deficit, cap federal spending as a share of the economy and amend the Constitution to require a balanced budget.

headline: Tale of a Puerto Rican Plantation Mistress
text: If the American South had Scarlett O’Hara as its Civil War antiheroine, the English-speaking Caribbean of the 1800s had Annie Palmer. The real-life mistress of a Jamaican sugar estate during the final days of slavery, Palmer was the subject of legend and many lurid novels, most enduringly 1929’s “White Witch of Rosehall.” Lore says (most likely inaccurately) that Palmer practiced obeah, or sorcery; bedded slaves, then killed them; and murdered three husbands. She set the standard for cruelty and debauchery in a woman presiding over a plantation.

headline: Inventing the Interstate
text: When “On the Road” was published, in 1957, it may have seemed a rousing dawn chorus for an awakening generation of postwar seekers, but it was also an encomium of sorts — for the year before, construction had begun on the National System of Interstate and Defense Highways. “You can’t do what I did anymore,” Kerouac would later say. And as noted in “Why Kerouac Matters,” by the New York Times reporter John Leland, even as Kerouac was writing, the author glimpsed that his kind of rambling “may soon be obsolete as America enters its High Civilization period and no one will get sentimental or poetic anymore about trains and dew on fences at dawn in Missouri.”

headline: How the Robber Barons Railroaded America
text: “Type of the modern! emblem of motion and power! pulse of the continent!” Walt Whitman sang in praise of the railroad. When he published those lines in 1876, the vast network that connected West to East was being widely hailed as the muscular marvel of the industrial age. It sped the bounty of farms and factories across the land, spawned hundreds of towns and cities along its routes, pioneered in marketing and managerial organization, and employed a huge and growing labor force. The men who created and ran the transcontinentals — Leland Stanford, Collis P. Huntington, Jay Gould, Mark Hopkins, Charles Francis Adams Jr., among others — were as famous in their era as such high-tech moguls as Bill Gates and Steve Jobs are today. Their entrepreneurial daring did much to transform the United States into a prosperous, developed nation.

headline: Such a Slick Package, but Gearbox Is a Drag
text: TO the long list of things that have gone awry despite the best of intentions, add the 6-speed automatic transmission in the 2012 Ford Focus — an otherwise admirably redesigned compact car.

headline: Blue Period
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#23", 592, 395, true, chameleonData);

headline: Modern Dance, in Your Hand
text: DANCES for an iPhone began the way most dances don’t: with an injury. But Richard Daniels, who at various times has worked as an arts administrator, a producer and a choreographer, was incapacitated and recovering from shoulder surgery in 2008 when the idea was born.

headline: A Melancholy Werewolf’s Existential Howl
text: It’s easy to see why werewolves might feel under-celebrated these days. While vampires and zombies have stormed the multiplexes and best-­seller lists, and Dr. Frankenstein’s monster has completed its cultural infiltration by transforming into the ubiquitous information appliances of daily life (if my smartphone doesn’t count as artificial life run amok I don’t know what does), werewolves have been largely left to idle at the side of the literary road. Where are these Freudian howlers of the night? Theirs has been rather a raw deal.

headline: Opening the Doors to Serve a Good Cause
text: BUILDING a portfolio of vintage cars can put a collector in the same situation as a dog that chases cars: what do you do once you’ve accomplished your goal?

headline: Chevy Convertibles: He Collected the Full Set
text: Ankeny, Iowa

headline: In New York, the Suddenly Buff Prewar Building
text: THE apartment house at 815 Park Avenue, built in 1916, features classical swags on its facade, large arched windows and a softly lighted lobby hung with museum-quality oils in elaborate frames. Converted to a co-op some 30 years ago, 815 Park seems like the ultimate prewar apartment building, little touched by the passage of time.

headline: Injured Romeo Undergoes Knee Surgery
text: Sam Troughton, the actor playing Romeo who was injured on Tuesday during the Royal Shakespeare Company’s performance of “Romeo and Juliet” at the Park Avenue Armory, has undergone arthroscopic surgery on his knee, according to Nada Zakula, a spokeswoman for the company. She said she did not know if he would be able to return to the role on Sunday, when the next performance is scheduled. The play is being presented as part of the Lincoln Center Festival.

headline: Solar Power for Darker Times
text: Amid the fretting over whether the renewable energy business will be dominated by foreign companies, a California venture that creates solar plants that can run around the clock has cut a deal to build a big plant in Spain, a country that is one of the most aggressive users of solar power.

headline: An Alzheimer’s Mystery Novel
text: Unreliable narrators come in many shapes. There are madmen, mystics, seducers, naïfs — Nabokov’s Humbert Humbert, the ghost-prone governess in “The Turn of the Screw” and Poe’s self-defeating paranoiac in “The Tell-Tale Heart,” for starters. And then there is Dr. Jennifer White, who narrates Alice LaPlante’s first novel. By the time “Turn of Mind” begins, she is losing her wits to Alzheimer’s disease and is the prime suspect in her best friend’s murder. She is as unreliable as they come.

headline: SRT’s Boss, Ralph Gilles, Mulls a Replacement for Dodge Magnum
text: ROSAMOND, Calif. — Could the station wagon make a comeback at Chrysler?

headline: Missing Artworks Said to Be Found in Home of Accused Picasso Thief
text: A man who was arrested in the theft of a Picasso drawing from a San Francisco gallery last week was keeping a virtual museum in his apartment, including 11 works stolen from New York galleries and hotels, according to the police.

headline: In Ukraine, Churches With a Distinctive Allure
text: IN western Ukraine, the side of the highway offers more unusual scenes than many performance-art pieces. On one spring day, an old woman cradled what looked like a baby but was actually a newborn lamb dressed in baby clothes. On another day, a young woman strutted down a dirt road in a micro-mini and precarious heels. Nearby, a pair of young dandies cruised in an ox cart.

headline: Infidelity Keeps Us Together
text: Congratulations to Dan Savage and his mantra “Good, Giving and Game.” And thanks to Mark Oppenheimer for bringing it beyond the alternative weeklies to a wider audience of mainstream, heterosexual couples (“Married, With Infidelities”). Honest communication with your partner surely is something to strive for in a long-term relationship, although it may be difficult at first for some women to define what they want, let alone articulate it.

headline: Devil in a Black Dress
text: Paz de la Huerta has an uncanny ability to attract enemies (and ghosts).

headline: The Would-Be Prince of Port-au-Prince
text: Wyclef Jean was in a rare state: nervous. He was trying to stick to his new role of wonky Haitian statesman, but the road kept distracting him. We were driving through Port-au-Prince as dusk fell, and he would interrupt his own discourse on trade rules or egg imports to ask the driver why a fire was burning on the roadside or to complain that our headlights were tempting danger or to mumble that the police escort, which he suspected of working for the opposition, shouldn’t sound its sirens.

headline: Bonus Feature: The Very First No. 1 Song
text: “Here we go with the Top 40 hits of the nation this week!” These words, spoken by Casey Kasem, kicked off the first broadcast of “American Top 40,” which aired on July 3, 1970, and it was carried by seven radio stations. Kasem, who would become one of the most recognizable broadcasters of his era (as well as providing the voice for Shaggy on “Scooby Doo”), was the host of the show until 1988, when he was replaced by Shadoe Stevens. (Despite his name, Stevens was in no way affiliated with “Scooby Doo.”) Stevens remained until 1994, when ABC canceled the show; it was reborn, under a new owner, in 1998, with Kasem once again as host. Ryan Seacrest joined the show as host in January 2004.

headline: Human Hairballs ’R’ Us
text: One summer Sunday years ago in Philadelphia, I stumbled onto the Mütter Museum. Back then maybe a few hundred people a year bothered to visit. A new director would soon parade human hairballs, pickled organs and Victorian surgical equipment from the museum’s collection on “Late Night With David Letterman,” and after that the Mütter joined institutions like the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Liberace Museum in Las Vegas as beloved American attractions. But that Sunday it was still empty and neglected, a little forbidding from the outside.

headline: A Rat’s Tale
text: I was 6 when my brother John leaned across the kitchen table and casually whispered that he had killed Santa Claus.

headline: Parental Guidance
text: Unable to have biological children, my husband and I went to an adoption agency and were matched with a pregnant woman. She says she signed up because she and her husband can’t afford another child. Adoption will cost around $25,000, of which $8,000 goes to her. My conscience keeps asking me why I don’t just give the $25,000 to the birth mother and let her take care of her own child. My rational mind says this was her choice, and we need each other equally. What do you say? NAME WITHHELD, CHARLOTTE, N.C.

headline: ‘Well, Here It Comes! The Biggest Song in the U.S.A.!’
text: Can you name the No. 1 song right now?

headline: July 17 — 23
text: Art

headline: Who Made This Mess of Planet Earth?
text: The Australian paleontologist and biologist Tim Flannery has earned his broad-brimmed field hat. Flannery is the discoverer of dozens of mammal and dinosaur species, extant and extinct, across Australia and Melanesia. In books like “The Future Eaters” (about the devastation wrought by the settlement of Australia) and “The Weather Makers” (about climate change), he has won accolades as a vivid chronicler of ecological history with an uncommonly broad sweep and an increasingly activist bent.

headline: Are Parents Too Involved in Children’s Sports?
text: One of the best parts of summer is getting children outside and active. The head-butting march of the United States women’s soccer team this particular summer underscores the power of getting physical.

headline: After 8 Decades, Tiny Toad Resurfaces in Asia
text: The Borneo rainbow toad, with its long spindly legs, looks a bit like an Abstract Expressionist canvas splattered in bright green, purple and red. But when this amphibian was last seen, in 1924, the painter Jackson Pollock was just 12, and the only image of the mysterious creature was a black-and-white sketch.

headline: From Honus to Derek, Memorabilia Is More Than Signed Bats
text: THE best birthday present I ever received came from my wife. She gave me a baseball from the 2009 World Series signed by Derek Jeter, the New York Yankees shortstop. I treasure it because he’s my favorite player but also because my newborn daughter slept in my arms while I watched the Yankees win that World Series.

headline: This Unit Definitely Has a ‘Purpose’
text: Remember the book “The Purpose Driven Life”? A new division of a major public relations agency is being driven by purpose.

headline: Time-Travel Adventure to Save the Life of Doctor Who
text: SALFORD, England — The 15 schoolchildren knew they weren’t in danger, but theater still worked its magic as they spied the six-foot-tall stone monster behind them in the corridor of a spaceship. When the dusky lighting went black, and a pulsing strobe light began to illuminate the monster closing in, they let out a collective shriek and fled through a portal that, mysteriously, opened onto a tented fairground where a sign announced the date: “6 July 1888.”

headline: Is There a Perjury Epidemic?
text: James B. Stewart dedicates his new book “to all who seek the truth.” But in his view, the ranks of committed truth-seekers are shrinking before our eyes. “Mounting evidence suggests that the broad public commitment to telling the truth under oath has been breaking down, eroding over recent decades, a trend that has been accelerating in recent years,” he declares. “Perjury has infected nearly every aspect of society.”

headline: After Test Results, European Banks Are Urged to Bolster Reserves
text: LONDON — About two dozen European banks were put under official pressure Friday to bolster their reserves, as the results of financial stress tests created more skepticism over the region’s will to deal with its festering financial crisis.

headline: Novelist John Banville, also known as Benjamin Black; Esmeralda Santiago on her new book, "Conquistadora"; notes from the field; and best-seller news.
text: This week, a conversation with novelist John Banville, who also writes crime fiction under the name Benjamin Black; Esmeralda Santiago on the setting and characters of her new book, "Conquistadora"; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Living In | Bushwick, Brooklyn
text: Bushwick takes its name from the town the Dutch established in 1660, Boswijck, or “heavy woods.” Annie Monguea and Irving Elgodo on Harman Street in front of the the Pa-La Loma Bicycle Club.

headline: A Call to Play Ball in Japan Followed Much Fretting
text: SENDAI, Japan — High school baseball players across Japan dream of playing for the national title in Koshien Stadium, yet few ever go. Teams from Tohoku High School — a sports powerhouse whose alumni include Yu Darvish, the best pitcher in Japan, and Kazuhiro Sasaki, the former closer of the Seattle Mariners — expect to go. They have made 40 trips to the tournament, but have never won.

headline: Rupert Murdoch Apologizes to Victims of Phone Hacking
text: Updated | 1:44 p.m. Since, remarkably, Rupert Murdoch’s personal letter of apology for the phone hacking scandal will run in its pages as a full-page ad on Saturday, The Guardian has obtained the complete text and posted it online.

headline: London Theater Journal: Aging, Acting and Acting Up
text: One of the pleasures (and pains) of going to the theater for many years is watching actors get older and grow up -– or not, as the case may be. Take Rupert Everett. The rakish, indignantly handsome Mr. Everett made his mark in theater 30 years ago in his early 20’s in Julian Mitchell’s “Another Country,” portraying a rebellious child of privilege with an aristocratic profile and a smoldering case of the sulks. As time passed, whenever Mr. Everett (who became a minor film star) returned to the theater, he continued to portray much the same person, but in a state of arrested development, like the drug-addicted, mother-fixated son in Noël Coward’s “Vortex” (1989) or a debonaire middle-aged but boyish Charles Condomine in Coward’s “Blithe Spirit,” on Broadway two years ago.

headline: Margaret Drabble’s Complete Stories
text: The discursive spaciousness of Margaret Drabble’s voice and vision lends itself to the long form, as her 17 splendid novels demonstrate. This may help to explain why her “complete short stories” make up so slender a volume. Drabble, it seems, just didn’t have enough time to write short stories (with apologies to Mark Twain). Of those collected here, 14 in all, the earliest dates from the 1950s, the most recent from the 1990s. Some are reed slim, but many glimmer with the irony, lyricism, moral vision and (despite their page counts) amplitude we associate with Drabble’s novels. They reflect back to us the last half of the 20th century, albeit in Drabble’s often 19th-century voice.

headline: The Vanguard Alights
text: THIS sprawling neighborhood in northern Brooklyn was one of the borough’s first European settlements, and has been known for many things over its long history: for its farms, then for its breweries and factories, then for the blight and crime that descended in the decades after those employers closed.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: This Sunday marks the first of the New Amsterdam “market specials,” an occasional series that will bring chefs and food purveyors to New York’s original market district,  located at the Old Fulton Fish Market on South Street and Peck Slip in Lower Manhattan.  From 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the market, Russ & Daughters will sell the short-seasoned Hollandse Nieuwe, or New Catch Holland Herring, with traditional garnishes: chopped raw onion and cornichons ($8). P&H Soda Company will sell house-made soft drinks ($3) to accompany the herring, and for dessert, Marja Samson is making poffertjes ($5), a traditional Dutch street food. Starting at noon, Pasanella and Son (115 South Street, across the street from the market) will pour small, complimentary shots of aquavit.

headline: After Ecclestone, the Future of Formula One According to Whitmarsh
text: Last weekend we published an interview with Bernie Ecclestone, the commercial boss of Formula One, on topics such as the digital future of Formula One and the future ownership of the series at a time when there are bids in the air.

headline: After Ecclestone, the Future of Formula One According to Whitmarsh
text: Last weekend we published an interview with Bernie Ecclestone, the commercial boss of Formula One, on topics such as the digital future of Formula One and the future ownership of the series at a time when there are bids in the air.

headline: C.F.D.A./Vogue Fashion Fund Finalists Announced
text: The Council of Fashion Designers of America and Vogue have announced the finalists for this year’s C.F.D.A./Vogue Fashion Fund award.

headline: Compromise in Minnesota Is Quick Fix on Budget
text: For days, the Democratic governor of Minnesota watched his state’s shutdown drag on, but insisted that, on principle, he could not go along with Republican lawmakers’ plans for the state’s budget.

headline: Poetry Chronicle
text: FLIES  By Michael Dickman.  Copper Canyon. Paper, $16.

headline: Paperback Row
text: NINE LIVES: In Search of the Sacred in Modern India,  by William Dalrymple (Vintage Departures, $16.) Dalrymple explores the stupefyingly diverse religious world of the subcontinent through interviews with nine remarkable individuals, including a Jain nun ritually starving herself to death; a mystic who inhabits a cremation ground, drinking from skulls; and a sculptor of Hindu idols who believes he is creating live deities.

headline: A Girl’s Postcards From Italy
text: Picture books that involve and engage young readers in the experiences of people packing up their lives and heading off to a new country, a new culture, a totally new way of living have always interested me. Perhaps because my own Italian grandparents did exactly that in the early 1900s. My father was born in Fall River, Mass., only a month or two after his parents settled into their new home.

headline: How to Be a Bicultural Schoolgirl
text: Let’s call them the original Gossip Girls. In Cristina García’s first young adult novel, three wealthy and adventurous ninth-grade girls from different worlds converge upon a Swiss boarding school for a summer of discovery. Vivien Wahl is the Miami-reared daughter of a Jewish Cuban exile father. Shirin Firouz is from Tehran, the treasured girl and math genius in a family of older brothers. Ingrid Baum is a bad girl queen bee from Canada, the daughter of German immigrants.

headline: Bookshelf: America
text: THE CROSSING  By Donna Jo Napoli. Illustrated by Jim Madsen.  40 pp. Atheneum. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 4 to 8)

headline: Story of an Evangelical Girlhood
text: Lacey Anne Byer, the heroine of Melissa Walker’s “Small Town Sinners,” is a born good girl: the 16-year-old daughter of the children’s pastor at the House of Enlightenment, an evangelical church in a working- and middle-­class enclave in the South — something like Dillon, Tex., in “Friday Night Lights.” Lacey even has a Tyra-like spitfire, a girl named Starla Joy, and a lovable Landry-like geek, Dean, for best friends.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: ABSOLUTE MONARCHS: A History of the Papacy,  by John Julius Norwich (Random House, $30.) Norwich, a writer of popular histories, finds that the truly great popes were outnumbered by the corrupt, the inept, the venal, the lecherous and the mediocre.

headline: Inside the List
text: ADVANCE MAN: A few weeks ago, I promised to eat my complete Harry Potter library if “A Dance With Dragons,” the eagerly awaited fifth installment in George R. R. Martin’s “Song of Ice and Fire” fantasy series, didn’t enter the hardcover fiction list at No. 1. That’s probably still a safe bet, though I did wonder if I should start firing up the barbecue after it was reported that Amazon Germany had accidentally shipped some 180 copies of “Dragons” ahead of the strict July 12 publication date, thus imperilling Martin’s carefully orchestrated siege of the global book market. (This week’s list reflects sales through July 9, though let it be noted that “Dragons” went into its sixth printing based on pre-orders alone. Charge!)

headline: Appeals Court Upholds Building Ban on Architect
text: A Manhattan appeals court upheld a decision on Thursday that essentially prevents the famous — to some, infamous — local architect Robert M. Scarano Jr. from doing business in New York.

headline: Sorkin to Co-Host CNBC’s ‘Squawk Box’
text: Andrew Ross Sorkin, the best-selling author and columnist at The New York Times, has been hired by CNBC to be the co-host of the morning financial show, “Squawk Box.” Here is the internal announcement from his editor in the business section, Larry Ingrassia:

headline: ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Repeal Isn’t a Quick Fix
text: Very soon, the military will signal that it has prepared itself for the repeal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy. This policy, in effect since the early days of the Clinton administration, allows gays and lesbians to serve as long as they do not identify themselves as such in public. Before signing the repeal into law, President Obama asked the military to take a reasonable amount of time to teach and train its soldiers about the policy changes. The military responded with a goal of training all currently serving soldiers by July 15. So far, that training has been delivered to nearly 95 percent of the military. Repeal could be final by the fall.

headline: The Jam | Nguzunguzu
text: The third installment of Sean Hanratty’s summer playlist is brought to you by the Los Angeles producers (and former violinists) Daniel Pineda and Asma Maroof, a k a Nguzunguzu. The group, which takes its name from a traditional Solomon Island figurehead used to protect against supernatural forces during canoe trips, offers a unique blend of R&B, house, cumbia and tribal music. They are known for improvising with, well, really weird sounds achieved through electronic instruments and a room full of synthesizers, as well as for an energy that Hanratty says is “incredible.” Pineda and Maroof, who have worked closely with the Sri Lankan songstress M.I.A., recently kicked off a tour with Gang Gang Dance and Total Freedom, and will be at Santos Party House on Thursday, July 21. (They are rumored to be playing the Capsule after-party on Monday, July 18!?)

headline: Chevys for All Seasons, Especially Summer
text: Dennis Albaugh of Ankeny, Iowa, has amassed what may be the definitive collection of open-top Chevrolets.

headline: Brave New World That’s as Familiar as the Machine It Fights With
text: I have played the future of mobile gaming. It is called Shadow Cities.

headline: Is the Six-Man Rotation Here to Stay?
text: In 1972 the Los Angeles Dodgers bucked seven decades of baseball precedent and added a fifth starting pitcher to their rotation. The quintet of Don Sutton, Claude Osteen, Al Downing, Tommy John and Bill Singer portended the future, and by the end of the decade the once revolutionary five-man rotation was adopted leaguewide.

headline: Downtown Theater to Take a Chance on Celebrated ‘Cymbeline’
text: Commercial theater producers seeking to make money off Shakespeare usually stick to tried-and-true audience draws like “Hamlet” or “Macbeth,” but even those can be financially risky without a celebrity in the title role. (Last season’s critically acclaimed “Merchant of Venice,” starring Al Pacino, narrowly turned a profit.) Next month, however, a group of commercial producers will try to make a go of “Cymbeline,” one of Shakespeare’s trickier tragic romances — though with a staging that received strong notices from  critics this winter.

headline: Reader Favorites: Your Twitter #fiction5
text: Well, we’ll have to agree to disagree: “Lolita,” which finished first in the survey of the magazine staff’s favorite fiction books, only managed to eke out 11th place on Twitter. Last week, after publishing our original post of our favorite fiction, we asked you to weigh in on Twitter under the hashtag #fiction5. Jer Thorp, the data artist in residence at The New York Times, gathered 4,500 tweets that used the hashtag #fiction5 over the following few days. He compiled the list below of your Twitter picks and presented us with the top contenders.

headline: Lead in New York Tap Water Is Back to Normal
text: The proportion of homes in New York City with elevated lead levels in their tap water is back to normal, city officials said this week, but all residents are still urged to run their tap water for at least half a minute before drinking or cooking with it.

headline: White Flight From the Nursing Home
text: The number of older Americans living in nursing homes continues to fall, and the proportion of residents who are black, Hispanic or Asian has climbed sharply. But don’t expect cheers from the Brown University researchers who’ve tracked this major shift in long-term care.

headline: As the Clock Runs Down, the Taylors Look Back On ‘Friday Night Lights’
text: For almost all of the critically lauded but ratings-challenged run of “Friday Night Lights” — which ends Friday on NBC — clear eyes and full hearts couldn’t win with Emmy voters.

headline: Bound in a Gay Union by a State Denying It

headline: Newark Museum Gets $1 Million Grant for African Art Collection
text: The Newark Museum has received a $1 million grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation to support initiatives related to its African art collection. The grant will allow the museum to hire a new assistant curator, doubling the size of its African art department, and to engage additional scholars for research, the museum’s director, Mary Sue Sweeney Price, said in a telephone interview.

text: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes about the market for baseball memorabilia. In the wake of Derek Jeter’s 3,000th hit, he was trying to understand the market for signed baseballs and bats, jerseys and photos. What sorts of items appreciate? And, he asked, how do you know if what you have is valuable?

headline: Designers Revisit Copyright Protection
text: Let’s see here. On Wednesday, ABS by Allen Schwartz began selling a series of royal-wedding-inspired dresses that includes a fairly good copy of the Alexander McQueen gown worn by Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, for $1,100. That same night, Representative Bob Goodlatte, a Virginia Republican, reintroduced legislation seeking to grant copyright protection to designers, presumably discouraging exactly that kind of knockoff fashion. And on Friday, the Proenza Schouler designers Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez went to Washington to plead their case before Congress.

headline: Embracing the One-Piece, Beyond the Pool

A regular on the television drama “Damages,” which is now on DirecTV’s Audience Network and which had its fourth-season premiere on July 13, Ms. Byrne is having a banner summer at the box office. She’s a cast member in the comedy “Bridesmaids” and “X-Men: First Class.” Ms. Byrne turns 32 on July 24.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Ghost Stories
text: There’s major turnover on the manga list this week with eight new additions. Only Naruto, a regular of the list, and Vampire Knight, about an academy whose evening students are creatures of the night, remain from the previous week. I’ve had difficulty reading manga: the traditional right-to-left layouts often confuse me and many series that are at Volume 50 or higher make me feel late to the party. Of the new books this week, Dengeki Daisy has a “Ghost” or “Sixth Sense” vibe to it. The series is about Teru Kurebayashi, who after the death of her brother has been receiving comforting messages from the mysterious Daisy, who communicates through her brother’s cell phone. Spooky! Volume 5 enters our list at No. 8 this week.

headline: Letters: The Siren Call of Cuba
text: To the Editor: Re the July 10 Practical Traveler column (“New Ways to Visit Cuba, Legally”): For years, my architect husband has yearned to visit Cuba for its artistic heritage. As a playwright, I’d like to go to experience firsthand the Cuban ethos. We have no interest in tourist traps or in political machinations. As travelers who like to create our own agenda, the thought of visiting lock-step with a gaggle of folks on a tour program makes us cringe. We certainly are not equipped to overthrow any government, so we are at a loss to understand why we can’t just choose our form of transit and travel to Cuba, bringing back sketches and snapshots and memories. Someone, please explain why we are kept from doing this. Anne Russell Wilmington, N.C.

headline: In Spain, Miró’s Majorca
text: A BRONZE Miró sculpture interrupts the sidewalk below the grand Cathedral of Palma de Mallorca. It stretches up, the height of two men, a hollowed concave rectangle topped by a large egg-shaped nugget tilted toward the Mediterranean. Day after day, tourists rush past it in a hustle, descending from the steep side street that winds down to the shaded Passeig de Born, a busy thoroughfare filled with clothing stores and mopeds.

headline: In Austin, Bungalows and Brews
text: TOURISTS in Austin often head straight to Sixth Street, with its jammed-together nightclubs, restaurants and bars advertising drink specials and Jell-O shots.

headline: Restaurant Report: Locanda, in San Francisco
text: In 1998, Craig Stoll and his soon-to-be wife, Annie, opened Delfina, whose Tuscan-influenced dishes established a new benchmark for Italian food in San Francisco, and a new center of gravity for the cuisine, in the city’s Mission district. In 2005, the Stolls opened a pizzeria next door, and in 2008, a second in Pacific Heights. In April, the couple added another Mission-based element to their empire: Locanda, an osteria that channels the culinary traditions of Rome.

headline: From City (Munich) to Forest (Bavarian)
text: FAR away on the other side of Germany, I imagined, travelers might be sampling the famous chocolate cakes and smoked hams of the well-traveled Black Forest. But here in the more remote and lesser-known Bayerischer Wald, or Bavarian Forest, the local delicacy arrived in a bottle: a clear, pale gold liqueur called Bärwurz, distilled from the unusual herbs that grow in this dense, hilly woodland along the German border with the Czech Republic.

headline: Lighting the Hopes of the Gridless

Or, in the case of F.D.R.’s Tennessee Valley Authority, “T.V.A.: Electricity For All.”

headline: A Hole in One and Age Lines; Watson Has Both

headline: Two City Opera Board Members Quit
text: Two more members of the board of New York City Opera have resigned in the wake of the company’s departure from Lincoln Center and artistic changes. Jonathan Sheffer, a conductor and composer who had been a trustee for two years, said on Friday he stepped down 10 days ago, but not because of the move. “I really felt at odds with the company’s artistic direction,” he said, adding that it had “broken faith with the audience.” The general and artistic director, George Steel, has been criticized by some for neglecting more traditional productions in favor of the offbeat.

headline: Asked & Answered | Raf Simons
text: The Belgian designer Raf Simons named his three-day mini-festival “Transmission” to convey how the participants convert the dynamic contradictions and contagious energy of Berlin’s creative scene into art. “Transmission” is the first installment of “The Avant-Garde Diaries,” a series of Mercedes-Benz sponsored cultural events to be curated by Simons that the car company will host in cities all over the world. For Berlin, Simons selected a group of artists who are inspired by the city but who are not necessarily based here, including the graphic designer Peter Saville, the industrial designer Konstantin Grcic, the Scottish dancer and choreographer Michael Clark, the British writer Jo-Ann Furniss, These New Puritans (a band from Southend-on-Sea), the Belgian artist Peter de Potter and New York’s very own Fischerspooner. “Transmission” also features a sampling of Simons’s favorite horror films. The show is physically situated in the Berlin Congress Center, with events running from noon to midnight. Theavantgardediaries.com, a digital magazine, will broadcast the key events for non-Berliners and introduce readers to the artists involved. Simons sat down with The Moment just hours before the opening to discuss Berlin’s significance as a contemporary creative hub.

headline: Loose Weapons in Rebel Hands

headline: Chicken Salad With Skordalia

headline: The Minimalist: Chicken Salad With Skordalia
text: The Greek dip skordalia is most easily described as eggless mayonnaise, but it’s so much better than that. Unlike “real” mayonnaise — an emulsion of egg (or just yolk), vinegar and lots of oil — skordalia consists mainly of nuts, with just a little oil and moistened bread, or potato, as a binder. Purée these ingredients with garlic and stock or milk (the latter is creamier, obviously), and you end up with a thick, silky and, most importantly, intensely flavorful sauce that’s terrific with crudités.

headline: Garlic and Sage Broth, Good for a Hangover or a Light Supper
text: If you haven’t thought about cooking with sage since Thanksgiving, now is a good time to think again. Fresh sage is great in a lot of summer dishes, from pastas to vegetables. You can get it at the farmers’ market, or in the supermarket in those annoying little plastic clamshells. Or ask your friend with the garden for a little bunch. But a little pot of sage wouldn’t go amiss on a sunny city kitchen windowsill, along with a thyme plant and a pot of rosemary. For a small investment you’ll have the sprig or two you need when you need it, ready to snip.

headline: As ‘Sinks’ for Carbon, Forests Are Even Mightier Than Assumed
text: The world’s forests are magnificent palaces of biodiversity, teeming with wacky and wonderful creatures and plants that seem otherworldly. But they’re also something far more mundane although useful: they’re giant sponges, soaking up vast amounts of carbon dioxide.

headline: ‘The Last Werewolf’
New Fund-Raising Totals Reveal Political Jockeying
text: By midnight Friday, the New York City Campaign Finance Board will post the latest six-month fundraising figures for candidates considering a run in 2013. And already, the leading contenders to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg have trumpeted their numbers, topped by the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, who pulled in $1.3 million, and the city’s comptroller, John C. Liu, who had $1 million.

headline: New Angle on an Oft-Visited Nightmare
text: THE French filmmaker Gilles Paquet-Brenner was aware he was taking on a subject that was daunting, unpopular and overworked. “I don’t think a 15-year-old young guy in high school would watch ‘Schindler’s List’ unless maybe some teacher assigned him,” he said. “My generation had ‘Schindler’s List,’ a later generation had ‘The Pianist,’ and in 10 years you’ll have another. Each generation needs its movie.”

headline: Virgin Mobile Changes Pricing
text: Into the summer squall of new phone plans, add Virgin Mobile (is owned by Sprint), which is changing the price of its no-contract plans. The change raises the prices of two tiers of service but lowers the cost for the unlimited voice plan. Data remains unlimited in all of the plans.

headline: As a Watchdog Starves, Wall Street Is Tossed a Bone
text: The economy is still suffering from the worst financial crisis since the Depression, and widespread anger persists that financial institutions that caused it received bailouts of billions of taxpayer dollars and haven’t been held accountable for any wrongdoing. Yet the House Appropriations Committee has responded by starving the agency responsible for bringing financial wrongdoers to justice — while putting over $200 million that could otherwise have been spent on investigations and enforcement actions back into the pockets of Wall Street.

text: BEIJING — Some nations have strategic oil reserves. Some keep grain reserves. China has both, and something others have somehow overlooked: a national pork reserve.

headline: Young Singers Take on an Old Story of Love
text: The legend of Don Juan — a womanizer blithely indifferent to consequences until suddenly held accountable — has inspired myriad playwrights, poets and composers. The legend certainly still seems relevant in light of the endless stream of high-profile men whose embarrassing escapades make headline news.

text: Time: 35 minutes, plus marinating time

headline: Hints of Pomegranate to Perk Up Chicken
text: OF all the condiments in my overstuffed pantry, pomegranate molasses ranks among the most intense.

headline: All Words, Yet at an Impasse of Sorts
text: The couple are obsessed by words: She is a grammar fiend and compulsive letter writer, bound up in nervous energy; he does endless crossword puzzles, his bulk settled into the couch almost permanently.

headline: No Grill Needed
text: You can’t make grilled pomegranate-glazed chicken without a grill. But you can still make excellent pomegranate-glazed chicken thighs in your oven. They won’t benefit from the smokiness of charcoal, but will still have plenty of tangy, complex, fruity flavor from the glaze. It’s a dish worth making. To do so, preheat your oven to 450 degrees and spread the chicken thighs on a baking pan. Roast, turning once, until brown, crisp-skinned and cooked through, 25 to 35 minutes. Then follow the rest of the recipe from that point and dig in.

headline: Ice Cream Convergence
text: More than a millennium ago, during the Tang Dynasty in China, someone had the bright idea to take fermented milk and ground rice, stir in dragon brain fragments — a k a camphor — and submerge the mixture in a pool of ice. The mothball-scented confection apparently pleased the emperor.

headline: Dina & Mark
text: Mark Thomas and Dina Kirschenbaum played Hermia and Lysander, lovers who wed, in their graduate school's production of "A Midsummer Night's Dream." After the curtain call, Mark proposed to Dina.

headline: #trendingNYC: The Week on Twitter
text: When Derek Jeter sent his 3,000th hit into the stands on Saturday, he also sent #Jeter and #3000 soaring up the weekend Twitter charts, as New Yorkers scrambled to commemorate their favorite Yankee’s achievement as well. @funnyordie (Verdict: funny), wrote:

headline: Airborne Bodies and Balls
text: For its “Extraordinary Moves” programming, the River to River Festival took to the air with the aid of — in order — skirts, balls and bodies. (This is what is known as saving the best for last.) On Thursday evening performances by the Australian group Strange Fruit, the juggler Michael Moschen and the Streb Extreme Action Company took place under a glaring sun at the World Financial Center Plaza.

text: In an interview in May, back when Jerry Seinfeld was finally getting around to launching his official Web site, this standup and sitcom star told The New York Times that his joining Twitter was about as likely as his running out of offbeat observations on airline travel: “That’s stand-up with a net,” Mr. Seinfeld said at the time.

headline: Sportsmanship, and a Knack for Finding the Killing Lead

headline: Harry Potter and You
text: We asked and you shared. Readers from around the world have submitted their Harry Potter photos. Check out a photo gallery here. We’re still looking for fan photos, so please submit them here.

headline: A View Inside King Kong’s Perch
text: I am pressing against a secure wall, not daring to step away. The wind is whipping against me — or is it howling? My feet feel rubbery on the narrow walkway. I think of those balconies on the upper floors of colonial homes in old ports, where pacing wives would gaze out to sea, seeking the long-overdue ships of sailor husbands: widows’ walks. If this particular walk were open to an anxiously pacing public, I can only imagine how many new widows and widowers would be left behind. But I look out, and the vision is literally breathtaking, the Hudson shimmering in the west, and a patch of green off to the north — Central Park — lying just beyond some half-hearted high-rises.

headline: When Cricket Was a Symbol, Not Just a Sport
text: AMERICANS would sooner watch a spelling bee than a cricket match. No, really: ESPN’s broadcast of the Scripps National Spelling Bee draws an average of four million viewers, while the network’s online coverage of 2011 World Cup Cricket generated some 1.3 million hits here. So what does that bode for a politics-ridden documentary about a cricket team — from the West Indies, no less, a part of the world that most Americans associate with piña coladas, not postcolonial politics?

headline: A Concept Is Minimal. The Works Sure Aren’t.
text: Franz Welser-Möst and the Cleveland Orchestra have taken up residence at Avery Fisher Hall for a series — part of the Lincoln Center Festival — called “Bruckner: (R)evolution,” in which Bruckner symphonies are juxtaposed with works by John Adams. It is an odd pairing, built on Mr. Welser-Möst’s interesting assertion that Bruckner is “the grandfather of Minimalism.”

headline: The Songs of Now Sound a Lot Like Then
text: ONCE pop music was something by which you could tell the decade, or even the year. But listening to the radio nowadays is disorienting, if you’re searching for a sound that screams, “It’s 2011!”

headline: Battle for Libya | July 15, 2011
text: The United States formally recognized the rebel leadership in Libya as the country’s legitimate government on Friday.

text: There has been a flurry of headline-grabbing developments in the slow-moving financial and fiscal crises on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: Obama’s Haul: Big Money From Big Donors
text: Twenty-seven fund-raisers collected more than $500,000 each in contributions for President Obama and the Democratic Party in the past three months, helping Mr. Obama collect a record haul of campaign cash as he starts his re-election effort.

headline: Best Way Not to Win a Pious Man’s Heart? Dance of the Seven Veils
text: Since 1896, Oscar Wilde’s “Salome” has provided opportunities for lush decadence — and who could object? — with its despotic voluptuary King Herod and the petulant title character. Now the Flea Theater is presenting a production of the play by the Black Moon Theater Company that teeters between a severe modernism and Wilde’s baroque verbal flourishes.

headline: Bloggingheads: Obama and Taxes
text: Mark Schmitt, left, of the Roosevelt Institute and Tim Carney of the Washington Examiner debate the politics of taxes.

headline: CBS Edges Rivals
text: CBS eked out a victory as the top-rated network on Thursday night as 6.5 million viewers tuned in to “Big Brother” at 9 p.m., more than any other program on the night, according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC’s “Wipeout” had an audience of 6.4 million at 8, but ABC was second for the night over all. CBS also drew 6.4 million viewers at 10 for a repeat of “The Mentalist,” while it broadcast back-to-back reruns of its sitcoms “The Big Bang Theory” (6.3 million) and “Rules of Engagement” (4.9 million). Fox was third with “So You Think You Can Dance” at 8 (5.2 million) followed by a repeat of “Glee” (2.9 million), and NBC finished fourth with low-rated comedy reruns and “Love Bites” at 10 (2 million).

headline: Cain Raised $2 Million and Contributed $500,000
text: Herman Cain raised $2 million during his first quarter as a presidential candidate, according to his campaign’s Federal Election Commission filing.

headline: Republicans Hold Up Vote on Extension of F.B.I. Term
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s plans for Congress to smoothly extend the tenure of Robert S. Mueller III as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation are derailing, raising an outside chance that he may have to step down temporarily early next month.

headline: Clashes, Some Deadly, Intensify in a Tumultuous City in Central Yemen
text: SANA, Yemen — Fighting between security forces and armed opposition tribesmen intensified on Friday in the city of Taiz. At least seven people were killed, including a high-ranking security official, in yet another sign of the breakdown in stability that has been pushing Yemen to the brink of chaos.

headline: The Revolution Is Not Over Yet
text: Tunis

headline: Catching Counterfeiters, a Real Cat-and-Mouse Game
text: The salesman found a bit of shade on the corner of Hester and Baxter Streets in Chinatown and waited. Not for long. A young woman approached, and he pulled a dog-eared pamphlet from the pocket of his cargo shorts.

headline: How Clergy Helped a Same-Sex Marriage Law Pass
text: Early in the week that ended with New York enacting same-sex marriage, the Rev. Anna Taylor Sweringen stood in a hallway just outside the State Senate chambers. She wore her clerical collar and held a sign saying, “Equality now.” Around her gathered ministers and rabbis of similar sentiment, all in Albany to lobby and pray for the right of gay couples to wed.

headline: Food Companies Act to Protect Consumers From E. Coli Illness
text: The federal government has spent years considering whether to take steps to help keep dangerous strains of E. coli bacteria out of the food supply, a question that has become even more urgent in the face of a deadly wave of E. coli sickness that swept through Europe and raised alarms on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: A Bad Economy Could Harm House Republicans
text: If you are a Republican trying to keep your job in Congress, your feelings about President Obama notwithstanding, would you rather the economy be better or worse?

headline: He’s a Con Man With a Heart of Gold
text: There are several plays battling it out in “Tryst,” at the Irish Repertory Theater. Trouble is, none have enough oomph to win the fight. Part melodrama, part thriller, part comedy and part romance, the script wanders through the genres, offering a story that’s frequently interesting yet ultimately unfocused.

headline: Pitchfork: Tune-Yards and EMA
text: CHICAGO — The first two saxophones of the Pitchfork Music Festival belonged to Merrill Garbus, a k a Tune-Yards. The sax matters now more than it has at any time since the recently departed Clarence Clemons was at his peak. But unlike some of her kitsch-minded contemporaries, who use the instrument to connote post-wink post-irony, Ms. Garbus makes her sax players work, using their meaty lines to thicken her one-woman ukulele-and-drums-and-howls cornucopia. Hers is hard, muscular, construction-site soul, and the frenzied saxophones behind her highlighted how much sweat making this music generates.

headline: No Jail Time in Trial Over N.S.A. Leak
text: BALTIMORE — A former spy agency official accused of leaking classified information to a newspaper walked out of court a free man on Friday, sentenced to a year’s probation and community service, after hearing the judge excoriate the government for its handling of the case.

headline: Plenty to Say at the British Open
text: SANDWICH, ENGLAND — They came in by the dozens to the press tent on Friday at the British Open. A sampling of what they said:

headline: No Matter How Debt Debate Ends, Governors See More Cuts for States
text: SALT LAKE CITY — The rancorous debate in Washington over whether to raise the federal debt ceiling is alarming many of the nation’s governors from both parties, who fear that whatever the outcome, much-needed money will almost certainly be drained from their states.

headline: Only a Few More Yards to Cover for N.F.L. and Players
text: After a flurry of deal-making over a two-day span, the N.F.L. is on the verge of a new labor agreement with its players, with just a few ancillary issues left to be settled, a person briefed on the negotiations said Friday. “It was a good day,” the person said.

headline: Los Angeles Puts It in Park as Freeway Project Starts
text: LOS ANGELES — In an atmosphere that veered from summer-camp giddy to dark anxiety, Los Angeles began Friday evening to close down 10 miles of one of its most storied and heavily traveled highways, Interstate 405, in a construction project that will test whether this region can, for a weekend, change the highway habits that have defined it for more than 50 years.

headline: On the Street | Voilà
text: The French house of Louis Vuitton simply changed the colors of its popular winter brown-check bag to ivory and beige — and a summer success was born.

headline: Held in Document Theft, ‘America’s Presidential Historian’ Faces New Scrutiny
text: WASHINGTON — Barry H. Landau, author and well-known presidential memorabilia collector, displayed his connections like pearls on a necklace.

headline: A Whole Different Pitch for the U.S.
text: FRANKFURT — Pia Sundhage has sought to motivate the United States women’s soccer team less with classic speeches than with classic rock.

headline: Foreclosure Protesters in Spain’s Cities Now Go Door to Door
text: MADRID — When the police arrived recently to evict María José del Coto Maeso, 53, they found the street in front of her ground-floor apartment crowded with protesters, and they retreated.

headline: A Book Party for the Dead
text: The big names on the invitation for a book party at the St. Regis New York hotel were all dead. Salvador Dalí, Alfred Hitchcock and Diana Vreeland had once lived or lived it up here on East 55th Street, we were told. Had they been among the guests on Wednesday at a party for the release of “It Happened Here” by Lesley M. M. Blume, a book chronicling the St. Regis’s creative history, they would no doubt have reveled again.

headline: John C. Truesdale, Labor Relations Board Chief, Dies at 89
text: John C. Truesdale, who rose from field investigator to executive secretary and ultimately chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, died on July 3 in Martinsburg, W.Va. He was 89.

headline: For a Bereft Street Corner in Queens, a Red-Letter Day
text: The dominant physical presence in Jackson Heights, Queens, is the elevated No. 7 train over Roosevelt Avenue, but many residents have become familiar with a couple of smaller, whimsical neighborhood features.

headline: Blundering Toward Recession: Beyond the Debt Stalemate
text: “Catastrophic.” “Calamitous.” “Major crisis.” “Self-inflicted wound.” Those are some of the ways Ben Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has described the fallout if Congress fails to raise the debt limit by the Aug. 2 deadline.

headline: Kicking Up the Dust in an Arizona Desert Town
text: QUARTZSITE, Ariz. — Like many folks in this blink-and-miss-it town on the western edge of the state, Ed Foster moved here to escape the hustle and bustle. He is delighted that the main drag is just a couple of miles long, bookended by gas stations. It doesn’t take much more than a working sewer and water hookup to make him happy.

headline: Blundering Toward Recession: Urgency and Sense Elude the House
text: The increasingly urgent cries to resolve the debt-ceiling stalemate — from Wall Street, bond rating companies, the Federal Reserve chairman, the White House, the Senate and pretty much everyone else — seem unable to penetrate the soundproof bunker built by House Republicans. Their leaders announced on Friday that they would waste precious days next week on a hopeless crusade for spending caps and a balanced budget amendment.

headline: For Strauss-Kahn, 2 Concerts, and a Stay, in the Berkshires
text: On the day Dominique Strauss-Kahn was released from house arrest, the paparazzi followed him to an Upper East Side restaurant. (One tabloid said the bill for his party of four came to $700.) Later some tabloids, cable channels and Web sites said he was spending the Independence Day weekend in the Hamptons. (He wasn’t.)

headline: A Look Into the Ocean’s Future
text: There is simply no exaggerating the importance of the oceans to earth’s overall ecological balance. Their health affects the health of all terrestrial life. A new report by an international coalition of marine scientists makes for grim reading. It concludes that the oceans are approaching irreversible, potentially catastrophic change.

headline: After Long Battle, Safer Cribs
text: BAYONNE, N.J. — At the back of a cavernous warehouse along a rough-and-tumble waterfront here, an area has been swept clean of boxes and forklifts to make way for baby safety.

headline: Day of Reckoning
text: Never apologize. Never back down. Never lose.

headline: An Opera on the Loose
text: The New York City Opera’s schedule for the coming season is not quite busking in the streets, but close. The company, which used to present as many as 20 productions in a season at Lincoln Center, will present four, which will be staged at BAM, El Museo del Barrio, and the Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College. If the opera management has its way, the chorus and the orchestra would be demoted from full-time employment to freelance status.

headline: A Tip Becomes a Twitter Torrent
text: For nearly 24 hours through Friday afternoon, a slice of the sports world was engaged in a Twitter uprising to force ESPN to end its reported suspension of Bruce Feldman, one of its college football writers. Thousands of Twitter posts were expended in the #freebruce campaign, which rose to No. 4 on Twitter’s trends list, a wild geyser of pro-Feldmanism.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Making Murder Count
text: New Orleans

headline: Fallback Plan Moving to Fore as Budget Talks Stall
text: WASHINGTON — With talks on a big budget deal at a stalemate, Congressional leaders turned Friday to negotiating a fallback plan for raising the debt limit as President Obama and House Republicans intensified their efforts to win over public opinion for the long battle ahead.

headline: School Officials and Union Agree on Pilot Program for Teacher Evaluations
text: In a step toward reshaping how all teachers in New York City’s 1,700 public schools are judged, the Department of Education and the city teachers’ union agreed on Friday to a pilot teacher-evaluation system that will take effect next year in 33 struggling schools.

headline: Talk of Passports, Not Passes, in Idled N.B.A.
text: This summer was supposed to be an opportunity for Jeremy Hazell to impress clubs with his play for an N.B.A. summer league team and earn an invitation to a training camp in the fall. From there, he would have worked to earn a spot on the team and the guaranteed contract that would go with it.

headline: Fleeing Somalia’s Drought
text: Thousands of people fleeing a drought in Somalia are arriving at the world’s largest refugee camp in Dadaab, Kenya.

headline: Transcripts of Veterans in Crisis
text: In a wing of a Veterans Affairs hospital in Canandaigua, N.Y., a small staff runs a national Internet chat service for veterans.

headline: Bachmann Off to Fast Start on Funds, but Plays Catch-Up
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Michele Bachmann collected nearly as much money in two weeks as several of her rivals for the Republican presidential nomination raised in more than two months, according to financial reports filed Friday, but President Obama outpaced all candidates by activating a network of high-dollar donors and grass-roots supporters.

headline: Two Buildings, Many Stories
text: With the demise of 11 and 9 Second Avenue, another piece of an older, messier New York dies, one made remarkable by the fact that it has existed for so long.

headline: In the East Village, Waiting for the Wrecking Ball
text: IN the beginning, there were two buildings.

headline: Colon Says He’s Fine, and Video Backs Him
text: TORONTO — In an alcove off to the side of the Yankees’ clubhouse, Joe Girardi sat in front of a computer on Friday afternoon and cued up video from Thursday’s game, preparing to watch all 42 pitches thrown by Bartolo Colon. Girardi studied them frame by frame, looking for evidence that Colon’s left hamstring was bothering him: a shorter leg kick, a tentative landing. Then he compared Colon’s mechanics to a start from earlier this season.

headline: A Bronx Oasis With a Gritty, Industrial Past
text: ELIZABETH GOMEZ feels a little protective about her beach. It’s a tiny crescent of sand, tucked between a thicket of reeds and some gently lapping waves, where she and five friends stretched out on blankets one recent sweltering Saturday, savoring their seclusion.

headline: Sommelier Stole Art Openly, Police Say
text: A man with a larcenous bent and modest means, eyeing some trifle in a shop, might just walk in, grab it and walk out. But if this thief has very refined, very expensive tastes, coveting something like, say, a Picasso, how does he manage to steal that?

headline: Fleeing Somalia's Drought
text: Thousands of people fleeing a drought in Somalia are arriving at the world’s largest refugee camp, in Dadaab, Kenya.

headline: Rangers Re-Sign Boyle
text: The Rangers announced that they agreed to terms on a contract with the restricted free-agent center Brian Boyle. Re-signing the 6-foot-7 Boyle, who scored 21 goals last season, leaves the Rangers with two restricted free agents still to sign, the top-six forwards Ryan Callahan and Brandon Dubinsky.

headline: Murdoch’s Reporters Report on Murdoch
text: One of the more bizarre aspects of the scandal at the British newspaper division of the News Corporation is that it has forced journalists at news organizations owned by the company to report extensively in recent days on the man who is, ultimately, their boss, Rupert Murdoch.

headline: Misery Follows as Somalis Try to Flee Hunger
text: DADAAB, Kenya — The people start trudging in at dawn, more than a thousand every day, exhausted, sick and starving, materializing out of the thin desert air to take their places at the gates of the world’s largest refugee camp, here in northern Kenya.

headline: For One Day, a Break From Cake
text: Vincent Buzzetta’s parents wanted him to be a pharmacist or a doctor, but instead settled for watching their chocoholic son become a cake-baking prodigy with his own shop, the Cake Artist, in West Brighton on Staten Island. Mr. Buzzetta, 21, who graduated from the French Culinary Institute’s pastry program at 18, now also has his own reality series on WE tv, “Staten Island Cakes.” He lives in the Old Town neighborhood of Staten Island with his parents, brother and sister, all of whom weigh in loudly on the frenetic show. ROBIN FINN

headline: Bachmann Off to Strong Start in Money Race
text: Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota collected nearly $1.7 million in her first two weeks as an official candidate for president, an early indication of her appeal to the Tea Party conservatives who she views as her core supporters.

headline: Returning Home From War
text: Listen as two veterans who receive care at the Veterans Outreach Center in Rochester, a veteran who now works there and an administrator talk about their experiences.

headline: Marathon Swimmers Complete Their Trek
text: DAVID BARRA’S seven-day swim from the Rip Van Winkle Bridge to the mouth of the Hudson River ended on Thursday with help from a roaring current.

headline: At Kentucky Speedway, a Pileup Off the Track
text: Nascar’s president, Mike Helton, answered 14 questions Friday at a news conference at a racetrack in Loudon, N.H. Nine questions, and his opening comments, dealt with a colossal traffic jam, not caused by stock cars, before a race last Saturday about 900 miles away in Kentucky.

headline: Saturday: Their Word Is Law
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I’ve said it before and I’ll say it again: if you can get through a Saturday puzzle with your life and your dignity intact, you are bound to come out a smarter person. Today was such a day for me, and I hope it was for you, too. But I came awfully close to this being a D.N.F. (Did Not Finish, for those of you who are new here) for me. That would have been a shame, primarily because I happen to love Patrick Berry’s puzzles, and secondly, because I can’t really write intelligently about the puzzle if I don’t finish, and that ticks off my editors like you can’t imagine.

headline: The Journal Becomes Fox-ified
text: It’s official. The Wall Street Journal has been Fox-ified.

headline: Rodriguez Drops Option Worth $17.5 Million
text: Francisco Rodriguez had been saying for months that he did not care about his $17.5 million vesting option for 2012, and on Friday the reason for that became clear.

headline: E-Book Revolution Upends a Publishing Course
text: FOR decades, even after it was renamed and relocated from its original home at Radcliffe, the Columbia Publishing Course seemed unchanging, a genteel summer tradition in the book business, a white-glove six-week course in which ambitious college graduates were educated in the time-honored basics of book editing, sales, cover design and publicity. Not this summer.

headline: A Voice for Those Silenced in a Mobster’s Reign
text: BOSTON — Heads turned as the lanky man made his way to the courtroom pews reserved for those who suffer because of the criminal Whitey Bulger. The face of an altar boy masked his rage, and a shirt of powder-blue covered his tattoos, including one evoking the Celtic cross that adorns his father’s gravestone.

headline: Why Subway Rats Aren’t Electrocuted by the Third Rail
text: Q. There is a small triangular park in the Brownsville neighborhood in Brooklyn called Zion Triangle. Why the odd name?

headline: Ahead of Election in March, Putin the Reformer Steps Up
text: MOSCOW — In what appeared to be a calculated pre-election appearance, Prime Minster Vladimir V. Putin on Friday reflected on his 11 years in power and acknowledged that elements of the system he created needed to change.

headline: They, Too, Sing America
text: Last week I spent a few days in the Deep South — a thousand miles from the moneyed canyons of Manhattan and the prattle of Washington politics — talking to everyday people, blue-collar workers, people not trying to win the future so much as survive the present.

headline: Marching to Sundhage’s New Pitch
text: If the United States is feeling any pressure heading into Sunday’s Women’s World Cup final against Japan, it is almost certainly not coming from Coach Pia Sundhage. Since taking over after the disastrous ending to the 2007 World Cup, Sundhage has brought a glass-is-half-full spirit that has been a big part of the team’s rebuilding. Read Jeré Longman’s article here, and come back to comment.

headline: Beware of Siren With Smartphone
text: Apparently there are some dangers to those Greek islands cruises that the travel agents don’t tell you about.

headline: Beloved French Rocker Gets Back to Work After Brush With Death
text: PARIS

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Yanks’ Rotation Begins to Show Wear and Tear
text: TORONTO — In January, the Yankees signed Freddy Garcia not for the accomplishments on his résumé — 18-game winner, 2-time All-Star, veteran of 12 major league seasons — but for the four words found under the skills section: knows how to pitch. That is a compliment of the highest order, a celebration of smarts and guile and resolve, all attributes needed to survive, and thrive, in the rough-and-tumble American League East.

headline: ‘Hairspray,’ the ’60s and the Greater Good
text: For all its many pleasures as tuneful entertainment, “Hairspray” is a musical that giddily celebrates subversive values.

headline: Sharks, Butterflies and a Ballroom
text: BRYAN DeLUCA, the executive director of the Long Island Aquarium and Exhibition Center, in Riverhead, knows exactly what has traditionally made the attraction, formerly Atlantis Marine World, a popular place to visit.

headline: High Crimes (With Laugh Track) and a Summer Share
text: Veanne Cox could probably play an entire episode of “Law and Order” all by herself. She has no problem enacting a courtroom scene without the help of other actors, rotating at rapid speed among the roles of court officer, lawyer and two witnesses, to hilarious effect.

headline: End Gets a Bit Nearer for the Mets
text: The Mets’ flags atop Citi Field remained a vivid blue and orange Friday, but after a loss to the Philadelphia Phillies, they seemed to gain a decidedly whiter hue. The Mets have not given up on the season just yet, but they moved a step closer.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Greek Gods Under Disco Lights
text: An old pleasure dome known as the Carousel House on the Asbury Park boardwalk is currently home to the New Jersey premiere of “Xanadu,” the daffy, delectably tuneful musical drawn from one of the worst movies ever made.

headline: A Cynical View of Careless Generosity
text: Enter the F. M. Kirby Shakespeare Theater just before a performance of “Timon of Athens,” and you are faced with something like a Dickensian store window at Christmastime. Downstage, you find actors dressed in shabby period elegance, transformed into mechanical toys, clicking in and out of the limited movements and poses that their 19th-century works allow them.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around New Jersey. Items may be submitted by mail to the New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: A Festival Carries the Torch of the Grateful Dead
text: DEADHEADS may not lack an instinct to gather, but they do require a good reason for doing so. For decades, Jerry Garcia, the Grateful Dead’s frontman, gave them one.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: A Farmers’ Market at a Historic Homestead
text: IN 1801, John Jay, who had served his country as president of the Second Continental Congress, minister to Spain during the American Revolution, secretary for foreign affairs under the Articles of Confederation, a key negotiator of the Treaty of Paris, first chief justice of the Supreme Court, two-term governor of New York, and a co-author of the Federalist Papers, retired — and who could blame him? — to 750 bucolic acres in Katonah.

headline: Nets’ Williams SignsWith Turkish Team
text: With a signature, a photo and a three-sentence Twitter post, Deron Williams sealed his commitment to a Turkish basketball team.

headline: The Catch of the Day, by the Pound or the Plate
text: ISLAND PARK, N.Y.

headline: Slumps in Consumer Spending
text: What consumers are cutting back on.

headline: More Than a Name Suggests
text: Summer entertaining without having to use the oven or stove is much easier if you live in the vicinity of No. 109 Cheese and Wine. This handsome shop, with a stonework wall offset by a guacamole green color scheme, carries a wealth of gourmet treats in addition to some 150 varieties of cheese.

headline: Turkey: Army Strikes Back at Rebels
text: Turkey launched a military offensive in the predominantly Kurdish southeast in retaliation for an ambush by Kurdish separatists that killed 13 soldiers on Thursday. Army helicopters were joined by civilian village guards in the operation, the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency reported. The army provided no details on the number of troops involved. The attack on Thursday, near Diyarbakir, was the deadliest ambush by Kurdish separatists in recent years, and Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan vowed that the rebels would pay a heavy price.

headline: Austrian Cuisine, Ready for Summer
text: AUSTRIAN restaurants, with their robust cuisine, don’t normally come to mind as good choices for summer dining. But Austria’s white wines — exquisitely refreshing in the warm weather — combined with lighter-than-usual fare make the Watch Factory Restaurant in Cheshire well worth a visit.

headline: Venezuelan Leader to Return to Cuba for Next Phase of Cancer Treatment
text: President Hugo Chávez said Friday that he would return to Cuba to begin a new phase of cancer treatment including chemotherapy. Mr. Chávez, 56, said he would go to Havana on Saturday “to begin what we’ve called the second phase.” He had surgery in Cuba last month to remove a cancerous tumor from his pelvic region. He acknowledged Wednesday that he required further treatment for cancer but has not said what kind of cancer he has. On Friday, he said he was sending a letter to the president of the National Assembly to secure authorization for his trip, as required by the Constitution.

headline: A Pizzeria From Another Era
text: Many of the food outlets in Lawrenceville’s Mercer Mall (Chevy’s, Arby’s, Hooters) can be found, duplicated, in malls across America. But Red Moon Pizza, which has been in business for more than 30 years, is related to no other pizza parlor of that name.

headline: A Resort Restaurant Focused on Simplicity
text: WHEN Janine Cinseruli was 16, she began a restaurant career that took her to Chicago, Miami and the East Village in Manhattan before she left it all behind to flip houses in Asbury Park. Or so she thought. Then a friend told her about a popular restaurant in Ocean Grove (the home of a 142-year-old Methodist camp meeting) whose owner wanted to sell.

headline: Animal Collective’s Music Fills the Space at Pitchfork
text: CHICAGO — Filling space is of optimal importance at a festival on the scale of Pitchfork. Union Park is the size of a few city blocks, and there are three stages: the two biggest at one end, separated by a few hundred feet, and the smallest at the opposite end.

headline: At Black Label’s Bike Kill, ‘Freedom Via Mayhem’
