text: Julie Glassberg spent more than a year with the New York chapter of the Black Label Bike Club, capturing the postindustrial landscapes its members inhabit.

headline: The World This Week
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: Russia: Abortion Restrictions Signed
text: President Dmitri A. Medvedev has signed into law the first steps intended to restrict abortion in Russia since the collapse of Communism. The changes require abortion providers to devote 10 percent of any advertising to describing the dangers of abortion to a woman’s health, and they make it illegal to describe abortion as a safe medical procedure. The changes, which will take effect in 30 days, were signed by Mr. Medvedev on Monday and announced Thursday on the Kremlin’s Web site. Parliament is expected to consider tighter restrictions on abortion in a separate bill this fall.

headline: California: ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Is Back, Temporarily
text: A federal appeals court has temporarily reinstated the policy that prohibits openly gay men and women from serving in the military — but prohibited any investigation, penalties or discharges under the rule. A three-judge panel on the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit had, on July 6, ordered the military to end the policy. The judges issued the three-page order late Friday in response to an emergency request by the Obama administration to let the Department of Defense continue its repeal process in an orderly fashion. The government provided “considerably more detailed information” about the repeal in its most recent filings, including statements that the military would be presenting its certification to repeal the policy to the president and top military officials “in a matter of weeks.” “Don’t ask, don’t tell” will officially end 60 days after certification.

headline: Pig, Pig and More Pig
text: A concoction called Bacon Explosion rolls bacon and sausage together and can be baked or cooked in a smoker.

headline: At Black Label’s Bike Kill, ‘Freedom via Mayhem’
text: Julie Glassberg spent more than a year with the New York chapter of the Black Label Bike Club, capturing the postindustrial landscapes its members inhabit.

headline: ‘Freedom, via Mayhem’
text: TAKE a dash of “Mad Max,” add a pinch of “Jackass,” sprinkle both over a wet batter of art students, bicycle messengers, anarchist welders and militant anti-globalist vegans, then let the mixture bake for, say, a decade in the oven of Brooklyn, and the resulting dish should taste a little like the Black Label Bike Club.

headline: Japan Operator Shutting Down Nuclear Reactor After Malfunction
text: TOKYO — Japan’s second-largest nuclear operator said Saturday that it was manually shutting down a reactor in central Japan after a technical malfunction.

headline: In Worley, Phillies Have a Valuable Spare Starter
text: With the array of aces at the Philadelphia Phillies’ disposal, it would almost be unfair if they were to unearth a future front-line starter to plug in at the back end of their star-studded rotation. But in Vance Worley, the Phillies might have found just that.

headline: Jerry Ragovoy, Writer of Soulful Ballads, Dies at 80
text: Jerry Ragovoy, who wrote or collaborated on some of the most soulful ballads of the 1960s, including the Rolling Stones hit “Time Is on My Side” and the Janis Joplin signatures “Piece of My Heart,” “Cry Baby” and “Try (Just a Little Bit Harder),” died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 80.

headline: A ‘Friday Night Lights’ Farewell
text: There are few series I can think of whose conclusions occasion feelings of sorrow. “The Sopranos” ended amid confusion and awe. We may miss the narrative and the ingeniously black comedy of it all, if not the actual characters, none of whom you really want tucking you into bed at night. The same can be said of “Big Love,” another of the greatest family dramas ever on television. Though we may miss its intelligent social commentary, we do not necessarily pine for the people in it to re-enter our lives. HBO renders characters ambiguously; we are not supposed to fall in love with each and every one of them.

headline: Francisco Villagrán Kramer, Guatemala Official, Dies at 84
text: Francisco Villagrán Kramer, a politician and an internationally known legal scholar who went into self-imposed exile in the United States after joining and then defying Guatemala’s right-wing military government in the late 1970s, died Tuesday. He was 84.

headline: Corrections: July 16
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Travis Bean, Aluminum Guitar Maker, Dies at 63
text: Travis Bean, a machinist who earned a nugget of rock ’n’ roll immortality by making electric guitars with necks fashioned out of aluminum instead of wood and selling them to members of the Grateful Dead and the Rolling Stones, died on July 10 in Burbank, Calif. He was 63.

headline: A Gentle Reminder of Paul McCartney’s Survival and Vitality
text: The cheerful, childlike doggerel of “Hello Goodbye” — ”I don’t know why you say goodbye/I say hello” — struck an unexpected note as Paul McCartney sang it on Friday night to start his two-night stand at Yankee Stadium. “Who is this Derek Jeter guy?” Mr. McCartney asked. “Somebody said he’s got more hits than me.”

headline: Sergio Agüero, the Son-in-Law of God, Escapes Long Shadows
text: What’s the dinner conversation like these days at Sergio Agüero’s house when his in-laws visit?

headline: Classic Ad: “See the U.S.A. in Your Chevrolet”
text: This week we present what might be the most classic of all car ads: Dinah Shore’s famous ode to Chevy, which sponsored multiple incarnations of her television show for more than a decade in the 1950s and 60s.

headline: East London Festival Puts Culture on the Water
text: Regents Canal was built in the early 19th century to carry coal and other goods across northern London. Although its commercial days are long over, it has found a new life as a popular site for boat trips and other leisure activities — among them the Shoreditch Festival, which will run in London’s East End from today to July 24. The festival puts on a colorful — and free — program of entertainment, including theater, dance and musical performances, as well as exploration of East London’s waterways.

headline: The Weekend Word: Fallbacks
text: Today’s Times

headline: Vatican Excommunicates Chinese Bishop
text: ROME — A Chinese bishop ordained without papal approval was excommunicated for accepting his new post, the Vatican announced Saturday.

headline: Use a Bigger Fork and You’ll Eat Less
text: By now you’ve probably heard — from nutritionists, diet books and TV personalities — that bigger plates encourage people to eat more food. A new study, published in The Journal of Consumer Research, finds that the size of your utensils has the opposite effect: using a bigger fork leads people to eat less.

headline: Clinton Chides Turkey on Rights Record
text: ISTANBUL — In a series of pointed statements, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton criticized Turkey, a close NATO ally, on Saturday, for its mixed record on press and other freedoms.

headline: The Political Economy of the Lesser Depression
text: Everyone in the forecasting business is scrambling to mark down both their estimates of second-quarter growth and their forecasts for later in the year. Goldman Sachs (no link) was pretty optimistic a few months ago; now they’ve grown quite pessimistic:

headline: Los Angeles Freeway Is Closed and Life Goes On
text: LOS ANGELES — The warnings had been grim: a knot of traffic stretching from the Pacific Ocean to downtown Los Angeles. Motorists struggling to make it from West Los Angeles across the Sepulveda Pass into the San Fernando Valley. A display of gridlock that would drain even the most hardened Los Angeles commuter, all caused by the weekend closing of a 10-mile stretch of Interstate 405.

headline: Clarke Leads a Blustery Third Round
text: SANDWICH, England — A Saturday that began with heavy rain, high winds and high scores at the British Open ended with clear skies, low scores and very high hopes for a clear-cut leader and a group of fast followers who all have something to prove.

headline: Innocence Is Lost With Mets’ Deal of Rodriguez
text: My 5-year-old son woke up Wednesday a child. Mommy had let him stay up way past bedtime to watch the first three innings of the All-Star Game. He munched on Cheerios awaiting another glorious day at summer camp. Then he saw the thick type at the top of the newspaper.

headline: In Central Florida, a Chorus of ‘Happy Trails’ to Anthony, Minus the ‘Happy’
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — When Casey Anthony stepped out of jail on Sunday after nearly three years inside, the Orange County Sheriff’s Office whisked her to ...

headline: Who Pays Rick Perry’s Travel Bill?
text: Gov. Rick Perry has been burning up the miles since he won re-election last year. He is on track to have made nearly 50 stops in 21 states by November.

headline: Murky Waters This Year in Free-Agent Pool
text: At some point, perhaps soon, the N.F.L. and its players will reach a new labor agreement, and the great free-agent gold rush of 2011 will begin. But for now, for as many as 500 free agents, there is no blueprint, no courting or being courted, only anticipation for what comes next and more labor pains induced in the form of unemployment.

headline: For Retired Players, No Seat at the Table
text: The N.F.L. legend Jim Brown added his voice to the growing chorus of retired players who feel that they have been discarded like worn tires.

headline: Reshuffling Blurs Picture, Jeopardizing Conferences
text: Being the commissioner of the Central Collegiate Hockey Association, one of the nation’s leading conferences, is ordinarily a pretty good deal. The conference, which has existed since 1971, sends multiple teams to the N.C.A.A. men’s hockey tournament every year and has won 9 of the past 27 national championships.

headline: Variety: A Past-its-Peak Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — If you watch a lot of television, there comes a point in most series where the entertainment level drops precipitously, and that is the point where the show is said to have “jumped the shark.” It might be a case of a specific character doing something that just strains viewers’ credulity, or the entire storyline might just lose its oomph. Either way, it’s a clear signal to everyone involved that it might be time to re-tool the show or pack up their toys and go home.

headline: Women’s World Cup: This Time, a Show Worth Watching
text: When the Women’s World Cup was played the United States in 1999, I went to the opening game at Giants Stadium, eager to be supportive. The atmosphere was great, the soccer dreadful. So slow, so clumsy — the women looked as if they were trying to play soccer under water. In 2003, and in 2007, I had trouble making myself watch on television.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Vincent Nobile: A Drag-Racing Whiz Kid
text: Vincent Nobile is 19 years old, just completed his first year as a business administration major at Adelphi University and lives with his parents in Dix Hills on Long Island. Nobile played shortstop in high school, and his bedroom is decorated with Yankees memorabilia.

headline: So Much Potential, So Far to Go for Young Basketball Prospect
text: NORTH AUGUSTA, S.C. — When the 7-foot-4 center Sim Bhullar walks through airports, people flock to him and ask him to pose for pictures. When he recently visited India, where his parents were born, so many approached him at the Sikh shrine known as the Golden Temple that he was ushered into an office. People hung on the bars of the office windows to catch a glance.

headline: World Cup Finalists Size Up Their Opponents
text: FRANKFURT, Germany — If it wasn’t yet apparent how confident Japan had grown after victories over Germany and Sweden in the Women’s World Cup, it became clear when Coach Norio Sasaki was asked about potential American vulnerability in Sunday’s final.

headline: Abby Wambach Stands Tall for U.S.
text: FRANKFURT — Abby Wambach’s halftime instructions to a teammate were simple and insistent: Just put the ball on the back post. We’ll get a goal.

headline: Last Golfer in Becomes Odd One Out
text: SANDWICH, England — Safely inside the interview tent with water still dripping off the bill of his cap, Matt Millar, the first man to finish on Saturday, looked over his shoulder toward the British Open course where he had just shot a 10-over-par 80.

headline: A Day of Apologies for the Murdochs, and of New Questions for Cameron
text: LONDON — As Rupert Murdoch’s newspaper empire on Saturday published full-page ads in every national newspaper in Britain under the words “We are sorry,” the government of Prime Minister David Cameron released information documenting the prime minister’s close ties to Murdoch company executives that continued even as the phone-hacking scandal grew.

headline: 2nd Loans, 2nd Wave of Losses
text: HAVE you heard the good news? Big banks are making more money than we thought.

headline: Fostering a Culture of Dissent
text: This interview with  David Sacks, founder, chairman and C.E.O. of Yammer, which offers workplace communication tools, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Law School Economics: Ka-Ching!
text: WITH apologies to show business, there’s no business like the business of law school.

headline: Interstate 405 Closed to Traffic
text: A 10-mile stretch of one of the nation’s busiest freeways has turned into a virtual ghost road in Los Angeles.

headline: Light-Eyed Players Deal With Glare, and Doubts
text: During the third inning of a March 17 spring training game, Chicago White Sox shortstop Alexei Ramirez hit a soft fly ball to left field. Milwaukee Brewers outfielder Mark Kotsay had his sunglasses on, as he always does, but as he ran in toward the ball it disappeared into the glare of the harsh Arizona sun.

headline: Stain From Tabloids Rubs Off on a Cozy Scotland Yard
text: LONDON — For nearly four years they lay piled in a Scotland Yard evidence room, six overstuffed plastic bags gathering dust and little else.

headline: Seeing Promise and Peril in Digital Records
text: TECHNICAL standards may seem arcane, but they are often powerful tools of economic development and social welfare. They can be essential building blocks for innovation and new industries. The basic software standards for the Web are striking proof.

headline: Arab Spring, Start-Up Summer?
text: LIKE so many other young people in Cairo, Yasmine el-Mehairy saw no future in Egypt. What she saw was a dead end.

headline: From Yankees’ Rotation to Nationals’ Bullpen, and Thriving
text: When the Yankees sent Tyler Clippard to the Washington Nationals at the winter meetings in December 2007, Clippard had never heard of the pitcher he was traded for.

headline: The Wages of Virtue and Vice
text: VICE and virtue are engaged in a titanic struggle on many fronts, and vice often appears to have the upper hand. Just read the headlines. Scandals in politics, sports, business and journalism seem to be popping up everywhere.

headline: Getting the Most Out of Social Security
text: SOCIAL SECURITY may be the most beloved of all the government’s programs, partly because it requires so little thinking. You pay taxes while you work, then you and your spouse collect until you die.

headline: Bring Your A Game
text: I WAS born in Fort Wayne, Ind., and moved to Dayton, Ohio, when I was 6. I colored paper doilies as a child and sold them around the neighborhood. In high school, I worked as a temp, which gave me experience in different companies. I also worked at McDonald’s and as a babysitter.

headline: Working Separately, Together
text: THE grass is always greener on the other side of the cubicle. Corporate types curse during long commutes and feel shackled to their desks when the weather outside is gorgeous. If only they could work from home and have a more flexible schedule.

headline: Girardi Shows Signs of Frustration
text: TORONTO — Manager Joe Girardi’s frustration with his team’s poor play in the first two games here seemed to boil over Saturday morning when he all but accused the Blue Jays of using off-the-field means to steal the Yankees’ signs. The day after applauding their resourcefulness in divining Russell Martin’s signals from second base, Girardi turned testy when asked why he told Martin on Friday night to use complicated signs even with no one on base.

headline: Compelling Tales, Rarely Told Well
text: THIS is going to be awkward. I’ve spent weeks, in fact, debating whether and how to say this in print. But it’s something that’s irked me for years. And while occupying this chair these last months, it’s a feeling that’s only strengthened: The fact is, I find the quality of too many business books, well, underwhelming. There. I said it.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: A tabloid closing in London, Captain America at the stock market, the results of stress tests on European banks and more.

headline: German Group That Cited Putin as ‘Role Model’ Cancels Prize After Outcry
text: BERLIN — A German nonprofit group canceled its annual prize ceremony on Saturday after its decision to honor Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia sparked a public outcry.

headline: Election Cycle Emerges as the Year of the Pledge, but Some Candidates Resist
text: This is the year presidential candidates are being asked to take the pledge.

headline: At Two-Year Colleges, Less Scrutiny Equals Less Athletic Equality
text: Los Angeles Southwest College has a new athletic field house and football stadium, but almost no female athletes.

headline: Union Yields on Benefits in Deal With Cuomo
text: New York State’s second-largest union of public workers, facing hundreds of layoffs that had been scheduled to take effect within days, agreed on Saturday to significant wage and benefit concessions in order to save the jobs of its members.

headline: J. Terrence Lanni, Ex-Chief of MGM Mirage, Dies at 68
text: J. Terrence Lanni, a gambling company executive who helped turn a single casino into the industry giant now known as MGM Resorts International, died on Thursday night at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 68.

headline: Making Sustainable Surfboards
text: Danny Hess of San Francisco left his job as a building contractor to devote himself to creating environmentally friendly and long-lasting surfboards.

headline: The Man Who Financed the Civil War
text: Washington, D.C., July 17, 1861

headline: Injured Romeo Will Miss Sunday’s Performance
text: Sam Troughton, the star of the Royal Shakespeare Company’s production of “Romeo and Juliet,” is recovering from arthroscopic surgery on his knee and will miss Sunday night’s performance at the Park Avenue Armory, a spokeswoman for the company, Nada Zakula, said.

headline: A Witness to 3,000, Again
text: The clip will be replayed for generations, along with the call from Michael Kay on the YES Network:

headline: Dalai Lama and Obama Meet to Talk About Tibet
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama met privately with the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibet, at the White House on Saturday, despite a warning from Beijing that the meeting would risk damaging relations between China and the United States.

headline: Sabathia Reminds the Yankees What They’re Not Missing
text: TORONTO — The Yankees have their flaws, as the first two games of a series here against the Blue Jays showed, but on days when C. C. Sabathia pitches, none of them seem to matter. Let others fret about an understaffed bullpen, a wobbly third baseman or an unsteady rotation. With Sabathia on the mound, the Yankees do not worry. They just watch, marvel and win.

headline: Brian Wilson: Part-Time Closer, Part-Time Statistician
text: As a starting pitcher in high school, Brian Wilson said, he kept the scorebook on the days he did not pitch. At Louisiana State, he kept the scorebook on days he manned the radar gun in the stands. Many pitchers perform these duties.

headline: Pacific Pinball Museum
text: Alameda Island, the site of a former military base, can feel like a 1950s-era small town, with its Craftsman-style homes and neighborhood bars. The addition of a pinball museum, where old-fashioned bonks are more common than electronic beeps, has only heightened that effect. Michael Schiess, a former museum exhibit builder, opened his Alameda pinball palace in 2001, attracting devoted “pinheads” and casual players alike.  ANDY WRIGHT

headline: Spectators Will Escape to Alcatraz for the Cup
text: Alcatraz, the fog-shrouded rock transformed from an island prison into one of San Francisco’s most famous landmarks, is about to get a new identity — best seat in the house for the America’s Cup.

headline: Scientists Fight a Deadly Oak-Tree Disease
text: On a hot summer day in 2008, a pair of plant disease researchers made an extraordinary discovery as they toured a hillside forest in San Mateo County: a stand of trees that had not been infected by the killer disease known as sudden oak death.

headline: Latest BART Shooting Prompts New Discussion of Reforms
text: After a white BART police officer shot and killed an unarmed black man shortly after New Year’s 2009, the transit agency agreed to 127 policy changes recommended by an independent auditor. They included arming officers with Tasers and providing crisis-intervention training for the BART police force.

headline: At the Break, the Sox Are in Sorry Shape
text: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Today is Sunday. It Must Be Time for a News Conference
text: Every day brings an effort by Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel to capture a news cycle or three.

headline: Foreclosure? Many Pets Are Losing Their Homes
text: People are not the only victims of the dismal economy. Pets are also being forced to cope. Several Chicago-area animal shelters report a sharp uptick in the number of abandoned dogs and cats in the last four years. “We certainly have seen an increase in dogs surrendered,” said Dr. Robyn Barbiers, executive director of the Anti-Cruelty Society. In its last fiscal year, ended June 2010, the shelter received 854 dogs. This year, the number jumped to nearly 1,000.

headline: Young Man’s Death Rattles Indiana Beach Community
text: It was a Fourth of July like any other in Long Beach, Ind., an idyllic lakeside getaway frequented by well-heeled members of Chicago’s Irish community — a “Norman Rockwell scene” in the words of several local residents — complete with a parade and fireworks over the golf course.

headline: A Texan in Washington Who Hasn’t Gone Native
text: Ross Ramsey, managing editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Jailbreaks Make for Good TV, but Remain Rare
text: Robert Dudley and Rickey Taylor wanted out of the Ector County Jail, apparently quite badly. Twice this year, using makeshift digging tools and squeezing through dark tunnels inside the jail in Odessa, they nearly succeeded, taking advantage of weaknesses in the West Texas facility.

headline: Four Hidden Beach Getaways, All Within State Lines
text: Tell someone you’re vacationing on the Texas coast, and you’ll probably get a sympathetic smile. This is a fair reaction in a state with more than 350 miles of coastline and, no offense to God’s country, a lot of underwhelming beaches.

headline: On the Rise in Tajikistan, Islam Worries an Authoritarian Government
text: DUSHANBE, Tajikistan — Islam is blossoming in Tajikistan. Beards are in style. Headscarves, too. Bazaars are doing a booming trade in prayer rugs, religious audio recordings and gaudy clocks featuring Muslim holy sites.

headline: Sunday: The End Is in Sight
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I really, really liked this one. Who knew there were so many familiar phrases that had a letter or letters within them that made the same sound as the last word in the phrase? Daniel A. Finan has found them for us, matched them up according to letter counts, and created a puzzle that just rocks, themewise. I would have liked it even more if there hadn’t been so much jumping around (“See X Down to get a hint to the answer to Y Across”), but all in all, I enjoyed myself.

headline: The V.A. Tries to Get Beyond Its Culture of No
text: The Veterans Affairs Department says that it is not only making strides in treating post-traumatic stress disorder and brain injuries and in preventing suicides, but is also upending its reputation for bureaucratic delays and unresponsiveness.

headline: A New Try at Curbing Piracy
text: After years of trying to stop illegal downloading of music and videos by suing their fans, enticing them to pay through easier formats, and encrypting digital files, the music and movie industries hope they have found an effective approach to fighting copyright theft. This month, several major Internet service providers, including Verizon, Comcast, AT&T and Time Warner Cable, agreed to help movie studios and record labels identify Internet users who downloaded copyrighted content illicitly, warn them about the piracy and punish recalcitrant abusers.

headline: Correspondence Between The New York Times and Scotland Yard
text: Documents show The New York Times’s request for information about the phone-hacking scandal at The News of the World that was sent last year to Scotland Yard, and its response.

headline: Are They Learning?
text: A cheating scandal in which scores of teachers and principals in Atlanta’s public schools falsified student test results has thrown the system into chaos and made its name synonymous with fraud. This shameful episode has destroyed trust in the schools and made it impossible to determine how much students are learning and whether the system is doing its job.

headline: Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me
text: NPR’s “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!” is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/programs/wait-wait-dont-tell-me/)

headline: Clashing Views on the Future of Natural Gas
text: A NEW YORK TIMES article last month, “Insiders Sound an Alarm Amid a Natural Gas Rush,” warned across two columns at the top of the front page that high expectations for companies drilling shale gas might be headed for a fall. It was the kind of story you wish The Times had written about Enron before it collapsed. Or about Bernard Madoff.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Seeking a Path Through Depression’s Landscape
text: Do antidepressants work? Doctors and patients respond to a letter on Wednesday that questioned their liberal use.

headline: The Critique of Pure Horror
text: WITH gruesome television series about vampires, werewolves, serial killers and zombies earning huge ratings, and a new cinematic bloodbath opening seemingly every week, the cultural appetite for horror raises a curious question: why do so many of us enjoy being disgusted and terrified?

headline: Should Cities Drive Food Trucks Off the Streets?
text: ATLANTA

headline: Oliver Sacks
text: What’s on your mind? The Sunday Review asked Oliver Sacks, a physician, author and professor of neurology and psychiatry at the Columbia University Medical Center.

headline: Books and Other Fetish Objects
text: I GOT a real thrill in December 1999 in the Reading Room of the Morgan Library in New York when the librarian, Sylvie Merian, brought me, after I had completed an application with a letter of reference and a photo ID, the first, oldest notebook of Isaac Newton. First I was required to study a microfilm version. There followed a certain amount of appropriate pomp. The notebook was lifted from a blue cloth drop-spine box and laid on a special padded stand. I was struck by how impossibly tiny it was — 58 leaves bound in vellum, just 2 3/4 inches wide, half the size I would have guessed from the enlarged microfilm images. There was his name, “Isacus Newton,” proudly inscribed by the 17-year-old with his quill, and the date, 1659.

headline: Patrolling Cancer’s Borderlands
text: THREE recent events highlight the extraordinary task that lies ahead for cancer prevention.

headline: How to Pull Off a Vanishing Act
text: IT’S starting to look likely — given news reports about her interest in fake names and disguises — that if Casey Anthony gets out of jail as scheduled this weekend, she will do her best to avoid the public eye and join the list of runaways that has recently included James (Whitey) Bulger, Ratko Mladic, Osama bin Laden and certain state senators from Wisconsin.

headline: Terrorism and the Law
text: The prosecution of a Somali national accused of supporting Al Qaeda is now headed for trial in a federal court, where it belonged all along. The Obama administration finally made the right decision over the usual self-serving objections of grandstanding senators from both parties. But it is troubling that the administration delayed this step for almost two months.

headline: Our Broken Escalator
text: YAMHILL, Ore.

headline: The Clash of Generations
text: ATHENS

headline: We’re Spent
text: THERE is no shortage of explanations for the economy’s maddening inability to leave behind the Great Recession and start adding large numbers of jobs: The deficit is too big. The stimulus was flawed. China is overtaking us. Businesses are overregulated. Wall Street is underregulated.

headline: Four With Links Between Scotland Yard and News International
text: Four With Links Between Scotland Yard and News International

headline: Growing Up, Then Going Home
text: Since 2009, unemployment among recent college graduates has risen, while starting salaries have fallen. The median student debt load for those who graduated from 2006 to 2010 is $20,000. Not surprisingly, 40 percent of 20-somethings move back in with their parents at least once. Here are some dispatches from the home front.

headline: Why Would Anyone Miss War?
text: SEVERAL years ago I spent time with a platoon of Army infantry at a remote outpost in eastern Afghanistan, and after the deployment I was surprised that only one of the soldiers chose to leave the military at the end of his contract; many others re-upped and eventually went on to fight for another year in the same area. The soldier who got out, Brendan O’Byrne, remained a good friend of mine as he struggled to fit in to civilian life back home.

headline: Lawmakers, Armed and Dangerous
text: WHILE all the country gaped last week at the acrimony ensnarling the federal government, Arizonans were treated to an additional, equally bizarre spectacle. You’ll be shocked to hear that a firearm was involved.

headline: Drought: A Creeping Disaster
text: FLOODS, tornadoes, earthquakes, tsunamis and other geological phenomena have left a trail of destruction during the first half of 2011. But this could be just the start to a remarkable year of bad weather. Next up: drought. In the South, 14 states are now baking in blast-furnace conditions — from Arizona, which is battling the largest wildfire in its history, to Florida, where fires have burned some 200,000 acres so far. Worse, drought, unlike earthquakes, hurricanes and other rapid-moving weather, could become a permanent condition in some regions.

headline: Pitchfork: Too Hot to Mosh, or Wear Black
text: CHICAGO — It’s hot. Don’t-wanna-move hot. Watch-a-band-for-10-minutes-then-find-3-minutes-of-shade hot. Popular outfit for boys: tank top, cut-off jeans, Vans with no socks. Popular outfit for girls: sundress, sandals, wide-brimmed hat.

headline: Education, Education, Education
text: My Sunday column is a despairing bleat at the cutbacks in education budgets around the country — including my old school, Yamhill-Carlton High School, here in Yamhill, Oregon. In years of writing about poverty, I’ve come to believe firmly that there are no perfect solutions either in America or abroad — but the closest thing to a silver bullet is an excellent education system. And it is so frustrating that that’s still what’s missing in so many communities.

headline: Ethnic Music Tests Limits in China
text: BEIJING — They have toured Europe, played alongside marquee names like the band Coldplay and earned plaudits in the international press. But here in China, the growing popularity of the Mongolian rock band Hanggai has not exactly inspired adulation from the authorities.

headline: Why Are Prosecutors Striking Out?
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Fighting for Folk
text: Hanggai, an ethnic Mongolian folk-rock band in Beijing, wants to show its audience that music made by minorities in China isn't always so traditional.

headline: Italy Versus Japan
text: A question (to which I don’t have the full answer): why are the interest rates on Italian and Japanese debt so different? As of right now, 10-year Japanese bonds are yielding 1.09%; 10-year Italian bonds 5.76%.

headline: Photo Replay: July 16
text: The day in sports, including heavy rain at the British Open and the beginning of the FINA Swimming World Championships.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Faces Military Limits
text: With the military’s ban on openly gay troops expected to end this fall, advocates for gay and lesbian service members are already looking ahead to the next battle: winning equal benefits for same-sex married couples.

headline: 'We're All Heterosexual'
text: John Becker, a gay-rights activist, posed as a patient seeking therapy at a Christian mental health clinic owned by Marcus Bachmann, Michele Bachmann's husband, and secretly taped the sessions.

headline: Options for Gay Patients
text: John Becker, a gay-rights activist, posed as a patient seeking therapy at a Christian mental health clinic owned by Marcus Bachmann, Michele Bachmann's husband, and secretly taped the sessions.

headline: Dealing With Rentiers
text: Not the best quality video — but Robin and I saw this production, and it was awesomely good.

headline: G.O.P. Freshmen Say Debt Concerns Them More Than Re-election
text: WASHINGTON — For years, legislation to raise the federal debt limit offered plenty of political theater on Capitol Hill, with the party out of power using it to rail against the party in power. As a senator, Barack Obama said in 2006 that a bill to raise the debt limit was “a sign of leadership failure.”

headline: Hairston Fills in With a Career Day, and the Mets Thwart Hamels Again
text: Despite delivering a long home run Friday, Carlos Beltran was racked with a fever and flulike symptoms Saturday, to the point that he could not make it to Citi Field. Considering he is the Mets’ leader in home runs, runs batted in and extra-base hits, his loss seemed a daunting one.

headline: Battle for Libya | July 16, 2011
text: Libyan rebels said their steady advance on Brega was slowed Saturday by the discovery of defensive trenches around the city that had been filled with flammable chemicals by retreating troops loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Chávez Puts His Trust in Castro for Care
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela boarded a plane bound for Cuba on Saturday to receive more treatment for a cancer whose details still remain a mystery to the outside world.

headline: Fowler and McIlroy: a Growing Gap
text: SANDWICH, England — Hailed as the present and future of golf after his romp at the United States Open, Rory McIlroy has not even been the best mop-topped 22-year-old at this British Open.

headline: Geoff Fisken, New Zealand Sheep Farmer and Scourge of Japanese Pilots, Dies at 96
text: Growing up on New Zealand’s North Island in the 1920s, Geoff Fisken seemed destined for a quiet life working on the vast sheep farms his father owned. But he became fascinated by airplanes when his father, Robert, began flying on his trips around the country. At 14, Geoff flew solo in a biplane.

headline: An Alarming New Stimulant, Legal in Many States
text: Dr. Jeffrey J. Narmi could not believe what he was seeing this spring in the emergency room at Schuylkill Medical Center in Pottsville, Pa.: people arriving so agitated, violent and psychotic that a small army of medical workers was needed to hold them down.

headline: For Bachmann, Gay Rights Stand Reflects Mix of Issues and Faith
text: ST. PAUL — In March 2004, with Massachusetts soon to allow gay couples to wed, Michele Bachmann delivered a dire warning to her fellow Minnesotans: The children of their state were at risk.

headline: Christian Counseling by Hopeful’s Spouse Prompts Questions
text: LAKE ELMO, Minn. — The receptionists at Bachmann & Associates, the Christian counseling center run by the husband of the presidential hopeful Michele Bachmann, were polite but firm in turning a reporter away the other day. A new sign was on the door. “Bachmann & Associates,” it said, “prohibits all soliciting, filming and photography in this building. NO MEDIA.”

headline: Charter School Battle Shifts to Affluent Suburbs
text: MILLBURN, N.J. — Matthew Stewart believes there is a place for charter schools. Just not in his schoolyard.

headline: New Stable of Wealthy Donors Fueled Obama Campaign’s Record Fund-Raising Quarter
text: President Obama recruited roughly 150 new elite donors, raising as much as a half a million dollars each, to help propel him to a large and early lead over his Republican opponents in the race for campaign cash, according to campaign filings released last week.

headline: Copa América Semifinals: Argentina Is Out
text: Argentina was eliminated from the Copa América quarterfinals by Uruguay in a penalty kick shootout on Saturday night, a fitting and maddening denouement for the host country in a tournament in which its talented team alternated between fabulous and (more often) frustrating.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 17
text: The looming debt deadline continues to cast shadows over the Sunday talk shows, but this time the discussion is spreading to include the outlook on the state and local levels. A few presidential candidates are also dropping in to share their opinions on how the nation can get out of its budget fix.

headline: After Decades in Top Ranks, a Shot at the Title, Finally
text: Players usually reach their peak in their 20s, so how is it that the grandmaster Boris Gelfand is getting his first crack at becoming world champion when he is 43?

headline: Ardis James, Who Established Center on Quilts, Is Dead at 85
text: Ardis Butler James, a Nebraska-born philanthropist who with her husband established what is now the largest public collection of quilts in the world, encompassing humbly elegant bed coverings by anonymous 18th-century hands and avant-garde wall hangings by celebrated 21st-century artists, died on July 7 in Stamford, Conn. She was 85.

headline: Egypt Military Aims to Cement Muscular Role in Government
text: CAIRO — The military council governing Egypt is moving to lay down ground rules for a new constitution that would protect and potentially expand its own authority indefinitely, possibly circumscribing the power of future elected officials.

headline: Assessing the Future in the Race for Top Amateur
text: SANDWICH, ENGLAND — An amateur who shoots a 65 in his first British Open round, makes the cut with ease and draws praise from none other than Tom Watson should be a lock for the silver medal awarded to the tournament’s leading amateur.

headline: When Did You Lose Your Fan ‘Innocence’?
text: As we are constantly reminded, major league sports are, at heart, a business. Many personnel decisions are based on dollars and cents, not legacies and fan favorites, and it is often the fans who take these decisions the hardest.

headline: Collecting Quilts
text: Ardis James and her husband, Robert, established what has become the world’s largest public collection of quilts, at the University of Nebraska, Lincoln.

headline: Mistake, Then Disaster for Phillies in a Drubbing
text: His shoes off but his gray game shirt still on, his head propped up by his big left hand, Philadelphia first baseman Ryan Howard sat stonily at his locker after the Phillies were drubbed, 11-2, by the Mets on Saturday. Howard had made a mistake that sent the game reeling out of control.

headline: Corrections: July 17
text: SPORTS

headline: Pitchfork: Mini-Explosions to Break Up the Soft Rock
text: CHICAGO — It takes a lot of experience to know what sort of stage banter works during a festival slot. It takes a whole lot more experience to throw all of that hard-earned knowledge out the window and just trust your inner motor.

headline: Agudelo and Bravo Added to M.L.S. All-Star Team
text: Major League Soccer Commissioner Don Garber added Red Bulls striker Juan Agudelo and Sporting Kansas City captain Omar Bravo to the league’s all-star team with his two picks Saturday.

headline: Abby Wambach’s Head for the Game
text: Jeré Longman looks at how Abby Wambach got so good at heading the ball, and how that skill has meant success for the United States women’s national team. Read the article here — don’t miss the graphic charting how many of Wambach’s World Cup shots have come on headers — and come back to comment.

headline: An Arrest and Scotland Yard Resignation Roil Britain
text: LONDON — Britain’s top police official resigned on Sunday, the latest casualty of the phone-hacking scandal engulfing British public life, just hours after Rebekah Brooks, the former chief executive of Rupert Murdoch’s News International, was arrested on suspicion of illegally intercepting phone calls and bribing the police.

headline: Holding Steady on Dreary Day, Clarke Captures His First Major
text: SANDWICH, England — On Sunday at Royal St. George’s, just before Darren Clarke tapped in the putt that would seal it all, the one that would mean the wait was over, that the British Open was his and the 20-year quest had come to an end, he stepped back, grinned, and spoke to himself.

headline: Penny-Wise Policy
text: Mark Thoma sends me to Jonathan Schwarz making the case that Obama knew perfectly well that the stimulus should have been bigger. I’m not sure that lets his advisers completely off the hook; there’s a big difference between saying, well, the macroeconomic case says this should be bigger, but smaller is OK, and saying — as they should have, and maybe some did — that a weak stimulus runs a large risk of setting us on a path toward a lost decade.

headline: In Athens, Clinton Praises Greece for Tackling Its Debt
text: ATHENS — Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Sunday emphasized Washington’s “strong support” for Greece’s commitment to right its debt-ridden economy through tough austerity measures, and she thanked the government for its contributions to NATO-led operations in Libya and diplomatic efforts in the Middle East.

headline: Rained Out in Vancouver
text: International soccer teams generally love coming to North America in the summer, but generally do not like playing on our fake grass, the plastic artificial surfaces in some big, big stadiums.

headline: For FIFA Executives, Luxury and Favors
text: PARIS — The titans of international soccer are used to pampering. Motorcades. Police escorts. Five-star hotels. Lavish dinners. Cash allowances of $500 a day, and an additional $250 for their wives or girlfriends.

headline: Times Editors Respond to my Shale Gas Column
text: Included below is a response from The Times national desk on my column Clashing Views on the Future of Natural Gas.

headline: Mystery Mortgage Economics
text: As most of our attention is focused on the debt-ceiling crisis, another issue is coming to a head: whether prosecutors will rush to let banks off the hook for mortgage abuses in return for a modest settlement, without having done anything like a complete investigation.

headline: Perry  ‘More Comfortable’ With Idea of a Run
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas says that he is getting “more and more comfortable every day” with the idea of running for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Both Sides Confident on Debt Talks Despite Impasse
text: WASHINGTON — Top Republican lawmakers and the Obama administration’s budget director predicted Sunday that an agreement would be reached before the federal government defaults on its debt in early August, but both sides continued to squabble over the details of competing proposals, offering little evidence that a deal was at hand.

headline: Egypt’s Antiquities Chief Says He Will Lose His Job
text: Zahi Hawass, Egypt’s antiquities minister, who has been under fire for his ties to the Mubarak regime, will lose his job in a cabinet reshuffle intended to appease the protesters in Tahrir Square, he confirmed to The New York Times by text message on Sunday. The full details of the cabinet changes have not yet been confirmed. Mr. Hawass’s pending departure was reported by an Egyptian newspaper, Youm7, and Mr. Hawass confirmed the report’s accuracy. Youm7 quoted him as saying that protesters outside his office tried to beat him as he left on Sunday.

headline: Former Ohio Attorney General to Head New Consumer Agency
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Sunday that he would nominate Richard Cordray, the former attorney general of Ohio, to lead the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, passing over Elizabeth Warren, the Harvard law professor who was the driving force behind the agency’s creation.

headline: Freeway Project Finishes (Surprise!) Ahead of Schedule
text: LOS ANGELES — Start your engines. It’s safe to come back.

headline: Japan Celebrates a Victory Worth Staying Up For
text: TOKYO — Fans here spilled into the streets at 6:45 a.m., hugging and cheering after Japan defeated the United States in the Women’s World Cup final to lift the spirits of a country still reeling from the earthquake and tsunami that struck on March 11.

headline: Women’s World Cup Final: Japan Stuns U.S. in Shootout
text: Japan won the Women’s World Cup for the first time on Sunday, stunning the United States in a penalty kick shootout after the teams played a pulsating 2-2 tie in Frankfurt, Germany.

headline: Creditors See Talks Advancing on 2nd Greek Rescue
text: The group representing Greece’s private creditors said Sunday that progress was being made in working out the involvement of international banks in the next Greek bailout.

headline: Get Them From The Greeks
text: I’ve complained a lot about the Hellenization of our economic discourse — the insistence, in the teeth of evidence, that America is just like Greece in budget terms. Now comes Lindsey Graham to promote the fallacy. So let’s talk, again, about why it’s nonsense.

headline: Millions of Muggles Propel Potter Film at Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — And now we know the spell for raining cash.

headline: Lawyer Says Mubarak Is in a Coma, but the Report Is Quickly Contradicted
text: CAIRO — Conflicts about the deteriorating health of former President Hosni Mubarak reached a new peak on Sunday, when his lawyer announced he had suffered a stroke and slipped into a coma, only to be contradicted hours later by state television and hospital officials who said he had a temporary bout of low blood pressure.

headline: Karzai Adviser Is Killed at Kabul Home
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A close adviser to President Hamid Karzai was killed on Sunday night after two gunmen stormed his walled home here. It was the second killing in less than a week of one of the president’s trusted but controversial political allies.

headline: Waiting for Harry, Chinese Filmgoers Get Patriotic Epic
text: BEIJING — It has been something of cruel summer for Chinese movie audiences. The latest installments of Hollywood blockbusters like “Transformers: Dark of the Moon” and “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2” have been delayed, and it is doubtful that American-made crowd pleasers like “Horrible Bosses” and “The Hangover Part II” will ever arrive in theaters. In the meantime countless moviegoers have been driven into cinemas as part of a government campaign to promote a sprawling epic about the Chinese Communist Party.

headline: When Subways Weren’t Sardine Cans
text: In a City Room post accompanying his article about the rise in weekend subway ridership, Michael M. Grynbaum asked readers to recount their memories of the city subway system of the 1970s and 1980s, when riders had plenty of leg room on weekends, but had to contend with plenty of problems, too. Below, some of the more interesting reader responses, edited for style and space.

headline: From a Long Toss From Shea to a Mets Closer
text: Pedro Beato vividly recalls the day he arrived in New York City from his native Dominican Republic.

headline: Scotland Yard Chief’s Resignation Statement
text: As my colleagues Alan Cowell and Ravi Somaiya report, the commissioner of London’s Metropolitan Police Service, Sir Paul Stephenson, resigned his post on Sunday, “as damage from a phone-hacking scandal moved to the highest levels of British public life.”

headline: After Brooklyn Boy’s Murder, Father of Etan Patz Has a Suggestion
text: Stanley Patz has been conditioned to expect his telephone to ring whenever a child goes missing, so he was bracing when he heard about the disappearance of an 8-year-old boy, Leiby Kletzky, last week in Brooklyn.

headline: Hughes Pitches More Like His Old Self in a Win
text: TORONTO — A man wearing a gray uniform with “New York” on the front and No. 65 on the back stood atop the Rogers Centre mound Sunday. He looked like Phil Hughes, but it had been so long since the Yankees saw him fire fastballs and curveballs with precision against major league hitters that it seemed possible an impostor had replaced him.

headline: Media Response to the Arrest of Rebekah Brooks
text: News of Sunday’s arrest of Rebekah Brooks, the former chief of Rupert Murdoch’s media operations in Britain, was greeted with a mix of righteous indignation that she had clung to power for so long, barely concealed glee by some of Mr. Murdoch’s rivals and conspicuous understatement in at least one of the tabloid newspapers that Ms. Brooks once edited.

headline: Illuminating California’s Proposition 8 Trial, Onstage
text: A new play based on the Proposition 8 trial over same-sex marriage in California, written by the Academy Award winner Dustin Lance Black (“Milk”), will be performed in a staged reading on Broadway in September and then produced at Carnegie Mellon University, Northwestern, the University of Michigan, and elsewhere.

headline: Reality Hits Hard, but the Short-Handed Mets Don’t, in a Sloppy Defeat
text: One day after bullying an All-Star pitcher on the league’s best team, the Mets on Sunday painted a slightly more accurate portrait of how a third-place team missing its four best hitters should look.

headline: This Carmen Seeks Liberty in a Bullring, With Strokes of Fate
text: The most important feature of the Mariinsky Ballet’s season at the Metropolitan Opera House last week is what it didn’t contain. It’s 50 years since the company (then named Kirov) first danced in New York and the West. Hitherto its visits have featured a large proportion of the 19th-century ballet classics. Not so this time. Of its three recent programs in New York, two were of ballets created in the 21st century, while the third was a pair of ballets from 1947 and 1967.

headline: High Kicks, Mugging and Poses in the Park
text: Oh, SummerStage. You mean so well. You invite us out to sit under the stars. You offer a variety of refreshments and seating options and let us come and go as we please, asking only unobtrusively for a small donation.

headline: A Captivity No Novelist Could Invent
text: “I would love to be a writer someday,” Jaycee Dugard wrote in her journal in 2002. “I love to write. I have no idea what I would write about.”

headline: Inspired Play From an Award-Worthy Career
text: There are two new inductees to the American Contract Bridge League’s Hall of Fame, Russ Arnold of Sunny Isles Beach, Fla., and Eric Kokish of Toronto.

headline: The Price of Typos
text: Some readers like to see portraits of authors they admire, study their personal histories or hear them read aloud. I like to know whether an author can spell. Nabokov spelled beautifully. Fitzgerald was crummy at spelling, bedeviled by entry-level traps like “definate.” Bad spellers, of course, can be sublime writers and good spellers punctilious duds. But it’s still intriguing that Fitzgerald, for all his gifts, didn’t perceive the word “finite” in definite, the way good spellers automatically do. Did this oversight color his impression of infinity? Infinaty?

headline: Gun-Totin’ Brünnhilde
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — Not three months after singing her first Brünnhilde in the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of Wagner’s “Walküre,” the soprano Deborah Voigt is performing the title role in Irving Berlin’s “Annie Get Your Gun” here at the Glimmerglass Festival. Though a wide-ranging repertory is an admirable quality in an artist, it is quite a leap from Wagner’s “Ring” to a classic Broadway musical. Coming into this production, Ms. Voigt risked looking foolish.

headline: The Old, Inexorable Story of a King’s Disintegration
text: The Royal Shakespeare Company’s production of “King Lear,” directed by David Farr, can be strongly recommended for hypersensitive souls. Have you always found the play to be too devastating to endure, its serial acts of cruelty too relentless to witness? Do you share Samuel Johnson’s moral outrage at the death of Cordelia in the last act? Hie thee to the Park Avenue Armory, where this competent but immaculately unwrenching production of Shakespeare’s harrowing tragedy is providing more than three hours of placid traffic on the stage.

headline: To Pique Interest, Start-Ups Try a Digital Velvet Rope
text: Demand for Google’s new social networking service, Google+, has been intense since its debut last month in a limited test mode. To get in, you must be invited by someone who is already a member, so Facebook and Twitter are peppered with requests for invitations to the service, and they have even been sold on eBay.

headline: Such Stuff as Dreams Are Made on: A Tribute to Cunningham
text: Let’s be pessimistic. Let’s say that when the Merce Cunningham Dance Company shuts down after Dec. 31, his choreography will very seldom be seen again. What will have left the world with it? Many different answers arose while watching the all-day Merce Fair on Saturday. This, as part of the Lincoln Center Festival, occupied seven separate spaces in the Frederick P. Rose Hall. It was called a fair because a wide range of goods was on offer. Cunningham died two years ago this month; this day was the last of his company’s many Lincoln Center appearances over the years.

headline: The Sacred and the Humane
text: Human Rights are all the rage. They have become, currently, a very popular arena for both political activism and rampant discourse. Human rights, as we all know, are the rights humans are due simply by virtue of being human. But there is nothing simple here, since both “human” and “rights” are concepts in need of investigation.

headline: Monday: Attack From Above
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — I realize that some of you solve the puzzle when it comes out the day before, but for the sake of making my point, let’s pretend that it’s Monday morning and you are settling in to solve with your first cup of coffee. You’ve spent the weekend wrestling with the tough Friday and Saturday grids, and you’ve devoted most of your Sunday to finishing the big puzzle and the variety. A challenge is a wonderful thing, but now you need something to ease you into your week.

headline: TNT Ends the Run of Ray Romano’s ‘Men’
text: Fans of TNT’s “Men of a Certain Age” fretted this month that the show might not make it to a third season, and it turns out they were right to worry: the channel said on Friday that it was canceling the drama after two seasons. “This was an extremely difficult decision for us,” TNT said in a statement that read in part, “While the show has featured great storytelling and impeccable performances, the audience simply hasn’t built to the point where we can continue the series.” The series — which averaged fewer than three million viewers in its second season — starred (above from left) Ray Romano, André Braugher and Scott Bakula as men who confronting life in their 50s, making the show something of an anomaly on TNT, which is best known for its crime procedurals. Mike Royce, a creator of the show, told AOL TV that he thanked TNT for trying: “It’s different from their other shows. But even though it’s different, they took a huge chance on it, and they gave it two seasons. The bottom line is that we would have gotten three episodes on a broadcast network.”

headline: Bessie Nominations to Be Announced
text: The 2011 New York Dance and Performance Awards, also known as the Bessies, will be presented on Oct. 24 at the Apollo Theater, organizers are to announce at a news conference on Monday. For the first time nominees in the “outstanding production” categories are being announced in advance. For outstanding production of a work performed in a location with more than 400 seats, the nominees are “Thirteen Diversions” by Christopher Wheeldon, performed by American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House; “Quartet” by Merce Cunningham, performed by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company at the Joyce Theater; and “The Bright Stream” by Alexei Ratmansky, performed by American Ballet Theater at the Met.

headline: Hertz to Buy Donlen, a Fleet Leasing Company
text: Hertz Global Holdings agreed on Sunday to buy the Donlen Corporation, a vehicle leasing and management company, for $250 million in cash. Hertz will also assume Donlen’s $680 million of debt.

headline: Tom Cruise Agrees to Play Jack Reacher
text: Never one to shy away from controversy, Tom Cruise, below, has agreed to play Jack Reacher in “One Shot,” an action thriller based on the best-selling series of books by Lee Child, according to Deadline.com. Reacher, a decorated military officer turned drifter, is described in the novels as standing 6 foot 5 and weighing 250 pounds; Mr. Cruise’s reported height is 5 foot 7. The physical discrepancy has already created some discontent among fans of the series, though Mr. Child has publicly supported the casting. “Reacher’s size in the books is a metaphor for an unstoppable force, which Cruise portrays in his own way,” he said. The movie, which is scheduled to begin filming in the fall, will be directed by Christopher McQuarrie, whose writing credits include “Valkyrie” and the coming “Mission: Impossible — Ghost Protocol,” both starring Mr. Cruise.

headline: Scrambling and Personalizing the Rock Timeline

With just one stage and six bands, it was the pared-down successor to 10 years of the Siren Music Festival that The Voice used to present at Coney Island.

headline: Pitchfork: Odd Future Pushes Back on Protest

headline: Flag Soared to the Moon, but Not Bids for 3 Scraps

They never made it to the moon, but rather were discarded in a trash bin and recovered by Thomas Moser, a NASA engineer. And now — mounted to a poster with a nice photograph, and signed by Mr. Armstrong himself — they have sold for $45,000.

headline: The Value of Medicaid
text: Medicaid is under assault these days from nearly every direction. Governors complain that they cannot afford to put up their share of the money. Congressional Republicans led by Paul Ryan want to reduce the federal contribution by $771 billion over the next decade and shift more costs to the states and low-income Americans. President Obama has expressed willingness to cut Washington’s contribution by $100 billion over that period to help reduce the deficit.

headline: John Brown Marches On
text: On July 18, 1861, the 12th Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry left Fort Warren, in Boston Harbor, and marched through the city for an official review on the Boston Common. Leading the way was the regiment’s colonel, Fletcher Webster, the eldest son of Daniel Webster. The regiment’s association with such an eminent personage endeared it to Boston’s most respectable citizens, who lined the streets and cheered as the men trooped by. On the Common, Edward Everett, representing the “ladies of Boston,” presented the regiment with an ornate flag — and then with an equally ornate celebratory address.

headline: Tickets for Final Shows by Cunningham Troupe
text: The Park Avenue Armory is announcing Aug. 15 as the on-sale date for the final six performances of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, along with world premieres by Shen Wei Dance Arts and Streb Extreme Action Company, completing the armory’s first full season of artistic programming. Tickets to all three can be can be purchased at armoryonpark.org. According to the last wishes of Mr. Cunningham, tickets to his company’s performances, which will be Dec. 29 to 31, are to cost $10. Announced before his death in 2009, the planned two-year legacy tour has traveled to more than 50 cities worldwide and signals an end to nearly 60 years of creativity from a master of modern dance and choreography. Rounding out the lineup, the new work by Shen Wei (Nov. 30 to Dec. 4), artist in residence at the armory, will combine digital projection with handmade scenic elements. Tickets will be $35. Streb (Dec. 14 to 22) will incorporate ziplines, bungee cords and trampolines for “Kiss the Air!,” a work that will make full use of the armory’s 55,000-square-foot performance hall. Tickets are to cost $30.

headline: The Samurai Shopper Takes a Pal
text: As a fledgling Samurai Shopper, I felt great empathy for the forlorn men I’d see, parked on department store settees, besieged by boredom as their wives inhabited nearby dressing rooms in nautical-striped whatnots or butterfly prints. Sometimes the wives stepped out to catwalk, sometimes not. It was then that I pledged never to drag anyone past the cordon sanitaire of ladies’ wear and make him sit like a cigar-store Indian while I swanned around in leather or lace, deciding what accentuated the positive and eliminated the muffin bloat around my belt.

headline: Stage Collapses During Cheap Trick Performance in Ottawa
text: Several people were reported injured when a stage collapsed Sunday evening during a performance by Cheap Trick during the Ottawa Bluesfest, though the band members were said to be unharmed, according to The Associated Press. Canadian weather services had predicted a thunderstorm in Ottawa on Sunday night, which struck while Cheap Trick was performing on the festival’s main stage. This YouTube video posted by a user named gastorch997 shows the stage coming down in a matter of seconds as stunned onlookers scream. A concertgoer named Meghan Hurley wrote in The Ottawa Citizen that she “heard a loud bang,” after which “a frightened woman” told her “almost in tears that the stage had collapsed.” Ms. Hurley added, “I glanced over to where we had sat only moments before and all that remained was a heap of chairs that looked like a windswept pile of kindling for a bonfire.”
