headline: Why You Avoid Your Most Important Financial Task
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: Alex Stupak to Get Deeper Into Mexico
text: The success of Empellón, his taco-centric Mexican place in the West Village that opened earlier this year, has encouraged Alex Stupak, the former pastry chef at WD-50, to plan a second restaurant, Empellón Cocina, due in late fall.

headline: Riding in the Alps: Part Poetry, Part Pain
text: Before Peter Thomson ran bicycle tours in the Alps, he watched the Tour de France on a small television as a teenage cyclist in rural Scotland. As professionals attacked the famous climbs, in the shadow of snowy peaks, through glaciers and meadows, Thomson sat transfixed.

headline: Herbert Hoover Was Hooveresque
text: Brad DeLong leads us to Herbert Hoover opposing what was, in effect, a mild fiscal stimulus in the form of early payment of veterans’ bonuses.

headline: Dave & Buster’s Files For I.P.O.
text: Dave & Buster’s Entertainment, the restaurant chain whose customers exchange arcade tickets for stuffed animals, critter rings and other trinkets, filed on Monday for an initial public offering, providing a quick exit for the private equity firm Oak Hill Capital Partners.

headline: Poster Boy Wonder
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#826", 592, 490, false, chameleonData);

headline: Chinese Firm Bids for Australian Miner Sundance
text: Hanlong Mining Investment of China disclosed on Monday that it had made an offer to buy Sundance Resources, an iron ore mining company listed in Australia, in a deal valuing the company at 1.44 billion Australian dollars ($1.52 billion).

headline: Bike: Expensive; Reader Advice: Priceless
text: You plan and you plan and you plan, and then it’s time to go and it turns out some basic decisions haven’t been made yet. I’m writing this somewhere over Nebraska, en route to Portland, Ore., where I pick up my bike on Monday morning for the trip home to New York. But I’m still not sure which route I’ll take out of town, or even which direction I’ll be going.

headline: Lats of Luck
text: I had to read the Robert Samuelson column Dean Baker mentions here for myself; did he really hold Latvia up as a role model for America? And the answer is, yes, he did.

headline: Police Station Raid Leaves 4 Dead in Western China
text: BEIJING — At least four people died Monday in the troubled Xinjiang region of western China after a group of armed attackers invaded a local police station and took hostages, state-run Chinese news outlets reported. The police station was said to have been set on fire.

headline: London Theater Journal: Amoral Clarity
text: LONDON — And so the sorry story continues, as people from the corridors of power confess their crimes and await their judgments. The glamorous favorite of the tyrant has fallen from her high perch, and it is rumored that further depths of corruption are waiting to be plumbed. Reputations everywhere are in tatters.

headline: Russia Says It Will Try Jail Doctors in ’09 Case
text: MOSCOW — Twenty months after a 37-year-old lawyer died in pretrial detention after repeatedly requesting medical care, the authorities on Monday announced that criminal cases have been opened against two former prison doctors in connection with his death.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Stewart-Hass Strengthens Case for Nascar Chase
text: The Chase for the Cup does not begin in earnest until mid-September, yet with only the top 12 Nascar Sprint Cup drivers allowed to move on to the race series’ de facto postseason, every strong finish is critical. The teammates Ryan Newman and Tony Stewart did all they could to strengthen their Chase prospects on Sunday, finishing first and second, respectively, at New Hampshire Motor Speedway for Stewart-Hass Racing.

headline: Street Style Photos: Neon
text: The best of readers’ street fashion submissions for the week of July 11.

headline: Second Death in Staten Island Pool Accident
text: A second man has died from injuries he received while participating in a training exercise at a Staten Island public pool last Wednesday, according to a pastor at the man’s church.

headline: Two Poussin Paintings Vandalized in London
text: Around 5 p.m. on Sunday a man with a can of red spray paint vandalized two 17th-century paintings by Nicolas Poussin that were on view at the National Gallery in London, according to The Observer.

headline: Wall Street’s Newest Regulator a Longtime Foe
text: Richard Cordray, President Obama’s pick to lead the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, is no stranger to Wall Street.

headline: A Guided Tour of the Past
text: “A hot August day, opening day of school, 4th grade,” Elisabeth Park, 72, wrote for one of her assignments. “This is a dress-up occasion, and I know full well that my appearance is a disaster. To begin with, my dress looks like a nightgown….”

headline: Vain Glorious | Summer Essentials
text: Planning to go somewhere hot, sunny and possibly a little buggy? Here are a few items you may want to consider bringing in order to stay protected and pretty — yet relatively pared down. Go to beauty.com.

headline: Patterns: Faster Treatment for the Married Man
text: After a heart attack, even a brief delay in getting medical attention may mean the difference between life and death. A new study suggests that being married is a significant factor in getting treatment faster — but only for men.

headline: Cities Report Surge in Graffiti
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Fresh blotches of graffiti decorate the backs of street signs here near the ocean. Tags have popped up on guardrails along the dirt trails near Griffith Park across town. There are, almost daily, fresh splashes on walls in the San Fernando Valley, on downtown Los Angeles buildings and on billboards along the highways.

headline: Plagiarism Suit Against J. K. Rowling Is Really, Truly Dead (For Now)
text: While all those associated with the “Harry Potter” film franchise presumably spent the   weekend rolling around in their portions of the money minted by the record-breaking opening of “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2,” a longstanding plagiarism case against the “Harry Potter” author J. K. Rowling has come to an end because of a shortage of funds.

headline: When Risk Misperceptions Create Risks
text: Here’s an open question from David Ropeik, the author of “How Risky Is It, Really?” — which I consider essential reading in navigating heated debating points on the perils and merits of modern life:

headline: Storybook Endings
text: It is hard to imagine two events stuffing two bigger heartwarming underdog stories into the span of a few hours than the Women’s World Cup and the British Open did Sunday. Before the day started, they had nothing in common beyond both involving sports — and with golf, some would even argue that point — but by the time they ended they were taxing our hankie supply and had fulfilled that oh-so-famous Yogi Berra quotation about it never being over until it’s over.

headline: Getting Images From an iPhoto to Lightroom
text: Photography savvy friends chide me for not using Adobe Photoshop Lightroom, both for organizing my photos and for making touch-ups. It is more powerful than iPhoto and less complicated than Photoshop, they say. The primary reason I haven’t used it was that my images were already in iPhoto, and attempts to automatically import them with Lightroom failed.

headline: Using Light to Send Data Across the Room
text: After Wi-Fi, will there be… Li-Fi?

headline: Groups Spent $1.8 Million in Same-Sex Marriage Push
text: The final push by gay-rights groups to legalize same-sex marriage in New York now has at least a partial price tag: $1.8 million.

headline: Removing  Obese Children From Their Parents
text: Should states take children from their parents and place them in foster care in cases of “life-threatening childhood obesity”? It is not a new question (I wrote this magazine article about it several years ago), but it was given new amplification and caused a new uproar when advocated in a commentary in the most recent Journal of the American Medical Association.

headline: The longest swim, stress and the alpha male (baboon), and treating chronic pain.
text: The champion swimmer Diana Nyad takes on a new challenge, Tara Parker Pope talks about a new study advocating aggressive treatment for chronic pain and Jim Gorman talks about the benefits of being a beta male -- especially if you're a baboon.

headline: Langella to Drop Names in Memoir
text: Frank Langella, who has memorably played Richard Nixon on stage and screen in “Frost/Nixon” (and of course Count Dracula in the film “Dracula”), will write of his up-close-and-personal encounters with Elizabeth Taylor, Laurence Olivier, William Styron, Marilyn Monroe, Arthur Miller and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, among others, in a memoir to be released next year, his publisher said on Monday. HarperCollins acquired the rights to “Dropped Names,” Mr. Langella’s first book, said Jonathan Burnham, the publisher of the Harper imprint. “Mr. Langella is a razor sharp writer with a brilliantly perceptive eye and a remarkable gift for the telling detail,” Mr. Burnham said in a statement. Mr. Langella, whose long career has included films like “Dave,” “Starting Out in the Evening” and “The Ninth Gate,” is set to return to Broadway this fall in the Terence Rattigan drama “Man and Boy.”

headline: App Smart Extra: BlackBerry Navigators
text: My recent App Smart column recommends applications for audible turn-by-turn navigation. The best ones can replace those pricey personal navigation devices that are always getting stolen from cars.

headline: No Numberplay Today
text: Rest the part of your brain that usually solves mathematical problems today. Numberplay, the weekly game, will return next Monday.

headline: Privacy Isn’t Dead. Just Ask Google+.
text: Some people have a very hard time trusting Facebook.

headline: Boehner and Cantor Meet Again With Obama
text: The two top House Republicans met privately with President Obama at the White House on Sunday as the House prepared to vote on a deficit-cutting measure strongly opposed by the White House.

headline: Upsurge in Graffiti Stirs Concern, and Debate
text: Almost daily, fresh splashes of graffiti are showing up in the San Fernando Valley, on buildings in downtown Los Angeles and on highway billboards.

headline: The Surprising Power of Promotional Products
text: When my grandparents moved into a retirement center, I helped with the garage sale. My cousin Claire and I were joking about how best to display the odds and ends from their 60 years together when I stumbled upon a gift from the gods of high kitsch. It was a letter opener, but this was not your typical letter opener.

headline: ‘Jesus Christ Superstar': From Canada to California to Broadway?
text: The Stratford Shakespeare Festival’s hit revival of “Jesus Christ Superstar,” the 1971 rock opera by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice about the last days of Jesus’ life, will transfer to La Jolla Playhouse in San Diego in late fall for six weeks of performances that may serve as a prelude for a move to Broadway.

headline: A Guide to Presidential Campaign Filings
text: The flurry of campaign finance reports filed by presidential candidates on July 15 are being dissected by strategists, journalists and political junkies. So what are they looking at, and what do those reports contain? Here’s a guide to reading the reports, using an annotated blank filing form from the Federal Election Commission.

headline: London Mayor Last Year Dismissed Hacking Allegations as ‘Codswallop’
text: Boris Johnson, London’s mayor, was pressed on Monday to explain why he initially dismissed allegations that the police had failed to notify thousands of victims of phone hacking as “a load of codswallop.”

headline: Choose Foods to Shed the Pounds
text: A new study from Harvard University supports many existing weight-control tips and suggests some new ones. To guard against creeping weight gain, weigh yourself regularly, at least once a week, on the same scale under the same conditions.

headline: To Find Tasty Larvae, Lizards Use Their Brains
text: Lizards aren’t the simpletons that some might take them for.

headline: Charlie Sheen Signs TV Deal for ‘Anger Management’
text: Charlie Sheen has made a deal that will — possibly — bring him back to television in a new situation comedy.

headline: More Weight on Less Meat
text: Today the Environmental Working Group (EWG) released “Meat Eater’s Guide to Climate Change and Health,” a comprehensive report that suggests what’s become a common refrain here and elsewhere: we all need to eat fewer animal products – not just meat, but dairy as well. The guide tracks the lifecycle of the food we eat, from production and processing to consumption and waste disposal. It’s tricked out with enough features, graphics, and factoids to keep you busy – or equal parts hopeful and despondent – for a while.

headline: Watchlist: New Online Slate of British TV Offerings for Americans
text: If your taste in television runs toward British detectives — not to mention British soap operas, British literary classics and British colonial romances — then a new streaming video making its debut on Monday may be just your cup of tea.

headline: Emirates Offers Radio App for Travelers
text: Do you want to immerse yourself in a new culture? On Monday, Emirates airlines released a new radio app aimed at those who want to explore before traveling or simply want to discover new places. The new app, Destination Radio, is free and available for the iPhone and iPod Touch.

headline: In Battery Park, Fish Tank Is New Public Square
text: At some point every day, Amanda Beck’s 11-month-old daughter, Emmy, says, “Bah,” to her. “It means she wants to see the fish,” Ms. Beck said one afternoon last week, holding Emmy up to the double-sided glass tank set into a wall in the lobby of Riverhouse, a luxury condominium building in Battery Park City.

headline: Photo Replay: July 18
text: The day in sports included the world swimming championships in Shanghai, the European fencing championships in England and surfing in South Africa.

headline: He’ll Take Consumer Protection for $1,000, Alex
text: Richard Cordray, the former attorney general of Ohio, has an extended  résumé  of experience to lead the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

headline: Out of Africa
text: Movies may not be high on lists of supplies needed by refugees, but for many people suffering the effects of war and long-term displacement, film screenings can be an all-too-rare source of diversion and psychological release, advocates say. This week, Film Forward, a Sundance Institute initiative, and FilmAid International, a humanitarian aid organization, are bringing a festival to Kenya’s sprawling Kakuma and Dadaab camps, home to hundreds of thousands of refugees.

headline: Lincoln Trust’s Enhanced View of Retirement Plan Costs
text: In recent weeks, the Your Money columnist Ron Lieber has written often about the impact of mutual fund expenses and other fees on the performance of 401(k) plans and the difficulty of determining just how much one is paying in expenses.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Rod Arnold joined the Media Ventures Group, New York, in a new post, senior vice president for business development and strategy. He had been chief operating officer and head of special projects at Charity: Water.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Ready to Swim 103 Miles With the Sharks
text: KEY WEST, Fla. — Any day now, Diana Nyad will set out to do something no athlete has ever done: swim all day and all night, then all day and all night, then all day again.

headline: Still Counting Calories? Your Weight-Loss Plan May Be Outdated
text: It’s no secret that Americans are fatter today than ever before, and not just those unlucky people who are genetically inclined to gain weight or have been overweight all their lives. Many who were lean as young adults have put on lots of unhealthy pounds as they pass into middle age and beyond.

headline: Superheroes, Surveyed and Sized Up
text: There’s nothing cool anymore about acknowledging the coolness of comic books. Popular culture is so far beyond that moment when comic characters — specifically those gifted, costumed adventurers known as superheroes — shed their reputation as fetish objects for children and marginalized adults and entered the mainstream. We’re now well into an era when every summer weekend brings the opening of an “X-Men” or “Green Lantern” movie. Colorful crime fighters’ vivid uniforms and rippling physiques are used to sell everything from pro football apparel to Broadway musicals, while the characters themselves, untethered from their decades-long narrative traditions, are reduced to mere commodities. Forget about rescuing Lois Lane or Aunt May — now it is the superhero himself who needs saving.

headline: A Male That May Mate Its Kind Into Extinction
text: A small agricultural pest called the cottony cushion scale exhibits a bizarre form of hermaphroditism in which parasitic males infect their daughters at birth. This parasite lives in the daughter and fertilizes her eggs.

headline: Facebook and NBC to Host Republican Debate in N.H.
text: Visit msnbc.com for breaking news, world news, and news about the economy

headline: Looking Inside the Consumer Bust
text: A few commenters responded to my Sunday column by asking whether consumer spending had really declined all that much. A blog post by Jared Bernstein discusses this issue. The crux of the argument is this chart, showing that consumer spending does not make up a smaller share of gross domestic product than a few years ago:

headline: Ads Celebrate the Age of Aquarium
text: One of the most venerable mantras in marketing is “Fish where the fish are.” That advice is being followed, in creative fashion, in a campaign for an attraction where there are plenty of fish.

headline: The Caucus | Michele Bachmann's Beliefs
text: July 18, 2011 - Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Paul Volpe discuss Michele Bachmann's evangelical background and the role it has played in her career and presidential campaign.

headline: Backe Names M.L.S. All-Star Roster
text: Red Bulls Coach Hans Backe named his gameday roster for the July 27 Major league Soccer All-Star Game on Monday. The league’s stars will play Manchester United that night at Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J.

headline: Caucus Video: Michele Bachmann, Faith and Politics
text: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Paul Volpe discuss Michele Bachmann’s evangelical beliefs and the role they have played in her career and presidential campaign.

headline: Reaganite Delusions
text: Michael Boskin has always been a politically ambitious Republican; but he used to know how to read basic economic data. Not anymore, I guess:

headline: Europe’s Economic Powerhouse Drifts East
text: DITZINGEN, GERMANY — Germany has long sat at the center of the European economy, but Europe is no longer as central to Germany as it used to be.

headline: Whistle-Blower in Phone-Hacking Case Reportedly Found Dead
text: Updated | 6:11 p.m. Sean Hoare, a former News of the World journalist who claimed that Andy Coulson, the tabloid’s former editor, knew about and encouraged phone hacking, was found dead on Monday, The Guardian reports.

headline: Remotely, Hobbyist Takes Control of a Tiny 200 M.P.H. Super Car
text: Later this summer at the Auto Club Dragway in Fontana, Calif., Nic Case, a clay-model sculptor at Ford’s advance design studios in Irvine, Calif, will attempt to lower his own land-speed record for a radio-controlled car.

headline: Really? The Claim: Allergies Reduce the Risk of Cancer
text: THE FACTS

headline: Trader Pleads Guilty to Threatening Financial Regulators
text: Vincent McCrudden, a former trader, pleaded guilty to charges that he threatened to kill more than 40 current and former regulatory officials, including Mary L. Schapiro of the Securities and Exchange Commission and Gary Gensler of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

headline: Sentence of the Week, Minimalist Edition
text: Please accept this minimalist midsummer Sentence of the Week. Our candidates:

headline: Atlantic Yards Arena Takes Shape, but Protests Carry On
text: Steel beams arc high into the Brooklyn sky, flanked by five cranes that rise from a deep, divisive hole in the ground. Sections of prefabricated concrete seat platforms and concourses — the guts of every sports arena since Roman times — are now in place.

headline: Online Reaction: Law School Economics
text: In Sunday’s Times, David Segal wrote about the legal education system, in which the interest of schools and students are often in conflict. From Mr. Segal’s article:

headline: For Runners, Soft Ground Can Be Hard on the Body
text: Hirofumi Tanaka, an exercise physiologist at the University of Texas at Austin, bristles when he sees dirt paths carved out of the grass along paved bicycling or running routes. The paths are created by runners who think softer ground protects them from injuries.

headline: Murdoch Aides Long Tried to Blunt Scandal Over Hacking
text: LONDON — Two days before it emerged that The News of the World had hacked the cellphone of a murdered schoolgirl, igniting a scandal that has shaken the media empire of Rupert Murdoch, his son James told friends that he thought the worst of the troubles were behind him. And he was confident that the News Corporation’s $12 billion bid for the satellite company British Sky Broadcasting would go through, according to a person present.

headline: Drawing Dance: Cunningham at Dartmouth
text: The Brooklyn-based artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the fifth in a series of graphite drawings he plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from Dartmouth College.

headline: News Corp. Braces for Legal Trouble in the U.S.
text: The burgeoning scandal at the News Corporation has crossed over to the United States as federal investigations of the company’s conduct have started. There is no clearer sign of the seriousness of the company’s potential exposure to criminal prosecution than its hiring of Brendan V. Sullivan Jr. of Williams & Connolly, one of the most aggressive criminal defense lawyers in the country.

headline: Chilled Summer Soups
text: Last week was a perfect week to be working with cold soups — what with the sweltering heat, I was happy to be drinking my lunch or dinner every day.

headline: TimesCast | July 18, 2011
text: The phone-hacking scandal in Britain takes down another top police official; and a British parliamentary committee anticipates the testimony of Rupert Murdoch, James Murdoch and Rebekah Brooks.

headline: Adapting as Vision and Independence Ebb
text: A man wakes up one morning to find that he cannot make out the details of a picture on the wall. His wife’s face, too, has become a blur. A trip to the ophthalmologist reveals he has macular degeneration.

headline: ‘Breaking Bad’ Cooks Up Record Numbers
text: Despite a 13-month absence after an excruciatingly tense Season 3 cliffhanger, “Breaking Bad” set a ratings record in its return to AMC on Sunday night. According to Nielsen, an estimated 2.6 million people tuned in to witness the further misadventures of the meth dealers Walter White (Bryan Cranston) and Jesse Pinkman (Aaron Paul) and to learn whether Jesse actually killed a fellow meth cooker. That number was 32 percent greater than the viewership for last season’s premiere, and was the highest total in the series’ history.

headline: What Americans Really Think About the Debt Ceiling
text: This month, a Gallup poll found that Americans are almost twice as likely to say they want their Congressional representative to vote against rather than for an increase in the debt ceiling (42 percent to 22 percent, with 35 percent saying they had no opinion).

headline: Student Reading Contest Winner | On Having Invasive Species for Dinner
text: For the second week of our Summer Reading Contest, we received 72 entries – many of which, we noticed, came from just three schools, identified by student writers as BSGE, VCHS and RHS. We’re grateful to the teachers and students from those schools for participating in the contest, and we hope more will join them.

headline: Ice Pop Update: The Meltiness Factor
text: One thing I didn’t have room to get into in the text accompanying this week’s popsicle matrix is what you might call the meltiness factor. Almost anything will freeze solid, but not everything will stay frozen for very long. Some of this week’s offerings begin melting more quickly than others.

headline: Return of ‘Breaking Bad’ Breaks Series Record
text: The AMC drama “Breaking Bad” returned from a long hiatus – so long it missed out on this year’s Emmy nominations – with the strongest ratings the show has recorded.

headline: European Governments Consider a Bank Tax to Finance Greek Bailout
text: BRUSSELS — With European leaders poised to hold crucial talks Thursday in what one diplomat called “the euro zone’s ultimate Cinderella moment,” officials on Monday were discussing elements that might prove essential to a second bailout of Greece, including the new idea of a special levy to ensure that banks share part of the cost.

headline: Egypt Revamps Cabinet as Protesters Seem to Lose Steam
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s interim military government unveiled a promised cabinet shake-up on Monday aimed at mollifying a 10-day-old protest in Tahrir Square as the protesters themselves appeared for the first time to begin to lose some momentum.

headline: Ja Rule Sentenced for Failing to Pay Taxes
text: Ja Rule’s long fall from grace reached a new low in a New Jersey courtroom on Monday when the Queens-born rapper and actor was sentenced to 28 months in prison for failing to file federal income tax returns over a five-year period.

headline: The China Model in Africa
text: A week ago a new country was created in Africa: South Sudan. By chance I had just finished reading “The White Nile,” by Alan Moorehead, which, despite some dated language, is a very readable tale of the 19th-century European intervention that ultimately led to the uneasy borders of Sudan, now redrawn.

headline: S.E.C. Freezes Assets of 3 Firms Accused of Insider Trading
text: A Manhattan federal judge has frozen the assets of three Swiss asset managers accused of illegally profiting from trades made ahead of the $1.2 billion sale of Arch Chemicals to the Lonza Group, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Monday.

headline: As Towering Star Retires, China Is Unprepared to Replace Him
text: BEIJING — Nine seasons after Yao Ming walked onto a basketball court in Texas and inspired a generation of young Chinese to learn to dribble — or at least to watch until the final buzzer — his looming exit from professional basketball is being accompanied by nostalgia for the man who became a national hero. It is also triggering frustration over why no one in China, which has tens of millions of basketball players, appears capable of replacing him as an N.B.A. star.

headline: Hazards: Secondhand Smoke May Affect Hearing
text: Add yet another item to the long list of damaging effects of secondhand smoke: hearing loss in teenagers.

headline: Deaths in Syria Tied to Rift Between Sects
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — At least six people have been killed in a wave of sectarian bloodshed in the central province of Homs, including three people whose bodies were mutilated, activists and residents there said Monday.

headline: Dodd-Frank Under Fire a Year Later
text: WASHINGTON — In the year since the passage of a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s financial regulatory system after the financial crisis, the stock market is up, banking profits have grown and institutions that invest on behalf of average Americans are praising the tougher stance in Washington.

headline: Antismoking Vaccine Fails in Late Trial
text: A vaccine meant to help people quit smoking has failed to work in a large, late-stage clinical trial, dealing a setback to efforts to harness the immune system to help people fight addictions.

headline: Battling Energy Waste in Hot, Rich Cities
text: Bettina Wassener, who is based in Hong Kong for the International Herald Tribune, has filed a Green column for The Times exploring why there is so much energy waste there and in other advanced cities. One reason is that energy costs are a tiny fraction of the price of owning expensive real estate, so why not have the windows open while the air conditioning is blasting.

headline: Armstrong’s Lawyers Allege Leaks in Investigation
text: The lawyers for Lance Armstrong have accused the government of publicly smearing Armstrong’s reputation during their continuing investigation of him and asked a federal judge to determine who is leaking confidential information to the news media.

headline: China’s Treasury Holdings Make U.S. Woes Its Own
text: SHANGHAI — However grim Washington’s debt and deficit negotiations may seem to Americans, the impasse is nearly as disturbing for China.

headline: A Running Debate: Dirt Trails or Pavement?
text: In today’s Personal Best column, Gina Kolata tells the story of Hirofumi Tanaka, an exercise physiologist at the University of Texas at Austin, who began running on a dirt path after recovering from an injury. He ended up twisting his ankle. She writes:

headline: G.O.P. Chairman Questions Legality of Obama Campaign Video
text: The Republican National Committee called on Monday for a federal investigation into whether President Obama violated federal law by using a room in the White House to film a video for his campaign encouraging supporters to enter a raffle contest.

headline: Swimming With Sharks, at 61
text: At the age of 61, Diana Nyad is taking on an athletic challenge that she could not complete in her 20s. She plans to swim about 60 hours in the churning sea, 103 miles across the Straits of Florida from Cuba to Key West.

headline: A Big Week for Daniel Radcliffe on Screen and Stage
text: It may not be $476 million, but the Broadway revival of “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying” had its most profitable eight performances last week since beginning in February — earning $1,177,086 — at the same time that its star, Daniel Radcliffe, was setting movie box offices on fire  in his final turn as the boy wizard.

headline: A Vaccine May Shield Boys Too
text: Snapshots of two clean-cut teenagers, a boy and a girl, stare out from a newspaper advertisement for the vaccine Gardasil. “Boys can be affected by HPV disease too,” says the bold headline. The ad urges parents to protect “both your son and daughter.”

headline: An Executive Cries. Flying Can Do That to You.
text: I REALLY love flying across country. When I look down, I often think of all those people who made the same trek on horseback. It would have taken months. If I did that, I probably would have died.

headline: Western Pine Merits Protection, Agency Says
text: The devastation that bark beetles and fungus have wreaked on hundreds of thousands of acres of whitebark pine trees in the northern Rockies has been tracked and chronicled for 30 years. Now the Fish and Wildlife Service has weighed in with a finding that climate change threatens the long-term survival of the species.

headline: For an Owner of a Shelby Cobra, a Bittersweet Return on Investment
text: Thomas Long, an artist who specializes in exotic hardwoods, says he lives the good life in Santa Barbara, Calif. He lives alone, half a block from the beach, in a warehouse he shares with a car that he bought 43 years ago for $4,200. “Life doesn’t get too much better,” he said in a telephone interview on Monday.

headline: Add Patience to a Leap of Faith to Discover Cancer Signatures
text: Are we outsmarting cancer? Or just ourselves?

headline: Media Decoder: The Murdochs to Testify
text: David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss the latest developments in the phone-hacking scandal and look ahead to Tuesday's testimony from Rupert Murdoch, James Murdoch and Rebekah Brooks.

headline: Epidemiology: In Losing Its Southern States to Secession, Sudan Also Sheds Its Guinea Worm Cases
text: As of July 15, one more country was declared free of the guinea worm: Sudan.

headline: To Vaccinate or Not (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: It’s About Time | A Nouveau Tourneau
text: Blocks away from its clock swamped, tourist-enticing flagship “Time Machine” store on 57th Street, Tourneau has just opened a new concept store. Same time zone, different world. Created by Eight Inc., the designers behind the state-of-the-art Apple stores, this soaring modernist space eschews the traditional “behind-the-counter” retail approach in favor of a more user-friendly shopping experience. Eight large watch tables allow for accessible, easy viewing from all sides, while digital screens embedded in walls feature informative, up-to-the-minute videos. The store also features its own Rolex boutique — New York City’s first — which occupies almost a third of the space. To celebrate the new Madison Avenue location, Tourneau has launched a new line of timepieces, the TNY series, with the clean lines and strong look of the city that inspired it. The Rush Hour watch, made from the high performance alloy DLC, features numerals and hands in vivid yellow. Hey taxi!

headline: A Consumer Bust? Or a Wage Bust?
text: Robert Reich, the professor, blogger and former labor secretary, sent the following e-mail in response to my Sunday column on the great consumer bust:

headline: Animals at Play
text: “The Exultant Ark” examines animal pleasure, with surprising, funny, touching, sad, heartwarming pictures by photographers from all over the world.

headline: The Joy of a Sun Bath, a Snuggle, a Bite of Pâté
text: Two ring-tailed lemurs, perhaps a pair, perhaps just two guys out to catch a few rays, sit side by side tilted back as if in beach chairs, their white bellies exposed, knees apart, feet splayed to catch every last drop of the Madagascar sun. All they need are cigars to complete the picture.

headline: Statements by Top Figures in the Hacking Scandal
text: Statements made by some of the key people in the investigation into phone-hacking and the relationship between the London police and newspapers owned by News International.

headline: Giving Chronic Pain a Medical Platform of Its Own
text: Most doctors view pain as a symptom of an underlying problem — treat the disease or the injury, and the pain goes away.

headline: Exercise: Limits in Heart Screenings for Youths
text: Screening young athletes with electrocardiograms to prevent sudden cardiac death may be ineffective, a new study has found. As it turns out, even pediatric cardiologists often fail to interpret the tests correctly.

headline: N.R.C. Chief Plans Quick Response to Post-Fukushima Study
text: The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Monday that it should decide within 90 days on how to address recommendations to be issued this week by a task force that examined the lessons of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear accident in Japan. Almost simultaneously, House Republicans and the industry’s trade association warned him not to rush.

headline: First-Place Sweep by American Girls at First Google Science Fair
text: As a budding inventor and scientist, Shree Bose, in second grade, tried to make blue spinach. In fourth grade she built a remote-controlled garbage can. In eighth grade she invented a railroad tie made out of recycled plastic and granite dust, an achievement that got her to the top 30 in a national science competition for middle school students.

headline: Video: The Murdochs Prepare to Testify
text: David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss the latest developments in the phone-hacking scandal and look ahead to Tuesday’s testimony from Rupert Murdoch, James Murdoch and Rebekah Brooks.

headline: ‘Yates of the Yard’ Explains His Resignation
text: Updated | 6:47 p.m. As my colleagues Alan Cowell and Sarah Lyall report, John Yates, the assistant commissioner of London’s Metropolitan Police Service and the country’s most senior counterterrorism officer, resigned his post on Monday over his role in the botched investigation of phone hacking at The News of the World.

headline: You Say ‘Pretentious’ as if It’s a Bad Thing
text: I was only peripherally aware of Miranda July before Katrina Onstad wrote about her for this Sunday’s magazine. Netflix occasionally suggests I stream her 2005 film “Me and You and Everyone We Know,” probably because I have viewed other so-called indie films. (It’s “quirky” — like “Clockwork Orange” and “Withnail and I”?) So I started to watch it. The movie begins with July doing a kind of spoken-word piece, and I knew I had heard her voice before. After a few maddening minutes, it hit me: She’s the one who did “The Arky Girl.”

headline: Teenager’s High-Five Is Plastered in Place
text: “Awkward,” a new comedy about suburban high school life, beginning on Tuesday on MTV, is both homage and rebuke: a tribute to the exquisite mix of satire and sincerity that distinguished “Freaks and Geeks,” and a takedown of the cloying sanctimony you witness after only a few minutes of something like “The Secret Life of the American Teenager.”

headline: In Washington, Bocce and Barolo
text: At Vinoteca, a wine bar in the U Street corridor of Washington, D.C.’s, the District’s popular bocce ball scene meets open-air snacking. Vinoteca itself is a perfectly fine wine bar, if a bit hushed and dimly lit, but the real action is happening around back: a clustered courtside next to a mock-rustic bocce ball lane made of tile and crushed oyster shells. Bocce — a game that can be described as shuffleboard with balls, or curling sans ice — is enjoying something of a youthful renaissance these days in Washington, spearheaded by the DC Bocce League, an organization with teams across the D.C. area and a membership roll that includes staffers, interns, pollsters, wonks and all manner of Washingtonian young professionals. They play mostly in outdoor parks and on lawns, but these sites have nothing on the backyard at Vinoteca, which could be a miniaturized village square in Torre del Greco, were it not for the condo developments towering above or the Rite Aid across the street. Such open-air surroundings are best accompanied by offerings from the outdoor grill: fresh barbecued monkfish in romesco, warmed olives and almonds, a bluefish tuna sandwich on rustic bread and assorted Mediterranean sausages. Perhaps best of all is the playful by-the-glass wine list, including a dry assyrtiko from Santorini, Greece, and a viognier from nearby Rappahannock Cellars, in Virginia.

headline: Moth Population Explosion
text: Q. Why are there more moths than ever before in my Manhattan apartment this season?

headline: I.B.M. Reports Strong Second-Quarter Earnings
text: I.B.M., which turned 100 last month, delivered better-than-expected quarterly results Monday that showed the old company had a lot of life in it.

headline: Noted Composer, Who Leapt Into Atonality, Meows Her Last
text: Ketzel, who won a prize for piano composition in 1997 and went on to be featured in a book, “The World of Women in Classical Music,” died Wednesday in Manhattan. She was 19 and lived on the Upper West Side.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, India, Israel and England.

headline: Chinese Upset Over Counterfeit Furniture
text: SHANGHAI — For years, DaVinci furniture stores have been places where wealthy Chinese in this and five other big cities can indulge their appetite for imported luxury.

headline: Back to the ’90s, Tootling a Flute
text: CHICAGO — I just want to say one word to you. Just one word. Are you listening?

headline: Ghost of Lehman Still Haunts Neuberger
text: When Lehman Brothers collapsed in September 2008, the asset manager that it owned, Neuberger Berman, was successfully spun out. Neuberger, however, has not managed to completely shake its connection to Lehman.

headline: Insight From Trouble in Recognizing Objects
text: Object agnosia is a rare disorder in which an individual cannot visually recognize objects. In the case of a patient known as SM, he mistook a harmonica for a cash register.

headline: Unions Say City Opera Invalidates Endowment
text: The beleaguered New York City Opera may be facing a new hurdle: questions about whether its move from Lincoln Center would place much of the company’s dwindling endowment at risk.

headline: Excerpt: 'Death Takes a Holiday'
text: Jill Paice and Julian Ovenden perform the number "More and More" from the Roundabout Theater production of "Death Takes a Holiday." (Video courtesy of the Roundabout.)

headline: A Chance to Hear Bruckner Anew, by Himself and With an Unexpected Partner
text: Three of the four concerts that made up “Bruckner: (R)evolution,” the Cleveland Orchestra’s contribution to this year’s Lincoln Center Festival and the opening volley of a continuing relationship between these institutions, adhered to a novel premise. In pairing symphonies by Anton Bruckner, long portrayed as the sacred fool of 19th-century European music, with works by John Adams, a sophisticated, protean contemporary American, the orchestra’s music director, Franz Welser-Möst, sought to cast both composers in a new light by illuminating connections.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, India, Israel and England.

headline: Brahms in a New Light, Resembling the Weightier Liszt
text: You might have expected that this year’s International Keyboard Institute and Festival at Mannes College the New School for Music would be virtually a symposium on the work of Franz Liszt. The 200th anniversary of Liszt’s birth is being commemorated this year, after all, and he is the patron saint of the grand Romantic approach to keyboard virtuosity that this festival, now in its 13th season, has always celebrated.

headline: Fox, CNN And MSNBC To Cover Murdoch Hearing
text: The widely anticipated testimony by Rupert Murdoch in the British Parliament will be covered live extensively on American television Tuesday morning.

headline: The Education of Marcus Bachmann
text: Marcus Bachmann, the husband of the Republican presidential candidate Michele Bachmann, focused his graduate studies on the contentious question of whether day care was harmful to young children, and argued in his Ph.D. dissertation that “parents who can do so should delay full-time day care until into the fourth year of a child’s life.’’

headline: Swimming With the Sharks
text: At age 61, Diana Nyad will attempt to be the only woman to swim from Cuba to Key West, Fla., without a shark cage.

headline: Media and Mistrust: A Response
text: The responses to my piece, “The Ways of Silencing,” were often passionate and certainly varied. My thanks to everyone who took the time to respond.

headline: A Climate Hazard, Medium Rare, Please
text: Eating a small cheeseburger for lunch is, in terms of greenhouse gas emissions, equivalent to driving an extra 10 miles.

headline: The Good Ol’ Days of 20 Years Ago
text: Are 18- to 34-year-olds too young to be nostalgic?

headline: Coburn Plan Proposes $9 Trillion in Cuts
text: Senator Tom Coburn of Oklahoma, who dropped out of the bipartisan group of senators known as the “Gang of Six” after it failed to come up with a plan to reduce the federal deficit, released his own budget plan Monday.

headline: N.B.A. to Announce Schedule That May Never Be Played
text: In order to cancel games, the N.B.A. first has to schedule them. So on Tuesday, the league will announce the dates, times and matchups for a season that might never happen — or at least, not on those dates and times.

headline: Clorox Rejects Icahn’s Takeover Bid
text: Clorox said on Monday that its board had rejected a $10.2 billion takeover bid by the investor Carl C. Icahn.

headline: Pitchfork Music Festival
text: The festival, a three-day event held since 2006, included 45 acts performing at Chicago’s Union Park.

headline: Can a Playground Be Too Safe?
text: When seesaws and tall slides and other perils were disappearing from New York’s playgrounds, Henry Stern drew a line in the sandbox. As the city’s parks commissioner in the 1990s, he issued an edict concerning the 10-foot-high jungle gym near his childhood home in northern Manhattan.

headline: Herders Say Weather Will Worsen
text: Clyde E. Goulden is the director of the Institute of Mongolian Biodiversity and Ecological Studies at the Academy of Natural Sciences in Philadelphia.

headline: Public Gives Obama the Edge on Debt Talks
text: While Americans are closely divided over whether the debt ceiling should be raised, the public gives President Obama higher marks than Congressional Republicans for his handling of the negotiations, according to the latest CBS News poll.

headline: New Albums by NRBQ and Oren Ambarchi and Jim O’Rourke
text: NRBQ

headline: Lulz Security Says It Hacked News Corporation Sites
text: 7:18 p.m. | Updated  Adding more details of the attacks.

headline: After Diabetic Woman’s Arrest, a $125,000 Settlement
text: Her decision to smoke a marijuana cigarette outside a Manhattan bar where she was attending a bachelorette party landed Jaime Rutkowski in jail, threatened her life and led to a lawsuit that on Monday yielded $125,000 from the city.

headline: Zimbabwe: Charges Are Dropped Against Energy Minister
text: The state withdrew a charge of criminal abuse of office on Monday against Energy Minister Elton Mangoma, a leader of the Movement for Democratic Change that has opposed President Robert Mugabe. Mr. Mangoma had been scheduled to go on trial on Monday. The state also further downgraded charges against Munyaradzi Gwisai and five other activists who had been accused in February of plotting to topple Mr. Mugabe after watching videos of the uprising in Egypt. The original treason charge has been replaced by a charge of conspiring to commit public violence and participating in a gathering to promote violence. They are scheduled for trial on Aug. 22.

headline: Vatican and Malaysia Normalize Ties
text: The Vatican and the predominantly Muslim nation of Malaysia established diplomatic relations on Monday, a sign that the Southeast Asian nation’s government was opening to religious minorities after interfaith tensions had shaken the country’s Catholic community. The Holy See announced the agreement after Pope Benedict XVI and high-ranking Vatican officials met with Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia at Castel Gandolfo, the pope’s summer residence outside Rome. In recent years, tensions have been high between Catholics, who make up about 3 percent of Malaysia’s population, and the Malaysian government. Catholics have complained of vandalism against churches and the government’s confiscation of Malay-language Bibles because of a ban on the use of “Allah” as a Malay-language translation for God.

headline: Yankees Waiting to See How Much Colon Has Left
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — In another two starts, Bartolo Colon should surpass the 100-inning mark, which he has not done since 2005. The Yankees were concerned about his durability heading into the season, and his struggles over his last two outings — 13 runs and 16 hits in six and a third innings — raised the possibility that he is nearing his expiration date. That issue has come into focus with the July 31 nonwaiver trade deadline less than two weeks away.

headline: Court Orders Thailand and Cambodia to Withdraw from Disputed Temple
text: The top judicial body of the United Nations ordered Cambodia and Thailand to withdraw troops from a disputed temple on Monday and established a demilitarized zone along their mountainous border. The two countries have fought each other numerous times in recent years near Preah Vihear, an ancient hilltop temple that stirs nationalist sentiments in both countries and where Cambodian troops are seen in the photo above. Both sides said they would comply with the order by the International Court of Justice in The Hague. However, the Thai military has in the past criticized concessions on the temple by the country’s civilian leadership and may balk at what they perceive as giving further ground to Cambodia.

headline: Russia: Four Arrested for Plotting Attack
text: Russian authorities have arrested four people suspected of planning a “major” terrorist attack in the Moscow region, Aleksandr Bortnikov, the head of Russia’s domestic intelligence agency, said Monday. The suspects, who were arrested several days ago, were from Russia’s North Caucasus, a violence-plagued, mostly Muslim region that is a hotbed of terrorist activity in Russia. Mr. Bortnikov said the suspects had planned to bomb transportation infrastructure and other crowded places, but did not provide further details. The police confiscated a homemade bomb with an estimated explosive force of 22 pounds of TNT, as well as other weapons and maps.

headline: New Rules for Hens
text: To the Editor:

headline: Schools Dropping 413 From Staff
text: The District of Columbia public schools has sent termination notices to 413 teachers and other school employees, including 288 for poor performance, under an evaluation system that has become a national model. District officials said that 113 of the employees had been rated ineffective, and that an additional 175 had been rated minimally effective for a second consecutive year in a system that emphasizes students’ performance on standardized tests as well as on classroom observations. In addition, 104 employees will be let go because they failed to meet state license requirements, and 21 others because they were unable to find permanent positions a year after losing their previous jobs as a result of budget cuts and program changes. Supporters of the evaluation system have praised it as setting clear standards and enforcing consequences for ineffective teaching. But it is disliked by some unionized teachers and has been criticized as doing little to help struggling teachers and not factoring in the challenges faced by those working in poor schools.

headline: No Protection for Pines in Peril
text: The Fish and Wildlife Service said Monday that the whitebark pine, devastated by bark beetles and fungus, deserved to be listed as threatened or endangered under the Endangered Species Act. But it said it could not spare money and staff time to do so and to give the trees the protections that come from a listing. The agency’s finding noted that scientific studies showed “a substantial and pervasive decline throughout almost the entire range of the species” in the West. The decline has been linked to global warming because the pine beetle is increasingly able to survive warmer winters and cause more damage when spring arrives. In the hardest-hit areas, Yellowstone and Glacier National Parks, about two-thirds of whitebark pines are gone.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,652 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: One Game of Rehab and Reyes Is Ready
text: Jose Reyes was back in a familiar role Monday afternoon, penciled in as the leadoff hitter and shortstop on the lineup card.

headline: Facts Sought on D.E.A. Informants
text: Two Republican lawmakers have asked the Drug Enforcement Administration to provide information about any confidential informants who have a connection to Operation Fast and Furious, an investigation into a network of gun traffickers in Arizona that has drawn controversy and Congressional scrutiny.

headline: Texas Tales
text: The Times has been running a Room for Debate on the Texas “jobs juggernaut”. And Texas has indeed been adding jobs faster than the rest of the nation, a fact that has become especially notable in the past couple of years, as overall job growth has been so poor.

headline: For Clarke, a Bonus and a Party
text: SANDWICH, England — Darren Clarke strolled into the room just after 9 a.m. Monday looking a bit like the winning quarterback the day after the Super Bowl. The new champion of the British Open, Clarke had the claret jug propped up on the table in front of him, and his unshaven face and red-rimmed eyes were reflected in it, as was the grin that a sleepless night could not wipe off his face.

headline: Question of Unpaid Benefits Is One of N.F.L.’s Last Details
text: While players began arriving in Washington on Monday, ready to consider the terms of a new N.F.L. labor deal, negotiators met again in New York, haggling over the final few details that stand in a way of an agreement in principle to end the four-month lockout.

headline: In India, an Egalitarian Jail
text: Tihar jail’s current occupants include three members of Parliament, a top bureaucrat and India’s 66th-richest man.

headline: Rehabilitation Comes to a Prison and to Its Inmates
text: NEW DELHI — At least two prime ministers — one future and one former — have spent a few nights behind its high walls. Its current occupants include three members of Parliament, a top bureaucrat and one of India’s richest men.

headline: Seeking Asylum: Some Lie, but More Are Legitimate
text: To the Editor:

headline: Beltran’s Legacy Should Include Times When He Swung
text: Carlos Beltran was sick again Monday, his flulike symptoms having worsened overnight. He had told teammates Sunday that they could expect him in the lineup against the Florida Marlins the next night, but instead he was sent to a doctor, and the Mets hoped he would keep his distance.

headline: Beyond the Cubicle
text: Most talk of work these days revolves around the latest unemployment figures, the difficulties of getting and/or holding onto a job and/or how we are all working more hours for less money and less vacation time, or the bleak prospects for newly minted college grads (starkly rendered by cartoonist Jenna Brager in the new anthology “Share or Die: Youth in Recession.”)

headline: Ways to Think About End-of-Life Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fairer Broadcast for Title Game
text: It has been a dozen years since ABC’s broadcast of the United States team’s victory in the 1999 Women’s World Cup final was a jingoistic embarrassment. China’s players, who lost to the Americans on penalty kicks, were faceless automatons to the network and its announcers, J. P. Dellacamera and Wendy Gebauer.

headline: Cuts to Teaching Hospitals
text: To the Editor:

headline: Trying to Revive Trusted Traveler Program
text: LIKE most business travelers, I’d welcome the opportunity to provide the government with some basic information to indicate that I am not inclined to acts of terrorism, and in turn to receive a special pass that lets me get through airport security with my shoes on and my personal dignity relatively intact.

headline: John S. Toll Dies at 87; Led Stony Brook University
text: John S. Toll, a physicist and educator who was president of Stony Brook University on Long Island during the public university building boom of the Rockefeller years, overseeing its transition from a state college with 1,700 students to a major research institution with an enrollment of 17,000, died on Friday in Bethesda, Md. He was 87.

headline: The New Consumer Agency
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Hated and the Hater, Both Touched by Crime
text: Mark Anthony Stroman, 41, a stonecutter from Dallas, shot people he believed were Arabs, saying he was enraged by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. He killed at least two: Vasudev Patel, an Indian immigrant who was Hindu, and Waqar Hasan, a Muslim born in Pakistan.

headline: Game Fixing Rattles Soccer Around World
text: International soccer authorities and law enforcement officials are struggling to combat rampant game fixing by what they describe as sprawling networks of organized crime, a problem that has plagued the sport for decades but appears to have intensified recently.

headline: Philadelphia’s Cardinal, Amid Scandal, Is Said to Be Retiring
text: Cardinal Justin Rigali, the Roman Catholic leader of Philadelphia, is expected to announce his retirement on Tuesday, some five months after the 1.5 million-member archdiocese was convulsed by evidence that officials had ignored sexual-abuse charges against dozens of currently active priests.

headline: Back to School? Summer Season for Shopping Is Early This Year
text: THIS year, for the back-to-school shopping season, it is, as a sage once said, getting late early out there.

headline: For Cuomo, Hairstyling and Makeup Fit for a Star
text: For Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, cleaning up Albany apparently began with cleaning up himself.

headline: Heart Warning Added to Label on Popular Antipsychotic Drug
text: AstraZeneca is adding a new heart warning to the labels of Seroquel, its blockbuster antipsychotic drug, at the request of the Food and Drug Administration, company and agency officials said on Monday.

headline: In Debt Crisis, a Legislative Trick Up the Sleeve
text: WASHINGTON — With Republicans and Democrats still deeply divided over how to shrink the budget deficit and the national debt, the only way for them to avoid a financial crisis at this late date may be to perform a legislative magic trick.

headline: Murdoch Faces Questions, but Gains Vocal Support
text: LONDON — Even by recent standards, it was a long day for Rupert Murdoch. The share price of News Corporation dropped another 4.29 percent, several of his largest newspaper Web sites were hacked and he spent much of his time cramming for his appearance before Parliament on Tuesday to answer questions about the hacking scandal that has engulfed his company and his family.

headline: Nephew Testifies Against Man in Terror Plot
text: The nephew of a man accused of lying to investigators and destroying evidence as federal agents scrambled in 2009 to prevent a plot to set off homemade bombs on Manhattan subway lines testified on Monday that his uncle, Mohammed Wali Zazi, had ordered family members to destroy bomb-making supplies that were stored in a relative’s garage in Colorado.

headline: Guilty Plea in Attack on Woman in Bar
text: A man who attacked a woman after she had rebuffed him in a Midtown bar last year pleaded guilty on Monday to charges under which he is expected to be sentenced to 16 years in prison.

headline: Bloggingheads: Debt-Ceiling Denialism
text: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The Daily Beast and Michael Brendan Dougherty of The American Conservative debate right-wing grassroots mistrust of economic experts.

headline: 24 Small Towns May Lose Air Service
text: Rural America, already struggling to recover from the recession and the flight of its young people, is about to take another blow: the loss of its airline service.

headline: In Connecticut, Unions Amend Voting Rules to Revive Deal
text: Facing 6,500 layoffs and punishing program cuts, the leadership of the state employees’ unions in Connecticut voted on Monday to change their bylaws to make it easier for union workers to approve a concession agreement whose rejection last month scrapped a budget-cutting deal with the state.

headline: Tracking the Storm
text: On the night that deadly tornadoes devastated parts of the South, Glenn Burns, the chief meteorologist of Channel 2 in Atlanta kept viewers up to date.

headline: Advancing Slowly on a Daunting Road
text: FRANKFURT

headline: Greek Union and Premier Brace for a Fight
text: ATHENS — Sitting in his office on a recent morning beneath photographs of Marx, Lenin and Che Guevara, Nikos Fotopoulos, the leader of Greece’s most powerful labor union, took a freshly printed flier from a stack. “We are ready for new battles,” it read.

headline: Murdoch’s Board Stands By as Scandal Widens
text: The board of the News Corporation might as well be named “Friends of Rupert.”

headline: For Three Same-Sex Couples, Together Many Years, the Wait Is About Over
text: On Sunday, New York becomes the sixth and largest state with legalized same-sex marriage. Over the ensuing weeks and months, gay and lesbian couples from around the state, and beyond, are expected to descend on city and town clerks’ offices seeking marriage licenses, with the legal recognition, and rights, that marriage brings.

headline: As Weather Becomes Big Story, TV Forecasters Play the Hero
text: ATLANTA — One evening in April, Tina Eller had the television on. Glenn Burns, the steely chief meteorologist for WSB-TV, said a tornado was three minutes away from slamming into her community.

headline: Syria’s Struggle
text: We are in awe at the courage of the Syrian people and disgusted by the brutality of President Bashar al-Assad and his henchmen. Mr. Assad has lost all legitimacy. The question now is what can the international community do to support the opposition and its demands for freedom?

headline: A New High-Tech Assault on Midtown Traffic Jams
text: It is an all-too-common sight in Midtown Manhattan: cars, taxis and trucks stacked behind one another, gridlock forming at intersections, horns blaring as pedestrians navigate the tight spaces between bumpers.

headline: Nobody Should Be Fooled. It’s Protectionism.
text: The World Trade Organization’s ruling this month against China’s restrictions on the export of raw materials is a welcome decision that we hope will temper China’s mercantilistic strategy, in which every policy decision is designed to favor Chinese exporters. It also should serve as a warning to others about these protectionist tools.

headline: The Tables Are Turned on Murdoch
text: You have to love the fact that when John Yates resigned on Monday as the assistant commissioner of the Metropolitan Police in London — a k a Scotland Yard — he complained about the “huge amount of inaccurate, ill-informed and, on occasion, downright malicious gossip” that had finally forced his hand.

headline: Time for Action on Freddie and Fannie
text: A year after passage of the Dodd-Frank act, the $10.5 trillion American mortgage market remains in limbo. One big reason is that the law scarcely touches Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and the Federal Housing Administration — the government-run lenders that dominate the home loan market.

headline: The Peak and Life Below It
text: A familiar metaphor for nature is the pyramid of life, with large predators living at the peak because they’re few in number and eat species lower on the pyramid. Like most simple metaphors, this one has a perceptual flaw. It creates the illusion that large predators have an effect only on the prey species immediately below them. The truth, as a growing body of scientific studies shows, is that the presence, and absence, of top predators cascades all through nature in surprisingly complex ways.

headline: True to Episcopal Church’s Past, Bishops Split on Gay Weddings
text: The Episcopal Church, which has been strained by gay-rights issues since the election of an openly gay bishop in New Hampshire eight years ago, is now divided over how to respond to the legalization of same-sex marriage in New York.

headline: Openly Gay Man Is First Confirmed as U.S. Judge
text: J. Paul Oetken, a former Clinton administration lawyer, on Monday became the first openly gay man to be confirmed as a federal judge.

headline: Tuesday: One Who’s Not Sure What’s Up
text: Administrivial Notepad Alert! There will be a Notepad in tomorrow’s puzzle that reads: When this puzzle is done, you will find that the ends of the answers to the five starred clues, when in the 15-/67-Across, comprise a 1-/71-Across. I know. Don’t panic. It will make more sense tomorrow.

headline: U.S. Women Return With Heads Held High
text: After their heartbreaking loss to Japan in the Women’s World Cup final, the players on the United States team were nevertheless treated to a hero’s welcome near Times Square on Monday. Onlookers gathered outside the W Hotel on 47th Street and Broadway like a flash mob, snapping photographs, seeking autographs and calling out “Hope!” at the popular goalkeeper Hope Solo.

headline: The Road Not Taken
text: Over the past months, Republicans enjoyed enormous advantages. Opinion polls showed that voters are eager to reduce the federal debt, and they want to do it mostly but not entirely through spending cuts.

headline: Make Birth Control Affordable
text: MY daughter, a divorced mother of three, called me recently to complain about the high cost of birth control. As a physician, I’m familiar with this problem, yet it never fails to frustrate me. Our health care system could save billions — and improve the health of women and families — by placing birth control within every woman’s reach. Instead, health insurers continue to charge fees that make it difficult, sometimes impossible, for women to prevent unintended pregnancy.

headline: Battle for Libya | July 18, 2011
text: Rebels fire artillery guns outside of Ajdabiya.

headline: Watchlist: Rebecca Black’s New Music Video
text: Ah, Rebecca Black. As you sing in your new music video, “My Moment,” you’ve “waited for so long” for your moment to come. It’s been five whole months since your first music video, “Friday,” made you famous in not quite the way you expected and was watched 160 million times on YouTube. You even turned 14 in the meantime. Now you’re going to be famous on your own terms, at your own Web site, plus on your YouTube channel and, starting Tuesday, at iTunes.

headline: Exiled Islamists Watch Rebellion Unfold at Home
text: LONDON — Abu Sohaib spends most of his time online these days, following the news from his native Libya. He is in constant contact with friends on the ground there, helping them map out strategy to fight the rule of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: In Makeup Game, It’s Like May Again for Mets and Marlins, but With McKeon
text: Jack McKeon was in town for barely 24 hours, but in that brief time, he gave a small demonstration of what baseball might look like if all managers did what he does, which is manage the game how he sees fit.

headline: Life After Land
text: Lund, Sweden

headline: On Nauru, a Sinking Feeling
text: Yaren, Nauru

headline: Software Designer Reports Error in Anthony Trial
text: MIAMI — Assertions by the prosecution that Casey Anthony conducted extensive computer searches on the word “chloroform” were based on inaccurate data, a software designer who testified at the trial said Monday.

headline: A Behemoth Vacation Home Rises in the Ozarks and So Does the Wild Speculation
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — There are some who insist the giant concrete structure a few hours south of here is actually a military bunker. Others speculate it is a secret facility designed to house extraterrestrial visitors. And still others suspect, more or less plausibly, a low-profile getaway for local boy Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie.

headline: Radiation-Tainted Beef Spreads Through Japan’s Markets
text: MINAMISOMA, Japan — Even after explosions rocked the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, Kuniaki Sato, who raises cattle here about 20 miles from the crippled complex, said he had received no clear warning from the government about the possible dangers of radiation to his herd.

headline: Lawmaker Requests End to Ethics Panel Investigation
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Maxine Waters, citing apparent misconduct by ethics committee staff last year, called on Monday for the termination of an investigation into allegations that her office may have acted inappropriately in helping a bank in which her husband owned stock to get federal bailout money in late 2008.

headline: Wisconsin Democrat Faces Recall Vote
text: The fate of one of the Wisconsin lawmakers who fled the state this year in an effort to block cuts to collective bargaining rights for public workers will be decided by voters on Tuesday.

headline: Marijuana May Be Studied for Combat Disorder
text: DENVER — For years now, some veterans groups and marijuana advocates have argued that the therapeutic benefits of the drug can help soothe the psychological wounds of battle. But with only anecdotal evidence as support, their claims have yet to gain widespread acceptance in medical circles.

headline: A.I.G. Weighs I.P.O. of Aircraft Unit
text: The American International Group is considering an initial public offering of its giant aircraft leasing business that could be held later this year, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Monday.

headline: Signing Away the Right to Govern
text: It used to be that a sworn oath to preserve, protect and defend the Constitution was the only promise required to become president. But that no longer seems to be enough for a growing number of Republican interest groups, who are demanding that presidential candidates sign pledges shackling them to the corners of conservative ideology. Many candidates are going along, and each pledge they sign undermines the basic principle of democratic government built on compromise and negotiation.

headline: Magnus Malan, Apartheid Defender, Dies at 81
text: Magnus Malan, a South African general and defense minister who in the 1980s helped devise and carry out his nation’s last-ditch strategy to preserve its system of rigid racial segregation, including ordering raids into surrounding countries, died on Monday in Cape Town. He was 81.

headline: Yankees Rally Against a Weary Rays Bullpen
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The Yankees’ flight landed around 8:15 the night before, or just about the time the Tampa Bay Rays were beginning an epic game against the Boston Red Sox that stretched for 16 innings and nearly six hours. As the Yankees unwound, the Rays exhausted their bullpen, a development with significant repercussions Monday night.

headline: Volvo Crash Prevention System Receives High Marks From Insurance Institute

headline: School Discipline Study Raises Fresh Questions
text: Raising new questions about the effectiveness of school discipline, a report scheduled for release on Tuesday found that 31 percent of Texas students were suspended off campus or expelled at least once during their years in middle and high school — at an average of almost four times apiece.

headline: China’s Biggest Search Engine, Known for Illegal Downloads, Makes Music Deal
text: BEIJING — Baidu, the dominant Chinese Internet search engine, on Tuesday announced a major licensing deal with three of the world’s largest music companies that would allow Chinese Web users to legally download and stream hundreds of thousands of songs free.

State-by-State Welfare Assistance

headline: Murdochs Deny That They Knew of Illegal Acts
text: LONDON — It was riveting theater, a newly emboldened parliamentary committee facing off against the 80-year-old Rupert Murdoch, the world’s most powerful media mogul, in a series of exchanges designed to get to the bottom of the phone hacking scandal that has engulfed not just Mr. Murdoch’s News Corporation, but also Britain’s political and law-enforcement elite.

headline: Artist? Journalist? Vestige?
text: Photography has entered such an extraordinary state of transformation that labels no longer serve a purpose. Photojournalist? Photographer? Artist? Today, it seems that we need to be all of the above if we’re to continue working in this sea of photography.

headline: Tilting the Soccer Field in Their Favor
text: Which is the more insidious problem in soccer: corruption and entitlement among the powerful men who rule the game from FIFA headquarters, or match-fixing by the players and referees at the bottom of it? Doreen Carvajal looked into the former in Monday’s Times, and Jeff Z. Klein tackled the latter — a growing, worldwide scourge — in Tuesday’s editions. Read both articles, then come back to comment.

headline: The Debt Limit and National Security
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul.

headline: Rembrandt and Degas: An Odd Pairing in Amsterdam
text: Rembrandt van Rijn and Edgar Degas don’t make for the most obvious pairing in art: the 17th-century Dutch painter is more associated with dark, somber portraits and landscapes, while the French Impressionist is best-known for his romantic pastel-hued scenes from ballet. But the Rijksmuseum (Jan Luijkenstraat 1; www.rijksmuseum.nl) is ingeniously devoting one show each year to the influence of great Dutch painters on those of other periods and nationalities, providing insight into relatively unexplored links between famous artists. Last year, Jan Steen was paired with Joan Miró. This year, through Oct. 23, the museum presents “Two Young Artists,” featuring more than 20 self-portraits of Rembrandt and Degas as they were beginning their early careers.

headline: Fantasy Focus: The All-Bust Team
text: Last week I wrote about the first-half fantasy all-stars. This week, let’s take on the busts. The criteria are as follows: (1) Least production given the cost; and (2) At least 250 at-bats for hitters (except catchers) and 80 innings or 30 appearances for pitchers. All statistics are through Sunday.

headline: Central Park Chapels to ‘Pop Up’ for Gay Marriages
text: Some couples may be married in a chapel made of three-dimensional plywood letters arranged in a circle. Others could find themselves in one composed of interlocking pipes connected with plastic zip ties. Certainly, the couples who marry inside such structures intend to form unions far more permanent than the sites where they will exchange vows.

headline: Am I Focusing on the Wrong Part of My Business?
text: It is now more than three years since the economy took a nosedive. For most small businesses, this has been even more challenging than previous recessions because we have also had to deal with the real estate collapse, a credit crisis and changes in the marketplace brought on by the Internet and other forces. Not an easy time. And I don’t see much evidence of a bounce back coming soon. I have come to the conclusion that it is time to reassess.

headline: At Bank of America, an $8.8 Billion Loss
text: 8:34 a.m. | Updated  Bank of America reported a loss of $8.8 billion in the second quarter as it doled out huge payments to settle legal claims related to its troubled mortgage division.

headline: Perry Eyes Religious Voters
text: If Gov. Rick Perry of Texas runs for president, one thing seems clear: he plans to make a concerted appeal to the conservative Christians who make up a large block of Iowa’s Republican caucus voters.

headline: At Funerals for Protesters, More Syrians Are Fatally Shot
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian security forces killed at least 15 people on Tuesday in the central city of Homs, residents and activists said, in a violent escalation in a place that has emerged as a focal point of the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: A Word With Mitch Winehouse
text: Mitch Winehouse, a former salesman and London cabby, is quick to say that he knows he is only getting a shot at being a professional jazz singer at the age of 60 because his daughter is Amy Winehouse, the British soul singer and songwriter whose struggles with addiction have been fodder for the tabloids. But he also makes it plain that he thinks he can sing, and says that he will dispel doubts about his talent.

headline: Wells Fargo Exceeds Expectations With $3.9 Billion Profit, Up 29%
text: Wells Fargo, the nation’s biggest consumer bank, said profit rose 29 percent in the second quarter from the period a year earlier as loan losses eased significantly.

headline: A Gamble for Vermont Yankee
text: The owners of the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant may be coming up fast on a crucial decision about the reactor’s future. The plant’s initial 40-year operating license expires in March 2012; the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is willing to let it run another 20 years, but the state of Vermont is not.

headline: Goldman Sachs Disappoints With Earnings of $1.05 Billion
text: 8:45 a.m. | Updated  Goldman Sachs reported profit of $1.05 billion on Tuesday, a weak showing that reflected the firm’s costly move to reduce risk and cut back trading activities.

headline: In Philadelphia, a Changing of the Guard in the Shadow of Scandal
text: PHILADELPHIA — As Cardinal Justin Rigali stepped aside Tuesday to make way for his successor on the public stage, he barely mentioned the sexual-abuse scandal that has engulfed his eight-year tenure as head of the 1.5 million-member Archdiocese of Philadelphia.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Counting Calories? Your Diet May Need Updating
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: The Cameras Watch, but Do They Give Criminals Pause?
text: Videos from surveillance cameras were important tools in capturing the man accused of abducting and murdering 8-year-old Leiby Kletzky in Brooklyn last week. They caught the boy at several points along his fatal walk in Borough Park, including the moment when he got into a car and was driven away. In short order, they led investigators to their suspect, Levi Aron.

headline: Scribd Creates a Paid News Site
text: Relatively few people are willing to pay for an online newspaper or magazine. But what if they could pay a monthly fee for a vast library of news, like Netflix’s subscription service for movies?

headline: Housing Starts Are Higher, but Analysts Are Cautious

headline: Scribblers and Madmen
text: Ezra Klein has a good column on the dangers of being wrong about Keynes. As he says, it’s very difficult to respond rationally to an economic crisis when politicians like Eric Cantor completely fail to understand what Keynesianism is all about:

headline: The Nagging Effect: Better Health for Married Men
text: Relationship researchers have long known that marriage is associated with better health, particularly for men. One reason is that wives often take on the role of caregiver, setting up doctor appointments and reminding, even nagging, their husbands to go.

headline: Gardasil for Daughters and Sons?
text: Parents of girls have struggled with whether to obtain the vaccine to protect their daughters from human papillomavirus. Now, parents of sons have to make a similar decision.

headline: Protest Yacht, Bound for Gaza, Is Diverted by Israeli Forces
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli naval forces boarded a French yacht off the Gaza coast on Tuesday as the yacht tried to breach the Israeli maritime blockade of the Palestinian enclave. The forces met no resistance, Israeli military officials said, and steered the boat toward the Israeli port of Ashdod.
