headline: London Theater Journal: Shakespeare as Cover Boy
text: LONDON — My favorite part of “Being Shakespeare,” Simon Callow’s one-man show about guess who, was the intermission. This is no dis to Mr. Callow, a gracious and well-spoken docent in the eternal museum that is the life and works of William Shakespeare. But it was at the interval (as Londoners call the rest period between acts, when the audience provides the dialogue) that I felt that the old glovemaker-turned-playwright was most truly alive.

headline: After Quake, Japanese Choose Peace of Mind Over Great View
text: TOKYO — From their spacious 24th-floor apartment here, Masako Tsubuku and her husband had a breathtaking view of Mount Fuji.

headline: For First Day of Gay Marriage, City Plans License Lottery
text: New York City officials, hoping to prevent confusion and disappointment as thousands of gay and lesbian couples prepare to marry, said Tuesday that the city would take the unusual step of limiting the number of marriages on Sunday, the first day the state will allow same-sex marriage.

headline: Talking to Children About Tragedy
text: The Brooklyn Tragedy 24 Hour Crisis Intervention Hot Line, (917) 710-8399, was deluged last week, after the brutal murder of young Leiby Kletzky. It is staffed by Chai Lifeline, an organization whose more-usual mission is to “restore the light of childhood to children whose innocence ended when life-threatening or lifelong illness was diagnosed.” It was not designed for such a tragedy; then again, what is?

headline: A 2nd News Executive, Now Arrested, May Have Counseled Cameron
text: LONDON — The British phone-hacking scandal crept closer to Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain on Tuesday when his party admitted that another former news executive recently arrested may have provided informal public relations advice before last year’s election.

text: Adele, the soulful British singer and songwriter who has dominated American and British charts this summer, was among the 12 artists nominated today for the Barclaycard Mercury Prize, along with the rapper Tinie Tempah and the electronic-music wunderkind James Blake.

text: This week on the Consults blog, Stephen Rose of the Foundation Fighting Blindness took reader questions about macular degeneration and related diseases. Here, Dr. Rose responds to questions about macular degeneration. See, too, his responses in “Vitamins for Vision Loss.”

text: The assassination of President Hamid Karzai’s half-brother Ahmed Wali Karzai in Kandahar last week suddenly brought back strong memories of the time I spent there with the Karzais almost exactly a year ago.

headline: Waiting for a Deal
text: We regret to inform you that all of the excitement of last weekend — those riveting soccer games and golf played for a while in a typhoon — has been replaced in the top sports news by lawyers in suits “anticipating a tentative agreement” to end the N.F.L. lockout. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, we are assured that an agreement is near. We think. Could get hung up, though. So check back when more lawyers in suits pony up to another microphone and we feel more of our brain cells sliding into a deep freeze.

text: Be careful before starting a Boy Scout troop in Gould, Ark. Or a Harry Potter fan club. Or a baseball team.

headline: July 19, 1911: The Day East River Tolls Melted Away
text: Ask not for whom the East River bridges were tolled. They would have still been tolled for thee, except for the fact that 100 years ago on Tuesday, Mayor William J. Gaynor rescinded the fee.

headline: Gay ‘Archie’ Character to Have His Own Comic Book
text: The gay pride parade continues in Riverdale, the longtime home of Archie Andrews and his friends. Kevin Keller, the first openly gay resident of the town, who was introduced in issue No. 202 of Veronica in September, will have his own monthly comic book starting in February. “He’s proven to be incredibly popular,” said Jon Goldwater, co-chief executive of Archie Comics. “We’re just so proud of the success of Kevin and the fact that he adds a new dynamic to Riverdale.”

headline: Watermelon Gazpacho
text: This is adapted from a watermelon and tomato soup in Anya von Bremzen’s wonderful book "The New Spanish Table." I’ll admit that I was skeptical about this recipe when I tried it, but it turned out to be a delicious surprise. The celery brings this combination together, so don’t leave it out.

headline: Debt Anxiety Raises Cost of Borrowing for Spain

headline: Giants on Tiptoe at a Los Angeles Museum
text: LOS ANGELES — One of the centerpieces of the impressive new Dinosaur Hall that opened this month in the Natural History Museum here is a tableau created from fossilized bones of the Cretaceous era.

headline: Bloomberg Pledges Money and Land for Engineering School
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg raised his offer on Tuesday to universities interested in setting up a school of engineering and applied sciences in New York City: along with practically free use of a swath of land, the city will contribute as much as $100 million.

headline: Bipartisan Plan for Budget Deal Buoys President
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama seized on the re-emergence of an ambitious bipartisan budget plan in the Senate on Tuesday to invigorate his push for a big debt-reduction deal, and he summoned Congressional leaders back to the bargaining table this week to “start talking turkey.”

headline: Geography Report Card Finds Students Lagging
text: Even as schools aim to better prepare students for a global work force, fewer than one in three American students are proficient in geography, with most eighth graders unable to explain what causes earthquakes or accurately describe the American Southwest, according to a report released Tuesday morning.

headline: The Very Long Weekend
text: I apologize. This blog post is anything but timely. I admit to being laid low by recent events: a Memorial Day fire led to a nightmare June of inspector hunting and permit gathering, culminating in two days of actual repair — all of which brought us to our third opening in less than a calendar year. Just in time for the Fourth of July. And fireworks. Not the celebratory exploding rainbows of the Grucci Brothers, more like the gruesome tales of the Brothers Grimm where an evil queen casts evil spells while stirring a smoldering cauldron behind a castle parapet in some dark forest.

headline: Mercedes-Benz Builds Twin Torture Chambers for Climate Tests
text: On Monday, Mercedes-Benz announced the completion of two climatic tunnels built to simulate extreme weather conditions for testing vehicles at its technology center in Sindelfingen, Germany.

headline: Steve Schneider’s Climate View
text: Today marks the first anniversary of the untimely death of Stephen H. Schneider, a central figure in the decades-long effort to understand the human influence on climate and pursue options for limiting risks from the ongoing buildup of human-generated greenhouse gases.

headline: Google+ iPhone App Surfaces in iTunes
text: On Tuesday, Google introduced a mobile version of Google+, the search giant’s new social networking service, for the iPhone.

headline: State Department Won’t Seek Extradition of the Quaids, Prosecutor Says
text: While they may live in fear of so-called “star whackers,” the Hollywood couple Randy and Evi Quaid are momentarily safe from United States authorities and will not be extradited from Canada, The Associated Press reported. The husband and wife fugitives have been wanted in California for months, and not by fans who want to tell Mr. Quaid they loved his performance in “The Last Detail”: in 2009 the couple were arrested in Texas for skipping out on a hotel bill in Santa Barbara, Calif., and missed several court dates before finally facing justice. (Charges against Mr. Quaid were dropped, and Mrs. Quaid was sentenced to probation and community service.)

headline: Court Permits Hindus Who Were Served Meat to Sue for a Purifying Trip to India
text: A New Jersey appeals court has ruled that a group of Hindu diners can sue to be flown to India to resolve a dispute over an order of samosas, The Star-Ledger is reporting.

headline: Is Obama Against Romney a Toss-Up?
text: Looking at head-to-head polls can be treacherous so far in advance of a presidential election. Instead, I’d suggest that you devote most of your attention to President Obama’s approval ratings and perhaps the favorability ratings of the Republican candidates, as well as to things like economic forecasts.

headline: Photo Replay: July 19
text: Amir Khan trained for his boxing match with Zab Judah this weekend in Las Vegas, while in Shanghai the world swimming championships featured the women’s 10-kilometer open water event.

headline: The Bright Spots in Hedge Funds
text: While the hedge fund industry has largely been flat this year, a few closely watched managers are standing out — welcome news for the portfolios that have struggled in recent years.

headline: Homeowners in Denial About Value of Properties
text: Homeowners, especially those who bought their houses after the real-estate bubble burst, are still having trouble accepting just how much the values of their properties may have fallen, says a new report from the real-estate site Zillow.

headline: How Spotted Hyenas Mate
text: Kay E. Holekamp, a zoologist at Michigan State University, writes from the Masai Mara National Reserve in Kenya, where she is studying the behavior of spotted hyenas.

text: The lawyer for Tristane Banon, the French writer who has accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn of sexually assaulting her several years ago, arrived at the Manhattan district attorney’s office Tuesday afternoon for an expected meeting with prosecutors.

text: UnitedHealth Group, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, reported its second-quarter results on Tuesday, and the good news for the industry looked as if it was likely to continue.

headline: Federal Authorities Arrest 14 Members of Anonymous
text: 6:15 p.m. | Updated Adding news of arrests by authorities.

headline: A Screen-Free Week at the Beach?
text: ML Nichols, a founder of theparentconnection.org, had better not be reading this today. She is off on vacation in Nantucket, Mass., and she was the one who declared it a screen-free week at the family beach house. After all, her Web site is dedicated to healthy parent-child connections, and is filled with photos of beach sand and backyard tents and trees, so she wants to practice as she preaches.

headline: Once-Celebrated Recklessness Leads to Dykstra’s Financial Fall
text: LOS ANGELES — Before promoting a single stock or venturing into the perilous world of magazine publishing, Lenny Dykstra lived the good life, essentially risk-free. He signed autographs, shook hands and banked the profits from his car-wash business.

headline: More Reserves May Be Asked of Top Banks
text: Regulators said on Tuesday that 28 of the world’s biggest and most interconnected banks would be required to hold more capital in reserve than less important banks would under proposals intended to keep the failure of one or two large institutions from causing a calamity.

headline: A Growing Crowd Follows ‘The Bachelorette’ and Her Search for Love
text: Reality programming once again dominated prime time as a two-hour version of “The Bachelorette” was the most-watched program on Monday evening, with an average of 7.7 million viewers tuning into ABC’s matchmaking show. As Ashley Hebert met the families of her various suitors and whittled down her true love options to three from four, the audience numbers actually grew over the course of the episode.

headline: A Look Inside Dinosaur Hall
text: Photographs of the newly refurbished dinosaur exhibition at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, which opened this month.

headline: In the Lab With the Ice Cream Makers

headline: On the Hunt for Brooklyn’s Greenest
text: These days, Bee Atwell patrols her shaded block in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, horticultural checklist in hand. Are the stoops brightened by potted plants? Are the hydrangeas properly watered? Do the tree beds have signs warning dogs to lift their hind legs elsewhere?

headline: Paul McCartney Documentary, ‘The Love We Make,’ Coming to Showtime
text: No amount of coverage of the lives of the Beatles could make us say it’s all too much, and the cable networks are surely relieved to hear it. Following an announcement by HBO that it had acquired a documentary about George Harrison, Showtime said on Tuesday that it would broadcast a nonfiction feature about Paul McCartney and his experiences in New York after the 9/11 terrorist attacks. The film, “The Love We Make,” will chronicle Mr. McCartney’s journey from Sept. 11, 2001, when his plane was grounded on a New York tarmac, through his planning for and performance at the “Concert for New York City” at Madison Square Garden the next month. “The Love We Make” will feature footage from that concert as well as appearances by Mr. McCartney’s friends and colleagues, including David Bowie, Eric Clapton, Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Pete Townshend, as well as his daughter Stella. It is directed by Bradley Kaplan and Albert Maysles, the venerated co-director of “Grey Gardens” and “Gimme Shelter,” as well as the 1964 documentary “What’s Happening! The Beatles in the U.S.A.”

headline: Google Looks for the Next Google
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Google thinks it can be young and crazy again. And it is betting $200 million that it is right.

headline: Anticlimax in Long-Running CSX Railroad Court Case
text: Remember the epic battle between CSX, the big railroad company, and the Children’s Investment Fund Management, a British hedge fund? If you do not, you are not alone. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit appears to have forgotten it as well. It took the federal court two years to give out its opinion deciding the litigation fight between the parties, in a ruling that came down on Monday that left some issues unsettled long after the battle subsided.

headline: Tunnel Vision
text: Eleven years after the documentary “Dark Days” was released, the film’s director Marc Singer revisits the train tunnel that once hosted a homeless community.

headline: Digital Diary: The Freedom to Forget?
text: Last week, a new report from researchers at Columbia revealed that our reliance on the Internet is affecting the way we remember information.

headline: How Do You Teach About 9/11?
text: Update, Aug. 12 |  Thank you to the many teachers who have written in so far — and please, keep those ideas coming! As we work behind the scenes to get ready for this anniversary, your creative and thoughtful responses have been enormously helpful.

headline: Voeckler Feels Yellow Jersey Slipping Away
text: GAP, France — Late Tuesday afternoon, in the capital of the Southern Alps, the French cyclist Thomas Voeckler wore both the yellow jersey and a frown. He led the Tour de France, still, for another day, maybe two, but almost certainly not for long.

headline: Atlantic Theater Company to Offer World Premieres
text: World-premiere productions of new plays by the Pulitzer Prize-winner John Patrick Shanley (“Doubt”), the filmmaker and writer Ethan Coen (“No Country for Old Men”) and the prolific playwright Adam Rapp (“The Metal Children”) are among the Atlantic Theater Company’s lineup for the 2011-12 Off Broadway season, executives there said on Tuesday.

headline: Minnesota Lawmakers Called to Special Session to End Impasse
text: Lawmakers in Minnesota were called back to the state Capitol on Tuesday afternoon for a special session intended to end a budget impasse that has brought state business to a standstill since July 1.

headline: The Caucus Click: Freshmen Rally at the White House
text: A group of House Republicans gathered in front of the White House to demand that President Obama offer specific details of his deficit-reduction plan.

headline: ‘An Anatomy of Addiction’
text: Prologue

headline: The Lure of Cocaine, Once Hailed as Cure-All
text: The world’s first cocaine millionaire was probably Angelo Mariani, a French chemist originally from Corsica, Dr. Howard Markel writes in his new book, “An Anatomy of Addiction.” Mariani combined ground coca leaves with Bordeaux in the 1860s and marketed his “tonic wine” under the name Vin Mariani. Each fluid ounce contained six milligrams of cocaine. The wine expert Robert Parker would surely have given this bright liquid 110 points.

headline: Women at the Republican Convention
text: With Sarah Palin as the first woman vice-presidential candidate of the Republican Party, women felt empowered at the convention.

headline: Day Two at the Republican Convention
text: The Republicans ramped up a full convention schedule a day after suspending activities because of a hurricane that struck the Gulf coast.

headline: The Republican Convention, Day Three
text: Gov. Sarah Palin electrified supporters with her vice-presidential acceptance speech.

headline: Working the Convention Crowds
text: Celebrities and politicians are among those who gather behind the scenes at the Democratic National Convention.

headline: First Day at the Democratic National Convention
text: Senator Edward M. Kennedy and Michelle Obama highlighted the opening night.

headline: Guarding the Party
text: A confluence of high-profile figures, protesters and tens of thousands of others in Denver left security officials with a heavy burden at the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Writing on Wall Street (Car Chase Optional)
text: Three writers with backgrounds on Wall Street blur the line between reality and fiction with thrillers set in the world of high finance. DealBook’s Kevin Roose brings together the writers — David T. Lender, H.T. Narea and Norb Vonnegut — for a roundtable discussion about whether a novel can hold a candle to the real drama of the Street.

headline: Day Three at the Democratic Convention
text: Senator Barack Obama was officially nominated as presidential candidate of the Democratic Party.

headline: In Toronto Suburb, Putting Curvaceous Into Condominiums
text: MISSISSAUGA, Ontario — People looking for the latest in twisting, gravity-defying architecture might start with the international cities of the Middle East or China, but you wouldn’t expect them to look here, in the suburbs outside Toronto.

headline: Energy Transfer Bumps Its Southern Union Bid
text: Locked in a bidding war for the Southern Union Company, Energy Transfer Equity said Tuesday that it would raise its bid for the pipeline operator to $5.9 billion, edging past a rival offer by the Williams Companies.

headline: Bachmann Says Migraines Won’t Be a Problem if She’s Elected President
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Michele Bachmann suffers from migraine headaches so intense that she has sometimes sought emergency medical treatment, but the congresswoman said Tuesday that the condition would not preclude her from serving as president if elected.

headline: The Chain Gang
text: We saw it first on the spring runways at Valentino and Chloé — models wearing delicate gold anklets with the daintiest flats. Then, for resort, the Row collaborated with the jewelry designer Ileana Makri on charmy versions of the accessory. And earlier this week the blogger Garance Doré confessed her love for the delicate adornment. It’s official: The anklet is de rigueur again. “I made one for myself last summer, and I absolutely love it,” the jewelry designer Irene Neuwirth says. “I don’t wear it every day, but I do find that once I put it on I don’t take it off.” Can’t wait until the Row’s resort version hits stores? Doré recommends doing it yourself. “I love the simple ones — tiny gold or silver bracelets will do, small beads I put on a string, or even just a piece of colored cord,” she says. “It’s charming when it feels easy.”

headline: DuPont Is Sued Over New Herbicide
text: A Pennsylvania homeowner and an Indiana golf course company have filed a class-action lawsuit against DuPont charging that the chemical giant was either negligent or reckless in putting a new weedkiller on the market.

headline: Christine Quinn on Gay Marriage Lottery
text: The City Council Speaker on the lottery system that will determine which of those same-sex couple who wish to wed on June 24 will be married by the city.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Rejects Diabetes Drug
text: A federal advisory committee recommended that a diabetes drug that works in a new way should not be approved because of safety concerns.

headline: Aphrodite and Me: Adventures in Cyprus
Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Afghanistan, Yemen and France.

headline: Ahead of Pebble Beach Auctions, a Tiger Hunter’s 1925 Rolls-Royce Awaits Its Prey
text: Kota, in the northern Indian state of Rajasthan, once was the dominion of Umed Singh II, a maharajah who is said to have enjoyed hunting big game from his 1925 Rolls-Royce New Phantom Torpedo Tourer. While there is no record that a torpedo had been mounted to the car, the body-style distinction is appropriate, as seemingly every other form of ballistic matériel found its way onto the car’s flanks or into its cabin.

headline: Political Advocacy Groups Denied Tax-Exempt Status
text: Three nonprofit advocacy groups that recruited and trained potential political candidates in the last several years have been denied tax exemption by the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: For Philadelphia Archdiocese, a Powerful Conservative Voice
text: Before he was named on Tuesday to lead the prominent but troubled Archdiocese of Philadelphia, Archbishop Charles J. Chaput spent the last 14 years in Denver establishing himself as one of the nation’s most prominent advocates of a politically engaged and conservative Catholicism.

headline: Venturing Outside Family, Devils Select a New Coach
text: The Devils hired Peter DeBoer on Tuesday as the latest member of their head-coaching carousel. He replaces Jacques Lemaire, who announced after the season that he would retire once again.

headline: TimesCast | July 19, 2011
text: Testimony is offered by Rupert Murdoch, James Murdoch and Rebekah Brooks before a British parliamentary committee, and Londoners react.

headline: A Look Inside Dinosaur Hall
text: Photographs of the newly refurbished dinosaur exhibition at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, which opened this month.

headline: The Fatty Crew Comes to Central Park
text: The first food cart fielded by the Fatty empire — Pullcart — has found its first permanent home: the Bethesda Terrace in Central Park.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Afghanistan, Yemen and France.

headline: Alone With Schubert and 2 Flying M.I.T. Robots
text: As Pilobolus continues its 40th-anniversary season at the Joyce Theater, the group, which started in 1971 and is named after a fungus, is — by the looks of it — working hard to maintain its playful edge. At least that was evident in Monday night’s program, which was overlong and slightly improvised to make up for the dancer Eriko Jimbo’s recent injury.

headline: At G.E. Plant in Connecticut, Volts Plug In to the Sun
text: PLAINVILLE, Conn. — On Monday morning, no fewer than five Chevrolet Volts were charging on 100 percent renewable energy from General Electric’s parking-lot Solar Carport. Opened in May, the 100-kilowatt solar installation, which also offers some shade and weather protection and has 10 connected G.E.-built chargers, is projected to last 25 years and provide 125 megawatt-hours of electricity annually, according to G.E.

headline: Strong Sales Help Extend Apple Streak
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Strong sales to shoppers in emerging markets and to business customers helped Apple extend its lengthy streak of stellar performance in its earnings report on Tuesday.

headline: Illegal Sale of Rice Wine Thrives in Chinese Enclaves
text: The restaurant looks like so many others in the roiling heart of Chinatown, in Lower Manhattan: a garish sign in Chinese and English, slapdash photos of featured dishes taped to the windows, and extended Chinese families crowding around tables, digging into communal plates of steamed fish, fried tofu and sautéed watercress.

headline: All Hail the Gang of Six (or Seven)
text: Finally, some not-dispiriting news from Washington: President Obama has given his qualified support to a new plan to reduce the deficit, remarking that it “is broadly consistent with what we’ve been working on at the White House.” And who put forward this proposal that could help stave off economic catastrophe? A bipartisan group of seven senators called the Gang of Six. (Congress has never been good with numbers.) Earlier this year, Bill Keller wrote a column for the magazine praising the gang’s efforts, which he said proved that the word “politician” need not be a synonym for “craven,” and it’s certainly worth rereading now.

headline: A Daughter of Strauss-Kahn Is Questioned
text: PARIS — Investigators have questioned the daughter of Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, as part of an investigation into accusations that he attempted to rape a young writer, Tristane Banon, in 2003, an official at the prosecutor’s office said on Tuesday.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘This is Spinal Tap’
text: A. O. Scott turns his critical meter up to 11 when looking back at Rob Reiner‘s 1984 comedy “This Is Spinal Tap.” The film, which takes a “mockumentary” look inside the workings of the fictional rock band Spinal Tap, succeeds because it takes its characters seriously.

headline: Profit Up 13%, UnitedHealth Raises Outlook
text: The UnitedHealth Group, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, reported its second-quarter results on Tuesday, and the good news for the industry appeared likely to continue. UnitedHealth announced a double-digit increase in profits and raised its estimates for 2011 earnings, according to its news release. Its net income rose 13 percent, to $1.27 billion, or $1.16 a share, compared with $1.12 billion, or 99 cents a share, one year ago. And revenue increased 8 percent, to $25.23 billion.

headline: Joffrey Ballet Dancers Agree to Tentative Deal
text: After threatening a lockout, the Joffrey Ballet has reached a tentative settlement with its dancers, The Chicago Sun-Times reported. The company, based in Chicago, was in a contract dispute over salaries and rehearsal hours. The Joffrey wanted to increase the hours, to the chagrin of the American Guild of Musical Artists, the union representing the dancers and stage managers, who maintained they were not being compensated adequately for the extra time. This month the managers of the Joffrey sent a letter to its dancers, who were on a scheduled vacation, telling them that performances would be canceled unless a contract was signed. Christopher Clinton Conway, the Joffrey’s executive director, told The Sun-Times that, pending a vote by the dancers, a tentative agreement had been reached. The new contract, for five years instead of the previous contract’s three, includes a minimum 10 percent raise. “The dancers will be back in class on Monday, and rehearsals will begin, as planned, on July 25,” Mr. Conway said. Representatives for the guild could not be reached, The Sun-Times said.

headline: Bushwacker Is a Tough Bull
text: Since October 2009, no professional bull rider has been able to stay on Bushwacker for eight seconds. At a recent event in Pueblo, Colo., the riders explained why he's so tough to ride.

headline: Jumping and Spinning, a Ballerina With Hooves
text: Dustin Elliott, a 145-pound professional cowboy, popped into the chute and felt energized by the lights above and the 1,600-pound bull beneath him. He wrapped a rope around his right hand, twisted right to left four times, then bounced up and down three times. The bull, meanwhile, looked casually to the left and waited.

headline: Pakistan’s Military Plotted to Tilt U.S. Policy, F.B.I. Says
text: WASHINGTON — Pakistan’s military, including its powerful spy agency, has spent $4 million over two decades in a covert attempt to tilt American policy against India’s control of much of Kashmir — including funneling campaign donations to members of Congress and presidential candidates, the F.B.I. claimed in court papers unsealed Tuesday.

headline: Hahn Is Sworn In to House of Representatives
text: The House of Representatives welcomed its 433rd member on Tuesday when Janice Hahn was sworn in, one week after her special election victory to replace former Representative Jane Harman in California’s 36th Congressional District.

headline: Panel Recommends Coverage for Contraception
text: WASHINGTON — A leading medical advisory panel recommended on Tuesday that all insurers be required to cover contraceptives for women free of charge as one of several preventive services under the new health care law.

headline: Columbia Student to Be Sentenced to 6 Months Over Drug Ring
text: A Columbia University student who was the main target of an undercover investigation of a ring that sold drugs from the campus will be sentenced to six months in jail after pleading guilty Tuesday to selling cocaine.

headline: Shades of Gay
text: Long before New York sanctioned same-sex marriage, iO Tillet Wright, a photographer and writer based here, was at work on a project celebrating sexual freedom. “My goal is to show the humanity that exists in every one of us through the simplicity of a face,” she says of her mission to photograph as many people as possible who “aren’t 100 percent straight.”

headline: New York’s New Frozen Treats
text: I HAD never been so grateful to see a banana.

headline: Quick! Before Summer Melts Away
text: New Yorkers enjoying the new sweets of the season at street fairs, flea markets and street carts.

headline: Bill Aims to Limit Identity Theft Using Medicare Cards
text: Proposed legislation in Congress seeks to reduce identity theft by eliminating distribution of Social Security numbers. Not on the computer, but on a small piece of paper carried by millions of people: the Medicare card.

headline: Legal Drama Has a Change of Venue, From Cable to Satellite
text: A select group of television viewers received an unusual voice mail recently. “Hi, this is John Goodman,” it began, in that actor’s familiar husky voice. “I’m calling to tell you about the season premiere of the Emmy Award-winning show ‘Damages,’ starring Glenn Close, Rose Byrne and me. Tune in tomorrow night on Channel 239. Hey, it’s only the best show on television. And it’s only on DirecTV.”

headline: Iced Coffee and Tea: (Not) Taking the Heat
text: ICED coffees and teas should be some of summer’s simplest pleasures, especially when we just steep them in cold tap water, with no kitchen heat and next to no effort. But if you make even a desultory search for advice on cold brewing, you may find yourself mopping your brow deciding how, and even whether, to proceed.

headline: Q. and A. With Harold McGee on Brewing Coffee and Tea
text: In his Curious Cook column this week, Harold McGee, whose most recent book is “Keys to Good Cooking: A Guide to Making the Best of Foods and Recipes,” writes about making iced coffee and tea. On Diner’s Journal he’ll be answering readers’ questions about brewing coffee and tea, hot or cold. Submit your question as a comment below and he’ll respond later this week.

headline: Damson Plums Flavor Finger Lakes Gin
text: Damson plum jam is utterly English. But take those dark little plums, grown by Red Jacket Orchards in Geneva, N.Y., extract the juice and mix it with small-batch gin from upstate and you have a thoroughly New York drink. It’s old-fashioned sloe gin, updated (sloes are a small plumlike fruit). Tart-sweet and 33 percent alcohol, it’s labeled liqueur by Scott Krahn, who makes it in the Finger Lakes region to add to the line of products made by his company, the American Gin Company based in Manhattan. It does wonders for iced black tea on a late summer afternoon. Use it in sparkling wine to give a new twist to kir royale. Or mix it 50-50 with plain gin, a splash of orange juice and a few drops of orange bitters over ice, and call it whatever you want. The liqueur’s name, Averell, nails its Empire State pedigree as it refers to a former governor, a Harriman, from a line of railroad moguls.

headline: Staff Tells N.R.C. That U.S. Rules Need Overhaul After Fukushima
text: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission’s rules are a patchwork that needs to be reorganized and integrated into a new structure to improve safety, the agency’s staff told the five members of the commission on Tuesday at a meeting.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Obama to Support Repeal of Defense of Marriage Act
text: President Obama will endorse a bill to repeal a law that limits the legal definition of marriage to a union between a man and a woman, the White House said on Tuesday, taking another step in support of gay rights.

headline: What Goes Best With Drama: Red, White or a Pint?
text: LONDON — Bartenders are rarely shy about offering an opinion or four. But on a recent evening at the Finborough Wine Cafe, in between pours of Beaujolais, the bartender Van Badham was memorably on point about the new play “Mirror Teeth” being performed in an upstairs room: A Christopher-Durang-meets-Caryl-Churchill satire about racism, sex and control in the British family, capped by a corker of an ending in which a desperate father pimps out his unstable 18-year-old daughter.

headline: Waters Confronts Ethics Committee
text: Representative Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, has now formally requested that the House Ethics Committee dismiss any charges against her and terminate its investigation into allegations that she improperly tried to influence the award of federal bailout funds to a bank in which her husband owned stock.

headline: Looking to Park? So Is Your Lunch
text: THE streets of New York are paved with gold, and Kenny Lao was out there on a recent morning, prospecting.

headline: The Allure of Romesco Spreads Far Beyond Spain
text: WITH Spanish cooking so much in the spotlight, it’s no surprise that romesco, one of the cuisine’s classic sauces, is reaching a wider audience.

headline: Ruby Jewel From California Is Sweet Corn With a Blush
text: In the Northeast, suggesting corn on the cob from California at this time of year is tantamount to treason. But we’re talking about a stunning red variety that’s sweet and nothing like the table decorations of late fall. It also has the juicy yet meaty texture of young corn.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Deep Blue Sea

headline: Dekalb Market Opening in Brooklyn
text: By Saturday, 22 shipping containers in an array of colors will be in place for the opening of Dekalb Market, a collection of food, clothing and other retailers in Downtown Brooklyn that will be open year-round.

headline: In Scarred Syria City, a Vision of a Life Free From Dictators
text: HAMA, Syria — In this city that bears the scars of one of the modern Middle East’s bloodiest episodes, the revolt against President Bashar al-Assad has begun to help Syrians imagine life after dictatorship as it forges new leaders, organizes its own defense and reckons with a grim past in an uncertain experiment that showcases the forces that could end Mr. Assad’s rule.

headline: Zillow Prices I.P.O. at $20 a Share
text: Zillow priced its initial public offering on Tuesday at a higher-than-anticipated $20 a share, as the real estate Web site became the latest beneficiary of investor hunger for Internet companies.

headline: Wendi Deng Murdoch Refuses to Pull a Punch
text: LONDON — The Murdoch who may have emerged in the best light from the grueling question-and-answer session in the British Parliament on Tuesday was not Rupert Murdoch or his son James, but his wife, Wendi.

headline: Diligently Turning Dostoyevsky German
text: It’s not apparent from the title, but Vadim Jendreyko’s elegant, slightly chilly documentary, “The Woman With the 5 Elephants,” is a profile of Svetlana Geier, a small and formidable woman who was the pre-eminent translator of Dostoyevsky’s novels into German. (The five elephants refer to her valedictory project, a 20-year effort to retranslate his five major novels, which she completed in 2007; she died, at 87, in 2010.)

headline: Episcopal Bishop in Western N.Y. to Allow Priests to Officiate at Gay Marriages
text: After much consultation, the Episcopal bishop in Western New York on Tuesday joined two of his peers in the state in allowing priests to officiate at same-sex weddings.

headline: A Western Photographer in Hama, Syria
text: On his return from Hama, Syria, where he had traveled with the correspondent Anthony Shadid, the photographer Moises Saman, a nominee for membership in the Magnum Photos collective, spoke by telephone with his colleagues James Estrin and David Furst. Their conversation has been edited and condensed.

headline: Ombudsman Criticizes ESPN’s Rules in Review of Reporter’s Book
text: A report by the Poynter Review Project, ESPN’s ombudsman, concluded Tuesday that fuzzy in-house rules about letting writers be co-authors of books with subjects they cover led in part to the network’s benching of the reporter Bruce Feldman. He had collaborated on the former Texas Tech football coach Mike Leach’s new autobiography.

headline: Jabra’s Speakerphone Is Exciting Because It’s Useful
text: Getting excited about a Bluetooth car speakerphone is a tough business. First, it’s a Bluetooth device, so if you’ve seen one, you’ve seen them all. Second, it’s a device made for the car so it’s kind of useless for folks who spend time on the subway.

headline: As Life Passes by, Venezuelans Are Always Standing in Line to Watch
text: CARACAS, Venezuela —Revolutions come and go. Construction frenzies reshape this city’s skyline and then go bust, leaving white elephants as testament. Oil prices rise and fall, and rise again. But one thing, at least, endures: the lines.

headline: Allende’s Death Was a Suicide, an Autopsy Concludes
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — A new autopsy has determined that President Salvador Allende of Chile killed himself with an assault rifle, Chilean officials said Tuesday, dispelling doubts that have persisted for 37 years about the exact circumstances of his death, including whether troops storming the presidential palace had murdered him.

headline: Arizona Officials, Fed Up With U.S. Efforts, Seek Donations to Build Border Fence
text: PHOENIX — Americans upset about illegal immigration have a new outlet for their rage: a fund set up by the State of Arizona that will use private donations to build a border wall.

headline: ESPN’s British Open Viewership Sags Again
text: The British Open’s weekend rounds shifted from ABC Sports to ESPN in 2010, and the tournament is struggling to recover the audience lost in its broadcast-to-cable transfer.

headline: Cuomo Says for Next 6 Months, He Will Focus on Creating Jobs
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, declaring the first phase of his governorship complete after a string of legislative victories, said Tuesday that he planned to devote the next six months to creating jobs, particularly in economically ailing communities upstate.

headline: Beyond the Proving Ground of War
text: To the Editor:

headline: N.B.A. Sets Schedule but Might Not Use It
text: The dates and times of a potentially glorious Knicks season were unveiled Tuesday, in vivid detail. The asterisks were implied.

headline: The Glenn Beck / DeBeers Connection
text: Kash, at the Street Light, has a very good post on the price of gold and its relationship or lack thereof to inflation fears. He points out that the market for gold is surprisingly small, so that it would take only a relatively small number of extra buyers to push the price way up, even when other, more direct measures of expected inflation remain low. And he draws a parallel with diamonds:

headline: An App for Reporting an Emergency
text: Today, when a tornado leaves a path of destruction or a fire engulfs a home, you can be sure a citizen with a cellphone camera has captured the devastation and posted it to Facebook or Twitter, or sent it to the media.

headline: Nissan Will Raise Price of the Leaf, Its Electric Car
text: DETROIT — Nissan Motor said Tuesday that it was raising the price of the Leaf electric car by several thousand dollars as it prepared to offer the vehicle with additional features in 21 new states by the end of the year.

headline: The Consumer Bubble
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama to Back Repeal of Law Restricting Marriage
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will endorse a bill to repeal the law that limits the legal definition of marriage to a union between a man and a woman, the White House said Tuesday, taking another step in support of gay rights.

headline: Couple Sues a Vermont Inn for Rejecting Gay Wedding
text: BOSTON — A lesbian couple is suing a Vermont inn, claiming it refused to host their fall wedding reception because of their sexual orientation.

headline: Beyond Greece, Europe Fears Financial Contagion in Italy and Spain
text: PARIS — As European leaders prepare to convene on Thursday in another emergency summit meeting, a new awareness is growing: Greece is effectively insolvent, contagion is spreading to Italy and Spain, and time is running out to shore up confidence in the euro.

headline: New Approach Proposed for Science Curriculums
text: A new framework for improving American science education calls for paring the curriculum to focus on core ideas and teaching students more about how to approach and solve problems rather than just memorizing factual nuggets.

headline: Wireless Speakers Cut the Cord to High Prices
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Standing in Line in Venezuela
text: Long lines, a vestige of old Soviet Eastern Europe, are part of Venezuelans’ daily grind.

headline: With N.F.L. Deal in Sight, Each Side Can Claim Gains
text: N.F.L. owners and players closed in on an agreement in principle Tuesday night on an expected 10-year labor contract. It would ensure that the 16-game season starts on time, give owners a bigger portion of revenue and limit how much money rookies can make.

headline: Icahn’s Activism Lifts Some Stocks, but Others Plunge
text: Aug. 17 | Updated

headline: A Better Sort of Pig
text: In May, I went to Iowa, primarily to learn more about so-called conventional agriculture, those thousand-acre farms growing corn and soybeans, planted, tended and harvested largely by machine. (We have plenty of the other type — what’s variously called traditional, or alternative, or non-conventional — in the Northeast.) But thanks to an auspicious combination of topsoil, climate, topography and weather, Iowa is among the best locales for farming in North America, and I saw a wide range of practices.

headline: John Mosca, a Restaurant’s Patriarch, Dies at 86
text: When John Mosca carried out a bowl of blue crab claws drenched in garlicky Italian dressing and set it on the bar at the Louisiana restaurant that bears his family name, he wouldn’t say much. He didn’t need to.

headline: Columbia Student Admits Selling Cocaine on Campus
text: A Columbia University student who was the main target of an undercover investigation of a ring that sold drugs from the campus will be sentenced to six months in jail after pleading guilty Tuesday to selling cocaine.

headline: Weak Recovery Weighs on Bank of America and Wells Fargo
text: Even as the big banks stanch their losses, they are reckoning with an unfortunate reality: the anemic recovery is hurting their results.

headline: Cost-Cutters, Except When the Spending Is Back Home
text: WASHINGTON — Freshman House Republicans who rode a wave of voter discontent into office last year vowed to stop out-of-control spending, but that has not stopped several of them from quietly trying to funnel millions of federal dollars into projects back home.

headline: Twitter Is Still Whistling
text: ASPEN, Colo. — Twitter is facing a federal government investigation, competition from Google+ and the departure of two of its founders. But Dick Costolo, Twitter’s chief executive, has a message for the naysayers: the business is growing just fine.

headline: Trusting Families to Help Themselves
text: On Friday, I reported on the Family Independence Initiative (F.I.I.), an organization that encourages low-income families to define their own goals and work towards them in mutual support groups, while carefully documenting their successes. (F.I.I. pays modest stipends for the research data provided by families.). So far, the few hundred families that F.I.I. has worked with have demonstrated impressive gains in areas like income and savings, debt reduction, skills training, and improvements in children’s grades and health care.

headline: Trenton Left-Hander Rushes to the Majors
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — When a player is promoted to the majors for the first time, the first person he tells is usually a parent. It was no different Tuesday for the left-hander Steve Garrison, who was recalled by the Yankees. Except that Garrison did not share the good news with his mother, Patty, over the phone. He just walked into the next room.

headline: After Budget Cuts, Defendants’ Wait to See a Judge Often Exceeds 24 Hours
text: In Brooklyn, a night in jail often lasts longer than one night. Sometimes it can drag out over two or even three nights.

headline: Creating Art via Webcam, Secretly
text: For three days last month, an artist named Kyle McDonald secretly programmed computers at two Apple stores in Lower Manhattan to shoot a webcam picture every minute. As people squinted, frowned, glared, grinned, grimaced, snarled and other ways looked at the screens, their pictures were snapped, silently. Then the photos were automatically sent to Mr. McDonald’s server.

headline: Utah Liquor Laws, as Mixed Up as Some Drinks
text: DRAPER, Utah — When Vuz Restaurant and Vuda Bar opened here a couple of months ago, the idea was to bring a dash of dining chic to this corner of the Salt Lake Valley.

headline: Negotiating Election Headwinds
text: WASHINGTON

headline: 16 Arrested as F.B.I. Hits the Hacking Group Anonymous
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In the most visible law enforcement response to a recent spate of online attacks, the Federal Bureau of Investigation on Tuesday announced the arrests of 16 people across the country in connection with strikes carried out by a loose, secretive federation of hackers called Anonymous.

headline: Bobblehead Has Its Day, but Davis Needs Time
text: A few hours before the Mets distributed Ike Davis bobblehead dolls for fans attending Tuesday’s game, the real-life version of the player created a ripple during an appearance at a Long Island day camp when he said that his chances of returning from an ankle injury this year were “not good.”

headline: Scandal Stirs U.S. Debate on Big Media
text: Progressive activists and public interest groups have long blasted Rupert Murdoch and his News Corporation for political biases. But in recent weeks they have seized on a new and more tangible reason to call for the revocation of his TV licenses and the breakup of his company: the British hacking scandal.

headline: Goldman’s Safer Positions Eat Deeply Into Its Profit
text: Yuri Gripas/ReutersDavid Viniar, chief financial officer of Goldman Sachs, told analysts that he would not “sugarcoat” the firm’s second-quarter results.

headline: At Fox News, a Scandal Hits Home
text: The pie attack may have been the best thing that happened to Fox News on Tuesday.

headline: Delay on Tejada’s Buffalo Shuttle
text: To make room for Jose Reyes on their roster Tuesday, the Mets had planned to send infielder Ruben Tejada to Class AAA Buffalo. But Tejada ended up unpacking his bags shortly after he was told he was to ship out of Queens.

headline: Obama vs. Romney, an Early Skirmish
text: A recent Twitter exchange between Bill Burton, a former adviser to President Obama who remains close to the White House, and Eric Fehrnstrom, a longtime adviser to Mitt Romney, highlights the different tacks the two 2012 campaigns are taking on issues.

headline: Open-Access Advocate Is Arrested for Huge Download
text: A respected Harvard researcher who also is an Internet folk hero has been arrested in Boston on charges related to computer hacking, which are based on allegations that he downloaded articles that he was entitled to get free.

headline: Time Running Out for a Bank Chief
text: Brian Moynihan, the chief of Bank of America, needs to kick it up a notch or two. He has spent much of his 18 months in the corner office cleaning up the mess left by his predecessor, Ken Lewis. But despite the yeoman efforts, he has failed to convince investors that he is turning the company around.

headline: Murdochs Caught a Break at Hearing, Stock Analysts Say
text: After days of intense anxiety over their appearance before a parliamentary committee on Tuesday, there seemed to be consensus inside the company and out that the Murdochs and the News Corporation had finally caught a break.

headline: Alex Steinweiss, Originator of Artistic Album Covers, Dies at 94
text: Alex Steinweiss, an art director and graphic designer who brought custom artwork to record album covers and invented the first packaging for long-playing records, died on Sunday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 94.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Wednesday: Limerick’s Land
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle by Peter A. Collins comes with a Notepad, and I highly suggest reading it so you catch all of the great stuff he has managed to cram into the grid. If you are not solving in a way that enables you to see it, the Notepad says: “When this puzzle is done, you will find that the ends of the answers to the five starred clues, when in the 15-/67-Across, comprise a 1-/71-Across.” That’s a fairly cryptic clue, so let’s get solving and see what he means.

headline: City in Rhode Island Asks Retirees to Sacrifice
text: CENTRAL FALLS, R.I. — The retirees came from near and far, gathering in a muggy auditorium here to listen to an urgent pitch: give back a big chunk of your pension or risk losing it all.

headline: A Gay Man Seeks a Place in an Orthodox World
text: In his evocative 2009 docudrama, “The Temperamentals,” the playwright Jon Marans examined the stigma of being gay in pre-Stonewall America, when the threat of exposure could leave friendships, careers and even lives dangling by a thread.

headline: 2nd Relative Says Man Planned to Destroy Evidence of Subway Terror Plot
text: The father of a man who plotted in 2009 to set off homemade bombs in Manhattan subway cars tried to thwart investigators by destroying evidence and misleading a grand jury, a relative testified on Tuesday.

headline: Marijuana for Patients May Proceed, Christie Says
text: New Jersey will forge ahead with its stalled medical marijuana program, Gov. Chris Christie said Tuesday, adding that he believed the people involved will not face federal prosecution.

headline: Lawyer Is Convicted of Larceny in a $100 Million Stock Swindle
text: A lawyer who helped to plot a $100 million securities fraud scheme that sold fundamentally worthless stocks to a series of investors, including Yale University, was convicted of grand larceny on Tuesday, prosecutors said.

headline: A Closer, and Skeptical, Look at Nontraded REITs
text: Last year, Cole Real Estate Investments of Phoenix, a sponsor of nontraded real estate investment trusts, refunded $3 million to the West Warwick, R.I., pension board, which had bought shares in one of its REITs despite strenuous objections from its investment adviser, who resigned in protest.

headline: Reyes and Beltran Return to Lineup, Lifting Mets’ Spirits and Fortunes
text: Jose Reyes had kicked off his plaid sneakers by 3:40 p.m. on Tuesday and had his wrists taped for batting practice, which was still an hour away. He said he had arrived at Citi Field at 1:50, a half-hour earlier than usual, eager to play his first game for the Mets in 17 days.

headline: Ivy League to Limit Full-Contact Football Practices
text: The Ivy League will announce on Wednesday that, in an effort to minimize head injuries among its football players, it will sharply reduce the number of allowable full-contact practices teams can hold.

headline: City Asking Cuomo to Veto a Measure It Helped Write
text: For the last three years, lawyers for the Bloomberg administration have argued in court alongside transportation union lawyers for the extension of unusual job protections for school bus drivers and other employees that can amount to lifetime job guarantees. But now that unlikely alliance is heading toward an abrupt end.

headline: West Calls Wasserman Schultz ‘Vile’
text: Representative Allen West, Republican of Florida, called Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Democrat of Florida, “the most vile, unprofessional, and despicable member of the U.S. House of Representatives” in an e-mail to her on Tuesday.

headline: U.S. Revises Its Response to Lawsuit on Anthrax
text: Embarrassed Justice Department officials rushed on Tuesday to correct their own filing in a lawsuit over the 2001 anthrax letters after learning that it appeared to contradict the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s conclusion that Bruce E. Ivins, an Army scientist, prepared the deadly powder in his Army laboratory.

headline: Harrisburg Council Rejects Financial Rescue Plan
text: HARRISBURG, Pa. — The City Council in this financially struggling city rejected a statesponsored recovery program on Tuesday, in an act of rebellion against state and county officials who had repeatedly pressured the city to accept it.

headline: Diabetes Drug Dapagliflozin Rejected by F.D.A. Panel
text: A federal advisory committee voted 9 to 6 on Tuesday that a first-of-its-kind diabetes drug should not be approved for use because of safety concerns, including a possible increased risk of breast and bladder cancers.

headline: Delaware: Suit Filed Over Herbicide
text: A Pennsylvania homeowner and an Indiana golf course company have filed a class-action lawsuit against DuPont charging that the company was negligent or reckless in putting a new weed killer on the market. The suit, filed Monday in federal court in Delaware, asserts that the herbicide, Imprelis, is killing trees, shrubs and ornamental plants across the country. It seeks compensation for all damage suffered as a result of applications of Imprelis, an injunction barring DuPont from selling the product and unspecified punitive damages. In a statement, DuPont said it was “confident that this purported class-action lawsuit is unfounded, and we will oppose it vigorously.”

headline: From Gallipoli to Singapore
text: Right before a clown threw blue shaving cream on Rupert Murdoch and Murdoch’s pink-clad wife threw a roundhouse at the clown, the most powerful media mogul in history was reminiscing about his father.

headline: California: Inquiry Into Life on the Run
text: A federal grand jury is to hear testimony on the time that the Boston crime boss James (Whitey) Bulger and his girlfriend, Catherine Greig, spent evading the authorities, living under aliases in a Santa Monica apartment a few blocks from the beach. Joshua Bond, the property manager of the building where Mr. Bulger and Ms. Greig lived since the late 1990s, said he received a subpoena last week asking him to appear in federal court in Boston next week. Mr. Bulger and Ms. Greig used the aliases Charles and Carol Gasko while they lived in Santa Monica, paying their $1,165 rent for their two-bedroom, rent-controlled apartment in cash. A tip led the F.B.I. to their apartment, and agents said they found guns, a hand grenade, handcuffs and $822,000 in cash hidden inside the walls.

headline: Ecolab Nears $5 Billion Deal for Nalco
text: Ecolab, the disinfectants maker, is near a deal to buy the water treatment company Nalco Holding  for about $5 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: Can Greeks Become Germans?
text: Athens

headline: Military Is Left Out of Draft for Egyptian Rule
text: CAIRO — A committee tapped by Egypt’s interim military rulers to draft guidelines for a new constitution has unexpectedly declined to include any provision about the role of the military, two members said Tuesday, rejecting public suggestions by both committee members and top military officers to grant the military a broad, protected role in the future government.

headline: Why We Need the Tabloids
text: Los Angeles

headline: No Reward for Colon in Yankees Loss to Rays
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Bartolo Colon’s right hand was wrapped in ice late Tuesday night, and so was his right shoulder. His left hamstring required no such treatment after holding up on the mound and in his mind. But the Yankees’ perception of a successful game did not begin and end with Colon, however impressively he pitched.

headline: Robot Cars Are Coming
text: Daniel Drezner, left, of Tufts University and Daniel H. Wilson, author of "Robopocalypse," debate self-driving cars.

headline: Sizzle Factor for a Restless Climate
text: ENJOYING the heat wave?

headline: Blame Congress
text: American Electric Power’s decision to shut down an ambitious experiment aimed at capturing greenhouse gases from a coal-fired power plant was a disappointing setback to efforts to control harmful global warming emissions from coal, among the world’s most abundant fuels.

headline: Europe at the Brink
text: Time is running out for salvaging Greece and, beyond it, Europe’s shared currency, the euro. Thursday’s emergency summit meeting looms as a Lehman Brothers moment.

headline: Hurting Poor Students
text: Extremists in Congress have long wanted to gut the spending restrictions in Title I, a federal law dating back to the 1960s that underwrites extra help for disadvantaged schoolchildren. A bill, approved by a House committee last week, would do just that, damaging one of most important civil rights programs in the country.

headline: Taxis Beyond Manhattan
text: Manhattan looks like a sea of taxis, but it’s a different picture in many other parts of the city. A city study of GPS data shows that 97.5 percent of the more than 13,230 yellow cabs pick up their fares in Manhattan or at the two city airports. That leaves about 80 percent of the city’s population underserved.

headline: State Street Will Cut 850 Jobs to Offset Costs
text: State Street, one of the country’s largest custody banks, will cut 850 more jobs over the next 20 months after reporting earnings that missed analysts’ estimates.

headline: Pierrette Alarie-Simoneau, Canadian Soprano, Dies at 89
text: Pierrette Alarie-Simoneau, an internationally known Canadian soprano who sang at the Metropolitan Opera in the 1940s, died on July 10 at her home in Victoria, British Columbia. She was 89.

headline: Murdoch, ‘Surprised and Shocked,’ Is Likely to Face More Questions
text: LONDON — Rupert and James Murdoch said repeatedly during their extended testimony before a parliamentary committee in Britain that their involvement in managing the News Corporation’s response to the phone hacking scandal was limited. Rupert Murdoch said he felt let down by “the people that I trusted and then, maybe the people they trusted.”

headline: Spirit of Middle East Protests Doesn’t Spare Israel
text: TEL AVIV — The tents are lined up on the grassy median of this city’s most stylish avenue, scores of them, populated by a downtown mix of characters: the unemployed down-and-out next to the artistic elite; half-naked men in straw hats; women in minidresses. Surrounding them are protest posters (“The only place left to live is the cemetery”) and designated spots for cooking or getting an Internet connection.

headline: Jordan’s Protesters Ask Little, and Receive Less
text: AMMAN, Jordan — Since January, when Jordan’s protest movement started holding regular demonstrations, the marches have grown, and persisted, but have never reached a critical mass. Hobbled by infighting and outflanked by King Abdullah II and his security forces, the protesters keep calling for greater freedoms and an end to corruption, but remain frustrated that their regular gatherings — sometimes only two-hour affairs — have hastened no real change.

headline: Is This Life After Assad?
text: In Hama, the revolt has begun to help Syrians imagine life after the father-and-son dictatorship.

headline: Corrections: July 20
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Athletic Performance and the Monthly Cycle
text: What makes a female athlete different from a male athlete? Watching Abby Wambach leap above defenders in a World Cup soccer game to head the ball decisively into the net, or seeing her teammate Megan Rapinoe streak a pass down the pitch, the answer might seem to be: not much. As a group, female athletes, like their male counterparts, display coordination, strength, grace, speed, stamina and a bracing competitiveness.

headline: Baryshnikov Arts Center  Announces Fall Season
text: The New York premiere of C.I.C.T./Théâtre des Bouffes du Nord’s production of Samuel Beckett’s “Fragments” is one of the highlights of the Baryshnikov Arts Center 2011 fall season, which will run from Sept. 8 to Dec. 16. “Fragments” is the center’s second co-presentation with Theater for a New Audience. Three new dance pieces, by the choreographers Deganit Shemy and Liz Gerring and the Irish step dancer Colin Dunne, are also in the lineup. Musical offerings include a co-presentation with the Orchestra of St. Luke’s and two world premiere evening-length performances by the International Contemporary Ensemble.

headline: U.S. to Close 800 Computer Data Centers
text: The federal government plans to shut 40 percent of its computer centers over the next four years to reduce its hefty technology budget and modernize the way it uses computers to manage data and provide services to citizens.

headline: Israelis Board Yacht Off Gaza
text: Israeli naval forces boarded a French yacht off the Gaza coast on Tuesday, as the yacht tried to breach the Israeli maritime blockade of the Palestinian enclave. The forces met no resistance, Israeli military officials said, and steered the yacht toward the Israeli port of Ashdod. The yacht is a remnant of an international flotilla that had planned to challenge the blockade last month but was mostly thwarted. The military said that when the yacht reached Ashdod, the passengers would be questioned by the Israeli police and then turned over to immigration authorities.

headline: France: War Dead Are Honored
text: French President Nicolas Sarkozy on Tuesday presided over a national ceremony in remembrance of the seven service members who were killed in Afghanistan last week, the deadliest week for French troops there since 2008. “The entire country bows before your coffins,” Mr. Sarkozy said in a speech at the Hôtel des Invalides, where Napoleon is buried. Five of the troops died in a suicide attack in eastern Afghanistan, while a French Navy commando was killed by insurgents and a 22-year-old soldier was shot by friendly fire. The toll amplified the calls to speed up the withdrawal of French troops from the country. In a surprise visit to Afghanistan last week, Mr. Sarkozy said that France would withdraw 1,000 of its approximately 4,000 troops from Afghanistan by the end of 2012.

headline: Word of the Day | carouse
text: carouse •\kə-ˈrauz\• verb/noun

headline: India: Clinton Urges Open Markets
text: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton pressed India on Tuesday to open its markets further and to amend a crucial regulation that would make it possible for American companies to bid for lucrative nuclear contracts there. Mrs. Clinton, stopping in India for three days on a 12-country tour, also pledged the United States’ support in fighting terrorism. Her visit, her second as secretary of state, came a week after three bombs ripped through heavily populated areas of Mumbai, killing 19 people.

headline: China: Reporting Team Disbanded
text: One of China’s leading investigative reporting teams has been disbanded because it focused too much on social ills, reporters in the team say. The China Economic Times five-person team was a rarity in China. It had tackled a variety of social problems, most recently for exposing how officials had covered up the distribution of fake vaccinations that had led to children’s deaths.

headline: NYT: Front Page for 07/20/2011
text: NYT: Front Page for 07/20/2011

headline: Is Dividing a Company the Way to Beat the Affordable Care Act?
text: That’s one notion that seems to be circulating among small-business owners and their advisers lately. Consultants at McKinsey & Company floated the suggestion as part of their controversial report on employer views of health insurance. And in The Times’s coverage of that report, Milt Freudenheim interviewed a small-business owner who said he was hoping to “game the system.” The owner, Gerry Harkins, who is also chairman of the National Federation of Independent Business’s Georgia State Leadership Council, said he might split his Atlanta-based construction company into two smaller companies to evade the overhaul’s employer mandate, specifically the penalties on companies that fail to offer affordable health insurance to employees.

headline: Afghanistan: Taliban Deny Reports of Leader’s Death, Citing Hacking
text: Taliban spokesmen denied reports sent through their e-mail and in text messages early Wednesday that their movement’s leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, was dead, saying that their Web sites and telephones had been hacked. Zabiullah Mujahid, one of the spokesmen, reached by telephone, said: “The enemy hijacked our telephone numbers and e-mails. They have sent out false texts and statements about death of Mullah Omar. In reality he is alive and in good condition.”

headline: Media Decoder: Murdoch's Testimony
text: Jeremy W. Peters and David Carr provide analysis of the testimony offered by Rupert Murdoch, James Murdoch and Rebekah Brooks before a British parliamentary committee.

headline: Battle for Libya | July 18, 2011
text: Supporters of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi gathered for a rally in Azizia while rebels battled for control of Brega in the east.

text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

text: Back from Germany and back to reality.

text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “Tough Calculus as Technical Schools Face Deep Cuts.”

headline: Cameron Tries to Shore Up Support in Hacking Scandal
text: LONDON — It was Prime Minister David Cameron’s turn to battle for his reputation, and potentially even his job, in the House of Commons on Wednesday in a debate on the phone hacking scandal that has convulsed Britain.

headline: Spotify Is Great, but Turntable.fm Is Amazing
text: Let’s get some obvious stuff out of the way:

headline: At the Theater, You Can Feel the Connection
text: LONDON — “MY dear Lady Disdain,” as she is sometimes called, has been struck by a compelling need to confide. And so Beatrice, in the beguiling person of Eve Best, walks to the edge of the stage at Shakespeare’s Globe — the popular Thames-side theater — shedding self-possession with every step. She is wearing an expression we have never seen on her before: elated, aghast and altogether undone.

headline: The Early Word: ‘Talking Turkey’
text: Today’s Times

headline: Roman Festivals Offer Al Fresco Dining
text: There’s little doubt that Rome is one of the best places in Europe to dine al fresco. But for a couple of months during the summer, things get even better, as several pop-up restaurants make dining under the stars not only irresistible, but too easy to pass up. Here is a brief look at some of the most appetizing options.

headline: Ferrari Testa Rossa Prototype Seeks an Auction Record at Pebble Beach
text: Plenty of significant cars have crossed plenty of auction blocks over the years on the Monterey Peninsula in California. The annual classic car week each August draws no shortage of eye-popping consignments, as auction companies do their best to bring fresh, exciting cars to market.

headline: Why Hasn’t Employment of the Elderly Fallen?
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Serbia Arrests Its Last Fugitive Accused of War Crimes
text: PARIS — The last Serbian fugitive wanted by a United Nations war crimes tribunal was arrested in a Serbian forest early Wednesday, a quiet event that appeared to remove the final major obstacle blocking the nation’s access to Western money and European Union membership.

headline: Does Google Make Us Smarter, Dumber or Both?
text: Why is your brain on Google better than your brain sans Google? Because it gives you somewhere to store all that trivia you would otherwise have to waste precious brain cells remembering. Or so says Jonah Lehrer, via Andrew Sullivan on the Daily Dish, who points out that Google not only helps us remember but also helps us correct our often faulty memories. “While the Web enables all sorts of other biases – it lets us filter news, for instance, to confirm what we already believe – the use of the Web as a vessel of transactive memory is mostly virtuous. We save hard drive space for what matters, while at the same time improving the accuracy of recall.” So forget all those warnings about how the Web just makes us dumber. It’s perfectly okay if you have to Google something you just read two seconds ago.

headline: Latest Updates on Phone Hacking Scandal
text: The Lede continued to follow developments in the phone hacking scandal in Britain on Wednesday. Video of Prime Minister David Cameron’s complete statement to the House of Commons on the scandal, and his answers to questions from members of Parliament, is embedded above.

headline: A Milestone in Brooklyn: 112 Birthdays
text: By now, Susannah Mushatt Jones knows her tastes are not changing.

headline: Yowie: Will This Start-Up Survive?
text: This is the first in a series of quick profiles of start-up companies. The Small Business Administration has found that about half of new businesses survive five years. Will this be one of the survivors?

headline: A Second Helping of Hip-Hop History From Justin Timberlake and Jimmy Fallon
text: “It’s not going to happen — we can’t do it again,” Justin Timberlake told the audience at “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon,” who at Tuesday’s show were perhaps expecting a reprise of “The History of Rap,” a 2010 performance in which he and Mr. Fallon rhymed their way from the Sugarhill Gang to Jay-Z and Alicia Keys, and in the process created a popular viral video.

headline: How ‘Gang of Six’ Revived Idea of Grand Debt Deal
text: For weeks, it had looked as if the year-long effort to reach a debt deal by the so-called Gang of Six in the Senate was defunct, a victim of the polarization in Washington, especially when it comes to taxes.

headline: Cnooc to Pay $2.1 Billion for Canadian Oil Sands Firm
text: OPTI Canada, a bankrupt oil sands producer, has agreed to sell itself to a wholly-owned subsidiary of the China National Offshore Oil Corporation, in a deal worth $2.1 billion, the company said on Wednesday.

headline: Now Showing | Paul Thek in Theory and Practice
text: If you’ve had your fill of glossy Pop Art and are suffering from aesthetic indigestion, “Prelude: Paul Thek in Process,” set to open this week in Berlin, is a wonderful palate cleanser — not to mention a poignant reminder that, when it comes to art, the means can be as, well, meaningful, as the ends. The curator Susanne Neubauer has focused on the ephemeral nature of a visionary artist’s practice, assembling rare slides, photographs, taped interviews, letters and other documents. The installation echoes Thek’s work, which, like his process, often reflected a sense of transience. A cascade of newspapers from walls to floor and pools of chicken wire are meant to evoke the spirit of his 1969 piece “Chicken Coop.”

headline: Yemen on the Brink of Hell
text: On May 29, a young woman named Bushra al- Maqtari joined a group of several thousand protesters marching down a trash-strewn boulevard in the Yemeni city of Taiz. The Arab world’s democratic uprising was five months old, and patience among the protesters in Taiz — Yemen’s second largest city — was wearing thin. Maqtari had been one of the first and most fearless leaders of the movement. She is a remarkable figure: a 31-year-old university administrator and fiction writer, she is also a childless divorcee who refused, until recently, to wear the abaya, the all-covering gown that is practically mandatory for women in Yemen. Tiny and frail, she has a round, lovely face, with level brows and tranquil brown eyes.

headline: The Perils of Polar Bears’ Longer Swims
text: In arguments over the impact of climate change, some of the images commonly associated with those clashes have attracted skeptical critiques, perhaps none more so than those of polar bears forced to swim longer distances because their sea ice habitat is melting. Some skeptics point out that polar bears are born swimmers and that the worries of environmentalists are therefore overdone.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Medical Panel Recommends Free Contraceptive Coverage
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Jet Order by American Is a Coup for Boeing’s Rival
text: PARIS — American Airlines announced on Wednesday a record order for 460 single-aisle planes from Airbus and Boeing in a deal worth more than $38 billion. The order breaks the longstanding monopoly that Boeing has had with the airline and forced a significant shift in the company’s strategy.

headline: French-German Proposal for Europe Emerges Before a Meeting on Greece
text: BRUSSELS — The leaders of Germany and France agreed late Wednesday on a proposal for a rescue plan for Greece to be presented to a summit meeting of European officials on Thursday, a statement from the French president said.

headline: PNC Profit Exceeds Expectations, Again
text: The PNC Financial Services Group on Wednesday reported a second-quarter profit of $912 million, up 12 percent from the period a year earlier, benefiting from strong gains in retail banking and asset management as well as improving credit conditions.

headline: A Star Who Clads Herself in Cool
text: UNIONDALE N.Y. — Rihanna isn’t cool because of her multitude of sexy, clever outfits; or her red hair, which sits flawless and immobile atop her head; or the ease with which she delivers a song, barely breaking a sweat, even on the most involved numbers.

headline: Then and Now, Worrisome Times in the Subways
text: My candidate for the best New York film ever was shown on a cable channel the other day. This was the classic “Taking of Pelham One Two Three,” released in 1974.

headline: Law and Order, Bulgarian Style
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria — Arms pinned behind his back, Alexei “The Tractor” Petrov lay with his face pushed to the floor after heavily armed masked police commandos raided his home early last year. The police then hauled him off in one of Bulgaria’s most pronounced efforts to take on the godfathers of racketeering, kidnapping and prostitution who have eroded trust in the country’s institutions and day-to-day life.

headline: Citadel Assails E*Trade and Calls for Sale
text: 8:05 p.m. | Updated

headline: Icahn Raises Bid for Clorox and Scolds Managers

headline: Takeout Totes
text: This is the season of the less-is-more clutch, with handfuls (pun intended) of designers offering palm-friendly options for girls on the go. Add to the list Beth Goodman, who in 2009 launched Marie Turnor Accessories, a collection of bags modeled after the most ubiquitous strapless carrier of all — the lunch bag. The idea came to her in Paris when she spotted a woman holding a perfect red paper bag. “I saw it as being a clutch,” Goodman explained. “It just looked to me like it should be,  it was such a chic and simple shape. I knew I had to create one in leather.” Her signature style, appropriately named the Picnic, is made of buttery-soft leather and comes in red, black, tan and white. For summer, Goodman is including a range of limited-edition colors — pale pink, purple, gold, bright turquoise and a sparkling aqua. Versatile, featherweight and with minimal hardware, they’re a welcome relief for our wardrobes and shoulders both.

headline: British Panel Accuses Murdoch Company of Impeding Inquiries
text: LONDON — A parliamentary panel investigating Britain’s spreading phone hacking scandal accused the Murdoch empire on Wednesday of “deliberate attempts” to thwart various investigations into what had happened.

headline: Bradley Cooper Going Down Under – Way Down Under – for ‘Paradise Lost’ Film
text: Having returned from a humid if lucrative trip to Bangkok (to shoot the smash summer comedy “The Hangover Part II”) with all of his digits intact, Bradley Cooper is headed to another sweltering location for his next movie – and we don’t mean Australia.

headline: Q&A: Learn Spanish and Do Some Good
text: My husband and I are interested in taking our rudimentary textbook Spanish to another level by living and volunteering (or working) in a Spanish-speaking country for a year. Can you suggest a safe, beautiful area that allows Americans to live for up to a year where we would have access to language classes, meaningful activities (I am a psychologist; he is a lawyer) and interesting people? (Mountainous hiking opportunities would be a plus.)

headline: Bachmann Reasserts Opposition to Debt Limit Increase
text: Representative Michele Bachmann continues to press her opposition to an increase in the debt ceiling as she runs another presidential campaign ad in Iowa this week.

headline: Ladies, We Have a Problem
text: I wanted to love SlutWalks, the viral protest movement that began this spring after a Toronto police officer told a group of college women that if they hoped to escape sexual assault, they should avoid dressing like “sluts.” In angry response, young women (and men) have marched in more than 70 cities around the world, often dressed in bras, halter tops and garter belts.

headline: Ahead of Security Transfer, Bombing Shakes Afghan City
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government officially took control of security in the capital of Helmand Province on Wednesday as part of a sweeping effort to begin to disentangle Western forces from the country.

headline: Commissioner’s Pick of Agudelo a Poke at the Red Bulls?
text: The FIFA U-20 World Cup begins next week in Colombia. The United States is not there, and neither is Juan Agudelo.
