headline: Calling George Will, Science Defender
text: I kind of figured that George Will’s January column urging Republican lawmakers to “rev the scientific engine” of America was a one-off.

headline: News Corp. to Stop Paying Legal Fees of Key Figure in Hacking Case
text: LONDON — Under pressure in the widening phone hacking scandal, the News Corporation on Wednesday said that it would no longer pay the legal fees for the private investigator at the center of the hacking and partly lifted a confidentiality agreement on one of its law firms to allow the firm to give evidence to Parliament and to the police.

headline: Two Paths in Budget Debate and in 2012
text: Apart from being a critical moment for the United States’ fiscal policy, the budget debates are an inflection point in the 2012 campaign. Particularly if an especially large deal is struck, like the Senate’s “Gang of Six” plan, or if negotiations break down and Congress struggles to raise the debt ceiling, it could dictate the strategies of both presidential and Congressional candidates.

text: TOP STORIES

headline: Planning the Perfect Vacation
text: WITH summer in full swing, the top priority of most travelers is simple: relax. But for many people that isn’t such an easy goal to attain.

headline: Countrywide to Distribute Settlement to Its Clients
text: More than 450,000 borrowers who were charged excessive fees by Countrywide Home Loans when they fell behind on their mortgages will finally begin receiving the $108 million the company agreed to pay in a settlement struck with the Federal Trade Commission in June 2010, the agency said Wednesday.

headline: In Turkey, a Home for Ancient Mosaics

headline: A New Type of Reward With Your Debit Card
text: Many banks are canceling or scaling back debit-card rewards programs, due to a pending cap on the swipe fees that bigger banks can charge merchants for processing transactions. USAA Bank, for instance, is canceling its debit rewards program as of Sept. 1.

headline: Will Lockout Harm Shumpert’s Progress as a Knick?

headline: Music of the Spheres
text: For most fans attending a baseball game is a summer diversion, an addiction, an act of devotion. I’m a music critic, so for me it’s something else too: an immersion in bustling, jumbled, enveloping sound. And if you think of the Yankees as an athletic orchestra, the team has a comfortable and acoustically lively new concert hall. What if I treated a game as a kind of outdoor musical piece?

The sanctioning body announced the new specification in February and completed its first on-track tests of fuel-injection systems this month at Kentucky Speedway.

headline: Gangs
text: If I seem sort of quiet on the debt ceiling stuff, it’s because (a) I have no idea how the political brinkmanship will play out (b) I believe that any deal like the Gang of Six proposal or whatever, even if enacted, offers little guide to what will actually happen starting after next year’s election. If it’s a Republican sweep, they will quickly dissipate any spending cuts with another round of tax cuts. If Democrats hold the White House and possibly even regain the House, they might conceivably turn to a solution that makes sense.

headline: Artifacts | Wolfgang Tillmans, Male Genus
text: It’s no secret that Wolfgang Tillmans has a special feeling for the men around him. In his portrait photographs, he examines them from every angle, indoors and out, in groups and alone, clothed and not. Sometimes he treats them as objects of desire and other times as simply as objects of curiosity. What’s strange is that, despite his camera’s studied distance from its subjects — friends in Tillman’s circle of acquaintance or landscapes, or rumpled clothing — his pictures read as very personal statements: Here are the people and the things I like and this is the way I like to see them. Which is part of their seduction.

headline: The Latest, Greatest Mash-Up

Sure, the Dangermouse-Beatles mashup, “The Grey Album,” was an instant classic in 2004, but beyond that and a rare few others, the thought of a third-party recklessly commingling two bands’ copyrighted music has always made me queasy.

headline: History Channel Turns Trash Into Ratings Gold
text: Trash really can be treasure, or least ratings gold, as History proved with its much-publicized cross-over event of three of its most popular shows last week. The gimmick, in which the stars of “American Pickers,” “American Restoration” and “Pawn Stars” joined forces to find, purchase and restore a 1957 Chevy 150 to pristine condition, worked, as the average 6.7 million total viewers tuning in made clear. But just how well became clearer with a look at the Top 10 list among basic cable shows for the week ending Sunday, according to Nielsen: the three shows all finished in the Top 10, with “Pawn Stars” second only to the Japan/U.S.A. final in the Women’s World Cup. “Pawn Stars,” in which viewers are privy to the haggling prowess of a family of pawnshop owners, has proved to be a major hit for History, as its ratings keep growing; the most recent episode, on Monday night, garnered 6.67 million viewers.

headline: From the Grand Bargain to the Gang of Six
text: Like Jon Chait and Matt Yglesias, I’m a little puzzled by the sudden wave of optimism about a potential deal based on the Gang of Six’s just-released bipartisan deficit reduction plan. So far as I can tell, the Gang of Six proposal bears a broad resemblance to the “grand bargain” that President Obama supposedly offered to John Boehner, except that the Gang’s tax reform proposals are more detailed (and raise more revenue) and its proposals for Social Security and Medicare cuts are less specific (there’s a lot of “requiring” Senate committees to come up with budget-cutting reforms). Depending on what came out of the entitlement reform process, I suppose that the Gang’s proposal could be a better deal for conservatives than what Obama offered Boehner. But more likely it would turn out to be a somewhat worse deal, with higher taxes and fewer real entitlement cuts, than the bargain House Republicans already inclined against when their own leader seemed to be considering it. (I recommend reading James Capretta for the sharpest conservative case against the Gang’s proposals, and Reihan Salam for some important qualifiers.)

text: Why not start with good news? Tom Zé — the luminous and original 74-year-old singer-songwriter from São Paulo, Brazil — not only played in New York on Tuesday night, for the first time in 12 years, but he also played a song about New York.

headline: Warning: Artists at Work
text: ON Monday evening in a vast studio in a warehouse building next to the Hudson Yards, where the creative department of Barneys New York envisions and assembles its ever-changing window displays, George Herms, an artist of the beat generation, was unpacking a box that was filled with warped squares of mirrored plastic.

headline: Return to the Elephant Club
text: Caitlin O’Connell-Rodwell, who teaches at the Stanford University School of Medicine, writes from Etosha National Park, Namibia, where she is studying elephant societies.

headline: Tom Zé at Alice Tully Hall
text: The 74-year-old singer-songwriter from São Paulo, Brazil played in New York on Tuesday for the first time in 12 years. Video courtesy Stephanie Berger Photography.

headline: M.T.A., Facing Shortfall, Finds Its Inner Suze Orman
text: As any budget-conscious New Yorker knows, it can be easier to cut back voluntarily on shoes, cocktails and rent than face a sobering conversation with a loved one or financial planner about thrifty living.

headline: Scene City: ‘Entourage’ Farewell
text: The after-party for the final season of “Entourage” was held at the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: U.N. Deadlock on Addressing Climate Shift
text: UNITED NATIONS — The persistent inability of the United Nations to forge international consensus on climate change issues was on display Wednesday, as Security Council members disagreed over whether they should address possible instability provoked by problems like rising sea levels or competition over water resources.

headline: Altidore Is the Cheese
text: Maybe it has been the language barrier: Spanish, Geordie English, Turkish. And now, Jozy Altidore faces the prospect of learning, or trying to learn, yet another European tongue — Dutch (though so many folks there learn English in elementary school).

headline: A First in Long History Of Newport Folk Festival
text: For the first time in its illustrious past the Newport Folk Festival has sold out tickets for its two days of events in advance, partly because of a strong effort to promote the event through social networking sites, organizers said. The festival, which was started in 1959 and became famous in the 1960s during the heyday of protest songs, has sold out before, most recently in 2002, when Bob Dylan returned to perform there after an absence of many years. But in past years people could always get tickets at the gate, even on the last day of the festival, which is held at Fort Adams State Park on Narragansett Bay. This year, all 20,000 tickets were sold in advance. George Wein, the producer who founded the festival with Pete Seeger, said the Internet buzz was only a sign of something deeper: a resurgence of interest in folk music in recent years, as rising bands like Mumford & Sons have racked up hits on pop and rock charts using a folk template. Alongside established headliners like Emmylou Harris, left, and Elvis Costello, above left, the lineup this year includes hot indie-rock groups with folk-inflected styles, like the Decemberists and the Head and the Heart.

headline: Dudes’ Night Out
text: THE life-parodying-Hollywood scene at the “Entourage” premiere reached its self-referential height around the time Andrew Dice Clay lighted a cigarette just off the red carpet. Mr. Clay, who plays himself on the show (that is, an aging comic seeking a comeback), wore a sleeveless leather jacket with “Brooklyn” in rhinestones on the back, blue snakeskin boots and tinted glasses.

headline: Gunbar
text: NEW YORK’S disappearing grunginess is often romanticized, but not every love letter is inked with enough passion. Gunbar, which opened in June, attempts to introduce the aesthetics of shuttered dives like Don Hill’s, CBGB and the Hole to the meatpacking district.

headline: The Flavors of the Moment
text: Trends come and go, but the dress persists.

headline: Hot, Sweaty, Claustrophobic? So Is the Cast
text: Some theater is escapist. “Home/sick,” a new play about the Weather Underground, might instead be called entrapist.

headline: Keeping Cool, Fashionably
text: TRENDS come and go, but the dress persists, secure in its status as a metaphor. Irwin Shaw captured its wispy allure in his classic short story, “The Girls in Their Summer Dresses,” using the dress to conjure a mood of diffuse urban longing.

headline: 10 Questions for Nick Ayers
text: Tim Pawlenty's campaign manager sat down with John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC in Urbandale, Iowa.

headline: Unusual Sounds to Play in a Park
text: The programming at free outdoor summer events often favors standard repertory, but the Washington Square Music Festival veered far off the beaten path with a concert called “The Joy of Unfamiliar Music” on Tuesday evening. A large crowd braved sweltering weather to hear the Festival Chamber Ensemble play works by Berio, Emmanuel Séjourné, Corrado Maria Saglietti and Vincenzo Gambaro.

headline: Claire Cain Miller on tension over Twitter apps; safeguarding voicemail; Intel's 320 Series solid-state drive; news.
text: Is Twitter competing with outside developers who have created apps for it? Bettina Edelstein speaks with Times technology reporter Claire Cain Miller about strains between Twitter and third-party developers. The phone-hacking scandal in Britain may have you wondering about your own cellphone security. J.D. Biersdorfer has info and tips for keeping your voicemail secure. And speed demon Pedro Rafael Rosado takes a look at the Intel 320 Series 160 GB 2.5-inch SSD. The news roundup includes a Google+ iPhone app; William Shatner shaking up Google+; a Reddit founder charged with data theft; Amazon Kindle textbook rentals; and the Toshiba Thrive tablet. J.D.'s tip of the week: making shortcuts for Web apps in Chrome.

headline: Don’t Be Blue: City Unveils Smurfs Week
text: City officials announced on Wednesday that next week would be Smurfs Week in New York City and that the Smurfs had been chosen as this year’s Get More NYC family ambassadors.

headline: Videos of Kinect Hacks in Action
text: Thousands of regular people are using Microsoft Kinect to create music instruments, artworks or other projects, as Peter Wayner writes in Thursday’s newspaper. Below are a few videos showing the types of things that tinkerers are coming up with.

headline: The Best Apps, Although a Thinner Selection, for Windows 7
text: Some people make it a big deal that Apple has 425,000 apps and Android has, by some counts, 250,000.

headline: Electricity Demand Soars in Mid-Atlantic States
text: As millions of air conditioners sucked power, electricity consumption in the mid-Atlantic region soared on Wednesday beyond the level that planners had estimated would be the peak for this year. But grid operators in that region, and in New England and New York, said they were confident they could meet demand during the current heat wave.

headline: Puritan Widow Confronts a Randy, Profane King
text: What is a lone Puritan widow in 1660s England to do when the Restoration government digs up her husband’s body, decapitates him posthumously and puts his head on a pike? If she is a character written by Howard Barker and played by the incomparable Jan Maxwell, she sets off on a journey to collect the pieces, no matter what that trip might do to her.

headline: Time for Sharing the Love and the Record Labels
text: How’s this for noncompetitive collegiality? You would think that John Zorn, the composer and saxophonist who also runs a new-music label, Tzadik, and an East Village performance space, the Stone, would use his small concert hall mainly as a showcase for his own music and for the works his label releases. He does some of that, but Mr. Zorn also regularly offers the Stone to other composers to do with as they please, often for weeks at a time, and they, in turn, present other composers. He also invites record labels that (in theory) compete with his own to offer showcases of their composers and performers.

headline: Tax Bills Imperil Slavery Museum
text: FREDERICKSBURG, Va. — It’s been 10 years since L. Douglas Wilder, the nation’s first elected black governor, unveiled a plan to build the United States National Slavery Museum on 38 acres here. It was to be the only institution of its kind, housed in a soaring glass-and-travertine building and illuminated at night so that cars passing on I-95 could see the full-scale replica of a slave ship in its atrium.

headline: Charles Isherwood on the quick return of "Hair" to Broadway.
text: Charles Isherwood on the quick return of "Hair" to Broadway.

headline: For a Top Player and Coach, Two Hall-of-Fame Addresses
text: Eric Kokish of Canada is this year’s winner of the American Contract Bridge League’s Blackwood Award for long-term service to bridge, which gains him admission to the league’s Hall of Fame. He joins Sami Kehela, Eric Murray and Percy Sheardown as the only people in both the American and Canadian Halls of Fame.

headline: 10 Questions for Nick Ayers
text: Once viewed as the top rival to Mitt Romney for the Republican presidential nomination, former Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota has struggled with lackluster donations, weak poll ratings, a widely criticized debate performance and new home-grown competition from Representative Michele Bachmann, a favorite of the Tea Party movement. Suddenly, those challenges have turned the Ames Straw Poll next month in Iowa into a critical early test for Mr. Pawlenty and Nick Ayers, his 28-year-old campaign manager

headline: Designing a House in Which Every Surface Is Skateable
text: Last year, Francois Perrin, an architect in Los Angeles, was approached with an intriguing proposition. Pierre-André Senizergues, a former professional skateboarder and the owner of a sportswear company, wanted a house in which every surface was skateable.

headline: A House Built on Trust
text: SCHUYLER, Va.

headline: A Cube With a Clever Layout
text: For her $150,000 home outside Charlottesville, Va., Alison Threatt made a descriptive “mind map,” and the architects interpreted from there.

headline: Karim Rashid Recasts the Post-It
text: One might think there is no category of product that Karim Rashid hasn’t been asked to redesign or rethink. After all, he has had more than 3,000 designs in production. But until recently, the Post-it note was an exception.

headline: Sales at Garnet Hill, Ochre and Others
text: Lekker Home is offering 25 percent off all online orders (except sale items) through July 31, with the code “Hot2011” (the Teak Stretch Table 55/87 by Ethnicraft, originally $2,000, is $1,500; a queen-size Oak Azur bed by Ethnicraft, above, regularly $2,300, is $1,725); information: lekkerhome.com.

headline: A Short Film on Living Together, Apart
text: His Chelsea studio was $1,800 a month; her West Village one-bedroom was just $800.

headline: Back Home, via France
text: FOR decades I knew where home was — the farm in Kentucky where I was raised. I was free to roam the world as long as my parents were still there. But now all that is gone, and in place of the family farm I have been going to France.

headline: $22,100 for a Stereo (That’s the Budget Model)
text: It might seem like $22,100 is a fortune to pay for a stereo system, but Steinway Lyngdorf’s S-Series is actually a budget model; the company’s more established Model D starts at $188,000, with two 7-foot, 384-pound speaker towers and a tweeter trimmed in 24-karat gold.

headline: A Half-Century Later, a Wegner Chair Is Reborn
text: Hans J. Wegner’s Oculus chair was designed in 1960, but there were only two prototypes made — one in orange fabric, the other in leather — and the chair was largely forgotten. A half-century later, in 2009, it was rediscovered when Knud Erik Hansen, the owner of the furniture maker Carl Hansen & Son, received an e-mail from the Wegner studio with a picture of the chair from a 1968 magazine.

headline: In Philadelphia, Going Green or Growing Wild?
text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: Playhouse Proud
text: High-end playhouses for children, which can cost as much as $200,000, come in a variety of styles.

headline: Child’s Play, Grown-Up Cash
text: APART from the open bar by the swimming pool, the main attraction at parties held at the Houston home of John Schiller, an oil company executive, and his wife, Kristi, a Playboy model turned blogger, is the $50,000 playhouse the couple had custom-built two years ago for their daughter, Sinclair, now 4.

headline: On Location | East Berlin
text: A woman in Berlin falls in love with an apartment once lived in by the chief architect for East Berlin.

headline: Chiesi's Day in Court
text: July 20, 2011 - Danielle Chiesi, one of the central players in the government's sprawling insider trading investigation, will go to jail.

headline: In Germany, Minimalism and Transparency
text: BERLIN — Long before Eva-Maria Steidel bought the stately apartment that once belonged to the chief architect for East Berlin, Hermann Henselmann, she had fallen in love with the grand boulevard that he helped mastermind. The broad street, Karl-Marx-Allee, which her apartment overlooks, was a kind of East Berlin Champs-Élysées lined with monumental eight-story buildings done in a muscular style of Stalinist architecture known as Socialist Realism. The boulevard is where East Germany’s top-ranking communist officials lived in generous apartments in wedding-cake buildings. After the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, she was determined to live there.

headline: Danielle Chiesi’s Day in Court
text: Danielle Chiesi, one of the central figures in the insider trading investigation into the Galleon Group hedge fund, was sentenced on Wednesday to 30 months in prison. DealBook’s Ben Protess reports from the federal courthouse at 500 Pearl Street in Manhattan.

headline: Who, and Where, Are America’s Composers?
text: I never wanted to be a composer.

headline: Out of Jail, Out of Sight
text: Early reports placed her in Ohio. Then came that sighting in California. But, wait, wasn’t that her back in Florida, running across an airport tarmac with a white cloth over her head?

headline: As U.S. Steps Back, Europe Takes Bigger Role in Mideast Peace Push
text: WASHINGTON — It is a truism of Middle East peacemaking that the United States is the pivotal player — the most credible broker between the Israelis and the Palestinians. But with talks at a standstill, the Obama administration now finds itself on the sidelines, and Europe is emerging as the key diplomatic actor.

headline: Food Crisis in Somalia Is a Famine, U.N. Says
text: MOMBASA, Kenya — The United Nations on Wednesday officially declared Somalia’s food crisis a famine in several parts of the country, with millions of people on the brink of starvation and aid deliveries complicated by the fact that Islamist militants aligned with Al Qaeda control the famine zones.

headline: Zynga Is Hit With Countersuit Over Game Designs
text: Vostu, a Brazilian company whose social games are popular in South America, filed a countersuit against the online gaming giant Zynga on Wednesday, responding to a suit from Zynga claiming that Vostu copied its game designs.

headline: Randstad to Buy SFN for $710 Million
text: Randstad Holding, the global temporary employment services company, said on Wednesday that it would buy the SFN Group for $709.8 million in cash to expand its human resource offerings in the United States.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Twitter’s Developers
text: On this week’s Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein talks to Claire Cain Miller, a Times technology reporter, about tension between Twitter and its third-party developers. Twitter has been buying companies that produce apps for Twitter or developing the apps on its own, which has raised questions about how the company treats competitors.

headline: Yankees Still Toying With Batting Order
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Brett Gardner leads the Yankees in on-base percentage, and he bats eighth or ninth. No one on the team has driven in more runs than Curtis Granderson, who is also tied for the most home runs, and he bats second. That lineup configuration seemed to work for Manager Joe Girardi when he had a full complement of players.

headline: A TV Mayor Is Mulling a Run for the Real Job
text: LOS ANGELES — Like most aspiring actors here, Eric Garcetti has a day job: he is president of the City Council, and he is openly pondering a run for mayor of Los Angeles.

headline: In L.A., Romney Returns to Familiar Script
text: NORTH HOLLYWOOD – With the paint peeling from the rooftops of the shuttered store fronts here, it was not exactly a glamorous backdrop. But it is likely for that reason that Mitt Romney chose this desolate strip mall in the San Fernando Valley, just north of Los Angeles, as the spot to criticize President Obama‘s economic policies.

headline: Social Media History Becomes a New Job Hurdle
text: Companies have long used criminal background checks, credit reports and even searches on Google and LinkedIn to probe the previous lives of prospective employees. Now, some companies are requiring job candidates to also pass a social media background check.

headline: Campus Crusade for Christ Is Renamed
text: Campus Crusade for Christ, a ministry founded by the evangelist Bill Bright, is changing its name because the word “crusade” has negative associations with the bloody Christian conquests of the 11th to 13th centuries. The new name, “Cru,” is already used by many of the group’s members and will go into full circulation in early 2012. When the group was founded in 1951, it was common for American evangelists to refer to their ministries as crusades. But missionaries working internationally say they now find that the term often causes offense, especially to Muslims. Another reason for the name change, according to a spokesman: Much of the work of the group, which has 25,000 missionaries in 191 countries, is no longer only on campuses.

headline: Q&A: Moving the Music to a New Machine
text: Q.

headline: Pennsylvania: Family Loses Decision in Dispute Over Rare Coins
text: The federal government was right to claim 10 rare gold coins worth millions of dollars each from a Philadelphia family in 2004, a jury decided Wednesday. The government had argued that since the mint never officially released the $20 “Double Eagles,” the coins — in the possession of the family of a Philadelphia gold dealer who died 21 years ago — must have been stolen and remained the property of the government. Only one such coin has ever been sold, bringing $7.6 million at auction in 2002. Judge Legrome D. Davis of Federal District Court will further rule on a motion that the government is the rightful owner of the coins. Assistant United States Attorney Jacqueline Romero said that the jurors “understood why it is we’re going after these things, and that there’s a larger principle involved here.” The Langbord family, heirs of the dealer, Israel Switt, are expected to appeal the decision.

headline: Over .500, Pirates Get Back in the Mix
text: PITTSBURGH — For 18 years, baseball teams have known where to shop for help in the pennant race. The Pittsburgh Pirates have finished each of those seasons with a losing record, and by July, things are usually so hopeless that they trade veterans to contenders. The last two World Series winners have each included two players acquired from Pittsburgh for prospects.

headline: Lack of Coordination Hampers Libya’s Rebels
text: While their tactical success has been remarkable, the guerrillas’ efforts have been weakened by poor communication and a dearth of ammunition.

headline: In Bankruptcy Court, Arguments Over Dollars and Sense
text: WILMINGTON, Del. — The Los Angeles Dodgers need a lot of money, that much is clear. At stake during a hearing Wednesday in federal bankruptcy court is who will lend the team $150 million: Major League Baseball or a hedge fund, Highbridge Capital.

headline: Admissions Survey
text: Admissions officers at 123 top graduate schools of education, engineering, psychology and public administration responded to a survey by Kaplan Test Prep. The full report will be released Aug. 1.

headline: Problems With Logistics, Coordination and Rivalries Hamper Libya’s Rebels
text: KIKLA, Libya — Ahmad Harari, a Libyan rebel fighting to overthrow Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, recounted how he was almost killed last week.

headline: Wambach, a Runner-Up, Returns to a Champion’s Welcome
text: ROCHESTER — Abby Wambach came home on Wednesday to a hero’s welcome.

headline: To Nullify Lead, Add a Bunch of Fish Bones
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Alaskan pollock is usually the faux stand-in for crab meat or the main ingredient in fast-food fish sandwiches. But now the flaky fish is moving into a new realm — as part of the solution to one of the nation’s longest-running toxic waste problems.

headline: Teaching Doctors How to Treat Addiction
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Disillusioned Generation
text: To the Editor:

headline: Despite Downgrade, Pluto Adds to Entourage
text: Pluto might not be a planet anymore, according to the definition of planethood adopted by the International Astronomical Union in 2006, but the icy little orb on the edge of the solar system still has a lot going on. On Wednesday, astronomers using the Hubble Space Telescope announced that they had discovered a new moon, only 8 to 21 miles in diameter, circling Pluto.

headline: For Parnell, Speed Comes Second
text: When the Mets right-hander Bobby Parnell entered Tuesday’s game against the St. Louis Cardinals, the bottom of one of the big scoreboards at Citi Field became a focal point. Pitch speeds are posted there, and Parnell soon hit 101 miles an hour with one blurring fastball.

headline: Rare Documents, Digitized
text: To the Editor:

headline: Big Retailers Make Pledge of Stores for ‘Food Deserts’
text: WASHINGTON — Executives from Wal-Mart, Walgreens, SuperValu and other stores joined Michelle Obama at the White House on Wednesday to announce a pledge to open or expand a combined 1,500 stores in communities that have limited access to nutritious food and are designated as “food deserts.”

headline: Why Can’t the (Pick Your Party) Make a Stronger Case?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Apple and Its Cash Hoard
text: Apple’s cash hoard is enormous and growing ever bigger.

headline: Schlecks in Tough Spot: One Can Win; One Must Help
text: MONCALIERI, Italy — Two hours after Stage 17 of the Tour de France concluded Wednesday, 20 miles from the finish in nearby Pinerolo, the brothers Schleck retired to the Idea Hotel here, to plot how to elevate one of them — no one will say who — into first place by Sunday evening.

headline: Egypt Rulers Outline Plan for Elections
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s interim military rulers established a system on Wednesday for what is promised to be the first free and open elections in the country’s history, laying out a complicated plan evidently designed as a compromise between the competing demands of liberal and Islamist groups.

headline: Concussion Treatment Cited in Suit Against N.F.L.
text: A group of 75 retired N.F.L. veterans sued the league in a California court on Tuesday, alleging that N.F.L. teams’ mismanagement of their concussions, and the league’s willful concealment of evidence of the long-term effects of head injuries, led to the players’ current brain damage.

headline: In Surprising Turn, N.F.L. Deal Still Lacks Final Approval
text: ATLANTA — The byzantine, often inscrutable negotiations toward a new N.F.L. labor agreement took another surprising turn on Wednesday when players, with a draft of the settlement in their hands in Washington, gave only a conditional recommendation for approval contingent on the negotiation of a few final terms, according to two people involved in the players’ actions.

headline: Signs of Intelligent Life in Congress
text: The House has been frittering away precious time on ideological games, forcing Congress to miss its Friday deadline for an agreement on raising the debt ceiling. Fortunately, there are signs of adulthood in Washington’s sandbox, and it remains possible that a deal could be reached to prevent the loss of America’s credit standing.

headline: Caution Urged on Raises for State Judges
text: ALBANY — A Cuomo administration official on Wednesday urged a state commission considering whether to increase the pay of New York judges to exercise restraint and “consider the state’s fiscal outlook.”

headline: As Rivals Stir, Romney Sticks to Playing It Safe
text: WASHINGTON — Tim Pawlenty forged ahead on an 18-city tour across Iowa, a dawn-to-dusk schedule of courting voters. Michele Bachmann released a new television ad warning against raising the nation’s debt limit. And Gov. Rick Perry of Texas inched even closer to entering the presidential race, inviting top-shelf donors to Austin.

headline: Wrong Pipeline, Wrong Assessment
text: For the second time in a year, the State Department has issued an environmental impact statement about the proposed Keystone XL pipeline, which would carry diluted bitumen — an acidic crude oil — from the tar sands of northern Alberta to the Texas Gulf Coast. And for the second time in a year, the Environmental Protection Agency has excoriated the State Department for the inadequacy of its assessment.

headline: No U.S. Peril for News Corp., at Least Not Yet
text: News Corporation’s British static could yet hit American airwaves. Phone-hacking and bribery charges already threaten Rupert Murdoch’s hold on pay-TV company British Sky Broadcasting, known as BSkyB. But his ownership of 27 United States Fox Broadcasting stations, home to hit shows like “American Idol,” could also be in jeopardy if the accusations prove true.

headline: In Court, Suggestions of Hacking Beyond The News of the World
text: LONDON — Front pages across Britain featured pictures of Rupert Murdoch apologizing for phone hacking at The News of the World. But further suggestions that the practice spread beyond his newspaper emerged in a small, nondescript courtroom on Wednesday, even as Prime Minister David Cameron broadened an inquiry into the conduct of the British press.

headline: Sound Medical Advice
text: In an encouraging development for women’s health, an advisory panel of leading experts has recommended that all insurers be required to offer contraceptives as well as other preventive services free of charge under the new health care law. The Obama administration seems inclined to follow the advice, which is even better news.

headline: Bronx Charter School Disciplined Over Admissions Methods
text: A South Bronx charter school has been put on probation for what city education officials called “serious violations” of state law mandating random admissions, including possibly testing or interviewing applicants before their enrollment.

headline: The Spirit of the Spacesuit
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Searching for Luxembourg’s Best
text: Quick: Who’s the greatest athlete ever from Luxembourg?

headline: Mets Said To Have Reworked Sale Terms
text: Even amid assertions that negotiations with David Einhorn were moving toward a positive conclusion next month, the Mets reopened discussions recently with at least one other serious bidder for a minority share of the team, according to two people with knowledge of the talks.

headline: So Long, Salon
text: I can picture the kind of New Yorkers who get their hair styled at home. They are involved in the field of infotainment. Their dogs have clothes. They know what ear-candling is. They are not me.

headline: Where Ignorant Armies Clash
text: After months of preparation by both the Union and Confederate governments, more than 80,000 soldiers held strategic positions across northern Virginia during the first weeks of July 1861. The largest army ever fielded by the United States, 35,000 strong and commanded by Brig. Gen. Irvin McDowell, occupied the area around Arlington and Alexandria, just across the Potomac River from Washington (see Map 1). A second Union force of 18,000 men, led by Brig. Gen. Robert Patterson, guarded the lower Shenandoah Valley, near Harpers Ferry.

headline: One Big, Happy Polygamous Family
text: Washington

headline: Lottery Numbers
City Pension Funds Refuse to Release Recipients’ Names
text: New York City officials are keeping secret the names of tens of thousands of retirees who get pensions from the city, a step that breaks with decades of tradition and has outraged advocates of open government.

headline: 2 Dads, 2 Daughters, 1 Big Day
text: Even in a city as diverse as New York and a neighborhood as progressive as the West Village, a little kid knows that having two dads is different. Eight-year-old Maeve certainly did.

headline: Wheeling and Dealing
text: DETROIT — American carmakers and the United Automobile Workers union open contract talks next week with a common task of preserving the comeback of an industry that was on the verge of collapse just two years ago.

headline: AstraZeneca Anticlotting Drug Wins Approval
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday approved Brilinta, a new blood thinner from AstraZeneca that the company hopes can rival Plavix, the No. 2 best-selling drug in the world.

headline: At Comic-Con, a Testing Ground for Toymakers
text: THIS summer’s hottest toys won’t be coming to a toy aisle near you. The only place to get them will be at Comic-Con International in San Diego.

headline: Bonuses for Billionaires
text: The first few times I heard House Republicans talk about our budget mess, I worried that they had plunged off the deep end. But as I kept on listening, a buzzer went off in my mind, and I came to understand how much sense the Tea Party caucus makes.

headline: Split Within Nuclear Regulatory Agency
text: WASHINGTON — A majority of the five-member Nuclear Regulatory Commission is signaling that it wants to move slowly on at least some new recommendations from its staff on how to reduce the chance of a Fukushima-type accident at an American reactor despite calls by its chairman for swift action.

headline: Thursday: Sharp Put-Down
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — You really can’t blame me for the title of today’s post. I usually look for a fun clue to use as a title, and this one was just too perfect to resist.

headline: Bloggingheads: Is Murdochism Bad?
text: Felix Salmon, left, of Reuters and Alex Massie of the Spectator debate Rupert Murdoch's influence on American society.

headline: Lawmakers Say Pakistani Plot Did Not Influence Actions
text: WASHINGTON — Last summer, half a dozen lawmakers met on Capitol Hill with a group of Pakistani-Americans and foreign visitors to discuss long-stalled efforts to negotiate peace in Kashmir, the border region claimed by both Pakistan and India.

headline: Tenant Suit to Oppose New School in Harlem
text: A group of tenants at a public housing development in Harlem said on Wednesday that they planned to sue the city and federal governments over the construction of a charter school on the grounds of the housing project.

headline: Sharpton Appears to Win Anchor Spot on MSNBC
text: After giving a nearly six-month tryout for the Internet talk show host Cenk Uygur, the cable news channel MSNBC is preparing to instead hand its 6 p.m. time slot to the Rev. Al Sharpton.

headline: At Virgin, Raising Revenue Without Raising Hackles
text: Into the summer squall of new phone plans, add the new no-contract plans from Virgin Mobile (owned by Sprint). The carrier is raising the prices of its bottom two tiers of service — to $35 from $25 for the 300-minute-a-month plan and to $45 from $40 for the 1,200-minute plan — but lowering the cost for the unlimited voice plan by $5, to $55. Data remains unlimited in all of the plans. The changes went into effect Wednesday.

headline: Experience Tops Youth as Garcia Halts Rays
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The Tampa Bay Rays continued one of the more amazing streaks in modern baseball Wednesday night, starting a pitcher younger than 30 years old for the 698th consecutive game. Their ability to identify, draft and develop talent has helped them compete in a cutthroat division against the Boston Red Sox and the Yankees, who opted to assemble this year’s rotation through different means.

headline: Promoting Mediation, Not Litigation, in Divorces
text: Elana Katz is director of the Family and Divorce Mediation Program at the Ackerman Institute for the Family in Manhattan, where she is also a senior faculty member, teaching and practicing collaborative divorce coaching. Originally from Peoria, Ill., she received a master’s degree in social work from Hunter College and also has a private practice in psychotherapy and mediation. Ms. Katz, 57, is divorced and lives on the Upper West Side; she has a daughter who is a teacher.

headline: Battle for Libya | July 20, 2011
text: Libyans cared for their wounded near Misurata’s western front line.

headline: Wall St. Makes Fallback Plans for Debt Crisis
text: Lawmakers in Washington are racing to reach a deal to save the country from defaulting on its debt, but on Wall Street, financial players are devising doomsday plans in case the clock runs out.

headline: Scalping Battle Putting ‘Fans’ in the Middle
text: It’s the summer concert season and, as usual, many fans are frustrated that rampant ticket scalping online has made seeing their favorite performer almost as much a frustration as a thrill. But now a new group says it wants to help.

headline: China: Death Toll Increases in Xinjiang
text: The authorities have increased the death toll in a clash on Monday in the restive western border region of Xinjiang, saying now that 18 people died in the violence. The state media reported on Monday that two police officers and two hostages had died in an attack on a police station in the city of Hotan. But state media said Wednesday that 14 others had also died in the attack. Exile groups representing the region’s largest minority, the Uighurs, said that the police had opened fired on unarmed demonstrators. But the state media said that protesters had attacked the station with grenades and explosives. Over the past two years, a series of riots and protests against the country’s majority ethnic group, the Han, has resulted in hundreds of deaths.

headline: Films at NewFest
text: Images from some of the films playing at NewFest, a New York film festival featuring movies with lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender themes.

headline: Italy: Two Setbacks for Belusconi
text: The lower house of Parliament on Wednesday voted to lift the immunity of a lawmaker from Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s People of Liberty party, allowing his arrest on corruption charges. The vote, by a secret ballot, was a blow to Mr. Berlusconi, showing that factions within his center-right coalition had gone against his wishes and voted to allow the arrest of the lawmaker, Alfonso Papa. Prosecutors in Naples have charged Mr. Papa with corruption, including the illegal dissemination of information protected by state secrecy in a complex scandal involving the trading of favors by people who prosecutors say are close to members of Mr. Berlusconi’s cabinet. In another sign of government disarray, Mr. Berlusconi’s coalition lost a vote in Parliament on Wednesday on a plan to resolve a garbage crisis in Naples.

headline: Harrisburg Finds Itself in Uncharted Financial Waters
text: HARRISBURG, Pa. — When officials here rejected a state-sponsored financial recovery plan on Tuesday night, the city was briefly transformed into the Greece of Pennsylvania, with residents taking a stand against fiscal austerity despite the risk to their own economy.

headline: Week Ahead in Film
text: Film

headline: Study Links Male Infertility to a Missing Protein
text: Scientists say they have found a potential cause for a number of otherwise unexplained cases of male infertility: the absence of a protein that coats sperm and allows them to reach an egg more easily.

headline: Canada: 1,800 Lose Citizenship
text: Canada will revoke the Canadian citizenship of 1,800 people who the government believes used fraud to obtain their status. Jason Kenney, the immigration minister, told a news conference on Wednesday that police and immigration investigators had found that most of the people had hired “crooked immigration consultants” to produce fake proof of residency in Canada. There has been a public debate about people who live in troubled parts of the world taking Canadian citizenship as a kind of insurance policy.

headline: France: Reactor Delayed Again
text: France’s main electricity company announced on Wednesday that it had delayed for another two years the completion of a third-generation nuclear power plant in Flamanville, in northern France, citing structural problems, construction accidents and new tests for safety after the Fukushima nuclear accident in Japan. The European pressurized reactor, already delayed, is now expected to be finished in 2016, and the cost for the project is expected to rise to six billion euros. “This delay is linked to both structural and economic reasons,” the company, EDF, said in a statement.

headline: Adm. Noel Gayler, Leader in the Pacific, Dies at 96
text: Retired Adm. Noel Gayler, a highly decorated pilot who in the 1970s served as commander of American forces in the Pacific and director of the National Security Agency, but who was an ardent advocate for nuclear disarmament, died on July 14 in Alexandria, Va. He was 96.

headline: Changes in Grand Central Station
text: A look, before and after, at the renovations of Grand Central Station.

headline: EBay Reports a Sales Gain but an Earnings Slide
text: EBay reported a decline in second-quarter income on Wednesday and forecast lower than anticipated earnings, a sign that its acquisition spree was weighing on profits.

headline: Beltran’s Homer Earns Cheers; Pagan’s Wins Game
text: With a full count and two outs in the fifth inning Wednesday night, Carlos Beltran walloped a pitch from the St. Louis right-hander Kyle McClellan. The ball soared far over the head of right fielder Jon Jay and dropped halfway into the second deck at Citi Field.

headline: Armando Orsini, a New York Restaurateur, Dies at 88
text: Armando Orsini, a New York restaurant owner whose good looks and Continental courtliness defined the atmosphere of dolce vita that made Orsini’s, on West 56th Street, a favorite hangout in the 1960s of movie stars, society people and diners willing to pay dearly to sit near them in velvety darkness, died on July 13 in Asheville, N.C. He was 88.

headline: Brooklyn 8-Year-Old Was Drugged, Then Suffocated, Medical Examiner Says
text: Leiby Kletzky, the 8-year-old boy who was killed last week after being kidnapped as he walked home alone from day camp, was drugged with painkillers and muscle relaxants before he was smothered to death, the city medical examiner’s office announced on Wednesday.

He pitched the last two innings of Wednesday’s 6-5 victory over the Cardinals in 10 innings — his longest outing in more than two years.

headline: Shows in Amsterdam and New York Offer ‘Glimpses’ Into Cities’ Futures
text: What will our cities look like in 30 years? That’s the question posed by joint shows in New York City and Amsterdam, as architecture centers in each city simultaneously display an international collaboration, “Glimpses of New York and Amsterdam in 2040.” The exhibition organizers challenged 10 architecture and design firms to imagine a healthier urban future that includes new waterside cityscapes, neighborhoods and transit systems for both cities. “Glimpses” will remain on view in New York at the Center for Architecture (536 LaGuardia Place; 212-683-0023; www.aiany.org) through Sept. 10, and at the Amsterdam Centre for Architecture/ARCAM (Prins Hendrikkade 600; 31-20-620-4878; www.arcam.nl) through Aug. 13.

headline: Prowling Around Arles for Photos
text: Outtakes by Kathy Ryan, the photography director, from the crowd at the magazine’s photo exhibition in Arles, France, prove two things. One, that there is an eager audience for photography, even in 100-plus-degree weather. (Don’t be fooled by how cool that cathedral interior looks.) Two, that the French really know how to dress for a photo show. Even the kids.

headline: Young New Yorkers on Gay Marriage
text: On Sunday, New York will become the largest state to allow same-sex couples to wed, a move that was approved by the State Senate last month to tearful and raucous applause. For many couples who have been waiting for decades for their union to be legally recognized, it was a joyous victory in a hard-fought battle for the same rights afforded to straight couples.

headline: When Words Get in the Way of Selling a Business
text: I’ve been in love, some might say obsessed, with the written word for as long as I can remember. That’s why, as an undergraduate, I declared my English major as early as I could. At the time I believed that such decisions should be based entirely on what you love to do. I loved to read and write, so it never occurred to me that I would be anything but an English major.

headline: Captivating Films, Complicated Truths
text: AT a time when journalism seems to be consumed in ever smaller bites — OMG! #NoTW! — a welcome and perhaps inevitable opposing tendency has emerged, devoted to the preservation of the long form. Basic information can arrive via tweets and updated blog posts, opinion can be dispensed and harvested across social networks and aggregations sites, but the pleasures and challenges of extended narrative require a different kind of time and space. Several worthy sites (notably longreads.com and longform.org) have popped up to steer the curious and patient readers and tablet wielders toward the kind of fact-based writing that resists the easy takeaway.

headline: Spirits of the South Pole
text: “It’s daft,” a man settled in a Glasgow pub said to me not long ago, talking about the sums that rare Scotch whiskies sometimes fetch at auction — the bottle of Dalmore 64-year-old, for example, that sold last month for nearly $200,000. “If you pay that much, you canna drink it, and wha’s the use a just lookin’ at the bottle?”

headline: Hey, Brooklyn, Where’d You Get Those Muscles?
text: “Captain America: The First Avenger” turns out in the end — and this is really the opposite of a spoiler — to have been a two-hour teaser for another movie. That picture, foreshadowed in the second “Hulk,” the first “Thor” and both “Iron Man” episodes and scheduled to open next May, will be called “The Avengers.” Whether you regard its imminence with resignation, dread or uncontainable glee depends on your standing in the Marvel Universe. Shareholders and die-hard fans no doubt already have the opening date circled on their calendars, and many of the rest of us will probably show up as well, either out of curiosity or solemn duty.

headline: As a River Warms, Hope Beckons
text: In my article in Thursday’s Times about the future of the Nisqually watershed in Washington State, I mention efforts by conservation groups and land trusts across the country to buy up land parcels that are expected to turn into valuable ecological assets someday — marshes or swamplands, for example — as the sea rolls further inland because of global warming.

headline: If It Were Hearst Instead of Murdoch …
text: Rupert Murdoch, who became a force to reckon with in this city when he bought The New York Post 35 years ago, is routinely compared to a news media titan of the past, William Randolph Hearst. Not that “news media” was a term in vogue in Hearst’s heyday, the early decades of the 20th century. “Press baron” was more like it.

headline: Optimism for Digital Plan, But Times Co. Posts Loss

headline: Are Unsellable Homes Holding Back Job Growth?
text: Many economists have argued that the continually deteriorating housing market may be holding workers back from relocating to areas where jobs are more plentiful. If you can’t sell your home in Detroit, where the unemployment rate is 11.6 percent, you’re not able to move to Fargo, where the rate is a mere 3.5 percent. That creates a geographic mismatch in the labor market, and keeps job growth lower than it might otherwise be if workers were more mobile.

headline: Bloomberg and Sierra Club Join Forces to Slow Coal
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York announced on Thursday that his main charitable organization would donate $50 million over four years to the Sierra Club’s campaign to shut down coal plants and move the United States toward cleaner sources of energy.

headline: For Eataly’s Birthday, Dine Around the Store
text: Eataly, the Italian megamarket, will mark its first birthday with lots of products on sale, but also a special event: a dine-around in all its restaurants on Aug. 31. Groups of 40 people will go from restaurant to restaurant in the market, starting with Manzo for a taste of mortadella-stuffed suckling pig, then Le Verdure for a fresh vegetable soup, La Pizza for focaccia with toppings, next La Pasta for spaghetti alla chitarra with sea urchin, then Le Pesce for swordfish “filet mignon,” and finally La Piazza for dessert. Each course, served at communal tables, includes wine. The cost is $180 per person including tax and tip. This extravaganza can be booked  at 45 minute intervals from 5 to 9:30 p.m.

headline: The Campbell Rangers Hit Bull Run
text: John “Captain Jack” Alexander beamed with pride after the First Battle of Bull Run. His south central Virginia cavalry had distinguished itself in its first big fight, and his official report praised his men’s participation in the momentous engagement. “From the commencement of the action in the morning until late in the evening they were under the enemy’s fire,” he wrote. “They remained firm and unshaken, exhibiting an anxiety only to meet the enemy, and awaiting patiently an opportunity to strike an effective blow.”

headline: A Little Less Frenzy at Comic-Con
text: SAN DIEGO— Some things about Comic-Con never change. There are still C-3PO heads for sale. You still have to dodge commuter trains to get inside the convention center. Attendees still don’t appear to have learned about deodorant. But as comic book, science fiction and fantasy fans swarmed downtown San Diego on Wednesday night for the convention’s traditional preview, something new floated in the air — a slight chill, and not just the weather.

headline: Lyrical Message for Syrian Leader: ‘Come on Bashar, Leave’
text: HAMA, Syria — As anthems go, this one is fittingly blunt. “Come on Bashar, leave,” it declares to President Bashar al-Assad. And in the weeks since it was heard in protests in this city, the song has become a symbol of the power of the protesters’ message, the confusion in their ranks and the violence of the government in stopping their dissent.

headline: Theater Talkback: Highlights From a Decade of Watching Shakespeare
text: 5:35 p.m. | Updated  Shakespeare surrounds us this season, perhaps even more than usual. Every summer brings the usual array of Shakespeare productions in parks and outdoor amphitheaters and, in New York at least, parking lots. The fare naturally tends toward the lighter and friskier side of the Shakespeare canon: on any given summer day, somewhere in America, you can see fairies frolicking alongside young lovers in flight from Athens in “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.”

headline: To Train a Teacher
text: A new education school in New York promises to revolutionize teacher prep.

headline: Ed Schools’ Pedagogical Puzzle
text: There will be no courses at the Relay Graduate School of Education, the first standalone college of teacher preparation to open in New York State for nearly 100 years. Instead, there will be some 60 modules, each focused on a different teaching technique. There will be no campus, because it is old-think to believe a building makes a school. Instead, the graduate students will be mentored primarily at the schools where they teach. And there will be no lectures. Direct instruction, as such experiences will be called, should not take place for more than 15 or 20 minutes at a time. After that, students should discuss ideas with one another or reflect on their own.

The German Grand Prix this weekend takes place at the Nurburgring, in Southern Germany, and at a press conference on Thursday there were the six German F1 drivers, more than any other nationality in the series.

headline: Eurofile | Istanbul’s Latest Hot Table
text: Among the world’s great kitchens, Turkish cooking may be more mauled than even Mexican when cooked off its home turf. Nearly every major city in the world has a mediocre kebab stand that is a sad substitute for the brilliantly regional cuisines of Turkey. This is why I always show up in Istanbul with a carefully plotted meal plan — the dearth of really good Turkish restaurants outside of Turkey means there are just so many dishes I don’t want to miss eating again before I go home.

headline: 36 Hours in Aspen
text: It’s entirely possible to go high-adrenaline by day and highbrow culture by night in this Colorado mountain town.

headline: 36 Hours in Aspen, Colo.
text: IT’S an open secret that Aspen isn’t just a glamorous winter resort. As the lineup of private jets at the tiny airport will attest, summer is when the mountain town’s festival scene brings in celebrities of almost every category — the likes of Yo-Yo Ma for the seasonlong Aspen Music Festival, Mario Batali for the Food & Wine Classic and Sandra Day O’Connor for the Ideas Festival. Along with them come classical-music fiends who carry their own scores and Food Network fans who go wild for live knife-skill demos from the stars of “Iron Chef.” Your seatmates on the puddle-jumper from Denver, however, are just as likely to be semi-pro cyclists or whitewater hounds sniffing out the best place to shoot the rapids. They know that summer in Aspen is when nature is in full swing, and the glowing fields of wild blue flax, prairie smoke and sunflowers, framed by snowcapped peaks and groves of aspen, do a fine job of wooing attention away from the glitterati. Not that you have to choose one world over the other. It’s entirely possible to go high-adrenaline by day and highbrow culture by night.

headline: Video of a Syrian Protest Anthem
text: Reporting from the Syrian city of Hama, my colleague Anthony Shadid writes on Thursday about the danger of even singing a popular protest anthem, “Yalla Erhal Ya Bashar,” or “Come on Bashar, Leave,” which calls on President Bashar al-Assad to step down.

headline: Lucian Freud, Figurative Painter Who Redefined Portraiture, Is Dead at 88
text: Lucian Freud, whose stark and revealing paintings of friends and intimates, splayed nude in his studio, recast the art of portraiture and offered a new approach to figurative art, died on Wednesday night at his home in London. He was 88.

headline: A Cool Debut for ‘Awkward’
text: Teen drama, both real and fictional, continues to be a winning formula for MTV. The network’s new scripted comedy series “Awkward” made its debut to strong ratings Tuesday night, following the hit show “Teen Mom,” a reality series whose title needs no explanation. Currently on its third season, “Teen Mom” drew 3.2 million viewers and was the most-watched cable show in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic for the night, a prize it has claimed each week since its season premiere on July 7, according to an analysis of Nielsen ratings data by TV by the Numbers. “Awkward,” which focuses on the teenage life of one Jenna Hamilton (Ashley Rickards), who wants nothing more than to fit in at her high school, picked up slightly more than 1.7 million viewers.

But some automakers are considering how to repurpose the packs to harness whatever utility may remain in their cells.

headline: Shhh! Interest Checking Is Now Available to Small Businesses
text: Thursday marks the one-year anniversary of the date the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform act became law, and it is also the day many of the law’s provisions take effect. Some of those measures are controversial, like new enforcement powers for the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and new limits on the fees banks can charge merchants for debit card transactions. Others have almost entirely escaped noticed. Among the little-discussed changes: a Depression-era ban on paying interest on business checking accounts has finally been retired. And big banks are quickly — and for the most part quietly — adapting.

headline: Egypt Antiquities Department Downgraded
text: Egypt’s antiquities department has been downgraded from a ministry to a cabinet-affiliated office, according to the Los Angeles Times, which cited an Egyptian cabinet spokesman Thursday. The announcement came after a new Cabinet was sworn in that did not include an antiquities minister. Egypt’s antiquities agency had been elevated to a ministry by the former president, Hosni Mubarak, in the last days of his rule; previously it had been under the Ministry of Culture. It still remained unclear, however, who the government intends to appoint to run the office. Last Sunday, officials said the prime minister, Essam Sharaf, planned to replace Zahi Hawass, the longtime antiquities chief, as part of a cabinet reshuffling aimed at appeasing protesters. Since the revolution, Mr. Hawass has come under fire for his ties to the Mubaraks and his financial relationships with American organizations like National Geographic. Mr. Sharaf at first said that he would appoint Abdel Fattah el Banna, a professor at the University of Cairo, as the new minister of antiquities, but he reversed himself after the choice drew protests from archeologists. In the meantime, Mr. Hawass said that Mr. Sharaf had asked him to continue to go to work, according to the Art Newspaper.

headline: Shanley’s Trilogy Finale: The Drama Behind the Drama
text: The writer John Patrick Shanley won a Pulitzer Prize in drama and a Tony Award for best play for “Doubt” in 2005 at his longtime theatrical home, the Manhattan Theater Club, which began producing his work in the mid-1980s. “Doubt” was the first in a trilogy; the second play, “Defiance,” was mounted in 2006 at the club and was popular with audiences (it had a healthy three-month run) but a bit less so with critics.

headline: Penitentiary Restores Prisoner’s Biblical Murals
text: In 1955 a remorseful prisoner at Eastern State Penitentiary in Philadelphia started expressing his newfound Roman Catholic faith on the jailhouse walls. The inmate, Lester Smith, had been convicted of a string of armed robberies. At first, while in his prison cell, he painted portraits of saints. Then the Eastern State staff noticed his talent and invited him to line the Catholic chaplain’s office suite with biblical murals.

headline: Spare Times July 2-28
text: Staten Island Outloud: Bessie Coleman (Saturday) She left a legacy of firsts, but Bessie Coleman, an early-20th-century pilot, is not a household name to many outside the aviation industry. She was the first black American woman to become a pilot, and the first black American, man or woman, to hold an international pilot’s license. (Above, she’s with her Curtiss JN-4 biplane in the 1920s.) Her story will be brought to life in a reading from her biographies on Saturday at 3 p.m., commemorating the 90th anniversary of her first flight. Sponsored by Staten Island OutLoud, the reading came about because a board member who had faced sexism when she sought to learn how to fly had developed an interest in female aviators, said Beth Gorrie, OutLoud’s executive director. Coleman faced both sexism and racism, causing her to study in France. In the United States she became a popular figure, performing stunts at air shows and surviving numerous crashes. But on a flight in 1926 to scout locations for a parachute jump, Coleman, then 34, was in a plane that took an unexpected plunge; not at the controls and not buckled into her seat, she was ejected and fell to her death. Her mechanic, who was flying the plane, also died. Members of the Bessie Coleman Aerospace Legacy, formerly the Bessie Coleman Foundation, are expected to attend the reading; model planes, including a model of Coleman’s biplane, will be flown. Miller Field, 801 New Dorp Lane, at Cedar Grove Avenue, Gateway National Recreation Area, New Dorp, Staten Island, (718) 907-0709; statenislandoutloud.org; free, but spectators should provide their own seating. Aptly, the reading will take place next to some old airplane hangars. (Anne Mancuso)

The actress Sarah Carter wears a mini with cap sleeves, while the starlet Malin Ackerman looks effortless in all white and the model Coco Rocha toughens up a sweetheart silhouette with biker boots. Clearly, we’re not the only ones connecting the dots.

headline: TLC Plans Series On Muslim Families
text: TLC, well known for its reality shows about abnormally big and small families in the heartland, has ordered a series about five Muslim families living in Dearborn, Mich. The series, called “All-American Muslim,” will have its debut in November, the channel said on Thursday. It is notable partly because Muslim-Americans are depicted relatively rarely on American television. “Through these families and their diverse experiences, we will explore how they blend their values and traditions with everyday life in America, providing insight into their culture with care and compassion,” Amy Winter, the general manager of TLC, said in a news release. Those in the series include a woman who is marrying an Irish Catholic man who is converting to Islam, a couple who are having their first child and a police official who works to reduce discrimination in his community.

headline: A Change in the Flight Plan for Next Superman Movie
text: SAN DIEGO— The news moved through Comic-Con like wildfire in a wheat field on Thursday: Warner Brothers is pushing the release of “Man of Steel” back by six months! There must be big problems! The reality, however, may be much less interesting, even if it does mean that fans will need to wait longer than they thought for Warner’s newest Superman flick.

headline: It’s Just Sex. We’re Just Friends. You Know the Rules. Etc., Etc.
text: “Friends With Benefits,” a breezy, speedy and (no kidding) funny comedy with a nicely matched Justin Timberlake and Mila Kunis that is about love and sex in the age of social networking, gets some of its juice and tang partly by trash-talking its own genre. The setup is familiar, as are the essential elements: a single man and a single woman, two battered hearts yet a pair of resilient, eager, pretty bodies. But Ms. Kunis’s character is dark and savvy, not blond and dippy, and when she comically rails against an unseen Katherine Heigl you may sigh with relief (fingers crossed) that you’re watching the “Scream” of romantic comedies.

headline: Move Over, Tequila, It’s Mescal’s Turn to Shine
text: ZUMPAHUACÁN, Mexico —Eyes pop open, mouths contort, a chorus of crisp “ahhs” rings through the room.

headline: Ring-Finger Follies
text: I HAVE had a love-hate relationship with my ring finger for more than half my life. I loved the symbolism that came with wearing a ring, but I hated the assumptions people made about bare ring fingers, especially when so many of us, for so long, have been prevented from being able to legally marry those we love.

headline: Where Do Dwarf-Eating Carp Come From?
text: Tarn Adams was in the carpeted spare bedroom that serves as his work space, trying to avert an apocalyptic outbreak of vampire dwarves. “If they just run wild biting people, half the dwarves in the colony will be infected in no time,” he said, shaking his head. “That would be no fun.” He was silent for a moment. “Maybe they have to bite you three times before you’re infected?”

text: DETROIT — The federal government on Thursday shed the last of its stake in Chrysler, giving majority control of the carmaker to Fiat, the Italian company, while leaving taxpayers $1.3 billion short of recovering the full investment they made two years ago to keep Chrysler from going out of business.

headline: When Sex Is Loneliness Multiplied
text: William Blake said that what men and women require of one another is “the lineaments of Gratified Desire.” Woody Allen said of masturbation, “It’s sex with someone I love.” But nothing is ever as simple as these sages would suggest, a point made with a lot of skin and a measure of wit in “Autoerotic,” Joe Swanberg and Adam Wingard’s collection of four tales of sexual confusion in Chicago.

headline: Her Fans, Squealing, Won’t Hold Their Peace
text: NEWARK — One big set piece for Taylor Swift’s new touring arena show acts out the title song of her 2010 album, “Speak Now.” On Wednesday night at the Prudential Center here, where her four-night run concludes on Sunday, it was a full-scale wedding scene, with a bride whose gown was, per the lyrics, “shaped like a pastry.”

headline: Improvisation, as Well as Intensity
text: These days many performers in classical music speak to audiences to share insights and stories. But it is not often that an artist disavows a performance he has just given.

headline: How to Hide From Annoying People on Google+
text: Google’s new social network, Google+, has been open to new members for only a few weeks, yet an estimated 10 million people have already signed up. This means many Google+ users are already facing a problem they had on Facebook: How do you deal with people who want to be your Google+ buddy if you don’t really like them that much?

headline: Rangel’s Birthday Fund-Raiser Regains Its Popularity
text: It’s been barely half a year since Representative Charles B. Rangel, the long-serving Harlem Democrat and dean of New York’s Congressional delegation, was censured by an overwhelming majority of his House colleagues for failing to pay income taxes and misusing his office to solicit fund-raising donations.

headline: The Night Belongs to Teenage Yearning
text: The teenagers in “The Myth of the American Sleepover,” David Robert Mitchell’s lovely debut feature, are linked in a great chain of liking, which is their euphemism for longing. “Do you smoke?” a boy asks a girl when she hands him a lighter to use on a bug-repellent candle. “No,” she says, “but I used to like a guy who smoked.”

headline: Everyone Meets Stan Lee at the ‘Con’
text: SAN DIEGO — A favorite theme at Comic-Con has always been – what else – Comic-Con. Those who attend count their years of faithful attendance, and love to tell stories about their first visit, their weirdest encounter, or how they met a wife, or an ex-wife, while navigating through a herd of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles at some long-ago “Con.”

The group, B’Tselem, says it was filmed on June 18 at a gasoline station in Beit Ummar, a town in the West Bank.
