headline: David Bowie, the Cool Chameleon From Mars
text: A few years ago the critic Chuck Klosterman, writing about rock music, made an argument of the sort that can really disrupt a dinner party. Mr. Klosterman declared, “Given the choice between hearing a great band and seeing a cool band, I’ll take the latter every single time.” He didn’t add, but he might have, “Discuss.”

headline: A Big Voice and an Awful Lot of Refinement for a Long Island Honky-Tonk
text: DEER PARK, N.Y. — Matty T’s Roadhouse is a tiny Northern outpost of Southern attitude, with signed memorabilia on the wall, a D.J. with a black cowboy hat and a Long Island accent, and a handful of fans testing out their line-dancing moves to Toby Keith songs between acts.

headline: Two Worlds, Not Quite Colliding
text: Images from “Another Earth,” a film that blends drama with science fiction.

headline: Showing Off Eclectic Tastes
text: THE tattoos on the body of the Brazilian rapper Marcelo D2 are more than decorations; they are also a statement of musical purpose and direction. One arm shows the image of the samba singer José Bezerra da Silva above the logo of the hardcore punk band Black Flag, while the face of Jimi Hendrix peeks out from the other. And on his neck is printed the title of John Coltrane’s most influential recording, “A Love Supreme.”

headline: Sorting Through Lending Costs
text: PLENTY of people have ideas about what you should be told when you’re shopping for a mortgage, but for now, that may not be much help.

headline: Sigmund Freud’s Cocaine Years
text: On April 21, 1884, a 28-year-old researcher in the field now called neuroscience sat down at the cluttered desk of his cramped room in Vienna General Hospital and composed a letter to his fiancée, Martha Bernays, telling her of his recent studies: “I have been reading about cocaine, the effective ingredient of coca leaves,” Sigmund Freud wrote, “which some Indian tribes chew in order to make themselves resistant to privation and fatigue.”

headline: Living in a Different World, Searching for a Second Chance
text: At one point in “Another Earth,” a coming-of-adulthood story that improbably blends a plaintive drama with romantic longing and far-out science fiction, a young woman, Rhoda (Brit Marling), apprehensively moves through her old room in her family’s home as if she were a stranger. Once a bright 17-year-old bound for M.I.T., she had taken a calamitous turn while drinking and driving, a detour that sent her to prison. Booze, youth and stupidity led to the accident, as did her distracting long look at a newly discovered planet, the blue marble twin of our own that gives the movie its metaphorically resonant title.

headline: Down South, Where the Stereotypes Bloom
text: This month I had occasion to spend 10 days in rural Alabama, on a lake serving as a weekend redoubt for the swells of Birmingham to the north and Atlanta to the northeast. The local restaurant, elegantly rustic in the manner of a dining spot in Aspen or Jackson Hole, offered a hickory-grilled rib-eye for $38 and an appetizer constructed around heirloom figs. Not far away, the only grocery store in town carried farro, interesting cheeses and a line of artisanal pickles from a fashionable Brooklyn purveyor that I am unable to find at my own neighborhood supermarket in that very borough.

headline: Toronto Exchange Owner to Begin Talks With Maple Group
text: OTTAWA — After abandoning a plan to merge with the London Stock Exchange, the parent of the Toronto Stock Exchange said Thursday that it will begin talks with the investment group that made a hostile bid in May.

headline: A Studio That Doesn’t Smack of a Dorm
text: ZACH LINDER, who had always shared an apartment, had every intention of renting a place of his own. Envisioning a small one-bedroom in a residential Brooklyn neighborhood, he drew up a budget: “$1,400 was my soft ceiling and $1,500 was my hard ceiling,” he said. “I thought I was being pretty reasonable and not tremendously overly neurotic and picky.”

headline: Boogaard’s Brother Could Face Drug Charges
text: MINNEAPOLIS — A brother of Derek Boogaard, the hockey enforcer for the Minnesota Wild and the Rangers who died of a painkiller-and-alcohol overdose in May, faces potential felony narcotics charges in relation to his brother’s death.

headline: Not That Kind of Nose Job
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.

headline: Putting the Park in Park Avenue
text: THE Park Avenue automobile tunnel under Murray Hill used to be pretty hairy, a 1,500-foot-long, two-lane, two-way road with solid walls on each side, not much clearance and cars barreling along at highway speeds.

headline: Connecticut Developers Bank on Young Singles
text: DEVELOPERS are zeroing in on downtown revitalization efforts in Hartford and Bridgeport, where new rentals have proved popular with young singles. In both cities, the market is hot for studios and one-bedrooms — partly, developers say, because this generation of 20-somethings does not like to share.

headline: Blockbuster Growth in the Met’s Attendance
text: Suddenly the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a hot ticket. Nearly 5.7 million people visited the museum in the fiscal year that ended June 30 — the highest number in 40 years and over 400,000 more visitors than in the previous year.

headline: Bygone Era, for Sale in Summit
text: SUMMIT

headline: A New Stage for Old Theaters
text: BEFORE Cyrus Hakakian acquired the Westbury Theater at a bankruptcy auction seven years ago, he never expected to end up in the entertainment business as well as being a landlord. A garment industry entrepreneur, he owns Cyrus Knits, a manufacturer of women’s knit blouses.

headline: From Theorems and Numbers, the Geometry of a Diverse Career
text: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. — “Throughout my life I have been able to see in my mind’s eye the painting I want to paint and the path I need to take to get there,” the artist Dorothea Rockburne has said. At 78, she is having her first full-dress retrospective, “Dorothea Rockburne: In My Mind’s Eye,” at the Parrish Art Museum here.

headline: Central Park Moonlight, Igniting Love for Mimi and Rodolfo
text: “Some opera companies come to the park, and they go, and they come, and they go,” a spokesman for the New York Grand Opera said from the stage of the Naumburg Bandshell in Central Park before the company’s performance of Puccini’s ever-popular “Bohème” there on Wednesday evening. The implication was obvious: at a time when even the mighty Metropolitan Opera has abandoned its longtime custom of presenting free concert performances of operas in the park each summer, the New York Grand Opera has carried on with its staged productions.

headline: Q & A
text: Anonymity vs. Public Voting

headline: Gary Jacob
text: Mr. Jacob, 61, is an executive vice president of the Glenwood Management Corporation, which develops, builds and manages rental apartments, including the Lucerne on the Upper East Side, Barclay Tower in TriBeCa and Emerald Green in Midtown. It recently began construction on its latest building, the Crystal Green. Glenwood was founded in 1961 by Leonard Litwin, the chairman.

headline: Senate Acts to Keep Mueller at F.B.I.
text: The Senate on Thursday set in motion a process to extend the tenure of Robert S. Mueller as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for about two years, after Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, agreed to stop blocking legislation necessary for that effort.

headline: Vampires Meet Auteurs at Fan Fest
text: SAN DIEGO

headline: Many Seek to Revamp Post Office
text: WASHINGTON — Until the deficit negotiations took center stage this summer, several members of Congress had another issue they wanted to focus on: an overhaul of the Postal Service, which is on the brink of insolvency.

headline: Borders to Begin Liquidating on Friday
text: The Borders Group prepared to enter its final chapter — liquidation — on Friday after a federal bankruptcy judge approved its plan to wind down its remaining stores.

headline: TimesCast | Close To A Debt Deal
text: July 21, 2011 - The Obama administration tells Congressional leaders it's closing in on a major budget deal with Republicans.

headline: Emrick, Voice of the N.H.L, Leaves Devils
text: The best local sports announcers are often as well known and as beloved as a team’s players. Think of Vin Scully and the Dodgers. Marv Albert and the Knicks. Mel Allen and the Yankees. Chick Hearn and the Lakers. Mike (Doc) Emrick became that distinctive figure for Devils fans for 21 seasons.

headline: A New ‘Spider-Man’ Suit Debuts to Decidedly Mixed Reviews
text: SAN DIEGO— Hollywood uses Comic-Con to introduce bits of upcoming films to the hardest of the hard-core fans, betting that the resulting frenzy will overflow into the mainstream. The risk is a negative reaction, which sends studios into crisis mode. Even lukewarm clapping can mean months of damage control.

headline: Wearing the Green, in More Ways Than One
text: WOODLAWN’S name is a pretty good example of truth in advertising: forested parks, lots of trees, thickets of greenery around the low stoops of century-old houses. Yet in this quiet corner of the Bronx along the Westchester border, the landscape feature that truly stands out is the bluestone in the sidewalks.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: The summer is filled with free and inexpensive live performances all over the city. Indoor and outdoor. Classic and comedy. Look to the Miser to find the one that’s right for you.

headline: Remember the Rangers? They’re Winning Again
text: In Major League Baseball, some teams’ narratives have an easier time grabbing headlines than others.

headline: R. Kelly Back at Home After Throat Surgery
text: R. Kelly, the rhythm and blues singer, was hospitalized briefly this week and underwent surgery to drain an abcess from one of his tonsils, his spokesman said. It is unclear when the 44-year-old Grammy award winning singer, known for his seductive vocals and lascivious lyrics, would be well enough to perform again. His appearance at a festival in Jamaica this weekend would likely be cancelled, the spokesman, Allan Mayer, said.

headline: After the Space Shuttle
text: The smooth landing of the shuttle Atlantis on Thursday closed an era in America’s human space flight program that had triumphs and tragedies over the past three decades but was long overdue to end. The question now is whether the nation can summon the will to push hard for a far more ambitious set of manned voyages.

headline: House Tour: Claverack, N.Y.
text: This open-plan house uses passive-house techniques to heat and cool the home not with technology, but with purposeful design.

headline: House Tour: Claverack, N.Y.
text: HOW MUCH $595,000. Taxes: $6,000.

headline: Mayor Gives $50 Million to Anti-Coal Campaign
text: WASHINGTON — Expressing frustration with the paralysis at the national and international levels on setting policies to combat climate change, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Thursday that he would donate $50 million to the Sierra Club’s campaign to shut down coal-fired power plants across the United States.

headline: ‘Ostalgia’
text: Images from an exhibition of art from and about Russia and the former Soviet bloc, now on view at the New Museum.

headline: Nose Job
text: Aircraft nose cones are treated as canvases at a gallery in East Hampton.

headline: An Unsatisfying Life
text: For a popular television actor, the leap to film can be dicey. Once the public has warmed to a specific persona, it can fiercely resist any dismantling of the illusion — which is why Steve Carell’s movie characters shrewdly retain the essence of his alter ego from “The Office,” Michael Scott.

headline: A Modernist Who Thrived at the Margins of Painting
text: Talent moves in mysterious ways, often not according to the dictates of the artists who possess it or the art experts who seek to define and categorize it.

headline: A Look at West Indies Cricket
text: For his documentary “Fire in Babylon,” a history of the West Indian dominance of international cricket in the 1970s and ’80s and of the symbolic weight its teams carried in a post-colonial era, Stevan Riley makes use of a variety of beguiling components. There is archival match footage, unfamiliar and exotic to the American viewer. There is an unusually charismatic and authoritative group of talking heads, including former star players like Michael Holding, Gordon Greenidge and Vivian Richards. And there are breaks for cricket songs by reggae and calypso musicians, most notably Lord Short Shirt’s “Vivian Richards,” a lilting, evocative tribute to that legendary batsman.

headline: A Cop Meets Bollywood
text: According to “Singham,” a fists-of-steel throwback of a Bollywood film, India suffers from three things: “pollution, population and corruption.” As for the first two, well, what to do? For corruption, though, the movie has a solution: Bajirao Singham (Ajay Devgn), a superman cop grown in village soil, with bulging muscles and rock-hard morals.

headline: Conversion of Apartments to Rentals for Tourists Is Surging
text: Last year, Pamela Kelley went to her landlord with a business proposition: She would move out of her rent-controlled apartment in the Russian Hill neighborhood of San Francisco if the owner agreed to turn the unit into a vacation rental and pay Ms. Kelley to manage it.

headline: Where Werner Herzog and Pee-Wee Herman Vie for Attention
text: SAN DIEGO — Never mind Stan Lee, the sophisticated star-watchers should keep an eye peeled here for Werner Herzog.

headline: Clogging of Courts Is Expected After Cuts
text: Drastic cutbacks at San Francisco Superior Court could be a boon to the expensive, for-profit dispute resolution industry, as people with the means to do so increasingly decide to pay for their own judge to resolve divorce, child custody and other legal battles.

headline: Tracking the Heat and Humidity
text: A bubble of hot and humid air is sitting over much of the Eastern United States.

headline: Suit Filed Arguing Title IX Uses Quotas
text: A group that advocates for changes to the gender-equity law known as Title IX announced Thursday that it was suing the Department of Education, arguing that the department is violating the Constitution by forcing high schools to use what it claims is a quota system to afford greater opportunities for female athletes.

headline: A Fine Tune To Match Your Entree
text: How does Bob Dylan taste?

headline: ‘Inside Scientology’
text: Introduction: The World's Fastest-Growing Religion

headline: Scientologists, Catholics and More Money Than God
text: We do not need these books to tell us that money and religion make for a poisonous combination. But it is of some interest to see that ancient truth confirmed in both a church as relatively new as Scientology and one as ancient as Roman Catholicism. Even religious leaders develop a certain swagger when they know they are backed by bundles of cash. When a French court fined Scientology nearly a million dollars, one of its officials shrugged that off as “chump change.” And when the Vatican ran a deficit of nearly 2.4 million euros in 2007, an Italian journalist familiar with the church’s finances dismissed the debt as “chopped liver.” Chump change or chopped liver, both churches have bigger sums they can get to and use, and few outsiders are given a look at how they do it. These two books trace the cash source of theological confidence.

headline: Lawsuits and Intrigue Over 3M Diagnostic Test
text: It is a legal scrap with tabloid sensibilities: extortion charges, libel claims, British royalty — and a prominent American protagonist, the 3M Corporation, purveyor of staples like Scotch tape and Post-it notes.

headline: Defending ‘Little Dogs’ but Playing Both Sides
text: When a special interest group tried to defeat Representative Senfronia Thompson’s insurance bill this session with a flier condemning the “nanny state” and showing an infant suckling a woman’s breast, Ms. Thompson could not contain her outrage. In one of her famously impassioned speeches — between threats to bloody noses — she blasted what she called the objectification, disrespect and “violence” toward women, slamming her fist so hard against the lectern that her bracelet shattered.

headline: Carmageddon’s Big Surprise
text: So, they shut down a 10-mile stretch of one of the world’s busiest freeways for repair last weekend, in the nation’s most driver-stressed metropolis, and gave it a scary name — Carmageddon. Predictions were that Los Angeles would look like Mike Huckabee’s arteries before he lost a hundred pounds, and that chaos and road rage would reign under the tired sunlight of the Southland.

headline: Prince Andrew Is Ending His Role as Business Envoy
text: LONDON — Prince Andrew will resign as an ambassador for British businesses abroad, Buckingham Palace said Thursday.

headline: Sharing Patents to Wipe Out AIDS
text: Not since the announcement in 1996 that antiretroviral therapy could effectively control H.I.V. has there been a season of AIDS news as hopeful as this one.  Trials of a new microbicide have brought positive results; ongoing studies of circumcision are showing that it gives strong, lasting, protection; a man has been cured of H.I.V. infection  and new animal and clinical trials are raising hopes that he won’t be alone.

headline: Fewer Perks and More Work for Wall St.’s Summer Interns
text: Wall Street interns have gone from pampered to pummeled.

headline: A.M.D. Turns to Profit From Loss
text: Advanced Micro Devices, a maker of processors for personal computers, reported quarterly profit on Thursday that beat analysts’ estimates, citing orders for a new range of chips.

headline: ‘Haboobs’ Stir Critics in Arizona
text: PHOENIX — The massive dust storms that swept through central Arizona this month have stirred up not just clouds of sand but a debate over what to call them.

headline: Tiger Woods’s Caddie Fires Back
text: Tiger Woods has always demanded loyalty from employees and associates as a prerequisite for continued employment or association. His caddie, Steve Williams, was always the embodiment of the loyal employee, going to whatever lengths he deemed necessary to protect Woods on the golf course and off it.

headline: After Blaze, Sewage Floods City Rivers
text: The rivers that run into New York Harbor will be unfit for recreational activities at least through Sunday because of a catastrophic fire that shut down one of the city’s largest sewage treatment plants, the city’s health department said Thursday.

headline: Debt Ceiling Uncertainty Puts States at Risk
text: The federal debt ceiling debate is already complicating life for state and local governments.

headline: A Turn to Internal Punishments in Ticket-Fixing Cases
text: A former top police union official who is a central figure in an investigation into ticket-fixing pleaded guilty in a Police Department administrative court on Thursday to fixing summonses — “whenever he was asked,” in the words of a department prosecutor.

headline: Time for a Much-Needed Respite at Saratoga’s Summer Meeting
text: These days there is plenty for horsemen and horseplayers to wring their hands over. No genuine stars emerged from this spring’s Triple Crown races, and no older horses have run their way into our consciousness.

headline: The Atlanta School Cheating Scandal
text: To the Editor:

headline: Atlanta Finds Its Identity as Tree Haven Is Threatened
text: ATLANTA — The sprawling canopy of magnolias, water oaks and pines that earned Atlanta the nickname “The City in a Forest” is looking significantly thinner these days.

headline: Farm Thieves Target Grapes, and Even Bees
text: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — Sgt. Walt Reed said he could tell right away that the grapes were stolen. They looked like an ordinary bunch. Except, he said, for the way they were dressed.

headline: M.T.A. Chief Is Resigning to Take a Job in Hong Kong
text: Just two years after being named chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Jay H. Walder announced on Thursday that he was resigning to take over the MTR Corporation, which runs Hong Kong’s sleek subway and commuter rail systems.

headline: Feeling the Heat? It’s Worse in Newark
text: NEWARK — This city has a problem. We’ve all heard about it, even if we give no more than a passing thought to the misfortune of those suffering here.

headline: Con Ed Says It’s Prepared for High Electricity Use
text: After the withering summer last year, officials at Consolidated Edison took solace in the forecast of merely “average” heat this year. But at midday Thursday, those hopes faded as the digital thermometers projected on wall-size screens climbed through the 90s and bolstered the sense that New York City was caught in a serious heat wave.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Pledge of Civility
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Marriage Lottery, City Expects to Meet Demand
text: New York City officials said Thursday that they expected to accommodate every couple who entered a lottery for the chance to wed on Sunday, the first day that same-sex marriage will be permitted in the state.

headline: A Change at the Top Has Jeter Following Gardner in the Yanks’ Lineup
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Derek Jeter is identified as the Yankees’ leadoff hitter, but he has batted second much more often over his career. He returned to that familiar role Thursday night against the Tampa Bay Rays after being dropped to accommodate Brett Gardner, whose .621 on-base percentage since the All-Star break earned him a promotion to the top of the order. Manager Joe Girardi hinted at such a change Wednesday, and on Thursday he suggested that he might maintain that configuration against right-handed pitching.

headline: Memorial Fund for Slain Boy
text: The parents of Leiby Kletzky, the 8-year-old Brooklyn boy who was kidnapped and murdered last week, set up a memorial fund on Thursday and released a statement urging people to give to charity in his memory.

headline: Local Service Airlines
text: To the Editor:

headline: Antitrust Hurdles Seen for Merger of Drug Benefit Managers
text: Two of the nation’s largest pharmacy benefit managers, Express Scripts and Medco Health Solutions, said on Thursday that they wanted to combine forces in a $29.1 billion merger that would account for about four of every 10 prescription claims in the country.

headline: Former Editor in Hacking Case, Found Living in Florida, Says He Will Return to Britain
text: LONDON — A key figure in Britain’s widening phone hacking scandal who had worked as an editor at The News of the World surfaced in Florida on Thursday, saying he was preparing to return to Britain and was talking to the British police.

headline: The Capture of Ambrose Burnside’s Valet
text: The brigade of Col. Ambrose Everett Burnside stumbled into the Union capital early in the morning of July 22, 1861. Foot-sore and exhausted after an all-night retreat following the debacle at Bull Run, the men and officers desperately sought food, then sleep.

headline: After a Deal, Only More Challenges
text: This article is by  Louise Story,   Eric Dash and  Julie Creswell

headline: To Cap, or Not
text: As people do more with their broadband connections — streaming movies, downloading music, moving files to and from the cloud — it might seem natural for Internet service providers to impose data caps on users to manage their networks and deal with congestion.

headline: To Preserve Its Currency Union, Europe Needs a Financial Union
text: If there was one lesson to be learned from the European sovereign debt crisis, it was that monetary union by itself cannot work indefinitely. If Europe really wants to preserve the advantages of the euro currency, it will need far more fiscal and economic integration. Nations will have to give up a significant amount of sovereignty.

headline: European Debt Crisis Timeline
text: Europe’s struggle with hundreds of billions of dollars in debt has rattled global markets, engendered protests and spawned flurries of deal-making.

headline: U.S., Seeking to Reshape Electric Grid, Adopts a Power Line Rule
text: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators laid down principles on Thursday for planning and paying for new power lines, part of a long-term policy effort to help the nation’s electricity grid grow enough to meet the demands of renewable energy and a competitive electricity market.

headline: Another Victory for Political Machines
text: The Internal Revenue Service has abruptly stopped its investigation of whether gift taxes are due from fat-cat donors to nonprofit advocacy groups, which are emerging as increasingly powerful, and stealthy, players in American politics.

headline: Why Is It Called a Wave?
text: Much of the country — and now the Northeast — is in the throes of an excessive heat alert. If a heat wave were a storm, like a blizzard or a hurricane, many people would have taken emergency measures, hunkering down, battening the hatches. But a heat wave comes with cloudless days, creating the illusion that it is merely a little more summer than they counted on.

headline: Me, Michele and Our Migraines
text: Washington

headline: Friday: Hassle-Free Fashion Item
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Have you ever wondered why the same old entries seem to keep popping up in puzzles time and again? Nothing against Brian Eno or Yoko Ono, but how many times can you stand filling in these names? Sometimes you just want to fill in a combination of letters you’ve never written before.

headline: Set Aside That Scythe, and Let’s Put on a Show
text: Lamenting the overwhelming burden of his job in one lush, soaring number after another, the Grim Reaper sings like a dream in the new musical “Death Takes a Holiday.” As played by the handsome British actor Julian Ovenden, he looks pretty slick too, particularly when he dons the guise of a Russian prince to play hooky from his corpse-culling duties and mingle with some swells in a swanky Italian villa. Small wonder that a voyage into the great unknown holds a strange allure for the imperiled heroine of this gorgeously sung but fusty musical, which opened on Thursday night at the Laura Pels Theater in a Roundabout Theater Company production. (Mr. Ovenden, seen in a preview performance, missed opening night because of illness and is expected back by next week.)

headline: TimesCast | Greek Rescue Plan
text: July 21, 2011 - European leaders work  on a short-term solution to Greece's debt problem.

headline: Read My Lips: No New Taxes
text: Washington

headline: F.D.A. Issues Alerts on the Heart Drug Multaq
text: American and European regulators issued safety alerts on Thursday about Multaq, a drug approved two years ago to treat abnormal heart rhythms.

headline: The Grand Bargain Lives!
text: Imagine you’re a member of Congress. You have your own preferred way to reduce debt. If you’re a Democrat, it probably involves protecting Medicare and raising taxes. If you’re a Republican, it probably involves cutting spending, reforming Medicare and keeping taxes low.

headline: Hot, and Getting Hotter
text: A wave of intense heat has enveloped most of the country with 40 states experiencing temperatures in the 90s and above.

headline: Milk Campaign Ended Amid Social Media Firestorm
text: A CAMPAIGN by a milk marketer to address the serious subject of premenstrual syndrome in a humorous fashion — by focusing on how men purportedly suffer from its effects along with women — is being ended early after an outpouring of criticism and comments about the tone of the ads and even a parody on FunnyorDie.com.

headline: The Lesser Depression
text: These are interesting times — and I mean that in the worst way. Right now we’re looking at not one but two looming crises, either of which could produce a global disaster. In the United States, right-wing fanatics in Congress may block a necessary rise in the debt ceiling, potentially wreaking havoc in world financial markets. Meanwhile, if the plan just agreed to by European heads of state fails to calm markets, we could see falling dominoes all across southern Europe — which would also wreak havoc in world financial markets.

headline: Among Victims, an Amish Farmer Quick to Adapt
text: JASPER, N.Y. — For several golden years, Melvin Hershberger lived the Amish dream. He rose early with his wife and brood of children, who now number a dozen, to tend to the family’s goat herd, twice a day milking 70 goats by hand.

headline: Express Scripts’ Bid for Medco Health Carries Risks
text: The $29.1 billion cash and stock offer by Express Scripts for Medco Health Solutions is not just one of the largest deals of the year. It is also a huge antitrust roll of the dice. The combination would create a behemoth in the pharmacy benefits management industry. So much so, it looks like a provocation to trustbusters.

headline: Rays Find Extra Ounce of Offense to Escape Pitching Duel
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — From C. C. Sabathia’s vacation in the Bahamas to James Shields’s sojourn to the All-Star Game in Arizona, there exists plenty of evidence that confirms that they have, in fact, left Yankee Stadium, where on July 10 they engaged in a captivating battle, each pitching a complete game without allowing an earned run. Playing on synthetic turf, not grass, and under a dome, not a bright sky, they reunited for a duel Thursday night at Tropicana Field, and it was as if they had never taken off their uniforms.

headline: The Plans for Reducing the Deficit
text: Lawmakers’ deficit-reduction proposals and the eventual failure of a bipartisan committee created to identify $1.2 trillion in deficit reductions.

headline: Canada: Penalties for Ex-Commander
text: Canada’s former military commander in Afghanistan was fined about $7,400 and given a symbolic reduction in rank after pleading guilty to having had a sexual relationship with a subordinate and for trying to block an investigation of the affair. The former commander, Daniel Ménard, 45, a brigadier general, had his rank reduced to colonel by a military judge in Montreal on Thursday. But because he has retired from the military, he will retain his former rank. General Ménard had the relationship with a female master corporal under his command in Afghanistan.

headline: Soldiering On When the Job Is White Hot
text: WICHITA FALLS, Tex. — The guys who cut the grass at the parks in this north central Texas city, which has endured 30 consecutive days of triple-digit heat, stuff ice packs into their bright orange vests.

headline: Sweating Through Flats and Sharps
text: CHICAGO — When the enormous stage doors roll open for the Grant Park Orchestra’s performance, a rush of hot air surges in among the musicians. The humid heat tends to send the instruments out of tune — and in unhappily assorted directions (the metal instruments’ notes may go sharp even as the woodwinds’ go flat). And there have been moments when Mary Stolper’s flute suddenly seemed to wish, in all the sweat, to “slide right off” her face.

headline: Hot? Back Home, They Call This Balmy
text: WASHINGTON — When Washingtonians, hungry and drooping these days, walk up to Rezwan Jahengir’s kebab truck, they see a man who seems at home in the heat.

headline: Indoor Work, but With Outdoor Temperatures
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Every morning, regardless of the mocking reading on the thermometer, Idris Raoufi bikes through this slow-roasted city on his way to work. And, of late, he arrives in a glistening coat of sweat.

headline: A Perfect Incentive to Get Done Quickly
text: ATLANTA — For Christopher Fanning, the summer heat is motivational.

headline: Treats for the Animals (Including the Humans)
text: BOSTON — The lion was panting. The tigers were gnawing at blood-flavored ice pops. And as the temperature approached 90 on Thursday at the Franklin Park Zoo, Jockamo the anteater was basking in the chilly spray of a garden hose, courtesy of Jeannine Jackle, one of his keepers.

headline: Judge Rules Against Union on City Plan to Close Schools
text: In a defeat for the city’s teachers’ union, a judge ruled on Thursday that the Education Department could proceed with plans to close 22 schools because of poor performance and place 15 charter schools in the buildings of traditional schools in September.

headline: A Settlement Over Katrina Moves Ahead
text: A New Orleans judge gave preliminary approval on Thursday to a settlement that would end a class-action lawsuit against one of the nation’s largest publicly owned health care companies on behalf of people trapped at a hospital after Hurricane Katrina.

headline: NYT: Front Page for 07/22/2011
text: NYT: Front Page for 07/22/2011

headline: TimesCast | July 21, 2011
text: July 21, 2011 - Explosions and a gun attack shake Norway; James Murdoch’s testimony before a Parliamentary committee is under scrutiny; and judges prepare for New York’s first gay weddings.

headline: Proposed Law Would Mandate Jail for Critics of Saudi King
text: A proposed Saudi counterterrorism law that would give the Interior Ministry sweeping powers and mandate jail sentences for criticizing the king would effectively squelch political dissent, human rights advocates said on Thursday.

headline: Word of the Day | impolitic
text: impolitic •\(ˌ)im-ˈpä-lə-ˌtik\• adjective

headline: Taking Aim at a Ritual of Summer
text: A plume of water sprayed high into the air near the intersection of West Augusta Boulevard and North Mozart Street on Wednesday afternoon after adults illegally opened a fire hydrant so children could play in the water as the heat index climbed to 108 degrees.

headline: Beyond the Glow of the Women’s World’s Cup
text: A friend took his family to a soccer-friendly pub so they could watch Sunday’s Women’s World Cup final among true believers in the Beautiful Game.

headline: A Scene From 'The Devil's Double'
text: This scene shows the physical transformation Latif Yahia undertook to become the body double for Uday Hussein.

headline: Sailing in the Heat Waves of a Prehistoric Lake
text: The Bonneville Salt Flats can play tricks on your eyes. Heat waves shimmering off the vast whiteness of salt-crusted earth can make the distant mountains seem to hover like floating islands. Phantom lakes appear and disappear. Objects vanish short of the horizon.

headline: California: Hunger Strike Has Ended, State Says
text: Inmates at Pelican Bay State Prison have ended their hunger strike, which began July 1, the State Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation said Thursday. But a coalition of advocates supporting the hunger strikers said the department’s announcement was premature and accused it of withholding information and underestimating participation in an effort to break the strike.

headline: Senate Acts to Keep Mueller as Director of F.B.I.
text: The Senate set in motion a process on Thursday to extend the tenure of Robert S. Mueller as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for about two years, after Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, agreed to stop blocking legislation necessary for that effort. By a voice vote, the Senate passed a bill that would create a special shortened term for the directorship that would last through 2012, and made an exception to a law that forbids anyone from serving in the position for more than 10 years. The House is expected to pass the bill swiftly. After President Obama signs it into law, he will nominate Mr. Mueller for the shortened term, and the Senate has already agreed to vote on confirming him after just two hours of debate.

headline: Military Reportedly Set on Repeal of ‘Don’t Ask’
text: The Pentagon’s leadership is expected to tell President Obama as early as Friday that the armed forces are now trained and ready to implement a repeal of the military’s ban on openly gay troops, officials disclosed. A repeal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” legislation was signed by Mr. Obama in December, and the Defense Department and the individual military services have been training their personnel in preparation for lifting the ban. But the defense secretary, Leon E. Panetta, and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. Mike Mullen, are required to certify to the president that the military is ready to implement a repeal without jeopardizing national security. The president then must endorse that certification, with a repeal coming into force in 60 days. News that certification was expected Friday was first reported by The Wall Street Journal online.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Standing Out in the Realm of Property Tax Assessments
text: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Duck Hunt
text: The Swamp Witches, a group of half a dozen women, take duck hunting seriously.

headline: ‘Book Doctor’ Opens English-Language Book Store in Berlin
text: If you are in Berlin and love to read, turn to Dialogue Books, a new English-language book store from Sharmaine Lovegrove. At Dialogue (Schonleinstrasse 31; 49-30-627-35111; www.dialoguebooks.org), which opened in May in Berlin’s Kreuzberg neighborhood, you may be greeted by Ms. Lovegrove’s smile and charming British accent. And as her self-proclaimed title of “book doctor” indicates, she’s happy to help you find exactly the book you are looking for.

headline: For Its Future Shape, Ferrari Turns the Reins Over to Design Students

headline: Tip of the Week: Making Shortcuts in Chrome
text: Desktop shortcuts can save time, and the Google Chrome browser includes a feature to quickly create shortcuts for your most frequently used Web sites and apps. To make one for a site or an app in the Chrome window, click the wrench icon in the toolbar, go to the Tools menu and choose the “Create application shortcuts” option. Select where on the computer you want to store the shortcut (like the desktop, Start menu or taskbar) and click the Create button.

headline: Going to Cuba in Luxury
text: Five-star hotels and luxury motor coaches may not be the first things that come to mind when you think of Cuba. But now they can be part of the experience. Abercrombie & Kent, the luxury travel company, is offering trips to Cuba from the United States made possible by President Obama’s loosening of travel restrictions earlier this year.

headline: Pressure on Murdochs Mounts in Hacking Scandal
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said Friday that James Murdoch still had “questions to answer” about the phone hacking scandal swirling around News International, the British arm of the media empire of his father, Rupert Murdoch, a day after the son’s testimony was called into question by two former News International executives.

headline: Leech, Meet Patient (This Won’t Hurt a Bit)
text: A woman in Andrew Plucinski’s office is squealing. “I don’t want to look at it!” She’s lying out on a hospital bed, her legs exposed, an arm thrown over her eyes.

headline: Markets Lend Their Support to Rescue Plan
text: Financial markets, at least one ratings agency and leaders in capitals across Europe on Friday gave cautious to enthusiastic votes of confidence for a sweeping deal to provide Greece with a second bailout.

headline: Chief Nuclear Negotiators From North and South Korea Meet for First Time Since 2008
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The chief nuclear negotiators for South and North Korea met Friday for the first time since 2008, raising cautious hopes that after months of recriminations the countries were inching toward broader talks on ending the North’s nuclear weapons program.

headline: The Jam | Thunder Horse Video

text: Our Summer Reading Contest began July 1, and we announced our first winner on July 11 and our second on July 18. Our next winner, who will come from among these entries, will be announced on July 25.

headline: Friday Reading: Pondering the Reuse of Electric Vehicle Batteries
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Fish Bones to the Rescue
text: The over-the-transom response to my article in Thursday’s paper on the use of fish bones to neutralize toxic lead in residential yards was swift, and worthy of response here.

headline: ‘Hair’ Encore: Three Same-Sex Marriages
text: Three gay couples who have ties to theater will wed on the Broadway stage of the St. James Theater on Monday night after the performance of the musical “Hair,” a day after New York State’s new marriage law takes effect. Among them is the Broadway actress Terri White, who received strong reviews in the 2009 Broadway revival of “Finian’s Rainbow” and will appear in the revival of “Follies” that begins next month.

headline: As Recovery Moves Ahead, G.E. Tops Expectations
text: The re-engineering of General Electric — a strategic overhaul begun in the depths of the financial crisis — remains on track and shows steady progress.

headline: Con Ed Trims Power in Queens and Westchester
text: Consolidated Edison has reduced power to parts of Queens and Westchester County because of electrical problems, but customers should not see any major effect, though they are being urged not to use their air-conditioners as the region girds for the possibility of record-breaking triple-digit temperatures and power demand.

headline: The Class Act in the Crosshairs
text: Congressional budget hawks have turned their attention to the Class Act, the nation’s first government-run long-term care insurance system. The program’s supporters and advocates, including more than 250 organizations representing older adults and people with disabilities, have fretted for some time about its fate, fearing that the Republican-controlled House of Representatives might try to dismantle it before it could take effect next year.

headline: Verizon’s Bet on iPhones Brings a Slow Return
text: When Verizon began selling a version of Apple’s iPhone, analysts and industry experts alike expected that customers, weary of congestion on AT&T’s network, the only carrier then selling the sleek device, would flee to Verizon in droves.

headline: Five Debt Questions in a Swirl of Uncertainty
text: One of the most astounding things about the debt fight consuming Washington is how many questions remain unanswered even for the politicians themselves who are racing against the clock to prevent an economic disaster.

headline: Sink and Swim
text: The night before the men’s 4x100-meter freestyle relay at the 2008 Olympics in Beijing, Cullen Jones was in bed, not sleeping, when Michael Phelps, his megastar teammate, knocked on the door. “Michael’s like, ‘LeBron and all the N.B.A. guys are downstairs, and they want to say hi to us,’ ” Jones recalled. “I’m half asleep. I say, ‘What!?’ This is huge for me. Huge.” A group of N.B.A. players’ calling on a bunch of relay swimmers is equivalent to Obama’s dropping by a state assemblyman’s home. “So I pull on clothes and run downstairs,” Jones, who is 27, told me as he recovered after a practice on the black leather couch in his apartment in Charlotte, N.C. “Le-Bron is talking to Michael, saying: ‘Good luck. Trying to get eight gold medals? That’s crazy.’ And here I come racing in, I’m shaking guys’ hands. Then I hear LeBron go, ‘Wait, you got a brother on the team?’ ”

headline: Stepping Into the Shoes of a Psychopath
text: IT’S hard to conceive of too many narratives in which Saddam Hussein might emerge as a second-tier villain. But in “The Devil’s Double” he is portrayed as a man who at least operated according to his own narrow code of loyalty and warped ethical compass, while his nihilistic son Uday is pure, unchecked evil.

text: 5:35 p.m. | Updated

headline: Conceder In Chief
text: Amanda Marcotte is right: of course the big problem is the craziness of the GOP. That said, I am among those in a state of suppressed rage and panic over the president’s negotiating strategy.

headline: Van Dusen Oregon Diary
text: Caroline Childs Van Dusen’s account of her family’s arduous, six-month journey from Michigan to Oregon in 1841. The Van Dusen’s are among the earliest families to have settled in New York City.

headline: Van Dusen Civil War Diary
text: A transcription of the diary kept by Charles Theron Van Dusen, during the Civil War. The Van Dusens are among the earliest families to have settled in New York City.

headline: Van Dusen Cookbook
text: Pages from the encyclopedic cookbook that Ellen Ann Drew Van Dusen, a Vermont homemaker who married in 1861, consulted in her day. The Van Dusen’s are among the earliest families to have settled in New York City.

text: I keep seeing comments along the lines of “Keynesianism doesn’t work, because liberals keep running deficits even when times are good, and never pay debt down.”

headline: Poly Styrene Pays a Posthumous Tribute to Michael Jackson
text: As far as posthumous tributes go, this one is a double rarity. Before she died in April, Poly Styrene, the leader of the pioneering punk act X-Ray Spex, recorded a song inspired by the death of another seminal performer: Michael Jackson.

headline: Art for T’s Sake
text: For every print edition of T, we ask an artist to reimagine our logo, and that original artwork opens the feature pages of the magazine. We’ve hosted the pyrotechnically inclined, the ephemera-minded, a chocolatier and a fashion designer or two you might have heard of. We’re always surprised and amazed by what comes in, and these stabs of pure visual pleasure have become one of our signatures. (We don’t like to play favorites with our editorial assignments … but this is one of our favorites.) To celebrate our 100th issue, which will be published on Aug. 21, we decided to commission a series of online-only versions.

headline: Huntsman’s Manager Quits Campaign Post
text: WASHINGTON — The manager for Jon M. Huntsman Jr.’s sleepy presidential campaign abruptly stepped down on Thursday as his remaining operatives vowed to quickly reinvigorate his bid for the Republican nomination.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

text: GE Capital has gone from burden to boon.

headline: Earnings Propel Tech, And Subdue Industrials
text: Technology stocks rose while industrial shares were lower on Friday as investors picked through the potential impact of corporate results and government debt deals on the global economy.

headline: Help Us Compile an Alternative David Bowie Playlist
text: In today’s Times, I review Paul Trynka’s new and close-to-definitive biography, “David Bowie: Starman.” Throughout his book, Mr. Trynka, a former editor of the British music magazine Mojo, points to some of Mr. Bowie’s lesser-known great songs. But I wanted a bit more of that. I wish to compile a Bowie playlist that omits the hits — “Heroes,” “Young Americans,” etc. — yet resonates perhaps even more mightily. Let’s call this deep alternate playlist: David Bowie, The Lonely Planet Guide.

headline: At Least 80 Dead in Norway Shooting
text: OSLO — A lone political extremist bombed the government center here on Friday, killing 7 people, the police said, before heading to an island summer camp for young members of the governing Labor Party and killing at least 80 people.

headline: Meet the Van Dusens
text: Members of the Van Dusen family  introduce you to some of the notable ancestors on their branches of the extended family tree.

headline: In Man Vs. Nature, Fox Sides With the Furry Guys
text: SAN DIEGO — “We’re rooting for the apes here,” noted Damon Lindelof, the co-creator of “Lost,” but employed on Thursday as the host of 20th Century Fox’s presentation to the Comic-Con crowd of some upcoming films. Mr. Lindelof, who voiced the usual nostalgia about his visits to Comic-Con back in the old days — that would be the mid-1990s — was referring to the distinctly pro-simian sentiment underlying “Rise of the Planet of the Apes,” which is set to open early next month.

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Investigates 4,400 Lotus Elises for Oil-Cooler Leaks
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating oil-cooler leaks on 4,400 Lotus Elise sports cars from the 2005-6 model years after receiving complaints from owners saying that a tire became coated with oil, causing handling problems.

headline: Going Green in New York: One Co-op’s Story
text: IT was the sight of apartment buildings in New York City belching plumes of black smoke into the sky that spurred Diane Nardone into action.

headline: Plan to Cut Budget of Ethics Office Fails House Vote
text: The plan to slash the budget of the Office of Congressional Ethics failed Friday by a 302-to-102 vote, after House members were forced to go on the record instead of deciding the matter more anonymously by a voice vote. But the proposal still gave critics of the three-year-old office an opportunity to air their grievances on the House floor.

headline: Putting Brooklyn on Historypin’s Map
text: When the digital team at the Brooklyn Museum first looked at the New York images included on Historypin, a social sharing site for old images, something seemed to be missing. Brooklyn. Our colleagues at Lens explain what happened next and how a partnership between the museum and Historypin is already paying historical dividends: “Using New Tools, Mapping Old Brooklyn.”

headline: Times Names David Leonhardt Washington Bureau Chief
text: The New York Times has named David Leonhardt, this year’s Pulitzer Prize winner for commentary and the paper’s Economic Scene columnist, as its next Washington bureau chief.

headline: Riding Alfresco, Motorcyclist Sets Record With 311.94 M.P.H. Run
text: Until recently, going faster than 300 miles per hour on two wheels required stuffing oneself feet-first into a torpedo-shaped, outrigger-equipped streamliner motorcycle.

headline: In Uruguay, Prison Cells as Galleries
text: IN 1811 Uruguay began the long process of winning independence. In this bicentennial year, Montevideo, the capital, has been adding new museums and expanding older ones as the country re-examines art and history.

headline: They’re Called Intensives for a Reason
text: FOR 15-year-old Mikayla Lambert this summer hasn’t been what most girls her age would consider awesome. Instead of sleeping late, she wakes up each morning at 8:30. While her friends might spend their days outside relaxing by a pool, she stays inside for hours. She has a curfew.

headline: Being Gay in Riverdale: Creator of ‘Archie’ Character Gives the Backstory
text: After the news this week that Kevin Keller, the only openly gay resident of Riverdale, the hometown of Archie Andrews, would be getting his own series we asked Dan Parent, who created Kevin, to answer a few questions by e-mail.

headline: Why Writers Belong Behind Bars
text: While researching the Marquis de Sade several years ago, I came across an intriguing biographical tidbit: that crazed French libertine, whose string of luridly violent works gave rise to the term “sadism,” actually began his literary career as a travel writer. In 1775, Sade embarked on a yearlong grand tour of Italy, and wrote an enormous (and enormously tedious) manuscript about the journey entitled “Voyage d’Italie.” The rambling opus, filled with ruminations on Florentine museums and Neapolitan customs, was never completed. Sade’s attention wandered to more carnal pleasures, and in 1777, he was arrested for a long list of unsavory imbroglios, including one that historians call the Little Girls Episode. Sade was thrown into the prison of Vincennes, and would spend most of his remaining life incarcerated. “Voyage d’Italie” soon joined a range of half-finished manuscripts from his youth, scraps of verse and staid dramatic pieces, none of which Sade ever had the discipline to bring to fruition.

headline: Strauss Joins Sibelius’s Vacation
text: HOW, you may ask, does an opera by Richard Strauss find its way into a music festival devoted largely to the world of Jean Sibelius? This great Finnish composer is the focal point of this year’s SummerScape extravaganza now under way at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., and an important operatic novelty is invariably a highlight of the festival. But Sibelius never wrote an opera of any size or substance. To include one by Strauss — even a relative rarity like “Die Liebe der Danae,” which receives what is said to be its first fully staged performance in the New York region on Friday evening — seems a bit of a stretch.

headline: Video and Updates on Attacks in Norway
text: This post was updated throughout the day, as more material became available.

headline: A Friday at the Races in the Eifel Mountains
text: NURBURGRING, Germany – Friday has been a cool day here in more ways than one.  Mark Webber got the better of Fernando Alonso AND his teammate Sebastian Vettel, setting the fastest time of the day in the second practice session this afternoon. And though the temperature is cool, the rain has held off so far.

headline: A Friday at the Races in the Eifel Mountains
text: NURBURGRING, Germany – Friday has been a cool day here in more ways than one.  Mark Webber got the better of Fernando Alonso AND his teammate Sebastian Vettel, setting the fastest time of the day in the second practice session this afternoon. And though the temperature is cool, the rain has held off so far.

headline: King of Virtuosos Is Weary Of His Crown
text: WHEN Marc-André Hamelin gave a piano recital at Le Poisson Rouge in September, he displayed all the hallmarks of a first-rate artist: a stellar technique, poise and probing musicianship. He did so in a program consisting entirely of his own compositions, a rare feat in an era when the composer-pianist is an increasingly endangered species.

headline: Prying Eyes
text: Once women got tired of being cast as helpless victims in crime novels and began running their own investigative agencies, authors had to scramble for other marginalized groups requiring the services of a detective hero. For more than a decade, P. L. Gaus has been writing quietly spellbinding mysteries about one such group, the conservative Old Order Amish of Holmes County, Ohio. Returning to the region in the seventh installment of his series, HARMLESS AS DOVES (Ohio University, $24.95), Gaus offers a sensitive account of the impact on this community when outsiders (that is, the cops) descend to deal with an Amish youth who has confessed to the murder of his fiancée’s older, richer and very persistent admirer.

headline: Up Front: Introducing Geoff Dyer’s New Column
text: Geoff Dyer, the author of uncategorizable books variously related to D. H. Lawrence, jazz, photography and India, has been strongly praised by his British contemporaries. According to Zadie Smith, “his prose is the equal of anyone in the country,” and James Wood refers to his work’s “louche and canny delight.”

headline: An Academic Author’s Unintentional Masterpiece
text: In this column I want to look at a not uncommon way of writing and structuring books. This approach, I will argue, involves the writer announcing at the outset what he or she will be doing in the pages that follow. The default format of academic research papers and textbooks, it serves the dual purpose of enabling the reader to skip to the bits that are of particular interest and — in keeping with the prerogatives of scholarship — preventing an authorial personality from intruding on the material being presented. But what happens when this basically plodding method seeps so deeply into a writer’s makeup as to constitute a stylistic signature, even a kind of ongoing flourish or extravagance?

headline: Now Showing | ‘Talk to Me’
text: “Talk to Me: Design and the Communication between People and Objects,” which opens on July 24 at the Museum of Modern Art, explores the ways in which people and objects communicate through design. In nearly 200 recent and new projects, the exhibition considers the “personalities” that designed objects now have through their interactive relationships with their users. Organized by Paola Antonelli, the senior curator in the museum’s department of architecture and design, and Kate Carmody, a curatorial assistant in the department, the exhibition examines everything from the now-famous MetroCard vending machines in New York to the Bat Billboard, which uses voice-recognition software to translate the calls of bats into messages that are displayed on the screen of the billboard. (The billboard itself also serves a low-tech function — that of housing the bats.)

headline: Inside the List
text: SLEEP, MEMORY: George R. R. Martin, as expected, claims the hardcover fiction throne with “A Dance With Dragons,” the fifth installment in his “Song of Ice and Fire” fantasy series.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE ART OF CRUELTY: A Reckoning,  by Maggie Nelson (Norton, $24.95.) Nelson examines representations of violence in the media, but refreshingly she largely aims her laments high up the cultural ladder — at the fine arts, literature, theater and even poetry.

headline: Paperback Row
text: BIG GIRLS DON’T CRY: The Election That Changed Everything for American Women,  by Rebecca Traister (Free Press, $15.) Traister, who covered the 2008 presidential campaign for Salon, analyzes it from a personal point of view, paying special attention to Hillary Clinton’s polarizing run, Michelle Obama’s potential as a first lady and Sarah Palin’s emergence, which “empowered Republican women eager to claim their share of the feminist legacy.”

headline: Con Ed Restores Full Power to Queens and Westchester
text: Updated, 12:04 p.m. | Consolidated Edison restored full power to about 136,000 customers in Queens and Westchester County by noon Friday, several hours after reducing voltage to more than 100,000 households there overnight.

headline: Tales From the Cubicle
text: The stories in Daniel Orozco’s debut collection convey a sense of workplace alienation that would make Karl Marx cringe. The opening lines of “Orientation,” the first story, place us squarely under the fluorescent lights of comically absurd employment: “Those are the offices and these are the cubicles. That’s my cubicle there, and this is your cubicle. This is your phone. Never answer your phone. Let the Voicemail System answer it. This is your Voicemail System Manual.”

headline: Harold McGee on Coffee and Tea
text: Harold McGee responds to readers’ questions about coffee and tea.

headline: Debt Ceiling Talks Collapse as Boehner Walks Out
text: WASHINGTON — Negotiations over a broad deficit reduction plan collapsed in acrimony on Friday after Speaker John A. Boehner suddenly broke off talks with President Obama, raising the risk of an economy-shaking default.

headline: Economist Q. & A. on Europe’s Debt Accord
text: European leaders reached an accord Thursday to reduce Greece’s debt burden and prevent a collapse of confidence that has threatened to engulf some of the region’s largest economies. Economix has asked three prominent economists to offer their views on the accord and the effects it may have, intended or otherwise, in Europe and the United States. They are:

headline: Several Sizes Too Small
text: In Vogue’s August “age issue,” the editors gush about the style proclivities of the teenage Fanning sisters, Dakota and Elle, who appear in a full-page photograph turned out in puff-sleeved glad rags from Louis Vuitton.

headline: A Picaresque of the Gold Rush
text: It is 1851 in the Oregon Territory, and Charlie and Eli Sisters have been ordered by the Commodore to go to California and kill a man called Hermann Kermit Warm. They ride their horses, Nimble and Tub, and along the way meet “the weeping man” and a dentist, Reginald Watts. These characters and their names, not completely Dickensian, or even Pynchonian, but not exactly commonplace either, are emblematic of Patrick DeWitt’s novel “The Sisters Brothers” — not always serious, not always funny, sometimes derivative of old westerns, sometimes a parody of them.

headline: Turkish Club Seeks to Add Another Star: Kobe Bryant
text: The Turkish basketball club Besiktas has made an offer to Los Angeles Lakers guard Kobe Bryant to play for its team during the N.B.A. lockout and is awaiting an answer from Bryant’s agent, Besiktas Coach Ergin Ataman said Friday.

headline: Heir Apparent at EADS Stirs Controversy With Web Video
text: PARIS — Arnaud Lagardère, the French billionaire who has been widely expected to become the chairman of the European aerospace group EADS next year, became an unwitting Internet sensation this past week after a Belgian magazine released a video of him posing and cuddling with his young, supermodel girlfriend.

headline: Big Deal | Landmark Status Weighed for Barbizon
text: The Barbizon, the 23-story brick building on the corner of 63rd Street and Lexington Avenue, has been reinvented several times over the last century, and the next chapter may be written by the city’s Landmarks Preservation Commission. At a city hearing scheduled for Tuesday, the building is up for consideration as a landmark.

headline: Around the World in One Day
text: “Life in a Day” features montages of ordinary acts from YouTube videos submitted by thousands of people who filmed themselves on July 24, 2010. Watch six clips from the 95-minute documentary.

headline: Overtime in Soccer City
text: On the second Sunday in July, exactly one year after the final game of the 2010 World Cup was played here at Johannesburg’s Soccer City stadium, the cappuccino machine inside the V.I.P. suite was firing up. A bottle of wine cooled in the fridge across the bar. In the stadium’s bathrooms, fresh liners were tucked into the wastebaskets and the soap dispensers were refilled to the brim, as if the 90,000 fans that flooded the venue in 2010 might reappear at any moment. Ephraim Nong, a stadium tour guide, showed me the pitch from the V.I.P. viewing deck. It is maintained religiously, he said: cut three times a week, the grass in shadow artificially sunned using giant lamps hung on wheeled racks.

headline: Around the World in One Day
text: How exactly do you make a documentary about a day in the life of a planet — about how people all over the world eat, sleep, pray, work and even learn to shave? You could start by asking everyone on YouTube to film their daily activities on a specific date; in this case, on July 24, 2010. Then you could ask all those people to send you their raw footage; in this case, 4,500 hours worth.

headline: The Cold Call
text: He wanted to meet inside the men’s restroom in the undergraduate library. I said, “No, outside, by the reference books.” When he asked how he’d know me, I told him I’d be wearing a baseball cap and a Marilyn Monroe T-shirt. I didn’t mention that I was a scrawny 115 pounds or that my face was ravaged by acne. And I didn’t mention that the hair beneath the baseball cap was a newly dyed neon orange.

headline: Cornel West Flunks the President
text: What’s with the black suit, white shirt, black tie outfit you always wear? Do you have anything else in your closet?  I’ve got four black suits that I circulate, and they are my cemetery clothes — my uniform that keeps me ready for battle.

headline: Don’t Ask, Do Tell?
text: A woman I was sleeping with, in an explicitly nonexclusive, “don’t ask, don’t tell” relationship, found a pimple and panicked that she had a sexually transmitted disease. I encouraged her to let a doctor assuage her fears, which he did the next morning, but first she insisted I tell her if I’d slept with anyone else. I had. (Safe sex.) But I worried a “yes” might end the relationship; saying nothing would have been the same as saying yes. So I lied. Was I ethically obligated to respond honestly? NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

headline: A Regulator Scorned
text: I first met Sheila Bair when she worked for Senator Bob Dole on his Senate finance committee staff; Joe Nocera’s article demonstrates what an outstanding public servant she has been as the former head of the F.D.I.C. She will probably hate me for saying this, but President Obama need look no further than Sheila as the successor to Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner.

headline: The Dark Art of ‘Breaking Bad’
text: This is a great program, unique among television series for its implacable moral ambiguities. I don’t blame Walt, then I do, then I don’t. The inscrutable morality in the program is cathartic for me, and it’s a formidable artistic achievement to keep the totally metaphysical conflict going. But I found it curious in David Segal’s article that Vince Gilligan, the show’s creator, said that he could not understand why someone would chose virtue in an absurd universe. The answer to this question is easily taken from Camus’s “Plague” and any number of existentialist texts. I think Gilligan is putting us on. In fact, when the debris from the exploded airplane falls into Walt’s pool, I thought the author’s intention was to tip his hand and justify the need for a social contract. (This scene would have made a good ending for the series.)

headline: The Enthusiast
text: The Enthusiast: Tony Gervino, contributing editor, The New York Times Magazine

headline: ‘Magically Resistant to the Ego-Bloating Properties of Hollywood Life’
text: Harriet Daimler, the protagonist of Iris Owens’s 1973 novel, “After Claude,” has a knack for eviscerating self-satisfied urban types. After rolling her eyes at a slender girl passing a joint (“ ‘I’m wrecked,’ she bragged, as though it took a special talent to get stoned”), Harriet utters a relatable prayer: “Lord, spare me these dimpled darlings who are always congratulating themselves for not having any thoughts or feelings.”

headline: On Green Dread and Agricultural Technology
text: Greenpeace would do well to start picking its shots more carefully.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Tundra Ale, which uses locally grown barley and hops, will be paired with food on Friday, from 6 to 8 p.m. at Jimmy’s No. 43, 43 East Seventh Street (Second Avenue), in the East Village, to benefit Slow Food. Tickets are $25 for Slow Food members and $35 for others.

headline: The Van Dusens Through History
text: An interactive family tree covering 15 generations of the Van Dusen family, among the earliest Europeans to settle in New York City.

headline: After 19 Stages, Tour Comes Down to Dash in Individual Time Trial
text: ALPE d’HUEZ, France — After 2,105 miles and nearly three weeks of racing, through three perilously steep climbs into the Alps, the Tour de France will be decided Saturday in a 26-mile sprint through Grenoble. This is like deciding a marathon with a 100-meter dash.

headline: The Van Dusens of New Amsterdam
text: THE project earned him an easy A.

headline: Janet Reitman's "Inside Scientology" and Adam Ross on His New Story collection, "Ladies and Gentlemen"
text: This week, Janet Reitman discusses her new book, "Inside Scientology"; Adam Ross describes the inspiration for his story collection, "Ladies and Gentlemen"; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Former China Mobile Official Sentenced in Bribery Case
text: SHANGHAI — A former executive at China Mobile, one of this country’s biggest state-owned telecommunications companies, was sentenced to death with a two-year reprieve Friday for accepting bribes, according to Xinhua, the state-run news agency.

headline: You Say Filandia, I Say Freedonia
text: Filandia is a town set high in the mountain slopes of the Cordillera Central range in Colombia. It is not connected with Finland, a European country that is much larger and considerably farther north, and has a different flag.

headline: Bonnie Jo Campbell’s Rural Michigan Gothic
text: Bonnie Jo Campbell’s first novel, “Q Road,” published in 2002, told the story of Rachel Crane, an isolated and determined young woman who lives in meth country outside Kalamazoo, Mich., with her even more eccentric mother, Margo. After Margo shoots a local womanizer who has designs on the under-age Rachel, she disappears, and Rachel, more out of practicality than love, marries the farmer who owns the property where she and her mother have always lived. “Q Road” was widely praised for its authentic rendering of rural Michigan: part dump, part wilderness and part farmland. “Once Upon a River,” Campbell’s second novel, leaves off where “Q Road” began — it is the story of Margo Crane, herself a difficult and willful young woman, who is 15 when the novel opens in the late 1970s.

headline: The Heat Starts Early, Then Breaks a Record
text: The temperature climbed to 104 in New York City — 2 degrees shy of the city’s record — and 108 in Newark, the highest temperature ever recorded there, as a heat wave around the region intensified on Friday afternoon.

headline: Legendary Signals Bigger Ambitions at Comic-Con
text: SAN DIEGO — It is unusual for Hollywood’s smaller production companies to preen at Comic-Con. It’s expensive, for starters, and their business partners — the big movie studios — generally prefer to control the messaging.

headline: Painter and Provocateur, Set in His Ways
text: He was the most interesting man in London, conventional wisdom had it. I don’t think I ever met anyone more remarkable.

headline: 104 Degrees in Central Park and Power Use Set Records
text: Updated, 3:15 p.m. | The mercury reached 104 degrees in Central Park at 2:10 p.m. on Friday, the hottest New York City has been since July 21, 1977, and only two degrees shy of the hottest temperature ever officially recorded in the city, the National Weather Service said.

headline: Fake Apple Stores Get Fake News Video
text: Earlier this week I wrote about a series of fake Apple Stores that have been cropping up in China. They look so real that even the store employees, who wear authentic Apple T-shirts and branded name-tags, believe they work for the real Apple.

headline: Fantasy Football: Breakouts and Sleepers
text: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football draft. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: Gordon S. Wood, Historian of the American Revolution
text: Gordon S. Wood is more than an American historian. He is almost an American institution. Of all the many teachers and writers of history in this Republic, few are held in such high esteem. Part of his reputation rises from his productivity — a stream of books, monographs, articles, lectures and commentary. Now he has added “The Idea of America” (along with a new edition of John Adams’s Revolutionary writings in two volumes for the Library of America series).

headline: Obama / Nixon
text: Bruce Bartlett says what you’re not supposed to say: Obama has governed as a moderate conservative, somewhat to the right of Richard Nixon. The frothing-at-the-mouth comments are an extra bonus.

headline: The Icahn Effect, Motorola Edition
text: Will Motorola Mobility feel the Icahn effect?

headline: Michigan Lawmakers Call Auto Mileage Proposals ‘Overly Aggressive’
text: Michigan’s congressional delegation has warned in a letter to the White House that new automobile fuel economy and emissions standards being drafted by the Obama administration are “not reasonably feasible” given the state of current technology and consumer buying habits.

headline: A World War II Veteran Revisits His Saviors
text: Bobbie Ann Mason’s new novel opens with a little history. A note explains that “during World War II, thousands of Allied aviators crashed or parachuted into Occupied Europe,” and many were helped home by the “escape-and-evasion networks” of the French Resistance. This information is followed by the roster of a flight crew based at Molesworth Airfield in England, home of the 303rd Bomb Group — specifically the men who took one Flying Fortress, the Dirty Lily, on a raid over Frankfurt on Jan. 31, 1944. This squadron did indeed bomb this German city from this airfield, but not on this night. And the names of the crew are fictitious. “The Girl in the Blue Beret” is a work in which the real and the imaginary are joined.

headline: ‘Slow Down and Savor Middle and High School’
text: Dave Marcus, the author of “Acceptance: A Legendary Guidance Counselor Helps Seven Kids Find the Right Colleges — and Find Themselves,” is a reliable source of measured advice on the college admissions process and on the importance of keeping it in the proper perspective. (Regular readers of The Choice know this first-hand from his posts for us, including one last year about a son who marches to the beat of a different educational drummer, which prompted several hundred comments.)

headline: Travels North of the Amazon
text: Have you ever considered visiting the Guianas, that fabled South American realm of gold and sugar, home to, as the British travel writer John Gimlette reports,“head-crushing jaguars, strangling snakes, rivers of stingrays and electric eels,” not to mention giant otters, “half-puppy, half-torpedo,” that snack on piranhas? The region’s tangled green knot of jungle, rock and savannah — now home to the countries of Guyana, Suriname and French Guiana — crouches between Venezuela and Brazil, veined by thousands of turbulent rivers, mulchily recoiling from 900 miles of Atlantic coastline.

headline: N.F.L. Owners’ Vote Puts Pressure on Players
text: In a way, you do have to hand it to the N.F.L owners. Once they set sail on the Good Ship Lockout, they have been all in. Never mind that it was an obvious ploy to fatten their bottom lines, to grab more of the league’s $9 billion in revenue and take advantage of a players union it believed would fold like a $2 umbrella. And now that the players have shown to be more in the $20 umbrella neighborhood, the owners rolled out their latest strategy, ratifying a collective bargaining agreement the players hadn’t agreed to and telling them they’re the ones holding up the season.

headline: From Budget Cuts to Dirty Bombs
text: Washington

headline: Stories of the Unkindness of Strangers
text: In “At the Zoo,” one of the stories in Caitlin Horrocks’s impressively sharp first book, a little boy recalls his grandfather’s interpretation of mouse thoughts: “I’m small! I’m frightened! Oh no! An owl!” The boy thinks, “I’m sorry you’re small and frightened; we are the same.” But quickly, his mind shifts. “Not the same. I am much bigger than you. I could hurt you.” Still in day care, he’s already exhibiting this most Horrocksian trait, “excitement at the capacity for harm.”

headline: Grand Bargains, Pro and Con
text: While we wait (and wait, and wait …) to find out if John Boehner and Barack Obama are about to snatch a significant deal from the jaws of a parliamentary maneuver, I recommend reading Yuval Levin’s powerful case against the sort of larger bargain that I’ve been suggesting conservatives should consider in these negotiations. The problem with the “big” deals that have been floated to date, Levin points out, is that none of them seriously address the long-term growth of Medicare spending: The entitlement reforms being considered, from retirement-age increases to modest means-testing, will generate only extremely modest savings when set against the projected cost explosion in the coming decades. And so it would be a mistake, he argues, for Republicans to make a significant concession on taxes without getting genuine structural reform to Medicare (along the lines of the Ryan plan, or the more centrist Rivlin-Domenici alternative) in return — a policy mistake, because it would concede too much for too little, and a political mistake, because calling something a “grand bargain” would leave the impression that our deficit problem has somehow been dealt with, when in fact this round of negotiations is just the opening act for a much larger and necessarily more controversial process of reform.

headline: Adam Ross’s Unsettling Stories
text: Adam Ross’s first novel, “Mr. Peanut,” which came out last year, showcased blazingly original work by a writer whose influences ranged from Raymond Chandler to Italo Calvino. His second book, a collection of stories, confirms the promise of his first. “Ladies and Gentlemen” is clever in all the right ways, even while paying homage to the most traditional of forms.

headline: Workers Struggle to Repair Damaged Sewage Plant
text: Hundreds of city employees and contractors, including workers from out of state, on Friday were trying to repair a badly damaged sewage treatment plant in Harlem that has discharged millions of gallons of untreated sewage into the Hudson and Harlem Rivers.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: RADIANCE  By Louis B. Jones.  Counterpoint, $24.

headline: Competing to Draw Gay Honeymooners
text: ALL newlyweds need a honeymoon — a fact that has the travel industry salivating.

headline: Striving for Productivity, Chasing Germany
text: IF the economies of the bailed-out countries in the euro zone are ever going to prosper again, they will have to somehow regain competitiveness with Germany, the dominant economy in the zone.

headline: A Trust Surges, Heirs and Taxes in Mind, but Mind the Details
text: JACQUELINE KENNEDY ONASSIS is remembered for many things — as a first lady, a preservationist, a fashion icon. But her legend stands tall in a far more esoteric realm: her will is revered in the world of trusts and estates, too.

headline: Asked & Answered | Helmut Lang
text: Back in 2008, when Helmut Lang installed a busted up disco ball on the floor of the Journal Gallery in Brooklyn, he explained that, in his mind anyway, the piece related to the Janus mythology — looking back and moving forward. “It’s also about transitions and new beginnings, representing time as one half respects the past and the other one looks into the future,” he said. But with his new installation at the Fireplace Project in East Hampton, N.Y., it appears that the past is no longer an issue for the designer who took what turned out to be a permanent hiatus from fashion in 2005 and has been working full time as an artist pretty much ever since. “Make It Hard,” as the show is called, comprises about 20 pillar-like sculptures, which Lang created after he shredded the thousands of pieces that remained in his archive. Sad as it may be to think about all of those wasted moleskin coats, lace and rubber dresses and motocross pants, “Make It Hard” is a poignant realization of Lang’s long-held conviction that fashion and art have become one. On the eve of the opening, Lang talked to The Moment about art, the passage of time and why there will never be another Helmut Lang sample sale ever again.

headline: Appeals Court Rejects S.E.C. Rule on Access to Proxy Materials
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court panel on Friday delivered a sharp rebuke to the Securities and Exchange Commission by throwing out a recently approved regulation that would have made it easier for shareholders to oust corporate directors.
