text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: The Coveter’s Dilemma
text: THIS may surprise you (or not, given the mercury’s recent leaps), but in the United States, the weather disasters that take the biggest toll on human life are not hurricanes, tornadoes, floods or blizzards. They are heat waves: slow, steady and quiet, wreaking havoc under the cover of a cheery blue sky.

headline: General Motors Confirms Diesel-Powered Chevrolet Cruze for 2013
text: Chevrolet has confirmed the North American introduction of a diesel-powered Chevrolet Cruze. In a statement released Friday, the brand said it would add a diesel Cruze variant to the lineup in 2013, ending more than a week of speculation precipitated by an initial report by The Associated Press. The Times reported on the story in last Sunday’s Automobiles section.

headline: Block by Block: West 52nd Street
text: Scenes from along West 52nd Street in Hell's Kitchen include horses at rest, kids and dogs at play and men at work.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: More Vampires
text: It seems not a week goes by without some presence of vampires on the graphic books lists. The manga list has three titles, Volume 5 of Rosario + Vampire: Season Two, about a school filled with creates of the night (bloodsuckers and werewolves), Volume 12 of Vampire Knight (about an academy whose night students are Dracula-wannabes) and Volume 10 of Dance in the Vampire Bund (about a once safe haven for vampires off the coast of Japan). Another variation of these vampire chronicles comes in “Blood Work,” which enters our hardcover list at No. 1 this week. The book is by Kim Harrison, whose “Hollows” novels are about a vampire and a witch who solve crimes. This original graphic novel delves into the early days of their partnership. Could this be the next AMC original series?

headline: This Age of Hicks
text: Matt Yglesias links to a libertarian blogger admitting some self-doubt after the failure of high inflation to materialize as predicted. I would offer a friendly word of caution to Mr. Lee: once he starts admitting the existence of contrary evidence, he’s on the road to becoming another Bruce Bartlett, who has become a moderate Democrat in all but name.

headline: The Grit and Glamour of West 52nd Street
text: AT quitting time one recent Wednesday just before the afternoon commuter rush, the clip-clop of hooves came lazily up the West Side Highway. Without direction from his driver, the carriage horse turned right on West 52nd Street. He was heading back to the barn.

headline: Tuition Refunds, but Not Quite on Equal Terms
text: Sallie Mae wants to be a cradle-to-grave resource, helping parents save for their children’s college educations until they’re 18, then lending students money for tuition, helping them save for their own children’s bills and so on until they’re great-grandparents.

text: The Bureau of Labor Statistics has produced the following chart showing weekly earnings by ethnic group and education, broken down into quartiles. It provides yet another excuse to talk about why college is worth it:

text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I write about Sallie Mae’s entry into the world of tuition refund insurance. Parents buy these policies in case their child needs to withdraw from college (or private nursery, primary or secondary school) for medical reasons sometime during the school year.

headline: ‘The Girl in the Blue Beret’
Heads Up, Phones Down: Avoiding the Battle-Axe at Comic-Con
text: SAN DIEGO — As the costumed Comic-Con thousands did their Zombie Shuffle past the convention center here on Friday morning, shockingly few — maybe one in 100 — were gazing down into the glow of a smartphone. That hasn’t been true on the streets of New York, or Los Angeles, or almost anywhere else with decent network service of late.

headline: Worldly Influences On a Young Artist
text: Zach Condon is growing up. Or trying to, anyway. At 25, Mr. Condon, better known as the songwriter behind the indie folk band Beirut, is already a music veteran, having arrived as a multi-instrumentalist teenager versed in global sounds: Balkan beats, French chanson, Mexican funeral. For Beirut’s third full-length album, “The Rip Tide,” out Aug. 30 from Pompeii Records/Revolver, he wanted to hone his influences.

But because hybrid mechanicals are often bundled with upscale features, the difference can amount to many thousands of dollars.

headline: Surfing and ‘Roughing It’ on Southern California Beaches
text: THE freeway was dark. Wisps of sea mist obscured the moon. At 2 a.m. there wasn’t another car on Highway 101, the southern extension of the Pacific Coast Highway that traces the edge of the continent from Orange County in California almost to the Oregon border. On the left side of the road as I drove south, miles of tract housing reached into the hills. Somewhere on the right, between the guardrail and the great void of the Pacific, was the entrance to the San Elijo campground.

text: THE UPSHOT

headline: After Gay Marriage, the Check-In Dance
text: NEW YORK’s first gay newlyweds are about to engage in a time-honored ritual: the honeymoon. So it's no surprise that hotels eager for the anticipated influx of business in the wake of last month’s hard-won marriage equality legislation are getting ready. But for those of us who routinely travel with our same-sex partners (legal or otherwise), the law, which goes into effect today, won’t automatically eradicate awkward moments on those occasions when you’d hope to be treated just like every other married couple.

headline: The Arts Take Root in Portugal’s ‘Cradle City’
text: THE earthy appeal of Guimarães, Portugal, was plentifully evident during a recent visit to Adega dos Caquinhos, a small, family-run restaurant in the city center. Profanity, served up in the warm, open-throated intonations of this region of northern Portugal, is as much a part of the menu as the veal chop or tripe stew. The matronly but sharp-tongued owner, Augusta Ribeiro, routinely dresses down customers for refusing wine, and once, I was told, she called a man impotent for asking for hot sauce. When I stopped in for lunch with Rui Torrinha, a local cultural organizer, it wasn’t long before he was being harangued for his vegetarianism.

headline: Restaurant Report: Hong Kong Capital Café
text: No one comes to Hong Kong for eggs and French toast. But one of the most memorable Hong Kong experiences is dining at a bing sutt (literally, “ice room”), a traditional cafe that serves Western-style breakfast dishes and drinks all day.

headline: A Bilbao on Siberia’s Edge?
text: I WAS wandering though a dozen curtained-off video galleries on the second floor of one of Russia’s newest cultural hot spots, the Perm Museum of Modern Art (Permm), watching provocative art videos by a Siberian performance group named Blue Noses, when I came across a plain cardboard box. Peering inside, I was startled to see a film loop projected from the ceiling of one of the Blue Noses dressed as Lenin manically twitching in his coffin.

headline: A Tour of California’s Surfing Beaches
text: The network of state beaches and campgrounds is one of the largest in the country and covers a third of California’s 840-mile coast.

text: This former fishing village on the Aegean offers shoppers everything from gems to carpets to curios.

text: Sales of the books in George R. R. Martin’s “Song of Ice and Fire” series have soared since April, when HBO started running a television series based on them.

headline: Zahi Hawass Discusses His Departure
text: Zahi Hawass, whose departure as Egypt’s minister of antiquities was announced in a cabinet reshuffle this week, said in an e-mail Friday that, while he continues to supervise the agency while his replacement is found, he will not be staying on for more than a few days “to help with the transition.” Mr. Hawass said, “I am retiring to focus on my own work, as a scholar and a writer,” adding he is looking forward to “living quietly as a private person, away from politics.” On Thursday, the Egyptian government said it is downgrading the antiquities department from a ministry to an office reporting to the prime minister, reversing a decision by former president Hosni Mubarak in the last days of his rule to elevate its status. It is still not clear who will run the office, which will again be known as the Supreme Council of Antiquities. Mr. Hawass was pushed out, along with several other cabinet members, as part of an effort by Prime Minister Essam Sharaf to appease protesters who had returned to Tahrir Square to demand further changes in the government.

headline: How to Survive a 103-Degree Weekend
text: The weather station in Central Park is currently reporting temperatures of 103 degrees. If you’re in the city this weekend, it’s time to get strategic about your eating options.

headline: The Grad Life
text: Students take a graphic snapshot of their experiences.

headline: Getting on the T.A. Track
text: A teaching assistantship is, at heart, merit-based financial aid, and an apprenticeship in instruction for the ivory-tower bound. They are awarded, like admission to a program itself, based on academic promise.

headline: Answers
text: Multi-Source Reasoning:

headline: Tips on Turning Back the Clock
text: The decision on how much money, and time, to spend prepping for an admissions test is personal. Buy books or CDs or DVDs; take full courses or short refresher classes; browse the Web (where I found an enlightening video on how to solve probability problems). But all agree: older applicants need to give themselves enough time to study and drill. “This is not a test you can cram for,” says Lee Weiss, the director of graduate programs for Kaplan Test Prep.

headline: A New Business Worldview
text: The Master of Business Administration began as a distinctly American creation, developed in response to the galloping industrial growth of the late 19th century and the new American phenomena to which it gave rise: the modern corporation, scientific marketing, mass advertising, investment banking. The professional manager was born and, to train him, the world’s first graduate school of management — at Dartmouth, in 1900. Eight years later, Harvard began offering what it claims was the world’s first M.B.A. And for the next century, the American academy was the uncontested capital of practical business education.

headline: A Little Rusty?
text: On the first day of test prep, after we had tackled a mini-G.R.E., the instructor assured our class that though she was 30 years old, she was still up on the latest test-taking trends. Finally, I thought, a problem I could easily solve. Answer: the last math class I had taken was three years before she was born.

headline: Betting on an E.M.B.A.
text: To make class, Valeri Cordón gets up at 5:30 a.m. on a Thursday to catch a flight from Costa Rica to Boston. At 8:30 a.m. Friday, he’s in his seat at Building E62 of the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management in Cambridge, where he will pretty much stay put for two intensive days of business education. Sunday morning — 72 hours after leaving home — he flies back to his wife and three children, usually through Miami, Atlanta or Dallas.

headline: Looking Ahead Behind the Ivy
text: The pace of change in business is quickening, and business schools are scrambling to keep up. A number of prominent B-schools, the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and Harvard Business School among them, have rethought their programs and are making changes to reflect the increasingly global scope of business and to improve students’ leadership and teamwork skills. Some schools are asking students to wrestle with questions about the ethical lapses that contributed to the financial crisis. Nitin Nohria, new dean of Harvard Business School and co-author of “Paths to Power: How Insiders and Outsiders Shaped American Business Leadership,” discussed the new courses, and the goals and thinking behind them.

headline: The Joke Is on the Ph.D.
text: Jorge Cham's comics started out as just another way for a grad student — himself — to procrastinate. Now he’s helping millions of others do the same.

headline: The Left-Leaning Tower
text: Why are conservatives such a minority at so many graduate schools? Conservatives like to blame liberal bias. Liberals like other explanations.

headline: Dissing the Doctorate
text: Adam J. Ruben spent seven years working on a Ph.D. in molecular biology at Johns Hopkins. On the side, he performed at open mikes and wrote a book that didn’t count toward his publish-or-perish count. “Surviving Your Stupid, Stupid Decision to Go to Grad School” was published by Broadway Books last year. Now Dr. Ruben teaches an undergraduate class on the stand-up comic in society at Johns Hopkins, when he’s not at his day job at Sanaria, working on a vaccine for malaria. Another hobby: rapping.

headline: A Two-for-One Deal: Bachelor’s Plus Master’s
text: Do you want a master’s with that bachelor’s? Think of it as adding fries and a Coke for an Extra Value Meal.

headline: Citations to Avoid
text: In thesis writing or application essays, impressive citations are important. Here are a few to leave out:

headline: The Critter People
text: Beyond the noisy throngs marveling at the dinosaurs, the dioramas and the immense blue whale, up on the fifth floor where visitors are not allowed, the American Museum of Natural History takes on an entirely different character.

headline: R.O.I.
text: Graduate school has long been a recession hideout, a place to add new skills and credentials that, presumably, increase job opportunities and salary in a market recovered by graduation. A year after 2008’s economic meltdown, applications to graduate school rose more than 8 percent. Last year, as the country hobbled toward recovery (or not), 27 percent of college seniors said they planned to attend immediately after graduation, up from 21 percent in 2007, according to the National Association of Colleges and Employers.

headline: The Essential T.A.
text: Jason G. Ball was thrilled when he was accepted two years ago at the University of California, Los Angeles, and could pursue a Ph.D. in political science. He was so thrilled, he enrolled without any assurance of a teaching assistantship or other financial support.

headline: GMAT Makeover
text: Anyone contemplating business school wants to know whether to take the GMAT now or wait until next June, when the integrated reasoning section is introduced. First, ask yourself this: Does an Excel file give you pause? The new section is what came of a 2009 survey of 740 faculty members, who were asked what the GMAT should measure that it didn’t. The section will replace one of two essays, and is heavy on data interpretation. “As the business environment changes, the business curriculum changes,” explains Ashok Sarathy, vice president for the Graduate Management Admission Council, which administers the test. What doesn’t change: total test time (at three and a half hours) and the verbal and quantitative sections. Try your hand at this preview, which GMAC created for Education Life. There are four new question types: multi-source reasoning, graphics interpretation, two-part analysis and sorting tables.

headline: How to Talk to Real People
text: Recognizing that scientists can be really, really hard to understand, Emory last semester introduced “Communicating Science” to teach grad students to write for and talk to laypeople. Students create presentations, blog and compose “elevator speeches” addressing various scenarios (see below).

headline: The Master’s as the New Bachelor’s
text: William Klein’s story may sound familiar to his fellow graduates. After earning his bachelor’s in history from the College at Brockport, he found himself living in his parents’ Buffalo home, working the same $7.25-an-hour waiter job he had in high school.

headline: Paying for an M.B.A.
text: Getting an executive M.B.A. can be onerous, both logistically and financially. While there are some scholarships, many students rely on loans.

headline: The Art of Community Engagement
text: Traditionally, a Master of Fine Arts program is studio-centric: students work in a single medium, putting together a unified body of work and attempting to become better artists. But today's M.F.A. programs have taken to challenging the conventional mold. One of the more popular alternatives is community art, in which students are encouraged to create work with larger public outreach.

headline: On Their Children’s Schools, Politicians Should Save the Outrage
text: If you’re a politician who has all kinds of things to say about public education, do voters have the right to know where you send your children to school?

headline: Univision Triumphs on a Barren Night of Broadcast TV
text: A relatively barren television landscape on Thursday night — with the big four networks running either comedy repeats or reality shows — allowed the Spanish-language Univision to score a ratings victory in the category advertiser-coveted demographic of 18- to 49-year-olds with its 8th Annual Youth Awards show, “Premios Juventud.” The three-hour ceremony, which featured performances from Ricky Martin and Pitbull, averaged 4.1 million total viewers. The winners were determined by online vote at univision.com. CBS had the most total viewers on the night thanks to a live eviction episode of “Big Brother” (6.7 million viewers). “Love Bites,” the sole NBC series not in repeats, fell to just under 1.8 million viewers for its (unplanned) final episode. The show was canceled earlier this week.

headline: Settlement Ends Bitter Infighting at a Fraternity
text: A century-old fraternity that was recently embroiled in internal strife between the national executives and members of several local chapters has reached a resolution to end the bitter infighting.

headline: Golf Country

On Thursday, it vowed to become the country’s biggest host for public electric vehicle charging stations by the end of the year. In total, stores will have about 800 chargers.

headline: Survivor of Attack Leads Nuclear Effort in Iran

headline: The Minimalist: Fast Blueberry Jam
text: If you’re a gardener, a farmers’ market enthusiast, or a member of a community-supported agriculture group, there will probably come a point in the summer when you will find yourself overwhelmed with fresh berries, which seem like a ticking time bomb as they begin to soften and rot. When that point comes, don’t think — just make jam.

headline: Obama Should Raise the Debt Ceiling on His Own
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA should announce that he will raise the debt ceiling unilaterally if he cannot reach a deal with Congress. Constitutionally, he would be on solid ground. Politically, he can’t lose. The public wants a deal. The threat to act unilaterally will only strengthen his bargaining power if Republicans don’t want to be frozen out; if they defy him, the public will throw their support to the president. Either way, Republicans look like the obstructionists and will pay a price.

headline: Creating Uncommon Vibes
text: OVER the last year I thought a lot about two albums by young jazz musicians: “Sun Rooms,” by Jason Adasiewicz, and “Waking Dreams,” by Chris Dingman. Both are vibraphonists, Mr. Adasiewicz from Chicago, Mr. Dingman from New York. They’re both seekers, both invading the space between free improvisation and the consensual mainstream jazz language, both suggesting changes of style and even function in their instrument. ... Hold on. What? They’re both vibraphonists?

headline: Some Professors Are Promoting More Industry Ties
text: A group of medical professors and researchers who take industry money — and are really proud of it — met in New York on Friday to sketch out plans to fight back against the opposition to conflicts of interest in medicine.

headline: Star Party Planner Is at the Ready
text: IN late 2008, Susan Holland met the Tony-winning Broadway producer Hal Luftig and his longtime partner, Stewart Adelson, a psychiatrist, at their Chelsea loft to discuss the wedding reception the two were planning for the coming spring.

headline: The Lincoln MKZ Hybrid Has a Trick Eyeball
text: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif. — In a mall parking lot here, I was trying to back a new Lincoln MKZ Hybrid, which I review in Sunday’s Automobiles section, out of a spot. Two huge S.U.V.’s were parked on either side of me, blocking my field of view of oncoming vehicles. Backing slowly, an alarm suddenly warned me of approaching cross traffic. The alert saved me from a collision with a careless, speeding driver.

headline: The Sovereign Debt Crises; Hulu and TV’s Future; the Status of Gold
text: This week: Jeff Sommer with Floyd Norris on the sovereign debt crises, David Gillen and Brian Stelter on Hulu and TV’s future, and Robert Shiller on taxing and spending. Also, Mr. Sommer on the status of gold.

headline: A Cobbler That Gives Fruit Real Support

headline: Gay and Married with Children
text: Among the 823 couples who plan to marry in New York City on Sunday are many with children. Odds are they have filled out a lot of legal documents already — to adopt and provide health care for their children, to establish guardianship, to smooth inheritance. What does this additional legal step mean, or not, when you have been raising children together for years, even decades?

headline: Fête Accompli | Soirée From Outer Space
text: Organizers of the annual Prospect Park Summer Soirée could not have picked a better night to throw a retro space-themed party. The landing of the Atlantis early Thursday morning, which marked the end of NASA’s shuttle program, and by extension, the end of an era in space exploration, had everyone thinking about starships and galaxies. If entering the event’s space, a charming 1905 Beaux Arts-style boathouse, to music from “2001: A Space Odyssey” felt a bit kitschy, well, so was the ’70s space-age-inspired look that prompted the party. Call it cosmic, but it worked.

headline: A Wedding? Oh, Yes, We Did That, Too
text: MY parents, Betty and Terry Doonan, met in a Royal Air Force soup kitchen at the end of World War II. They had both run away from home a few years prior and were disinclined to return to their respective birthplaces.

headline: Salt and Sweat, Blood and Guts, but No Girls!
text: “DEADLIEST CATCH” has masculine mystique.

headline: Seeking a Place to Settle, Without Being Too Settled
text: WHEN Mary McBride met Leslie Klotz at a Christmas party in 2005, Ms. McBride was 37 and living in Brooklyn in an unrenovated and mostly unfurnished loft. She had a picnic table, a bed, a guitar, some blue jeans and an enormous poster of Dolly Parton on the wall. That was enough.

headline: Ludovic Lefebvre Hopes to Open in New York as Early as Fall
text: Ludovic Lefebvre, whose LudoBites is the most acclaimed rootless restaurant in Los Angeles, has told the Feast that he is hoping to open a place in New York as early as November. He said he and his wife, Kristine, have looked throughout the city.

headline: A Great Way to Eat Your Fruit
text: This brown butter cake is a happy landing pad for almost any summer fruit. Try it with apricots, sweet cherries, berries (a mix would be perfect) or plums. As long as the fruit is juicy and soft, it will work. The juicy factor, however, does rule out apples and most pears unless you poach or sauté them first — a good thing to keep in mind if you’re saving this recipe for fall.

headline: It’s Soooo Cold/Hot. I Can’t Wait for Summer/Winter!
text: Just remember: 182 days ago, you were cursing the cold and praying for summer. O.K., maybe you were having fun building a snowman and wishing every day could be a winter wonderland. In any case, this too shall pass.

headline: Getting Interactive at Comic-Con With ‘Conan the Barbarian’
text: SAN DIEGO— Patience is often in short supply on Comic-Con’s trade show floor, where lines of fans waiting to get an autograph or check out a particular booth snake through the already gridlocked aisles. Lionsgate, the studio that “Saw” built, is normally one of the biggest line generators, because it loads its exhibit area with technology. Last year, for instance, the studio invited attendees to make videos of themselves trapped inside a coffin; Lionsgate then emailed them the result to share with their friends online. The stunt promoted “Buried,” a thriller starring Ryan Reynolds, and it was a huge Comic-Con hit (although it didn’t pay off in box office success).

headline: Alfresco Surprises to Go With Mendelssohn
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — The concert was supposed to be all Mendelssohn, but the sound of Gershwin’s “Summertime” was unmistakable, floating lazily through the early evening humidity.

headline: A Day of Relentless Heat
text: As temperatures rose well above 100 degrees in New York on Friday, people across the city resorted to a variety of ways to cope.

headline: Ending Up All Alone, and Making It Beautiful
text: DURHAM, N.C.—When it comes to peeling away the surface of a relationship to expose its defects — or that especially aggressive point where tension turns to hostility — the American choreographer Paul Taylor has a way of ripping off the bandage. Through his dances he reveals the meat of the human condition, and he likes it raw.

headline: The Week in Pictures for July 22
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a book party, same-sex marriage, and a hot day in Newark.

headline: Celebrating Forefather of Graffiti
text: A short Greek-American kid named Demetrius who lived on West 183rd Street in the late 1960s was by no means the first teenager to think of writing something in indelible ink on someone else’s property. He never considered himself an artist, and his illicit career of leaving his name and street number on hundreds, maybe thousands, of surfaces throughout the five boroughs of New York City ended after only a couple of years, when he put aside his Magic Marker and went off dutifully to college.

headline: This Sunday: The Story My Mom Will Try to Skip
text: There are few things in life that I avoid as strenuously as video games. Sure, I played a bit of Pong and Pac Man in my day. But when games started becoming these immersive, life-devouring experiences, I stayed away. Not because I consider them stupid or beneath me. I don’t know whether such games make us smarter or if they represent important achievements of pop culture. All I know is that if I brought an Xbox into my apartment, I’m scared I might never do anything else.

headline: War of the Rose
text: David Brooks and me, on Charlie Rose tonight. No columnists were harmed in the making of this program — possibly because one was in northern Virginia and the other in central New Jersey.

headline: Living With the Greenhouse Effect
text: “Living with the greenhouse effect” was the subtitle of my October, 1988, cover story for Discover Magazine — my first lengthy exploration of the science pointing to a growing human influence on climate. The cover line on the piece, which followed a scorching summer across much of the country, was, “This summer was merely a warmup.”

headline: Light to Broadway
text: Judith Light (ABC’s “Ugly Betty,” “Lombardi” on Broadway) will replace Linda Lavin as the sharp-tongued Silda in the Jon Robin Baitz play “Other Desert Cities,” which transfers to the Booth Theater on Broadway in October after a run earlier this year at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, presented by Lincoln Center Theater. Ms. Lavin is starring this fall in the Off Broadway play “The Lyons.”

headline: The Simple Pleasure of Tacos
text: THE appeal of tacos lies in their simplicity, in their hot-off-the-griddle-ness, their savory, spicy two bites of pleasure. I’ll admit I’ve eaten my share of tacos on the run, and happily, at market stalls south of the border, some unlikely joints in Texas and in downtown Manhattan. Part of the joy is the immediacy and the pace. Hunger sated, now. Another part is seeing a real taco master at work. I’ve patronized a popular place in San Francisco’s Mission district for more than 20 years. The tacos are excellent, but a big part of the draw is watching the sole longtime chef flipping tortillas, chopping meat and building beautiful tacos at incredible speed, never losing his cool.

headline: Biography Revives Push to Reopen Malcolm X Case
text: The death of Malcolm X, shot dead at the Audubon Ballroom in Upper Manhattan in 1965, never inflamed the public imagination in the same way the assassinations of John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. did. But scholars have long believed that a bungled investigation resulted in the imprisonment of the innocent and allowed some of those responsible to go free. Over the decades, efforts to reopen the case have failed.

headline: Wright Is Tanned, Rehabbed and Ready
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — David Wright was in uniform Friday, taking batting practice and in the Mets’ lineup for the first time since he went on the disabled list May 16 with a stress fracture in his lower back.

headline: In His Year of Working Furiously, Spielberg Makes a Summer Stop
text: SAN DIEGO — “You’ll be kids the rest of your lives!” shouted Steven Spielberg to a crowd of more than 6,000 roaring fantasy fans at the Comic-Con International convention here on Friday. “I feel the same way!”

headline: TimesCast | James Murdoch Under Scrutiny
text: July 22, 2011 - News Corporation executive James Murdoch's testimony before parliament is now under question.

headline: Recipes for Summer Fruit
text: Three dozen ways to use peaches, berries and more, including pies and crumbles, cold soups and refreshing drinks.

headline: Emotional Guy, Speaking for Others
text: Danny Aiello, a big guy with a big New Yawk accent, is best known for roles like Sal, the boisterous pizzeria owner in Spike Lee’s 1989 film, “Do the Right Thing,” which won him an Oscar nomination. In the play “The Shoemaker,” which is now in previews and opens on Sunday at the Acorn Theater, Mr. Aiello is a different kind of New Yorker. A wounded immigrant, he seethes with rage and sadness in the title role of an Italian Jewish shoemaker named Giuseppe, holed up in his shop in Hell’s Kitchen on 9/11, trying to shut out the chaos outside and the memories of loss it ignites.

headline: A Taco Truck in Your Kitchen
text: A good taco is a wonderful thing, whether you get it through a stainless steel truck window or at a favorite taqueria. Or at your house. For summer entertaining, tacos are fast, easy, and mighty tasty, made from the simplest ingredients. Take a steaming corn tortilla, add a little sizzled spicy pork and splash of salsa. Now, open a cold beer.

headline: Pawlenty Hits the Ice (and Scores)
text: URBANDALE, Iowa — Hockey is big in the life of Tim Pawlenty, as both sport and symbol.

headline: For Judge Accustomed to Harsh Cases, Volunteering for Something Sunnier
text: As the administrative judge of the Bronx criminal division state Supreme Court, Justice Efrain Alvarado usually spends his days presiding over the grimiest of cases.

headline: Cast, Rehearse, Perform (and Hurry)
text: When a show closes on opening night, the result can be tears and regret. But when the musical “Dr. Williams” ended its run on the night of its premiere, its creators couldn’t have been happier.

headline: AppSmart Extra: Book Apps for Adults
text: In a recent App Smart column on children’s book apps, I lauded The Fantastic Flying Books of Morris Lessmore, which doesn’t struggle to follow the metaphor of traditional books. Instead, it’s part film, part written narrative, part oral tale, and, as a whole, something that eludes easy description.

headline: Four Pianists, Teaming and Competing
text: Bill Charlap and Bill Mays faced each other squarely across the 92nd Street Y stage on Wednesday night, each stationed at a piano, taking turns but hardly holding back. It was early in the second half of a concert called “The Key Players,” part of the Jazz in July series. A projection on the back wall showed both pianists’ hands at work as they imbued an aptly titled standard, “We Could Make Such Beautiful Music Together,” with an air of thoughtful, chummy competition.

headline: On the Street | Blue Chip
text: Blue has taken the spotlight, from the intense hues of hydrangeas in gardens and markets, to the shades that the fashion world contributes.

headline: To Start Trumps From Your Hand or Dummy?
text: The premier event at the Summer North American Championships, which are taking place in Toronto, is the Spingold Knockout Teams.

headline: Joe Lee Wilson, a Leader of ’70s Loft-Jazz Movement, Dies at 75
text: Joe Lee Wilson, an acclaimed singer who was also a leader of the loft-jazz movement in the 1970s, died on Sunday at his home in Brighton, England. He was 75.

headline: Obama Ends ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Policy
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama formally certified on Friday that the American military is ready for the repeal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy as Pentagon officials said that nearly two million service members had been trained in preparation for gay men and women serving openly in their ranks.

headline: A Writer Frees Herself by Speaking Out
text: PARIS

headline: Backbone!
text: So President Obama — perhaps with some backstopping from Democrats in Congress — has his limits. And he seemed genuinely angry. Good.

headline: Street Style Photos: Florals
text: The best of readers’ street fashion submissions for the week of July 18.

headline: But There Is Still Joy in the World
text: To lift our spirits after a nasty week.

headline: As Other Tracks Close Doors, Saratoga Braves the Heat
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — Dale Romans leaned back in his golf cart Friday morning and wiped the sweat from his brow.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,465 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,663 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: For-Profit College Company Settles Whistle-Blower Suit
text: Kaplan Inc., a subsidiary of The Washington Post Company, agreed Friday to pay $1.6 million to bring an end to investigations and charges relating to the surgical technology program at its CHI Institute in Broomall, Pa.

headline: Iranian Exile Group Poses Vexing Issue for U.S. in Iraq
text: CAMP ASHRAF, Iraq — The more than 3,000 people living here once represented a powerful paramilitary organization bent on overthrowing the government in Iran. In the 1970s, the group killed Americans in Tehran, and after being given refuge by Saddam Hussein its members were suspected of serving as a mercenary unit that took part in his violent suppression of the Kurds in the north of Iraq and the Shiites in the south.

headline: A Diplomatic Mission Bearing Islamic Hip-Hop
text: WASHINGTON — In 2005, when the State Department invited Native Deen, one of the most prominent Islamic hip-hop groups in America, to do a good-will tour of Mali, Senegal and Nigeria, the band’s members did not know what to do.

headline: Surfing the Rockaways
text: With the explosion of the surf scene in recent years, the profile of the Rockaways as a place to catch the waves is rising.

headline: New Lawyer Joins Defense for Suspect in Boy’s Death
text: The lawyer representing Levi Aron, the man accused of kidnapping, killing and dismembering an 8-year-old boy in Brooklyn, announced on Friday that he had brought in a lawyer with deeper experience in mental health issues and the insanity defense to assist him.

headline: Cameron Under Pressure
text: Since we gathered here last, the News International phone-hacking scandal has unfolded with staggering speed: the past week brought the resignations of top News Corporation executives and two ranking British police officials, the unexplained death of a former News of the World editor and whistleblower, and the beginning of sometimes dramatic government hearings on the matter, one featuring Rupert and James Murdoch, a shaving cream pie and an amazing flying spouse (pink jacket).

headline: Andy Schleck Has Time on His Side, but Showdown Favors Evans’s Style
text: There is good news and bad news for Andy Schleck, the plucky, spindly cyclist who is leading the Tour de France after finishing second the past two years.

headline: Catching the Waves in the Rockaways
text: Young surfers make the early-morning trek on the A train out to the Rockaways, to tap the ocean’s enduring power.

headline: Heat ... Wave? Bubble? Dome? Seeking an Apt Name as the Hot Days Pile Up
text: “Everybody talks about the weather, but I guess TV meteorologists have to do it more cleverly,” said Jay Trobec, a weatherman at KELO-TV in Sioux Falls, S.D., as he sought to explain why the phrase “heat dome” is suddenly being heard and seen everywhere.

headline: Finding a Place in the Neighborhood
text: A classic neighborhood spot in a neighborhood without many, Sud Vino & Cucina has already become the kind of place the locals root for after just four months. In a developing corner of Bedford-Stuyvesant, on Bedford Avenue just south of Lexington, the space hits many familiar notes: a long exposed brick wall functions as a rotating art gallery; Edison bulbs dangle from the ceiling on red cords; the bar is fashioned out of wood reclaimed from a Brooklyn water tower. But it has won ardent fans for its homey feeling (a painting of the restaurant’s name by the owner Giuseppe Di Franco’s daughter Jaiden, 7, hangs at the front of the room), its selection of about 20 wines and its menu of rustic Italian pastas, salads, antipasti and crostini. On Wednesday, two waiters on a culinary expedition were quickly won over.

headline: Law Student’s Alter Ego: Filmmaker
text: SCARSDALE, N.Y.

headline: Riding the Rails to Ride the Waves
text: ON any given summer morning, they pop up on the A-train platform at Nostrand Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, along with the Caribbean women headed to nursing duty in Queens and the security workers and European tourists off to Kennedy Airport: young men with bagged surfboards dangling from their shoulders. Out to the Rockaways in Queens they ride, mostly getting off at Broad Channel, changing for the shuttle to the main break at Beach 90th Street, where new waterfront condominiums overlook rows of Dutch Colonials and enormous apartment complexes jut out to the shoreline far into the distance.

headline: Players in a Greek Drama
text: This summer, David Riley is one of the world’s most powerful financial analysts.

headline: Podcast: Debt Crises, Jobs, Gold and Hulu
text: Sovereign debt crises continue to simmer on both sides of the Atlantic, but there was some progress, in Europe, at least.

headline: Dodd-Frank Backers Clash With Regulator
text: WASHINGTON — John Walsh voiced the frustrations of many bankers when he warned in a speech last month that federal regulators were not paying attention to the cumulative impact of new rules and restrictions, jeopardizing the ability of banks to support economic growth.

headline: How Hot Is 104? New York Counts the Miseries
text: It felt like Death Valley as stifling heat reached down on Friday and took the city in its clammy grip, transforming the streets and sidewalks into hot griddles and creating instant dripping wretchedness.

headline: Truck Crash Halts Amtrak Service
text: Amtrak suspended all service between New York and Boston on Friday after a tractor-trailer struck and damaged a power system near New Haven.

headline: Release of Sealed Records Leads to Row Over Immigrant Prosecutions
text: A dispute has erupted over the federal government’s decision to prosecute at least a half dozen illegal immigrants in New York whose status was discovered after a state agency mistakenly provided sealed arrest records to immigration authorities last year.

headline: Romney Seeing Smaller Pool for Donations in Second Run
text: Dozens of former top donors to Mitt Romney remain on the sidelines as he mounts his second bid for the presidency, hampering his efforts to cement his status as the Republican front-runner and build a fund-raising machine that can compete effectively with President Obama.

headline: Terrorist’s Father Is Convicted of Lying
text: The father of a man who plotted to set off homemade bombs in Manhattan subway cars was convicted of obstructing justice and conspiring to obstruct justice during a federal investigation of his son.

headline: No Windmill, but Still a Cure for the Wicked
text: Perhaps you’ve noticed the trend among certain people these days to decide that certain other people are not living acceptable lives and must be reformed. I’m all for the concept, so long as I’m the one deciding what’s acceptable and doing the reforming. And I have something that most of the other self-appointed judges don’t: the Putt-Putt System of Personal Redemption.

headline: Dodgers Ordered to Bargain With M.L.B. on a Loan
text: A federal bankruptcy court judge on Friday rejected the Los Angeles Dodgers’ plan to borrow $150 million from a hedge fund and ordered them to negotiate “cooperatively” with Major League Baseball for a loan of the same amount on better terms. But the judge, Kevin Gross, said the loan could not lead to control of the team.

headline: In Greek Pact, Compromises and Intrigues
text: BERLIN — The latest bailout in the Greek rescue has all the elements of what is fast becoming almost commonplace European intrigue.

headline: ‘A Right Scarry Time’
text: The First Battle of Bull Run was poorly fought but well-documented: dozens of paintings and scores of after-action photographs demonstrate the horror of that first major engagement.

headline: Private Conant and the First Bull Run Prisoners
text: Two days after the momentous victory of Southern arms at the Battle of Bull Run, the first train crowded with Union prisoners of war rolled into Richmond, Va. A motley crew of bedraggled federals poured out of the cars. Curious citizens buzzed with excitement as guards marched the men through the Confederate capital.

headline: Working as a Way of Living
text: Robert Wilson, the multifaceted artist and the director of avant-garde creations like “Einstein on the Beach,” is one cosmic cat. Mr. Wilson is as likely to collaborate with Lou Reed and Laurie Anderson as with members of the local Shinnecock Indian tribe. He established the Watermill Center on Long Island, a cultural think tank for young artists and scholars, in 1992 and acknowledges it as his legacy; its annual benefit gala is July 30. Mr. Wilson’s 70th birthday is being celebrated Oct. 4 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with the opening of his production of Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill’s “Threepenny Opera.” He keeps to a daily work regimen, but on Sundays allows himself time to relax and smell the roses on his six-acre retreat.  ROBIN FINN

headline: Giving Voice to Immigrants, Past and Present
text: Ambivalence about immigration is as American as, well, corned beef, pizza, knishes, black-eyed peas, empanadas — and apple pie. Which is why “Toward a Better Life: America’s New Immigrants in Their Own Words — From Ellis Island to the Present” (Prometheus Books, $26) is a welcome reminder that the vast majority of today’s newcomers are tomorrow’s productive citizens and that they gravitate here for the same reasons their predecessors did for centuries; some of them even become the antiforeigners of the future.

headline: NASA Picks Rover Destination: Mountain on Mars
text: NASA’s next Mars rover — the ambitious, beleaguered, delayed Mars Science Laboratory — finally has a destination.

headline: Shiraz Spill Sinks Winemaker’s Dream, for Now
text: SYDNEY, Australia — An Australian winemaker’s hopes of breaking into the American market this season came crashing down on Friday, along with a 12-ton container holding more than $1 million worth of premium shiraz that toppled from a forklift and shattered on a warehouse floor.

headline: State Housing Official Arrested After Car Crash
text: The New York State housing commissioner, Darryl C. Towns, was arrested over the Fourth of July weekend on a charge of driving while intoxicated after he crashed his car in Westchester County, the police said.

headline: Wright Returns and All Seems Well, for Now
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — In his first major league at-bat since May 15, David Wright twisted his torso without pain, uncoiled and ripped a run-scoring double to right field.

headline: Revamped Humvee Draws Military’s Eye
text: An innovative chimney to vent blasts from buried bombs could make the Humvee safer and bring the most popular military vehicle since the Jeep back from the sidelines in Afghanistan.

headline: Energy Use Soars in City Under Grip of Scorcher
text: The morning coffee had not gone cold at Consolidated Edison’s headquarters before its executives could see that trouble was brewing.

headline: As Transit Chief Leaves Post, Challenges for Agency Persist
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Friday began a search for a new chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, as rider advocates, union leaders and analysts warned that the next leader of the agency faces a daunting set of financial and operational challenges.

headline: Saturday: Change Around the Thames
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — There are a lot of you who will hate me for saying this, but this one was all around fun, even for a Saturday. Lots of great, long answers stretched across a fairly open grid and clues that are tricky without being impossible, making for a smooth solve. I may become a good Saturday solver after all.

headline: Ordering Food by Phone, Without Saying a Word
text: APP GrubHub

headline: The Party That Can’t Say Yes
text: For days, the White House has infuriated its Democratic allies in Congress by offering House Republicans more and more in exchange for a deal to raise the debt ceiling and prevent default. But it was never enough, and, on Friday evening, it became clear that it may never be enough. Speaker John Boehner again walked away from the “grand bargain” he had been negotiating with President Obama, leaving the country teetering on the brink of another economic collapse.

headline: Tale of Glass in Burger Lingers
text: The police officer, recalling that night, sounds like an actor in a fast-food commercial: “At some point, something told me, grab a Big Mac.” And so on a freezing January night in 2005, the officer, John Florio, then 39, stopped at the drive-through window of a McDonald’s in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx. He ordered the combo, a Big Mac with fries and a Coke.

headline: Some Sense in Europe
text: Europe’s leaders finally woke up — and not a moment too soon.

headline: Roger Cohen Speaks to Gen. Petraeus
text: Excerpts from a conversation between Roger Cohen, the Op-Ed columnist for International Herald Tribune, and Gen. David Petraeus.

headline: Fair Deals in New York and Connecticut
text: There are now thousands of workers in New York and Connecticut whose jobs depend on the good sense of their fellow union members.

headline: Changing Course
text: The International Maritime Organization, an agency of the United Nations, has introduced important, if still too limited, rules to reduce emissions from large cargo ships. Tankers, container ships and other freighters, most of which burn a coarse petroleum sludge called bunker fuel, now contribute about 3.3 percent of global carbon dioxide emissions, though some analysts argue the figure may be considerably higher. Without new restrictions, emissions from increased shipping could nearly triple by 2050.

headline: Worthy Rivals for the Crown in Smartphones
text: First sold to the public just four years ago, the Apple iPhone melded the vast potential of the Internet with a multimedia player, a still and video camera, e-mail, texting, instant messaging, social networking and other applications — now 425,000 and counting — into one elegant, easy-to-use touch-screen package. And it makes voice calls. Rarely has one device so upended a market.

headline: Malawi President Blames Protesters for Violence
text: CAPE TOWN — Facing international condemnation for his government’s use of force against peaceful demonstrators, Malawi’s president defiantly blamed protest organizers and political opponents on Friday for the violence that left 18 people dead this week. And he warned them against a return to the streets.

headline: Labor Peace Within Reach for Two N.F.L. Leaders
text: After the tumult of Thursday, the N.F.L. went mostly silent Friday. That was in recognition of the mourning for the Patriots owner Robert Kraft’s wife, Myra, whose funeral in Boston was attended by other owners, league officials and the players association executive director, DeMaurice Smith.

headline: The Great Evil
text: The current political environment and the debt-crisis debate remind me of the 1997 science-fiction film “The Fifth Element.”

text: YONKERS

headline: In the Hamptons, Where the Ferraris Flock
text: We were balled up in a fetal position in the tiny back seat of a black Ferrari convertible as it cruised across the Hamptons last Saturday afternoon. As we lost feeling in our legs, we listened while a passenger tried to convince himself it was a “practical” family car.

text: It’s finally live.

headline: New McCafé Beverages Lift Results at McDonald’s
text: McDonald’s said second-quarter profit rose 15 percent, topping analysts’ estimates, as more consumers ate out and McCafé beverages raised sales. Net income climbed to $1.41 billion, or $1.35 a share, from $1.23 billion, or $1.13 a share, a year earlier, McDonald’s said in a statement Friday. The average estimate of 22 analysts surveyed by Bloomberg was $1.28 a share. Sales rose 16 percent to $6.91 billion. Stock in McDonald’s, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., rose $2.02, to $88.56 a share.

headline: Georgia Frees 4 Photographers Held as Spies for Russia
text: TBILISI, Georgia — Four Georgian photographers accused of spying for Russia were released from custody on Friday as part of a plea bargain agreement, hastily resolving a case that had drawn angry criticism from fellow journalists and media watchdog groups.

headline: Music and Fashion, Poised for Takeoff
text: CHRIS JONES, a founder of MTK: Music to Know, a new festival to be held in East Hampton on Aug. 13 and 14, has a way of looking on the bright side.

headline: Puns and Parodies, and a Killer Rabbit
text: There are jokes tucked into the program for “Monty Python’s Spamalot” and jokes folded into the overture. The entire opening song is a comic blunder, the result of a loony misunderstanding. It’s impossible to escape the puns, parodies and silly noises that pepper the musical now playing in Patchogue in a Gateway Playhouse production that improves upon the pleasures of the 2005 Broadway blockbuster, which ran for nearly four years.

headline: Elliot Handler, Co-Founder of Mattel Toys, Dies at 95
text: Elliot Handler, who co-founded the Mattel toy company and designed the plastic playthings that have filled millions of Christmas stockings, made dinner parties possible by occupying otherwise fidgety children, and stubbed countless parents’ toes, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 95.

headline: City Is Stunned at Teenager’s Arrest in Parents’ Deaths
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, FLA. — Tyler Hadley was giving a party for 60 people at his home here last Saturday night when, according to police, he confessed to a friend that he had killed his parents. The friend refused to believe him, until the 17-year-old Mr. Hadley showed him a bloody shoe print in the garage. The friend entered the house and said he saw blood near the door of the master bedroom. When he opened it he saw a partly covered body sticking out from a heap of items on the floor.

headline: Town Turns to iPads in Cost-Cutting Move
text: While Apple started selling iPads to the public only 15 months ago, the 1.5-pound tablet computers seem well on their way toward ubiquity. This year, Alaska Airlines began issuing them to pilots to replace the 25 pounds of paper flight manuals they were required to carry on flights. Now, Cornelius, N.C., with a population of about 25,000, has stopped printing meeting agenda packages for town commissioners and has given them iPads instead. Anthony Roberts, the town manager (with Bence Hoyle, the police chief), discusses.

headline: Isolation and Mortality by the Swimming Pool
text: I remembered the swimming pool. I didn’t remember the bug zapper.

headline: Glitter That Epitomized an Ancient Culture
text: Gold was so entwined with the ancient culture of Java, the chief island of the Indonesian archipelago, that even its dogs, it was said, wore golden collars.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Man Cleared After 3 Arrests in Stadium Attack
text: LOS ANGELES — Three new suspects have been arrested in the opening day beating of a San Francisco Giants fan outside Dodger Stadium, and the police announced Friday that the previous suspect has been cleared.

headline: Suspicions About Former Editor in Battle Over Story Complicate Hacking Scandal
text: LONDON — On Dec. 21 last year, The Daily Telegraph was preparing to publish a blockbuster exclusive: Vince Cable, the government’s business secretary, had been caught on tape boasting that he had “declared war” on Rupert Murdoch and would find a convenient legal excuse to block the News Corporation’s bid for British Sky Broadcasting, Britain’s most lucrative satellite television network.

headline: The Dumb Blonde With an I.Q. of 172 (No Joke)
text: When Pheonix Vaughn coughed, the mystery was solved.

headline: Brothel’s Guests: Love and Dreams
text: An unpretentious brothel in Mississippi is the setting for “Follow Me to Nellie’s,” a new play by Dominique Morisseau about African-Americans coping in different ways with their segregated existence in 1955. Even as several characters strive for greater equality, others merely dream of better times.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around New Jersey. Items may be submitted by mail to the New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: In 3 Countries, Challenging the Vatican on Female Priests
text: More than 150 Roman Catholic priests in the United States have signed a statement in support of a fellow cleric who faces dismissal for participating in a ceremony that purported to ordain a woman as a priest, in defiance of church teaching.

headline: At a Baking Ballpark, Using Precaution and Invention to Stay Cool
text: As humidity enveloped commuters and sun baked the city’s sidewalks, the Yankees struggled through the heat like other New Yorkers on Friday afternoon as they prepared to go to work in their return to Yankee Stadium.

headline: A Pour and a Plate
text: Larchmont enjoys a luxury of good little restaurants, but Vintage 1891, open since March, brings something new to town: nightlife. In a historic brick building, this wine lounge offers beautifully plated food and a svelte refuge from the heat. The wine list is first-class; the rosemary popcorn ($4) is addictive.

headline: Exclusively Italian, and Adriatic to Boot
text: FEW restaurants in the county will offer one cuisine exclusively. Scalini Osteria, however, not only has embraced the cooking of Italy, but also has created a menu of memorable dishes simply by featuring the country’s classic regional fare.

headline: A Welcome Picnic Guest
text: Lieb Family Cellars, in Cutchogue, has become synonymous with both dry and sparkling pinot blanc on Long Island. Its dry version, a perennial favorite of consumers and restaurants, mimics the pinot blanc of Alsace.

headline: Hamptons Fare With Informal Feel
text: SOUTH Edison has the look of Montauk but the food and prices of the Hamptons. The year-old restaurant serves exciting fare created by the chef Todd Mitgang, the former executive chef and co-owner of Crave Ceviche Bar in Manhattan. Steven Kristel is his partner in this venture.

headline: Hardware and Produce
text: One of Connecticut’s more reliable produce stands is by the entrance to Paul’s and Sandy’s Too in East Hampton. The sprawling garden center and hardware store maintains 15 greenhouses filled with plants, but it does not grow any of its own fruits and vegetables. Instead, a broad array of produce is trucked in daily, largely from area farms.

headline: Clubby, for After Work or a Movie
text: WHAT makes Bar Rosso, a clubby cafe in downtown Stamford, such a magnet for those under 40 is partly its location: half a block from the lively outdoor happy-hour scene on Bedford Street across from the Avon Theater Film Center.

headline: France: Kidnapping Was Part of Ritual
text: A teenage girl, whose kidnapping on Sunday from a park in Privas, in southeast France, riveted the country, was found unharmed on Friday, apparently taken by her fiancé’s family as part of a Chechen premarriage ritual, the police said. The girl, who was not named and who was thought to be 16 or 17, was found by the police in the southwestern Haute-Garonne region with the family of her fiancé, said a spokeswoman for the Privas police. The family said they were simply following an old North Caucasus tradition, like others in the Chechen diaspora. The kidnapping originates as a response by a man when a young woman’s family refuses a marriage. After the abduction and a night spent away from home, the young women is considered “soiled,” and the family would then consent to the union. Religious leaders among the Chechens, who are mostly Muslim, are trying to put an end to the tradition.

headline: Murdoch Papers Could Lose Special Access to 2012 Athletes
text: Rupert Murdoch’s British newspapers could lose exclusive access to the country’s athletes as they prepare for next year’s Summer Games in London because of the phone-hacking scandal that led to the closing of the tabloid The News of the World and testimony before Parliament by Murdoch and his son James.

headline: Romney Running Again, and Finding Fund-Raising Support in Different Places
text: While Mitt Romney’s fund-raising totals were down in nearly every region in the first six months of 2011, the distribution of where he found his money changed, too.

headline: Small-Town Doctors Made in a Small Kansas Town
text: SALINA, Kan. — This state, so sparsely populated in parts that five counties have no doctors at all, has struggled for years to encourage young doctors to relocate to rural communities, where health problems are often exacerbated by a lack of even the most basic care.

headline: A Mexican Import Wins New Fans
text: HIGHLANDS, N.J.

headline: Legal Marijuana in Arizona, but Not for the Sellers
text: PHOENIX — Marijuana is known to cause red eyes, gales of laughter and the munchies. In Arizona, add another side effect: utter confusion.

headline: Scientists Retract Report on Predicting Longevity
text: Scientists who asserted last year that they could predict with 77 percent accuracy who would live past 100 have retracted their report in the journal Science, yet say they are right anyway.

headline: Heat, Humidity and Concern for Hughes, but the Yankees’ Offense Rolls
text: As humidity enveloped commuters and the sun baked the city’s sidewalks, the Yankees struggled through the heat like other New Yorkers on Friday afternoon while they prepared to go to work in their return to Yankee Stadium.

headline: Opening the Sewers
text: Raw sewage was released into the Hudson and Harlem rivers after a fire at the North River Wastewater Treatment Plant forced its closure.

headline: Bruce Sundlun, Rhode Island Governor With Flair, Dies at 91
text: Bruce G. Sundlun, a former Democratic governor of Rhode Island whose tenure was marked by dramatic events both public and private, including a statewide banking crisis on his first day in office and a lawsuit — happily resolved — by a Midwestern teenager who said she was his daughter, died on Thursday at his home in Jamestown, R.I. He was 91.

headline: Fertile Ground for Golf in Northern Ireland
text: PORTRUSH, Northern Ireland — In the gray light of dawn, a solitary man carried his golf bag toward the green. The wind was blowing hard, whistling down the North Channel toward Belfast. Squinting from an outcropping 100 feet above the links of Royal Portrush Golf Club, one could see the man leaning hard to the right to keep his balance.

headline: Amid High Temperatures, Workers Stop Sewage Plant’s Flow Into River
text: It sounds like a job dreamed up by an especially sadistic boss: stop a multimillion-gallon torrent of raw sewage that is flowing into two rivers, fouling beaches and ruining weekend plans. Every minute counts, and it is the hottest day of the year. Now get out there!

headline: Rev. Mary M. Simpson, a Pioneer in Episcopal Clergy, Dies at 85
text: The Rev. Mary Michael Simpson, the first Episcopal nun to be ordained a priest and the first ordained woman to preach a sermon in Westminster Abbey, died Wednesday in Augusta, Ga. She was 85.

headline: Timeline of the Standard American Diet
text: This selection of events tracks the devolution of the Standard American Diet.

headline: California: A Schwarzenegger Son Is Injured
text: Christopher Schwarzenegger, the 13-year-old son of Maria Shriver and Arnold Schwarzenegger, the former governor, was seriously injured in a surfing or boogie-boarding accident in Malibu, and is recovering after “a scary week” in a Los Angeles-area hospital, his family said Friday. In a statement released by Ms. Shriver and Mr. Schwarzenegger, who separated this year, they said they were optimistic about their son’s recovery. “While it has been a very scary week, Christopher is surrounded by his family and friends,” the statement said. “He is a brave boy and is expected to make a full recovery.” Christopher is the youngest of the couple’s four children.

headline: The Week in Pictures for July 22
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a book party, same-sex marriage, and a hot day in Newark.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Wildfires in Australia
text: A series of wildfires that tore across the southern state of Victoria over the weekend killed at least 128 people, the state police said.

headline: Battle for Libya | July 22, 2011
text: Funerals were held for rebels and an image of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was unveiled at the Green Square in Tripoli.

text: NATIONAL

headline: The World This Week, Part 1
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: The World This Week, Part 2
text: A look at the latest in the illegal phone hacking scandal and in this year's Tour de France.

headline: Boomtown to Bust
text: In Lehigh Acres, Fla., reshaped by the housing boom, the bust is testing whether the experience of shared struggle will pull people together or tear them apart.

headline: Oslo Suspect Wrote of Fear of Islam and Plan for War
text: OSLO — The Norwegian man charged Saturday with a pair of attacks in Oslo that killed at least 92 people left behind a detailed manifesto outlining his preparations and calling for a Christian war to defend Europe against the threat of Muslim domination, according to Norwegian and American officials familiar with the investigation.

headline: Unfavorable Ratings for Both Major Parties Near Record Highs
text: A new CNN poll finds that 55 percent of voters have a negative view of the Republican Party, tied for their second-highest unfavorable score since CNN began asking this question in 1992. The Republicans also achieved a 55 percent unfavorable rating in a poll conducted in April 2009, although the party’s all-time high, 57 percent, was recorded as the House of Representatives was in the process of impeaching Bill Clinton in December, 1998.

headline: The Weekend Word: Breakdown
text: Today’s Times

headline: Urban Forager | Sweet Wineberry
text: Sweet wineberries — relatives of raspberries — aren’t available by the pint in supermarkets, but they should be. In the last few weeks, this citrusy wild fruit, which tastes like a cross between a raspberry and a California orange, has been ripening throughout the metro area, growing along roadsides, park trails and on the edges of clearings.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Supporters to Give Red Bulls the Silent Treatment
text: The Red Bulls’ most boisterous fans — members of the club’s three prominent supporters groups — say they love their team but do not particularly care for the recent decision to write off the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup.

headline: Kei Igawa: The Lost Yankee
text: TRENTON — In the middle of a bright Manhattan summer afternoon, the Yankees’ $46 million pitcher steps from his fashionable East Side apartment building and slips into a waiting Lexus for a chauffeured ride to the ballpark.

headline: Speed Hiker Thrives on Natural Rhythms of the Appalachian Trail
text: On a sunny July afternoon, a dirt road tucked inside the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area near Blairstown, N.J., was calm and serene. A deer, uninterested in the sight of a man eating a peanut butter sandwich while leaning against his car, strolled across the road and disappeared into the woods. A few yards away, a stream tumbled under a wooden footbridge.

headline: With Shaun White
text: Shaun White, the professional snowboarder and skateboarder, competed this weekend in skate vert at the Dew Tour season opener in Ocean City, Md. At the Winter X Games, White, a two-time Olympic gold medalist in the halfpipe, has dominated slopestyle snowboarding, which involves performing tricks in the air as well as on rails and boxes. This month the International Olympic Committee approved the inclusion of men’s and women’s slopestyle, and freestyle skiing for the 2014 Games in Sochi, Russia. White, 24, visited Manhattan recently to promote his signature line of Oakley sunglasses. VINCENT M. MALLOZZI

headline: Remembering the Manager That Got Away
text: Mordechai I. Twersky, a freelance writer and broadcast journalist, lives in Israel.

headline: Naked Blackmail
text: It turns out that in the final stages of the debt negotiations, Republicans suddenly added a new demand — a trigger that would end up eliminating the individual mandate in health care reform.

headline: Profiles in Un-courage
text: Matt Yglesias notes the odd failure of reasonably sensible Republican macroeconomists to confront their party’s descent into hard-money madness. He analyzes it as follows:

headline: Kei Igawa’s Journey
text: Igawa, the 32-year-old pitcher from Japan, has spent the last four years playing in the minor leagues with a major-league contract after not living up to high expectations.

headline: Webber Beats Germans to Pole, but Will He Lead a Lap?
text: NÜRBURGRING, Germany — With six German drivers in the series, two of them world champions and one of them the man who won the championship last year and is dominating the current one, it would be logical if a German scored pole position in today’s qualifying session for the German Grand Prix.

headline: Webber Beats Germans to Pole, but Will He Lead a Lap?

headline: Phelps Seeks Strong Finishing Kick to His Career
text: Michael Phelps’s strategy in the 200-meter butterfly, his signature event, is deceptively simple for such a grueling race: establish an easy rhythm on the first lap, build momentum on the second, break loose on the third and finish strong.

headline: Roaming the Field for Detroit: A Jack-of-All-Trades
text: MINNEAPOLIS — In the late 1990s at Mount Lebanon High School in Pittsburgh, the baseball team included two future major league shortstops. One day, Josh Wilson would pitch and Don Kelly would play short. When Wilson did not pitch, he and Kelly alternated between middle infield spots.

headline: Swim, Meet
text: A collection of photos by Kate Orlinsky.

headline: Lawmakers Renew Push for Deal on Cutting Deficit
text: WASHINGTON — Despite growing fears that world markets might react negatively to a breakdown in the federal budget negotiations, Congressional leaders clashed Saturday night as they tried to reach a new deficit-reduction agreement that Speaker John A. Boehner told colleagues could cut $3 trillion to $4 trillion in spending over 10 years.

headline: Variety: Genius at Work
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s Variety puzzle is a special one that was originally solved at the most recent National Puzzlers’ League convention, held July 7-10 in Providence, R.I. Jeffrey Harris, of Norwalk, Conn., completed this puzzle in an astounding 3 minutes and 35 seconds.

headline: Volleyball Star Is on the Path to Recovery
text: Stacy Sykora does not remember the rainy April night when the bus carrying her Vôlei Futuro volleyball team overturned just yards from the gym where the women were to play.

headline: What Obama Was Willing to Give Away
text: Jonathan Cohn summarizes what seems to have been in the deal that Boehner walked away from; it’s horrifying. Above all, the proposed rise in the age of Medicare eligibility was a real betrayal of both Democratic principles and good government.

headline: Cadel Evans Set to Win First Tour de France
text: GRENOBLE, France — Cadel Evans rocketed past the finish line Saturday, all but certain of his triumph in the Tour de France. As fellow Australians everywhere burst into celebration, Evans presented them with the portrait of a champion: body bent, muscles bulging, vigilant until the end.

headline: Inflation and the Right, Then and Now
text: Jonathan Chait notes that conservative attitudes toward monetary policy were very different when a Republican was in the White House. What he doesn’t note is that there were several points in the Bush years when annual inflation ran relatively high:

headline: My Name Is Legion (Self-indulgent)
text: Reading some of the comments here and elsewhere, I have to admit that I’m impressed by the range of sins I have apparently committed. I’m someone who always wants to run bigger deficits AND I’m inconsistent because I said deficits were bad under Bush but good under Obama. I’m a slavish admirer of Obama AND someone who has had it in for the president ever since the primary, when I kept warning that he wasn’t really committed to progressive ideas.

headline: Hulu, Billed as Tomorrow’s TV, Looks Boxed In
text: PICTURE this: TV anyway, anywhere.

text: Dalian, China
