text: N.F.L. players and owners are one and the same.

headline: The Banks Still Want a Waiver
text: HOW should banks atone for those foreclosure abuses — all the robo-signing and shoddy recordkeeping that jettisoned so many people from their homes?

headline: At Peace With Indy 500 Mistake, Hildebrand Perseveres
text: The morning after J. R. Hildebrand became famous for losing the Indianapolis 500 on the 800th of 800 left turns, his boss, John Barnes, showed up at his race team’s office and wondered what he could offer Hildebrand as a consolation prize.

headline: When You Persevere, ‘No’ Turns to ‘Yes’
text: This interview with  Stacey Allaster, the chairwoman and C.E.O. of the Women’s Tennis Association, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Our Game Is Lifted
text: ROCHESTER — Our bus turned the corner toward the stadium. A full two hours before kickoff of the Western New York versus magicJack game last Wednesday, people were already searching for parking and making their way to the stadium gate, where the line stretched down the block. Chills.

headline: The Auteur vs. the Committee
text: AT Apple, one is the magic number.

headline: Amy Winehouse Found Dead in London, Police Say
text: LONDON — Amy Winehouse, the Grammy-award winning singer who has battled addiction problems for years, was found dead on Saturday at her apartment in London, the police said. She was 27.

headline: Slowing Down to Savor the Data
text: “DATA beats opinion” has long been a mantra at Google, where evidence-based research tends to rule. But now the company is showing its softer side with Think Quarterly, a business-to-business publication whose first United States issue is to make its debut online this week.

headline: Taxing and Spending, in Balance
text: THE fight over the debt ceiling has deflected attention from the serious problems of fixing the economy and finding jobs for the 14 million unemployed. Worse, it has created strong negative feelings about fiscal policy, just when other policy measures seem incapable of restoring economic health.

headline: In a Gold Lovefest, Shades of 1980
text: THE worse things get, the better it looks for gold. That’s been the pattern this summer.

headline: Default Seen as Unlikely, but Markets Prepare
text: WASHINGTON — World markets have behaved until now as if it were inevitable that Congress would raise the debt ceiling, the maximum amount the federal government can borrow, before the Treasury Department exhausts its ability to pay all of its bills in early August. The breakdown of negotiations Friday has jolted that sense of equanimity, wrenching the worst-case scenario from unthinkable to merely unlikely.

headline: M.L.S. All-Stars All Around the Town
text: Major League Soccer and its corporate partners will hold a series of events in the New York metropolitan area leading up to Wednesday’s All-Star Game at Red Bull Arena against Manchester United (8:50 p.m. kickoff, Eastern; ESPN2, Galavision, TSN).

headline: Online, Clues to a Suspected Attacker’s Motives
text: Last Updated | Sunday | 6:38 p.m. As my colleague Steven Erlanger reports, “The Norwegian police on Saturday charged a man they identified as a right-wing fundamentalist Christian in connection with a bombing in central Oslo and a shooting attack on a nearby island that killed at least 92 people.”

headline: A Mr. Nader Is Calling, and He Wants a Refund
text: A FEW weeks ago, Ralph Nader rang.

headline: Collaborate and Compete
text: I STARTED playing tennis at the age of 5, and at 8 I was playing competitively in tournaments. As I grew older, playing doubles taught me about collaboration, and playing one-on-one taught me how to outthink and outsmart an opponent. I was also a television buff, especially when it came to commercials.

headline: After Long Wait, Gay Couples Marry in New York
text: Hundreds of gay and lesbian couples across New York State began marrying on Sunday — the first taking their vows just after midnight — in the culmination of a long battle in the Legislature and a new milestone for gay rights advocates seeking to legalize same-sex marriage across the nation.

headline: Joe Nathan’s Finishing Touch Is Back
text: For all the pitchers lost this season to Tommy John surgery — including Brett Anderson, Joba Chamberlain, Jorge De La Rosa, Daisuke Matsuzaka and Adam Wainwright — one recent patient has a message: returning to your old self takes time.

headline: The Personal Energy Crisis
text: I CAN pinpoint the moment I realized that we’d reached a tipping point. It was almost exactly a year ago. I was standing in the parking lot of a large technology company in Silicon Valley, with a senior executive I’d come to know well. The company that employed him was widely viewed as a great place to work, and this executive is one of the most upbeat people I know.

headline: Toll Climbs to 80 in NATO Raid on Insurgent Camp in Southeastern Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The number of insurgents reported killed in a NATO attack on a large encampment in a remote area of Paktika Province rose to 80 on Saturday, said Afghan officials, adding that they were concerned that there could be more undetected militant camps within the country’s borders.

headline: The New Math of Law School
text: The New Math of Law School

headline: China Arrests Its Most-Wanted Fugitive After Canada Deports Him
text: BEIJING — In a closely watched case that could affect Chinese citizens in other Western countries, state security officials arrested China’s most-wanted fugitive on Saturday after Canadian authorities deported him, ending more than a decade of attempts to escape imprisonment here.

headline: A Goalie Speaks Up, on the Field and Off
text: LITTLE FALLS, N.J. — In full goalkeeping regalia — long pants, long-sleeve shirt and padded gloves that had to be peeled off — Frank Rost stood tall in the 100-degree heat Friday morning, beads of perspiration cascading down his face after the Red Bulls’ abbreviated practice session at Montclair State University.

headline: Amy Winehouse
text: Amy Winehouse, the singer and songwriter who shot to fame with “Rehab,” won five Grammy Awards and sold more than five million albums, has died at age 27.

headline: Protesters Urge President to Step Down in Senegal
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Thousands filled a sandy plaza here Saturday to demonstrate against Senegal’s president, Abdoulaye Wade, who is trying to extend his time in office in what critics say is a violation of the country’s Constitution.

headline: At Least 35 Killed and 210 Hurt in Crash of 2 Trains in China
text: BEIJING — -At least 35 people died and 210 were injured Saturday night in a train accident on a high-speed line in coastal China. It was the most serious blow yet to the country’s beleaguered rail-modernization program.

headline: A Rock-Solid Conservative Who’s Willing to Bend
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Tom Coburn of Oklahoma was a Tea Partier long before the movement even had a name, the family physician who came to Washington to hammer on Democrats and Republicans alike. His years of bill blocking earned him the nickname Dr. No.

headline: Amy Winehouse, British Soul Singer With a Troubled Life, Dies at 27
text: Amy Winehouse, the British singer who found worldwide fame with a sassy, hip-hop-inflected take on retro soul, yet became a tabloid fixture as her problems with drugs and alcohol led to a strikingly public career collapse, was found dead on Saturday in her apartment in London, the police said. She was 27.

headline: McKenry’s Big Break Comes After Trade to Pirates
text: On the night of June 12, Mike McKenry was scanning his groceries at the supermarket checkout line in Pawtucket, R.I., when his cellphone rang. McKenry, then a part-time catcher for the Boston Red Sox’ Class AAA team, had no reason to expect what he was about to hear.

headline: Heat Deaths Rise, but Cooler Air Is in the Forecast
text: A punishing wave of heat and humidity continued its hold over a large part of the country on Saturday, raising the toll of heat-related deaths even as forecasters promised that relief, in the form of cooler air from Canada, would arrive Sunday.

headline: Scientific Advances on Contraceptives for Men
text: Steve Owens had always left birth control to his wife, who took the pill. After all, male methods were vasectomy, which he did not want, and condoms, which he described as: “Well, condoms are condoms.”

headline: Swim, Meet
text: A collection of photos by Kate Orlinsky on the joys of swimming pools.

headline: Doubts Grow in Egypt About Trial for Mubarak
text: CAIRO — Former President Hosni Mubarak is officially scheduled to go to trial in 10 days on charges that could carry the death penalty. But the question preoccupying Cairo right now is not whether he will be found guilty, but this: What will happen when his trial is almost certainly postponed?

headline: Survivors of Utoya Island
text: Norwegians recount the attack on Utoya island by suspected shooter Anders Behring Breivik.

text: This article is by  Jeremy W. Peters,  Michael Barbaro and  Javier C. Hernandez.

headline: Video of a Lethal Injection Reopens Questions on the Privacy of Executions
text: As Andrew Grant DeYoung died by lethal injection in a prison in Jackson, Ga., on Thursday night, a video camera watched silently.

headline: Burnett Works Hard, to No Avail, in Yankees’ Loss
text: The powder-blue shirt of the home-plate umpire Bill Welke was soaked through by the sixth inning Saturday, probably because it was sunny and close to 100 degrees at Yankee Stadium. A. J. Burnett was also grinding through another start, making Welke’s and everyone else’s day longer.

headline: Nguyen Cao Ky, South Vietnam Leader, Dies at 80
text: Nguyen Cao Ky, the flamboyant former South Vietnamese Air Force commander who served for two years as his country’s wartime leader, then fled to the United States when Saigon fell to the Communists, died Saturday at the age of 80.

headline: Bad Food? Tax It, and Subsidize Vegetables
text: Mark Bittman writes about food for the opinion section.

headline: The End of Awe
text: WEDNESDAY found both the British prime minister and the Irish taoiseach passionately addressing their parliaments about the demystified lords of their universes.

headline: Republicans, Zealots and Our Security
text: IF China or Iran threatened our national credit rating and tried to drive up our interest rates, or if they sought to damage our education system, we would erupt in outrage.

headline: Make Way for the Radical Center
text: DID I mention that I’ve signed a pledge — just like those Republican congressmen who have signed written promises to different political enforcers not to raise taxes or permit same-sex marriage? My pledge is to never vote for anyone stupid enough to sign a pledge — thereby abdicating their governing responsibilities in a period of incredibly rapid change and financial stress. Sorry, I’ve signed it. Nothing more I can do.

headline: Much Ado About Michele
text: MICHELE BACHMANN is the gift that never stops giving.

text: After the devastating accident at Japan’s Fukushima nuclear plant, many Americans have asked whether something just as horrible could happen here.

headline: When Wealth Breeds Rage
text: John Githongo is the chief executive of Inuka Kenya Trust and chairman of the Africa Institute for Governing With Integrity. He was Kenya’s permanent secretary for governance and ethics from 2003 to 2005.

text: Mark Derr is the author of the forthcoming “How the Dog Became the Dog: From Wolves to Our Best Friends.”

headline: The Sleepover Question
text: Amy Schalet is an assistant professor of sociology at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, and the author of the forthcoming “Not Under My Roof: Parents, Teens and the Culture of Sex.”

headline: Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me
text: NPR’s “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!” is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/programs/wait-wait-dont-tell-me/)

headline: Remembering Myra Kraft
text: The best story about Myra Kraft to emerge among the touching remembrances following her death this week after a long battle with cancer came from her son Jonathan. He recalled how his mom, during a family trip to South Africa in the era of apartheid, demanded that a white police officer who was taking black men into custody arrest her, too. Jonathan remembered his dad, the Patriots owner Robert K. Kraft, telling him not to let his mother get in trouble. So he threw his mom, a petite woman, over his shoulder and hauled her away.

headline: Jeff Moss
text: Kate Murphy is a journalist in Houston who writes frequently for The New York Times.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Lessons From the Tabloid Scandal
text: Questions about media practices, bias and influence, both in Britain and the United States, arise from the Murdoch affair. Readers offer divergent views in response to a letter on Thursday.

headline: Did a Vaccination Ruse Hurt Children’s Health?
text: To the Editor:

headline: One Step Forward, More to Take
text: It was a profoundly important and deeply gratifying sight: Some of the top officers and civilian leaders of the United States military announcing at the Pentagon on Friday that they had, at last, given their approval to tearing down one of the last walls of official bigotry and discrimination in the United States.

headline: Herman Cain’s Bigotry
text: Among a dreary Republican field, Herman Cain stands out for using religious bigotry to gain political traction for his presidential ambitions.

headline: How the Deficit Got This Big
text: With President Obama and Republican leaders calling for cutting the budget by trillions over the next 10 years, it is worth asking how we got here — from healthy surpluses at the end of the Clinton era, and the promise of future surpluses, to nine straight years of deficits, including the $1.3 trillion shortfall in 2010. The answer is largely the Bush-era tax cuts, war spending in Iraq and Afghanistan, and recessions.

headline: Decoding Your E-Mail Personality
text: Ben Zimmer, a former On Language columnist for The New York Times Magazine, is the executive producer of VisualThesaurus.com and Vocabulary.com.

headline: Finding the Secret 11 Words
text: Sam Roberts is the urban affairs correspondent for The New York Times.

headline: Showdown in China Highlights Busy Month
text: There is no peak season for chess, but several overlapping tournaments are keeping top players busy.

headline: After Floods, Debate Over Missouri River Rolls On
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The meandering path of the Missouri River, charted by Lewis and Clark, once served as the main travel artery across the Great Plains, carrying people and goods between the comforts of St. Louis and the wilds of the Montana territory.

headline: Shooting Death Presents Test for a New Police Chief
text: As a police captain in San Francisco’s violent Bayview neighborhood, Greg Suhr operated from the streets. The stocky veteran schmoozed small-business owners and community leaders and prided himself on a culture of transparency. By the time he left this year, homicides in the Bayview had dropped by 50 percent.

headline: Sunday: Nine of Diamonds
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Welcome to the ninth inning of the week, the big grid, or, as some of us in the puzzle world call it, The Show. You have to be good to get to The Show, and Kurt Mueller is emerging from the minors to pitch us a puzzle full of punny baseball references. Settle in with your hot dogs and peanuts and enjoy the solve.

headline: Rise of Consumer Credit in Chile and Brazil Leads to Big Debts and Lender Abuses
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — For Ana María Silva, what began as purchases of perfume and two pairs of shoes spiraled into a credit card nightmare, as her debt multiplied tenfold in five years — and not all because of her spending.

headline: When Game Ends, Gulls Flock to Stands
text: It is a perennial late-game conversation starter at Giants home games: “How do the gulls know to swarm to the ballpark during the ninth inning?”

headline: Looking at the Mix for a Child-Friendly City
text: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: The Fernandez Mansion
text: The Fernandez Mansion is a rare local example of 19th-century architecture combining Second Empire French with elements of Queen Anne and Northern Italian styles. Perched near the waterfront in Pinole, the mansion, with its tower-like construction, gabled roof and projecting cupola, has the classic look of a haunted house.

headline: Justice Department Declines to Reopen Malcolm X Case
text: The Justice Department has declined a request to reinvestigate the Malcolm X assassination, saying that the statute of limitations has expired on any federal laws that might apply, like the National Firearms Act of 1934, according to a statement released Saturday.

headline: The City Payroll May Include a Few Too Many Bosses
text: In City Hall’s Department of Family and Support Services, the relatively small band of employees receive supervision from no less than one commissioner, 14 deputy commissioners, 4 assistant commissioners, 6 assistants to the commissioner and 17 others with the word “director” in their titles.

headline: A Plan for Chicago Too Big to Be Visionary
text: David Greising writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: A Fashionable Getaway, Saugatuck Battles Change
text: In the 1800s and early 1900s, Saugatuck’s harbor was where ships were loaded with tons of lumber, peaches and other goods from Michigan’s forests and fields and sent down Lake Michigan to Chicago. Chicago artists and architects flocked to the town, 140 miles northeast of Chicago, founding Oxbow, the century-old painting school now affiliated with the School of the Art Institute of Chicago.

headline: Marc Jacobs Store in Village Closes After Parts of Ceiling Fall
text: Though it was scalding hot outdoors and both an air-conditioner and a fan whirred invitingly in the Marc Jacobs women’s shop at Bank and West Fourth Streets in Greenwich Village, inside was the last place several employees wanted to be early Saturday afternoon.

headline: Hildy Johnson Would Have Happily Hacked
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Herzog Found at Comic-Con
text: SAN DIEGO—Werner Herzog has been found, here at the Comic-Con International convention, perhaps farther up the river than even Kurtz dared to tread.

headline: Adversity Creates a Boom for ‘Reclaimed Water’
text: FORT WORTH — At the plant that treats most of this city’s sewage, water sloshes and foams within giant concrete walls. This is cleaned-up sewage, made even purer by processes the plant expanded just a few months ago. Now some treated water runs through specially labeled, purple-colored pipes to irrigate nearby golf courses and a park, instead of just being dumped into the nearby Trinity River, as it had for decades.

headline: Readers Comment on My Budget Column
text: My Sunday column argues that we usually think of national security challenges coming from terrorists or enemy countries, but one major challenge to American national security right now comes from the grotesque mishandling of the Washington budget battle. A default would do enormous damage to American interests, and some of the Republican budget cuts — particularly in education — have already done the same. I wish we were as vigorous in standing up to domestic threats to national security as foreign ones, but we’re not. Read the column and post your thoughts.

headline: Beijing Bars Writers From a Literary Celebration, Continuing a Crackdown
text: BEIJING — For Chinese authors who join the international writers’ organization PEN, membership would appear to have very few privileges. Many of its members are subjected to frequent harassment; four of them are currently in prison, including one of its founders, Liu Xiaobo, the essayist and Nobel Peace Prize laureate serving 11 years for subversion. All told, the group counts 40 journalists, novelists and historians imprisoned because of their writings.

headline: In the City of Brotherly Heat
text: PHILADELPHIA — In Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia, the temperature was 100 degrees when Kyle Kendrick threw the first pitch against the San Diego Padres at 4:12 p.m., but the heat didn’t dampen the spirits of the officially sold-out crowd.

headline: Change in Rating Formula Creates Anxiety in Schools
text: On Friday, the Texas Education Agency will publicly release its annual accountability ratings for the state’s 1,000-plus school districts. School officials always eye this day with nervous anticipation, but this year many are feeling more than a twinge of dread.

headline: With Some Rich Car Fans, Formula One Could Work
text: Sebastian Vettel of Germany is dominating Formula One again this season, building on his 2010 championship with six wins in nine races. But that’s nothing compared with the underdog triumph that Formula One itself just pulled: getting money from the state of Texas.

headline: Tension Turns Into Approval Among ‘Spider-Man’ Fans at Comic-Con
text: SAN DIEGO — They came, they saw and some walked — several hundred Comic-Con attendees poured out of the giant Hall H about halfway through the “Amazing Spider-Man” presentation. But Sony Pictures Entertainment and its coming reboot of the “Spider-Man” series won the battle for fans’ hearts and minds at the fan convention on Friday.

headline: A Neophyte in the House, but Not in Politics, Sours on the Experience
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Players Committee Expected to Ratify N.F.L. Labor Agreement on Monday
text: N.F.L. players and owners made such significant progress on their remaining differences Saturday that tentative plans were being made for the players’ executive committee to meet in Washington on Monday. The hope is that they will vote to ratify the agreement that will end the lockout after more than four months.

headline: Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, Military Chief in 1990s, Dies at 75
text: Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, the first foreign-born soldier to become the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, died Saturday morning at an Army hospital in Washington State of complications after a stroke. He was 75.

headline: Charles Manatt, Former Democratic National Chairman, Dies at 75
text: Charles T. Manatt, a lawyer who founded one of the country’s largest law firms and served as chairman of the Democratic National Committee during the Reagan administration, died on Friday of complications stemming from a stroke. He was 75.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 24
text: With time running out for a deficit reduction compromise to avert a federal government default, all eyes are on President Obama and Congressional leadership. The Sunday talk shows are no exception.

headline: For Young Campers, Island Turned Into Fatal Trap
text: OSLO — It has been a rite of passage for Norway’s liberal elite for decades: a summer camp set on a verdant Nordic isle called Utoya, where this week hundreds of young people gathered to meet government ministers, dive into election strategy sessions and maybe find a little summer romance.

headline: James T. Molloy, Last Doorkeeper of the House, Is Dead at 75
text: James T. Molloy, the 34th and last doorkeeper of the House of Representatives, known for heralding the opening of joint sessions of Congress by bellowing “Mr. Speaker, the president of the United States!” from the rear of the House chamber, died on Tuesday in Rochester. He was 75.

headline: Warren Leslie Dies at 84; Wrote Book That Rankled Dallas
text: Warren Leslie, who in 1964 raised hackles in Dallas, his adopted hometown, when he contended in a book that a climate of right-wing extremism had primed the city to become the scene of a national tragedy — the assassination of President John F. Kennedy — died on July 6 at his home in Chicago. He was 84.

headline: CNN Host Is Dragged Into Phone Scandal
text: LONDON — It was perhaps inevitable that the phone hacking accusations in Britain would cross the Atlantic and reach Piers Morgan, the flamboyant former Fleet Street editor who is now the host of “Piers Morgan Tonight” on CNN.

headline: The Fans Needed Fans, Too
text: It was high noon on Saturday, about an hour before the first pitch at Yankee Stadium, where fans were anticipating several scorching hours and the possibility of the temperature reaching triple digits for the second day in a row.

headline: Norway Attacks Put Spotlight on Rise of Right-Wing Sentiment in Europe
text: BERLIN — The attacks in Oslo on Friday have riveted new attention on right-wing extremists not just in Norway but across Europe, where opposition to Muslim immigrants, globalization, the power of the European Union and the drive toward multiculturalism has proven a potent political force and, in a few cases, a spur to violence.

headline: Mets’ Santana Is Hopeful but Cautious About Return
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Johan Santana is scheduled to throw a bullpen session in front of the Mets’ coaching staff Sunday morning, which may be the last step before he starts pitching in minor league games.

headline: New York Detective Is Shot and Wounded in Miami Beach
text: An off-duty New York City detective was hospitalized in Miami Beach early Saturday after he was shot by assailants outside the hotel where he was staying, the authorities said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
With Water and Bobbleheads, Cincinnati Copes
text: CINCINNATI — A brief midday thunderstorm quickly gave way to sunny skies and staggering heat and humidity as the Reds faced the Atlanta Braves. The Reds offered fans free sunscreen and cups of ice, temporarily lifted a ban on open containers of water being brought into the ballpark and opened three air-conditioned rooms for distressed fans to escape the heat.

headline: Pakistan Spies on Its Diaspora, Spreading Fear
text: The article is by  Mark Mazzetti,  Eric Schmitt and  Charlie Savage.

headline: Aftermath of Norway Violence
text: As Norwegians began to cope with the killings in Oslo and on an island to the northwest, survivors met with their families and the search for bodies continued.

headline: As the Mets Reach 50-50, A Key Step For Santana
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — For five nearly impeccable innings, Chris Capuano pitched like an ace, holding the Florida Marlins scoreless on only two hits before they got to him for four runs in the sixth inning.

headline: March Against Egypt’s Military Collapses Into Violence
text: CAIRO — The first major protest aimed squarely at Egypt’s transitional military rulers ended Saturday night in violent clashes with neighborhood youths, who are opposed to the continued demonstrations that threaten stability.

headline: Kei Igawa: The Lost Yankee
text: Having been plucked from a Japanese baseball all-star team roster in 2007 and introduced at a lavish news conference, Kei Igawa was expected to be a staple in the Yankees’ starting rotation. But he didn’t last long.

headline: For Winehouse, Life Was Messier Than Music
text: She was just getting started. Amy Winehouse, dead at 27, was only two albums into a career, and a life, which would be derailed by alcohol, drugs and bad choices.

headline: Swim, Meet: The Joys of Public Pools
text: Public spaces almost universally serve as great equalizers, but perhaps none so much as the public pool. Los Angeles’s aquatics division operates 38 outdoor pools. New York City has 54, thanks in part to the controversial Parks Commissioner Robert Moses, who opened 11 enormous swimming pools in the oppressively hot summer of 1936, during the Depression. And there must be thousands covering the distance in between, millions of games of Marco Polo, hundreds of millions of handstand contests.

headline: Beacon Theater Returns to Elegance
text: A panoramic view of the newly restored Beacon Theater.

headline: Fertility Industry Under Scrutiny
text: Fertility clinics have come under pressure to reduce multiple births from in vitro procedures since Nadya Suleman gave birth to octuplets.

headline: The Beacon Is Back
text: The Beacon Theater, shut for seven months for restoration, will reopen with a celebratory concert by Paul Simon.

headline: Attacks in Kabul
text: Taliban suicide bombers staged coordinated attacks at government buildings in Kabul, killing at least 20 people and wounding 54 others.

headline: Corrections: July 24
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Gay Marriage | With a Kiss and a Vow, the Day Begins
text: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. — Against a cascade of rainbow-colored falls and with cicadas humming in the background, Kitty Lambert and Cheryle Rudd became one of the first, if not the first, same-sex couples to wed in New York State shortly after midnight on Sunday.

headline: Iranian Scientist Gunned Down at Home
text: Gunmen riding motorcycles fatally shot an Iranian scientist in front of his house in Tehran on Saturday, Iranian news agencies reported. It appeared to be the latest in a series of attacks that Iranian authorities have called an assassination campaign directed by Israeli, American and British intelligence agencies against the country’s nuclear program.

headline: Battle for Libya | July 23, 2011
text: Rebels took their positions outside the Bir-Ayyad gate near Zintan, 75 miles southwest of Tripoli.

headline: Adding Up the Government’s Total Bailout Tab
text: An overview of government support, beyond the $700 billion bailout known as TARP, given to companies from banks to car companies.

headline: Stump Takes Best in Show
text: Stump the Sussex spaniel took home Best in Show at the 133rd Annual Westminster Kennel Club show, becoming the oldest to win the award.

headline: Amid Tears, Flickering Candles and Flowers, a Shaken Norway Mourns
text: OSLO — Sunday was a day of remembrance and self-examination for Norway, a small country shaken by the massacre of at least 93 of its people, many of them children, by one of its own.

headline: Job Losses in January
text: Employers in the United States have shed about 3.6 million jobs since December 2007.

headline: Surfing the Rockaways
text: With the explosion of the surf scene in recent years, the profile of the Rockaways as a place to catch the waves is rising.

headline: Outside of Paris, a Castle Hosts Contemporary Art and More
text: Château de Blandy-les-Tours, a turreted castle about 45 minutes from Paris, has been rescued from 200 years of neglect and turned into an exhibition space that showcases contemporary art against a romantic backdrop of Medieval architecture. Its current show also has a particularly contemporary feel, referencing the recent political upheavals of the so-called Arab Spring.

headline: Train Wreck in China Heightens Unease on Safety Standards
text: BEIJING — A deadly train accident in eastern China has added to a national sense of unease that safety may have been sacrificed in the country’s rush to modernize.

headline: Gay Marriage | In Albany, Wedding Bells Ring Repeatedly
text: ALBANY— With regrets to the couples who took their vows at Niagara Falls, Dale Getto and Barbara Laven have a strong claim to the title of first same-sex couple married in the State of New York.

headline: Bin Hammam Is Latest FIFA Official to Go, but Cloud Remains
text: FIFA, the ruling body of world soccer since 1904, is shedding its senior executives in an attempt to appear to be moving faster than its corrupters.

headline: Gay Marriage | Waiting to Make History
text: The first day gay marriage is legal in New York.

headline: North Korean Envoy to Visit U.S. for Nuclear Talks
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A senior North Korean diplomat believed to be an important strategist in his government’s nuclear negotiations with the United States will visit New York this week to discuss restarting talks seeking to end the North’s nuclear weapons program, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Sunday.

headline: President Pushover
text: Updated: Drew article now available.

headline: Gay Marriage | First a Kidney, Now a Husband
text: For Michael Fury, 62, a husband may be the second most significant addition of the year. He received a new kidney in April, after five years on the transplant list.

headline: Hamilton Races to Second Victory of the Year at Nurburgring
text: NURBURGRING, Germany — For the first time in 15 races, Sebastian Vettel, the reigning world champion who is leading this year’s Formula One series, failed to start from the first or second position.

headline: Hamilton Races to Second Victory of the Year at Nurburgring
text: NURBURGRING, Germany — For the first time in 15 races, Sebastian Vettel, the reigning world champion who is leading this year’s Formula One series, failed to start from the first or second position.

headline: After Long Wait, Same-Sex Couples Marry in New York
text: Hundreds of gay and lesbian couples, from retirees in Woodstock to college students in Manhattan, rushed to tiny town halls and big city clerks’ offices across New York to wed in the first hours of legal same-sex marriage on Sunday, turning a slumbering summer day into an emotional celebration.

headline: Gay Marriage | At Least One Disappointed Caterer
text: As dozens of jubilant same-sex couples set out on Sunday to celebrate their nuptials in Queens, there was at least one disappointed resident.

headline: Gay Marriage | The Protesters
text: On Sunday morning, corsages, congratulations and rainbow umbrellas filled the sidewalks surrounding the city clerk’s office in Manhattan, but a few opponents of same-sex marriage fought to be heard above the joyous din.

headline: Gay Marriage | Traveling From Missouri to Staten Island for Big Day
text: For their first date, Steve Mulrooney and Jerome Van Wert rode the Staten Island ferry under the moonlight. They were so enamored with each other that night, under the stars and wrapped in a blanket, they didn’t realize they had docked until the boat’s captain told them they had to leave.

headline: Rival Debt Plans Being Assembled by Party Leaders
text: WASHINGTON — The House speaker, John A. Boehner, and the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, were preparing separate backup plans to raise the nation’s debt ceiling on Sunday after they and the White House were unable to form a bipartisan plan that would end an increasingly grim standoff over the federal budget.

headline: Gay Marriage | A Tribute to Two Moms in the Bronx
text: John Sullivan, 40, carried the rings: one gold, one silver, but otherwise identical and studded with minute diamonds from the wedding ring of his mother, Maryann.

headline: Gay Marriage | Woodstock, N.Y., 10:25 A.M.
text: A same-sex couple received the first marriage license Sunday in Woodstock, N.Y.

headline: Reader-Submitted Heat Wave Photos
text: Readers sent photos of how they were coping with the heat.

headline: Santana Feeling Good After Bullpen Session
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Johan Santana said he felt good after throwing 45 pitches in the bullpen Sunday morning, paving the way for him to begin pitching in minor league rehabilitation games.

headline: Never Too Old to Change, or to Win the Tour de France
text: PARIS — Cadel Evans became the first Australian and, at 34, the oldest man in 88 years to win the Tour de France on Sunday. He only wished Aldo Sassi had been alive to see it.

text: Inside the Brooklyn Community Room on the first floor of Borough Hall, newlyweds helped themselves to cake and Champagne, courtesy of the borough president, Marty Markowitz.

headline: Europe Turns to the Cloud
text: BERLIN — When the founders of Shutl, a British courier service that makes deliveries in 90 minutes in busy London, decided to set up a business that ran exclusively on cloud computing, they needed to get creative.

headline: Gay Marriage | Downtown Brooklyn, 10:40 A.M.
text: Christine C. Quinn, speaker of the City Council, witnessed the marriage of Justin Daniel, 32, right, and Joshua Cogswell, 35, in Brooklyn. The couple have been together for 10 years. When Mr. Daniel had trouble removing his ring so that Mr. Cogswell could put it back on for the ceremony — he had had it on for so long — Ms. Quinn unleashed one of her trademark belly laughs, joking that it reminded her of an “I Love Lucy” episode. Mr. Cogswell said that the couple had not expected the council speaker to attend their wedding, but that having the surprise guest “was awesome.”

headline: The 14th Amendment, the Debt Ceiling and a Way Out
text: WASHINGTON — A few days ago, former President Bill Clinton identified a constitutional escape hatch should President Obama and Congress fail to come to terms on a deficit reduction plan before the government hits its borrowing ceiling.

headline: Puerto Rico in History, Imagined and Real
text: KATONAH, N.Y. — On a cold, clear January day in 2008 Esmeralda Santiago walked downstairs to her office in her hilltop home here to immerse herself in writing the final pages of “Conquistadora,” her new novel. She was a week away from the deadline for this epic about her beloved Puerto Rico featuring a big cast of characters that includes the slave-driving, sugar plantation queen of the title, one Ana Cubillas. But when Ms. Santiago opened the computer document of her manuscript that day, the words looked something like this: Agttt Higg Bowq Sm. Pvxef byiz alwb.

headline: Gay Marriage | To Hyphenate, or Not to Hyphenate?
text: BUFFALO — The issue was names. Last names. Would they be adopting each other’s?

headline: Gay Marriage | For Many Judges, It’s Personal
text: Of the fourteen judges who volunteered to marry gay and lesbian couples in the Bronx, many had come forward for a reason.

headline: Europe’s Troubled Economies Join the Rescue Team
text: LONDON — Can a bailout fund whose backers include some of the countries it may be called upon to bail out really succeed? That’s the question being asked by skeptical investors about the European Financial Stability Facility — the rescue fund of 440 billion euros, or $632 billion, that is being given new, amplified powers to help the euro zone end the sovereign debt crisis.

headline: Means-testing Medicare
text: I’ve been thinking about this issue more since Friday’s duel to the death discussion with David Brooks, and have come to the conclusion that this is an even worse idea, on pure policy grounds, than even most liberals realize.

headline: Gay Marriage | Brookhaven, N.Y., 10:40 A.M.
text: Kelly Franke, 25, left, talks on the phone to her mother, Nancy, who is in Seattle and could not make it to her wedding to Courtney Scott, 25, beside her, at Brookhaven Town Hall.

headline: Greek Bailout Negotiator Predicts Some Benefits for Banks
text: The finance industry’s lead negotiator on debt relief for Greece said that though a deal reached last week would lead to write-offs at some institutions, the move would help assuage fears about the health of European banks.

headline: Gay Marriage | From Rehab to Vows
text: Gwendolyn Williams, 49, and Karen Cofield, 48, met in rehab. They were working through addictions to crack cocaine. Five years later, they’re still together, living on 167th Street in the Bronx, with a cat named MooMoo.

headline: Gay Marriage | After Islam, a Journey to the Altar
text: Diana Khan, 46, never thought she would be trading in her Muslim headscarf for a wife.

headline: Gay Marriage | Looking for Somebody to Marry
text: Andy Maskin came to the city clerk’s office in Manhattan on Sunday for a wedding two years in the making. It just wasn’t his own.

headline: Gay Marriage | An Officer Is Swept Up in the Moment
text: Perhaps it was the moment when the stern-faced New York police officer standing guard at the chapel door suddenly burst into tears that Israel Maldonado and Mark Massaro will always remember when they reminisce about their three-minute wedding ceremony in Queens.

headline: Dual Life of Singer-Songwriter and Brearley Senior
text: For Sarah Solovay, a New York City-based singer and songwriter who opened for John Mayer this spring, summers are particularly sweet. Ms. Solovay spends her days recording music and her nights performing on the Lower East Side or working on new music.

headline: Mulling a Future Without Beltran, the Mets Stumble Against the Marlins
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Concerned about how his team will react if and when Carlos Beltran is traded, Mets Manager Terry Collins has already begun to think about what he will say to his team after a potential deal that is expected to happen in the next week.

text: Hundreds of couples began marrying on Sunday in a new milestone for gay rights.

headline: Enthusiasm for Perry at Iowa Event
text: SEARSBORO, Iowa — Rick Perry is not yet in the race for president, but don’t tell the the people collecting e-mail addresses alongside tables for other, declared candidates at a gun-rights rally here on Saturday.

headline: Yankees Take Series and Hope to Keep Taking Advantage of Schedule
text: Against a wall in Nick Swisher’s locker hangs a season schedule that is the approximate size of a love seat. The dates during this homestand are unmarked, but if Swisher were a little more brazen, these 10 games would be circled and underlined, perhaps with fluorescent pink highlighter.

headline: Gay Marriage | After a Battle, a Celebration
text: One of the last weddings performed at Brookhaven Town Hall, on Long Island, was of Dan Evans, 67, and Jim Kelly (now Kelly-Evans), 62, who divide their time between the Fairmount section of Philadelphia and Cherry Grove, on Fire Island.

headline: This Week’s Economic Reports
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the S.& P./Case-Shiller housing price index for May; new home sales for June; consumer confidence for July (Tuesday); durable goods for June; the Federal Reserve’s beige book (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and pending home sales for May (Thursday); second-quarter gross domestic product; the Chicago PMI and Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for July (Friday).

headline: In China, Apple Finds a Sweet Spot
text: SHANGHAI — A year after opening a flagship store here, Apple has a problem that any retailer would envy: the huge 16,000-square-foot space is already too small.

headline: Writing Again, Third Point’s Loeb Takes Swipe at Obama
text: Daniel S. Loeb, the founder of Third Point, isn’t shy about speaking his mind.

headline: Moody’s Blues, Poor Standards, and the Debt
text: The invaluable Mike Konczal tells us the truth about the rating agencies and public-sector debt: not only do they constantly make mistakes, they do so in a consistent direction. Namely, they hold public-sector borrowers to vastly higher standards than they hold private borrowers.

headline: The Confidence Game at Google+
text: It’s extremely satisfying having just 20 friends on the new Google+.

headline: The Cool Ferocity of a King Inflamed by Jealousy
text: A thrill of true feeling runs through virtually every scene of the Royal Shakespeare Company’s production of “The Winter’s Tale” at the Park Avenue Armory. Scalding jealousy, hunger for revenge, young love in rapturous bloom, the soul-corroding sorrow of regret: all are evoked in the saturated colors that have sometimes been missing from the company’s New York repertory season this summer.

headline: Through a Portal, to a World Where Listless Blue Creatures Await
text: The Studio, as it’s called, is a rectangular room with a gray floor and a silver-tin ceiling. It is one of those anonymous places in Brooklyn — on an industrial block in Sunset Park — where dances are built and then delivered to a theater. For “Sugar doesn’t live here,” seen on Friday night, the choreographer Stacy Grossfield stays put.

headline: Passing Up Three No-Trump and Earning a Game Swing
text: At the Summer North American Championships in Toronto the final of the Morehead Grand National Teams Championship Flight was scheduled to end late Sunday. It was between District 9, Florida (Warren Spector, Michael Becker, David Berkowitz, Gary Cohler, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell), and District 6, Maryland, Virginia and Washington (Steve Robinson, Peter Boyd, Beth Palmer, Bill Pettis, Bill Cole and Steve Landen).

headline: Coming Up for Air in a Suffocating Life
text: E M A declaims more than she sings, though she can sing quite well. Sometimes she just mumbles. She’s got a husky voice, the sort that sounds bruised regardless of how it’s deployed. She owes something — many things — to the Velvet Underground, but without that band’s urbane grit.

headline: Steady Stream of Poses, Leaps and Everyday Chaos
text: In terms of watching dance in a park, the only circumstance more unappealing than SummerStage on its own — seeing dances with little or no nuance gets dull — is SummerStage during a heat wave. (Although it does help to imagine the life of a baseball catcher in August.) On a steamy Saturday night the festival offered a somewhat thematically random program, showcasing Jamel Gaines and his Creative Outlet Dance Theater of Brooklyn (the warm-up act) and Keigwin + Company (the headliner).

headline: Pursuing Answers, Two Years After a Tragic Collision
text: The story of Diane Schuler and the horrifying collision she caused is a series of mysteries that probably can’t be solved but that could, from some angles, be seen as fairly easy to explain. The layers of anger, guilt and what many would call blind faith that surround the case, however, have given it a tragic intensity, making the unanswerability of the questions seem profoundly painful.

headline: The Unluck of the Irish in Love, Soccer and Business
text: What the Chicago Cubs are to baseball, Ireland is to the global economy.

headline: Monday: Flowers on a Proverbial Path
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Mondays — the day, not the puzzle — are tough on everyone, but today we have a unique way to start off the week.

headline: In Movie of Mine Rescue, Producer Looks to His Roots
text: LOS ANGELES — In a study crammed with keepsakes of his Hollywood life, Mike Medavoy, the movie producer, keeps a black-and-white snapshot of some boyhood soccer pals. He is the gangly mop-top in the middle. The legend reads: “Chile, 1957.”

headline: La MaMa Lineup for 50th Season
text: La MaMa Experimental Theater Club has announced the lineup for its 50th season and is calling it Homecomings. It’s the company’s first full season since the death of its founder, Ellen Stewart, in January. A two-day celebration, on Oct. 16 and 17, to open the season and honor Ms. Stewart, above, will feature a World Block Party with Blue Man Group and the Silver Cloud Singers, among others, and a performance by Patti Smith at a La MaMa 50 Gala. Season highlights include a revival of the director and choreographer Ping Chong’s experimental 1985 play “Angels of Swedenborg”; a Hip-Hop Theater Festival; and the world premiere of “Stopped Bridge of Dreams,” a new work by John Jesurun. A new artists-in-conversation series, Monday Nights at La MaMa, is also scheduled and is to feature Julie Taymor, Philip Glass and other La MaMa alumni discussing their work. In a statement released by the company the artistic director, Mia Yoo, said the coming season would bring “together artists who have worked here through the years with artists who are new to La MaMa, creating a dialogue, an energy, whatever you want to call it, this combustible creative force that will move the theater into the next 50 years.”

headline: Captain America Outperforms His Peers
text: Superhero fatigue? Not at the North American box office, where the summer’s fourth major movie based on comic book characters, “Captain America: The First Avenger” (right, Chris Evans in the title role) was a strong No. 1 over the weekend, selling an estimated $65.8 million in tickets. That result beat the opening totals for the summer’s other three superhero films: “Thor,” “X-Men: First Class” and “Green Lantern.” The Disney-owned Marvel Studios, which produced the well-reviewed “Captain America” for about $140 million, and Paramount Pictures, which distributed it, had worried about competition from “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2” (Warner Brothers). But the boy wizard fell to second place in the second weekend, taking in about $48 million for a new domestic total of $274 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. “Friends With Benefits” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was third with an estimated $18.5 million. Showing continued strength, “Transformers: Dark of the Moon” (Paramount) was fourth, taking in about $12 million for a four-week total of $326 million. “Horrible Bosses” (Warner) chugged along in fifth place, selling an estimated $11.7 million for a three-week total of $82.4 million.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Villain Cited in Comic-Con Scuffle
text: Rhys Ifans, who has been cast to play a villain in “The Amazing Spider-Man” film next summer, was cited with a misdemeanor battery charge on Friday night in San Diego before a panel at Comic-Con International, the country’s most important comic book convention, in which he was scheduled to appear to promote the movie, according to TheWrap.com. The police said that Mr. Ifans, above, shoved a female security guard after a member of his entourage was unable to enter the hall where the panel was taking place. In a statement Lt. Andra Brown, a spokeswoman for  the San Diego Police, said that Mr. Ifans had been “abusive, belligerent and aggressive,” and that he had been given a citation. The panel was organized to quell fans’ doubts about the direction of the popular Spider-Man character. The movie is a large financial risk for Sony Pictures Entertainment, which plans a series of wall-crawling adventures featuring Andrew Garfield in the title role. “Rhys Ifans was detained by Comic-Con security after a brief incident backstage prior to and immediately following the ‘Amazing Spider-Man’ panel,” a Sony spokesman said in a statement. “Police were notified, and a citation was issued to Mr. Ifans, who deeply regrets this incident.” The film is to be released next July.

headline: Accuser of Strauss-Kahn Goes Public
text: The woman who has accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, of sexual assault in a Manhattan hotel room has granted her first interviews to Newsweek and ABC News, which will begin broadcasting segments of the interview Monday morning on its “Good Morning America” program.

headline: No Vaccine for Agony From Viral E-Mail
text: The readers to whom Helen Schulman’s novel “This Beautiful Life” will most appeal are those who already know everything about it. Ms. Schulman holds a mirror up to the lives of moneyed, elite New York private-school families and invites such people to nod in recognition. In terms of a less provincial audience “This Beautiful Life” should please anyone who enjoys seeing the destruction of a happy family framed as a self-fulfilling prophecy. The cover art depicts a house of cards. What might happen to that house of cards by the time Ms. Schulman’s story of a calamitous prep-school sex scandal is over?

headline: Mastering Self-Invention Then and Now
text: In the pseudodocumentary “Downtown 81,” Jean-Michel Basquiat is captured living out a day in the life of a downtown New York artist: heavy on hard luck, hoping someone will buy a painting of his to keep him afloat, but rich in friends and immersed in a circle full of musicians, artists, beautiful women and more.

headline: Four Pianists, Teaming and Competing
text: Bill Charlap and Bill Mays faced each other squarely across the 92nd Street Y stage on Wednesday night, each stationed at a piano, taking turns but hardly holding back. It was early in the second half of a concert called “The Key Players,” part of the Jazz in July series. A projection on the back wall showed both pianists’ hands at work as they imbued an aptly titled standard, “We Could Make Such Beautiful Music Together,” with an air of thoughtful, chummy competition.

headline: Bluegrass and Jazz Bands, With More in Common Than You’d Think
text: Del McCoury’s bluegrass group and the Preservation Hall Jazz Band did the proper adult thing on Wednesday night: they resolved their differences, surrounded by expensive claret.

headline: I Now Pronounce You ...
text: Hundreds of same-sex couples flocked to a New York City office to hear the long-awaited words, "I now pronounce you — married."

headline: Gawker Will Go to Court in Fox Investigation
text: Gawker, the popular blog based in New York, is going to court to investigate the relationship between the Fox News chairman, Roger Ailes, and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

headline: With Fan at the Helm, Marvel Safely Steers Its Heroes to the Screen
text: LOS ANGELES — Power in Hollywood is usually telegraphed in the least subtle way possible. People hopscotch to meetings by helicopter (Ryan Kavanaugh of Relativity Media), camp courtside at Lakers games (Jeffrey Katzenberg) and build HBO series around their antics (the superagent Ari Emanuel).

headline: ‘The Winter’s Tale’
text: Photos of the Royal Shakespeare Company’s production at the Park Avenue Armory.

headline: Rule Changes Proposed for Research on Humans
text: The government is proposing sweeping changes in the rules covering research involving human subjects, an effort officials say would strengthen protections while reducing red tape that can impede studies.

headline: Why Tyrants Love the Murdoch Scandal
text: Whether the scandal afflicting News Corp. represents the beginning of the fall of the House of Murdoch or just another thrilling episode in the career of the Teflon tycoon, I can’t say. There is plenty enough spectacle without speculation.

headline: At 100, Still Keeping Time as the Leader of the Band
text: NEW ORLEANS — At midnight last Saturday, friends and well-wishers sang “Happy Birthday” to the trumpet player who led the band that night at the Palm Court Jazz Cafe. When they finished, the trumpet player turned to a few young women sitting behind him.

headline: In Libya’s West, Signs of Growing Frustration With NATO
text: One of the consistent experiences of reporting alongside opposition fighters in Libya is feeling the delineation between what the rank and file have to say of the NATO bombing campaign and the statements of the officials in the Transitional National Council, the de facto rebel authority.

headline: N.F.L. Lockout Keeps Rookie Free Agents in Limbo
text: Chase Beeler, an all-American center at Stanford in 2010, has spent the last two weeks watching the N.F.L. Network and searching the Internet for clues about when his professional career might begin. He has not let the back-and-forth drama of the lockout’s last days bother him.

headline: ‘Free Culture’ Advocate May Pay High Price
text: A GUY walks into a candy store and sees one of those “leave a penny, take a penny” trays. He picks it up, cups his hands and asks, “What can I get for 68 cents?”

headline: As Familiar Face Contemplates Senate Run, Democrats Weigh Possibilities
text: BOSTON — Elizabeth Warren might still be weeks away from deciding whether she wants to run for the United States Senate. But with the news last week that Ms. Warren would be returning to Massachusetts, where she teaches law at Harvard, a sound-bite war about her potential candidacy started in earnest.

headline: The Meaning of Bull Run

It was a Sunday. Some people thought one major battle would be the very war itself, the beginning and the end, the resolution of decades of arguing over the place of slavery in the future of the United States.

headline: New Documentary Follows Leading Yiddish Writer’s Life in New York City
text: Sholem Aleichem arrived in New York in 1906 as the world’s most famous Yiddish writer — a distinction his comic but often disturbing stories of Eastern European life might have mocked as grandiose. Seeking refuge from Russian pogroms, he hoped to explore “the Golden Land” his readers were settling in and earn needed money as a playwright.

headline: The Maze of Moral Relativism
text: Relativism about morality has come to play an increasingly important role in contemporary culture.  To many thoughtful people, and especially to those who are unwilling to derive their morality from a religion, it appears unavoidable.  Where would absolute facts about right and wrong come from, they reason, if there is no supreme being to decree them? We should reject moral absolutes, even as we keep our moral convictions, allowing that there can be right and wrong relative to this or that moral code, but no right and wrong per se.  (See, for example, Stanley Fish’s 2001 op-ed, “Condemnation Without Absolutes.”)[1]

headline: Taliban Blamed in Death of Afghan Officer’s 8-Year-Old Son
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan —Kidnappers believed to be Taliban abducted the 8-year-old son of a police officer in southern Afghanistan, strangled him with a man’s shawl and dumped his body into a stream during the weekend, in apparent retaliation for the father’s refusal to give them his police truck.

headline: More Than Kin, and Less Than Kind
text: AT the hearing into the News of the World phone hacking scandal in London this past Tuesday, the commissioner of Scotland Yard did something unusual for a policeman. He quoted Shakespeare. Explaining the swiftness of his resignation, he mangled a bit of Macbeth: “If ’twere best it were done, ’twere well it were done quickly.” The reference was perfectly fitting for a scandal whose defining adjective is coming to be “Shakespearean.”

But what the president was offering to the G.O.P., especially on Medicare, was a very bad deal for America.

headline: PBS Announces Plans for 9/11 Anniversary
text: PBS has announced plans to commemorate the 10th anniversary of 9/11 with a mixture of new programs and repeats. The schedule, starting in the week leading up to the anniversary, is to include “America Remembers — 9/11,” a “PBS NewsHour” presentation exploring the lasting effects that the terrorist attacks have had across the United States; the New York Philharmonic 10th Anniversary Concert for 9/11, conducted by Alan Gilbert and taped the day before; and “Engineering Ground Zero,” about the construction of One World Trade Center, including interviews with the architect David Childs and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. “Frontline” will also contribute new programs and presentations of previous documentaries focusing on the response to the attacks. PBS.org will supplement the television shows with full-episode streaming.

headline: Oaths of Oddness: The Surprising Pledges of Comic-Con
text: In pop culture as in politics, there are consumers so discerning that they will not commit disposable income or cast votes unless they know in advance exactly what they’re getting from a blockbuster movie or a candidate for office, and these people want their commitments up front – preferably in the form of a verbal oath or written pledge. If you make such a declaration as an election contender, you might be abdicating your “governing responsibilities in a period of incredibly rapid change and financial stress,” as Thomas Friedman has written, but if you do so as the star or creator of a forthcoming fantasy-themed work, you might just be participating in Comic-Con International, which wrapped up in San Diego over the weekend.

According to his daughter, Blue began exhibiting symptoms of dementia about 15 years ago. His brain will be sent to Boston University for further study. headline: Many Historic Districts Have No Hardware to Show for It
text: When the city officially recognized Douglaston Hill in Queens as a historic district in 2004, the community celebrated. Three years later, residents of Dumbo, Brooklyn, breathed a sigh of relief when their neighborhood, too, finally won its historic designation. With landmarking, the neighborhoods’ buildings would be protected by the city and all changes to the area would need the city’s approval.

headline: Numberplay: The Bart and Lisa Paradox
text: Joshua Zucker is back to nourish our neurons. Before we begin, a quick note — let’s keep the conversation accessible for the first three days this week. If you’re a newbie (and aren’t we all in some ways?) this is the time to ask questions and throw out ideas. There are some terrific solvers in the Numberplay community. This is a great opportunity to mix it up with them.

headline: Australia and Malaysia Sign a Refugee Swap Deal
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Australia and Malaysia signed a refugee-swapping agreement on Monday that aims to stem the flow of asylum seekers to Australia’s shores. Although the plan promises that the migrants Australia will send to Malaysia will have more rights than the migrants already here, it has failed to satisfy refugee advocates, who accuse Australia of abandoning its international obligations.

headline: A Mixed Reception for Pandora
text: Pandora edged up modestly on Monday, even as analysts gave mixed reviews to the online music service.

headline: Copa América: Uruguay Tops Paraguay in Final
text: Uruguay claimed its record 15th Copa América championship on Sunday, beating Paraguay decisively in the final, 3-0, at the Estadio Monumental in Buenos Aires and reinforcing its claim as the best team in South America. Luis Suárez scored Uruguay’s first goal — his fourth of the tournament — and Diego Forlán added two for the champions.

headline: Heat Claims Life of Brooklyn Woman, 94
text: An ailing 94-year-old Brooklyn woman died from the heat on Saturday afternoon; it is the first heat-related death the city medical examiner’s office has certified this summer. The medical examiner’s office listed the cause of death, which occurred at 12:35 p.m., as “hyperthermia due to exposure to high environmental temperature with underlying natural disease.” It provided no other information about the woman or the circumstances of her death. At that time, the outside temperature was 92 to 95 degrees in New York City, the National Weather Service said.

headline: Draft Reform Law in Syria Fails to Mollify Protesters
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s cabinet has passed a draft law allowing the formation of political parties to work alongside the ruling Baath Party of President Bashar al-Assad, a step in a series of promised changes that antigovernment protesters have dismissed as superficial and useless.

headline: Equal Workloads for Husbands and Wives
text: Motherlode got its start with a magazine piece I wrote three years ago about the elusive goal of “equally shared parenting.” Back then I cited the latest figures from the University of Wisconsin National Survey of Families and Households, which showed that the ratio of housework done by women to that done by men was about two to one, that the child care ratio was three to one and that both measurements had been at those levels for decades.

headline: Chrysler And U.A.W. Open Talks On Contract

headline: London Theater Journal: Funny Then and There, Here and Now
text: LONDON — There is timely comedy, which is what most satire, stand-up and sitcoms are. And then there is timeless comedy, which, properly performed, should feel as old as the hills and as fresh as ocean air. Or in the case of “One Man, Two Guvnors,” Richard Bean’s smash play at the National Theater, ocean air scented with the fumes of warm beer, melting taffy and frying fish and chips.

text: BEIJING — Rescuers said Monday that they had recovered several more bodies from the wreckage of Saturday’s high-speed train collision in eastern China, putting the death toll at 39, including two Americans.

headline: Evolution Right Under Our Noses
text: To study evolution, Jason Munshi-South has tracked elephants in central Africa and proboscis monkeys in the wilds of Borneo. But for his most recent expedition, he took the A train.

headline: A Mystical Tale, From Tee to Green
text: For many golfers Michael Murphy’s 1972 novel, “Golf in the Kingdom,” is practically a sacred text. It’s about a young man, modeled on Mr. Murphy himself, who on his way to an ashram in India stops off in Scotland, where his life is transformed by an encounter with a golf pro and mystic named Shivas Irons, who knows as much about Pythagoras and the Hindu scriptures as he does about hitting a high fade. Several filmmakers have felt similarly transported by reading the book, and “Golf in the Kingdom” has been optioned or in development since before it was even published. Gus Van Sant was interested for a while. Sean Connery was approached about playing Shivas. Clint Eastwood fell in love with the book and clung to the rights for a decade or so before giving up.

headline: Varied Views of Obama’s Environmental Record
text: Yale Environment 360, an online publication of the university’s school of forestry and environmental studies, has rounded up some assessments of President Obama’s performance on environment and energy issues as his first term shifts into its home stretch. The commentary comes from people as varied as Joe Romm of the liberal Center for American Progress, who gives the president an “F,” to Kenneth Green of the libertarian American Enterprise Institute, who criticizes the president for letting the Environmental Protection Agency overstep its bounds.

headline: Drink Up | North Philly Beer, Part 1
text: On Poplar Street, between Second and Third Street in the Northern Liberties neighborhood of Philadelphia, there sits a placard placed by the Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission. It reads, “AMERICA’S FIRST LAGER: In 1840, John Wagner brought lager yeast from his native Bavaria and brewed the nation’s first lager beer. Later, other German immigrants began brewing lagers, which soon became popular & promoted growth of America’s brewing industry.”

headline: To the People Who Haven’t Saved Anything Yet
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: The Intern Blogger Returns
text: Good news for those who mourned the disappearance of Mumbles, the banking intern who began blogging pseudonymously this summer and promptly quit after two posts: a new Wall Street intern blogger has made his debut.

headline: Facebook iPad App Surfaces in iPhone App, Blogger Says
text: 2:09 p.m. | Updated Adding comment from Facebook spokesperson.

headline: A Perfect Vinaigrette
text: Melissa Clark, the author of the Good Appetite column, demonstrates simple ways to make great salad dressing.

headline: Russia Youth Group and Putin Distance Themselves From Killer’s Compliments
text: MOSCOW — A Russian youth group and Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin strove on Monday to distance themselves from positive references to them in the manifesto written by Anders Behring Breivik, the avowed anti-immigrant extremist who is the lone suspect in the mass killings in Norway.

headline: What the Well-Dressed Salad Is Wearing This Summer
text: Are you wilting faster than an overdressed salad? I am. It’s hot out, and to me that’s salad weather. (Actually, every season is salad weather to me, but I crave it more as the temperature rises.) The best-tasting salads rely on good greens lightly coated in a well-made vinaigrette, which is a snap to make once you know a few little tricks. The first is to always dissolve the salt in the acid before adding the oil. Then give it a good whisking or, even easier, shake, shake, shake it up in a jar. To see it all come together, watch my latest video.

headline: Video of Irish Leader’s Speech Attacking the Vatican
text: As my colleague Rachel Donadio reports, “the Vatican has recalled its ambassador to Ireland following the release of an Irish government report that the Vatican had discouraged efforts by bishops to report cases of sex abuse to the police.”

headline: Booing the Boy Next Door
text: MINNEAPOLIS — The limestone that covers the outer walls of Target Field is said to be 450 million years old. It was quarried in Mankato, Minn., and gives the park a warm kind of glow, not only from the outside but also from the dugout roofs, the backstop and the corner walls, near the foul poles. It is local, enduring and appealing.

headline: On Debt Talks, a Lose-Lose-Lose-Lose Situation
text: Endemol/NBC Universal Sorry, Howie Mandel: Deal or no deal, the American economy probably still loses.

headline: Two Shots of Hooch
text: Does anything stand out when you compare the following passages, the first from Raymond Chandler’s “Farewell, My Lovely,” the second from John Buchan’s “The 39 Steps”?

headline: Markowitz Fined $20,000 for Wife’s Free Overseas Trips
text: The city’s Conflicts of Interest Board fined the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, $20,000 on Monday for accepting free travel expenses for his wife on three overseas business trips. It was Mr. Markowitz’s second ethics violation of the year, and the fine was the largest the board has levied against an elected official.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Lucas Benini joined Buddy Media, New York, in a new post, managing director for Europe, as the company opens a European operation, based in London. Mr. Benini had been vice president and commercial director at comScore Europe, part of comScore.

headline: A Mobile Browser That Sips Data
text: Now that Verizon, AT&T and T-Mobile have dropped their unlimited data plans, some smartphone users need to be more careful about their heavy Internet use. Streaming video and audio are the worst data hogs, but browsing lots of Web pages can add up to a gigabyte per month or more.

headline: China Steps Up Web Monitoring, Driving Many Wi-Fi Users Away
text: BEIJING — New regulations that require bars, restaurants, hotels and bookstores to install costly Web monitoring software are prompting many businesses to cut Internet access and sending a chill through the capital’s game-playing, Web-grazing literati who have come to expect free Wi-Fi with their lattes and green tea.

text: Q.

headline: Paul Blevin, Waving the Flag Worldwide for IndyCar Racing
text: IRWINDALE, Calif. — At 5 years old, Paul Blevin wandered away from his mother at Lakeside Speedway in Kansas City, Kan. The worried Mrs. Blevin later found her child on the flag stand.

headline: Guess Who’s Tanking?
text: Many people feared a calamitous morning in the markets, as investors reacted to the continuing stalemate over the debt ceiling. Well, it has been fairly calamitous — but not for the United States. The big news, instead, is that Italian and Spanish spreads — the difference between interest rates on their bonds and interest rates on (presumably safe) German bonds — have widened drastically again. Last week’s big rescue plan apparently didn’t restore confidence.

headline: Group Readies Suit Seeking to Nullify Gay Marriages
text: An organization that opposes same-sex marriage said on Monday that it would file a lawsuit against the State Senate, seeking to overturn the legalization of such marriages and to nullify the hundreds of gay and lesbian weddings that have taken place in New York State since the law took effect on Sunday.

headline: Animal Planet Starts Filming on ‘Whale Wars’ Spin-off
text: The Sea Shepherd Conservation Society, the environmental group featured on the Animal Planet series “Whale Wars,” may be down one ship in its fleet at present, but that hasn’t discouraged that cable network from ordering a second series about the group and its efforts to halt whale hunts around the world. On Monday, Animal Planet announced that it had started filming on a program tentatively titled “The Faroe Islands Project,” which it said will chronicle Sea Shepherd’s campaign to stop an annual whale hunt known as “The Grind” in the Faroes, an island group and Danish protectorate between the Norwegian Sea and the Atlantic Ocean.

headline: Sun’s Rays May Leave Mysterious Marks
text: For adults and children alike, summer is the season to take in the mystery of the outdoors, its unexpected pleasures and hidden thrills.

text: Q. Why do some people become seasick while others on the same boat do not?

headline: With BlackBerry in Decline, RIM Will Shed 2,000 Jobs
text: As it struggles with the declining popularity of the BlackBerry line of smartphones, Research In Motion said on Monday that it would begin laying off about 2,000 employees, 10.5 percent of its work force, this week.

headline: Moderation Fails (Blog Issues)
text: The Times comment moderation software, which works badly even when it’s working well, is currently not working at all. I’ll come back to your comments later today, maybe.

headline: Pelosi Seeks Ethics Investigation of Wu’s Conduct
text: Democratic leaders in the House have called for an immediate ethics investigation into allegations that Representative David Wu, a Democrat from Oregon, engaged in unwanted sexual activity with a teenage daughter of a donor.

headline: Blame for Extinction Spreads to Methane Gas
text: Two hundred million years ago, at the end of the Triassic period, a mass extinction, often attributed to major volcanic activity, wiped out half of all marine life on Earth. But new research published in the journal Science suggests that the extinction was more likely to have been caused by the release of at least 12,000 gigatons of methane from the seafloor into the atmosphere.

text: You can sell effectively only if you are sold on what you are selling.

headline: Rocky Surprises on the Far Side of the Moon
text: The broad, dark plains on the Moon’s near side, visible to the naked eye, have long been known to be volcanic deposits made of basaltic lava flows.

headline: Food: Deal Will Help Build a Better Cassava
text: A roundabout deal for a tiny snippet of DNA that will help build a better cassava was announced recently by the Dow Chemical Company and the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center in St. Louis.

text: The new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has ignited fear on Wall Street. But many banks may eventually benefit from the regulator’s careful watch, according to a new report by Moody’s Investors Service.

headline: Think Global Gets a Russian Lifeline
text: A month after filing for bankruptcy, which marked the fourth time in the company’s history that it suffered a financial collapse, Think Global AS has been saved, again.

headline: Envoy Says U.S. Will Start Afghan Pullout, Slowly
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The new American ambassador to Afghanistan took the oath of office on Monday, saying in a succinct but personal speech that the United States would start to pull back from its engagement here — but only gradually.

headline: Oslo Court Relays Attack Suspect’s Statement
text: Updated | 5:43 p.m. As my colleague Steven Erlanger reports from Oslo, the 32-year-old man accused of devastating twin attacks that killed at least 76 people on Friday appeared at a closed arraignment hearing on Monday.

text: Well, actually on those who claim that both sides are at fault. From his Cooper Union address:

text: The Look: Electrifying – a neon yellow bouclé sheath is broken up by black leather trim, the effect of which is chic scuba-sporty.

headline: Norwegian Killer’s Father: ‘He Should Have Taken His Own Life’
text: STOCKHOLM, Sweden — The estranged father of the anti-immigrant extremist arrested for the mass killing in Norway said in an interview published Monday that he was shocked and despondent over the news and that his son “should have taken his own life, too.”
