headline: Debt Crisis Has Already Hurt Economy, Bloomberg Says
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, in a blistering critique of Washington politics, will argue on Monday that the failure of national leaders to reach an agreement on the debt ceiling has already done damage to the economy.

headline: ‘The Memory of All That’
text: When I started spending time with the man who would be my husband, I began to notice a strong and pleasing odor of coffee wafting up from his feet. Not only did his shoes smell good, they also occasionally contained a few grains of actual coffee grounds. This was, I soon discovered, the consequence of Nick having purchased an enormous and ancient coffee grinder from a defunct A&P in Vermont for eight dollars. In his tiny makeshift cabin on the edge of a forest in rural Connecticut there was only one electrical outlet wired seriously enough not to blow all the fuses every time he ground coffee, and it was in the back of his only closet. How could I not fall in love with a man whose feet smelled of freshly ground coffee?

headline: When Granny Met Gershwin, and Other Gossip
text: By all descriptions, the 1926 musical “Oh, Kay!” qualifies as light entertainment. But when the novelist Katharine Weber saw a 1989 revival, at the Goodspeed Opera House in Connecticut, the show came with weight attached. Its music was written by George Gershwin, who had been the lover of Kay Swift, Ms. Weber’s maternal grandmother, who may have inspired the show’s title character. In any case, one of Ms. Weber’s theatergoing companions, an old friend of the family, told her that Ms. Weber’s father had once been a beau of Ms. Swift, who had subsequently introduced him to her daughter, who became Ms. Weber’s mother. If that were true, then her father would have been her grandmother’s lover. The mind reels before this erotically annotated genealogy.

headline: Showdown Nears on Debt as Obama Warns of ‘Crisis’
text: WASHINGTON — The Democratic-led Senate and Republican-led House on Monday barreled toward a showdown on competing plans to cut spending and raise the debt limit as a resolution to the intensifying crisis remained farther from sight just one week before a possible federal default.

headline: Highly Anticipated Kanye West and Jay-Z Album Set for Release
text: After months of speculation on hip-hop blogs and in publications, Kanye West and Jay-Z announced on Monday that they would release their first album together, titled “Watch the Throne,” (Roc-A-Fella. Roc Nation/ Def Jam) on Aug. 8. But the record will initially only be available through iTunes. The album will go on sale in record stores and on Internet outlets four days later.

headline: Their Zeal Changed Lives, if Not the System
text: “Man down in the men’s washroom!” This cry is not part of the usual hospital soundtrack, but when Dr. David A. Ansell heard it as he sped down a corridor in the old Cook County Hospital in Chicago, he barely broke stride. He veered into the men’s room, tried the locked door of the stall where a crumpled body lay, hoisted himself up over the fetid contents of the adjacent toilet, balanced on the metal divider and prepared to descend and administer CPR.

headline: Ads Attack Republicans on Debt Ceiling
text: The debt ceiling debacle is now the subject of political ads against Republican members of the House.

headline: Another Legal Challenge to the City’s Charter Schools
text: Department of Education officials went out for drinks on Friday to celebrate the city’s preliminary victory in a lawsuit that sought to block 15 charter schools from sharing space in traditional public school buildings.

headline: Photo Replay: July 25
text: A gold medal in the 50-meter butterfly at the world swimming championships in Shanghai, a medal of recognition for Yao Ming upon his retirement from basketball and the end of the N.F.L. lockout.

headline: In Greek Debt Deal, Clear Benefits for the Banks
text: FRANKFURT — Europe's latest plan to prop up Greece looks suspiciously like a plan to bolster European banks.

headline: Weapons Retrieved in Iraq Point to Iran
text: VICTORY BASE COMPLEX, Iraq – Arrayed on a table in an air-conditioned room are the killing tools from attacks on American soldiers over the last several months – the detritus of munitions smuggled in from Iran, according to the soldiers here whose job it is to conduct the forensic analysis of evidence collected from the battlefield.

headline: CBS Wins Sunday Night With Familiar Shows
text: CBS once again held the top ratings spot for Sunday in both total viewers and adults 18-49 with two mainstays, “60 minutes” (8.2 million viewers) and “Big Brother” (6.9 million). They were followed by the debut of the network’s latest reality show, “Same Name,” in which a celebrity lives the life of an ordinary person who shares the same name; 5.3 million viewers watched the episode on Sunday featuring the actor David Hasselhoff. Future guests are to include Kathy Griffin, Mike Tyson and Reggie Bush of the New Orleans Saints. On AMC, “Breaking Bad” retained a large portion of its season-premiere audience with a total of 2 million viewers for the second episode. It was the second-most-watched episode in series history. “Breaking Bad” is ahead of last season’s viewership total by 30 percent.

headline: Beware of Banks’ Flawed Focus on Return on Equity
text: Anat Admati is the George G.C. Parker professor of finance and economics at Stanford University‘s graduate school of business and a co-author of “Fallacies, Irrelevant Facts and Myths in the Discussion of Capital Regulation: Why Bank Equity is Not Expensive.”

headline: Chinese Magazine Says Reporter’s E-Mail Was Hacked
text: Updated | 4:37 p.m. The independent Chinese magazine Caixin has said that unidentified hackers broke into the private Gmail account of one of its investigative reporters following the publication of articles that accused local government officials of taking part in child-trafficking.

headline: Default In A Liquidity Trap (Very Wonkish)
text: Nick Rowe asks a good question: if we took our models seriously, what would we expect the effects of threatened default to be on the larger economy? His answer is that expected default should work just like expected inflation, which means that if anything it should be favorable right now.

headline: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company at Lincoln Center
text: The Brooklyn-based artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the sixth in a series of graphite drawings he plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from Lincoln Center.

headline: Dolphin Tool Helps to Find Fare on Seafloor
text: In the 1980s it was discovered that some bottlenose dolphins in Shark Bay, Australia, rip up marine basket sponges from the seafloor and place them on their beaks for protection as they forage for food along rocky substrate. It is the only known instance of tool use by dolphins in the wild.

headline: Winehouse Autopsy Inconclusive; Sales of Singer’s Records Increase Online
text: Medical examiners in London were unable Monday to pinpoint what killed Amy Winehouse, the 27-year-old pop singer found dead in her home Saturday, and it will take at least two weeks before toxicology tests are completed, the Metropolitan Police said, according to the Associated Press.

headline: The Nature of a Lie
text: To the Editor:

headline: Catching Amy Winehouse
text: Like most of the media world, I learned that Amy Winehouse had died via Twitter, as my timeline filled up with heartfelt condolences from friends, fans and other musicians. M.I.A. even released a tribute demo.

headline: British Journalist Sells Book on Hacking Scandal
text: The hacking scandal in Britain has caught the attention of the publishing industry.

headline: TimesCast | July 25, 2011
text: The Norway attack suspect appears in court; Democrats and Republicans offer different approaches to raising the debt ceiling; and the N.F.L. lockout ends.

headline: Women’s Committee Backs 3 Democrats for House
text: Taking action against what it calls Republicans’ “war on women,” a political action committee that backs the candidacies of women who support abortion rights endorsed three Democrats on Monday.

headline: Putting Men on the Pill
text: For years, contraception has been mostly a woman’s responsibility. But now scientists are studying new treatments that may help men control fertility.

headline: On Jobs, the U.S. Is Turning Into Europe
text: Hide your kids, and hide your wives. Economists’ worse fears have come true: The United States has been slowly turning into Europe.

headline: Allowing Teenage Sex in Your House
text: I have written here about the work of Amy Schalet, who has studied the divergent ways that Dutch and American parents talk to their children about sex (the Dutch are more accepting), and the apparent effects on teen pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases in both countries (they are higher in the United States).

headline: She’s a Rainbow
text: In the artist Alia Penner’s eyes, everything looks better covered in rainbows. Not girly, pastel rainbows, but brilliant acid hues that bring to mind Peter Max and Sonia Delaunay. When the California-born artist isn’t painting rainbow-framed portals into alternate universes, she brings her pop psychedelic sensibility to album covers and posters for L.A. bands and happenings, helping to define the contemporary look of the city. Now, after dipping her toes into fashion with illustrations for Erin Wasson’s RVCA ad campaign and the hand-lettered titles for a Missoni film by Kenneth Anger, Penner, the former fashion editor of Arthur magazine, has introduced Mombi, a line of dresses named for a witch in Frank L. Baum’s Oz series, at Colette in Paris.

headline: 2012 Honda CR-V Concept Makes Web Debut
text: The fourth generation of the CR-V, Honda’s bread-and-butter mini-ute, is officially on track to reach showrooms by the end of this year, with a revised interior, some flashy new bodywork and a more fuel-efficient 2.4-liter engine.

headline: Regimens: Downside for a Urinary Infection Remedy
text: Women with recurrent urinary tract infections sometimes must take low-dose antibiotics for months to control the problem. Many prefer to try something less onerous, like cranberry extract or juice, which several studies have suggested can prevent these infections.

headline: A Forbidding Kingdom of Snow Leopards
text: Thomas McCarthy, director of the snow leopard program for the conservation group Panthera, has spent nearly two decades crisscrossing the absurdly rugged Himalayan plateau to study a magnificent, densely furred, rosette-stenciled cat that may well be the world’s most reliable no-show.

headline: RDG Capital Is Said to Demand Seat on DST Board
text: RDG Capital, the activist investment firm, has demanded a seat on the board of DST Systems, the data processing company, as well as the appointment of two additional independent directors, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Evolution on a small island, running with the elephants and is Alzheimer's disease preventable?

headline: Patterns: How Milk Is Expressed Affects Nursing
text: When a newborn fails to latch onto the breast or suck successfully, mothers can express their breast milk by hand or by using an electric pump. A new study suggests that those who express by hand are more likely to still be nursing two months later.

text: Photographs from Norway, England, Egypt and Israel.

text: SANA, Yemen — Fighting in southern Yemen intensified in recent days as tribesmen in Abyan Province sided with government troops against Islamic militants.

text: Five men speak about mourning the loss of their wives and how grieving with other men has helped.

text: A selection of images from your ceremonies and celebrations.

headline: Bargains on Used Goods May Prove Costly
text: In the heat of summer, when yard sales and flea markets are in full swing, it is tempting to take advantage of sidewalk bargains on everything from toys to hedge trimmers. But caution is in order: Buying used can be hazardous to your health, experts say.

text: When Jon M. Huntsman Jr.‘s campaign manager quit last week, his presidential advisers promised that he would soon become more aggressive.

headline: Biting the Bullet, Vermont Yankee Orders Fuel
text: Unless a court intervenes, the clock is winding down on the Vermont Yankee nuclear reactor. Its initial license expires next March, and the state of Vermont is blocking a permit that it needs to run beyond then.

headline: A Nora Who Could Text All Her Discontents
text: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — The whinny of the paper shredder into which a fate-changing letter is dispatched inspires startled laughter in the Williamstown Theater Festival’s production of “A Doll’s House,” starring Lily Rabe as the theater’s most famous door slammer, Nora Helmer.

headline: Childbirth: A Drug Shortens Labor but Does Little Else
text: The drug Pitocin is a safe and effective way to speed childbirth, a new review of studies has found, but it does not reduce the number of Caesarean sections or forceps deliveries.

headline: ‘Rec Room’ Is the New Way to Expand an Apartment
text: Selling real estate in New York has long involved its own sort of code. “Quiet” means dark, back-of-the-building; “cozy” means small; and “flexible” means “not really,” as in the “flex 1BR” that is actually a studio with a nook. But as developers seek to wring every last bit of space out of their projects, another term has cropped up more and more: “rec room,” meaning an underground space that is not legally a bedroom, although many people use it that way.

headline: Point and Shoot and Sightsee
text: Leica cameras and Lonely Planet travel guides have teamed up for photo-oriented city tours.

headline: Video Shows a Suspect’s Escape From Arrest
text: The police are looking for help in tracking down a nimble man who broke the tackles of two officers who tried to arrest him for urinating on a car on Christopher Street in the West Village and then raced off into the wee hours of Sunday morning.

headline: Correction

Neither precaution is necessary, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. More information can be found at cdc.gov/vaccines.

headline: Englander Said to Be Looking to Sell Millennium Stake

headline: Can Technology Prevent the Death of Children Left Behind in Cars?

They were followed by the debut of the network’s latest reality show, “Same Name,” in which a celebrity lives the life of an ordinary person who shares the same name; 5.3 million viewers watched the episode on Sunday featuring the actor David Hasselhoff.  Future guests are to include Kathy Griffin, Mike Tyson and Reggie Bush of the New Orleans Saints. text: To the Editor:

headline: Helicopters Jam the Skies Above Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES — Helicopters swooped low over the Sepulveda Pass the weekend of July 16 to monitor the shutdown of Interstate 405. The week before, paparazzi helicopters hovered as Prince William and his wife, the Duchess of Cambridge, settled into Hancock Park. Indeed, every day brings a steady swarm of buzzing copters crisscrossing the vast Southern California sprawl in what many officials say are greater numbers than ever before.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Back to the Future’
text: This week, A. O. Scott remembers the ’80s and the ’50s with the high-energy Robert Zemeckis comedy/adventure “Back to the Future.”

headline: Intern Rising | Victoria Horning Handbags
text: “I never carried a real handbag until I started designing them,” says the debutante accessories designer Victoria Horning. “But now, every morning I take the bag I choose to wear so seriously!” Horning, a 24-year-old Manhattanite who graduated from some of fashion’s most prestigious prep schools (read: internships at Vogue, Alexander Wang and Nina Ricci), had terrific experience and no place to tote it. So, she started a label, making bags and cummerbunds out of calf hair, leather, alligator and stingray. It was a relatively modest project — that is, until word got out and her girlfriends wanted in. Today, the made-in-New York collection features six handbags, including the off-white lambskin one that Horning chose for her appointment with T (above). “I just hope to see lots of girls wearing them, especially the Kates,” she says. “You know, Bosworth and Moss.” Oh, yes.

headline: It’s Fashionable to Take a Trip to Another Universe
text: The thing about parallel universes — which may be great or terrible — is that in theory they don’t collide.

headline: Men in Grief Seek Others Who Mourn as They Do
text: In 1990, Sam and Gretchen Feldman cashed out on their share of a national chain of men’s apparel stores and retired to Martha’s Vineyard, Mass. There, they devoted their time to volunteer work and an active social calendar. The following years were golden ones for the Feldmans, but in 2007 Mrs. Feldman learned she had cancer. She died a year later.

headline: How Men Experience Grief
text: The loss of a loved one is a profoundly heartbreaking experience, but it is not the same for everyone, as reported in Tuesday’s Science Times.

headline: Migraine Miseries Push Patients to Ways of Coping
text: The news that the presidential candidate Michele Bachmann suffers from severe migraines has touched off a national discussion about a surprisingly common disorder that is little understood and often undertreated.

headline: Dramatic Brush Strokes From Strings
text: From Haydn’s time on, quartets have been laboratories in which composers can experiment freely, using the ensemble’s balanced texture as ballast for their boldest ideas and often finding ways to charm and startle at the same time. For its second and final contribution to this year’s Summergarden series at the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art, on Sunday evening, the New Juilliard Ensemble offered a concise overview of contemporary quartet composition that touched on several contrasting approaches: among them the painterly, the emotional, the dramatic and the abstract.

headline: Codebook Shows an Encryption Form Dates Back to Telegraphs
text: If not for a computer scientist’s hobby of collecting old telegraph codebooks, a crucial chapter in modern cryptography might have been lost to history.

headline: Paying Tribute to New York, by Way of Brazil
text: The Brazilian rapper Marcelo D2 named his 2003 album “Looking for the Perfect Beat” after a song by the rapper Afrika Bambaataa. But in a career that has made him one of Brazil’s top rappers, Marcelo D2 chose two beats rather than one: the samba of Rio de Janeiro, where he was born, and the old-school hip-hop of New York City.

headline: On This Field, Regulators Find No One Is Too Big to Fail
text: “Too big to fail” is something to be feared and loathed in Washington — except on the softball field.

headline: Summer’s Treasure: Tomatoes
text: Elizabeth Eckholt, a chef in Northern California who specializes in “healing” foods, believes that greens, cucumbers, celery and seaweeds help maintain health by preventing the body from becoming overly acidic. This notion gives me pause, and for one big reason: I love tomatoes, and they are notoriously acidic.

headline: You Pursue a Wall Street Cabal. Or Do You?
text: For 250 years Bydder Financial has been one of the most powerful forces in the global economy. It has underwritten the expansion of American multinational corporations, shaping the destiny of smaller countries to suit the priorities of the United States and of Bydder itself. From its august headquarters on Broad Street, barely a block from the New York Stock Exchange, Bydder stands astride international commerce like a colossus (or perhaps Croesus).

headline: Survivor Describes Moments of Terror in Attack in Norway
text: OSLO — Tore Sinding Bekkedal cowered in a bathroom for most of the 90 minutes during which a Norwegian gunman unleashed his carnage on Friday on the island of Utoya, a sanctuary for center-left political debate among Norwegian youth.

headline: Early Media Prophet Is Now Getting His Due
text: OTTAWA — By the time Marshall McLuhan died in 1980, the once provocative voice that had propelled him to international stardom rare for an academic had been silenced by a stroke. In his home country, Canada, he had become something of a national embarrassment, often seen as an eccentric at best, a charlatan at worst.

headline: Michael Jackson Tribute Is Announced, Then Questioned
text: Several members of Michael Jackson’s family announced plans on Monday for a grand tribute concert in October. But those plans were immediately called into question when Jackson’s estate said it had not authorized the event, and two of Jackson’s brothers said they would not support it because the event was scheduled to take place during the criminal trial of Jackson’s doctor.

headline: Worker at Gowanus Tunnel Site Is Injured in Fall

headline: Volleys Fly in House Debate on E.P.A. and Interior

headline: City Room: Apple’s Plans for Grand Central Terminal
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is gearing up to face a new challenge in traffic control: managing the masses of people lining up at Grand Central for the latest Apple release or Shake Shack burgers. At the transportation authority’s committee hearings Monday, the agency’s director of real estate, Jeffrey Rosen, confirmed that in the coming months Apple will open a store wrapping around the east side of the balcony at Grand Central terminal and a Shake Shack restaurant will open up in the basement, around the corner from the Oyster Bar. Read the entire blog post on City Room.

headline: Contract Talks May Delay Soap’s Move to the Web

headline: Tribes Watch and Wait After Karzai Brother’s Killing

The white stone has a quiet to it that stands in stark contrast to the din he left behind.

headline: Shame and Responsibility: A Response
text: Writing about guilt feelings can open the floodgates to readers’ own painful and unresolved guilt, but also to outrage at those who should feel guilt, but don’t.  The probing and rich comments I received online and by e-mail about my essay, “The Moral Logic of Survivor Guilt,” touched on both responses and set me thinking more about the appropriateness of various guilt feelings.

headline: News of the World’s Desperate Final Hours
text: As day broke over Libya a few weeks ago, so did reports that News of the World hacked the phones of a murdered teenager, the victims of the 7/7 London bombings and possibly soldiers killed in Iraq and Afghanistan. I was on a 410-foot-long British Navy warship that was firing missiles into Libya, covering the war for News of the World. I called my boss. “It couldn’t be much worse, son,” he said. “Get home.”

headline: Unsettling Wariness in Norway, Where Police Are Rarely Armed

He has become a magnet for people trying to escape fear and the cooped-up life caused by violence.

text: OSLO — This is one of the most placid and pleasant capitals of Europe, but Oslo is a divided city. The west of the city is rich, safe and predominantly white; the east, poorer, less safe and populated by immigrants, many of them Muslim.

It also lets private creditors off lightly while making taxpayers elsewhere in the euro zone pay through the nose. It doesn’t even mean the end of the crisis.

headline: California: Half of ‘Dream’ Act Signed
text: Gov. Jerry Brown signed into law Monday legislation that would allow illegal immigrants to receive privately financed scholarships for state universities. The bill is part of package known as the California Dream Act, which would entitle those students to the same kind of state aid that American citizens and legal residents can receive. That bill has passed the state Assembly, but has not come to the floor for a vote in the Senate. The Democratic-controlled Legislature has passed similar bills in the past, but they were vetoed by then-Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, a Republican. Mr. Brown is a Democrat.

headline: Wins and Answers Out of Reach for Mariners
text: The expansion Mariners pulled on their trident caps in 1977, and the logo choice might have angered Poseidon: fourteen consecutive losing seasons followed. They once employed a player whose surname came to epitomize offensive futility. Only one of the 28 cities that currently boast major league teams has never hosted a World Series game. That would be Seattle, and there seems a better chance of Starbucks banning coffee than that streak ending this October.

headline: For Dogs, Entrees From Same Butchers Who Feed Their Masters
text: From the moment Mookie tasted his new dog food, he was a forever-changed Jack Russell terrier. He devoured that first meal, his tongue lapping even the underside of the bowl, desperately searching for more. And then Mookie, who is 9, started barking — at the refrigerator.

headline: Israel: Dead Sea Arms Smuggling
text: The Israeli military said it intercepted a rubber dinghy that was carrying 10 assault rifles and 10 ammunition clips as it made its way Monday across the Dead Sea to the West Bank from Jordan. A military spokeswoman said two Palestinians on board were arrested and the event was being treated as a smuggling attempt rather than a terrorist attack.

headline: Tiny Fists Hold Tight
text: Mutton busting, a kind of rodeo with children riding sheep, used to be the stuff or back corrals and halftime entertainment. But it is attracting a wider, more suburban audience and becoming a real competition.

headline: Little Lambs, Not the Sheep, Get Early Lessons in the Rodeo Life
text: AURORA, Colo. — Kaden Bustamante tottered out of the rodeo arena after the brief, rough ride he had endured on a careening mount landed him face down in the dirt. He spit dust from his mouth and tried to stanch the blood that had begun to pour from his nose.

headline: Where Can You Hide 12 Volcanoes? (Hint: It’s Big and Blue)
text: Here’s a reminder that we know more about the topography of Mars than that of the Earth’s ocean-covered regions and that there is much remaining to be discovered here on our home planet.

headline: The All-Seeing Eye
text: In the aftermath of Bull Run, Washington was invaded — not by Confederate troops, but by a horde of stragglers, limping back in various degrees of discombobulation and post-traumatic stress. Some were soldiers, some simply hangers-on who had come out for the show and lost their way in the fog of war. One of the stranger-looking refugees was a short, bearded man with a straw hat and spectacles, and a watch fob dangling from his belt — along with a sword concealed awkwardly under his overcoat. A contemporary said he looked like “a Paris art student.” This confused apparition, more comical than belligerent, was Mathew Brady, the most famous photographer in the United States. Appropriately, he went straight to the nearest camera, and promptly recorded a not-very-heroic moment in American history.

headline: As Trade Talks Linger, the Mets Try to Move On
text: CINCINNATI — That Carlos Beltran, the Mets’ star right fielder, will be traded in the coming days is almost inevitable, his departure from the team an apparent formality. Only the details remain in the air, and conjecture regarding his impending departure will hang in the Mets clubhouse until a trade is completed.

Making things even more difficult, many employers, staffing agencies and online job-posting firms are expressly screening out applicants who are unemployed, apparently as an expedient to cull résumés, or on the presumption that the unemployed are poor performers.

headline: Tuesday: Can’t-Miss Event
text: Administrivial Lollapuzzoola-Flogging Alert! This just in from the “Be More Smarter” team: If you cannot make it in person to the insanely fun day that is Lollapuzzoola 4 on August 6 — and I highly recommend it, it’s a blast — hosts Brian Cimmet and Patrick Blindauer are offering the “staycation” play-at-home version for a mere $10. It’s not quite like watching Brian try to find the source of the irritating chirping noise in the room in person, but it’s the next best thing. The puzzle suite will be available to non-attendees during the week of August 7-14 ONLY. After August 14, the puzzles go back into the Lollapuzzoola vault (i.e., the constructors’ personal files), and they will not sell another copy, so hurry and place your order now!

headline: Turkey: Sentence in Editor’s Death
text: An Istanbul court sentenced a man to almost 23 years in jail on Monday for the killing of an ethnic Armenian journalist who criticized nationalist tendencies in Turkey. The man, Ogun Samast, an ultranationalist, shot the journalist, Hrant Dink, in January 2007. The death of Mr. Dink, the editor of the only Turkish-Armenian bilingual newspaper in Turkey, led to public discussions about the way Armenians are treated.

headline: For Giants, Many Free Agents and Little Cap Room to Spare

headline: Hospital Executive Bribed 3 Lawmakers, Judge Is Told

headline: Congress in the Lead

headline: This Is Considered Punishment?

The bank was Wells Fargo, which was also fined $85 million and ordered to compensate customers it had unfairly — indeed, illegally — taken advantage of during the subprime bubble.

headline: Federal Auditors Will Soon Review Health Insurance Rates in 10 States

headline: Louisiana: Judge Is Asked to Provide New Oversight for BP Fund
text: Lawyers suing BP over last year’s oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico have filed a brief asking a federal judge in New Orleans to take over the $20 billion fund that the company established to compensate victims. The lawyers argue that the fund has only paid some 16 percent of “interim” claims from people with continuing damage, calling it an “abject failure.” The fund, administered by Kenneth R. Feinberg, has paid $4.8 billion so far in emergency and final claims, including hundreds of millions of dollars in interim claims. Mr. Feinberg has argued that many claims are presented with inadequate documentation, and said, “20,000 interim claims and the payment of over $250 million is not exactly evidence of failure.” The brief also called for Judge Carl J. Barbier of Federal District Court to declare invalid the final settlements’ provisions releasing BP and other companies involved with the spill from further suits.

headline: Lincoln Center Announces New Discussion Series
text: Business, not cultural affairs, will be on the breakfast menu at Lincoln Center this fall as the Center begins a morning series where leaders will “discuss significant issues facing American society.” Reynold Levy, the center’s president is to announce the breakfast series on Tuesday.

headline: Michael Cacoyannis, Director of ‘Zorba the Greek,’ Dies at 90
text: Michael Cacoyannis, a Greek filmmaker whose art-house films and adaptations of Euripides for stage and screen were critically acclaimed, but who was best known as the director of the 1964 Hollywood hit “Zorba the Greek,” died on Monday in Athens. He was 90.

headline: The Republican Wreckage
text: House Republicans have lost sight of the country’s welfare. It’s hard to conclude anything else from their latest actions, including the House speaker’s dismissal of President Obama’s plea for compromise Monday night. They have largely succeeded in their campaign to ransom America’s economy for the biggest spending cuts in a generation. They have warped an exercise in paying off current debt into an argument about future spending. Yet, when they win another concession, they walk away.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Trade-Deadline Observations
text: If you have a pitcher who is a candidate to be traded — James Shields, Jeff Niemann, Erik Bedard, Hiroki Kuroda or Wandy Rodriguez, for example — things are more likely to get worse than they are to get better. That’s because most of the prospective buyers are teams in hitters’ parks. None of the teams with the most extreme pitchers’ parks — the Mariners, the Rays, the Athletics, the Padres, the Mets, the Dodgers or the Marlins — are buying right now, and that means your pitcher is likely to wind up in Yankee Stadium, Arlington, the Great American Ballpark, Miller Field, U.S. Cellular Field or some other place where baseballs tend to fly into the seats. The presumably better run support will help, as will not having to face that team’s offense anymore, but if you’re a Shields owner, you would probably rather the deadline come and go uneventfully.

headline: The Beaches of Paris Return to the Banks of the Seine
text: You may not be able to go snorkeling in the Seine, but this summer, Paris has again transformed the banks of its river into a Caribbean-like beach paradise. In 2002, Bertrand Delanoe, the mayor of Paris, inaugurated the idea of Paris Plages. Open through Aug. 21, the beaches offer an unusual perspective on the city and a great opportunity to slow down between museum and monument visits.

headline: Who Made That Penny?
text: The penny is a neglected coin. Frequently orphaned on the street. Mercilessly taunted for its mediocrity. In an age of trillion-dollar debt and billion-dollar bank bailouts, America’s lowest common denomination seems to bear little value as an individual monetary unit. Yet the copper-toned coin bearing Lincoln’s profile still holds a unique place in our national identity. Phrases like Benjamin Franklin’s “A penny saved is a penny earned” and the actual artifact itself (shown above is a photographic penny spectrum by the designer Bob Dinetz,) are as American is it gets. The same cannot be said of the origins of its designer.

headline: The End of Eurosclerosis

This vision had some truth in the 1990s, but was becoming less and less true even before the crisis, which hit US employment much harder than European employment.

headline: Getting To a Deal
text: Last night’s prime-time back-and-forth between President Obama and John Boehner was interesting political theater, and a useful digest of the arguments (“shared sacrifice” versus “no new taxes”) that we’re going to hear a lot over the next year or so — both in the presidential election and, if we only get a short-term increase in the debt ceiling, in the run-up to the next round of deficit brinksmanship. But it felt irrelevant to the endgame that’s currently taking shape in Congress. The president will almost certainly sign any bill that can pass both houses of Congress, and we’re down to three scenarios for how that happens. Assuming that Boehner can muster enough Republican votes to pass the plan he announced yesterday — which would cut a trillion dollars in discretionary spending, raise the debt ceiling for six months, and then empower yet another bipartisan commission try to negotiate a longer-term deal — and assuming that Harry Reid can find the votes to push his plan, with similar spending cuts but a longer debt-ceiling extension, through the Democratic-controlled Senate, then some compromise between the Boehner plan and the Reid plan seems like a natural solution to the impasse. (Ezra Klein has one plausible example of what such a compromise might look like.) However, enough Republicans regard Boehner’s plan as a sellout to begin with that the speaker of the House might not be able to make that compromise, in which case it becomes a question of who cracks first: Enough moderate Senate Democrats to push the Boehner plan through that body, or enough moderate House Republicans to push a version of the Reid plan through the House. (Note that Nancy Pelosi has endorsed Reid’s plan, suggesting that most House Democrats would vote for it if necessary.)

headline: ‘New’ Mike Hammer Novels by Mickey Spillane to Be Published

The independent publisher Titan Books said it had acquired the worldwide and digital rights to three unpublished Mike Hammer novels from Spillane’s archives that would be completed by the mystery writer Max Allan Collins and released between 2012 and 2014.

headline: U2 Documentary Will Open Toronto Film Festival
text: Long before Bono and the Edge were best known as the composers of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” they and their U2 band mates Adam Clayton and Larry Mullen Jr. were more immediately associated with best-selling rock albums like “Achtung Baby.” It is this more felicitous time in the band’s history that is revisited in Davis Guggenheim’s documentary “From the Sky Down,” which will open the 2011 Toronto International Film Festival, the festival’s organizers said on Tuesday. The new film from Mr. Guggenheim, the director of “An Inconvenient Truth” and “Waiting for Superman,” will chronicle the creation and legacy of “Achtung Baby,” the 1991 U2 album that included hits like “One” and “Mysterious Ways,” using archival footage and new interviews. It will make its debut at a gala presentation on Sept. 8.

headline: Everyone Should Learn Japanese
text: OK, maybe not. But you really shouldn’t be commenting on current economic events unless you’ve studied the last time a major economy found itself up against the zero lower bound on interest rates. Those of us who had paid attention to Japan knew that large increases in the monetary base wouldn’t be inflationary and that large government borrowing wouldn’t drive up interest rates. Those who hadn’t got it completely wrong.

headline: Brooklyn Girl, 10, Dies From Heat
text: A 10-year-old Brooklyn girl died on Saturday from the heat, combined with an underlying medical condition, the medical examiner’s office said. Medical examiners released no information about the girl other than the time of death, 6:25 p.m. The high temperature on Saturday was 100 degrees. A 94-year-old woman also died Saturday of the heat, combined with an underlying disease.

headline: Man Booker Prize List Ranges Far and Wide
text: An eclectic group of 13 writers was chosen on Tuesday for the longlist of this year’s Man Booker Prize, considered the most prestigious award for fiction in the English-speaking world. Stella Rimington, the chairwoman of the judges, said in a statement: “We are delighted by the quality and breadth of our longlist, which emerged from an impassioned discussion. The list ranges from the Wild West to multiethnic London via post-cold war Moscow and Bucharest, and includes four first novels.” The prize honors what the judges deem to be the best novel of the year by an author in the former British Commonwealth, Ireland or Zimbabwe.

headline: London Theater Journal: Nothing Rings True Like Authenticity
text: LONDON – I heard the city singing as I walked along the South Bank on Monday night. O.K., what I really heard was just people talking – and occasionally yelling, barking or squealing. As usual. But because I had just left a show in which the line between song and speech had been thoroughly dissolved, my ears were suddenly tuned into previously unheard melodies lurking in human conversation. I felt kind of like Gene Kelly being an American in Paris, but in a grimmer, more reflective mood.

headline: Notes From the Underground | The Pablo Picasso
text: As I pushed my way to the front of the thick crowd in the basement of Santos Party House, I encountered no less than a dozen shirtless dudes throwing themselves around, whirling sweat and crowd surfing. The Pablo Picasso were playing what could be described as the soundtrack to the March of the Alpha Male, and I expected them to look the part. On the contrary, the band of five boys is refreshingly nerdy in appearance. The endearingly scrawny lead singer could easily be mistaken an I.T. tech who broke free of his keyboard and grabbed a microphone, were it not for his surprisingly deep baritone wailing over heavy, rolling drums. The curator and photographer Tim Barber, who hosted the party, looked pleased with the chaotic state of affairs in the mosh pit, as he ambled about, pressing extra rolls of film into my hand to be sure the moment was documented.

headline: ‘Swamp People’ Haul In Big Ratings
text: Cable television loves shows that pit the hunter vs. the hunted, and a crunching of last week’s Nielsen ratings reveals that a new king of the genre can be crowned. “Swamp People” on History, which follows Cajun alligator hunters who fight for their lives and their livelihood in the Louisiana swamp, pulled in 5.5 million total viewers for its Season 2 finale last week, overtaking “The Deadliest Catch” on Discovery, which had 3 million total viewers. It was the most-viewed cable show last Thursday in total viewers. Among all Thursday programming, including the broadcast networks, “Swamp People” was only bested by “Big Brother” in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic and finished the season up 32 percent over the viewership totals from Season 1. It also cracked the top 10 in the weekly cable chart at No. 6. Overall, History dominated the top of the chart with “Pawn Stars” (at No. 1 and No. 3, with just under 6.7 million and 6.4 million viewers, respectively) and “American Pickers” (at No. 5 with 5.6 million viewers).

headline: TimesCast | Breivik Pleads Not Guilty

headline: Vote on Boehner Plan Delayed Amid Opposition
text: WASHINGTON — House Republican leaders were forced on Tuesday night to delay a vote scheduled on their plan to raise the nation’s debt ceiling, as conservative lawmakers expressed skepticism and Congressional budget officials said the plan did not deliver the promised savings.

headline: Off the Dictated Path in North Korea
text: PYONGYANG, North Korea — A little boy skips along grasping a classmate’s hand, his cheeks flushed and a badge of the Great Leader’s smiling face pinned to his Winnie the Pooh sweatshirt. Men in military green share a joke over beers at a German-style pub next door to the Juche tower. Schoolgirls wearing the red scarves of the Young Pioneers sway in unison as they sing a classic Korean tune that I, too, learned as a child.

Missing those perfect loafers on eBay by mere seconds or logging on to a Gilt sale after it’s already been ravaged by the hungriest shoppers can be a major letdown. So, T editors scoured the Internet and designed a foolproof guide to shopping the best discount sites. Happy clicking!

text: The mischievous Web site Gawker has marketed a T-shirt, aimed, you assume, at especially odious young people, that reads: “Yes, I am quietly judging you.” If there is to be a Second Coming, I hope Jesus will be good-humored enough to wear his.

headline: Amazon’s Profit Falls, but Beats Expectations, as Company Invests

headline: At the Jersey Shore, at the End of His Rope
text: If you’re contemplating suicide by hanging, keep in mind that it’s sensible to have that last cigarette before stepping onto the chair. That’s the little, um, life lesson enacted with bleak comic panache in the opening moments of “All New People,” a slick and slight but lively new comedy by Zach Braff at the Second Stage Theater.

headline: Conspiracy Theories About Republicans and the Economy
text: In the last few days, several readers, economists and radio hosts have asked me whether I buy the most cynical interpretation of the debt crisis stalemate: maybe Republicans are reluctant to raise the debt ceiling, or are calling for austerity measures that could slow the recovery, because they actually want the economy to do badly. That way voters will demand a change in political leadership, and vote more Republicans into office in 2012.

headline: On Tap or in Bottles, a Chef’s Brews
text: Anderson Sant’anna De Lima is fermenting, blending and conditioning nine different beers in a warren of former offices in the basement of his restaurant, 508 GastroBrewery, in SoHo. A brewer at heart, he said becoming licensed in his native Brazil was too complicated, so he became a chef. Then, two years ago, his wife, chef and business partner, Jennifer Sant’anna Hill (the couple are shown above), bought him a home-brewing kit for Christmas. For the last month he has been serving his beers.

headline: Making New Yorkers Say Cheese, Smile or No

headline: Lots of Fish Swim at Huge Asian Store
text: The choices are almost mind-boggling at Sky Foods, a 36,000-square-foot supermarket in a new shopping mall in Flushing, Queens. The seafood department stocks 30 kinds of live fish and shellfish, including Dungeness crabs for around $7.99 a pound, a nasty-looking freshwater fish called marble goby and, soon, live frogs. Meats have a vast counter and are also sold precut in packages, like fresh beef tendon, whole partridges and elegant rounds of sliced duck gizzards. The owner, Chung Fat Supermarket Group, which has other markets in the borough, and Ed Wu, the manager, have made a particular effort to stock organic Asian produce. Dried noodles line both sides of a 60-foot aisle. “Some of these noodles I can’t even name,” Mr. Wu said.

headline: That’s Not Trash, That’s Dinner
text: LAST week in Chelsea, Mich., as people wilted and vegetables flourished in the intense heat, Anne Elder ran through some of her favorite summer ingredients: pearly garlic “rounds” that flower at the top of the plant in hot weather, the spreading leaves of the broccoli plant, yellow dandelion flowers that she dips whole into batter and deep fries.

headline: ‘The Camping Cookbook’
text: In “The Camping Cookbook,” Annie Bell, an English food writer, (her “Gorgeous Vegetables” won us over), shows how to cook and serve food beyond hot dogs with no real counter space, and limited sources of heat and clean water. Pack a cutting board and a small grill. Wash produce at home. Freezing meat, poultry or bottled drinks turns your cooler into an icebox.

headline: Legend Bar and Restaurant
text: LEGEND Bar and Restaurant, a Sichuan restaurant in Chelsea, circled the block for months before parking in its current spot as one of the city’s top Chinese destinations.

headline: Met and Chorus Union Agree on Contract
text: The Metropolitan Opera and the union representing choristers, stage managers, dancers and staff directors have reached an agreement on a new three-year contract, officials said on Tuesday. Talks were continuing with the other two major unions at the Met, those representing the stagehands and orchestra. The agreement with the American Guild of Musical Artists, which covers the chorus, was reached in May and ratified on June 19 during the Met’s tour of Japan. Met officials wanted to hold off on the announcement until the other two contracts were settled. The chorus agreement was to have expired on Sunday, the same day that the other two agreements end: with the orchestra, represented by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians; and the stagehands, represented by Local 1 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees. The guild employees received 2 percent raises for each year. The talks are being led by Joseph Volpe, the former general manager, who was succeeded by Peter Gelb. Mr. Volpe himself is a former stagehand and is considered well versed in labor matters at the Met. The Met finished this year without a deficit but has an accumulated deficit of $51 million, Mr. Gelb said. Pension funds are $78 million underfunded, and the endowment is $243 million, more than $100 million off its peak before the recession. “We have large financial weights hanging on our backs that we are constantly reminded of,” he said.

text: A Tasting of Italy

headline: Fatal Fall at a Ballpark Brings Higher Railings and Awareness

headline: Share Your Stem-to-Root Recipes

A few guidelines: using peelings for stock or soup doesn’t count; neither do recipes for beet greens, turnip tops and other common ingredients; and of course, please steer clear of apple seeds, cherry pits and other plant material with toxic potential.

headline: Lions, Check. Giraffes, Check. Squirrels, Check. Squirrels?

And getting a good look at a springsnail requires one to squint hard, preferably into a magnifying glass. But both creatures are among the latest additions to the Phoenix Zoo, where they are being held in safekeeping because of a worse-than-average fire season that has threatened their fragile habitats.

headline: Romney and Perry: Dual Front-Runners?
text: At the betting market Intrade, Texas Gov. Rick Perry has overtaken Mitt Romney and is now considered the most likely person to win the Republican presidential contest. Mr. Perry is given a 35 percent chance of claiming the nomination as compared to Mr. Romney at 29 percent; Michelle Bachmann is a distant third place and assigned a 9 percent chance of winning.

text: The manifesto of the man charged in the Norway attacks spells out plans for using anthrax as part of his war to defend Europe against what he called the rising threat of Muslim domination.

headline: A Decision for Clean Air
text: Federal mandates under the 1970 Clean Air Act have produced cleaner cars, fuels and factories, significantly improving the air Americans breathe. Yet the underlying standards setting limits on ground-level ozone, the main component of harmful smog, have remained unchanged since 1997 — even as science has made it abundantly clear that the standard is still not strong enough to protect public health.

headline: Iowa Polling to Test Paul’s Move to Mainstream
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — Representative Ron Paul has a message for the ardent followers who read his books with a highlighter and donate to his fund-raising “money bombs” on the Internet: Winning the Iowa Straw Poll next month would “rock the establishment.”

headline: Winehouse, Breivik and Deadly Ideals
text: The news often reads as if written by a hard-line surrealist. Look at the morning’s home page or front page headlines: The world appears to be nothing but a series of nonsequiturs, bizarre conjunctions at every turn, a bundle of isolated phenomena with no apparent meaning or connection. Take two very recent events, each of them entirely singular, extraordinary, and in their different ways tragic. Just a few days ago, I read about them on the same page of a newspaper, immediately adjacent to one another, separated only by a thin black line. I was shocked by the proximity. It was like an oxymoron, or a Zen koan, I couldn’t make any sense of it. Amy Winehouse and Anders Behring Breivik.

headline: Chavez Comes Off the Disabled List and Into the Yankees’ Lineup
text: It had been so long since Eric Chavez saw his name on the Yankees lineup card that as he got dressed Tuesday afternoon, he admitted he was not sure when he had last played in a major league game.

headline: Nominee to Lead Joint Chiefs Warns Against Deep Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, President Obama’s nominee to be chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, warned on Tuesday that proposed cuts in the military budget of up to $1 trillion would be “extraordinarily difficult and very high risk.”

headline: Major League Soccer’s Annual Showcase Poses a Real Test

headline: Irradiation and the ‘Ick Factor’
text: After the E. coli outbreak in Europe last month — which sickened more than 3000 people and killed at least 50 — it was impossible not to think about irradiation. “What if,” I asked myself, “those little fenugreek seeds had been irradiated?” Might there have been fewer deaths, fewer cases of hemolytic-uremic syndrome (essentially, kidney failure; there were 900), fewer tragic stories?

Read the article here, and come back to comment.

headline: N.F.L. Begins Very Short Off-Season

That was a change from the timeline the league had set out earlier in the day the lockout was put to rest, and it was so unexpected that at least one team told an agent it did not see the note for several hours after it was sent.

headline: Ripple Effects of a Messy Divorce: A Tenant’s Eviction

Moments later, the children’s mother emerged in tears, her arms held back by two officers, as her daughter and sons wailed, neighbors cursed and passers-by stopped to shake their heads and stare.

text: Less than one-fifth of the world’s forests are intact, and every year about 30 million acres are destroyed. With pressure on forests only expected to increase, the race is on to find a balancing point between commercial and conservation interests.

headline: Weiner’s Exit Sets Off a Race to Be Israel’s Better Friend
text: Assemblyman David I. Weprin, the Democratic candidate to replace former Representative Anthony D. Weiner in a special election on Sept. 13, is a Modern Orthodox Jew who keeps kosher, observes the Sabbath and has been to Israel at least eight times. So it comes as a surprise that, at this early stage of the short campaign, New York’s Ninth Congressional District finds itself talking about an unlikely subject — whether Mr. Weprin, who is unabashedly pro-Israel, is the best pro-Israel advocate.

headline: Giants Cutting Ties to Shaun O’Hara and Rich Seubert
text: As the Giants’ headquarters reopened for business, they wasted little time reordering their roster Tuesday, telling the veteran offensive linemen Rich Seubert and Shaun O’Hara, two pillars of their Super Bowl team of four seasons ago, that they would be released.

headline: A Joyous First Swim, but a Risky One
text: For a group of Israeli and Palestinian women, a day on the town and a swim in the ocean were acts of civil disobedience.

headline: Where Politics Are Complex, Simple Joys at the Beach
text: TEL AVIV — Skittish at first, then wide-eyed with delight, the women and girls entered the sea, smiling, splashing and then joining hands, getting knocked over by the waves, throwing back their heads and ultimately laughing with joy.

headline: A Sharpie Campaign, Aimed at Teenagers, Urges Self-Expression
text: SHARPIE, whose permanent markers were immortalized by NFL receiver Terrell Owens when he pulled a Sharpie out of his sock to sign a football after scoring a touchdown, is turning to more minor celebrities to promote its products.

headline: Storing Water for a Dry Day Leads to Suits
text: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — Peter Key knew something was strange when the water levels in his tropical fish tank began to go down last summer. Then the washing machine took 40 minutes to fill, and the toilets would not flush.

headline: A Trade Barrier to Defeating AIDS
text: In Friday’s Fixes column, I wrote about the Medicines Patent Pool, a new organization trying to make AIDS drugs better, cheaper and available sooner to people who need them in poor countries.   It relies on voluntary donations of rights by patent holders, most of them pharmaceutical companies.   Its success is crucial;  new research shows that if we can dramatically increase the number of people on antiretroviral medicines, we can not only save millions of lives, but potentially cause the epidemic to die away.

text: John B. Mattingly, the commissioner of the Administration for Children’s Services, is stepping down after seven years on the job, the mayor’s office announced on Tuesday.

headline: Wednesday: The Problem With These Clue
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — There are those who believe that there are only a limited number of original ideas left for crossword themes and there are those who believe that original ideas are limitless and can come from anywhere. I tend to fall somewhere along the middle of that spectrum. Even if the way an idea is presented is not entirely original, I still appreciate and admire a theme that is solidly constructed and has some great entry/cluing combinations.

Another envisioned an urban farm to draw children, as well as all-important grant money from foundations. Others pictured a dog run, an amphitheater, a sculpture garden and a music barge.

headline: The Reid Plan vs. the Boehner Plan
text: With only days to go before the deadline to raise the debt limit or face national default, there are two plans on the table: the Reid plan endorsed by President Obama; and the Boehner plan, which Mr. Obama has suggested he would veto if it ever reaches his desk.

headline: Negotiators Nearing Deal on Mileage for Vehicles
text: DETROIT — The Obama administration and automakers are nearing an agreement to increase fuel economy standards for vehicles to 54.5 miles per gallon by 2025, a lower target than the White House had sought.

headline: A Denial of Reality
text: How can so many Republican lawmakers justify pushing their country toward catastrophic default just to score ideological points? The answer can be found in their statements and writings: They are constructing an alternative reality far different from that of most Americans.

text: Credit rating agencies have been questioning Congress about its credibility. Now, Congress gets to turn the tables.

headline: Lebanon: Bomb Hits U.N. Convoy
text: A roadside bomb planted at the entrance to the southern port city of Sidon struck a United Nations convoy Tuesday, wounding five French soldiers, one of them seriously, the United Nations said. The attack comes just two months after another bomb near the same spot wounded six Italian peacekeepers. Prime Minister Najib Mikati ordered an investigation, though there was no immediate claim of responsibility.

headline: Can’t We Do This Right?
text: There is only one thing worse than Republicans and Democrats failing to agree to lift the debt ceiling, and that is lifting the debt ceiling without a well-thought-out plan and with hasty cuts totaling trillions of dollars over a decade. What business do you know — that is still in business — that would operate this way: making massive long-term cuts, negotiated by exhausted executives, without any strategic plan? It certainly wouldn’t be a business you’d expect to thrive. Maybe you can grow without a plan. But if you cut without a plan, you will almost surely hit an artery or a bone that could really debilitate you. That, I fear, is where we are heading.

headline: Affluent Buyers Reviving Market for Miami Homes
text: MIAMI — South Florida is the default capital of the country. Here in Miami-Dade County, one out of five households with mortgages is in foreclosure. Nearby Broward and Palm Beach counties are not far behind. Nearly 200,000 South Florida families are stuck in the mire of default.

headline: Consequence of Lower Ratings

headline: 4 Are Charged in Drug Sting
text: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan announced Tuesday that they had charged four men from other nations, including Iran and Lebanon, in connection with sting operations run by the Drug Enforcement Administration. Two men were charged with conspiring to provide material support to Hezbollah, which the United States considers a terrorist organization. Officials said they sought to buy surface-to-air missiles from informants working for the D.E.A. One of the men, along with a third defendant, was also accused in a heroin conspiracy to benefit Hezbollah. Another man, an Afghan, was charged with narcoterrorism conspiracy in a scheme to move arms and money to the Taliban, officials said.

headline: Not O.K. at the O.K. Corral
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Perfect, No, but One to Remember
text: David Cone was in the Yankees’ clubhouse Tuesday afternoon, showing a group of fans around as part of some charity work. Everywhere he went, he was greeted warmly, with players and coaches and staff shaking his hand and smiling. Cone was part of four championship teams with the Yankees, but he is remembered, as much as anything else, for his one day of perfection: July 18, 1999, when he retired all 27 Montreal Expos he faced in pitching only the third perfect game in franchise history.

headline: Georgia: Mother Gets Retrial in Jaywalking Death
text: A judge on Tuesday granted a retrial to a woman who was sentenced to probation for her role in her 4-year-old son’s death in a street-crossing accident. The case of Raquel Nelson, 30, has prompted a national outcry from parents and lawyers who argue that it would be unfair to make her spend up to three years in jail because she allowed her young son, A. J., to cross the street outside of a crosswalk. He was killed in an Atlanta suburb in a hit-and-run accident in October. Before the judge granted the retrial, a jury had sentenced Ms. Nelson to a year of probation on a misdemeanor charge of vehicular homicide. The driver served six months in jail for the crime. Ms. Nelson’s lawyer said she would probably accept the retrial in order to disprove her guilt, even though that would reopen the possibility of jail time.

headline: A Mighty Few and India’s Richest Rich
text: More than 60 percent of India’s billionaire wealth resides with just 11 individuals or families.

headline: Among Twists in Budget Woes, Tensions Over Teaching the Deaf

headline: Class-Consciousness in the Office Building Market
text: There are roughly 400 million square feet of commercial real estate in Manhattan, an amount equal to more than 9,000 acres. For the last three decades, as the office market grew and matured, brokers and tenants began slicing that space into classes that signaled a building’s amenities and location and, of course, the rent that its landlord could charge.

headline: Neglected Manhattan Transit Hub Is to Undergo a Major Makeover
text: For decades, the George Washington Bridge Bus Station in Upper Manhattan has seemed like the also-ran of Manhattan transportation hubs.

headline: Access to Health Care Benefits for Gay Partners Is Gauged
text: WASHINGTON — In the first comprehensive count of domestic partner benefits by a federal government agency, the Bureau of Labor Statistics found that about one-third of all workers had access to health care benefits for same-sex partners.

headline: G.D. Spradlin, Prolific Character Actor, Dies at 90
text: G. D. Spradlin, whose experience as a corporate lawyer, independent oilman and rancher influenced his nuanced portrayals of authority figures in more than 70 films and television shows, including “The Godfather: Part II” and “Apocalypse Now,” died on Sunday at his cattle ranch in San Luis Obispo, Calif. He was 90.

text: CINCINNATI — Terry Collins stood in the visiting manager’s office here at Great American Ball Park late Tuesday, his face conveying equal parts admiration and disbelief.

headline: Dan Peek, of the Rock Band America, Dies at 60
text: Dan Peek, an original member of the rock band America who later forsook the group for a life in Christian music, died on Sunday at his home in Farmington, Mo. He was 60.

headline: Frank Foster, Jazz Saxophonist, Composer and Arranger, Dies at 82
text: Frank Foster, a saxophonist, composer and arranger who helped shape the sound of the Count Basie Orchestra during its popular heyday in the 1950s and ’60s and later led expressive large and small groups of his own, died on Tuesday at his home in Chesapeake, Va. He was 82.

headline: Troubled Olympian Kills Himself, Police Say
text: Jeret Peterson, a charismatic, pioneering United States Winter Olympian who won a silver medal in the freestyle aerials during the 2010 Vancouver Games, was found dead in a remote Utah canyon Monday night in what police are calling a suicide.

headline: How Exercise Can Keep the Brain Fit
text: For those of us hoping to keep our brains fit and healthy well into middle age and beyond, the latest science offers some reassurance. Activity appears to be critical, though scientists have yet to prove that exercise can ward off serious problems like Alzheimer’s disease. But what about the more mundane, creeping memory loss that begins about the time our 30s recede, when car keys and people’s names evaporate? It’s not Alzheimer’s, but it’s worrying. Can activity ameliorate its slow advance — and maintain vocabulary retrieval skills, so that the word “ameliorate” leaps to mind when needed?

headline: Colleges Join Plan for Faster Computer Networks
text: A coalition of 29 American universities is throwing its weight behind a plan to build ultra-high-speed computer networks — with Internet service several hundred times faster than what is now commercially available — in the communities surrounding the participating colleges.

The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack on the mayor, who held dual citizenship in Afghanistan and the United States.

In attendance were David Strickland, the N.H.T.S.A. administrator; auto industry representatives; child safety proponents; technical experts; and a mother whose child died from hyperthermia this year.

headline: Touring London’s Houses of Parliament
text: Even without the excitement of the phone hacking scandal hearings taking place there, London’s Houses of Parliament make a fascinating destination. Home to the British Parliament for over 450 years and, before that, home to the royal family, they offer a unique view into the government of Great Britain and its daily workings.

headline: Bring It, Readers: Sentence of the Week Needs You
text: Our critic-at-large, Sam Anderson, is on vacation this week. But Sentence of the Week marches on without him! Or at least it’s going to try. To fill the gap Sam left behind, we need your sentences. When he returns from Japan, he will select a sentence of the week from among your contributions. Please write in with the very best sentence you read this week.

headline: Plan Would Keep Qaddafi in Libya, but Out of Power
text: WASHINGTON — With Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi showing no signs, so far, of yielding to Western demands, diplomats from the United States, Britain and France have adopted a new tactic in recent days: offering the besieged leader the opportunity to remain in Libya if he dissolves the government and steps aside.

headline: The Very Picky Customer
text: We got a call from a potential client a week ago Monday, which isn’t unusual. We get two or three calls every day. Our phones are set up so that they all ring whenever a call comes in. I sit within a couple of feet of my other two salesmen, Don and Nathan, and whoever is free grabs the call. I happened to be in the middle of writing an e-mail that day, so I let it ring and Don picked up. He answered: “Paul Downs Cabinetmakers, Don speaking, can I help you?”

headline: A Last Call at the Oak Room at the Plaza
text: Every time Jaelin Sarper, a teacher from Singapore, visits New York, she makes sure to spend time savoring one of her favorite local icons. It’s not the Statue of Liberty or a trip to Magnolia Bakery for cupcakes. She makes her way to the Oak Room at the Plaza Hotel where she had her first martini, bought by her father.

headline: British Women Face Hurdles and Indifference
text: No amount of sideways rain at Royal St. George’s could obscure the view that the sun is shining on the British empire. The British Open began with three men from the British Isles among the top four golfers in the world and ended with a fourth, Darren Clarke of Northern Ireland, clasping the claret jug.

headline: Scorecard: Republican Supporters and Opponents of Boehner Plan

headline: Stinger: James O’Keefe’s Greatest Hits
text: The temperature was hovering near 90 degrees on the afternoon of Memorial Day when James O’Keefe III emerged from the woods and ambled over to my car. He was tall and thin, with pale skin and matted reddish hair. When his mug shot ran in the papers, some people told him he looked like Matthew Modine. Others said Lee Harvey Oswald. On the day I met him, he wore muddy work boots, filthy jeans and, despite the heat, a long-sleeved shirt. “Keeps the mosquitoes off,” he said. All day he was in the outback of a regional park just west of the Hudson, breaking rocks with a pickax to construct a trail. As a boy he was an Eagle Scout, but this wasn’t a nature project. O’Keefe, the man whose video stings helped take down high-ranking people at National Public Radio and led to the demise of Acorn, the nation’s biggest grass-roots community organizing group, was doing federal time.

headline: Apes From the Future, Holding a Mirror to Today
text: THE evolution of species takes place over millenniums. Pop-culture franchises just don’t have that kind of time. Rupert Wyatt’s “Rise of the Planet of the Apes,” opening Aug. 5, is the seventh film about the peculiarly advanced simians invented by Pierre Boulle in his 1963 novel “Planet of the Apes” and the first in 10 years. The last “Apes” picture, directed by Tim Burton, was a remake of Franklin J. Schaffner’s original 1968 adaptation of the Boulle novel; the first film generated four sequels, a couple of TV series (one live action, one animated), a line of comic books and a jungleful of merchandise before the brand began to peter out, ceding its dominance to other, stronger market beasts like “Star Wars” and “Batman.” The apes had a nice run, but nothing lasts forever. Species die out. Empires fall. Profits decline. New heads of studios rise.

headline: Babies to Heroes: A Field Guide to Big-Screen Men
text: THERE are times, particularly during the summer, when the big screen seems overrun with the alpha and omega of contemporary masculinity: the big babies of comedies and the hard-bodied manly men of superhero fantasies. There are a handful of other types in play, yet even these represent a fairly limited spectrum, from the idealized to the abject. The movies may be male dominated, but images of men are surprisingly narrow: often missing in action is the regular guy who wakes up every morning, kisses his wife (or husband) and manages not to do anything especially silly or heroic in the course of his working day.

headline: Greek and Cyprus Credit Ratings Cut
text: In the latest downgrades to hit the euro zone, Greece’s credit rating was cut by Standard & Poor’s on Wednesday, while Moody’s Investors Service cut the rating for Cyprus.

headline: 3 Ways to Keep Your Data With You at All Times
text: It always happens: When traveling for business, you always forget to send yourself an important file or drag a presentation onto your flash drive at the last minute. The result? Frantic phone calls to a distant office or rummaging through old files to find a replacement.

headline: The Guilty Parties

Situation resolved.

headline: Eurowoe

headline: Ristretto | Kickstand Concentrate
text: This is turning into the summer when New York’s flirtation with cold-brew coffee became a hopeless romance, or maybe a desperate obsession. Coffee made by letting grounds and cool water steep overnight was nearly impossible to find in the city as recently as 2008; now it’s sold in growlers, tapped in Queens, plied at a pushcart on the High Line and swigged from stubbies on the sidewalk outside the Ace Hotel.

headline: Lockerbie Convict Appears at Rally in Libya

headline: India and Pakistan Report Progress in Easing Strains
text: NEW DELHI — The foreign ministers of India and Pakistan met here on Wednesday, agreeing to a set of small but significant concessions to ease tensions in the disputed border region of Kashmir and pledging to work toward closer ties between their mutually wary, nuclear-armed countries.

headline: The Auto Industry, Stuck in the Slow Lane
text: Many of those grasping for a sign of economic optimism these days have pointed to the auto industry. The argument is that as supply chains come back on line following the Japanese earthquake and tsunami, more automobiles will be available for sale to consumers who have been waiting for cars to arrive.

headline: Q. and A. on the Debt Ceiling
text: For a time it seemed safe for many people going about their summers to try to ignore the debt ceiling drama playing out in Washington. If Wall Street had not seemed overly concerned that the United States was headed toward default, why should anyone else worry? And there is the long history of crying wolf in Washington: in April everyone finally got up to speed on the threatened shutdown of the federal government just in time to see it averted by an 11th-hour deal.

headline: Budget Office Gives Reid Relatively Good News
text: The Congressional Budget Office said Wednesday that a deficit reduction plan offered by the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, would reduce budget deficits by $2.2 trillion over the next 10 years.

headline: Study Finds Medicare Drug Plan Reduces Health Spending
text: The federal government’s prescription drug plan for the elderly, known as Medicare Part D, has been heralded as a success when it comes to reducing out-of-pocket expenses for many patients and encouraging them to use and continue taking essential medicines.

headline: The Empire Strikes Out: Artist Prevails in British Suit Over ‘Star Wars’ Costumes
text: Take a lesson from “Star Wars”: you can have all the resources in the galaxy at your disposal, and sometimes the little guy still prevails. In this case, that little guy is Andrew Ainsworth, a British artist who helped design the stark, almost featureless costumes worn by the villainous storm troopers in George Lucas‘s original 1977 space-adventure movie, and who has won the right to sell replicas of those costumes without permission from Mr. Lucas or his studio, Lucasfilm.

headline: J.D. Power Study: For Consumers, New Vehicles Hold Record Levels of Appeal
text: The overall appeal of new vehicles has reached its highest point since 1996, when J.D. Power & Associates first began surveying customers about how much they enjoyed their purchases, according to a study by the consumer research and consulting firm. The 2011 Automotive Performance, Execution and Layout (Apeal) study, released Wednesday, showed that the industry average for the survey continued its steady rise, increasing from 778 in 2010 to 781 this year, based on a 1,000-point scale.

headline: Europe by E-Rail, Sort of
