text: Talkie Mangal stands in the doorway of 17 East 176th Street in the Bronx, following a water main break earlier Wednesday morning.

headline: See You in Six Months?
text: John Boehner’s debt ceiling proposal, which the House will presumably vote on (and pass, I suspect) tomorrow, would raise the debt ceiling sufficiently to allow the government to function through February of 2012. In the mean time, it would empower a bipartisan commission to come up with $1.6-1.8 trillion in further savings by November of 2011, which would then be voted on in both houses of Congress under up-or-down, no filibusters allowed rules. If the bipartisan commission’s recommendations are passed, the president would be authorized to request a further debt ceiling increase that would carry the country through the rest of his first term.

headline: Pirate Picture Books Ahoy!
text: Just how child-friendly are pirates? Given the horrific headlines about actual pirates off the coast of Somalia, isn’t it odd that parents happily read bedtime stories about the descendants of Long John Silver and eagerly look forward to the day when their preschoolers will be old enough to watch “Pirates of the Caribbean” on DVD?

headline: A Battery That Squeezes More Miles Out of Gasoline
text: On Monday I wrote about odd new devices  that would help big trucks meet new standards for heavy vehicles’ fuel economy that are expected to be issued any day now. Also expected imminently were new corporate average fuel economy (known as CAFE) standards for cars, pickups, minivans and S.U.V.’s.

headline: After Long Night, an Unbelievable Call
text: 2:39 p.m. | Updated with Pirates filing a complaint

headline: Leave the Tusks, Take the Cannoli
text: Caitlin O’Connell-Rodwell, who teaches at the Stanford University School of Medicine and is the author of “The Elephant’s Secret Sense,” writes from Etosha National Park, Namibia, where she is studying elephant societies.

headline: Olives and Exercise: The Upshot
text: I set out for my Mediterranean trip this summer with two self-improvement goals: to get regular exercise (by running or doing the equivalent three times a week) and to learn to like olives (by eating every one that came my way, which in this part of the world, was a lot).

headline: Credit Agency Tells Congress a Default Is Unlikely
text: WASHINGTON — The United States is unlikely to default on its debt obligations but its credit rating could still be lowered if it doesn’t come up with an adequate plan to address spending and its soaring budget deficit, an official from one of the country’s largest credit rating agencies told a House panel Wednesday.

headline: McCain vs. the Tea Party
text: Is the old John McCain back?

headline: The Science of Boys and Girls
text: Annie Murphy Paul wanted her second child to be a boy. She announces this in the first sentence of Chapter 5 of “Origins: How the Nine Months Before Birth Shape  the Rest of Our Lives,” where she writes:

headline: SAC Capital to Close Fund to New Investors
text: The rumors have swirled for months now — would SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund run by Steven A. Cohen that has $14 billion in assets under management, actually refuse to take new money from investors?

headline: Phelps Wins Gold in His Signature Event, the 200 Butterfly
text: SHANGHAI — Michael Phelps pulled away in the final lap of the 200-meter butterfly final Wednesday night to capture his first gold medal at the swimming world championships and send a message that his prowess remains.

headline: Someone Just Like Me Said, ‘Buy It’
text: MAGAZINES have long been oracles of beauty advice for women. These days, beauty bloggers, celebrities and tweeting makeup artists also dole out tips and tout must-have products — that they may have received free. But Makeup Alley, a 12-year-old low-frills Web site that focuses on user-generated reviews, has quietly come to be the standard bearer for the unvarnished truth about beauty products online.

headline: Print Books: Should They Stay or Should They Go?
text: At the end of the week, I’ll be moving west and writing about technology from The New York Times’s San Francisco bureau.

headline: At the Twilight of Night Life
text: “Candelabras,” said Serge Becker in an excited whisper. He was eyeing the onstage additions awaiting Alicia Keys at Joe’s Pub, the intimate supper club at the Public Theater of which he is part owner.

headline: Mister H in the Mondrian SoHo
text: THE new night-life flurry in Chinatown has usually involved underground dance parties in dim sum parlors. But Mister H is far less subversive. The lounge, which opened in March at the Mondrian SoHo hotel, is run by Armin Amiri, the scene veteran from Socialista and Bungalow 8.

headline: RUB Is Opening a Nassau Branch
text: Islanders fans, and anyone with tickets for the Nassau Coliseum, take note. RUB BBQ is opening a branch near the arena. And the smashed burgers, which you can only get on Mondays at the original Chelsea location, will be available every day. Doors open on Tuesday.

headline: The Caucus | Boehner's Perilous Moment
text: July 27, 2011 - Jackie Calmes on whether House Speaker John A. Boehner can control his caucus. Also, John Harwood reports from inside Mitt Romney's campaign in New Hampshire.

headline: Commandos From Israel Raid Theater in West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli commandos stormed a famous Palestinian theater in the West Bank early Wednesday, arresting two men associated with it and damaging the building, a witness said.

headline: Readers Share Their Spatial-Humanities Projects
text: As an article we posted on Tuesday about the new field of spatial humanities explains, technology like the programs behind Google Earth, MapQuest and the G.P.S. devices in cars has enabled scholars in all sorts of disciplines to recreate landscapes both real and imagined.

headline: Now Selling | Textfield Titles at Creatures of Comfort
text: For its fifth in-store project, the SoHo shop Creatures of Comfort collaborated with the publishing and distribution company Textfield Inc. on “No More Reality,” a temporary bookstore and exhibition. Through Aug. 25, works by the artists Phil Chang, Arthur Ou, Eduardo Sarabia and Anna Sew Hoy — all Textfield Inc. favorites — play a supporting role to the printing house founder Jonathan Maghen’s curiously obscure and graphic selection of paperbacks and monographs. No book costs more than $100 (not even the artist Jennifer Doyle’s lovingly compiled “Municipal du Futbol,” about amateur soccer in Los Angeles, which includes two clothbound books, a jersey, nine artist lithographs and a poster). Pick up “The Portable John Latham” or the hilarious “Hippie Photos and Surfer Man” by the photographer Doniella Davy while you shop for Maison Martin Margiela clothes and Robert Clergerie shoes (fall’s tassel-top loafers and embossed leather wedges just arrived, p.s.).

headline: Afghan Deadpan: Kabul Gets Its Version of ‘The Office’
text: Saad Mohseni, an Afghan media mogul who owns the popular Tolo TV network, has alerted his Twitter followers to stand by for the debut next month of a new comedy series, “The Ministry,” which appears to be an Afghan version of “The Office” in all but name.

headline: A Proenza Schouler Deal Is Near
text: A European private-equity firm is expected to sell its shares in the design house Proenza Schouler to a group of New York investors led by John Howard, the chief executive of Irving Place Capital, and Andrew Rosen, a seasoned garment industry executive behind Theory and Helmut Lang.

headline: Math Camp
text: On Bard College’s campus, a free summer camp for low-income students who excel in mathematics.

headline: Caucus Video: Speaker Boehner’s Perilous Moment; Mitt Romney in New Hampshire
text: Jackie Calmes reports on whether House Speaker John A. Boehner can control members of his caucus in the debt ceiling standoff. Also, John Harwood reports from inside Mitt Romney’s campaign in New Hampshire.

headline: G.M. Says Opel Unit Not for Sale
text: DETROIT — General Motors is not interested in selling its European unit, Adam Opel, the carmaker’s chief executive said Wednesday, countering widespread speculation.

headline: Where the Job Growth Is: At the Low End
text: There’s more unhappy news for the millions of Americans hoping for a surge in the number of good, high-paying jobs — a new report concludes that the great bulk of new jobs created since the economic recovery began are in lower-wage occupations, paying $13.52 or less an hour.

headline: Capitalizing on a Weak Commercial Real Estate Market
text: From 2009 to 2010, the commercial real estate market in the United States seemed bottomless. Whether seeking manufacturing, office or retail space, those looking to lease or buy were in the driver’s seat, said Fred Schmidt, president and chief operating officer for Coldwell Banker Commercial in Parsippany, N.J. After the supply of space hit a peak in the fourth quarter of 2010, he said, the market began a slow recovery — “but it’s definitely still a tenant’s and buyer’s market.”

headline: N.F.L.’s Game of Catch-Up
text: While everyone seemed to predict that the end of the N.F.L. lockout would result in a free agency free-for-all, no one stepped forward with a properly absurd proposal for how it should be handled. We like the idea of putting all players’ names on Ping-Pong balls and have them spit out of a lottery hopper. Or perhaps the whole thing should be handled like Bingo. Auction paddles, anyone? No, wait, let’s just play it all as a big video game. Or maybe Bob Barker has some time on his hands. “Plaxico Burress, come on down!”

headline: Met Museum to Stay Open for McQueen Show Later Than Ever Before
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has never catered to the late-night crowd, but on Aug. 6 and 7, the last two days of its blockbuster exhibition “Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty,’’ it will keep the show open until midnight. Having combed through the museum’s records, officials there said they believed that this would be the first time the Met has stayed open so late.

headline: Renaming the Campaigns
text: “A soldier will fight long and hard for a bit of colored ribbon.”

headline: Are You Paying Too Much for Space?
text: We’ve just published a small-business guide by Eilene Zimmerman that offers several examples of small-business owners who have taken advantage of one bright spot in a dark economy — a favorable market for leasing or buying commercial real estate.

headline: When You Want to Collect Social Security vs. When You Should
text: Last week, we reviewed AARP’s new Social Security calculator, which helps you figure out when to begin collecting benefits. This week, we’re reviewing some more tools that will help you make this decision. Below, we take a look at the second one.

headline: Accuser in Strauss-Kahn Case Meets With Prosecutors
text: The hotel housekeeper who accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn of sexually assaulting her arrived at the Manhattan district attorney’s office shortly after 10 a.m. Wednesday to meet with prosecutors handling the case.

headline: In China, a More Western Approach to Elder Care
text: In any discussion here about the decision to move an older person into some sort of care facility, we can virtually count on a denunciation in the comments section, often from someone citing immigrant roots. Americans are too self-centered, too careerist, goes the criticism.

headline: Photo Replay: July 27
text: The world swimming championships continued in Shanghai and Ervin Santana threw a no-hitter for the Los Angeles Angels in Cleveland.

headline: Lehman Suit by Investors Is Allowed to Continue
text: 6:21 p.m. | Updated

headline: Winehouse’s Record Sales Skyrocket; Adele No. 1 for 11th Week
text: The numbers are in: Amy Winehouse, who died last Saturday at age 27, will re-enter the Top 10 of the Billboard album chart this week, with her music racking up greater sales in the days after her death than it had since January.

headline: Bucking the Speaker, and Crossing the Line
text: Tensions in the House Republican caucus are running so high that an e-mail by a junior staffer has riled its members.

headline: New Norway Video Shows Strength of Blast
text: New videos from the moment of the blast in Oslo and its immediate aftermath have continued to emerge as Norway struggles to cope with scale of Friday’s devastating violence.

headline: BMW Group Appoints New President for North American Region
text: Jim O’Donnell, the president of BMW of North America, is retiring on a high note, with the company entertaining realistic notions of becoming the No. 1 luxury automotive brand in the United States. The executive will be succeeded in October by Ludwig Willisch, who oversaw BMW’s M performance division before being promoted to head European sales.

headline: British Police Make Arrest in Net Attacks
text: The British police announced the arrest on Wednesday of a 19-year-old man who they said was the spokesman of the online vigilante group Lulz Security, which has claimed responsibility for a string of attacks on the Web sites of government agencies and private corporations.

headline: Flooding in Bronx After Water Line Breaks
text: A major water supply line in the Bronx burst on Wednesday morning, flooding Jerome Avenue for several blocks near 177th Street, halting traffic, disrupting subway and bus service and damaging two nearby gas mains.

headline: Beards: Rugged? Trendy? Or Unreliable?
text: The beard has become a symbol of youthful rebellion (and a different sort of conformity) for the first time since the heyday of Fillmore East.

headline: What Your Beard Says About You
text: FOUR years ago, I grew the first full beard of my adult life on a whim. I was 41, and it was neither a fashion statement nor a midlife crisis, but it came at a fortuitous time: the style world just happened to be entering the Postmillennial He-Man Beard Epoch.

headline: Chelsea Hotel to Stop Taking Reservations
text: The legendary Chelsea Hotel will stop taking reservations next Tuesday, Curbed reports. Living With Legends: Hotel Chelsea Blog reports that the news “could mean many things,” including the chance to do construction under reduced scrutiny or challenge the union.

headline: Taking the Scissors to Annoying Labels
text: LEAH MISSBACH DAY, 52, a photojournalist in Chicago, likes designer labels like Balenciaga, Alexander Wang and Dries Van Noten. But not next to her skin. “I cut them out because they’re scratchy and they bug me,” she said. “I’ve got a whole drawer full of tags.”

headline: Mets Set to Send Beltran to Giants
text: The Mets and the San Francisco Giants are on the verge of completing a trade that would send Carlos Beltran to the Giants in exchange for a top prospect who is likely to be Zack Wheeler, a right-handed pitcher taken in the first round of the 2009 draft. The pending deal was confirmed by a person in baseball with knowledge of the talks. More details here, with updates to follow. Are the Mets on the right path, and should more big names be following Beltran out of town?

headline: A Hectic, and Often Hidden, Day in the Life
text: As if there wasn’t enough going on at the United States Capitol on Wednesday, it was all happening with cameras rolling.

headline: N.F.L. Free-for-All Central
text: Big signing news of the day, so farThe Titans added a bit of stability with the signing of former Seahawks quarterback Matt Hasselbeck on Monday, although that is sort of like saying you’ve added some fresh water to the Atlantic Ocean. But after sending Vince Young into exile and having Kerry Collins retire instead of dive into this reclamation project, the Titans desperately needed not to throw their first-round draft pick Jake Locker straight into the lion pit. They put out a call for a veteran stop-gap and Hasselbeck, 35, answered, to the tune of $21 million over three years, the Tennessean reported.

headline: Textile Museum to Move to George Washington University
text: The Textile Museum  will move to George Washington University’s Foggy Bottom campus and become part of a new museum scheduled to open in 2014, the two institutions announced on Tuesday.

headline: Boehner on Why to Back His Plan
text: The House speaker, John A. Boehner, told a radio host on Wednesday that Republicans should support his plan for a debt ceiling increase because “Barack Obama hates it, Harry Reid hates it, Nancy Pelosi hates it.”

headline: Beltran All but Gone to the Giants
text: CINCINNATI — Carlos Beltran’s jersey was still on view Wednesday afternoon in the same corner stall where it had been all week at Great American Ballpark, a lingering reminder of what was and no longer is.

headline: Angels’ Ervin Santana Throws No-Hitter Against Indians
text: CLEVELAND — Ervin Santana pitched the first solo no-hitter for the Angels in nearly 27 years, getting some long overdue revenge against the Cleveland Indians and leading Los Angeles to a 3-1 win Wednesday.

headline: What Would Che Say?
text: OF beautiful people Cuba has many. Any visitor to the island or its satellite country, Miami, knows that.

headline: Theater Talkback: In Protest of Pre-Show Announcements
text: This summer ArtsBeat is inviting members of the theater world to contribute to the weekly Theater Talkback column, alternating with the critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood. Recent posts have examined the challenges of casting the role of Fanny Brice in “Funny Girl” and unusual settings for Shakespeare stagings. This week, Laura Motta, a New York-based writer, editor and blogger (her blog signature is Lucky) writes about the value of letting shows speak for themselves.

headline: S.B.A. Unveils New Venture Capital Fund
text: The Small Business Administration announced on Tuesday that it had formed a $130 million venture capital fund to invest in high-growth companies in Michigan. The fund is the first of what Karen Mills, the S.B.A. administrator, said is a $1 billion commitment over five years through what the agency calls Impact Investment funds, part of the Obama administration’s Startup America initiative announced in January.

headline: Now Showing | Knotty and Nice
text: New York design aficionados who are looking to beat the heat will find nothing but cool this summer at Ralph Pucci International, where a series of exhibitions, all on view through the end of the year, illustrates the very different approaches of their subjects. “Revival,” by the French designer Jerome Abel Seguin, contains nine sculptural pieces made of slices of enormous mahogany trees that were felled in central Java early in the 20th century. The pieces, some of which even contain large stones that became embedded in the trees, are at once graphic and textural, primal, and extremely powerful.

headline: ‘America’s Got Talent’ Makes Another Splash in the Ratings
text: Buoyed by the record-setting performance of Professor Splash, a professional diver who belly-flopped into a 12-inch kiddie pool from 3 stories up, “America’s Got Talent” on NBC was once again the most watched show on Tuesday with 11.2 million viewers overall, and it was No. 1 in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, according to Nielsen data.

headline: Shift in Europe Seen in Debate on Immigrants
text: BERLIN — Less than a week after the mass killings in Norway, evidence of a shift in the debate over Islam and the radical right in Europe already appeared to be taking hold on a traumatized Continent.

headline: Finding Humanity by Breaking Rules
text: Leah Millis grew up in Denver. A trip to Haiti as a teenager inspired her pursuit of photojournalism as a career. Now 23, she is studying at the Metropolitan State College of Denver and spending the summer as an intern at The Star Tribune in Minneapolis. Her conversation with Kerri MacDonald, part of the Turning Point series, has been edited.

headline: It’s All Over but the Face-Saving?
text: It remains unclear whether the House will pass a bill by the speaker, John A. Boehner, to raise the debt ceiling, though prospects appear to be significantly better today than they did yesterday. Still, the math looks to be pretty close.

headline: Reversing the Brain Drain:  Expanding Medical Opportunities in Rwanda
text: For decades, young doctors and nurses have been fleeing poor countries for the bright lights and fat paychecks of wealthier nations, abandoning the parts of the world with the highest burden of disease and most desperate need for medical help. Sixty percent of medical doctors who trained in Ghana in the 1980s have since left the country, and there are more Ethiopian doctors in Washington DC than in all of Ethiopia. Sub-Saharan Africa today houses more than a tenth of the world’s population, and shoulders a quarter of the global burden of disease, but it has just three percent of the world’s health care workers.

headline: O.K. to Go Dance Crazy
text: OK Go is premiering their latest video “All Is Not Lost,” which includes an interactive HTML5 version.

headline: Sundance’s Digital Move Seeks to Link Filmmakers and Audiences
text: LOS ANGELES— Every year more than 50 percent of the movies shown at the Sundance Film Festival fail to achieve the big prize: acquisition by a theatrical distributor. Can Sundance’s new year-round digital delivery plan help those cinematic leftovers find an audience?

headline: Fill-In | The Federal Debt Ceiling
text: We removed 20 words, phrases and names from the Times Topics overview about the federal debt ceiling. Can you fill them all in?

headline: How the South Bronx’s Ruins Became Fertile Ground
text: This week in my Gotham column I wrote of the resurrection of the South Bronx, a brilliant coming back to life that owes much to the multidecade efforts of government.

headline: Proxy Access in Limbo After Court Rules Against It
text: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has taken a chainsaw to the Securities and Exchange Commission’s proxy access rule, striking it down in a 21-page opinion. A panel of three judges from the appeals court based its ruling last week on what it perceived to be the S.E.C.’s failure to fully consider the costs and the benefits of this rule. With the S.E.C. wounded and proxy access seemingly on life support, if not dead, the question is what comes next?

headline: Getting a Refund for Taxes Paid on Airfares
text: Earlier this week our colleague Joe Sharkey reported on a lapse in federal airfare taxes.

headline: Unredacted Documents: Federal Officials Quietly Question Shale Gas
text: The Times reviewed thousands of pages of documents related to shale gas, including hundreds of industry e-mails, internal agency documents and analyst reports. A selection is here.

headline: Online Music, Unshackled
text: Everybody seems to think that record company executives are big, greedy dunderheads. “How dare you charge for music?” the college set shouts. “Music wants to be free!”

headline: Once Unthinkable, Breakup of Big Banks Now Seems Feasible
text: What was made can be unmade.

headline: British Authority Bans Two Ads by L’Oréal
text: For L’Oréal, beauty is not always in the eye of the beholder.

headline: Mystery Tombstone Finds Its Place of Rest
text: A year later, the mystery of why the tombstone of a woman who died in 1910 was found on the Lower East Side remains unsolved, but the tombstone has finally been installed in its rightful place: at the grave site of the woman, Hinda Amchanitzky, who wrote what has been described as the first Yiddish cookbook published in America.

headline: Walter Reed Hospital Holds Closing Ceremony
text: WASHINGTON — History has marched through the halls of Walter Reed Army Medical Center, where presidents, princes, kings and generals mingled in their hospital gowns.

headline: Scene City: AIDS Benefit Turns Up Heat
text: Like zombies in the dusk, grim-faced guests on the summer social circuit arrived at Steven Klein’s AIDS benefit in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

headline: When the Party Approaches Its Boiling Point
text: STEVEN KLEIN is an affable photographer whose work has a dark and sadistic edge that verges on the demonic. And just below its surface, the big party he hosted last Saturday at his sprawling property in Bridgehampton, N.Y. — West Kill Farm — for AIDS Community Research Initiative of America had a bit of an edge, too.

headline: TimesCast | July 27, 2011
text: The columnist David Leonhardt argues for long-term commitment to the nation's fiscal health; Britain recognizes the rebels as Libya's legitimate government; and Amy Winehouse's record sales skyrocket.

headline: A Walk Down Money Lane
text: DealBook takes a historical tour of lower Manhattan's famous real estate. Richard M. Warshauer, a senior managing director at Colliers International, has been leading the annual tours for 24 years.

headline: Homes for $1.495 Million
text: A house in California with Pacific views; a renovated barn on 58 acres in Indiana; and a house on seven acres in Connecticut.

headline: Tomato Stracciatella
text: Stracciatella is like an Italian egg drop soup. This particular version is adapted from one of my favorite cookbooks, "Cooking From an Italian Garden," by Jon Cohen and Paola Scaravelli. I’d never seen a stracciatella with tomatoes until I came across this recipe.

headline: Trenton Pizzeria Stakes Claim to Being the Nation’s Oldest
text: Nick Azzaro, above, says his pizzeria in Trenton, N.J., not Lombardi’s in Manhattan, is the oldest in the country. And it seems as if he’s making a fair claim.

headline: Homegrown Hurt
text: We are so accustomed to seeing terrorism through the lens of 9/11 that it may be hard to recapture how shocking it was to realize, 16 years ago in Oklahoma City, that devastating terrorism can be completely homegrown. The mass murder committed in Norway last Friday by a Norwegian anti-immigrant extremist brings Oklahoma City forcefully to mind for the first time in a long while. The bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building on April 19, 1995, by two disaffected Americans killed 168 people. At the time, it was the worst single incident of terrorism ever committed on American soil. Today’s young adults, not yet then even in their teens, may barely remember it.

headline: Jeremy Clarkson Goes Digital in Forza 4
text: If the automotive world, or the world in general, needs more Jeremy Clarkson, it’s about to get it, thanks to Microsoft.

headline: A Walk Down Money Lane
text: Manhattan’s financial district offers a wealth of history for the real estate-inclined tourist. Richard M. Warshauer, a senior managing director at Colliers International, has been leading the annual tours for 24 years. Earlier this year, DealBook’s Ben Protess took a walk with Mr. Warshauer to see what he could learn.

headline: In Southern Styria, a Hilltop House
text: A three-bedroom house with two guesthouses and a pool in Styria, Austria is on the market for $2.5 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Austria
text: A THREE-BEDROOM HILLTOP HOUSE WITH TWO GUESTHOUSES IN STYRIA, AUSTRIA

headline: Shopping for Footstools With Steven Sclaroff
text: The interior and product designer shopped for quirky footstools near his TriBeCa office.

headline: The Game Is Afoot, But Which One?
text: President Obama said on Monday night that the battle over the debt ceiling was “a dangerous game we’ve never played before, and we can’t afford to play it now.”

headline: U.S. Soccer’s Home and the World’s New Destination
text: Harrison, N.J.

headline: Blackstone Is Said to Hold Talks to Buy Emdeon
text: The Blackstone Group is in discussions to buy Emdeon, a medical data services provider, for about $3 billion including debt, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

headline: A Gamble on Art on the ‘Redneck Riviera’ May Not Be Paying Off
text: ATLANTA — When the Ohr-O’Keefe Museum of Art opened in November in Biloxi, Miss., residents were not sure what to make of the quirky little museum dedicated to an eccentric Mississippi potter and designed by the architect Frank Gehry.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Libya, Korea and China.

headline: Estimates of When the U.S. Will Run Out of Money
text: Chart showing the amount of the nation’s cash reserves and estimates for when it will run out if the debt ceiling is not raised.

headline: Republicans Show a Motivational Video
text: As motivational videos go, you can see how it might be appealing.

headline: Summer Styles | Great Lengths
text: We have yet to see separates make a significant comeback, even though we’re a month into summer. Maxi dresses with allover prints and simple silhouettes are everywhere, and women are opting to wear them most often with shoes that disappear behind the longer hemlines. The actress Halle Berry, with her daughter Nahla, pairs a graphic ikat with a fringed bag and barely there sandals, while the breakout star of the summer, Rosie Huntington-Whiteley, puts a casual spin on wallpaper print and the “Gossip Girl” actress Jessica Szohr accessorizes a strapless with long gold chains.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Libya, South Korea and China.

headline: The Bad Girls Before Amy Winehouse
text: Amy Winehouse was a 5-foot-3 almanac of visual reference.

headline: A Bad Girl With a Touch of Genius
text: “IT’S hard to look that cheap and pull it off,” John Waters said admiringly of Amy Winehouse, some days after the English singer was found dead in her London bed.

headline: To Fill a Gap in Commercial Radio, Classically Trained Apps
text: It’s been a long decade for classical music fans, with the virtual disappearance of the genre from commercial radio.

headline: Callahan and Rangers Agree to Terms on New Deal
text: 3:46 p.m. | Updated  Rangers President and General Manager Glen Sather announced Wednesday that the club has agreed to terms with forward Ryan Callahan on a new contract.

headline: Victims of the Norway Attacks
text: The police in Norway have now confirmed the identities of all 77 people killed in July’s attacks on Oslo and Utoya Island. Learn more about the victims.

headline: What You Get for ... $1.495 Million
text: CORYDON, IND.

headline: With 17 Hits, Mariners End 17-Game Skid
text: The Seattle Mariners tried everything over the past three weeks, shuffling lineups and altering warm-up routines and even shaving mustaches, in an attempt to break their franchise-worst run of 17 consecutive defeats. Nothing worked.

headline: Pac-12 Conference to Create Seven TV Channels
text: The Pacific-12 Conference, which has made no secret of its desire to create a network to showcase its newly expanded league, announced Wednesday that it would create six regional channels and a national one.

headline: S&P Finds Merit in Some Debt Plans
text: One of the country’s major credit rating agencies said on Wednesday that some of the deficit-cutting plans being considered in Congress could help to avoid a downgrade in the nation’s credit rating, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Permies at Work
text: An eco-ideology with no publicists or big names, has bubbled from the underground, into the mainstream, as a way of moving toward a sustainable future.

headline: Japan’s Comfort Music
text: About a week ago, Rob Walker had a Riff column in the magazine on the declining interest in hit charts and No. 1 songs. That was on my mind when I saw a report last weekend on TV Japan, a cable service in the United States. The report said that sales of oldies in Japan had taken off since the earthquake/tsunami/nuclear disaster. People, it seems, are seeking comfort in those old, familiar tunes.

headline: Study of Medical Device Rules Is Attacked, Unseen
text: Allies of the medical device industry are waging an extraordinary campaign in Washington to discredit a coming report by one of the country’s pre-eminent scientific groups that examines possible new regulations on the industry.

headline: War Changes a Man, and a Play
text: The journey from invincible optimism to embittered defeat is a short one for Harry Heegan, the young soldier at the center of Sean O’Casey’s 1928 play “The Silver Tassie.” The echoes of Harry’s joyous cries at a soccer victory in the play’s opening scene still seem to be resounding in the air when he raises his voice at its mournful end, strumming a banjo and hymning the death of his young spirit as his friends and family look on in awkward sympathy.

headline: 81 Children Rescued in Raids on Trafficking Ring, Chinese Officials Say
text: BEIJING — In a significant illustration of China’s illicit trade in babies, the Ministry of Public Security said Wednesday that the police had rescued 81 children from a major child trafficking ring that had operated throughout eastern China.

headline: In Western Water Wars, Fighters and, Yes, Peacemakers
text: Writing about water in a region where water is scarce can be a daunting business. In a graduate program, the prerequisites would be geology, hydrology, chemistry, law and engineering — especially law and engineering. The people involved in the issue (who call themselves “water buffaloes,” not without pride) tend to be defined by their fights as much as their accomplishments. In fact, when they are won, the fights are synonymous with their accomplishments.

headline: Rock Chronicle Inspires Battle Over Its Legacy
text: Steve Baltin had been toiling as a freelance music writer for a decade when an entrepreneur named Jason Turner approached him a year ago about resurrecting Creem magazine, the irreverent and sardonic publication that defined rock in the 1970s. The offer to edit a once-famous magazine was tempting, to say the least.

headline: A closer look at Lion, the new version of Mac OS X; website translation; the term "rickrolling;" news.
text: Alan Yacavone, an Apple expert from the Times's News Technology team, stops by to discuss Lion and its new features and design changes. J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Jack Welde, the CEO of Smartling (http://www.smartling.com), about website translation and how his company uses the cloud and the crowd (-sourcing) to offer different language options. Freshly rickrolled, Pedro Rafael Rosado has something to say about that old prank. The news roundup includes YouTube taking up 22 percent of all mobile bandwidth; Walmart giving its Vudu video service an extra push; a new Mozilla mobile platform project; the resignation of a top U.S. cyber official; release of the Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.1 tablet with 4G service; and an Apple security update. J.D.'s tip of the week: a feature in Microsoft Office 2010 and 2007 for Windows called KeyTips, which lets you jump into ribbon menus with just a few keystrokes and shows you what to press.

headline: Fine Tuning Behind Closed Doors
text: A look at six rehearsals at the 42nd Street Studios in Times Square.

headline: Rehearsals, Side by Side and Glorified
text: FORTY-SECOND STREET has long catered to the needs of New Yorkers, tourists, theater lovers, moviegoers, small-time hustlers, global corporations, shoppers, restaurateurs, news hounds, thrill seekers, hopefuls and has-beens. But until the New 42nd Street Studios was completed in 2000, there was precious little space for performing artists to rehearse.

headline: In Turkey, a Sprawling Home In a Series of Caves
text: A couple carved a sanctuary from a hillside of buff-colored volcanic rock in Cappadocia.

headline: A Journeyman Soul Singer Embraces His Audience in Word and in Deed
text: The line between showmanship and sentiment is often thick and impermeable, but midway through his Tuesday evening performance in Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, Charles Bradley obliterated it.

headline: Swedish Pair Wins Von Zedtwitz Title by Less Than a Board
text: TORONTO — At the American Contract Bridge League’s Summer North America Championships here on Sunday the Von Zedtwitz Life Master Pairs was won by Peter Bertheau and Per-Olla Cullin from Sweden. They finished less than a board ahead of Tarek Sadek from Egypt and Zia Mahmood of New York. Third were Jan Jansma from the Netherlands and Jay Borker of Greenwich, Conn. Bertheau and Cullin will play for Sweden in this year’s Bermuda Bowl world team championship, but not as partners.

headline: Senate Extends Term of F.B.I. Director
text: The Senate on Wednesday voted unanimously to extend the tenure of Robert S. Mueller III as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, allowing him to serve for two more years.

headline: ‘The Great American Hall of Wonders’
text: Images from a new exhibition of “Art, Science, and Invention in the 19th Century.”

headline: The Catching of Two Joseph Hellers
text: “Just One Catch” is a soup-to-nuts chronicle of the life of  Joseph Heller. It is by Tracy Daugherty, who should not be confused with Mr. Heller’s daughter. Erica Heller’s own book about her father is “Yossarian Slept Here,” and there are many places where Heller’s daughter and Mr. Daugherty overlap. This situation is so jarring that it has driven Christopher Buckley, not ordinarily known for cornball silliness, to two giddy attacks of wordplay. About the biography he blurbs, “A major achievement, or should I say major major major?” in honor of Major Major, a major character in Heller’s “Catch-22.” His blurb for Ms. Heller: “I think this is going to be one hell(er) of a memoir.”

headline: The World as America Dreamed It
text: WASHINGTON — The first thing we see on entering the new exhibition at the Smithsonian American Art Museum here is a life-size painting of a formally dressed, graciously welcoming, aged gentleman. He is lifting a heavy red drape and gesturing as if inviting us to visit the marvels within. Beyond the curtain we glimpse walls lined with hundreds of glass cases, each containing stuffed birds. We see visitors strolling past, engaged in contemplation or struck with amazement. We also spot part of a mastodon skeleton, discovered in 1801 by the same man who lifts the curtain.

headline: TeenNick Finds Success in the Nostalgic ’90s
text: Viacom’s research appears to have been proved right: twenty-somethings do want their old Nickelodeon shows back.

headline: Obama the Moderate Conservative
text: No time to do any original posting tonight. But for those who missed the first time I linked to it, here’s Bruce Bartlett — an economic adviser to Ronald Reagan — explaining why Obama is indeed a moderate conservative in practical terms.

headline: Best of All Possible Worlds: When Life Gives You Mud, Take a Mud Bath
text: It would be comforting to imagine that “The Optimists,” Goran Paskaljevic’s viciously funny gloss of Voltaire’s “Candide,” was a site-specific satire of this Serbian director’s homeland in the post-Milosevic era. The film’s five vignettes, whose characters cling to irrational optimism in the face of poverty, injustice and hatred, are all set in an unidentified Eastern European wasteland of bleak farming villages, one of which has been inundated by a flood.

headline: Government Seeks More Information on Google’s Admeld Acquisition
text: The Justice Department has asked Google for more information and time as it investigates the search giant’s $400 million acquisition of Admeld, a display advertising company, Google said on Wednesday.

headline: A Publisher Plays Coy With Book Release
text: Over the last few days buyers for bookstores around the country have opened their e-mail to find a mysterious last-minute addition to the Little, Brown & Company fall lineup.

headline: It’s Never Too Late to Learn How to Succeed While in Fortress Mode
text: If you enjoyed Jonah Weiner’s article on Tarn and Zach Adams and the brilliance of their computer game, Dwarf Fortress, then you will likely also enjoy this interview with Wiener over on the excellent Boing Boing podcast Gweek 010. And if at some point during your reading of the story you thought to yourself, with some small amount of melancholy, I would like to learn how to plant crops and forge weapons and protect myself against vampire dwarves, but I am not the kind of person who even knows how to distinguish the military from the nobles, then you are in luck. At the University of Reddit, starting Aug. 3, there’s a class being offered on Dwarf Fortress basics. So go forth and remember, the hippos like the sewers!

headline: Republicans Seek Big Cuts in Environmental Rules
text: With the nation’s attention diverted by the drama over the debt ceiling, Republicans in the House of Representatives are loading up an appropriations bill with 39 ways — and counting — to significantly curtail environmental regulation.

headline: Boehner’s Bill Gets a Boost
text: A new version of Speaker John A. Boehner’s House debt-ceiling bill would cut spending by $917 billion over 10 years, according to the Congressional Budget Office, giving the speaker’s legislation a fresh boost in advance of a possible vote on Thursday.

headline: Chicharito Sustains Concussion
text: HARRISON, N.J. — Manchester United’s fabled cone of silence was activated Tuesday night when the team’s young Mexican star, Javier Hernández, known as Chicharito, was injured during an evening training session. But the club kept the news under wraps until only hours before the start of its match against the Major League Soccer all-stars.

headline: Senate Democrats Promise to Reject Boehner Plan
text: Fifty-three Democratic senators have signed a letter to House Speaker John A. Boehner saying they intend to vote against his plan for an increase in the debt ceiling, virtually assuring its defeat in the Senate even as the speaker lines up Republican votes to pass it in the House on Thursday.

headline: Queens Family Court Judge Is Picked to Lead the City’s Child Welfare Agency
text: The Bloomberg administration on Wednesday appointed Ronald E. Richter, a Family Court judge with broad experience in the child welfare and juvenile justice systems, as the next commissioner of the Administration for Children’s Services.

headline: TimesCast | The Long-Term Fix
text: July 27, 2011 - As Washington tries to avert a fiscal crisis, David Leonhardt, Economix columnist, argues a long-term commitment to the nation's fiscal health is more important than short-term fixes.

headline: TimesCast | Britain's Stance on Libya
text: July 27, 2011 - Britain follows the United States, France, and 30 other countries, recognizing the rebels as Libya's legitimate government.

headline: Dress Codes in New York Clubs: Will This Get Me In?
text: GENTLEMEN who prefer Ed Hardy shirts, those dragon-happy hallmarks of “Jersey Shore” chic, will not be getting into the Mulberry Project, the subterranean speakeasy cocktail lounge in Little Italy, any time soon. If you prefer your dress shirts colorful and boldly striped, don’t bother with the club Provocateur, in the meatpacking district. Baggy, low-slung jeans your style? Lots of East Village bars may be O.K. with that, but there will be no Continental for you tonight.

headline: Gender Roles
text: The movie “Gun Hill Road” distinguishes itself from other recent transgender films by relying on an actress who is herself transgender.

headline: A Better Way to Sort Out What’s Hot on Twitter
text: If you’ve tried to search for posts on Twitter’s built-in search box, you know it can be frustrating.

headline: Rick Astley Will Save Us All
text: With the country — maybe the world — on the edge of economic Armageddon and the parties seemingly incapable of cooperating even in the direst of circumstances, the White House has a message of unity.

headline: For a Day at the Beach, Take Sunscreen and a Flash
text: Ah, summer: the time for sun, sand and harshly lighted photos of the family grimacing into the sun.

headline: Carlyle’s Plane Unit I.P.O. Priced Below Expected Range
text: 11:26 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Permaculture Movement Grows From Underground
text: AS a way to save the world, digging a ditch next to a hillock of sheep dung would seem to be a modest start. Granted, the ditch was not just a ditch. It was meant to be a “swale,” an earthwork for slowing the flow of water down a slope on a hobby farm in western Wisconsin.

headline: Computer Drives to Start Your Day Quicker
text: For many people, waiting for their computers to boot up is time passed drumming their fingers, making a cup of coffee or watching the grass grow. The delay is because of starting the hard drive, which has to awaken and rev up to retrieve stored data.

headline: Footstools
text: STEVEN SCLAROFF is a big fan of footstools, “both for their intended use and as extra pull-up seating,” he said. “I have them all over my house, and if a lot of people are coming over, I just herd them all into the living room.”

headline: A Professional Gardener on Shielding Plants From Stifling Heat
text: Gardeners often think Mother Nature has it in for them, and they may not be far off-base this summer. Triple-digit temperatures and severe droughts in many parts of the country have made the act of gardening borderline Sisyphean, if not a health risk. Just ask the country singer Loretta Lynn: she was hospitalized earlier this month for heat exhaustion after spending time in her Tennessee garden. (“There ain’t a tomato worth it,” Ms. Lynn was quoted as saying in an Associated Press article.)

headline: A Hummingbird Feeder That Floats on the Breeze
text: In 2004, the ceramicist Jim Schatz left Manhattan to set up a studio in Greene, N.Y., near Binghamton. “Living here, on a creek, exposed me to the birds,” Mr. Schatz said. “And the birds led me to thinking about bird products.”

headline: A Decanter Inspired by a Snake
text: Maximilian J. Riedel, the chief executive officer of Riedel Crystal of America, was born in 1977, the Year of the Snake, which may explain his fondness for serpents.

headline: A SoHo Hotel, but Not in SoHo
text: With the opening of the Nolitan next week, visitors who want proximity to SoHo’s shops and restaurants can get it without actually staying in the area, one of the most congested in the city. The 55-room boutique hotel, on the corner of Kenmare and Elizabeth Streets, is close by, but feels worlds away, thanks in part to its design.

headline: Sales at Crate and Barrel and Others
text: Selected bedding is on sale at Crate and Barrel, through Sunday (feather-down bed pillows, pictured, originally about $40 to about $60, are about $33 to about $50; Marimekko Tikkula Spice sheet sets, originally about $85 to $149, are about $45 to $109); 650 Madison Avenue (59th Street), (212) 308-0011, and 611 Broadway (Houston Street), (212) 780-0004, or crateandbarrel.com.

headline: Old Windows Find a Following
text: NEEDHAM, Mass.

headline: And Now, an Upholstered Folding Chair
text: For those who are short on seating and space but loath to invest in conventional plastic folding chairs, the Terai offers a happy medium: an upholstered folding chair.

headline: A Montauk Surf Shack
text: The founder of the ad agency Chandelier Creative turned a summer rental in Montauk, N.Y., into a weekend outpost for his staff.

headline: A Stage Set in Montauk, With Bees and Ocean
text: MONTAUK, N.Y.

headline: In Cappadocia, Returning to the Cave
text: ORTAHISAR, Turkey

headline: Should Religion Play a Role in Politics?
text: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

headline: Improved Sales Help Boeing Beat Forecasts
text: Boeing on Wednesday exceeded profit expectations for the second quarter as a result of more plane sales, a development that helped it raise its 2011 earnings guidance.

headline: Congress at Impasse Over F.A.A.
text: WASHINGTON — The debt ceiling debate may seem to be taking forever, but as an example of legislative dysfunction it is difficult to beat the repeated failure of Congress to manage the affairs of the Federal Aviation Administration.

headline: Kosovo Firebombing Underscores New Ethnic Tensions
text: BERLIN — Two violent episodes this week along Kosovo’s northern border with Serbia — the latest being Wednesday’s firebombing of a customs post by a group of about 200 Serbs — have shed new light on the increase in tensions in the area between ethnic Serbs and Albanians.

headline: Should Polygamists Be Left Alone?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Aid to Science Program
text: To the Editor:

headline: Human Run-Ins With Bears May Portend Deeper Changes
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — Griffin W. Smith has some practical advice to offer about bears. As a cross-country trail runner, he has seen them in the woods many times in southern Colorado.

headline: Ryan Callahan and Rangers Avoid Unpleasantness of Arbitration
text: The Rangers and Ryan Callahan, their linchpin player of the future, agreed to terms for a contract extension Wednesday afternoon, only hours before a scheduled salary-arbitration meeting in Toronto on Thursday.

headline: Third-Party Candidates
text: To the Editor:

headline: Recuperating From Surgery, Perry Persists in Campaign
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — As he travels across the state and the country in a bid to gather momentum and donors for a possible presidential run, Gov. Rick Perry has let nothing slow him down. Not even spinal fusion surgery.

headline: After Dreams of Acting, an Unexpected Role
text: When Luke Babcock Keller, 25, left Chicago to join his girlfriend in New York last August, he had aspirations to act and to produce videos and a bachelor’s degree in communications from DePaul University, but he didn’t have a job. With his nest egg running on empty, he contacted a temp agency and was sent to IceStone, a manufacturer of countertop slabs made from recycled glass in a cement matrix. In January, IceStone hired him for its operations team. He lives in Bushwick with his girlfriend, Ayisha Jaffer, and two roommates.

headline: Jeret Peterson, Skier Known for a Daring Move, Dies at 29
text: Jeret Peterson, a skier who won a silver medal in freestyle aerials with the United States men’s team at the 2010 Vancouver Olympics, but whose skiing prowess was often overshadowed by his tumultuous personal life, died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound on Monday night in Lambs Canyon, between Salt Lake City and Park City, Utah. He was 29.

headline: Once Nearly 100%, Teacher Tenure Rate Drops to 58% as Rules Tighten
text: The era of automatic tenure for teachers in New York City is over, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Wednesday.

headline: U.S. and Europe Battle Over Carbon Fees for Airlines
text: Sharply divergent climate change policies on opposite sides of the Atlantic are setting off political fireworks as European environmental regulators prepare to extend their reach across the ocean. Starting Jan. 1, the European Union will require all carriers entering or leaving its airports to either reduce their emissions or pay a charge — whether the airline is United, Air France or Lufthansa.

headline: Earthly Dream Is Realized in the Rain Forest
text: The beauty here is not necessarily for everyone. Pounded by up to 170 inches of precipitation each year, these grand old woods are wetter and grayer and gloomier than most. Then again, not every summer traveler seeks sunshine.

headline: Advice to Romney
text: To the Editor:

headline: Challenging Wal-Mart
text: To the Editor:

headline: Safe Births in Africa
text: To the Editor:

headline: Battle for Libya | July 27, 2011
text: British Foreign Secretary William Hague announced formal diplomatic recognition of the Libyan rebels on Wednesday.

headline: Sharpton’s Push for Comcast Raises Issues About Possible MSNBC Job
text: Last year, Comcast was lining up the Rev. Al Sharpton to lobby for its bid for NBCUniversal. This year, the cable news channel owned by NBCUniversal, MSNBC, is weighing whether to make him a daily television host.

headline: With G.O.P. Unity at Risk, Boehner Tries Tougher Style
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner is a laid-back leader who likes to say that his role is to let the House work its will. But with the nation’s economic standing and his own political future at risk, Mr. Boehner jettisoned his usual laissez-faire approach on Wednesday.

headline: Before a Diplomatic Showdown, a Budget Crisis Saps Palestinians’ Confidence
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — As the Palestinian Authority faces some of the hardest choices in its history regarding relations with Israel, membership in the United Nations and unity with Hamas, it is mired in a severe economic crisis, leading many here to a sense of foreboding and despair.

headline: An Underachieving Symbol of the Mets’ Lost Decade
text: A full decade has come and gone since the Mets’ last pennant in 2000.

headline: U.S. Loses Ally as Iraqi General Waits for Trial
text: This article is by  Tim Arango,  Duraid Adnan and  Yasir Ghazi.

headline: Eulogies for Bin Laden, Shrouded in Mystery
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — The posters were plastered around the campus of Pakistan’s largest university last month, inviting students to enter a poetry and essay contest eulogizing a major historical figure who spent his last years living in seclusion in this nation.

headline: President on Sidelines in Critical Battle Over Debt Ceiling
text: WASHINGTON — For an hour on Wednesday the White House press secretary, Jay Carney, fielded questions about what, if anything, President Obama was doing to help end the impasse in Congress over the imminent need to raise the nation’s borrowing limit.

headline: This Is Your Brain on Summer
text: Baltimore

headline: Treasury to Weigh Which Bills to Pay
text: WASHINGTON — The Treasury Department is preparing to answer a question that it has dodged and rebuffed for months: If there’s not enough money for everyone, who is left empty-handed?

headline: Norwegians Concede a Role in Chilean Salmon Virus
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — A virus that has killed millions of salmon in Chile and ravaged the fish farming industry there was probably brought over from Norway, a major salmon producer has acknowledged.

headline: Judge May Let 9/11 Lawsuit Pursue Damages for Suffering on Doomed Flight
text: The final minutes of the passengers on United Airlines Flight 175, the second plane to strike the World Trade Center, were sheer horror, as reported in calls to the ground. The hijackers used pepper spray and knives. A flight attendant had been stabbed; both pilots had been killed.

headline: Cost of Treating Veterans Will Rise Long Past Wars
text: WASHINGTON — Though the withdrawal of American military forces from Iraq and Afghanistan will save the nation billions of dollars a year, another cost of war is projected to continue rising for decades to come: caring for the veterans.

headline: Russia: U.S. Is Warned on Visas
text: The Russian government cautioned in a statement issued Wednesday that it would “not leave unanswered the unfriendly steps” taken by the United States in barring several dozen Russian officials from receiving American visas over their involvement in the detention and death of the Russian lawyer Sergei L. Magnitsky two years ago. It was one of the Obama administration’s sharpest responses yet to human rights abuses in Russia. The Russian Foreign Ministry said in its statement that the visa ban, coming into force despite the thaw in the two countries’ relations, represented “an instrument of the past.”

headline: An I.P.O. Built on the Basics: Sugar and Coffee
text: The latest splashy stock debut had all the markings of a sizzling technology start-up company: a better-than-expected offering price, a swarm of investors clamoring for shares and a first-day pop that defied a broader market drop.

headline: China: New Role for Military Vessel
text: China’s defense ministry said the nation’s much-publicized first aircraft carrier, a Soviet-era hulk being refitted in a north China shipyard, will be used purely for research and training and not for deployment in military situations, Xinhua reported.

headline: Coughlin to Have Meeting With Old Nemesis, Burress
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The news at Giants camp Wednesday was a lot like the weather in London: if you did not like it, you could wait an hour for it to change. And when Plaxico Burress is involved, the winds are always shifting.

headline: Appealing to Runners, Even the Barefoot Brigade
text: UNLIKE the economy generally, sales for running shoes are sprinting along, with retail sales for the first half of 2011 up 18 percent over the same period last year, according to SportsOneSource, a market research firm that focuses on sporting goods.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Justice? Vengeance? You Need Both
text: NORWAY, a nation far removed from the wickedness of the world, is now facing one of its greatest moral challenges: What to do with Anders Behring Breivik, the man who has confessed to massacring 76 people, many of them children. Norway does not allow for capital punishment, and the longest prison sentence a killer can usually receive there is 21 years. A country of such otherwise good fortune and peaceful intention is now unprepared — legally and morally —to deal with such a monstrous atrocity.

headline: Slavery and Freedom at Bull Run
text: On the morning of Sunday, July 21, 1861, John Parker and three other men opened fire on Union forces. In the chaos of the Civil War’s first major battle, the group, which was operating a cannon, “couldn’t see the Yankees at all and only fired at random.”

headline: Over the Verrazano, Into the Shadows
text: The Ghost Hunter has Louis Vuitton floor mats, and this I did not expect. He arrives at my building in a customized white Mitsubishi Eclipse with a sound system that’s Madison-Square-Garden-loud and a TV hidden in the dash. It’s less Ghostmobile, more getaway car. I’d forgotten that, esoteric hobbies aside, the Ghost Hunter was born and raised in Brooklyn. And like a lot of guys from Bergen Beach, he loves his car.

headline: Political Links Seen Behind New Jersey Detention Center Bid
text: Three weeks ago, Essex County, N.J., announced that it was seeking a company to run a 450-bed immigrant detention center, hoping to take advantage of a federally financed initiative to set up such facilities with better supervision and medical care.

headline: Heavy Spending Begins, With More on the Way
text: On the second day after the lockout ended, the N.F.L. seemed to slow down to catch its breath. The expected rush of draft pick signings has not materialized yet because of confusion among agents and teams about the new rookie pay system.

headline: Ford to Increase Its Plant Capacity in India
text: NEW DELHI — The Ford Motor Company plans to invest almost $1 billion in northwest India, building factories to make nearly a quarter of a million cars a year, company executives said on Wednesday.

headline: The Path From Poetry to Drudgery
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Life Out There: Eden in a Test Tube
text: To better recognize extraterrestrial life should they come upon it, scientists are working to create simple life forms in a lab. But, as Dennis Overbye reports, they first have to agree what life is.

headline: Deal to Sell a $200 Million Stake in the Mets Is Nearly Done
text: The Mets’ deal to sell a minority stake in the team for $200 million to David Einhorn, a hedge fund manager, is finished except for completing the deal’s paperwork, said one person briefed on the sale.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Lion
text: On this week’s Bits: Tech Talk podcast, we take a long look at Lion, the latest version of the Mac operating system, which was released last week. Our discussion is led by Alan Yacavone, an Apple expert on The Times’s information technology team.

headline: ‘It’s Alive! It’s Alive!’ Maybe Right Here on Earth
text: SAN DIEGO — Here in a laboratory perched on the edge of the continent, researchers are trying to construct Life As We Don’t Know It in a thimbleful of liquid.

headline: Investors, Worried About Debt Talks, Look for Havens
text: Think of it as the flight to safety every investor would like a seat on. The only problem? Nothing is taking off.

headline: Thursday: Now I Get It
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Want to feel a lot better about yourself? We all have our Achilles’ heels when it comes to solving crossword puzzles. For some, it might be categorical, like pop culture or music. For others, it might be directional: I received a lot of mail from confused readers when Caleb Rasmussen’s “U-Turn” puzzle was published (Across Lite, Solution, blog).

headline: Obama and His Discontents
text: The administration of President Obama has never held much regard for its left flank. Admonished by the vice president to “stop whining,” inveighed against by the president himself for “griping and groaning,” the liberal critics have been generally viewed by the White House as petulant children. “The Professional Left,” former press secretary Robert Gibbs dubbed them, a gang of nettlesome romantics who “ought to be drug-tested,” and would not be happy until “we have Canadian health care and we’ve eliminated the Pentagon.”

headline: South Africa: Survey on Schools Details Corruption and Worries
text: A major survey of teachers, students and principals in South Africa’s public schools by Transparency International found that a third of principals believed the highest corruption risk was embezzlement at the provincial level, in textbook procurement and school construction. The report also found that a quarter of students said schools were unsafe, with rape and violence major problems, while half the students said they did not always have a desk.

headline: Unearthing Traces of African-American Village Displaced by Central Park
text: For more than a decade, anthropologists and historians pieced together the history of a short-lived African-American community that was snuffed out in the 1850s by the creation of Central Park. They combed vital records and tax documents, scanned parkland using radar and studied soil borings.

headline: Dunkin’ Donuts Offers a Bubble Lesson
text: Silicon Valley has no monopoly on bubble thinking. This week’s initial public offering of Dunkin’ Brands, owner of the coffee and doughnuts chain and Baskin-Robbins ice cream shops, shows that in a low-growth world, even old-school businesses are capable of exciting investors to new heights of giddiness.

headline: America’s Credibility Is at Risk
text: Until this week, Wall Street has shrugged off each new low in the debt-limit debate, confident — in a whistling-past-the-graveyard kind of way — that Washington would raise the debt limit on time.

headline: Rev. John Stott, Major Evangelical Figure, Dies at 90
text: The Rev. John Stott, one of the world’s most influential figures in the spread of evangelical Christianity over the past half-century, died Wednesday in Lingfield, Surrey, in the south of England. He was 90.

headline: Bike Sting Operation Draws Arrests, and Criticism
text: Last month, police officers in the East Village tried out a sting operation specifically aimed at bicycle deliverymen, who they believe often ride stolen bikes. A plainclothes officer wheeled a black Trek bicycle through the neighborhood, approaching deliverymen with a tempting offer.

headline: This Is Called ‘Small’ Government
text: What has happened to the Federal Aviation Administration in the last few days should remind everyone of the costs of the Republicans’ obstructionism and their slash-and-burn budget games.

headline: Summer Hoops in New York City
text: Zach Zarba, with eight seasons as an N.B.A. referee under his belt, is uncertain when or if he will get to start his ninth.

headline: Housekeeper’s Lawyer Says She Was Misquoted
text: A lawyer for the hotel housekeeper who accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn of sexually assaulting her in May said Wednesday that taped conversations, two of them made a day after the encounter, prove that his client had no intention of exploiting the charges against Mr. Strauss-Kahn to make money.

headline: Sensible and Humane
text: There is no good reason to deprive patients with cancer or H.I.V. or Lou Gehrig’s disease of the relief from pain or extreme nausea that could come from using marijuana.

headline: Climate Change and the Plight of the Whitebark Pine
text: For centuries, the whitebark pine, Pinus albicaulis, has grown on hundreds of thousands of acres across the West. It is a keystone species of an entire ecosystem — one now seriously at risk. Most of the whitebark pines in Yellowstone and Glacier National Parks are dead. It has been declared an endangered species in Canada. And, last week, the Fish and Wildlife Service stated that the whitebark pine “warranted” listing as threatened or endangered, making it one of the very few species officially acknowledged as threatened by climate change.

headline: Beltran’s Replacement Hits Homer as Mets Win
text: CINCINNATI — Lucas Duda is a large young man who doubts he can fill the huge void left by Carlos Beltran in the Mets’ outfield.

headline: Lincecum, Cain and Wheeler?
text: The Mets may have come up with an ingenious solution to finding pitching prospects. Let the champion San Francisco Giants make the decision for them.

headline: Peach Rivalry
text: Georgia has been claiming peaches as its own for more than 100 years, but it now faces a challenge, with South Carolina shipping out nearly twice as many peaches so far this summer.

headline: Obama's Negotiating Skills
text: Adam Serwer, left, of The American Prospect and Katherine Mangu-Ward of Reason debate Obama's negotiating skills during the debt ceiling showdown.

headline: Peach Rivalry Becomes War Between the Tastes
text: CLEMSON, S.C. — The South has plenty of rivalries. Auburn and Alabama fight over football dominance. North Carolina and Tennessee battle over barbecue.

headline: Florida: Drug Laws Ruled Unconstitutional
text: A federal judge in Orlando on Wednesday declared the state’s controlled-substances laws unconstitutional. A 2002 Florida law eliminated the requirement of a “guilty mind,” or “mens rea,” as part of a drug offense. Briefs attacking the Florida law, in which a defendant need not know that a substance is illegal to be convicted of possessing or selling it, had been filed by groups including the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, the American Civil Liberties Union and dozens of law professors. Judge Mary S. Scriven of Federal District Court threw out the drug delivery charges against Mackle Vincent Shelton, and ordered a new sentencing hearing on other charges. Florida’s unique law expressly eliminating mens rea for drug offenses, the judge wrote, is “atavistic and repugnant to the common law.” The state is expected to appeal the decision, which could leave hundreds, if not thousands, of convictions in question and affect pending cases.

headline: Senate Extends Term of F.B.I. Director
text: The Senate on Wednesday voted unanimously to extend the tenure of Robert S. Mueller III as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for two more years. Mr. Mueller, first appointed by President George W. Bush, was to step down on Aug. 2 because of a 10-year term limit imposed during the post-Watergate era. But President Obama asked Congress to allow Mr. Mueller to stay on, arguing that his national security team needed continuity because the Pentagon and the Central Intelligence Agency were getting new leaders.

headline: Manchester United Dismantles M.L.S.’s Best in Repeat of Last Year
text: HARRISON, N.J. — Once again, one of the richest soccer clubs in the world, which boasts some of the best players on the planet, showed a team of the best Major League Soccer has to offer that you get what you pay for, or don’t.

headline: Bankrupt Evangelical Megachurch May Get a Roman Catholic Makeover
text: GARDEN GROVE, Calif.— The Crystal Cathedral, once a symbol of America’s evangelical movement where thousands of congregants attended services each Sunday, may be about to make a major religious conversion: The Roman Catholic Church is looking to buy the headquarters of the bankrupt megachurch.

headline: Justices Are Asked to Hear Challenge to Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court was asked on Wednesday to hear a challenge to the health care overhaul law, raising the possibility that the justices could rule on the matter by next summer, just months before the presidential election. Similar requests are likely to follow, and it is not clear which if any of them the court will agree to hear.

headline: Ultimate Clambake
text: Time: 4 to 6 hours

headline: Let’s Have a Real Nice Clambake
text: A clambake is one of those absurdly demanding culinary tasks that can still be performed by normal people — that is, nonchefs. And your first clambake can go well: the hardest part is finding the right beach, preferably one with an abundance of seaweed, big rocks and dry wood. It’s still not an intuitive process; at my first clambake, I wound up scraped, burned and sore, and the food I produced was undercooked and sandy. Part of this was drinking too much, too early, and part of it was that I was making it up as I went along.

headline: The Hidden Costs of Medical Student Debt
text: He was a senior surgeon many of us in training wanted to emulate — smart, busy and beloved by patients and staff. But we loved him most because he could have been any one of us. He had slogged through the same training program some 15 years earlier, and he had survived.

headline: The Beltran Years, By the Numbers
text: To some Mets fans, Carlos Beltran was the player who took the famous called third strike in Game 7 of the 2006 N.L.C.S.; who was tagged out at home in a 2009 game against St. Louis because he declined to slide; who would maddeningly choose, on occasion, to bunt runners over rather than go for a big inning; who would play deep in center rather than challenge batters to hit it over his head.

headline: Explosion Contained at Power Plant in Queens
text: A small explosion occurred at a power plant in Queens on Wednesday night, though no one was injured.

headline: Chinese Officials Blame Design Flaws in Deadly Train Crash
text: BEIJING — Chinese railway officials blame “serious design flaws” in railroad signaling equipment for the high-speed train crash in eastern China that left 39 people dead and 192 people injured on Saturday, the official news agency Xinhua reported Thursday.

headline: China: Officials Say They Saved 81 Babies From Child Traffickers
text: The Ministry of Public Security said Wednesday that the police had rescued 81 children from a child trafficking ring in eastern China. Xinhua, China’s official news agency, reported that 13 babies were rescued in Hebei Province ranging in age from 10 days to 4 months; most were girls. Liu Ancheng, a ministry deputy director, blamed the practice of “buying and selling children in this country” on the traditional preference for boy babies.

headline: Kill, Kill, Kill, Kill...
text: A look at the “Friday the 13th” franchise over the years and the many activities at Camp Crystal Lake.

headline: Bonds Build Jerome Avenue
text: The tale of the bonds used to build the road that eventually became Jerome Avenue in the Bronx.

headline: Five Days Later, Chinese Concede Design Flaw Had Role in Wreck
text: BEIJING — China broke days of stony silence on Thursday about the cause of a deadly crash on its new high-speed rail system, as officials acknowledged a serious design flaw in signaling equipment and the prime minister visited the crash site and promised to prosecute those responsible for an accident that has infuriated the Chinese public.

headline: 2 Die as Asiana Cargo Plane Crashes Off South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — An Asiana Airlines cargo plane crashed into waters off the southern coast of South Korea on Thursday after reporting a fire in its cargo compartments, government officials said.

headline: People and Explosives Missing After South Korea Deluge
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Thousands of soldiers and police officers searched muddy wreckage and rain-swollen streams on Thursday for victims, survivors and explosives after floods and mudslides set off by torrential rain killed at least 59 people. Ten others were reported missing.

text: Today’s question was written by Susan Behrens, who is a professor at Marymount Manhattan College and the author of “Grammar: A Pocket Guide.” Her question comes from the obituary “Rev. Mary M. Simpson, a Pioneer in Episcopal Clergy, Dies at 85.”

headline: Berlin Beer Festival to Offer 2,000 Brews
text: From Aug. 5 to 7, if you come upon bar maids in silly costumes and gallons of beer flowing from taps, you haven’t stumbled on an out-of-season Oktoberfest. This is the Berlin International Beer Festival, in which Communist-era housing blocks provide the backdrop for a suds-themed party.

text: Today’s Times

headline: And Speaking of Sentences …
text: As long as we are making lists of great sentences, let me include my favorite line from a film trailer: “We’ve got 500 years of prison time at this table. And that’s a lot of wisdom.” It comes from “The Interrupters,” a new documentary by Steve James (“Hoop Dreams”) and Alex Kotlowitz, the author of several books, including “There Are No Children Here,” and many great stories for this magazine.
