headline: Earbuds That Don’t Sweat Sweat
text: The JF3 Freedom Bluetooth stereo headphones from Jaybird are made for this heat wave — the headphones are designed to be sweat-proof. They even come with a lifetime guarantee against damage caused by sweat.

headline: Losing at Restaurant Roulette
text: “You should feel honored we are here tonight,” said the young woman at the bar.“I do feel honored. Any particular reason?” I asked.“We had reservations at three restaurants and chose this one.”“She’s not kidding,” said her boyfriend.“I’m delighted,” I said. “But I feel bad for the other guys.”“Don’t worry,” she said. “We called and canceled.”“We’re very polite people,” added her beau. “Picky, but polite.”“Just curious,” I said. “When did you call them?”“When was it, honey? Six, six-thirty?”“Yes. Just before we came over to Southfork.”

headline: Alex Trebek Chases Suspected Burglar, Inspiring Awful ‘Jeopardy!’ Jokes
text: KGO Television in San Francisco reports that the “Jeopardy!” host Alex Trebek appeared Wednesday at the National Geographic World Championship on crutches, having torn his Achilles tendon earlier that morning when he chased after a burglar who broke into his room and tried to steal cash and other items from him. (The suspect, a 56-year-old woman, was arrested and charged with felony burglary and possession of stolen property.)

headline: Twin Blasts Leave 12 Dead in Iraqi City
text: BAGHDAD — Two explosions struck outside a bank in Tikrit, Saddam Hussein’s hometown, on Thursday, just as soldiers were lining up to cash their paychecks. The first report on casualties indicated that 12 people died and 28 were wounded, a local official said.

headline: Eurofail
text: For some reason events in European bonds markets aren’t making big headlines. But they should be: even as the GOP does its best to destroy America’s credit, things are falling apart, with a vengeance, on the other side of the Atlantic.

headline: Q. and A.: ‘The Rambunctious Garden’
text: The Madrona Woods cascade down a hillside and through a ravine, connecting the Seattle neighborhood where I live with Lake Washington below. Thanks to volunteer efforts and timely financing, native plants thrive along the pathways, and a restored creek empties into the lake at a recreated cove, offering habitat for salmon fingerlings.

headline: When They Play Women, It’s Not Just an Act
text: FOR someone whose only acting experience was playing a Boy George lookalike in a high school production of the musical “The Wedding Singer,” Harmony Santana is having an incredible year. Ms. Santana is making her big-screen debut in Rashaad Ernesto Green’s coming-out drama “Gun Hill Road,” which had its premiere in January at the Sundance Film Festival. Last month the movie made a splash on the gay film-festival circuit, opening Outfest in Los Angeles and closing Newfest in New York. It opens commercially in New York on Aug. 5.

headline: Italy's Borrowing Costs Jump
text: PARIS — Italy’s borrowing costs rose almost a full percentage point from a month ago at an auction of 10-year bonds Thursday, to the highest rate in more than a decade, in another troubling sign that the latest rescue package for the euro zone has not eased investors’ concerns.

headline: With Sales Plummeting, Nintendo Pares Outlook And Cuts a Retail Price
text: TOKYO — In a striking reversal of fortune for the world’s largest video game maker, Nintendo drastically cut its annual profit outlook on Thursday and said it would deeply discount its new 3DS hand-held device as it struggles to stem a flow of users to casual online games.

headline: Bank of Ireland Gets a Boost From Wilbur Ross and Investors
text: Wilbur Ross is not afraid of a debt crisis.

headline: Lazard Profit Rises 23%, but Misses Estimates
text: 8:45 a.m. | Updated Lazard‘s second-quarter profit rose 23 percent from the period a year earlier, as increasing deal activity and growth in assets under management bolstered results, the investment bank said on Thursday.

headline: After a Year of Inspections, 69 Percent of City Restaurants Have A’s
text: A full year after the city’s health commissioner, Thomas A Farley, placed the first blue-and-white Grade A food-safety placard in the front window of Spark’s Deli in Long Island City, Queens, officials say nearly every restaurant in New York has been inspected and most are making the grade.        Of the city’s 24,000 restaurants, 69 percent had been issued an A, 15 percent a B and 4 percent a C as of July 1, said Susan Craig, a health department spokeswoman. Twelve percent had “grade pending” designations.        During the course of the year, 40 percent of the restaurants received an A grade on initial inspection, Ms. Craig said. Of the restaurants initially granted a C grade, 55 percent had advanced to an A or B grade on their next inspection.

headline: Foreign Entanglements, New York Style
text: George Washington took the presidential oath of office in Lower Manhattan in 1789, but he didn’t spend much time here; the country’s nascent government soon moved to Philadelphia. Maybe if he had stuck around longer, people in this city would have taken closer to heart his later warning against foreign entanglements.

headline: L-3 to Spin Off a Government Services Unit
text: L-3 Communications Holdings said on Thursday that it planned to spin off some of its government services operations into a new company, freeing it from potential conflicts of interest with its parent.

headline: Border Crossers
text: As a vicious drug war rages right on the other side of the Mexican border, El Paso quietly prospers. This isn’t illogical. This is just how it works.

headline: Life on the Line
text: El Paso and Ciudad Juárez lie together uncomfortably like an estranged couple, surrounded on all sides by mountains and desert. The cities are separated by the thin trickle of the Rio Grande, which flows through concrete channels, built to put an end to the river’s natural habit of changing course and muddying boundaries. One side is Texas; the other, Mexico. The border’s way of life — its business, legitimate and otherwise — has always relied upon the circumvention of this dividing line.

headline: Suicide Bombers Attack Afghan Provincial Capital
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban launched one of their most audacious surprise attacks on Thursday, sending a squad of at least seven suicide bombers into the capital of a relatively stable southern province with the aim of assassinating the provincial governor and an influential powerbroker. Neither was killed, but security and health officials said at least 21 civilians had died in the collateral mayhem, half of them children.

headline: The Lowdown | Wade Slitkin
text: When Wade Slitkin leaves a room, the most common utterance is: “That kid’s gonna do big things.” Slitkin just has this air about him — of intelligence and keen intuition. He’s the kind of guy you would trust with your puppy. A street-smart product of inner-city public schools, Slitkin worked in “special markets” for several major book publishers, until it became clear that he was building rocket ships in the belly of a dinosaur. Two years ago, he scraped up his savings and, together with two of his buddies, Stephen Lynch and Brett Dovman, created Panelfly, an app designed to revolutionize storytelling in modern times. Cryptically described as “SuperMedia,” Panelfly, according to the official description, unlocks the full potential around a media franchise, pulling related films, books, games, interviews and art together into a singular experience, transforming how we experience entertainment altogether. At a time when everyone in the publishing and media industries is scratching their heads and bordering on desperation, Slitkin is being heralded as a boy genius.

headline: George Clooney’s ‘Ides of March’ Will Open Venice Film Festival
text: Though it was bad news for Julius Caesar “The Ides of March” has already proved a good-luck charm for George Clooney: his new political thriller of that title will make its debut as the opening night offering of the Venice Film Festival, its organizers said on Thursday. Mr. Clooney directed the film, which is adapted from the Beau Willimon play “Farragut North,” and stars as an aspiring presidential candidate who turns to a novice press secretary (played by Ryan Gosling) to help manage his campaign. Other films that will be shown in competition at the festival, which will run from Aug. 31 through Sept. 10, include Roman Polanski’s “Carnage,” his film adaptation of “God of Carnage,” starring Jodie Foster, Kate Winslet, Christoph Waltz and John C. Reilly; “Dark Horse,” a new film by Todd Solondz, starring Mia Farrow, Christopher Walken, Justin Bartha and Selma Blair; William Friedkin‘s film version of “Killer Joe,” starring Matthew McConaughey and Emile Hirsch; and David Cronenberg‘s “Dangerous Method,” his drama about Carl Jung and Sigmund Freud. The festival’s out-of-competition lineup will include “W.E.”, a new film directed by Madonna; “Contagion,” directed by Steven Soderbergh; and “Wilde Salome,” directed by and starring Al Pacino. The festival’s closing-night film will be “Damsels in Distress,” the first new feature in more than a decade from Whit Stillman.

headline: With Sewage in Hudson, a Big Blow to Business
text: The frontiersmen of the Hudson River, as some like to call themselves, arrived over two decades ago determined to transform the filthy industrial waterway slicked with oily rainbows into an aquatic playground fit for a 21st-century city.

headline: Zawahri, Al Qaeda’s New Leader, Praises Syrian Protesters
text: In what appeared to be his first video message since succeeding Osama bin Laden as the leader of Al Qaeda, Ayman al-Zawahri expressed strong support for antigovernment protesters in Syria, claiming that their movement to topple the country’s authoritarian leader was rooted in a wider regional conflict with the United States and Israel.

headline: Freshman Republicans Face Defining Debt Vote
text: When it comes to politics, there may be no more closely watched group on Thursday than the 87 House Republicans who were elected to Congress for the first time in 2010.

headline: New Hacking Case Outrages Britain
text: LONDON — Britain was awash in a new surge of outrage over the phone hacking scandal on Thursday as news emerged that Scotland Yard had added to the list of probable victims a woman whose 8-year-old daughter was murdered by a repeat sex offender in 2000.

headline: Housekeeper’s Lawyer Says She Was Misquoted
text: A lawyer for the hotel housekeeper who accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn of sexually assaulting her in May said Wednesday that taped conversations, two of them made a day after the encounter, prove that his client had no intention of exploiting the charges against Mr. Strauss-Kahn to make money.

headline: Surveying the Electoral Damage of the Debt Debate
text: Republicans may not have scored a knockout blow on the policy elements of the debt ceiling debate. But since the remaining proposals consist entirely of spending cuts while still reducing the debt significantly, the judges ought to award them a unanimous decision unless something changes in the last round.

headline: House Puts Off Debt Vote as Press by Boehner Fails
text: WASHINGTON — Short of support from their conservative members, House Republican leaders on Thursday abruptly put off a vote on their proposal to raise the debt ceiling and cut government spending, throwing last-ditch efforts to avert a government default next week into disarray.

headline: Cataclysms, Climate Change and California Opinion
text: One of the pleasures of following the annual surveys of the state’s environmental attitudes by the Public Policy Institute of California is witnessing how one-time cataclysms (financial crises, tsunamis, oil spills and the like) throw the neat progression of opinion change out of whack for a year or so. And then, like a rubber band springing back into shape, the attitudes largely revert to their old patterns; the cataclysm seems to have little lasting influence.

headline: Hear ‘So Many Stars,’ a Song From the New Barbra Streisand Album
text: You know Alan and Marilyn Bergman as the husband-and-wife songwriters of award-winning songs like “The Way We Were,” “The Windmills of Your Mind” and “It Might Be You.” You know Barbra Streisand as Barbra Streisand. The three have been friends since the Bergmans first saw the 18-year-old Ms. Streisand perform at the Bon Soir, a Greenwich Village club where she shared a dressing room with Phyllis Diller, and though Ms. Streisand has since graduated to bigger performance spaces, her artistic collaboration with the Bergmans has endured.

headline: Thursday Reading: Veteran Care Costs Will Continue to Rise
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Straddling the Border, Eccentrically
text: “CAN’T believe the risks I’m taking,” the Mexican songwriter Ximena Sariñana sings in “Different,” the single and opening track of her self-titled new album, due for release on Tuesday. It’s the way she felt, she said by telephone from Los Angeles, as she changed languages and home countries to seize a chance at reaching the wider world.

headline: Here Comes the Neighborhood
text: If you want to revisit some memory lanes, at least of the Parker Brothers sort, from back when you were pretty sure you would make a great real estate tycoon when you grew up, then go to Google Maps and plug in the address for the Revel Casino, which was featured in last weekend’s Look essay. There it is: 500 Boardwalk, Atlantic City, right around the corner from the original Vermont and Oriental Avenues. (Somehow it seems fitting that Morgan Stanley, which lost around a billion dollars on its Revel investment, failed to put the casino on one of the farther-off orange properties, particularly New York Avenue, which, if I read this and this right, is the optimal Monopoly strategy.)

headline: N.F.L. Free-for-All Central, Starring Kolb, Haynesworth and Rice

But it would not be proper mayhem unless something really head-slapping happened. Like, say, the Patriots trading for Albert Haynesworth.

headline: Analyze This: A Webisode’s Id Meets Its TV Ego
text: GIVEN the (purportedly) rising status of, and increased investment in, online video, you would expect Showtime’s television version of “Web Therapy” — one of the most accomplished and high-profile of Web series — to be getting a lot more attention than it is. It’s hard to generate buzz, though, when a show is given little or no promotion and buried at 11 p.m. on Tuesdays.

headline: Dear FloFab: My Dinner Guests Invite Their Own Guests

headline: Museum of Modern Art Raising Admission and Membership Fees
text: The Museum of Modern Art, faced with what it calls “escalating costs in virtually all aspects of operating the museum,’’ is raising its admission price to $25 for adults from $20, where it has been since 2004. The change takes effect on Sept. 1. Admission will remain free for children 16 and under; the charge for full-time students will rise to $14 from $12.

headline: Art That Interacts if You Interface
text: The Museum of Modern Art’s “Talk to Me: Design and the Communication Between People and Objects” is one of the smartest design shows in years — by which I mean that it’s intelligent but also that it’s made for the texting, tweeting, social-networking, app-downloading, smartphone-wielding museumgoer.

headline: Video: A Smartphone Showdown

headline: Florida Judge Throws Out Verdict in Ford Unintended-Acceleration Case
text: A Florida judge on July 20 said Ford misled the court and federal safety investigators by concealing documents in a case decided in Ford’s favor in 2010. According to the judge, the documents proved that unintended acceleration in certain vehicles could have been caused by electromagnetic interference with those vehicles’ cruise control systems.

headline: Poetry Pairing | July 28, 2011
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. headline: Weak Earnings in Germany Raise Concerns of Slowing Growth
text: FRANKFURT — Underwhelming earnings reports Thursday from several of Germany’s largest companies, along with a report showing a slump in confidence among European business and consumers, raised concerns that growth could be slowing even in the Continent’s strongest economies.

headline: New Blood for ‘The Walking Dead': AMC Replaces Producer

headline: Reborn in the Bronx, and Celebrating Its Identity

headline: Brooklyn Philharmonic Announces 2011-12 Season
text: The Brooklyn Philharmonic has announced its first season under a new music director, Alan Pierson: a slate of grab-bag community concerts with a strong popular-music inflection. The organization will offer a series of concerts in three neighborhoods — Brighton Beach, Bedford-Stuyvesant and downtown Brooklyn — to be played in theaters, at a Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. and at the Brooklyn Public Library, among other sites. Each set of concerts includes an orchestral affair, chamber music performance and family workshop. The orchestra stopped performing at the Brooklyn Academy of Music after financial woes forced it to cut back on activity two years ago.

headline: Vettel: Fear and Loathing on the Autobahn

headline: The Road Giveth and Taketh a Bit, Too
text: WALLA WALLA, Wash. — The world wasn’t built for bicyclists. The hazards for us are both natural (hills, headwinds) and man-made (bridges, speeding truckers hauling double trailers, fishtailing RVs, pavement strewn with debris). On a long-distance ride, a bite of anxiety accompanies every turn onto a new road. What awaits?

headline: London Theater Journal: Freedom to Explore in ‘The Cherry Orchard’
text: LONDON — Do you know that Chekhov play about the aging vaudevillians who get together to put on one last show for one another? No, I didn’t realize that was what “The Cherry Orchard” is about either. But that was more or less the impression I had after seeing Howard Davies’s interpretation at the National Theater, which stars Zoë Wanamaker as the unlucky-in-love Ranyevskaya.

headline: A’s Demote Reliever After Wildness at Stadium

If you don’t recall the TC, it was a mid-’80s Chrysler LeBaron with a Maserati trident. That mongrel gave opera windows a bad name, which is saying something.

headline: A Young Clown Follows in a Father’s Giant Footsteps

headline: Keeping Score: Adam Dunn’s Historically Bad Season
text: This generation of baseball fans has grown accustomed to records falling, both at the plate and on the mound, but this season the Chicago White Sox slugger Adam Dunn is quietly making history of a different sort. With a batting average of .161, he is on track to put up the lowest single-season batting average by any player qualified for a batting title since 1910.

Backers said the huge construction project, new roads and wave of shoppers would bring hundreds of sorely needed jobs to this bucolic corner of Tuscany.

headline: The Great Fleet Street Novel
text: “If you’d gone to a publisher in 1981 with a proposal for a science-fiction novel that consisted of a really clear and simple description of the world today,” William Gibson told The Paris Review recently, “they’d have read your proposal and said: ‘Well, it’s impossible. This is ridiculous.’ ” You’d have gotten a similar reaction if you’d gone to a publisher earlier this year with a proposal for a novel that went something like this: journalists on a British tabloid hack into and delete the voice mail messages of a missing (murdered, it turns out) teenage girl. Their activities are exposed by a rival outfit, to widespread public outrage. The paper in question is shut down by its owner, despite having a circulation of millions. Senior policemen, who hired former journalists from the paper as press officers, resign. Evidence emerges of illegal payments from the paper to corrupt police in exchange for information about celebrities, politicians and crime victims. Several journalists are arrested, including two former editors of the paper, one of whom had worked for the prime minister. A whistle-blower is found dead (though police say it isn’t suspicious). The paper’s owner, mogul of an international media empire, is summoned to testify before Parliament. And the allegations of wrongdoing just keep coming.

headline: Extraterrestrials Land at the O.K. Corral
text: Galloping across the desert, his inscrutable baby blues fixed on the horizon, Daniel Craig makes for a surprisingly convincing cowboy. Some actors, including a few in his new movie, “Cowboys & Aliens,” look too modern for old-timey roles. There isn’t enough grit, suffering and poor nutrition in their faces, and their gestures and gaits are timed to the impatient rhythms of the information age. But Mr. Craig, with his brutally handsome face and coiled physicality, looks like a rawhide whip that’s just itching to get cracking.

text: The Look: Blue with a view — a knit dress in classic navy with jewels that outshine the shoes is tops.

headline: Goldman and Citigroup’s Bond Sale Thwarted by S.&P.

headline: 36 Hours in Budapest
text: A weekend here provides a glimpse of the city’s justifiable pride, as well as an authentic sense of place.

headline: 36 Hours in Budapest
text: LIKE much of post-Communist Europe, Budapest has replaced the image of the impoverished East with symbols of international luxury, like the Four Seasons Hotel Gresham Palace and a new branch of Nobu, the high-end Japanese restaurant. But unlike many other cities in the region, the Hungarian capital’s brightest spots are often native-born, rather than imports. From stately Buda in the west to Pest’s shabby-chic streets east of the Danube, a range of new attractions show off the achievements of local artists, producers, vintners and chefs. Even if you don’t end up tasting every last domestic food specialty identified as a “hungarikum,” or tracking down every up-and-coming designer, a weekend here provides a glimpse of the city’s justifiable pride, as well as an authentic sense of place.

headline: Summer Percussion Special
text: This week: summer percussion special. Larry Rohter talks music and philosophy with the percussionist/composer Adam Rudolph; Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen sort out the new vibraphone scene in jazz. And new CDs by Kelly Rowland, Joss Stone and Cerebral Ballzy. Ben Ratliff is the host.

headline: Innovation from the Bottom Up
text: The Rockefeller Foundation, in deciding how to dispense tens of millions of dollars in grants each year, typically sends scouting teams around the world to search out problems impeding human well-being and organizations or individuals working to address them.

headline: Good and Evil on Cable
text: In the interest of talking about something besides the debt ceiling for a moment, here’s an engaging Chuck Klosterman piece comparing moral agency on “Mad Men,” “The Wire” and “The Sopranos” to the moral landscape of AMC’s returning hit “Breaking Bad” (currently the best show on television, for my money). Klosterman notes that “all of these series grapple with morality — more than anything else, it’s the reason they’re better than the shows around them.” But he argues that “the first three examples all create realities where individual agency is detached” and questions of personal moral choice aren’t foregrounded: “Mad Men” because it’s set in the 1960s, making its characters’ actions more a “commentary on the era” than a window into their souls, “The Wire” because it’s “more political than philosophical,” bent on constantly emphasizing the way “everyone is simultaneously good and bad” in order to offer a critique of American society as a whole, and “The Sopranos” because the fact all its major characters were involved with organized crime and its protagonist murdered people for money meant that there were never any unresolved questions over Tony Soprano’s ‘goodness.'” (We knew he was “fundamentally bad,” Klosterman argues, because “otherwise he couldn’t exist as the person he was.”)

headline: Bradley Fired As National Team Coach
text: Sunil Gulati, president of United States Soccer, announced on Thursday that Bob Bradley had been relieved of his duties as head coach of the men’s national team. More details here. Is this the solution for the program’s recent struggles?

headline: The Netflix-Hulu Divide
text: While it has been known that Netflix and Hulu streaming users are consuming internet bandwidth at a huge and ever increasing rate, what hasn’t been widely reported is just what they’ve been watching with these services. According to a recent survey conducted by Nielsen, less than half of Netflix users watch on their home computer, instead opting to connect via video-game consoles hooked up to their television. Conversely, almost 90 percent of Hulu users watch directly on their computer. Thirty-six percent of all Netflix users watch both movies and television shows while, unsurprisingly, 73 percent of Hulu users watch television programs. Only 9 percent who use Hulu use the service to watch movies. Streaming on mobile devices such as cellphones or tablets like the iPad hasn’t gone beyond early adopters just yet – only 6 percent of Netflix users and 3 percent of all Hulu users watch on the go.

headline: Popcast: Summer Percussion Special

headline: New York at First Bite: Oh, the Places You’ll Go
text: Dead of summer, but still the postman trudges forth to the mountaintop with questions for Mr. Critic, meditating on his zafu pillow. This week brought queries about a first-time trip to New York City, about where to feed a world-weary New Yorker and about where to hold a rehearsal dinner for American expatriates in from London and seeking British food. You may add your own voices to the choir at the Diner’s Journal blog. And feel free to send your questions about restaurants in New York City to dinejournal@nytimes.com.

headline: A Taxonomy of Movie Men
text: In their joint column this weekend, the Times film critics A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis provide an exhaustive (and quite funny) field guide to modern male cinematic archetypes. The round-up includes the Big Baby (e.g. “smiley, sexless Kevin James” or the Zach Galafianakis type, “edgier, crueler, with beards”); the Brave Boy (“brooding and brash,” like Harry Potter or [10 points here if you can name Shia LaBoeuf’s character in the Transformer films]*); the Husband (“henpecked and undersexed”); and the Wimp (“subsets include the Nerd, the Geek, the Nebbish and, often offensively, the Gay Guy”).

headline: Ex-Yankee Irabu Found Dead
text: Hideki Irabu, the former Yankees pitcher who struggled to live up to grand expectations after coming over from Japan, was found dead in Los Angeles on Thursday. He was 42. Police are investigating Irabu’s death as a possible suicide, according to various reports. Irabu came to the United States in 1997 billed as one of Japan’s premier right-handed pitchers. The Padres owned his rights, but Irabu refused to play for any team but the Yankees. San Diego traded him to the Yankees, who signed him to a four-year, $12.8 million contract. His career began with such promise, when he struck out nine and allowed two runs as the Yankees defeated Detroit in his major league debut, on July 10, 1997. That start proved the highlight of the season. He was banished to the bullpen and the minor leagues, and he finished the year 5-4 with a 7.09 earned run average. In 1999, Steinbrenner erupted after Irabu failed to cover first base during an exhibition game, calling him a fat toad.   In three seasons with the Yankees, Irabu was 29-20 and pitched in only one postseason game, when he came out of the bullpen to allow eight runs to the Red Sox in Game 3 of the 1999 American League Championship Series. Two months later, Irabu was traded to Montreal, where he started 14 games over 2000 and 2001, before finishing his career with Texas in 2002. He retired in 2004 after pitching two seasons for the Hanshin Tigers in Japan.

headline: Another Teary Moment for Boehner
text: By all accounts, House Speaker John A. Boehner has been a relentless, cold-eyed negotiator in the debt ceiling face-off with President Obama.

headline: The Halt and the Lame
text: Simon Johnson writes about who’s worse — America or Europe? Basically I agree with his assessment: Europe has more fundamental problems in sheer economic terms, because it adopted a single currency without the necessary institutions to make it workable. America has a long-run budget problem, but our current mess is entirely political. Unfortunately, that doesn’t make it any easier to solve.

headline: The Culturialist | Ukrainian Passport
text: Back in 2007, Peter Doroshenko, who was then the artistic director of the Victor Pinchuk Foundation, asked a handful of artists to respond to the question “Where is Ukraine going?” for an installation at the Ukrainian pavilion during the Venice Biennale. The photographer Juergen Teller visited Kiev three times in five months for the project, and the photos he took on these trips speak to the extraordinary wealth he saw there. Teller’s view of Kiev is steeped in the language of fashion and excess — models, hair, makeup, styling — and interspersed with more candid snaps of everyday scenes.

headline: Brooks Boasted of Paper’s Campaign in Murdered Girl’s Memory
text: Updated | Friday | 11:31 a.m. As my colleagues Sarah Lyall and Ravi Somaiya report, British police officials investigating the hacking of phones by News of the World journalists “have added to the list of probable victims a woman whose 8-year-old daughter was murdered by a repeat sex offender in 2000.”

text: A three-par golf course in the Hamptons known as the Pox is popular for its lack of snobbery, and for its pancakes.

headline: ‘Northwest Corner’

headline: Reconstructive Surgery for a Shattered Family
text: The Humpty-Dumpty of families, the Arnos seem irreparably broken apart. We first came to know them in John Burnham Schwartz’s 1998 novel, “Reservation Road.” Eloquently told but brutal, the story follows the Arnos and another family as they collide in a horrific car accident and shatter.

headline: MoMa PS 1 Plans 9/11 Exhibition
text: Images of 9/11 are embedded in our visual memory: the airplanes flying into the twin towers; the towers crumbling; the fleeing people; the stark Manhattan skyline when it was over.

headline: A Haven for Golf, or Fried Eggs
text: THE beige bunker that houses the Poxabogue Golf Center and its fragrant Fairway Restaurant sits unpretentiously on the shoulder of Montauk Highway in billionaire-studded Sagaponack, as if protected by squatters’ rights. The driving range popped up on the horizon in 1957, one step ahead of the zoning czars. A 1961 variance grandfathered the beginner-tolerant nine-hole, par-3 public golf course into the picture.

headline: Rights Advocates Criticize Light Sentences in Sectarian Killings in Indonesia
text: SERANG, Indonesia — Twelve members of a mob that set upon adherents of an Islamic sect, killing three of them, received sentences of three to six months in jail on Thursday. Rights advocates criticized the ruling as an example of growing impunity for violence against religious minorities in Indonesia.

headline: Below the High Line, Spiraling Roller Skaters
text: The man was an island of bliss in the midst of chaos. He twirled, spinning on roller skates under the High Line, balanced and composed. Around him, people were falling. Legs splayed. Wrists buckled. An ankle was sprained.

headline: The Caucus Click: Conscientious Objection
text: A group of clergy members were arrested in the Capitol Rotunda while protesting against budget cuts.

headline: A Fount of Soul, Full Throttle and Unbowed
text: WANTAGH, N.Y. — Aretha Franklin isn’t letting medical problems sideline her anymore. At Jones Beach Theater on Wednesday night she let fly a voice with its power, range and improvisational spirit fully alive. Her songs were about the strength and the value of a good woman’s love, freely given, and about the healing powers of faith. She sang about earthly and divine ecstasy, and she sang simply to exult in her voice.

headline: A.B.: After Bradley, Who?
text: Four weeks ago, the Goal blog asked Sunil Gulati, the president of the United States Soccer Federation, about the status of the national team coach, Bob Bradley, after the American team’s uneven showing in the Concacaf Gold Cup. The e-mail response was that there would be something at the end of the week, that being the end of June.

text: Craig Johnson’s tender indie comedy, “True Adolescents,” examines the interim passages of male lives when time is nervously frittered away and the future looms through the mist like a giant scary question mark.

headline: An Apartment With a Little Give
text: KATIE WADE, a copywriter for a pharmaceutical advertising agency who grew up in New Jersey, moved to New York in 2003 after graduating from Georgetown. She did the usual bouncing around — living in one apartment after another with various friends from high school and college. But after a few years, she decided it was finally time to acquire a place of her own.

headline: AstraZeneca Settles Most Seroquel Suits
text: The British drug maker AstraZeneca has settled in principle nearly all of the American product liability lawsuits over Seroquel, its blockbuster antipsychotic drug, the company said in a quarterly earnings report on Thursday.

text: Reality television offers at least two other stops after a 12-step program — there’s Dr. Drew and then Dr. Dolittle.

headline: Lehman Case Hints at Need to Stiffen Audit Rules
text: The company misled investors and its officers and directors may be held liable. But the company’s auditor seems likely to escape any responsibility for an audit that wrongly concluded the company’s financial statements were completely proper.

headline: Death of Rebel Leader Stirs Fears of Tribal Conflict
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — The top rebel military commander was killed Thursday, and members of his tribe greeted the announcement with gunfire and angry threats. The violent outburst stirred fears that a tribal feud could divide the forces struggling to topple the Libyan dictator, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Charting the American Debt Crisis
text: America has a long history of raising the debt limit to accommodate spending. A look at some of the issues in the debate over the nation’s debt.

headline: No Bringing Up Baby on Facebook
text: My husband and I are expecting our first child, and we plan to tell his parents after the first trimester. My mother-in-law posts photos and personal information on Facebook indiscriminately. But for privacy and safety reasons, I prefer no mention of my pregnancy on Facebook or anything about our child, even after he is born. Subtle messages don’t always register with her. How can I inform her that her involvement in my baby’s life will wane if she does not comply with my wishes? Anonymous

headline: It’s Paris, and Everyone Is Rotten but the Man Chased by the Police
text: “Point Blank” is an exhilarating adrenaline rush with breakneck momentum so shrewdly calculated that you could imagine its French director, Fred Cavayé, standing by with a heart-rate monitor. Just when the beats per minute have accelerated beyond 160, and you are gasping for air, a momentary respite gives you a few seconds to wipe your brow, catch your breath and take a sip from your water bottle. Then you’re shoved back into the race. I can’t recall another thriller that has maintained this kind of velocity without going kablooey and losing its train of thought.

headline: ‘This Beautiful Life’
text: Her mouth filled the screen. Purple lip gloss, clear braces.

headline: Up Front: Maria Russo
text: Maria Russo is at work on a memoir of her Roman Catholic girlhood in New York, where, she recalled in a recent e-mail, as a student from Queens enrolled at Hunter College High School, she was part of an earlier wave of upwardly mobile teenagers like Jake, the troubled son in Helen Schulman’s latest novel, “This Beautiful Life.” Although, Russo explained, “we didn’t have cellphones and had to rely strictly on word of mouth about where the parties were.”

headline: Total Family Breakdown, 21st-Century Manhattan Style
text: Helen Schulman’s latest novel tells the story of the Bergamots, a family of four whose expensive new Manhattan life comes crashing down when 15-year-old Jake forwards to a friend a sexually explicit video made for him, unsolicited, by a 13-year-old girl named Daisy Cavanaugh. As the video, forwarded again and again, goes viral, the tabloid media go bananas, linking Jake and Daisy in an ominous and humiliating celebrity. What can the future hold for unformed, vulnerable kids who bumble their way into the lowliest realm of the permanent record that is the Internet? (Or, in ­Daisy’s case, reach it by simulating sex with a toy baseball bat.) Should their parents be held responsible, or are they equally victimized by the seductions and traps of digital life?

headline: A Russian Who Ignores Those Old Stereotypes
text: It seems odd that a pianist as accomplished as Dmitri Alexeev does not perform in New York more often than he does. Now 63, Mr. Alexeev studied at the Moscow Conservatory and won a string of competition prizes in the early 1970s. But he has sidestepped the stereotypes of both Russian pianism (big, brawny and loud) and the international competition style (dazzling but risk averse). His recital on Wednesday as part of the International Keyboard Institute and Festival at the Mannes College the New School for Music showed him to be a thoughtful, poetic player willing to go out on a limb, interpretively, usually to superb effect.

headline: Paying for Title Insurance
text: THERE’S not much you can do about title insurance.

headline: A Big-Voiced Singer Takes Off In Several Directions at Once
text: Sia sang a new, unreleased song early in her sold-out show at Webster Hall on Wednesday night, projecting clearly over a tidy churn. The song was “Hostage,” written with Nick Valensi of the Strokes, and its message — feeling powerless to break free of a lover’s mistreatment — was a fine match for the expressive bigness of her voice. Its sound, more distractingly, was pure Strokes: strobing guitar chords, peppy bass line, terse drumming.

headline: Faces Still Alive, Centuries Later
text: The most useful knowledge we have about the great 17th-century Dutch painter Frans Hals is what we glean from the vibrant, shimmering surfaces of his art. He was an amazingly gifted technician, capable of defining the human face in passages of seemingly quick, vivacious brush strokes that convey both physical solidity and expressive fluidity. He was also something of an empath, intuitively alert, it would seem, to what was going on behind those faces. He approached his subjects with an open, nonjudgmental equanimity, whether he depicted them singly or in groups, in dignified repose or unbridled revelry.

headline: John T. Livingston
text: Mr. Livingston, 58, is the president of the Tishman Construction Corporation and the chief executive of construction services for the Aecom Technology Corporation, which acquired Tishman in July 2010 for $245 million in cash and stock. Tishman is the construction manager for several ground-zero projects, including 1 World Trade Center and the PATH Terminal Hub.

headline: Dance Listings July 29 — Aug. 4
text: Dance

headline: A Lost Child, but Not Mine
text: ON the third anniversary of my abortion, I found out via MySpace that my ex-boyfriend was having a baby with another woman. It was none of my business, except I somehow convinced myself that his new baby was a replica of ours, and as such I felt a sense of ownership, of responsibility for the child’s well-being.

headline: Confronting a Plague of Violence
text: The stories in “The Interrupters,” a hard wallop of a documentary, may weigh heavily on your heart and head, but they will also probably infuriate you. When a frail-looking child with startled eyes breaks down crying, her tiny hands covering her tiny face as she talks about a neighborhood shooting, it’s hard not to want to gather her up in your arms. It’s also difficult not to feel outrage along with a sense of confused, familiar helplessness because this child lives in that war-torn part of the world called Chicago.

headline: ‘Frans Hals’
text: Images from an exhibition of the artist’s work at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Is That All There Is? Milking Life for More
text: To appreciate “The Future,” Miranda July’s ingeniously constructed wonder cabinet of a movie, you may first have to pass through a stage of mild annoyance or even something more intense. A recent profile in The New York Times Magazine depicted Ms. July — a quiet figure on the screen and a thoughtful, witty presence on the page — as an improbably polarizing filmmaker, as likely to be scorned for her supposed preciosity as celebrated for her ingenuity. And the first part of “The Future” seems, quite deliberately, to test the spectrum of audience response. Are you curious? Enchanted? Frustrated? All of the above?

headline: This Isn’t Kansas: It’s a Quinceañera That Sets the Scene
text: This isn’t your grandparents’ “Wizard of Oz.” Or your parents’ “Wiz.” Or your older sister’s “Wicked.”

headline: Poll Finds Modest Rise in Support for Bike Lanes and Wal-Mart
text: New York voters are saying yes to Wal-Mart and bicycle lanes in modestly increasing numbers, according to a Quinnipiac University poll released on Thursday.

headline: Building With the Elderly in Mind
text: AFTER a several-year hiatus, four assisted-living facilities and a continuing-care retirement community are finally being developed in Westchester County, an underserved market with a large and rapidly growing population of wealthy elderly residents, builders say.

headline: Security Experts Say Police Arrested Wrong Hacker
text: Did they catch the wrong guy?

headline: A Haven for Golf, or Fried Eggs
text: The beige bunker that houses the Poxabogue Golf Center and its fragrant Fairway Restaurant sits unpretentiously on the shoulder of Montauk Highway in billionaire-studded Sagaponack, as if protected by squatters’ rights. The driving range popped up on the horizon in 1957, one step ahead of the zoning czars. A 1961 variance grandfathered the beginner-tolerant nine-hole, par-3 public golf course into the picture.

headline: Allure of Waterfront Homes Dims
text: Asharoken

headline: New Development for a Tired Industrial Town
text: HARRISON

headline: Weekend Miser
text: It’s the thick of summer, and the heat can make you just a bit crazier than usual. But how do you cope when even your therapist abandons the stifling city?

headline: Brooms and Ball, but No Wizards
text: BROOMBALL, a remote cousin of ice hockey, has come a long way since street-car workers in Canada began swatting a small soccer ball around the ice with corn brooms 100 years or so ago. Brooms, for one thing, are just so passé. For another, broomball players need no ice.

headline: A Beijing Bohemian in the East Village
text: The Chinese government did what it set out do with the artist and gadfly Ai Weiwei: silenced him. Or did it? When he was released from detention in June, he was under orders not to discuss the experience, or human rights issues generally, with anyone. Talking about politics nonstop for years via blogs and tweets was what landed him in jail. No one expected to see him back on the Internet anytime soon.

headline: Yelp Hires a C.F.O. on the Road to Going Public
text: Yelp, the review site for local businesses, is joining the rush of big-name Web start-ups that want to go public.

text: DETROIT — Fiat unveiled a new management structure on Thursday, taking a major step toward bringing Chrysler into its fold, a week after acquiring majority control of the once-bankrupt carmaker.

headline: Despite Its Turmoil, Syria Still Looks Like an Oasis to Iraqis
text: BAGHDAD — At a roadside station here, where buses bound for Syria leave dozens of times a week, the space between two troubled nations is measured by notions of prosperity and security.

text: Boulder, Colo.

text: A house inspired by Richard Neutra comes alive with the sounds of summer.

headline: Dakota Discrimination Suit May Proceed, a Judge Rules
text: A discrimination lawsuit against the Dakota apartment building may go forward, a State Supreme Court judge in Manhattan ruled on Wednesday, widening a window into the building’s inner workings and threatening to tarnish its genteel image.

headline: House Tour: Olive, N.Y.
