headline: Removing Barriers to Salmon Migration
text: OLYMPIC NATIONAL PARK, Wash. — Beginning late this summer, one of the most promising and pure acts of environmental restoration the region and the nation have ever seen will get under way here, experts say, in the form of the largest dam removal project in American history.

headline: Obama to Speak on Debt Crisis
text: President Obama will deliver a statement about the debt-ceiling fight at 10:20 a.m. at the White House. His appearance will start what is sure to be an eventful day in the partisan showdown over the budget, with the clock ticking toward midnight on Tuesday, when the government will exhaust its ability to pay all its bills without additional borrowing.

headline: Opportunity on Madison
text: WHEN word came last spring that the Metropolitan Museum of Art would lease the Marcel Breuer building on Madison Avenue after the Whitney Museum leaves it for a new downtown home in 2015, the first thing I felt was joy. When I learned that the Met planned to use the building to display its own collection of modern and contemporary art, my instant thought was: Why?

headline: On the Edge
text: After decades of cleanup and the efforts of committed conservationists like Don Riepe, Jamaica Bay is once again a rich sanctuary for shorebirds in New York City.

headline: Stocks Fall After G.D.P. Data
text: A disappointing report on the nation’s second-quarter economic activity spurred a steep initial decline in stocks in the United States on Friday, adding to the malaise in the markets as investors wait for an outcome of the debt ceiling debate in Washington.

headline: The Debt Crisis — What Should Congress Do?
text: What do you think Congress should do: raise tax revenues, cut programs or just increase the debt ceiling?

headline: Senate Quickly Kills Boehner Debt Bill
text: WASHINGTON — After a 24-hour delay and concessions to conservatives, the House on Friday narrowly approved a Republican fiscal plan that the Senate quickly rejected in a standoff over the federal debt ceiling that was keeping the government on a path to potential default.

headline: Helmet Heads
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#105", 592, 395, true, chameleonData);

headline: House Leaders Meet Again to Round Up Votes
text: House Republicans prepared to head into a crucial closed-door session in the basement of the Capitol at 10 a.m. Friday.

headline: Mine Explosion in Ukraine Kills 17
text: MOSCOW — An early-morning explosion deep in a coal mine in Ukraine on Friday killed 17 miners and left 9 others missing in a nation where poor maintenance and lax safety regulation make mining a perilous profession.

headline: Spain Calls Snap Elections
text: SANTANDER, Spain — Prime Minister José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero said Friday that he would call an early general election for Nov. 20, bowing to pressure from opposition politicians and business leaders after the governing Socialist Party suffered severe losses in regional and municipal elections two months ago.

headline: Mark Rylance Gives Away His Tony Award for ‘Jerusalem’
text: Folks, this may come as a surprise from a man who, in lieu of giving an acceptance speech at an awards show chose to recite a bit of verse from an obscure poet, but Mark Rylance, it seems, has done something eccentric. Mr. Rylance, who last month won a Tony Award for his portrayal of a hard-living quasi-mystical itinerant man in the Jez Butterworth play “Jerusalem,” has given away that trophy to a British man who helped inspire his performance.

headline: Friday Reading: Embracing Energy Conservation
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: UBS Hires Bank of America Executive
text: UBS has recruited Mike Stewart, co-head of global equities at Bank of America, to become co-heard of global securities and head of securities in the Americas.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Executions Should Be Televised
text: Mr. Shemtob is an assistant professor of criminal justice at Central Connecticut State University. Mr. Lat, a former federal prosecutor, is the founder of Above the Law, a legal blog.

headline: Crisis of the House Divided
text: Jonah Goldberg, on the ongoing agony of the House Republican caucus:

headline: Hawk Cam | Bobby Visits Nest as Pip Explores Union Square
text: Things have been quiet indeed up on the red-tailed hawk nest above Washington Square Park. But on Thursday afternoon at about 2:45, Bobby, father of Pip, came back to do a little ritualistic tidying. John Blakeman, hawk expert and nest watcher, said that the visit means that Bobby has every intention of returning to the nest to breed again.

headline: When Shilling on the Web, Think Small
text: Mariah Carey and Barack Obama each had something to sell this week, and they made live videos to do it. Both videos bombed. Ms. Carey’s pitch on HSN, for tracksuits and other sundries from her fashion label, was too weird. Mr. Obama’s pitch on the networks for Congressional compromise wasn’t nearly weird enough.

headline: Range-Extending Option for Electric BMW i3: a Smart Hedge?
text: On Friday in Frankfurt, BMW showed working prototypes of its i3 electric runabout and i8 plug-in hybrid sports coupe. The carbon-fiber-reinforced concepts were relatively faithful to the renderings that accompanied the launch of the German automaker’s “i” subbrand in February. A new wrinkle, however, is the addition of an optional gasoline-burning range extender for the i3, an otherwise purely electric car.

headline: The Learning Network Is on Hiatus Next Week
text: We’re busy working behind the scenes these days, including helping our Newspaper in Education colleagues with their annual series of teacher workshops (PDF), which this year we’ve enjoyed presenting out at The New York Times printing plant in Queens. (Please note: all workshops are now closed.)

headline: TimesCast | Nafissatou Diallo Speaks
text: July 28, 2011 - The hotel maid accusing Dominique Straus-Kahn of sexual assault, speaks out again at a Brooklyn press conference.

headline: Obama Calls for Bipartisan Solution on Debt
text: President Obama urged deadlocked lawmakers on Friday morning to find a way to resolve their differences and compromise as the clock ticks toward the possibility of a default if the nation’s debt ceiling is not raised by Tuesday.

headline: The Caucus | Voters on the Debt Crisis
text: Abby Goodnough and Marc Lacey visited ideologically divergent districts in Massachusetts and Arizona. They found differing political views but an agreement about the dysfunction of Washington.

headline: Davis Polk Lawyer Nominated for Federal Bench
text: ISLESBORO, Maine — President Obama on Thursday afternoon nominated Ronnie Abrams, a lawyer at Davis Polk & Wardwell, to serve as a judge in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Reid Says He Will Move Ahead With His Bill
text: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, said he would move ahead on Friday with a Democratic plan to increase the debt limit, saying he could no longer wait for House Republicans to complete their version.

headline: How Do You Feel About Medicare?
text: What Americans really think about Medicare: They like it. They don’t want to see it significantly changed. But they’re conscious of the federal deficit and willing to consider a number of strategies to reduce the gap, including raising taxes on high earners, spending less on foreign aid and overseas military commitments, and limiting tax deductions for large corporations. They’re even amenable to certain cost-cutting measures in Medicare itself.

headline: Plants, Climate and a Midsummer Festival
text: Laura Fox, a postdoctoral researcher with the University of Pennsylvania, writes from Mongolia, where she is studying the effects of climatic warming on steppe vegetation.

headline: On Hudson Pollution, Back to Routine Worries
text: Water tests along the Hudson River show that bacteria levels are falling near the North River Wastewater Treatment Plant in Harlem, which stopped treating sewage for a few days last week because of a fire.

headline: Linda Ronstadt Writing a Memoir
text: Linda Ronstadt is joining the music memoir club with her own book, “Heart Like a Wheel,” said her publisher, Simon & Schuster. The memoir, titled after her hit 1974 album, will focus on her long career, during which she has sold more than 100 million records. “Few singers have been as wide-ranging or as distinctive in their artistry,” Jonathan Karp, the publisher of Simon & Schuster, said in a statement. “Linda Ronstadt has a singular voice, and that is true on the page as well.” The book is tentatively scheduled for publication in 2013.

headline: Jamaica Bay: Wilderness on the Edge
text: OF all the ways to describe Jamaica Bay — it is the city’s largest open space, it is a perch of choice for more than 300 species of birds, it is that wetland thing you fly above while landing at (or leaving) Kennedy Airport — the most suggestive of its singularity is that it sits within the only national park in the United States you can reach by subway.

headline: Heart and Soul
text: Susana Baca, the acclaimed singer and soul of Afro-Peruano music, became the first black cabinet minister of independent Peru when she was sworn in as minister of culture on Thursday by the country’s new president, Ollanta Humala. Baca, 67, is revered for mixing Andean and African rhythms and has played a key role in the revival of Afro-Peruano music and dance — folkloric traditions long sidelined in Peru.

headline: G.O.P. Fervor Cuts 2 Ways for Boehner
text: WASHINGTON — There is an old Texas saying often applied to politics that you need to “dance with the one that brung you.” But many of the Tea Party-infused freshmen who helped the Republican Party take control of the House last November are here to polka while their leadership is begging them to waltz.

headline: Helen Schulman on her novel, "The Beautiful Life"; how computers reveal the jargon of fiction; best-seller news.
text: This week, Helen Schulman on her new novel, "The Beautiful Life"; the linguist Ben Zimmer explains how computers reveal the jargon of fiction; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: 8,400 Volvo S80 Sedans Recalled for Sudden Loss of Power Assist
text: Volvo is recalling about 8,400 of its S80 sedans from 2007 for possible steering problems.

headline: Google Introduces Hotel Search
text: Google on Thursday joined sites like Kayak, Expedia and Hotels.com by introducing a tool for searching hotels.

headline: In Court, Lost in Translation
text: The most recent controversy in the Dominique Strauss-Kahn case has exposed an area in the criminal justice system where questions regularly arise: translations.

headline: For S.E.C. Interns, Wall Street Is a World Away
text: DealBook recently examined the lives of Wall Street interns, who spend their summers wrangling pitch books and trimming Excel spreadsheets. (And sometimes, blogging surreptitiously.)

headline: London Theater Journal: A Wink and a Smirk, but Rarely a Blush
text: LONDON — Women without knickers kept showing up on the stage the other day, in two different theaters. And, honestly, I wasn’t hanging out in those hole-in-the-wall clubs in Soho, land of gentlemen’s entertainments bathed in sad neon light. No, I was in respectable fringe theaters, watching earnest and worthy productions of plays with big themes – which happened to involve women in search of sexual satisfaction removing their underpants and then waiting for something to happen.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Mysteries of Lisbon’
text: The critic A. O. Scott narrates a scene from Raoul Ruiz’s “Mysteries of Lisbon,” in which the central character is escorted by his mentor to find out who his mother is.

headline: The All-American
text: James Traub challenges Senator John Kerry’s impression that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel “is prepared to make real sacrifices for peace” by claiming that “there’s scant evidence that this is so.” On the contrary, Netanyahu has demonstrated his commitment to peace in both word and deed. In 2009, he articulated his policy of a “Palestinian state side by side with the Jewish state” and in a recent speech to Congress, he stated that, in a peace agreement, “some settlements will end up beyond Israel’s borders” and that “with creativity and goodwill a solution can be found” to the Jerusalem issue. He removed hundreds of checkpoints to strengthen the Palestinian economy in the West Bank and implemented an unprecedented 10-month moratorium on new settlement construction. Throughout, he has repeatedly expressed his readiness to negotiate with the Palestinians, without preconditions, to achieve peace.

headline: Block Quote
text: Gone from this mid-’70s film are the euphoric bams and pows and the psychedelia of the television version; gone are Alfred, Robin, the bat signal and virtually everything that made the kids’ version so much fun. Indeed, Clint Eastwood makes his leather mask (mixed with his rough, leathery visage) into something akin to a fetish show. The film starts with a scene in a pool hall. Three roughnecks harass a group of women when Batman shows up. They have knives, but this Batman (with no real tricks up his sleeve) is a born brawler. When Batman finally beats the tar out of the three guys, he looks at the women with a vacuous stare. The credits then play over Batman listening to a cop-radio mix with Quincy Jones’s score. After the opening three against one, you’ve got the clever standoff fight of the heavyweight-boxer type against Batman; the 40-against-one standoff in the alleyway; the marksmen fight with its constant zoom-ins; and the raid on Joker’s palace. Had Peckinpah directed these last two sequences (and not, as has been credited, Eastwood, with an assist from Hal Needham), it might be one of the greatest films Peckinpah ever directed. Still, when people ask me what’s my favorite superhero film, I usually point to this one. Or Ang Lee’s “Hulk.”

headline: Jon Favreau, From Swingers to Aliens
text: The new film you’ve directed, “Cowboys and Aliens,” has a pretty absurd name. The Times even reported last year that when people saw the trailer, they’d laugh, thinking it was a parody. Did you ever consider renaming it?

headline: Geekdom Revisited
text: In junior high school, I was bullied. A boy named Dominick made fun of my appearance until I could barely look at myself in the mirror. He and his friends snapped my training bra in the hallway. They heard I made out with a boy after a school dance and started calling me a slut. I had stomachaches in the morning and cried myself to sleep at night.

headline: There’s No ‘I’ in ‘Tea Party’
text: I wasn’t even a page into this article before it dawned on me that you revealed the crux of the problem in Washington (where I now live). Note that Kevin McCarthy rides bikes with Republicans, meets all morning with Republicans, dines with Republicans: it’s like existing in an endless loop of self-congratulatory, self-assured (some would say arrogant) self-talk. How are these people ever to know what anyone else is thinking if all they do is meet with each other?

headline: Miranda July Is Totally Not Kidding
text: Miranda July is dark, dark, dark. I hate earnestness, and I am often allergic to sincerity, but if that’s all you see in her work, you’re missing the point. The cutesiness and humor are there to counterbalance the terror and anxiety of everyday life; the former gives you a little relief while you gird yourself for the latter.

headline: Money Cometh to Me Now!
text: Travis Cross, a 43-year-old unemployed hairdresser, was among the 200 or so people, most of them black and sharply dressed, filling the pews of Mount Pleasant Baptist Church in Norfolk, Va., late last month. They had come to see visiting preacher Dr. Leroy Thompson — “the man of God, himself,” Cross called him — hold his “Money Cometh to You” conference, which promises that the Lord can solve even the worst financial problems. It was a message the congregation desperately wanted to hear; some of the bordering neighborhoods have unemployment rates over 15 percent.

headline: Armchair Ethicist
text: Have a strong opinion? Discuss this letter with the Ethicist at nytimes.com/6thfloor on Tuesday, Aug. 2, between 1 and 5 p.m., E.S.T.

headline: The Prescription to Save Ailing Superheroes
text: It’s probably not a good sign for the superhero genre as a whole that the most talked-about comic-book movies of summer 2011 are the ones due out in 2012. But it’s not even August, and the conversation in superhero-nerdspace is all about leaked trailers for “The Dark Knight Rises” and “The Avengers,” both scheduled to be released next year, or about how Andrew Garfield, that kid from “The Social Network,” looks in his Spider-Man suit.

headline: A Mild-Mannered Maniac
text: In the small bookstore of the Cinémathèque Française in Paris, a wall of shelves is devoted to works by and about the great auteurs — monographs, coffee-table tomes, DVDs. The pantheon of world cinema is too large for the available space, so the masters are arrayed in double rows, one behind the other. In order to browse, you must dig and rearrange, and on a recent visit, I felt a bit like a cinephile-archaeologist or a monomaniacal archivist as I burrowed past Ozu and Pasolini and displaced a row of Scorsese, making my determined way to Raoul Ruiz. I unearthed a small cache of movies directed by this Chilean-born filmmaker, who has made his home in Paris since the mid-1970s. I also found a book of interviews from the 1980s and another, “Poétique du Cinéma,” based on lectures he gave, mostly at American universities, over the years. The title of one lecture is “Cinema as Clandestine Voyage,” which might describe a curious viewer’s sometimes baffling but frequently enchanting journey through Ruiz’s films.

headline: Duty Calls
text: I’ve been called for jury duty, and I’m shocked by the lies that other prospective jurors tell to get themselves disqualified. I know that’s not fair; everyone deserves his day in court. But it’s not fair to me that because of their lies I’m more likely to suffer the inconvenience of a long trial. May I tell the lawyers things about myself that are perfectly true but which I’m mentioning only to get out of the jury box and back to my job? DAVID S., NEW YORK

headline: Merck Plans More Job Cuts
text: Merck will cut about 13,000 jobs by the end of 2015, in addition to the 20,000 jobs it has shed since a merger in 2009, the pharmaceutical company announced Friday in its quarterly earnings report.

headline: The President Calls In His Hashtag Team
text: The White House is trying to drive home its central political message every way it can.

headline: A New Unlimited JetBlue Pass
text: JetBlue’s All You Can Jet pass attracted a loyal following, and when the program wasn’t offered this year, fans expressed their disappointment on blogs and on Twitter. (Where We Jet aggregated tweets on the topic.)

headline: Fantasy Football: Players to Ignore on Draft Day
text: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football draft. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: Weekend Fare
text: In a city full of ethnic pride, Pakistanis, Colombians and Swiss get their turn to strut this weekend.

headline: Impressed by Weeds
text: To Britain’s train spotters, bird-watching “twitchers” and upper-class twits, let us now add the weed geek. Not so long ago, you’d find them of a weekend on coach tours of East London refuse tips (a k a landfills). You could listen for their whistles when they chanced upon a choice specimen, and watch as they gathered to photograph the plant and debate its identity. If you looked carefully among the participants, you’d espy Britain’s foremost nature writer, Richard Mabey, the author, most recently, of “Weeds: In Defense of Nature’s Most Unloved Plants.”

headline: House Phone Lines Are Jammed Again
text: Telephone circuits into the House of Representatives were once again near capacity on Friday after President Obama called on Americans to keep up their calls to Congress.

headline: Usual Growth Leaders Absent From Recovery
text: WHY has the job picture been so bleak in the current recovery? A large part of the problem can be traced to unusual weakness in two categories: construction jobs and government jobs.

headline: Nicholas Ray Archives Find a Home in Texas
text: Nicholas Ray, the director of the 1955 film classic “Rebel Without a Cause,” was pretty much banished from Hollywood in the early 1960s as a result of his drug and alcohol addictions, and volatile temper. But his early work influenced a generation of filmmakers. Now his voluminous archives have been bought from his widow, Susan Ray, by the Harry Ransom Center, a humanities research library and museum at the University of Texas at Austin.

headline: Gowanus: Big Development Can Wait
text: Superfund designation halted large-scale construction around the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. But as small businesses and artists move in, there has been a different kind of development.

headline: Why We Deregulated the Banks
text: Seven years ago, James Mann published “Rise of the Vulcans,” a history of the neoconservative foreign-policy advisers who rose to prominence with the presidency of George W. Bush. Mann traced the group’s origins to the 1970s, when figures like Dick Cheney and Donald Rumsfeld got their start in government, and told how events from East Asia to Kuwait solidified their faith in American assertiveness abroad. Of course, Mann was writing against the backdrop of the Iraq invasion. The belief system he chronicled had culminated in overreach.

headline: Plug-and-Play Batteries: Trying Out a Quick-Swap Station for E.V.’s
text: Gladsaxe, Denmark

headline: In Gowanus, Big Development Can Wait
text: WHEN a baby whale lost its way and wandered into the mouth of the Gowanus Canal in 2007, it was christened Sludgie the Whale.

headline: New York Is Ready for Its Close-Up
text: New York has played many roles on television recently.

headline: The Truth About Federal Spending
text: Whenever someone like me or Bruce Bartlett points out how little Obama resembles the right’s portrait of a raging leftist, someone is sure to come back with the assertion that Obama has presided over a vast expansion of federal spending. Even people who really should know better, like John Taylor, do it.

headline: Top Generals Quit in Group, Stunning Turks
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s top military commanders resigned en masse on Friday, a move without precedent in Turkish history that many analysts saw as a failed effort by a beleaguered institution to exert what is left of its dwindling political power.

headline: How Sweet It Is: $27 Million in Fees for Dunkin’s Underwriters
text: Earlier this week, Dunkin’ Brands made its stock market debut with a blockbuster public offering, with shares soaring 46.6 percent on the first day of trading.

headline: A Dutch Factory Town, Now a Design Center
text: SOMETIMES the most sublime and unusual enterprises can grow out of the grimmest of circumstances. In the late 1970s and ’80s, Philips, the multinational company best known for electronics, which had been based in the small city of Eindhoven in southern Holland since its founding in the 1890s, started to farm out its production to Asia. Not only were hundreds of skilled professionals out of work, but the city was also left with several abandoned and polluted factory complexes just a few minutes from the city center.

headline: A Fresh Face for U.S. Soccer
text: After courting him twice without success, the United States Soccer Federation on Friday hired Jürgen Klinsmann to coach and revive a seemingly stale men’s national team.

headline: A Neighborhood for Man and Dog
text: NEARLY three years ago, when Richard Rethemeyer moved to New York from San Francisco, he paid $1.16 million for 1,400 lovely square feet in the ClockTower, at 1 Main Street in Dumbo, Brooklyn. The plan was for his girlfriend to join him there.

headline: Paddock Notes from Budapest, Good, Bad and Indifferent
text: BUDAPEST – Somehow the rain stayed away from the Hungaroring on Friday, but there were some wet tears here and there with some of the news items floating around the paddock.

headline: Paddock Notes from Budapest, Good, Bad and Indifferent
text: BUDAPEST – Somehow the rain stayed away from the Hungaroring on Friday, but there were some wet tears here and there with some of the news items floating around the paddock.

headline: The Caucus | Debt Fight Down to the Wire
text: July 29, 2011 - Jennifer Steinhauer reports on the back and forth in Washington. Also, voices from voters in Massachusetts and Arizona.

headline: Tuning in to Nostalgia (and Even Videos) on MTV
text: First, let’s put to rest a common misunderstanding: yes, MTV still plays music videos. Honest. Watch in the early morning for an hour or two under the “AMTV” tag — I’ve seen them only when awake for a doctor’s appointment or, more likely, up late for an overnight deadline, but they’re there, you naysayers.

headline: Summer Tomatoes: Stuffed, Sweet and Souped Up
text: Few foods are as versatile as the tomato, as Martha Rose Shulman demonstrates in this week’s Recipes for Health. She offers tomatoes that are Sicilian and stuffed, slow roasted, sweet and sour, souped up or succulent in salad.

headline: Latest Out of Tailpipes: Electricity With Exhaust
text: EVEN the most efficient of modern cars has a wasteful streak: only about a quarter of the energy contained in the fuel the engine burns is converted to motion. Much of the lost energy flows out of the tailpipe in the form of hot exhaust gases, researchers at General Motors say.

headline: Europe’s Incentive Plans for Spurring E.V. Sales
text: EUROPEAN governments are reaching deep into their pockets and plumbing the depths of their imaginations to get electric vehicles out of showrooms and onto the highway. Though the goals of the individual countries are mostly similar — carbon-free fleets in pollution-free cities — many different approaches to making it happen are in place.

headline: Original Model T's
text: No. 2 in a series of commissioned artworks.

headline: Original Model T's
text: No. 2 in a series of commissioned artworks.

headline: The Fine Art of Dwarf Fortress
text: Last Sunday the magazine published a story about two brothers and their creation of the computer game Dwarf Fortress. The story presented a visual challenge — a photograph of  Tarn and Zach Adams working on computers seemed like an unsatisfactory option. Instead, we had the idea of creating portraits of Tarn and Zach Adams from the ASCII characters and 16 colors (seen below) that are the building blocks of their game. So we contacted Tarn to see if he would help us with this. What ensued sort of blew our minds.

headline: Reviving a Habitat
text: The largest dam removal project in American history will take away barriers that have contained the Elwha River in Washington State for nearly a century.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE LONGEST WAR: The Enduring Conflict Between America and Al-Qaeda,  by Peter L. Bergen (Free Press, $16.) Bergen, a national security analyst for CNN and the author of two previous books about Osama bin Laden, covers the global sweep of the last 10 years — the Sept. 11 attacks, the invasions of Afghanistan and Iraq, America’s relationship with Pakistan and the death of Bin Laden — and provides an intimate look at Al Qaeda’s history and motives.

headline: Amazon.com Moves Closer to Acquiring a Major British Rival
text: Amazon.com, which has an estimated 70 percent of the online book market in Britain, got closer this week to controlling the rest of it when the Irish Competition Authority approved its pending purchase of a major rival, the Book Depository. But the blessing of the main regulatory body, the Office of Fair Trading, is no sure thing in a country that appears to be more concerned about media monopoly in the wake of the News Corporation hacking scandal.

headline: In Sapphire’s New Novel, Life Without Precious
text: Fifteen years after the heralded publication of her first novel, “Push” — the basis for the 2009 film “Precious” — Sapphire has written a new novel, “The Kid,” which traces the life of Precious’ second child, Abdul. At its best, “The Kid” captures the grueling heartbreak of trying to love anything when the world doesn’t love you enough, of trying to summon desire or affection in the absence of any healthy context for either one.

headline: Inside the List
text: NAMING NAMES: The cover of Laura Ingraham’s latest best seller, “Of Thee I Zing: America’s Cultural Decline From Muffin Tops to Body Shots,” shows the conservative firebrand dressed up like George Washington crossing the Delaware.

headline: Master of the Gilded Age Congress
text: Every serious student of Congress is familiar with Thomas B. Reed, a dominant speaker of the House near the end of the 19th century who was known as a “czar” for his use of the House rules to achieve the goals of his Republican majority. He was the precursor of the much more authoritarian “Uncle Joe” Cannon, whose ham-handed exercise of power led to the storied 1910 revolt that created the seniority system in Congress. It was Reed who transformed the speakership for the 20th century, but to most Americans, he is at best a dim figure from history, perhaps a candidate for a particularly tough question on “Jeopardy!”

headline: Being German in 1945
text: The story of the denazification of Germany after 1945 comes in two versions. The one we know best allows us to congratulate ourselves on a job well done. We turned the most powerful and frightening dictatorship in Europe into a stable, peaceable and functioning democracy for the first time in its history. This is the story we grew up with during the cold war, one that justified the partition and occupation of the country over many decades. And the invasion of Iraq in 2003 made it seem relevant in an entirely new way. It stood as a salutary contrast with the sheer superficiality and short-sightedness of the Bush administration’s approach to military occupation.

headline: A Novel of Dark Sexual Obsession
text: The allure of destructive relationships is complicated. We don’t like them when they happen to us (or maybe sometimes we do), but we love reading or talking about them. It’s the drama, the guaranteed narrative arc. We know they almost always end badly, but the details are so irresistible: She did what? Again? What was she thinking? Why would anyone go back after the deadbeat took her car, ate all her bacon and gave his 12-year-old the keys to her apartment without telling her he had a 12-year-old? That’s crazy. Tell me more!

headline: Caucus Video: Debt Fight Down to the Wire
text: Jennifer Steinhauer reports on the back and forth in Washington on the debt ceiling. Also, voices of voters in Massachusetts and Arizona.

headline: A Scrappy Slum Urchin Goes to Sea
text: In his “Lectures on Literature,” Vladimir Nabokov suggests that for “The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde,” Robert Louis Stevenson borrowed his “fog . . . from a Dickensian studio to envelop a conventional London.” The British writer Carol Birch similarly borrows elements of Dickens’s London for “Jamrach’s Menagerie,” her 11th novel and her first to be published in the United States.

headline: The Age of Anti-Serious Seriousness
text: Like most critics, Lee Siegel is sometimes right. Unlike most critics, he is always abrasive, even when the reader happens to agree with him. A writer’s inexhaustible readiness to vex his audience requires some fortitude, and Siegel is nothing if not energetic. In essays on many subjects involving art, literature, the Internet, politics, film and television, he presents himself as a gadfly whose assiduous pursuit of the truth must inevitably cost him some friends. “I am not what you would call a nice critic,” Siegel wrote in The Guardian of London in 2008. Fair enough. So exactly what kind of critic is he?

headline: The Pitfalls and Pleasures of the Current Realist Novel
text: Lately the realist novel’s been getting realistic. Originally developed in response to a highfalutin form gone stale, realism has a long and glorious tradition of extraordinary yarns about ordinary people. But the name “realism” was never quite right. Authors as disparate as Mark Twain, Émile Zola and Edith Wharton are called “realists,” which would be fitting if you spent your adolescence drifting down the Mississippi, worked out your love problems by drowning your rival and attempted suicide by sled.

headline: Know Thyself: Easier Said Than Done
text: A few days before a review of my latest book appeared in these pages, I wrote to my editor, saying I had seen an advance copy and how much I liked the color illustration of the yellow moon. He replied that I must be mistaken, since the Book Review doesn’t use color. The next weekend he wrote to say he couldn’t think what had come over him — he reads the Book Review every week, and had somehow not noticed the color. Odd. And yet these lapses can happen to the best of us. Ask yourself what the Roman number four on the face of the church clock looks like. Most people will answer it looks like IV, but almost certainly the truth is it looks like IIII.

headline: The Jargon of the Novel, Computed
text: We like to think that modern fiction, particularly American fiction, is free from the artificial stylistic pretensions of the past. Richard Bridgman expressed a common view in his 1966 book “The Colloquial Style in America.” “Whereas in the 19th century a very real distinction could be made between the vernacular and standard diction as they were used in prose,” Bridgman wrote, “in the 20th century the vernacular had virtually become standard.” Thanks to such pioneers as Mark Twain, Stephen Crane, Gertrude Stein and Ernest Hemingway, the story goes, ornate classicism was replaced by a straight-talking vox populi.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: AN ANATOMY OF ADDICTION: Sigmund Freud, William Halsted, and the Miracle Drug Cocaine,  by Howard Markel (Pantheon, $28.95.) An absorbing and well-documented account of the ways cocaine affected the careers of two clinical pathbreakers.

headline: Sex, Lies and Data Mining
text: The concentrated essence of this curious book is contained in its 11th chapter, which attempts to explain what the “Mona Lisa” has in common with Chicken McNuggets, vampire novels and the concluding scene of most pornographic videos. Each of these works of human creativity, Ogi Ogas and Sai Gaddam write in “A Billion Wicked Thoughts,” exploits perceptual trickery to arouse and gratify our desires. The enigma of the Gioconda smile; the technologically engineered “crave­ability” of fast food; the alluring, “alpha among alphas” quality of the paranormal hero; that climactic moment beamed to watchers on a hundred million laptop screens: all rely on the artful manipulation of our brains.

headline: The Role of Government Spending
text: As Congress continues to wrangle over a debt reduction bill that will inevitably cut government spending, Friday’s estimates of second-quarter gross domestic product provided a sobering look at how a decline in public spending and investment can restrain growth.

headline: Vietnamese Grilled Duck Salad With Cucumber, Radishes and Peanuts
text: Time: 40 minutes plus at least 90 minutes’ marinating

headline: Duck Fat for Later, a Salad for Now
text: WHEN I cook duck, it’s just as often for the rendered fat as it is for the meat. As much as I love the gamy, sweet flesh, it’s the fat that I really crave. I keep a jar of the heady stuff in the fridge, pulling it out when I want to sauté fish or potatoes or kale, or pop a vat of popcorn. I use it to make pie crusts and biscuits, and to fry chicken. When my supplies run low, I simply cook up some more duck to replenish it.

headline: Democrats Threaten Saturday Night Debt Fever
text: Get ready for Mr. Smith meets the debt ceiling.

headline: Obama and Bush to Visit New York for 9/11 Anniversary
text: The 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks will be a grand but subdued affair in New York City that will involve two presidents, poetry readings and visits by victims’ family members to the new memorial, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Friday.

headline: Hollywood East
text: Major television shows and feature films find benefits to shooting in Queens.

headline: Sandwiches Take a Turn With Tomatoes
text: OLD Mr. Brown, a man I knew in Oakland, Calif., never ate anything but sandwiches. Ask him to a meal, pass the breadbasket. He put everything, from soup to nuts, between two slices. Evidently it was a lifelong obsession.

headline: Killers of Libyan Rebel General Were Among His Own Forces
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — The leadership of the Libyan rebels acknowledged late Friday that a group of their own soldiers had killed their top military commander, contradicting statements made a day earlier as the rebels scrambled to avoid tribal revenge attacks that could divide their ranks.

headline: Genworth Plans for Possible Split
text: Shares of Genworth Financial rose on Friday after its chief executive said that the insurance company was getting prepared to split off its mortgage insurance business.

headline: Little More Than Great Tomatoes and Bread
text: Good tomatoes are in, finally. Real, farm-grown meaty tomatoes, like classic Beefsteak and Brandywine and Lemon Boy, and sweet cherry tomatoes of different colors. So a fine tomato salad comes to mind, but what about a sandwich? Not a BLT; not tomato, avocado and sprouts. Rather, a Mediterranean sandwich of tomatoes with capers, anchovy and basil, piled into a freshly baked roll. A little bit soggy, completely heavenly. And no need to turn on the oven. Read about it, along with a few other sandwich reveries, in this week’s City Kitchen.

headline: The Prius V: A Hybrid That Hauls More Stuff
text: TESTED 2012 Prius V (though Toyota, which seems to have a shortage of capital letters, prefers “v”).

headline: Living in Midland Beach, S.I.
text: Small one-story bungalows built decades ago, and two-story brick semidetached homes or town houses built more recently, sit side by side in this Staten Island neighborhood.

headline: Germany Goes Electric
text: With the battery-powered i3 compact and i8 plug-in hybrid sport coupe, BMW is making an ambitious venture into electric-car development.

headline: Economic Growth: Worse Than We Thought
text: The good news six months ago was that the United States economy, as measured by gross domestic product, had completely recovered all the losses it suffered in the recession.

headline: Wall St., Prepared for the Worst, in Wait-and-See Mode
text: Wall Street executives and traders will spend the weekend holding their breath as the debt impasse continues to suck all the oxygen from the room.

headline: Low Prices, Slow Traffic, Copious Sand
text: WHEN Lina Shuster takes portraits of clients for her photography business, she often uses the beach as a backdrop. Luckily for her, that means going just a few blocks from home.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Haunted Real Estate (and Hero)
text: The hardcover list has three new books this week. At No. 1 is Volume 4 of Locke and Key, by Joe Hill and Gabriel Rodriguez, about Keyhouse, a family estate in New England whose doors transform anyone who walks through them. The Lockes are the family in question and they must navigate various crises while learning about the mansion and the various keys. The writer is the son of Stephen King, who knows a bit about New England suspense. The series began in 2008 and has completed four six-issue storylines so far. The current series, Clockworks, began this month.

headline: In Battle for Patents, Google Buys a Batch From I.B.M.
text: In the heated battle for technology patents, Google is using its checkbook to bulk up.

headline: Islamists Flood Square in Cairo in Show of Strength
text: CAIRO — Tens of thousands of Egyptian Islamists poured into Tahrir Square on Friday calling for a state bound by strict religious law and delivering a persuasive show of force in a turbulent country showing deep divisions and growing signs of polarization.

headline: Bomb Hits Syrian Pipeline as Protests Continue
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government said Friday that an oil pipeline had been hit by a bomb in what the authorities called a terrorist attack, as the country’s uprising continued with the Friday protests that have become a ritual there. Security forces killed nine people at the demonstrations, protesters and activists said.

headline: ‘Project Runway’ Returns
text: Let the squabbling begin.

headline: Owning a Ranch Offers Returns Beyond the Financial
text: AMONG the fantasies that keep many of us going on dreary days, owning a vast ranch out West would surely rank up there, along with living on a beach or gazing out over your vineyard at night.

headline: Cars and Fuel: What Constructive Compromise Looks Like
text: Environmentalists, politicians, corporate and union lobbyists and the auto industry have been embroiled for months in hashing out the details for cutting the fuel use and emissions of American cars and light trucks through 2025, and the result was on display in Washington today.

headline: Big Deal | An S. Klein Sale Item
text: In the summer of 1909, a year after the giant house on Westerleigh Road in Purchase, N.Y., was built, it was described by The New York Times as “one of the finest country mansions in Westchester County.”

headline: Moving a Special Needs Child to China
text: Having a family means constructing an equation. Every choice, each conclusion, means shuffling all the factors, deciding how much weight to give to each.

headline: Giants Restructure Jacobs’s Contract
text: The Giants and running back Brandon Jacobs have agreed to a restructured contract that will provide the team with much-needed relief under the salary cap.

headline: U.S. Soccer Gets Its Man: Klinsmann Hired
text: After a long courtship, Jürgen Klinsmann was named coach of the United States national team on Friday. He will be introduced at a news conference on Monday, and will coach his first game against Mexico on Aug. 10 in Philadelphia. Read Jeré Longman’s article here, and come back to comment.

headline: Revved-Up Cinema
text: A look at the custom work that went into the making of the film “Bellflower.”

headline: 2007 Letter Clearing a Tabloid Comes Under Scrutiny
text: LONDON — When a Parliamentary committee first confronted The News of the World with charges of phone hacking in 2007, the paper’s owners produced a reassuring, one-paragraph letter from a prominent London law firm named Harbottle & Lewis.

headline: Options for Self-Publishing Proliferate, Easing the Bar to Entry
text: I’M a snob. Oh, I don’t particularly care what kind of car you drive or if you wear the latest designer fashions, but until recently I turned up my nose at authors who published their own books.

headline: Build the Apocalypse Inside Your Garage
text: THE indie drama “Bellflower,” opening Friday, charts a familiar tale, the blossoming and deterioration of a romance. But the way the story is told is far from conventional. This might be the first relationship tale that begins with cricket eating and involves a bleach-squirting muscle car and a homemade flamethrower.

headline: The Jam | Erick Swenson
text: The Texas installation artist Erick Swenson is known for turning heads with his portrayals of hybrid creatures that look hauntingly real. His 2004 Whitney Biennial contribution showcased an animal with a fawnlike body, ears of a rabbit and a nose of a dog, frozen in a dramatic stance over what appears to be a woven rug (but is actually hand-painted fiberglass). He once created a half-eaten carcass of a killer whale and laid it across a monstrous crumpled-up ice floe — a piece so well done, critics said, it could be a natural history museum display. So how does Swenson fit in here with our downtown playlist, brought to you by Sean Hanratty? Hanratty chose Swenson for The Jam’s fifth installment not only because of their shared Texan roots but also because, he says, “I’ve always been so intrigued with the sort of fantastical nature of his work and materials. I knew his playlist would contain a lot of classic songs with a very strong backbone.”

headline: 2 More Deaths Attributed to Heat
text: Two additional deaths were attributed to the heat on July 23, the city medical examiner’s office said on Friday, bringing the heat-related death toll for the day, when the temperature reached 100 degrees, to four.

headline: Recipes for Summer Tomatoes
text: A variety of ways to use tomatoes at the height of the season.

headline: Restaurant Report: Delancey, in Seattle
text: On a quiet street in the Ballard neighborhood of Seattle sits a cozy little restaurant on the verge of being thrust into a rather public life.

headline: Letters: Planning the Perfect Vacation
text: To the Editor: The headline says it all: “Planning the Perfect Vacation” (Practical Traveler, July 24.) Two words that should never come between you and a little R&R are “planning” and “perfect.” If they are still part of your modus operandi, you are not there yet.

headline: North Fork Dining Catches Up
text: THE North Fork of Long Island has developed a reputation for its wineries. Just as the vineyards of Napa and Sonoma led to the emergence of a vibrant dining scene, a growing number of chefs with impressive pedigrees — including some with Long Island roots — are opening their own restaurants on the North Fork to feed the winery-hopping crowds.

headline: Hotel Review: La Maison Blanche on Shelter Island, N.Y.
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: Dalston in East London Welcomes New Arrivals
text: A traditionally Jewish area in East London morphs into a multiethnic working-class enclave.

headline: Montana’s Fading Glaciers
text: Glacier National Park’s skein of well-maintained trails traverses every section of its million-plus acres and can accommodate any level of ability.

headline: Casa Lever Spreads Out to Its Park Avenue Terrace
text: Casa Lever is opening an outdoor bar, lounge and restaurant in the public courtyard that wraps the lobby of Lever House, its home. This elaborate seasonal addition, which will open on Wednesday, if not earlier, will double the restaurant’s capacity.

headline: Automakers React to 54.5 M.P.G.
text: After months of hand-wringing by industry lobbies and environmental groups, President Obama announced the new round of Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards, known as CAFE, on Friday in Washington. The standards call for a 5 percent annual increase in fuel economy for passenger cars from 2017 to 2025, culminating in a mandated 54.5 miles per gallon.

headline: Tension Rises as Islamists Dominate Tahrir Square
text: As my colleague Anthony Shadid reports, tens of thousands of Egyptians poured into Tahrir Square on Friday for a day that had been billed as one of unified protest against the interim military government. But the turnout was lopsided, dominated by members of religious movements, ranging from the most conservative, the Salafists, to the relatively moderate Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Indulging a Fantasy
text: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan writes about what for some is the ultimate fantasy: owning a ranch out West. He says that owning a ranch, and selling the products raised on it, has lately emerged as an alternative investment class. But he quickly adds that the investment is only for the wealthy who are not looking for a quick return.

headline: ‘Red Tails,’ Lucas’s Tuskegee Airmen Movie, Lands a Release Date
text: It was a long time ago – 1994, to be precise – when George Lucas produced his last film that was not connected to his “Indiana Jones” or “Star Wars” fantasy franchises. Now his long-in-the-works film about the fighting men of a very different war finally has a release date: on Friday, Lucasfilm said that “Red Tails,” a film about the Tuskegee Airmen, the all-black pilot group that fought in World War II, would be released on Jan. 20. The film is directed by Anthony Hemingway, who has directed for television series including “Treme,” “True Blood” and “CSI: NY,” and its ensemble cast features Cuba Gooding Jr., Terrence Howard and Bryan Cranston, as well as Tristan Wilds (of “The Wire” and “90210”), Cliff Smith (better known as the rapper Method Man), Ne-Yo and Elijah Kelley.

headline: European Soccer Clubs Challenging FIFA
text: PARIS — Long disgruntled European soccer clubs are mounting a muscular new challenge to FIFA, the international soccer federation, by pressing a dispute over finances and decision-making into the political arena, where the powerful body will face scrutiny of its management.

headline: A Vine’s Acoustics Send a Bat Signal
text: Flowers attract bees and birds with their colors and scents. Now, a new study reports that a rain forest vine in Cuba attracts nectar-feeding bats with sound.

headline: ‘Wall Street Wives’ Finds a Cast
text: “Wall Street Wives” is one step closer to the small screen.

headline: Madoff Trustee’s Job Just Became Much Tougher
text: Shannon Stapleton/ReutersIrving H. Picard, the court-appointed trustee in the Madoff fraud case.

headline: Nibblers Affect Climate Tales That Tree Rings Tell
text: For more than 100 years, tree rings have served as a reliable way to estimate past climate conditions because in warmer years, which usually mean better growing conditions, tree rings tend to be wider. But herbivores that nibble away at trees also have an effect on tree ring size — a phenomenon that was known but never measured. Now, researchers from Norway and Scotland report the significant effect of grazing sheep on tree ring size over a nine-year period.

headline: Heidi Klum and Tim Gunn Make It Work on ‘Runway’
text: The fashion guru Tim Gunn and the model Heidi Klum made a not quite triumphant but still satisfactory return to New York City as “Project Runway” had its Season 9 premiere on Lifetime on Thursday night.  The fashion designer competition averaged 2.7 million total viewers according to Nielsen, making small gains over the premiere from last season.  It was certainly an eventful episode, as four of the twenty contestants were eliminated by the 20-minute mark.

headline: Exposing Literary Style, One Word at a Time
text: In this week’s Mechanic Muse column for the Book Review, I look at how vast new databases and techniques can help scholars of the digital humanities zero in on the nitty-gritty of literary style, right down to the level of individual words. An exciting development over the past few years is that many of the tools that scholars use to plumb the depths of literary usage are now publicly available online. These resources aren’t locked up in an ivory tower, accessible only to an elite band of researchers. Call it the democratization of digital scholarship.

headline: On the Street | Sizzling
text: The fashion star of the recent heat wave was the shirt, in its many styles.

headline: Lawyers, Coins, and Money
text: So if something does pass the House, it will demand a constitutional balanced-budget amendment as the price of a second vote next year. I think we can safely say that the political process has failed. Now what?

headline: This Sunday: Where Would You Like to Go?
text: A pleasure of making this magazine (and, I hope, reading it) is the wide range of places we get to cover. It’s one factor that we take into account as we put together an issue — how many different corners of the world can we pack into our pages? Here’s where our writers take us this week:

headline: A City’s Hard Edges, Softened by Joy
text: Is there a creature as imaginative or as indefatigable as the city child in search of a place to play? New York would seem to have been designed for everything but youthful frolic. And, to be sure, it can hold great perils. Yet from generation to generation — ever since the kids sang “Ring Around the Rosie” and “London Bridge Is Falling Down” — the sidewalks of New York have yielded to youngsters’ inexhaustible need to frisk, exult, screech, plot and plunge.

headline: Twilight of the Glaciers
text: AN hour or so up ahead, at the higher elevations along the trail that leads over Siyeh Pass, huckleberries were ripening. Even a dawdling day hiker like me knows that huckleberries can quickly mean grizzlies in Glacier National Park. I indulged a nervous tic and patted around for the loud red aerosol can on my belt, whose label reads Counter Assault. It’s effective as a bear repellent, but even more reliable at making an urbanite feel faintly ridiculous.

headline: In Europe, Five Libraries That Offer Respite From the Crowds
text: EUROPEAN cities are feet-on-the-pavement destinations, where many of us find ourselves trudging along familiar routes with hordes of tourists just like us. To take a break, we are likely to stop at the cafes and museum gardens already overcrowded with fellow travelers.

headline: To Japan or Not? Travelers Weigh Risks With Bargains
text: THE earthquake and tsunami that hit northeastern Japan on March 11, and the nuclear crisis that followed, have had an impact on nearly every corner of the economy, perhaps none more directly than the tourist industry. The number of foreign visitors has plunged 50 percent since the triple disasters, according to the Japan National Tourism Organization.

headline: TimesCast | July 29, 2011
text: The House prepares to vote on Speaker John A. Boehner's modified plan to raise debt ceiling, and new data show that the United States' economic growth has slowed considerably since last year.

headline: Big Deal | Sold for $30.55 million
text: A penthouse at the Time Warner Center that closed for $30.55 million was the highest sale of the week, according to city property records.

headline: Ruling Upholds Gene Patent in Cancer Test
text: In a closely watched case, a federal appeals court ruled on Friday that genes can be patented, overturning a lower court decision that had shocked the biotechnology industry.

headline: Pasta With Anchovies and Arugula
text: Mark Bittman more than triples the greens in a punchy pasta recipe from the Minimalist archives.

headline: Tip of the Week: Shortcuts into Office’s Ribbon
text: Hate having to grab the mouse to navigate the Ribbon in Microsoft Office? The KeyTips feature, built into all the programs in the Office 2010 and Office 2007 suites, lets you jump into Ribbon menus with just a few keystrokes so you can leave the mouse on its pad.

headline: Audrey Saunders and Robert Hess
text: THE couple’s first face-to-face meeting in 2002 took place exactly where it should have — at a bar.

headline: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
text: Did Niagara Falls host the first same-sex wedding in New York State? Hard to say.

headline: Charting Wu Lyf at the Knitting Factory
text: Wu Lyf is an indie rock band from Manchester, England, known for its churchy anthems and its secretive, anonymous air. (The band’s name supposedly stands for World Unite/Lucifer Youth Foundation and is pronounced woo life.) The band recently released its debut album, “Go Tell Fire to the Mountain” (L Y F Recordings) and performed at the Knitting Factory in Brooklyn. The artist Andrew Kuo breaks the show down.

headline: Chic in Review | America’s Biggest Top Model
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Finding Poetry in a Couple’s Pain
text: ROME

headline: Polar Bear Science and the Spin Cycle
text: [Oct. 2, 2012, 1:23 p.m. | Updated | Charles Monnett, the federal biologist at the heart of the investigation described below, has been cleared of scientific misconduct over his polar bear surveys (report link), but his case remains a source of disputes at several levels — as described in detail by Jill Burke in Alaska Dispatch. There’s more from Nature’s news blog. Media Matters (repost at Climate Progress) is pressing Fox News, which promised to follow the investigation after hyping it, to report the results.]

headline: Striking Out the Side, and Then Some
text: Ron Montgomery leaned close to his computer in Williamsburg, Va., on July 1 as a radio play-by-play man 600 miles away described the most unforgettable inning of his son’s life.

headline: The New York Film Festival Brings ‘Carnage’ to Opening Night
text: The New York Film Festival has announced its opening-night selection, but its director is not likely to walk the red carpet.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Norway and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Norway, Libya, Egypt and Ukraine.

headline: N.F.L. Moves: Young Joins Eagles, Jets Vie for Asomugha
text: 4:08 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Minimalist: Pasta With Anchovies and Arugula
text: The original version of this recipe, which I wrote in 2000 to accompany a column about the many wonders of anchovies, is one of the rare Minimalist recipes I wasn’t entirely happy with when I recently re-examined it. The basic idea is good: chewy pasta with salty, complex anchovies. And hot, muddy arugula is a fantastic combination. Add a pinch of red pepper flakes and you’re really talking.

headline: What Would It Take to End Stalemate
text: Politicians are loath to make painful decisions unless they are forced to. This week, as stocks kept sinking, the question was whether the markets would finally force their hand.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Norway and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Norway, Libya, Egypt and Afghanistan.

headline: O'Keefe's Candid Camera
text: James O’Keefe’s viral videos have helped expose government waste and abuse — or maybe just some well-meaning mistakes — and even taken down a high-ranking official. They have also landed the undercover conservative in front of a judge.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Helen Schulman’s ‘This Beautiful Life’
text: On the cover of Sunday’s Book Review, Maria Russo reviews Helen Schulman’s latest novel, “This Beautiful Life,” which “tells the story of the Bergamots, a family of four whose expensive new Manhattan life comes crashing down when 15-year-old Jake forwards to a friend a sexually explicit video made for him, unsolicited, by a 13-year-old girl named Daisy Cavanaugh.”

headline: Nutrition: Stealthy Vegetables: Getting Children to Eat More
text: Good news for parents: You can get your children to eat zucchini, broccoli, tomatoes, cauliflower and squash — and like them.

headline: Risks: Women’s Cancer Risk Increases With Height, Study Finds
text: The taller a woman is, the greater her risk for cancer, a large study has found.

headline: Radiation’s Role in (Safely) Feeding the Planet
text: I was glad to see Mark Bittman offer a solid appraisal of the merits of irradiation as a means of cutting the chances of outbreaks of food-borne illness, and to see the followup Big Think post by David Ropeik providing more depth on what he calls the “perception gap” between people’s fears of this technology and its risks.

headline: Japan Proposes Aggressive Recovery Plan
text: TOKYO — Japan on Friday proposed an aggressive plan to spend 13 trillion yen ($167 billion) over five years in hopes of bringing about a swift recovery after its recent natural and nuclear disasters.

headline: Old Lesson for New, Tough-Talking Governors: ‘It’s the Economy …’
text: To read their press clippings, Govs. Andrew M. Cuomo and Chris Christie appear headstrong brothers on a roll, dominating their political cultures and even blowing a tough-guy kiss or two at each other.

headline: The Week That Was, in Verse
text: It’s not all about the debt ceiling deadline, you know? Here, we run down the top DealBook stories from the week, in poetic form:

headline: At the Met, McQueen’s Final Showstopper
text: THERE was a reason Alexander McQueen, who committed suicide last year at the age of 40, was considered one of the greatest fashion designers of his generation, admired by his peers for his astounding technical ability and idolized by students for his near-fearless risk taking. “People don’t want to see clothes,” he once said. “They want to see something that fuels the imagination.”

headline: Rejecting the 14th Amendment, Again
text: While President Obama’s critics on the right regularly call him a tyrant, in the debt-limit showdown he is flatly rejecting presidential powers that others claim for him.

headline: Readers’ Comments: A Refresher Course
text: The team here at FiveThirtyEight is going to be making an effort to post reader comments faster, hopefully making for a livelier discussion with more back-and-forth. So it seemed a good time to go over our policy regarding comments.

headline: A Pianist’s Pensive and Fanciful Sides
text: The Russian pianist Daniil Trifonov has had quite a year so far. In May, two months after turning 20, he took first prize in the Arthur Rubinstein International Piano Master Competition in Tel Aviv. In June he won the gold medal in the International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow.

headline: Ranking the Presidents by G.D.P.
text: The revised G.D.P. numbers damage the economic growth numbers for Obama and the George W. Bush administrations.

headline: Projecting Our Nature Onto Ravenous Bears
text: Park managers in the United States and Canada have responded to a recent wave of encounters between bears and people with new rules -– for the human side of the equation, anyway. Bears will still be allowed to be bears, but in Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming, managers clarified rules this week about how close visitors can “willfully approach” the animals for, say, a photograph: 100 yards.

headline: A Paper Calendar? It’s 2011
text: LAST month, I did something that not once in my 20 years as an overscheduled, neurotically punctual, paper-bound calendar keeper had I done before: I left my personal organizer (as Filofaxes, Day Runners and such are known to the trade) at the office.

headline: New Ways to Find the Perfect Hotel
text: Hotels are the new sweet spot for online and mobile booking tools.

headline: Democratic Allies Offer Early Glimpse Into Money Race
text: A coalition of independent Democratic-leaning groups announced on Friday that they had raised more than $10 million since the beginning of the year, offering an early glimpse into efforts by Democratic operatives to match the Republican-backed independent groups that played a pivotal role in last year’s midterm elections.

headline: The A-List? They Must Be Grading on a Curve
text: IF the weave-pulling, table-flipping antics of the “Real Housewives” seem crass, you probably haven’t caught “The A-List” on Logo yet.

headline: New York Post Employees Told to ‘Preserve’ Documents
text: Employees of The New York Post, Rupert Murdoch’s irreverent and hard-charging city tabloid, were told Friday to keep any documents they may have that pertain to the kind of illegal activity that has led to numerous arrests and a widening investigation at the News Corporation’s British newspapers.

headline: Another Round for the Bad Boys
text: HOW profoundly has “Animal House” penetrated American culture since it was released 33 years ago, on July 28, 1978? Headline writers would be immeasurably impoverished without its title to play on, editorialists would have to think of other ways of describing Congressional dysfunction, and judges would need to come up with new ways of rebuking delinquent celebrities, rather than quoting the sage advice offered by Dean Wormer (John Vernon) to Flounder (Stephen Furst): “Fat, drunk and stupid is no way to go through life, son.”

headline: Two British Families Crack Jokes in Ways Familiar and Strange
text: The big news at BBC America this week was the announcement of “Copper,” its first original drama series. For the channel, it’s a major step in establishing an independent identity; it’s also a sign that that identity will be increasingly American. The show will be set in New York in the 1860s and produced by Yanks, including the veterans Tom Fontana and Barry Levinson (“Oz,” “Homicide: Life on the Street”).

headline: Jacqueline Harrington, Andrew Holm
text: Jacqueline Dorothy Harrington and Andrew Erlich Holm were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Dr. Alvin Kass at the Pierre in New York.

headline: Geri Armine-Klein, Cynthia Armine-Klein
text: Geri Robin Armine-Klein and Cynthia Ann Armine-Klein are to be married Sunday afternoon at the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue in Brooklyn. Rabbi Hara E. Person is to perform the ceremony.

text: Rachel Joan Posner Gross and Jonathan David Winkelman were married Saturday evening at the Museum of Contemporary Art’s Warehouse in Chicago. Lindsay Gaskins, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the ceremony, officiated.

Strobe Talbott, a friend of the couple who is a former deputy secretary of state and now the president of the Brookings Institution in Washington, received permission from the Ohio secretary of state to officiate.

Sword and Mr. Sword Sr. of Princeton, N.J. Terri Orr, a justice of the peace for the town of Waltham, Mass., officiated at the Crane Estate, an event space in Ipswich, Mass.

Robert Bruce Birdsey of Richmond, Va. The bridegroom’s father, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Mary’s by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Northeast Harbor, Me., with the Rev. Patricia Rome Robertson, the church’s rector, taking part.

text: Sophie Klein and Jonathan Kelner were married Saturday evening at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York. Rabbi Laurie Phillips officiated.

text: Amanda Grace Mattei and Bennett Eastman Rathbun were married Saturday at Johnson Chapel on the campus of Amherst College in Amherst, Mass. Sarah W. Buttenwieser, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

text: Cara Michelle Swan and Jacob William Lupfer were married Saturday at Anchor Pocket Park in Fernandina Beach, Fla. Karen Roumillat, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

Saris of the District of Massachusetts in Boston.

Mumm of Federal District Court in Los Angeles, and an uncle of the bride, participated.

Koslow and Dr. Jeffrey Koslow of Cherry Hill, N.J. The ceremony was led by Paul W. Davis, a friend of the family who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate.

text: Nicole Eugenie Oncina and Jeffrey Traer Bernstein were married Saturday evening at a branch of the Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego in the La Jolla section of San Diego. Mitchell Frazer, a cousin of the bridegroom who was appointed as a deputy commissioner of civil marriages by San Diego County for the event, officiated.

headline: Nina Morrison and Carina Biggs

text: Christopher Lockwood and John Boone were married Monday in Hillsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Galen Guengerich, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the couple’s country home, where he also led a commitment ceremony on July 23.

headline: Pixie Seth, Kevin Polowy
text: Prakrti Seth and Kevin Luke Polowy were married on Saturday in Java Center, N.Y. Samuel J. Sellers, a friend who was ordained by the American Fellowship Church for the event, officiated at Beaver Hollow Conference Center.

headline: Kacey Wood and Christopher Pohlad
text: Sara Kacey Wood and Christopher Robert Pohlad were married Saturday at the Our Lady of Good Voyage Chapel in Roche Harbor on San Juan Island in Washington State. The Rev. Ralph J. Goman, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Katharine McCarthy, William Rosener
text: Katharine Joy McCarthy and William Lincoln Rosener were married Saturday in Rye, N.Y. Carol A. Fabietti, an aunt of the bridegroom who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Wainwright House, an event space.

headline: Boehner’s Bill and the Balanced Budget Amendment
text: Speaker John A. Boehner’s debt ceiling bill would essentially require a two-thirds vote in both chambers of Congress before the nation’s debt ceiling could be raised next year.

headline: Caesar Stovall, Army Medic Turned Givenchy Model
text: THE military trains its personnel to do battle, and so does fashion. The techniques and methods may differ, but the core precepts are the same.

headline: Some Death, Some Struggle, Some Strain, Yet So Much Still Is Joyful
text: No choreographer alive is more bewildering than Mark Morris. Much of his work is strikingly cerebral and schematic, and yet its main effect tends to be the direct opposite. His dancers exude a visceral urgency, an innocent charm and a “you could do this too” simplicity of style that turn the connection between them and the audience into a bond of love and recognition. On one level, his dances are all about the raw stuff of dance itself. On another, they plainly have much to say. They are about the multiple layers of their music, and yet, in terms of timing, imagery and structure, their fit to the score is frequently — deliberately — disconcerting.

headline: A Team of Introvert and Extrovert
text: HOLMDEL, N.J. — Weezer, established in 1992, and the Flaming Lips, established in 1983, have both had multiple-act, hill-and-dale careers in what used to be called alternative rock. Presumably, so have their listeners, some of whom are closing in on 50. But they don’t have much else in common, and that’s partly why their collaboration on Thursday at PNC Bank Arts Center here — repeated on Friday at Jones Beach — felt like a bright idea.

headline: Danes Deliver Rare Works by a Native Son
text: The official biography of the Royal Danish Orchestra does not mince words: this, we are told, is “the oldest orchestral institution in the world,” tracing its origin to the trumpet corps in the court of King Christian I and dating from 1448. To put that date into perspective, the institution was founded 100 years before the Dresden Staatskapelle, often cited as one of the world’s oldest orchestras; 435 years before the Norwegian composer Johan Svendsen inaugurated the Danish orchestra’s symphonic concert series; and 441 years before the Danish composer Carl Nielsen took his position among its second violins.

headline: The Disappointing GDP Numbers; Microsoft's Bing; News
text: The Disappointing GDP Numbers; Microsoft's Bing; News

headline: For Asian-American Stars, Many Web Fans
text: ASIAN roles in Hollywood have come a long way since Mickey Rooney played a Japanese neighbor in “Breakfast at Tiffany’s.” But the dearth of Asian lead characters today suggests that there is still a way to go.

headline: Motherlode: Annie Murphy Paul
text: Lisa Belkin interviews Annie Murphy Paul, the author of Origins.

headline: Will Fetal Science Lead to Lawsuits?
text: Annie Murphy Paul came to visit me at The Times earlier this week, and we chatted in front of some cameras about her book “Origins: How the  Nine Months Before Birth Shape the Rest of Our Lives.” Much of our conversation was about the potential use and misuse of fetal origins research: Would it be a trigger for greater resources toward helping pregnant women be healthy? To reduce their stress, improve their nutrition, and clean their environments? Or would it become just one more way to blame the mother?

headline: Lion’s Upgraded, Robust Security Features
text: New bells and whistles aren’t the only reason to upgrade to Lion. The new version of Apple’s operating system for the Mac also includes updated security features.

headline: When You Know How to Defend, Take Control
text: TORONTO — At the Summer Nationals here on Thursday night, the Wagar Women’s Knockout Teams was won by Joyce Hampton of Blythewood, S.C.; Jenny Wolpert of Jupiter, Fla.; Sabine Auken from Denmark; Daniela von Arnim from Germany; and Bénédicte Cronier and Sylvie Willard from France. They defeated Valerie Westheimer of New York; Hjordis Eythorsdottir of Huntsville, Ala. (Disa, as she is known); Mildred Breed of Austin, Tex.; and Shawn Quinn of Sugar Land, Tex., by 165 international match points to 131.

headline: Grow Local and Eat Local, City Council Says
text: In an effort to ramp up support for the consumption and production of local food, the City Council passed a package of bills on Thursday to facilitate the building of rooftop greenhouses and free up land for urban gardens.

headline: More on the Mother-Daughter Sex Talk
text: A response from Kathleen Volk Miller, whose essay about her very frank talk with her daughter led to a lot of equally frank responses.

headline: More Layoffs at The Los Angeles Times
text: On Wednesday, The Los Angeles Times announced a small round of layoffs but would not say exactly how many employees had been affected.

headline: Keeping His Cool in a Meltdown
text: Michael Wolff, 57, the editorial director of Adweek magazine, is also a contributing editor for Vanity Fair; the founder of newser.com, a news aggregation Web site; and author of “Burn Rate,” an account of his travails during the dot-com boom, and “The Man Who Owns the News,” a biography of Rupert Murdoch.

headline: House Passes Short-Term Increase in Debt Ceiling
text: The House of Representatives on Friday approved a plan for a short-term increase in the debt ceiling and for cuts in spending, ending a week of intense fighting among Republicans and shifting the endgame of the debate to the Senate.

headline: In West Africa, Democracy Struggles to Survive
text: DAKAR, Senegal — President Obama hosted four recently elected West African presidents on Friday in a gesture of support for the continent’s nascent democracies. Given what they are wrestling with, they could certainly use it.

headline: How Boehner’s Bill Has Hurt, and How It Could Help, Republicans
text: As I wrote on Wednesday, there is not all that much difference between the proposals put forth earlier this week by the speaker of the House, John A. Boehner, and the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid. Both came up with roughly the same amount in deficit reduction (accounting tricks notwithstanding). Both set up bipartisan commissions to achieve more. Neither raised taxes, but both raised the debt ceiling. But Mr. Boehner’s bill did so for six months, while Mr. Reid’s did so through the end of 2012.

headline: Making Use of Duck Fat
text: If you’ve never rendered duck fat, it’s easy as long as you go low and slow, letting the fat melt over low heat so it doesn’t burn. Here is a more detailed explanation of the technique I mention in my latest column:

headline: For a Family Business, a Recurring Role in the TV Spotlight
text: It is a reality TV phenomenon, watched by audiences from Los Angeles to Qatar, but for Philip Sauma, 33, watching on the flat screen in his brother’s living room in Hell’s Kitchen, it is the family business. “Those are our feathers,” he said Thursday night, pointing to black plumes. “Those are ours!”

headline: Got Briefs? This Run’s for You
text: The air this time of year is thick with athletic elitism. Some people think that just because they can complete a half-marathon or swim around Manhattan or get 3,000 hits they are somehow more athletically worthy than the rest of us. Yes, those things take a certain amount of commitment. But so does standing in Central Park in long johns, Dr. Seuss boxer shorts and a $48 undershirt. The guy willing to do that deserves a hall of fame, too.

headline: Happily Ever After, ‘I Do’ or Not
text: ARNOLD SCAASI was once asked by a writer for The Times whether, should same-sex marriage become legal, he would wed his partner, Parker Ladd.

headline: Toasts Away for Arnold Scaasi and Parker Ladd
text: Photos from the reception in honor of the couple at Le Cirque in New York.

headline: Giants Range Not So Far for a New Punter
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Seeking to bring in some competition at punter after Matt Dodge struggled through his rookie season in 2010, the Giants did not look far.

headline: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: Unlikely Spy
text: “Portrait of a Spy,” the 11th book in Daniel Silva’s series about Gabriel Allon, an art restorer who doubles as an Israeli spy, arrives at No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list.

headline: A City’s Hard Edges, Softened by Joy
text: Is there a creature as imaginative or as indefatigable as the city child in search of a place to play? New York would seem to have been designed for everything but youthful frolic. And, to be sure, it can hold great perils. Yet from generation to generation — ever since the kids sang “Ring Around the Rosie” and “London Bridge Is Falling Down” — the sidewalks of New York have yielded to youngsters’ inexhaustible need to frisk, exult, screech, plot and plunge.

headline: Former SAC Manager Gets 2½-Year Jail Term in Insider Case
text: A former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors was sentenced to two and a half years in prison on Friday after he pleaded guilty in April to insider trading.

headline: The Hudson and Four Beaches Are Deemed Safe Again
text: More than a week after a sewage discharge contaminated New York’s waterways, city officials have finally told residents the magic words: Your rivers’ fecal coliform readings have returned to acceptable levels.

headline: Boehner’s Last Word as Debate Crosses Capitol
text: Just moments after House Speaker John A. Boehner secured passage of his modified debt ceiling legislation, an op-ed he penned appeared on the website of the conservative National Review Online.

headline: Norway Displays Unity at Attack Victim’s Funeral
text: NESODDEN, Norway — While her friends saved for iPads, Bano Rashid worked at an amusement park last summer to buy a bunad, the ornate and expensive national costume of Norway. Though she was an Iraqi Kurd who came here as a child, Ms. Rashid wanted to stretch the limits of the country’s blond and blue-eyed identity, to help redefine what it means to be Norwegian.

text: Now that Jürgen Klinsmann is the new American soccer coach, who plays Joachim Löw in this performance?

headline: A War-Hardened Filmmaker Delves Into Islam
text: On his way home from covering the Persian Gulf war, the filmmaker Greg Barker stayed overnight in a small Egyptian village. Early the next morning, an undulating sound awakened him. For someone raised in Southern California, where predawn interruptions usually come from car alarms, it took some time to realize he was hearing the muezzin’s call to prayer.

headline: How to Pick a Site for a Nuclear Waste Dump
text: The United States can find a way to dispose of its nuclear waste, even if the current program is at an impasse, according to the blue-ribbon commission established by President Obama after he ended the government’s planning for making Yucca Mountain in Nevada the nation’s nuclear waste repository.

headline: Podcast: G.D.P., European Stocks, Bernanke and Bing
text: If you were hoping for some economic good news to close out July, forget it. Not only did the Commerce Department offer up a gloomy assessment of the second-quarter gross domestic product, it also said the recession of 2007-9 was deeper and the recovery slower than we thought.
