headline: No Little League World Series for Ugandan Team
text: For nearly two weeks, the players of the Rev. John Foundation Little League team from Kampala, Uganda, believed they were headed to Williamsport, Pa., for the Little League World Series. The team of 11- to 13-year-olds, which plays with donated equipment, was the first African team to advance that far.

headline: The Week in Pictures for July 29
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a heat wave, the first day of same-sex marriage in New York, and the public appearance of Nafissatou Diallo.

headline: Tour Champion Evans to Race in Colorado
text: The Australian cyclist Cadel Evans, fresh off of his first Tour de France victory, has confirmed that he will compete in the inaugural USA Pro Cycling Challenge in Colorado this month, the race’s organizers said.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Photos
text: Debate in Washington over the national debt ceiling and in Europe over weak economies; the designed slowing of China’s economy; emission requirements for flights to Europe and more.

headline: Wearing One Glove, Suspect Robs Three Banks
text: Federal officials issued an unusual warning to New York City banks on Friday: Be on the lookout for a man wearing only one glove.

headline: N.R.C. Lowers Estimate of How Many Would Die in Meltdown
text: ROCKVILLE, Md. — The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is approaching completion of an ambitious study that concludes that a meltdown at a typical American reactor would lead to far fewer deaths than previously assumed.

headline: In an Early 1900s Neighborhood, a Glimpse of ‘2001’
text: When it showed up unannounced in April, the neighbors stared, goggle-eyed. Some compared the scene to one in a classic Stanley Kubrick film.

headline: On the Party Circuit, and Upsetting the Party
text: BEIJING

headline: Safety Agency Cites Tortilla Company Where Worker Died
text: The federal government has cited a tortilla company in Brooklyn for violations carrying fines totaling over $62,000 after an investigation into the death of a worker who fell into an industrial mixing machine at its factory, officials said Friday.

headline: Remap Aids Democrats in California
text: LOS ANGELES — California’s nonpartisan redistricting commission, charged with redrawing the state’s Congressional and legislative districts free from party politics, approved its final set of maps on Friday.

headline: Sound of Gunfire From Island Sent Civilians to Teenagers’ Rescue
text: SUNDVOLLEN, Norway — On a sunny, placid Friday one week ago Marcel Gleffe was relaxing at Utvika, a pristine campsite on Lake Tyrifjorden not far from here, when he recognized the sound coming from Utoya, an island less than a half-mile away. Some at the camp thought it was fireworks. No, said Mr. Gleffe, a German with a military background, it was gunfire.

headline: Excitement Times Two for New Jersey Trainer
text: Kelly Breen is a Jersey-bred. He grew up in Old Bridge. He learned how to ride horses in Morganville. He figured out how to bet on them on the front side of Monmouth Park. He was taught how to train them by the old-timers on the backside of that charming track on the Jersey Shore.

headline: Scold Your Own
text: 11:58 p.m. | Updated to reflect news developments.

headline: Senate Tables Boehner Bill
text: The United States Senate quickly dispatched the debt ceiling bill passed by the House Friday evening, tabling the Republican bill indefinitely and moving quickly to start consideration of a Democratic plan that would avoid default on Tuesday.

headline: Partners Push a Tap Wine Manifesto
text: “WARNING: Wine Not Beer,” reads the disclaimer on the draft handle behind the bar at Terroir Tribeca, a wine bar on Harrison Street in Manhattan. You’ll find the same thing at the restaurants Buttermilk Channel and Colicchio & Sons, where the taps dispense red, white and rosé, all from a keg-wine company known as the Gotham Project.

headline: The Courage to Testify, but No Desire to Elaborate
text: The boy is 13 now, whip-thin and taller than he was two years ago, but after what happened then, not as quick. He opened the door of his family’s 14th-floor apartment in a Bronx project on Thursday morning and said no, he could not talk right now, because his parents were not home.

headline: The Southern Cross
text: Confederate Gen. G.T. Beauregard was worried. It was the afternoon of July 21, 1861, and fighting had raged since daylight after General Irwin McDowell’s Union army attacked Beauregard from across the small Virginia stream known as Bull Run. The battle seesawed throughout the day, but fresh troops rushed in from the Shenandoah Valley had finally given Beauregard the advantage. Now, just as victory seemed certain, he spied a heavy column of troops more than a mile away maneuvering on his flank.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Q. The liner notes for one of my albums mentions a Black Swan Records in New York. It sounds interesting. Could you tell me about the company?

headline: Yogi Guardians, on a Healing Mission
text: ANA FORREST is an itinerant yoga teacher riding the circuit, selling out workshops in South Africa and conducting training sessions in Houston. She is to Yoga Journal as Angelina Jolie is to Us magazine: a mainstay.

headline: A Huge Star Was Stuck Outside, Stamping Her Feet
text: No one could ignore the elephant in the room, or rather at the corner of Franklin and Church Streets in TriBeCa on Thursday night. Minnie, a 5,000-pound Asian elephant, ambled down the street at 10 p.m. to the Theater Bar, where she spent the night outside snorting up fish-shaped candy and causing a minor traffic jam.

headline: Caddie Choice Serves as Window Into Woods’s Thinking
text: Everything is just talk until Tiger Woods actually shows up next week in Akron, Ohio, for the W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational, rested and presumably healthy after three months of his new R&R: recuperation and rehabilitation.

headline: Global Concern Over U.S. Debt Ceiling Disagreement
text: PARIS — While the debt debacle in Washington preoccupies America, it is causing jitters in power corridors from Beijing to Brussels. The stewards of the world’s largest economies are anxious for a compromise, to keep their own finances from suffering collateral damage.

headline: How Different Types of Republicans Voted on Boehner’s Revised Debt Plan
text: Analysis of how different Republican blocs voted on the revised debt plan.

headline: Muddying the Budget Waters
text: All the political wrangling over the budget in Washington has been focused on one theme: how much the government should cut and when those cuts should take effect.

headline: Afghan Team Denied Chance at 2012 Olympics
text: Afghanistan’s national men’s basketball team will not get a chance to qualify for the 2012 Olympics after requests for visas to travel to a prequalifying tournament were denied.

headline: Regulators Seek Records on Claims for Gas Wells
text: WASHINGTON — The Securities and Exchange Commission sent subpoenas this week to energy companies asking them for documents about how they calculate and publicly disclose the performance of their shale gas wells, according to oil and gas industry lawyers.

headline: End of a Bar, and Its Surprisingly Artistic Life
text: MARS BAR, the dive joint on the first floor of 11 Second Avenue, closed last week amid ballyhoo. (It was mentioned in the Metropolitan cover story on July 17, “Waiting for the Wrecking Ball.”)

headline: In Uganda, a Failure to Deliver
text: A lawsuit over the death of a woman in labor may be the first legal test of an African government’s obligation to provide basic maternal care and also raises questions about the impact of foreign aid.

headline: Governor Said to Have Irked Transit Leader Who Is Leaving
text: Jay H. Walder, chairman of the embattled Metropolitan Transportation Authority, traveled to Albany earlier this year seeking help for a transit system in peril. Mr. Walder, a kid from Queens who rose to the top of his field and harbored big ambitions for his state, was not unlike the man he had hoped to see: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: Spinning the American Songbook
text: On Sunday afternoons for the past four decades, Jonathan Schwartz has been spinning the wax and waxing poetic on all things Sinatra and American standard. Now 72, Mr. Schwartz can be heard every day of the week on Sirius Satellite Radio — Channel 71 — but weekends still find him at his longtime home on the FM dial, WNYC. He lives in Midtown Manhattan with the actress  Zohra Lampert, whom he married last year. Mr. Schwartz’s daughter, Casey, 28, and son, Adam, 24, often join them for dinner.

headline: Maternal Deaths Focus Harsh Light on Uganda
text: ARUA, Uganda — Jennifer Anguko was slowly bleeding to death right in the maternity ward of a major public hospital. Only a lone midwife was on duty, the hospital later admitted, and no doctor examined her for 12 hours. An obstetrician who investigated the case said Ms. Anguko, the mother of three young children, had arrived in time to be saved.

headline: Sorry, W.J.B., to Bring This Up Again
text: You — collectively, and perhaps you specifically — delighted me by your thoughtful and articulate responses to my confessional column involving the William Jennings Bryan jape committed by me and my rascally friends.

headline: Nova Is Set to Return to the Yankees’ Rotation, for a Day at Least
text: Manager Joe Girardi needed a little prodding Friday before announcing that Ivan Nova would start the second game of a day-night doubleheader Saturday against the Baltimore Orioles at Yankee Stadium. Exactly what happens to Nova after that will be determined once he pitches.

headline: How Would You Shore Up Social Security?
text: This week’s Your Money column discusses a proposal that would tinker with one of the most beloved features of Social Security: the cost-of-living adjustment.

headline: In Belarus, Just Being Can Prompt an Arrest
text: MOSCOW — Iron-fisted authorities in Belarus have responded to a burst of creative modes of protest by young protesters with a rather surreal innovation of their own: a law that prohibits people from standing together and doing nothing.

headline: The Madoff Trustee’s Bad Day
text: Jed Rakoff is one of the most respected federal judges in the country, so when he issues an opinion calling one side’s arguments “convoluted,” “conjecture” and “a stretch,” people tend to take notice.

headline: Bloggingheads: Debt Limit Endgame
text: Jonathan Rauch, left, of the Brookings Institution and Rich Lowry of National Review debate possible conclusions for the debt limit crisis.

headline: Asomugha Rejects Jets; Picks Eagles
text: Every once in a while, a player comes along who consumes a team’s attention. For the Jets, that player was Nnamdi Asomugha, the elite, free-agent cornerback of the Oakland Raiders.

headline: It’s Up to the Senate
text: It was hard to imagine that the House bill to raise the debt limit, and slash and burn the economy, could get any worse. But on Friday it did.

headline: Some Good News for the Planet
text: There is at least some positive news from Washington: a major agreement to bring American consumers cleaner cars — dramatically cutting greenhouse gas pollution, raising fuel economy standards and increasing Detroit’s ability to compete in world markets.

headline: New York Judges Deserve a Raise
text: New York State’s 1,300 judges have not had a raise or even a cost-of-living adjustment for a dozen years. Their salaries now lag behind the pay of federal judges, senior assistant district attorneys and Legal Aid lawyers in New York City. In many instances, judges even earn less than their own law clerks whose salaries are set by union collective bargaining. Judges on the State Supreme Court, New York’s main trial court, earn $136,700 — $37,300 less than comparable federal judges.

headline: Judge Agrees to Limit Writer’s Testimony
text: WASHINGTON — A federal judge dealt a setback on Friday to the Obama administration’s crackdown on the leaking of government secrets to journalists, sharply limiting what prosecutors can ask the author of a book about the C.I.A. in court.

headline: Soldier Arrested in Suspected Bomb Plot Had Series of Disputes With Army
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — The 21-year-old Army private arrested here this week made his first appearance in federal court on Friday, two days after telling investigators he planned to detonate explosive devices at a restaurant frequented by soldiers from nearby Fort Hood, the culmination of a series of disputes between the private and the military over his Muslim beliefs and his pending deployment to Afghanistan.

headline: John Boehner, Escape Artist
text: With the House of Representatives voting tonight to pass an implausibly right-wing debt ceiling bill after failing, yesterday, to pass the somewhat more plausible but still quite conservative alternative, Ezra Klein expressed bafflement at John Boehner’s legislative strategy:

headline: Mending Fences
text: While the horses have been on vacation across the road in a neighbor’s pasture, my own pastures have grown into what looks like the first stage of abandonment. The grass is high, and so are the thistles and burdock. Here and there, sumac is trying to grow unnoticed. Several of the fences are down — intentionally — and in two of the pastures lie the trunks of dead sugar maples, cut into log lengths. They remind me of whale bones I once saw on an island off the coast of southern Chile.

headline: Off-Season Reduced, N.F.L. Runs Through Millions
text: After more than four months of fighting over money, the National Football League has proved — in four of the most frenetic and expensive days in its history — that it did not forget how to spend it.

headline: Filly Remains Undefeated
text: The undefeated See You at Peelers won her division of Yonkers Raceway’s $233,230 New York Sire Stakes Rye Pace on Thursday, her 21st lifetime victory and eighth as a 3-year-old. An easy two-and-a-half-length victor, she completed the mile in 1 minute 52.2 seconds, a track record for her 3-year-old filly weight class.

headline: John H. Marburger, Bush Science Adviser, Dies at 70
text: John H. Marburger III, a physicist, former college president and Democrat who served as science adviser to President George W. Bush and was frequently called on to defend his policies on birth control, stem cell research and climate change, died Thursday at his home in Port Jefferson, Long Island. He was 70.

headline: White House Adviser says U.S. Has 6 Months to ‘Knock Out’ Rattled Qaeda Leadership
text: ASPEN, Colo. — President Obama’s top adviser on Pakistan said Friday that the United States had six months to deliver “a knockout blow” to Al Qaeda’s senior leadership in Pakistan while the group was still in turmoil after the killing of Osama bin Laden.

headline: Philanthropists Start Requiring Management Courses to Keep Nonprofits Productive
text: Pierre M. Omidyar and Peter B. Lewis are in many ways opposites. Mr. Omidyar, the founder of eBay, is shy, soft-spoken and formal, while Mr. Lewis, who made Progressive Insurance into the powerhouse it is today, bluntly speaks his mind and revels in stopping people midsentence by taking off his prosthetic leg during meetings.

headline: Obama Reveals Details of Gas Mileage Rules
text: DETROIT — President Obama announced new automobile fuel-efficiency standards on Friday that require an average 54.5 miles per gallon by 2025. But even if the auto industry manages to meet the new standards, it is unlikely car buyers will see many fuel-economy stickers with such high mileage.

headline: Lottery Numbers
That Aug. 2 Deadline? It May Be Impossible, Veteran Lawmakers Say
text: WASHINGTON — Here is advice from veterans of past budget battles in Congress that went to the brink: This time, be afraid. Be very afraid.

headline: Precautions at New York Post as Tabloid Inquiry Expands
text: Employees of The New York Post, Rupert Murdoch’s irreverent and hard-charging city tabloid, were told Friday to keep any documents that may pertain to the kind of illegal activity that has led to arrests and a widening investigation at the News Corporation’s British newspapers.

headline: Absences Stand Out as Giants Practice
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Seventy-seven Giants players reported to the Timex Performance Center for the first day of training camp Friday, but most of the talk was about two players who were not there: Plaxico Burress and Osi Umenyiora.

headline: Robert C. W. Ettinger, a Proponent of Life After (Deep-Frozen) Death, Is Dead at 92
text: Robert C. W. Ettinger, a science fiction writer and physics instructor whose idea of freezing the dead for future reanimation repelled most scientists, inspired Woody Allen and Mike Myers to some of their best work and persuaded at least 105 game humans to pay $28,000 each to have their bodies preserved in liquid nitrogen at his Cryonics Institute in suburban Detroit, died on July 23 at his home in Clinton Township, Mich. He was 92.

headline: Enjoy Park Greenery, City Says, but Not as Salad
text: Maybe it is the spiraling cost of food in a tough economy or the logical next step in the movement to eat locally. Whatever the reason, New Yorkers are increasingly fanning out across the city’s parks to hunt and gather edible wild plants, like mushrooms, American ginger and elderberries.

headline: Saturday: Something Seen on a Pad
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Did this Saturday puzzle seem easier to you than others? It started off a bit slowly for me in the northwest, but once I got that all-important toehold, it fell pretty easily. It was well worth hanging in there, too. Patrick Berry’s grid today is crammed with shiny, brand new entries and irresistible cluing.

headline: Free Concerts, Yonkers to Tarrytown
text: WHILE the Caramoor and Litchfield festivals fill the first weekend in August with some of the finest jazz a fan can buy, Westchester will be awash in free performances throughout the month as Jazz Forum Arts’s 12th annual summer concert series concludes with 16 shows at five locations.

headline: Where Summertime Means Jazz
text: FOR jazz fans, the absence this summer of a festival in New York City produced by George Wein, who founded the Newport Jazz Festival and for many years staged sister events in the city, has been conspicuous. But the undiminished presence of the Caramoor and Litchfield jazz festivals — both among the top-ticketed events in the metropolitan region — has offered some consolation.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: My Very Own Captain America
text: My grandfather spoke to me this week. That would’ve been unremarkable if not for the fact that he died four years ago.

headline: Debt Crisis? Bankruptcy Fears? See Jefferson County, Ala.
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — A few hundred miles north of here, politicians are fighting over debt. It is a spirited debate, full of discussions about what kind of country will be left for future generations and pledges not to kick the can down the road.

headline: Visual Meditations on Death
text: “Death may be the greatest of all human blessings,” the Greek philosopher Socrates wrote. Many years later, the Welsh poet Dylan Thomas offered a divergent view: “Do not go gentle into that good night.”

headline: From Elite Duck-Hunting Enclaves to Public Pastures
text: RIFLES, decoys and low-slung boats are among the objects and images that greet visitors to “Private Places Public Spaces: Suffolk County’s Elite Hunt Clubs and Regional Decoys,” a new exhibition at the Suffolk County Historical Society in Riverhead. But the show’s aim reaches beyond tracing the history of a recreational activity and a folk art on Long Island, said Kathryn M. Curran, the curator of the show and the historical society’s incoming director.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to  cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should  be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Mets Get Close Look at Pitcher They Know
text: WASHINGTON — On the second anniversary of his shoulder operation, Chien-Ming Wang toed the pitcher’s rubber at Nationals Park here as many curious people fixed their eyes upon him and his rebuilt shoulder.

headline: China Jails Journalist Who Reported on Corruption
text: BEIJING — A Chinese court has upheld the eight-year sentence of an investigative journalist in Shandong Province who had already completed a four-year term on charges of “extortion and blackmail” — charges that his lawyers say were concocted to silence him.

headline: For Republican Freshmen, the Power of Saying No
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Mo Brooks of Alabama knew his own power when he stood face to face with Speaker John A. Boehner in the cloakroom off the House floor.

headline: For Young Artists, a Return to the Easel
text: SOME vegetarians have issues with the name of an exhibition currently at the Shore Institute of the Contemporary Arts, in Long Branch, according to Doug Ferrari, the museum’s executive director. The show, “Fresh Meat/Young Blood: New Jersey’s New Masters,” displays the work of the latest crop of graduates from New Jersey’s master of fine arts programs.

headline: Myths, Legends and Cuban Culture
text: One thing you will learn at “Ajiaco: Stirrings of the Cuban Soul” is that Cuba contains an extraordinary mix of cultures, derived from many African ethnic groups, Europe, Asia and the native Amerindians. What is not apparent in this exhibition, on view at the Newark Museum, is that contemporary art associated with Cuba — that is, made by artists living in Cuba or who are Cuban-born but living in the United States — is similarly heterogeneous.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide  to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar  should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Vince Young Is New Project for the Eagles
text: The Eagles, having shipped their backup quarterback, Kevin Kolb, to the Cardinals on Thursday, found his replacement in Vince Young, who was released by the Titans on Thursday. The Eagles’ last quarterback reclamation project, Michael Vick, said he was thrilled the team was taking on Young as its next project.

headline: Nuclear-Detection Effort Is Halted as Ineffective
text: ASPEN, Colo. — The Obama administration has quietly canceled a much-criticized billion-dollar program to equip ports across the United States with detectors to pick out radioactive material and nuclear weapons being shipped into the country, after acknowledging that the devices did not work.

headline: Phone Hacker Points Finger at Paper
text: The private investigator who went to prison for his role in the phone hacking scandal at The News of the World said Friday that he had acted on instructions from the newspaper.

headline: Locally Grown Food, From Backyard Hive
text: IT’S a hot July day at Peter Pratt’s Inn in Yorktown Heights and the honeybees are, well, busy. Standing here in full bee-protection regalia, with Craig Purdy, a co-owner of Peter Pratt’s and the Ümami Café in Croton-on-Hudson, I am about to see where honey comes from.

headline: Sandwiches Get Creative
text: What do restaurant chefs chat about in the kitchen while preparing dinner? If the chefs are Jonathan Contes, 29, and Tate Morris, 34, who are part owners of Mosaic in St. James, the talk frequently turns to the perfect sandwich.

headline: View a Yacht, or Two, With Your Dinner
text: A BALMY summer night, a waterfront table for two and views of glistening white yachts at anchor: that sums up the allure of  the Patio at the Freeport Inn and Marina. The new restaurant, which opened in May, is mainly outdoors; the interior contains a 30-foot bar and a few small tables.

headline: Death Toll Rises From High-Speed Train Crash in China
text: The death toll from a high-speed train crash in eastern China last week rose to 40 late on Thursday as a critically injured passenger died in the hospital.

headline: Defying a Stereotype With Gourmet Dishes
text: NEW MILFORD, Conn.

headline: From the Sea to Your Plate
text: Fish and chips are the headliner at Cod Almighty Chippery. But at this fast-casual restaurant, which opened last August in a strip mall in Westfield, there are also other catches: “po’ boy” sandwiches with fried clams ($8.25), fish tacos ($7) and steamed mussels ($7.95), to name a few.

headline: A Local Italian Staple, Back to Its Family Roots
text: THE crowd of cars around Luchento’s Ristorante had long intrigued me, but it was a recent facade renovation that propelled me through the doors. Once there, I found a dining style evocative of scenes in vintage photographs or films.

headline: Battle for Libya | July 29, 2011
text: Thousands of mourners attended the funeral of top rebel military commander, Gen. Abdul Fattah Younes, in Benghazi on Friday.

headline: Obama’s Crucible Moment at Intersection of Politics and the Economy
text: WASHINGTON — It was a day that brought fresh evidence of all the forces converging on President Obama in the latter half of his term: a weakened economy he cannot lift, a deeply divided Congress he cannot move and, as a result, a level of political risk he seems hard-pressed to control.

headline: Biologist’s Suspension Is Not Related to Scientific Integrity, Bureau Official Says
text: A spokeswoman for the federal Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement issued a brief statement on Friday denying that Charles Monnett, a wildlife biologist and manager of scientific contracts, was suspended because of possible misconduct involving his scientific reports on dead polar bears in the Beaufort Sea. Melissa Schwartz, the bureau’s deputy chief of staff and communications director, wrote in an e-mail, “The agency placed Mr. Monnett on administrative leave for reasons having nothing to do with scientific integrity, his 2006 journal article or issues related to permitting,” a reference to the bureau’s role in permitting offshore drilling. “Any suggestions or speculation to the contrary are wrong,” Ms. Schwartz concluded. Dr. Monnett was told of the leave in an official letter on July 18, which referred to a continuing investigation by the department’s inspector general into “integrity issues.” A few days before his suspension, a long-running contract involving polar bear research by scientists at the University of Alberta was abruptly put on hold. It is not clear whether the action involving that contract is connected to Dr. Monnett’s suspension.

headline: Judge Orders Release of Nixon’s Watergate Testimony
text: A federal judge in Washington has ordered the release of hundreds of pages of President Richard M. Nixon’s 1975 testimony about Watergate. The judge, Royce C. Lamberth III of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia, wrote in a decision issued Friday that “nearly 40 years later, Watergate continues to capture both scholarly and public interest.” The Obama administration objected to the release, citing the privacy of people mentioned in the testimony. But Judge Lamberth wrote that the “undisputed historical interest” in the testimony, among other factors, far outweighed “the need to maintain the secrecy of the records.” The transcripts will not be released right away; the government can appeal the decision. Stanley I. Kutler, a leading Watergate historian who filed suit to get the documents last year, said that Nixon’s grand jury testimony was “a rare opportunity to hear him — what should I say? — unplugged. There are no aides, there are no lawyers, there are no spin doctors.” With the possible penalty of perjury over his head, Professor Kutler said, “My guess is he told those people the truth.” A spokesman for the Department of Justice, Charles S. Miller, said the agency was reviewing the judge’s decision and had not determined its next step.

headline: Ruthless and Relentless, Phillies’ Amaro Strikes Again
text: Which adjective best describes Ruben Amaro, the general manager of the Philadelphia Phillies. Ruthless? Relentless? Both work pretty well. Amaro made another significant trade on Friday, acquiring the two-time All-Star outfielder Hunter Pence from the Houston Astros for three minor leaguers and a player to be named later.

headline: Corrections: July 30
text: NATIONAL

headline: David Servan-Schreiber, Exponent of Cancer Treatments, Dies at 50
text: PARIS — Dr. David Servan-Schreiber, a psychiatrist and best-selling author whose cancer diagnosis at the age of 31 compelled him to explore and then popularize the use of natural and holistic methods in dealing with cancer and depression, died on July 24 in a hospital near Fécamp, France. He was 50.

headline: Photo Replay: July 29
text: The day in sports, including day 14 of FINA World Swimming Championships and more N.F.L. teams returning to training camp.

headline: Like Seaside Heights, but With a Duomo
text: FLORENCE, Italy

headline: Lawyers for Clemens Ask Judge to Dismiss Charges
text: The lawyers for Roger Clemens have asked a federal judge to dismiss the charges against him, accusing the prosecutors at Clemens’s perjury trial earlier this month of sabotaging the government’s case to elicit a mistrial because the proceedings were going badly for them.

headline: Burnett Goes 8 Innings, but Gives Up More Than Yanks Can Afford
text: The Yankees right-hander A. J. Burnett retired the Baltimore Orioles on 10 first-inning pitches Friday, but one was hit so hard that Nick Swisher slammed into the wall making a running catch. Soon, the Orioles smacked just enough pitches to open spots, dooming Burnett again.

headline: Changing Gears Electronically
text: A look at an electronic gear system that will be used by some teams in the Tour of California that begins Saturday.

headline: Victims of Flight 3407
text: Musicians and law students, parents and pilots were among the 50 people who died on Continental Connection Flight 3407.

text: Today’s Times

headline: NATO Strikes at Libyan State TV
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — NATO said Saturday that it had disabled three Libyan state television transmission dishes in Tripoli with airstrikes overnight, as the alliance took steps to remove the main instrument of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s propaganda from the airwaves.

headline: End of a Bar, and Its Surprisingly Artistic Life
The Corrosion of the Conservative Economic Mind
text: First Michael Boskin, now John Taylor: there seems be an epidemic of politically conservative economists who used to be technically competent repeating the obviously wrong falsehood that Reagan ushered in an era of “unprecedented” growth.

headline: Warped Discourse, Again
text: Just worth reminding everyone: We have a deeply depressed economy — more deeply than we realized, according to the GDP revisions — which is clearly suffering from a lack of demand. Meanwhile, the government is able to borrow at very low interest rates:

headline: The Malevolent Ex-Maestro
text: After playing a key role in creating the greatest economic disaster in three generations, you might have expected Alan Greenspan to lie low. But no, he’s out there issuing opinions, which for some reason still get listened to. Worse: he keeps calling for a return to the very regime he favored before, the regime that led to disaster.

headline: Thome’s Pursuit of 600 Interrupted by Aches
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Jim Thome’s two lockers at Target Field contain the usual trappings of a veteran player: workout T-shirts of various designs, multiple pairs of cleats and assorted knick-knacks. But the one visible concession to Thome’s age — he turns 41 on Aug. 27 — was the hand-held muscle stimulator, about the size of a hair dryer, plugged in and ready for use.

headline: Moves at Trade Deadline Can Be Great Deal of Trouble
text: The most important thing to know about baseball trades made in July is that most of them do not amount to much. Few of the stars traded to contenders will be the difference between winning and losing, and few of the young prospects traded for stars will become stars. Still, we have had a flurry of activity leading to Sunday’s deadline for nonwaiver trades (don’t ask), with stars like Carlos Beltran and numerous lesser lights changing teams and kindling hope among their new teams’ fans.

headline: In Final Seconds, Vettel Takes Pole Position Again
text: BUDAPEST — “Yes! Yes!” shouted Sebastian Vettel in his car on his wind-down lap on Saturday after scoring pole position for the Hungarian Grand Prix on Sunday.

headline: In Final Seconds, Vettel Takes Pole Position Again
text: BUDAPEST — “Yes! Yes!” shouted Sebastian Vettel in his car on his wind-down lap on Saturday after scoring pole position for the Hungarian Grand Prix on Sunday.

headline: Red Bulls Go to London … and Win
text: The Red Bulls may be struggling mightily in their domestic league, but that malaise was left behind when the club traveled to London for the Emirates Cup and came away with a 1-0 win against Paris St. Germain at the home of Arsenal in north London on Saturday morning.

headline: Amid New Talks, Some Optimism on Debt Crisis
text: WASHINGTON — New budget talks between top Congressional Republicans and President Obama made progress late Saturday, suddenly stirring optimism that a last-minute deal could be reached to avert a potential federal default that threatened significant economic and political consequences.

headline: Taking a Closer Look at the Result of a Credit Downgrade
text: WASHINGTON — As political leaders race to avoid a default on the nation’s debts by striking a deal to borrow more money, there is a growing chance that a secondary goal, preserving the nation’s pristine credit rating, might slip beyond reach.

headline: Variety: A Proportional Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Hands up if you were (or still are) comic book fans. Me too. I still enjoy secretly thumbing through some of the comics that might be lying around the house (being able to enjoy the things of childhood a bit longer is one of the reasons I had kids in the first place), but I never really gave much thought as to why cartoonists made the interesting choice to letter their characters’ voices in all capital letters.

headline: Gunmen Attack Sinai Gas Pipeline
text: CAIRO — For the third time this month, gunmen attacked the strategic pipeline carrying natural gas from Egypt across the Sinai Peninsula to Israel and Jordan, Egyptian security officials said on Saturday.

headline: Some Bankers Never Learn
text: YOU’D think the mortgage bust would qualify as a teachable moment.

headline: Sure Cure for the Debt Problem: Economic Growth
text: NOT so long ago, the National Debt Clock, perched above the Avenue of the Americas, a block east of Times Square, was running backward.

headline: With Tannenbaum, Jets Show Audacity From the Top Down
text: Examine Mike Tannenbaum’s transaction history as the Jets’ general manager, and an obvious pattern emerges. He trades up, he trades down, he trades sideways. He deconstructs, he rebuilds. He acquires players with checkered pasts, hazy presents and promising futures.

headline: Turkish Prime Minister Climbs a Higher Perch in Wake of Resignations
text: ISTANBUL — Fifty years ago, when a populist prime minister tangled with the Turkish military, he ended up on the gallows, the mandate of three election victories little consolation. This time around, the rivalry climaxed with most of Turkey’s military command resigning simultaneously, its leader complaining of powerlessness and bad press.

headline: A Q&A With Jerry Glanville
text: The N.F.L. is back in business, and its 32 coaches are scrambling to cram months of preparation into a couple of weeks. There are some underemployed football coaches out there, but Jerry Glanville, though idle, had the pedal to the metal in the hills of north Georgia.

text: This interview with  Peter Löscher, president and C.E.O. of Siemens A.G., was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: For Caddies, There’s More Than Just Schlepping a Bag
text: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va. — Stepping inside the ropes at a PGA Tour event is not for the faint of heart. It requires physical strength, mental toughness, resiliency, good golf course management, accuracy, a lot of nerve and a thick skin.

text: AMERICA has always had an apocalyptic strain. Yet it also seems to believe that if, or when, The End comes, it will still come out on top.

headline: The Video Store, Reinvented by Necessity
text: ON Sunday evening, a group of men and women will gather in a screening room here to watch — and sing along to — the movie musical “Jesus Christ Superstar.” Many will be festively attired in bell-bottoms, love beads and big-hair wigs.

headline: Lessons Learned on TV for Eduardo Perez
text: Eduardo Perez had worked more than five years as an analyst for ESPN before the Florida Marlins hired him as hitting coach in June. Perez, 41, played in the majors as recently as 2006, but the lessons he took from his television producers have come in just as handy as anything he learned as a player.

headline: Putting a Shared Office to the Test
text: Q. You work from home and want to try co-working, in which you share office space with others but work independently. How do you get started?

headline: In Georgia, a Spy Case and a National Rorschach Test
text: TBILISI, Georgia — Last week, several days after the photographer Giorgi Abdaladze confessed to selling classified documents to Russia’s foreign intelligence service, he was released without being sentenced to a prison term or even given a fine. After Georgian officials had publicly excoriated Mr. Abdaladze as being a participant in a brazen espionage campaign, his 15-day prosecution ended as abruptly as it had begun.

headline: The Vending Machine Kid
text: MY parents are distributors who sell snacks to vending machine operators. They used to bring me to the office during the summers.

headline: 11 Shiites in Pakistan Die in Sectarian Attacks
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Gunmen opened fire on a commuter van and a rickshaw in the southwestern city of Quetta on Saturday, killing at least 11 Shiite Muslims, according to police officials. It was the latest in a series of deadly sectarian attacks in the city in the past few days.

headline: Farmers Oppose G.O.P. Bill on Immigration
text: PATTERSON, Calif. — Farmers across the country are rallying to fight a Republican-sponsored bill that would force them and all other employers to verify the legal immigration status of their workers, a move some say could imperil not only future harvests but also the agricultural community’s traditional support for conservative candidates.

headline: A Search Engine Match-Up: How Different Are Google and Bing?
text: Microsoft has invested billions of dollars in Bing, its search engine. But it faces a daunting rival in Google, the giant in search. To compete, Microsoft has focused on aggregating and presenting specific kinds of information in areas like travel, restaurants and recipes as part of a search result. Below is a look at some of the specific ways that Bing is trying to distinguish itself from Google.

text: AS returns dried up for domestic stocks over the past decade, investors began to take their money overseas. But economic growth seems to be drying up in Europe, thanks to the debt crisis and resulting austerity measures there. So do investors need to rethink their exposure abroad?

headline: U.S. Report Finds Security Deteriorating in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — Over the past year, security in Iraq has deteriorated and electricity shortages and corruption have continued unabated, according to a report released Saturday by a special inspector appointed by Congress to oversee Iraq’s reconstruction.

headline: Bring Back Poppy
text: WATCHING today’s Republicans being led around by an extremist Tea Party faction, with no adult supervision, I find my mind drifting back to the late 1980s when I was assigned to cover the administration of George H.W. Bush, who I believe is one of our most underrated presidents. I have long admired the elder Bush for the deftness with which he dealt with the collapse of the Soviet empire. But, in later years, I came to admire him even more for the fact that he believed that math and science were not matters of opinion — a view increasingly rare in today’s G.O.P.

headline: Riding With Fans Before Going to Work in Front of Them

Would there be a lot of foul balls? Would he need his glove to catch them? Should he be ready on each pitch? How old is Stephen Strasburg?

headline: They Risked Their Lives
text: The Iraq war, thankfully, is nearly over for this country. Not so for thousands of Iraqis who have worked with American troops and diplomats since the 2003 invasion as interpreters, drivers and fixers. They have long been targeted by militants. As American troops depart — the last are due to leave the country by the end of December — they are increasingly on their own.

headline: Howard Stein, Who Helped Teach Public to Invest, Dies at 84
text: Howard Stein, a former chief of the Dreyfus Corporation who as one of the fathers of the mutual fund industry introduced innovations like the first money market fund with no initial fee, died on Tuesday at his home in Southampton, N.Y. He was 84.
