headline: More About the Reagan Non-miracle
text: Reagan did not start an era of unprecedented growth by any measure: employment, GDP, productivity, whatever. But maybe the easiest way to see what didn’t happen is to look at median family income in constant dollars:

headline: Writer Gets New Vision From Film
text: Alex Kotlowitz stood at the edge of a red carpet outside the Chatham I.C.E. movie theater on Wednesday evening, sweating slightly in the heat. It was an hour before a special “friends and family” premiere of his documentary, “The Interrupters,” and he was greeting new arrivals with back-slapping, one-armed hugs. “Come over here for a picture, A K.,” someone called out. Everyone on the film got a nickname, Mr. Kotlowitz explained. “I was A. K. — you know, for AK-47,” he added, deadpan.

headline: Umenyiora Ends Holdout and Reports to Giants Camp
text: 6:54 p.m. | Updated EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants had their first walkthrough of training camp Saturday morning and Osi Umenyiora, as expected, was nowhere to be found at the Timex Performance Center. Umenyiora, unhappy with his contract, seemingly decided to hold out for a second day and pay the consequences — $30,000 worth.

headline: Kids These Days: A Group With a Sound if Not a Genre
text: Vic Mensa was so determined to get into Lollapalooza last year that he tried jumping a fence near some downtown train tracks, brushed against an electrical transformer powering the trains, fell 25 feet to the ground and wound up in the hospital.

headline: Catholic Group Based in Chicago Leads Protest Against Church
text: It’s a long way from the Vatican to Roscoe Village, but a group based in that North Side neighborhood is leading a high-profile protest among American priests that challenges the Roman Catholic Church’s ban on ordination of women.

headline: Sunny and Welcoming, Providing Books and a Safe Place
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 31
text: With an ominous deadline to raise the debt ceiling looming on Tuesday, the White House and Congressional lawmakers are still far from reaching a deal. The impasse raises the central question of this Sunday’s talk shows: Will America default?

headline: One Way to Guarantee More Trouble
text: Nearly six in 10 public school students in Texas were suspended or expelled at least once between seventh and 12th grade. That was the astounding finding of an analysis tracking nearly one million students in 3,900 Texas schools.

headline: Concealed Weapons Against the Environment
text: While almost no one was looking, House Republicans embarked last week on a broad assault on the nation’s environmental laws, using as their weapon the 2012 spending bill for the Interior Department and the Environmental Protection Agency. When debate began Monday, the bill included an astonishing 39 anti-environmental riders — so called because they ride along on appropriations bills even though they have nothing to do with spending and are designed to change policy, in this case disastrously.

headline: Long Day for Yankees; Longer One for Orioles
text: At the start of a long day of baseball, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi was asked how he felt about doubleheaders — either the traditional back-to-back variety or the split doubleheader, with games at 1 p.m. and 7 p.m., like the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles played Saturday. Girardi frowned.

headline: Hollywood Film Exchanges
text: Three MGM lions on a building on Hyde Street in today’s seamy Tenderloin district are a reminder of a bit of Hollywood history. From the 1930s to the 1960s, the area was home to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, 20th Century-Fox, Paramount, Columbia and other Hollywood studios, which set up film distribution centers along Hyde Street between Golden Gate and Eddy.

headline: Local Basketball Stars Shun Bay Area Colleges
text: Brandon Ashley is 17, 6-foot-8 and one of the most sought-after prep basketball stars in the country.

headline: Owners Abandoning Ill and Aging Pets in Hard Times
text: A Pit Bull puppy with Parvovirus and a Shih Tzu that had been hit by a car are just two examples of pets that have been abandoned by their owners at East Bay animal shelters in recent months.

headline: A Tax Policy With San Francisco Roots
text: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Attack on a Patrol in Afghanistan Kills Seven
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A bomb attack on a patrol killed two NATO soldiers and five Afghan soldiers on Friday evening, in an impoverished area of eastern Afghanistan where the Afghan government has little presence and where there have not previously been many lethal attacks on soldiers.

headline: Manning’s $90 Million Deal Gives the Colts Flexibility
text: In one of the oddest negotiations in the N.F.L.’s current free-agency frenzy, Indianapolis Colts quarterback Peyton Manning agreed to a contract Saturday that will not give him the highest annual salary in the game — even though his team owner vowed more than a year ago to give him a deal that would make him the highest paid player in N.F.L. history.

headline: Perry’s Legion: The Folks Behind the Man
text: Gov. Rick Perry’s inner circle has evolved significantly since he was first elected to the Texas House in 1984. He changed parties, for one thing, becoming a Republican and shucking one political infrastructure for another. And he changed offices, moving from the House to the Texas Department of Agriculture, from there to the lieutenant governorship and from there, with the election of George W. Bush to the presidency in 2000, into the office he holds today.

headline: Museum Shows History and Power of Wind Energy
text: LUBBOCK — A century ago, Texas was covered with windmills, which pumped water from aquifers so cattle could drink and gardens could grow. Thousands of these old-style models still exist in remote pastures, but in recent years far taller and more powerful turbines have sprouted atop western mesas, transforming this oil and gas state into the national leader in wind-generated electrical power.

headline: Analysis Reveals Asylum Records of Judges
text: The Mexican journalist Emilio Gutiérrez has sought political asylum in the United States since June 2008, when he and his teenage son fled the small town of Ascensión, Chihuahua, in the pre-dawn hours and arrived at the Antelope Wells, N.M., border crossing.

headline: A Mobilization in Washington by Wall Street
text: After a year of clashing with Washington over new financial reforms, the country’s most powerful bankers have found common ground with regulators in the hard-fought effort to lift the debt ceiling and avoid a default.

headline: Sunday: Separate Checks
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — One of the rules of crossword construction states that thou shalt not repeat words in a grid. Today’s puzzle skirts that rule very efficiently. In her own clever way, Pamela Klawitter repeats entries to her heart’s content, just never in the same space. You’ll see what I mean.

headline: Down a Dirt Road
text: A crew from Comedy Central’s “Colbert Report” traveled from New York to Bogart, Ga., to sit on the front porch and talk to Bobby Kirk, who has become an unlikely savant of country wisdom.

headline: He Said It Was Too Hot to Fish, and That Was Just for Starters
text: BOGART, Ga. — It was hard not to notice that the stream of tobacco juice spit expertly by Bobby Kirk barely missed the sassy summer sandals on the feet of the New York television producer.

headline: Which Republicans Might Support Reid’s Debt Bill?
text: Sooner or later, if the debt ceiling is to be increased, some kind of bill will need to be passed out of the Democratic-led Senate. Unless Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, is willing to take a procedural gamble, it will need 60 votes to overcome a Republican filibuster.

headline: John Stott and Evangelical Christians
text: I’m actually off on vacation in Ashland, Oregon, enjoying the Oregon Shakespeare Festival with my family, and I hadn’t intended to write a column for Sunday. But then I saw that John Stott had died, and I didn’t want to miss the chance to write about him and evangelicals more broadly — hence my Sunday column on the subject. We in the op-ed world don’t write about religion perhaps as much as we should: it’s a huge force shaping society and policy, and yet rarely makes the op-ed pages. And evangelicals in particular, especially serious ones, tend to be neglected since there are so few evangelicals in major news organizations. About one-third of America is evangelical, yet you’d be hard pressed to find many (with the exception of black evangelicals, whose politics are very different from white evangelicals) in leading news organizations.

headline: Rivers and Risks in South Dakota
text: Even as experts warn that climate change is increasing the frequency and severity of flooding, developers continue to build homes in flood-prone areas, including in Dakota Dunes, S.D.

headline: In the Flood Zone, but Astonished by High Water
text: DAKOTA DUNES, S.D. — Some skeptical locals offered a warning when developers transformed this mostly barren peninsula at the intersection of two rivers into an exclusive planned community, complete with million-dollar homes and a private golf course designed by Arnold Palmer.

headline: A Korean ‘Sacred Duty’ Harbors a Dark Side
text: SEOUL, South Korea — “If anyone could be a marine, I’d never have joined.” That is the slogan of South Korea’s Marine Corps, and it speaks volumes about the force’s sense of its elite status; it is a particularly bold assertion in a country where most able-bodied men perform mandatory military service.

headline: Times Editors Respond to Column on Redactions
text: Included below is a response from The Times national desk on my column Why Redacting E-mails Is a Bad Idea.

headline: Frank Bender, ‘Recomposer’ of Faces of the Dead, Dies at 70
text: Frank Bender, a forensic sculptor whose work — haunting, three-dimensional faces in clay — helped identify the forgotten dead and apprehend the fugitive living, died on Thursday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 70.

headline: Trade in Pork Bellies Comes to an End, but the Lore Lives
text: CHICAGO — This city’s market for the pork belly, a commodity nearly everyone seemed to have heard of but only a small, close-knit fraternity truly understood, is no more.

headline: Battle for Libya | July 30, 2011
text: Rebels inspected a camp abandoned by government army soldiers in the village of Hawamid.

headline: At Least Somebody in Washington Can Make a Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Mike Rizzo, the Washington Nationals’ general manager, was a busy man Saturday, concluding two trades, including one that sent away his starting pitcher for that night’s game.

headline: Coming Together to Pray, and Also to Find Reduced-Rate Energy Deals
text: WASHINGTON — Like manna from heaven, thousands of dollars in new revenue is raining on a group of congregations here from the unlikeliest of sources: the utility bill.

headline: In Afghanistan, Rage at Young Lovers
text: HERAT, Afghanistan — The two teenagers met inside an ice cream factory through darting glances before roll call, murmured hellos as supervisors looked away and, finally, a phone number folded up and tossed discreetly onto the workroom floor.

headline: Islamic Law and American Courts
text: Two lawyers offer opposing views on a growing movement to restrict American judges from considering Islamic law, also known as shariah, when adjudicating cases.

headline: The Man Behind the Anti-Shariah Movement
text: NASHVILLE — Tennessee’s latest woes include high unemployment, continuing foreclosures and a battle over collective-bargaining rights for teachers. But when a Republican representative took the Statehouse floor during a recent hearing, he warned of a new threat to his constituents’ way of life: Islamic law.

headline: A Digital Matchmaker for the City and Its Public
text: ONE of the most popular online inventions of New York City’s government is The Daily Pothole, a blog that tracks, in gravelly detail, the milling and paving of street cavities from Midwood to Midtown. It is eye candy for the asphalt-obsessed: panoramic photos accompanied by comic captions (“Bump!” “Sneak Attack!”) and a goggle-eyed mascot named Warmy, an asphalt plug, to boot.

headline: Corrections: July 31
text: NATIONAL

headline: Stay Thirsty Moves Out of Shadow of Uncle Mo
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — Mike Repole stood up. He sat down. He passed The Daily Racing Form to a relative and wiped the nervous sweat from his brow.

headline: Osi Umenyiora Shows Up but Is Still Unhappy
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants had their first walkthrough of training camp Saturday morning, and Osi Umenyiora, as expected, was nowhere to be found at the Timex Performance Center. Umenyiora, unhappy with his contract, seemingly decided to hold out for a second day and pay the consequences — $30,000 worth.

headline: The War Comes Home for Lee
text: Disunion hit home swiftly for Robert E. Lee, the Virginian colonel who spurned President Lincoln’s offer to lead the Union forces just before the Civil War broke out. Lee, as everyone knows, went on to lead the Confederate army. Less well known is that, soon after he sided with the South, he also lost his home.

headline: Joe Arroyo, Star of Salsa and Colombian Music Giant, Dies at 55
text: Joe Arroyo, a Colombian songwriter, singer and bandleader whose pan-Caribbean salsa hybrids and historically conscious lyrics made him one of his country’s most respected musicians, died on Tuesday in Barranquilla, his adopted home city in Colombia. He was 55.

headline: Cleveland Completes Jimenez Trade
text: Brian Cashman, the Yankees’ general manager, likes to call himself a big-game hunter, never shying from the most prominent players available in trades. This month, the glitziest name on the market has been Ubaldo Jimenez, the starting pitcher for the National League in the 2010 All-Star Game.

headline: His Thumb Healed, Kim Has a Win in His Grasp
text: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va. — Anthony Kim, who said he felt his game beginning to turn around two weeks ago at the British Open, kept things moving in the right direction on Saturday at the Greenbrier Classic, shooting an eight-under-par 62 to take the lead going into the final round for the first time in 15 months.

headline: Armenia Takes Team Title; Chinese Player Is Top Scorer
text: The Chess Olympiad, which was first held in 1924, is the most elite national team event in the world. But the World Team Championship is in some ways more competitive because it includes only 10 squads, so there are no easy matches.

headline: Senate Delays Vote as Debt Talks Progress
text: The Senate will delay a crucial vote on the Democratic debt ceiling bill until 1 p.m. Sunday as both Democratic and Republican lawmakers said a potential compromise was in the works that would avert a federal default after midnight on Tuesday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Rightward Tilt Leaves Obama With Party Rift
text: WASHINGTON — However the debt limit showdown ends, one thing is clear: under pressure from Congressional Republicans, President Obama has moved rightward on budget policy, deepening a rift within his party heading into the next election.

headline: The New Look on a Smaller Scale
text: A few notable recent products represent the concepts of universal design and stylish design for aging.

headline: User-Friendly Design
text: Ways to adapt homes so they suit people as they age or cope with disabilities.

headline: Mets’ Loss to Nationals Ends 5-Game Winning Streak
text: WASHINGTON — After scoring 34 runs in their previous four games, including at least eight in each of those contests, the Mets could not even get a runner to third base until there were two outs in the ninth inning Saturday.

headline: For Barcelona, No Messi and No Xavi. For United? No Complaints.
text: LANDOVER, Md. — To the annoying but joyful sound of vuvuzelas, the horns made famous at the World Cup in South Africa last year, and the cheers of a packed crowd of soccer groupies at FedEx Field, Barcelona and Manchester United played what was marketed as a friendly match on Saturday.

headline: Photo Replay: July 30
text: The day in sports, including Day 15 of FINA World Swimming Championships and competitors in the Formula One race.

headline: The New Housing Plan
text: President Obama's housing plan is expected to help as many as seven million to nine million homeowners by making it easier for them to either refinance their mortgages or renegotiate payments.

headline: Defenses Are Thickened at Afghan Border to Choke Off Militants’ Routes
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — American and allied forces in Afghanistan are strengthening a layered defense along the border with Pakistan to seize Haqqani network militants as they try to make their way to Kabul to carry out spectacular attacks, according to senior military officers.

headline: U.S. Draws Jamaica in World Cup Qualifying
text: The United States was drawn into a group with Jamaica and two second-round qualifiers on Saturday for the semifinal round of Concacaf qualifying for the 2014 World Cup.

headline: Sony’s New Camera Punches Above Its Weight
text: You probably know all of the advantages of digital SLR cameras: interchangeable lenses; large sensors for better image quality and better low light shots; and no shutter lag. But you might not realize that you can get almost all of those features in a much smaller (though no less expensive) package.

headline: Cooling Dips for the Roman Summer
text: During the Roman summer, oppressive heat waves are common, leaving captive tourists to bake in museum halls lacking air conditioning or roast on cobblestone streets. Few hotels in town offer swimming pools — and those that do charge a premium to nonguests who wish to take a dip. But if you are willing to plunk down some cash, there are options, as well as a few cheaper ones offered by the city.

headline: When People Pay You To Take Their Money
text: Look at the rates on inflation-protected US bonds:

headline: Stabbed Motorist Fatally Strikes Girl, Then Dies
text: For additional coverage, see the N.Y./Region section.

headline: McConnell Sees Deal “Very Close”; Focus Is on Triggers for Cuts
text: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, said Sunday morning that he was “very close” to recommending to his members that they sign on to a debt deal with President Obama and the Democrats.

headline: Syrians Strike Restive Cities in Fierce Raids
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian military and security forces assaulted Hama and other restive cities before dawn on Sunday, killing at least 70 people in the broadest and fiercest crackdown yet by the government of President Bashar al-Assad on the four-month uprising against his rule, activists and residents said.

headline: Plaxico Burress Signs With Jets
text: There was once a gifted but controversial receiver who attended a Big Ten university, joined the Pittsburgh Steelers as a heralded first-round draft pick and caught the winning touchdown pass in a Super Bowl. He also made a series of poor decisions, fell out of favor and had his character called into question.

headline: Media Blackout in China After Wreck
text: BEIJING — After days of growing public fury over last month’s high-speed train crash and the government’s reaction, Chinese authorities have enacted a virtual news blackout on the disaster except for positive stories or information officially released by the government.

headline: As States Struggle, How Much for the Arts?
text: 8:15 p.m. |Update: Readers Respond

headline: My Get-Rich Scheme
text: Please, just let me play poker with President Obama. I’ll make millions in no time at all.

headline: Peru’s New Culture Minister Is Susana Baca
text: The Afro-Peruvian folk singer Susana Baca has been named minister of culture in Peru for the new populist government of President Ollanta Humala, who took office last week.

headline: ‘The Smurfs’ Are Blue, but They’re Rolling in Green
text: Smurfs humiliated a cluster of Hollywood’s heaviest weights at the weekend box office. Analysts had predicted that “Cowboys & Aliens” — starring Daniel Craig and Harrison Ford, directed by Jon Favreau (“Iron Man”) and produced by Brian Grazer and Steven Spielberg — would easily dominate ticket sales. Instead, it was a photo finish with “The Smurfs,” a cartoon-live action hybrid. Both films took in an estimated $36.2 million at North American theaters, as “The Smurfs” outperformed expectations, and “Cowboys & Aliens” failed to capture young men in significant numbers.

headline: Obama and Leaders Reach Debt Deal
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Congressional leaders of both parties said late Sunday that they had agreed to a framework for a budget deal that would cut trillions of dollars in federal spending over the next decade and clear the way for an increase in the government’s borrowing limit.

headline: Deadly Violence Strikes Chinese City Racked by Ethnic Tensions
text: BEIJING — A weekend of violence in China’s far western Xinjiang region has left at least 18 people dead in the ancient city of Kashgar, state-controlled media reported Sunday. It was the second major episode of violence in the last several weeks in an area racked by ethnic tensions.

headline: Deal May Avert Default, but Some Ask, ‘Is That Good?’
text: The resounding view on Wall Street and among many financial regulators and veteran lawmakers is that there will be a catastrophe if the United States does not raise its debt limit in the next few days.

headline: China’s Low Roaming Fees Won’t Be Matched Soon
text: BERLIN — When Su Xiaoqin, a Chinese translator living in Düsseldorf, calls family and friends back in Shanghai, she does not use the mobile network of her German operator, O2. She pops in the SIM card for China Mobile.

headline: Senate Blocks Reid’s Debt Ceiling Plan
text: The Senate voted Sunday not to move forward with a Democratic debt plan as Congress prepared to take up a bipartisan deal to raise the debt ceiling as soon as it is reached this weekend.

headline: Schwarzenegger Now Has a Hometown Museum
text: A new museum honoring Arnold Schwarzenegger, the bodybuilder, movie star and former California governor, opened on Saturday in the Austrian village where he was born, Thal, near Graz, to coincide with his 64th birthday. The museum, located in the house where Mr. Schwarzenegger lived from birth until he departed in 1966 for England and then the United States, clearly has his blessing: exhibits include not only his childhood bed and first weight-lifting equipment but also a sword from “Conan the Barbarian,” memorabilia from the “Terminator” movies and a copy of the desk he used as governor. Despite the recent blows to Mr. Schwarzenegger’s image in the United States with his disclosure that he fathered a child out of wedlock, “his career was so exciting and so special and I think the Austrian people are really proud” of him, Helga Forstner, the museum coordinator, told the BBC.

headline: Buying a Final Resting Place, Very Gently Used
text: For sale: 101-year-old Greek Revival building in landmark area. Top-quality granite exterior, marble interior, high ceiling, custom-made window by famous artist. Immediate occupancy: vacant since the 1950s. Sleeps eight. Asking $750,000.

headline: HSBC to Announce 10,000 Job Cuts
text: LONDON — HSBC, Europe’s biggest bank, plans to announce thousands of job cuts on Monday as part of a wide-ranging cost-reduction program that started in May, a person with direct knowledge of the decision said Sunday.

headline: Outcry From the Left Precedes Debt Deal
text: Liberals began tearing into President Obama and Democrats on Sunday, accusing them of caving to Republican demands even before final details of a debt ceiling agreement have been announced.

headline: Video From Deadly Raids in Syria
text: At dawn on Sunday, Syrian security forces backed by tanks and snipers stormed Hama and other cities, killing at least 75 people in a brutal crackdown by the government of President Bashar al-Assad against the four-month old uprising against his rule.

headline: HSBC to Sell Upstate N.Y. Branches to First Niagara for $1 Billion
text: 3:23 p.m. | Updated

headline: Lochte and U.S. Cap Dominance With a Flourish
text: SHANGHAI — Ryan Lochte captured his fifth gold medal on the final day of the world swimming championships with a performance that may help him stake a claim to being the best in his sport.

headline: Yankees Make Zero Moves as Deadline Passes
text: It wasn’t the most exciting trade deadline in recent memory, but there were a couple of significant moves on Sunday.

headline: Jeter Leaves Game, but Finger Is Not Broken
text: Derek Jeter departed Yankee Stadium for a seven-game trip late Sunday afternoon with a thick wrapping around his right middle finger, which was battered twice by flying baseballs within 18 hours. His finger is not broken, and Jeter, not surprisingly, said he was hurting but fine.

headline: Tax Cut Memories
text: Obama, at his press conference last December, announcing his surrender to the GOP on tax cuts; the questioner was Marc Ambinder:

headline: The Debt Ceiling, in Pop Culture
text: During the financial crisis, the bank-run scene from “It’s A Wonderful Life” proved a useful pop-culture reference for helping people understand what was happening to the economy.

headline: Button Wins Wild, Rain-Soaked Hungarian Grand Prix
text: BUDAPEST – The Formula One rules makers have sometimes considered sprinkling tracks with water to artificially enhance the excitement of the racing.

headline: Button Wins Wild, Rain-Soaked Hungarian Grand Prix
text: BUDAPEST – The Formula One rules makers have sometimes considered sprinkling tracks with water to artificially enhance the excitement of the racing.

headline: Mets’ Long Trip Ends With Loss in 9th Inning
text: WASHINGTON — Daniel Murphy rushed in to retrieve the bunted ball and without the slightest hesitation spun around and fired the ball to third baseman David Wright to cut down the lead runner in a tie game in the ninth inning.

headline: A Very Big Man and the Brother Who Resents Him
text: When the journalist David Whitehouse began circulating the first few chapters of his debut novel, “Bed,” he soon found himself picked up as a London client of the William Morris Agency. He was amazed at this good fortune. “Suddenly, I was walking around like Charlie Big Potatoes, thinking all sorts of good things were going to happen to me,” he has told interviewers. “But what actually did happen was, well, nothing.”

headline: Reid Backs Debt Deal and Hopes for Sunday Night Debt Vote
text: 5:29 p.m. | Updated A spokesman for Senator Harry Reid said the Senate majority leader has “signed off on the debt-ceiling agreement pending caucus approval.”

headline: A von Trier Tragedy, Recast as Opera
text: If Sarah Bernhardt’s definitive performance in Victorien Sardou’s 1887 play “La Tosca” had been available through Netflix, would Puccini ever have based an opera on it? Would his “Tosca” have stood a chance?

headline: Children in the Fields, but Not at Play
text: “The Harvest/La Cosecha,” an earnest documentary about child migrant farmworkers in the United States, has a muckraking agenda but a melancholy soul. As it follows a 16-year-old boy and two girls, 12 and 14, through one harvest cycle, it depicts their lives as a more or less voluntary indentured servitude and provides a detailed, sometimes heartbreaking, mostly hopeless portrait of a permanent American underclass. But the tone is never angry; resignation is the primary note, and an ability to endure that isn’t so much resilience as stubbornness.

headline: Benghazi Clash Exposes Cracks in Rebel Ranks
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — Rebel fighters challenging the rule of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi waged an eight-hour gunfight here in their de facto capital on Sunday, against what their leaders called a “fifth column” of Qaddafi loyalists who had posed as a rebel brigade. It was the latest sign of discord and trickery in the rebel ranks to emerge in the four days since the killing of the rebels’ top military leader, Gen. Abdul Fattah Younes, a former Qaddafi confidant who had defected to their side.

headline: Diva’s Struggles and Songs, Shared With Candor
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — Opera singers have written their share of celebrity tell-all memoirs. The soprano Deborah Voigt recently sold her autobiography to HarperCollins, scheduled for release in two years. She has already gone public about her struggles with obesity, which led her to undergo gastric bypass surgery in 2004.

headline: Exploring the Intricacies of the 17th Century
text: The 4x4 Baroque Music Festival began as an early-music fan’s farewell to the summer, with four free concerts offered around Labor Day. This year the festival’s players — a core of early-music stars, including the harpsichordist Avi Stein and the violinist Robert Mealy — have moved it to midsummer: the series began on Friday evening and runs through Wednesday at St. Peter’s Lutheran Church.

headline: Monday: Whacked-Out Mental State
text: Administrivial Tournament “Save the Date” Alert! Will Shortz has announced the date of the 2011 Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament, the proceeds of which benefit the Pleasantville Fund for Learning. Save Oct. 21 (exact starting time to be determined) if you will be in the area and would like to have a fun, low-key tournament experience, meet some of your favorite constructors and help raise money for a great cause. Plus, if history holds, the desserts provided are not to be believed. The location will be Will’s brand-new table tennis club — the Westchester Table Tennis Center, located at 175 Tompkins Ave., in Pleasantville, N.Y. It’s three and a half blocks from the Pleasantville train station on MetroNorth. I’m told that the space is twice as large as the former location, which should nicely accommodate the growing legions of tournament fans, and you can even arrive early and play some table tennis! You can read more about the club here, and registration for the tournament is accepted at the door.

headline: Flaunting Latino Clichés in Effort to Defuse Them
text: FOR some Hollywood movies, clichés are everything. An asteroid destroys a major city. A shadowy figure appears behind someone in the reflection of medicine cabinet mirror. A Latina maid marries a successful businessman and lives happily ever after.

headline: Muscling Through a Murky, Hardcore Night in a Box
text: People straighten up around John Joseph, the singer for the Cro-Mags. He reminds you that the best of his music, New York hardcore, has a history and a set of standards, musical and ethical; he has no time for what people choose to do outside of those standards. He’s not hectoring you, exactly, about punk and veganism and the economy and your ability to rise to the occasion; he’s making strong recommendations and asking withering questions. Like “What are you, tired?”

headline: Romantic Temperament Applied to Monuments
text: The pianist Marc-André Hamelin is fearless. No successful performer can afford to show fear from the stage, but with Mr. Hamelin, fearlessness is something more: a positive attribute, a confident calm that he exudes even while unleashing volcanic eruptions of sound and emotion.

headline: A Malian Singer Sets Her West African Message to a Dance Beat
text: Regal, righteous and funky, the Malian singer and songwriter Oumou Sangare commanded the stage of Celebrate Brooklyn! on Friday night at the Prospect Park Bandshell. Wearing a white caftan, a red necklace and a white headscarf that her movements kept shaking loose, Ms. Sangare praised and admonished: End forced child marriage, share good fortune, seek wisdom, don’t waste your youth. She was taking on the traditional West African singer’s role as community conscience while delivering her messages with a modern kick.

headline: Uncertainty Driving Treasury Bill Fluctuations
text: In normal times, it is hard to find a financial market that is more boring than the one where short-term Treasury bills are traded.

headline: Girl-Group Hits From Rock’s Women
text: It was all about love. Waiting for it, finding it, showing it, fearing for it, fighting for it, sometimes losing it, sometimes taking it all the way to happy-ever-after marriage. On Saturday afternoon the rock archivists of the Ponderosa Stomp and Lincoln Center Out of Doors presented a fond four-hour marathon of girl-group songs from the early 1960s, sung by the women who made them.

headline: Into the Pool, Slowly but With Feeling
text: Forty years after they began to collaborate, the performance duo Eiko & Koma remain among New York’s greatest and most extraordinary performers. Their particular secret is that, while moving with extreme slowness, they are masters of suspense. Watching, you’re kept on tenterhooks: what will happen next?

headline: Ahab Has a Wife and a Heart. Oh, and a Whale.
text: Some people argue passionately over which is the Great American Novel, “Moby-Dick” or “The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn.”

headline: Film Hitches a Weird Ride on Kesey’s Bus
text: “Magic Trip: Ken Kesey’s Search for a Kool Place,” a film by Alex Gibney and Alison Ellwood that opens on Friday, is an exercise in what they call “archival vérité.” It’s a documentary that uses old footage to recreate a documentary that Kesey intended to make about his 1964 cross-country bus trip — the one so memorably chronicled in Tom Wolfe’s account, “The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test.”

headline: Cry Havoc! The Blood Sport Called Politics
text: With the country mired in political stalemate and economic peril looming, imperialism suddenly doesn’t sound so bad, does it?

headline: No High-Card Points, but a Decision to Make
text: TORONTO — At the Summer North American Championships here, the final of the premier event, the Spingold Knockout Teams, was scheduled to finish late on Sunday. The 64-board match was between Team Monaco (Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness) and Nick Nickell, Ralph Katz, Bob Hamman, Zia Mahmood, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell.

headline: Ticket Sales Start-Up Aims at Smaller Box Offices
text: On July 23, 3,000 carnivores salivated their way through Meatopia, a festival on a Brooklyn pier where 45 chefs from around the country offered fleshy dishes like veal belly gyros and Southern pulled-pork shooters.

headline: State Department Taps will.i.am for China Effort
text: The State Department is teaming up with the hip-hop artist will.i.am, a founder of the Black Eyed Peas, to organize a concert in Beijing this year to encourage cultural and educational exchanges between the United States and China. The announcement came after Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton met on Friday in Washington with will.i.am, above, a creator of the 2008 viral video “Yes, We Can” that boosted support for Barack Obama among the young, to discuss the Obama administration’s “100,000 Strong Initiative,” aimed at increasing the number and diversity of Americans studying in China. For the event will.i.am and other American and Chinese artists will perform; no date or location for the show has been specified.

headline: The Kings of Leon Are Feeling the Heat
text: Despite their image as road-hardened Southern boys, the Kings of Leon seem to have wilted over the weekend in the heat of Texas, where the band cut short a concert on Friday night in Dallas and postponed a show on Saturday in Houston. Before going offstage, promising but failing to return, the lead singer Caleb Followill told the Dallas audience, “I’m about to fall down here because I’m so goddamn hot.” But a pair of tweets by the bass player Jared Followill, his younger brother, suggested that tensions within the group, which has had a string of chart-topping CDs, may also have figured in the actions. “There are internal sicknesses & problems that have needed to be addressed,” he wrote in one message. In the other one he added: “I can’t lie. There are problems in our band bigger than not drinking enough Gatorade.”

headline: Two Theater Chains Block Documentary
text: Two major movie theater chains, AMC and Regal, have instructed their properties not to show “Electric Daisy Carnival Experience,” about an increasingly popular annual electronic dance music festival, after a confrontation between fans and the police during an event last week in Los Angeles to promote the film, which is scheduled to open nationally on Thursday. “It is extremely disheartening that some theaters wrongly associated an unaffiliated block party, and its disorderly crowd, with the private screening of the film,” Insomniac, the movie’s promoter and the festival’s organizer, posted on its Web site, adding that the movie, which features interviews with or performances by rave music stars like David Guetta, Steve Aoki and DJ Kaskade, whose impromptu street performance set off the Los Angeles disturbance, “will continue to be shown in hundreds of theaters nationwide.”

headline: Judge Says TV Will Show Mubarak on Trial
text: CAIRO — The trial of former President Hosni Mubarak will be held in a large hall that can accommodate 600 spectators, and will be broadcast on Egyptian state television, the judge who will preside over the trial said Sunday.

headline: ‘Julius Caesar’
text: Photos from the Royal Shakespeare Company production at the Park Avenue Armory.

headline: ‘She’s Got the Power!’
text: At Lincoln Center on Saturday afternoon “She’s Got the Power!” presented a four-hour marathon of girl-group songs from the 1960s.

headline: The Pedestrian’s Thrilling Countdown
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Bringing Comfort Food to Print Fans
text: After an improbable rise as a chef who took a tiny noodle shop in New York and parlayed it into a kind of punk rock culinary movement and five wildly successful restaurants, David Chang seemed destined to become a television star. Now famous and ubiquitous, he would be a natural to join the legions of knife-wielding, apron-wearing stars who terrorize amateur cooks for the benefit of an audience. Either that or he could look into the camera and patiently explain how you too could make food that would knock people out of their chairs.

headline: Opposing the Health Law, Florida Refuses Millions
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — When it comes to pursuing federal largess, most of the states that oppose the 2010 health care law have refused to let either principle or politics block their paths to the trough. If Washington is doling out dollars, Republican governors and legislators typically figure they might as well get their share.

headline: Exploring a City Hidden Behind Its Modern Face
text: There is the Atlanta that most tourists see, all shimmering skyline, vast parks and Olympic torch statues. And then there is the hidden city, the one you see with a flashlight when A. J. Arend is your guide.

headline: A Patent Fever Over Smartphones
text: A Patent Fever Over Smartphones

headline: Children’s Publisher Backing Off Its Corporate Ties
text: Two months after Scholastic, the world’s largest publisher of children’s books, was hit with a barrage of criticism for distributing an unbalanced curriculum sponsored by the coal industry, the company is cutting back its InSchool marketing division’s corporate-sponsored projects, and creating a new review board to vet its materials.
